HEADLINE: THE MALTA SUMMIT;
Gorbachev Lauds Religion on Eve of Meeting Pope

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 30

 BODY:
On the eve of an encounter with Pope John Paul II, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said tonight that the Soviet Union had erred in long rejecting religion and now needed its moral force to help make his plans for a restructured society work.
''We have changed our attitude on some matters, such as religion, for example, which admittedly we used to treat in a simplistic manner,'' said Mr. Gorbachev, whose meeting with the Pope on Friday will be the first between a Soviet Communist leader and the spiritual guide to the world's 850 million Roman Catholics.
''Now we not only proceed from the assumption that no one should interfere in matters of the individual's conscience,'' he said. ''We also say that the moral values that religion generated and embodied for centuries can help in the work of renewal in our country, too.'' 
''In fact,'' Mr. Gorbachev added, ''this is already happening.''
Mr. Gorbachev travels to Malta on Friday night, where he will meet aboard Soviet and American warships in a Maltese harbor with President Bush on Saturday and Sunday.
His thoughts on religion came in a multi-themed speech that was as much a philosophical reflection as a political statement. In it, the Soviet leader offered a vision of a new Europe, one that would be ''a commonwealth of sovereign democratic states,'' based on spiritual values, pluralism, religious tolerance and mutual understanding.
''The world is on the threshold of an entirely new era,'' he said, and he proposed a 35-nation ''European summit'' meeting next year to consider the swift changes that he said were turning not only Eastern Europe upside down but the West as well.
It would be, Mr. Gorbachev told his Italian hosts, ''a Helsinki 2 meeting,'' an updated version of the 1975 conference that confirmed Europe's borders and set rules governing human rights, economic cooperation and military security. Such a gathering had already been planned for 1992, but he said that rapidly unfolding events required that it be held sooner.
On the second day of a three-day visit here, the Soviet leader also issued a joint statement with Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy asserting that ''the curtain of mistrust between the East and the West is crumbling'' as one Communist-bloc nation after another succumbs to demands for democratic reform.
 
A Ban on Chemical Weapons
The two men agreed that ''the future international order should increasingly be based on the universal values of freedom, of all forms of national, ethnic and religious tolerance, and of pluralism.''
Looking ahead to his meeting with President Bush off Malta this weekend, Mr. Gorbachev predicted in his speech tonight that their discussions would ''enable us to take a new constructive step in the movement from mutual understanding to mutual action'' in United States-Soviet relations. In the statement with Mr. Andreotti, he said that he wanted an arms-reduction agreement next year that would include a global ban on chemical weapons and a 50 percent cut in both superpowers' offensive strategic weapons.
Mr. Gorbachev's trip to Italy has assumed an importance not foreseen when arrangements for it were begun many months ago. This turned out to be his first chance to talk directly with a major Western country about the tumultuous events in Eastern Europe, and it also has served as a warm-up for his conferences with Mr. Bush.
His speech tonight was billed as a capstone to the Italian part of his journey, before he crosses the Tiber River to enter Vatican City. He delivered it in a meeting room on the Capitoline Hill, the political and religious center of ancient Rome. The room is named after Julius Caesar, which seemed an appropriately symbolic flourish, for there is no question that Mr. Gorbachev has been a conqueror of Roman hearts and minds during his brief stay here.
 
'No Return to the Past'
In his remarks, he talked about the difficulties he faces in trying to restructure Soviet life and what he called the Stalinist legacy of suppressed ethnic problems. To Italy's leaders, he acknowledged that economic hardships persist, including bare store shelves. But the entire Communist bloc, he said, had crossed the Rubicon of change, even if there is also now the danger of political instability in Europe.
''Having embarked upon the road of radical reform, the Socialist countries, one after another, are crossing the line beyond which there is no return to the past,'' he said.
Mr. Gorbachev cautioned Western nations against trying to exploit the turmoil in the East with ''clumsy behavior or provocative statements,'' or viewing recent events as proof of capitalism's triumph over Communism in the cold war. Attempts ''to tilt the events solely to one's own advantage are fraught with chaos,'' he said.
In fact, he insisted, Communism is far from dead and it was ''wishful thinking'' to believe it is. Now, he said, Communism has ''new opportunities for moving toward its just and noble goals, for releasing the enormous humanistic and democratic potential contained in the socialist ideal.''
But ''we have abandoned the claim to have a monopoly on the truth,'' the Soviet leader said. ''We no longer think that we are the best and that we are always right, that those who disagree with us are our enemies.''

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Unease Fills Western Allies Over Rapid Changes in East

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
The joyous revolution of freedom sweeping Eastern Europe is confronting Western Europe with some of its gravest decisions in 40 years.
Among the most daunting challenges is how to maintain the movement toward European unity if, as most Western European leaders expect, the West Germans become distracted from that old goal by the newly aroused prospects of achieving German unification - a vision spelled out by Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Bonn on Tuesday.
Another concern questions where the United States and the Soviet Union will fit in the suddenly shifting European landscape. Many Western Europeans think the natural course of events will bind them more closely to the new Soviet Union, which after all shares the same continent, and pry them loose from their security and economic ties to the United States.
 
The Worry Over Germany
The biggest worry of all, to many Europeans, is West Germany itself, increasingly inclined to take charge of its destiny in ways that would have been unthinkable a decade or even a year ago. Mr. Kohl, for example, outlined his ideas for German unification Tuesday without any prior consultation with his allies, though the United States, Britain and France share with the Soviet Union a treaty responsibility for ''Germany as a whole'' that dates back to 1945. 
Conversations with politicians, business leaders, students, writers and ordinary people from Wales to West Berlin in recent weeks leave a clear impression of unease, a sense that without wise actions the dream come true in Eastern Europe could easily turn into unpleasant realities.
What is also becoming apparent is that rapid changes can bring long submerged cultural, historical and political differences of the 12 members of the European Community to the surface. Indeed, this risk has appeared just as those nations are poised to eliminate the remaining trade barriers among their 320 million people by the end of 1992.
The unease is compounded by a feeling that Western leaders have not been saying what they really think about the central problem of a united Germany. For four decades, when reunification appeared impossible, all of them implicitly accepted it by saying that a truly free, united Europe, East and West, was the ultimate goal. Now that the reintegration of Europe and the Germanys no longer looks so distant, said Klaus Bolling, a former head of West Germany's mission to East Berlin, ''We're seeing a tremendous outbreak of hypocrisy.''
''It seems a little bit insulting to Germany to say that it needs to be anchored into Europe,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said on BBC television Monday night, clearly hoping to anchor the West Germans even more firmly with such expressed sentiments.
''I am not afraid of reunification,'' President Francois Mitterrand of France said in Bonn earlier this month. ''If the Germans want to be a single nation in a single state, this must be founded on the will of the German nation, and nobody can oppose it.'' But officials in Paris now explain that what the President intended by the statement was to calm the fears of many French people over unification, and to encourage the Germans not to be distracted from the unfinished work of building the European Community.
Mr. Kohl tried to reassure other European leaders in Paris on Nov. 18, that West Germany saw ''no alternative'' but to work for German unity within the existing European context.
 
Gorbachev and Reunification
''We agreed not to raise the question of the existing borders,'' Mrs. Thatcher acknowledged, but diplomats in Bonn, Paris and London all agree that the reason German reunification was left off the agenda was the fear that forcing the issue could bring down President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on whom they think all the fragile changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe continue to depend. All the Western European leaders agreed over dinner in Paris on Nov. 18 that Mr. Gorbachev was at a critical juncture and that they should do nothing to undermine his position.
Officially, reunification will not be on the agenda when President Bush sees Mr. Gorbachev off Malta this weekend, but hardly anyone in Europe thinks it can stay off forever.
''To talk about the breakup of NATO does no one any good at all,'' Mrs. Thatcher said Tuesday night. But questions are even beginning to surface at the popular level all over Western Europe about whether there will be any need for an American-dominated military alliance against possible Soviet attack, when or if that threat no longer exists.
 
The Shape of Europe
 
The People Sense A Turning Point
Ordinary people, as well as their political leaders, sense that a historical turning point is being reached. ''We thought we had everything perfect in the Common Market,'' said Janet Semper, who lives in Westminster Abbey with her husband, Colin, a resident canon there. ''We were letting in one country at a time - Spain, Portugal, Greece, and then in comes this wonderful rabble through the Berlin wall and now we have to rethink the whole thing.''
''The instant the Berlin wall comes down, France is no longer the center of Europe - it's on the periphery,'' said Francois Barbey, a 48-year-old real estate salesman in Paris. ''People say we've won. We've come to the end of one world, but we haven't found the key to the next.''
John le Carre, whose master spy George Smiley got his Soviet counterpart, Karla, to defect across the Berlin wall in his 1980 novel, ''Smiley's People,'' put it this way in a recent essay: ''Smiley had won, as the West has won now. But the sweets of victory elude us - as they eluded Smiley, partly because he had forgotten what he was fighting for, partly because he feared that his masters preferred the comforts of permanent aggression to the hardship of new choices and alignments.''
''We really invent the enemies we need,'' the novelist, whose real name is David Cornwell, explained later. ''We could be making the discovery that Russia, once the military threat is removed, is a huge, untidy third world problem that will demand time, effort and money - lots of money - to fix. It could be a terrible headache.''
To many people, the German question already is. ''I don't know what will become of this land,'' Mr. Bolling said in his home in West Berlin. ''There'll be bound to be a cooling off vis-a-vis America as the prospect of a united Germany comes into view. Already the people of West Berlin are complaining about how the three allied military commanders have just bought 10 new Mercedes cars with their money, and they're asking how much longer they have to go on paying for such things.''
Already Lufthansa, the West German airline, is demanding that Britain, France and the United States relinquish their monopoly on flying between West Germany and West Berlin.
''The division into Eastern and Western Europe was a construction of the cold war,'' Heinz Ruhnau, Lufthansa's chairman, told Die Welt the day before the wall came down. ''East and West have to recognize that their status positions can't be maintained any longer after 40 years.''
''We all want a relationship with the United States,'' said Sergio Romano, a former diplomat who was Italy's Ambassador to Moscow until earlier this year. ''But I imagine we would all prefer that it not be so hierarchical as it has been.''
NATO diplomats in Brussels say that the organization, like the Warsaw Pact, will have to convert itself into an instrument for managing change and monitoring complex negotiated arms control agreements over the next few years, but in London, Paris and Bonn, diplomats complain that such thinking is only in its embryonic stage, and not well coordinated.
 
The Forming of a Union
 
Contradictions In the Community
If events in Eastern Europe are only beginning to spark a rethinking of NATO's role, they have uncovered contradictions about the European Community that have existed since the Treaty of Rome established it in 1957. In those early days, President Charles de Gaulle of France insisted that Europe not be a federation but a collection of sovereign, cooperating nation states. De Gaulle called it ''l'Europe des patries,'' and used it as an excuse for keeping out Britain in the early 1960's, because he feared the British would turn the European Community into an Anglo-Saxon United States of Europe.
Now all the European leaders but one - the British Prime Minister -have agreed that the changes in the East require urgently forging ahead to more federalism in the community. ''For the European Community to remain the center of gravity that it is, we must accelerate,'' said Jacques Delors, its executive president, two weeks ago.
Mrs. Thatcher wants to complete the 1992 program, but is wary of surrendering more British sovereignty to the community's executive commission in Brussels, which she says is not fully accountable to any democratic parliament. As Eastern European countries evolve toward political and economic democracy, her close advisers believe, the community should stay loose and flexible. ''This isn't the time to become more exclusive,'' one of them explained.
''I do not believe in a federation of Europe, a United States of Europe,'' Mrs. Thatcher said again on television Monday. ''I believe it will work far better if we cooperate together as 12 sovereign states.''
French officials expect that Mrs. Thatcher will be alone in opposing a call at the next European Community summit in Strasbourg, France, Dec. 8-9, for a conference that would consider changes in the Treaty of Rome to permit full monetary union, though they say they are not sure the Germans will not have developed second thoughts as well.
But if changes in the East continue, the European Community will no longer be limited to the 12, and one of the main subjects on the agenda in Strasbourg will be how to respond to the clamor in Eastern Europe to get in on the prosperity.
The 12 agreed in principle in Paris earlier this month to provide economic aid to all Eastern European countries, but only if they make clear progress toward economic and political democracy. Separately or together, Le Monde calculated the other day, the Europeans and the other industrial democracies have given or pledged more than $6 billion in aid or loans to Eastern Europe, mainly Hungary and Poland, this year.
West German and French officials believe that Bonn is prepared to offer even more than that to East Germany. ''It wouldn't be hard to make a success out of East Germany,'' one French diplomat observed. ''It could be more prosperous than Portugal in five years.''
The larger question behind this is whether Poland and Hungary, and now possibly East Germany and Czechoslovakia, should be allowed or encouraged to join the European Community, with associate membership as a first step.
''The E.C. already has various bilateral 'association agreements' with other countries; more can be struck in Eastern Europe as reform takes hold,'' The Economist newspaper wrote last week, a suggestion that was endorsed by Mrs. Thatcher. A former President of France, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, has suggested that the community tailor these association agreements country by country, and tie them to price reform, privatization and currency convertibility in each one.
Some European leaders speak of a Marshall Plan for Eastern Europe, with a leading role for the West; Le Monde said that Marshall aid from the United States from 1947 to 1948 totaled $13 billion, worth $171 billion today.
''A Marshall Plan now is impossible,'' Prof. Alfred Grosser, a French expert on Germany, said. ''You have hardly anyone in the Soviet Union, and not many in Eastern Europe, who know how to manage a market economy.''
In addition, all Eastern currencies have been pegged at wildly artificial rates against Western ones for years, and to get them down to realistic exchange values will be painful. In West Germany, the mark, now one of the world's strongest currencies, was introduced in June 1948 at a rate of one for every 10 old German reichsmarks, causing tremendous resentment and pain until people regained confidence in their money and the economy started functioning again.
Representatives of 24 industrial democracies, including the European Community, the United States, Japan and South Korea, will meet in Brussels on Dec. 13 for more discussions about how to help. ''The socialist models are collapsing,'' said Francois Perigot, head of the French employers' federation in Paris. ''If all they get from our system is black markets, petty corruption, unemployment and social indifference, they could turn away from our model. Europe shouldn't give them a bad example.''
 
The Soviet Threat
 
Some Confusion Amid Power Shifts
But essentially Europe is confused. No journalist, politician, professor or economic expert saw that change would come so suddenly to so many countries all over the East. What has happened has left many of them in breathless bewilderment.
All ordinary people can see for sure is that a Soviet threat that made them dependent on the United States has receded, and that for better or for worse the Europe they have known for 40 years will rapidly change into something else.
''Everyone everywhere is talking about it, of course,'' said Raymond Kingsley-Taylor, chapter clerk of Hereford Cathedral. ''There's relief, sheer stunned surprise, and apprehension.''
''Europe will become more and more aggressively competitive against Japan, and distance itself from the Americans,'' said Jacques Seguela, a French advertising executive and author in Paris. ''The Soviet Union will be part of this new Europe.'' He will open an advertising agency in Moscow Jan. 1 and two in Hungary and Poland.
Anke van der Valk, a 38-year-old social worker in Delft, the Netherlands, agreed. ''Those Eastern lands belong to Europe,'' she said. ''I think they should join the Common Market.'' But, she added, ''I'm a bit afraid of a united Germany. Better for the two Germanys to remain separate, and let both of them be members of the European Community.''
''All the French public opinion polls show that between 60 and 70 percent of the French people say German reunification wouldn't bother them,'' said Professor Grosser, France's leading expert on Germany. But in the Quai d'Orsay, some diplomats speak of the shelling of Rheims Cathedral in the Franco-Prussian War of 1870 as if it were yesterday.
''National pride caused all the problems we're seeing today,'' said Markus Doll, a 22-year-old student in Hamburg. ''The people who used to say 'We are Germans' now say 'We are Europeans.' For me it's no better. They should say 'We are people, just like everybody else.' ''

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Czechs Fault Policies of Hard-line Communists as Cause of Industrial Lag

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Frantisek Kucera, the general manager of the century-old Tos Hostivar Machinery Company, is one of those who lost out in the bargain that the hard-line Communist Government made to keep itself in power - cutting back on crucial investments to keep workers docile by providing them oranges, automobiles and homes.
Like most Czechoslovaks, Mr. Kucera is proud that his country was one of the 10 most advanced industrial nations before World War II, but now he complains that both his company and the nation's economy have slipped badly.
''We gave the Government 90 percent of our profits, but they gave us back very little for research and development and modernization,'' said Mr. Kucera, whose company manufactures machine tools, the metal-cutting machines used to make automobiles, airplanes and appliances.
 
Falling 15 Years Behind
Czechoslovak executives and economists often point to the machine tool industry as a symbol of the nation's decline. Before World War II, Czechoslovak companies like Tos Hostivar were ranked alongside those in Germany and the United States in making the world's most advanced metal-cutting machines. But by the late 1960's the Czechoslovaks had fallen some three years behind Western makers of machine tools, and now with the companies starved of money needed for modernization, they have fallen 15 years behind in key technologies. 
Now that Prague is at least orally committed to political and economic reform, the Czechoslovaks are spoiling to close the gap with the West, but they worry that it will take a long time to overcome the glaring economic errors made by the ousted Communist regime.
These days the Czechoslovaks take little solace that their nation and East Germany have long been the two richest Eastern European countries. In comparison to the economic production of Poland and Bulgaria, Prague was far ahead. But this nation has always thought of itself as being the most western of the Slavic countries, and in their hearts many Czechoslovaks see the proper standard of comparison, at the very least, as Austria and perhaps Belgium or France. And most often they blame Communist rule for having made them fall so far behind.
What has emerged unmistakably here in the last two weeks is that despite the intention of the now discredited Communists to placate workers, those same workers moved to revoke the leadership's mandate. Their overwhelming participation in the two-hour general strike on Monday is seen as a vote of no confidence in the policies and in those who claimed to rule in the name of the working class.
 
Freedom, Not Oranges
''It was a very primitive notion that they could buy off people with more oranges,'' said Ludek Urban, a Czechoslovak economist. ''The Government underestimated the needs of people, especially younger people. They didn't demonstrate for more oranges, but for more freedom.''
On the other hand, the Czechoslovak party's trade-off did seem to work for much of the last decade, when workers and intellectuals in neighboring Poland challenged the authority of the state and party with strikes and clandestine activity. In that time, protest in Czechoslovakia was limited to a small circle in which workers were almost entirely absent.
But now, having won large doses of freedom in the last few days, the Czechoslovaks are beginning to debate how they will use their new-found freedom to transform the economy.
Many economists say they are sure that the wave of democratic reforms will necessarily result in better economic performance. ''The Communist leaders were arrogant, and there was no one to stop them from having incompetents run the economy,'' said Milos Zeman, an economist who stirred a controversy in August in preparing a study for the Government on the nation's economic problems. ''The lack of understanding of economics by the Politburo members was incredible.'' #49th in University Graduates Hard-line Communists did not like the gloomy nature of Mr. Zeman's study, and he was dismissed. In arguing that the Government was robbing the nation's future, he noted, for example, that 6 percent of Czech adults have university degrees, placing a nation that prides itself on being cultured 49th in the world in this measure.
The Czechoslovak opposition has long maintained that there cannot be economic change without political change, a line recently echoed by Prime Minister Ladislav Adamec. He and the key opposition figures say more democracy will mean more accountability, and that should force the Government to find competent people to run the economy.
As teams of experts draft blueprints for the Czechoslovak economy, there is general agreement on two ideas. First, the Government should inject more market forces into the rigid economy. This is expected to help improve the quality of products and help push enterprises to increase productivity.
Second, it is agreed, Czechoslovakia will have an easier time than Poland or Hungary in moving away from Communist economics. But it might have a harder time than East Germany, which can count on special assistance from West Germany.
 
Ahead of Poland and Hungary
''Our starting point for making reforms is probably better than some other nations in Eastern Europe,'' said Vaclav Klaus, an opposition economist who is in the running to be the Finance Minister in the coalition government to be named this week.
The Czechoslovaks have not piled up the huge foreign debts that Poland and Hungary and East Germany have, although they have been criticized for sometimes using loans to buy oranges rather than crucial capital goods. In addition, even if Czechoslovakia's industry is somewhat neglected, its industrial base in steel, coal, machinery and chemicals remains far stronger than those of Poland or Hungary. Czechoslovakia has a deeply embedded industrial tradition, while Poland and Hungary were largely agricultural before World War II.
''We all have fallen about the same amount since Communist rule began, but since we started out as a more advanced country, we still remain better off,'' said Mr. Zeman. He likes to recall how in 1937, Time magazine ran a cover story about the Czechoslovaks and their advanced economy, calling them the ''Yankees of Europe.''
Mr. Zeman and Mr. Klaus are among the economists working in Civic Forum, the umbrella group for the opposition that was crucial in precipitating the fall of the Communist regime. The group's seven-part program says, ''We intend to abandon our long-standing methods of running the economy.'' It said the economic structure dampens motivation to work and has paid little attention to the environment. #47 Percent Want State Control ''We are convinced that this economic system cannot be improved by minor modifications,'' it said. ''We want to create a developed market, not deformed by bureaucratic interventions.'' Civic Forum added that it wanted to establish various forms of ownership, while guaranteeing ''the necessary minimum of public and social services.''
According to one poll, 47 percent of Czechoslovaks want their economy to remain state-controlled, while 43 percent want it to be a mixed economy. Only 3 percent said they favored capitalism. Thus, the Czechoslovaks appear far less eager than the Poles to place state-owned industry in private hands.
''Privatization is not the word I would push here today,'' said Mr. Klaus. ''It's definitely not on the agenda for the next few years.''
Many Czechoslovaks talk of Sweden's social democracy as their model, because of its commitment to equality in social services and its restrictions on the workings of the free market. Many are still enamored of the goal of ''socialism with a human face,'' an ideal made famous by Alexander Dubcek, the leader ousted by the Warsaw Pact invasion of 1968.
 
Denmark Cited as a Model
Denmark is also often cited as a model because, like Czechoslovakia, it has a long tradition of employee-owned and farmer-owned cooperatives. Cooperatives in which people own nontradeable shares can be a way station towards setting up a capital market where shares are traded, many economists say.
Walter Kamarek, an economist, whom many opposition figures favor to become Prime Minister or Deputy Prime Minister, called today in a news conference for a market economy and a major restructuring of industry.
Mr. Kamarek, the director of the Economic Forecasting Institute, says the nation needs to reduce its reliance on heavy industries like steel and coal, for which there is huge overcapacity in the world. He wants this nation of 15 million to stop spreading itself thin and to invest in specialized industries like electronics and advanced machinery.
At his 2,600-employee machine tool company in Prague's grimy industrial outskirts, Mr. Kucera has not yet begun to think about privatization and restructuring. One thing he is sure of, however, is that the political changes will mean a more decentralized economy and thus more autonomy for management.
''Right now, whenever we get a new order, we are never sure we can get the steel and parts we need to fill the order,'' he said. ''We spend a lot of time on paperwork asking the Government for this or that, instead of devoting our time to developing for the future.''
Tos Hostivar executives also complain that the Western embargo on shipping sophisticated technology to Eastern Europe has made it hard for their company to update its products.
Mr. Kucera hopes that the democratization process in Eastern Europe will persuade the West to lift the embargo to help these countries move ahead.

CITY: PRAGUE, CZECH REPUBLIC (92%);

PUB-DATE: December 1, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Survey Finds Americans Favor a Reunited Germany

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The upheaval in Eastern Europe has left Americans optimistic and ready for even greater change in the region. Two out of three say East and West Germany should be reunited, and an equal number predict that Eastern Europe will be largely out of Soviet control a year from now.
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll found few signs of apprehension about a reunified Germany, even among Americans aged 65 and over, the generation that fought World War II. Only 16 percent of Americans said they thought a reunified Germany would ''try to dominate the world,'' while 73 percent said it would not.
The poll reflects a broader trend, with new surveys in France and Britain showing similar support for a unified Germany. 
Sixty-seven percent of the American public said they felt Germany should be reunited, including 64 percent of those aged 65 and older. Seventy-four percent of the French said reunification was ''desirable,'' although 49 percent said it was desirable only several years down the road, according to a survey published this week by the French newspaper Le Figaro.
And 61 percent of the British public said it would be ''a good idea'' for the two Germanys to reunite, according to a poll conducted for The Sunday Times of London.
 
Germans 'Should Be Together'
Americans justified reunification on the simplest of grounds. ''The German people should be together'' was the explanation volunteered by 51 percent of those who supported it. ''No people should be pulled against the other half of their country, not them or us,'' said Vermadine Beach, 69 years old, of Fairfield, Calif., in a follow-up interview after the survey was completed.
The telephone survey of 1,297 adults conducted Sunday through Tuesday reflected an American public caught up in the political movements sweeping the Eastern bloc. Sixty-seven percent said that based on current events, the Soviet Union would not be in control of most countries in Eastern Europe a year from now.
Even if those countries develop governments where the Communists are not in control, 50 percent of Americans said the Russians would ''let them go ahead'' rather than ''use its troops to crack down''; 31 percent predicted a crackdown.
The public voiced a clear sense of diminished Soviet dominance: 59 percent said the Soviet Union was simply putting up with changes in Eastern Europe that it could not do anything about, while 20 percent said it was encouraging the change. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
On Soviet Communism
Almost half - 49 percent - predicted that the Soviet Union itself would not have a Communist Government 25 years from now; 38 percent said it would.
There were limits to the American optimism about Eastern Europe. ''I just feel that the leaders are not as willing as people might think to give up their beliefs, or their little areas of power,'' said Carol Cocco, 38, of Marshallville, Ohio, in a follow-up interview. ''I just can't imagine that whole bloc being a total democracy all the way around.''
And while 37 percent said they thought the cold war was over, 54 percent disagreed. Six percent thought the United States and its allies had won the cold war; 28 percent said it was over but neither side had really won.
Much of the public was cautious about the appropriate American response to the changes in Europe. Fifty-four percent said American troop strength in Western Europe should stay at about the same level as it is today; 27 percent said it should be reduced and 7 percent said the troops should be totally withdrawn.
Age made a difference in those judgments, but in a perhaps surprising way: 26 percent of those 18 to 29 said American troops should be reduced or eliminated in Western Europe. But 42 percent of the World War II generation - those aged 65 and over - said they supported a cut or a total withdrawal.
But there was no overwhelming sentiment to slash the Pentagon's budget, a subject of sharp debate in recent weeks. The annual 5 percent cuts under consideration by the Bush Administration for the next three years were supported by 42 percent of Americans. Another 21 percent said those cuts were too little, while 25 percent said the Pentagon's budget should be left alone.
For all the changes in Eastern Europe and the pleas for American aid to help it along, Americans retained a traditional tightfistedness when it came to direct United States assistance. Fifty-six percent said the United States should not increase aid to Eastern European countries that are becoming more independent of the Soviet Union, while 36 percent said it should.
And when asked if the United States should spend at least $1 billion in foreign aid to help Eastern European countries develop stable economies, 57 percent said no and 32 percent said yes. The three-year aid package for Poland and Hungary, recently passed by the Congress and signed by President Bush this week, came to just under $1 billion, and it was criticized by many politicians as too modest.
Benjamin I. Page, a professor of political science at Northwestern University who is conducting a study of American public opinion over the last 50 years, said, ''Large-scale foreign aid is just about always unpopular.''
 
Enthusiasm for More Trade
Sixty-seven percent of Americans said Mr. Bush had not been too slow in reacting to the events in Eastern Europe; the charge of timidity was frequently made by the Democrats this fall, most prominently by George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader.
The public showed considerable enthusiasm for greater trade with Eastern Europe: 71 percent favored giving the same international trading privileges to Eastern European countries that the United States gives to other friendly nations, while 19 percent opposed it.
A majority of Americans - 58 percent - said the United States should encourage American businesses to invest in these countries, while 36 percent said it should not.
Support for aid to Eastern Europe and trade with it was higher among those with more education. But support for a reunified Germany was higher among those with a high school education or less: 72 percent, compared to 57 percent of those who had college or postgraduate degrees.
Lech Walesa, the Polish leader who recently toured the United States, had a favorability rating that the average American Presidential candidate yearns for: 40 percent. Only 5 percent had an unfavorable opinion. Another 40 percent said they had not heard enough to develop an opinion.
The British survey was conducted Nov. 23 to 24, in person by MORI for The Sunday Times of London, with 1,071 respondents; it is scheduled for publication there on Sunday. The French survey, published by Le Figaro this week, was based on telephone interviews with 1,000 respondents, conducted Nov. 21 to 23 by the French Organization for Polling Research and Studies.
 
How the Poll Was Taken
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 26 to 28 with 1,297 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for those without college education it is plus or minus four percentage points; for those with college education it is also plus or minus four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: THE MALTA SUMMIT;
Bush Heads to Malta Ready For a 'Historic Opportunity'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
President Bush left today for his first summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, saying the two leaders had a ''powerful and historic opportunity'' to transform East-West relations.
Administration officials said the President was carrying a variety of ideas with him to Malta on speeding negotiations with Moscow to relax legal restrictions on American trade with the Soviet Union.
They said this could lead to a new trade agreement that would take effect if and when Mr. Bush decides to waive the 1974 Jackson-Vanik Amendment. That law prohibits the United States from granting most-favored-nation status to Communist countries unless they allow free emigration by their citizens. Countries with most-favored-nation status can export certain products to the United States with relatively low tariffs. 
Addressing several hundred Administration officials at a farewell ceremony in the White House Rose Garden, the President said the Malta meeting ''represents a point of departure, the beginning of a process as full of promise as any that we've ever known.''
The President said: ''America understands the magnitude of Mr. Gorbachev's challenges, and let there be no misunderstanding: We support perestroika; we support Chairman Gorbachev's efforts to relax the grip of the centralized government, to move toward pluralism and the free expression of ideas. No one can deny that there is a new openness in the Soviet Union. The change is dramatic.''
 
'Not in Some Kind of Competition'
He added: ''I believe the people of Europe can see that Mr. Gorbachev and I - East and West - are not in some kind of competition. Rather, we're both working to make the world a more peaceful one.''
The President departed on his nine-hour flight at 6:45 P.M.
Until now the Administration has held that the President would not waive the Jackson-Vanik Amendment to the 1974 Trade Act until the Kremlin both enacted a new open emigration law and put it into practice. However, American officials note that 51,336 Jews were allowed to emigrate from the Soviet Union in the first 10 months of this year, , topping the previous record of 51,000 in 1979, and that the Kremlin has submitted a new Soviet emigration law to the Supreme Soviet that is expected to be passed around February or March.
As a result, the President is going to Malta prepared to examine ways in which Washington and Moscow might begin to overcome the restrictions of Jackson-Vanik even before the new Soviet legislation is passed, officials said.
The President's advisers want to accomplish something in Malta beyond mere rhetoric, to demonstrate an enthusiastic, forward-looking attitude toward the Soviet leader and a willingness to engage in closer economic relations.
Even if the Jackson-Vanik Amendment is waived by the President, the Soviet Union would not be able to take advantage of most-favored-nation provisions because it has no trade agreement with the United States. Although a Soviet-American trade agreement was reached in October 1972, it was never implemented because of Jackson-Vanik and other trade restrictions, and was eventually abrogated by Moscow.
 
'Laying the Groundwork Now'
As a result, one proposal being carried by the President to Malta is for the United States and Soviet Union to begin negotiations quickly on a new comprehensive commercial trade agreement, even before the Supreme Soviet enacts the pending legislation allowing freer emigration.
A joint Soviet-American commerical commission met for two days earlier this month and formed a group to study how such an agreement would be negotiated. Depending on what the President hears from Mr. Gorbachev, particularly any assurances he might provide on when the Soviet emigration legislation will be approved, Mr. Bush may offer to start negotiations now on a new trade agreement. That way, when Jackson-Vanik is waived, as now seems inevitable, a trade arrangement between the two countries might already be in place.

HEADLINE: Budget Office Proposes $8 Billion Medicare Cut

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The White House budget office has proposed saving $8 billion in Medicare spending that would otherwise be required in the next fiscal year under current law.
The budget proposal would mean that the health insurance program for the elderly and the disabled would sustain the largest reduction in terms of dollars of any domestic program, and perhaps any Government program, Bush Administration officials said.
Any such reductions would need the approval of both Congress and the President, and some members of Congress today expressed strong opposition to the proposed cuts for the fiscal year 199l.
In this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, 1990, Medicare spending is set to reach $114 billion. If that same spending rate was sustained for 1991, the Medicare budget would grow to $130 billion. 
But a copy of the budget proposal, which has not been made public, shows that the Bush Administration hopes to keep Federal spending to $122 billion. The $8 billion reduction would be achieved through $5.5 billion in curtailed programs and $2.5 billion in new revenue.
Health-care experts contend that the higher spending rate is needed to maintain adequate services for beneficiaries of Medicare, which provides health insurance for 33 million elderly or disabled people.
''Congress is going to fight this budget,'' said Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,100 private hospitals. ''If you keep drying up money for health care, services will have to be reduced. Either you close emergency rooms and trauma centers, or you fire nurses and technicians.''
 
Opposition Among Republicans
The budget proposal also came under attack from Congressional Republicans. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, sent his Republican colleagues in the House a letter today stating, ''Many of America's hospitals -particularly our rural, inner city and teaching hospitals - simply cannot continue to absorb another year of significant budget cuts.'' He asked them to sign the letter, to be sent to President Bush.
Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican, is circulating a similar letter in the Senate.
''Like many, I am particularly troubled by the effect of low Medicare reimbursements on our most vulnerable hospitals - those in rural areas and inner cities,'' Senator Kassebaum wrote. She was among 41 senators who joined 248 House members last year in calling for a one-year halt on further reductions in Medicare hospital payments.
The Office of Management and Budget specifically proposed a $5.5 billion reduction in the growth of spending, mainly through reductions in Federal funds for medical education and capital improvements for urban hospitals, and in a lower hospital reimbursement rate than would occur under current law.
The budget plan also recommended reductions in payments to some physicians, including some surgeons, whose fees were considered excessive by the physician-payment legislation recently approved by Congress.
Much of the $2.5 billion in increased revenue would come from a payroll tax under a proposal to include all new state and local government workers under the health plan.
 
Earlier Move for Cuts
Last year, the Bush Administration also sought major cuts in the growth of Medicare, but Congress restored half the money after the plan met strong opposition from the health industry.
Under the new budget plan, hospitals would receive a 4 percent increase in payments for Medicare patients, based on inflation, rather than the 5.5 percent increase under current law.
Financing of AIDS research and treatment would be slightly reduced, by $7 million, from the $1.6 billion budgeted this year. But funds for research and programs on alcohol and drug abuse would increase by $45 million, to $2.5 billion.
The budget plan would provide $27 billion for the operation of the Department of Health and Human Services, up from $25.2 billion in the current fiscal year. The budget office would reduce the agency's staff to 111,000 employees from 119,500.
The budget office's plan would provide significantly less Federal financing than had been requested by the department of health. The health agency had sought $3 billion more in Medicare spending and $225 million more for AIDS.
 
Health Secretary's Concern
The agency also sought $200 million more than the $1.3 billion budget office proposal for Head Start, and $365 million more than the budget office's $4.2 billion proposed for the Social Security Administration.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, expressed his dismay in a letter to Richard G. Darman, the budget director.
The Secretary said that he appreciated ''the constraints imposed by a difficult deficit reduction target for the coming fiscal year.''
''But I question classifying certain Presidential initiatives as 'beyond what can now be accommodated,' '' he said.
Head Start represented the President's commitment for expanded enrollment of low-income children, Dr. Sullivan said. ''This program is also a key element of the management objective to strengthen families which was agreed upon by O.M.B. and the Department earlier this year.''
Similarly, he said, the Social Security Administration ''must be adequately funded in order to insure that our 132 million workers receive proper credit for all earned wages to which they are entitled.''
Under the budget proposal, the National Institutes of Health would receive $6.6 billion, about the same as its current spending level. The Food and Drug Administration would receive $563 million, up from the current budget of $513 million.

HEADLINE: Help Mr. Gorbachev Help the West

 BODY:
When President Bush meets President Gorbachev tomorrow, it will be with the best of intentions for improving Soviet-American relations. But it's still not clear that he has a clear and compelling strategy for doing so.
The goal of such a strategy can be quickly stated: Help Mr. Gorbachev keep doing those things that advance Western interests as well as his own. There are three principal ways: Negotiate deep arms reductions to permit deep cuts in military spending; reach understandings about Eastern Europe to minimize potential friction, and take immediate practical steps to assist the faltering Soviet economy. 
After temporizing, Mr. Bush now states unequivocally that Western interests lie in the success of Mr. Gorbachev's reforms. Make no mistake about the importance of that admission.
It is Mr. Gorbachev who has reduced Soviet military forces, granted limited internal freedoms and encouraged the openings in Eastern Europe. It is he who is thus doing precisely what the West has long demanded, and spent trillions of dollars to achieve. Soviet economic weaknesses would have compelled any leader to retract the Bear's claws and controls. But it was far from inevitable that the change would be so profound.
Mr. Gorbachev might fail. Reports persist about empty food shelves, potentially crippling strikes, rampant crime and anti-Semitism and a bleak winter ahead. It would be unwise to assume he is not in jeopardy. And it would be foolhardy to believe that, if he loses, he will be succeeded by benevolent reformers. Chaos and misery breed absolutists and hard-liners.
To prevent this and help Mr. Gorbachev further devolve central power, the United States and the West can follow a three-pronged strategy:
Arms Control. Both the Soviet Union and the U.S. want to reduce arms expenditures and concentrate on other needs. The best way is mutual arms reductions on an unprecedented scale. The mutuality is necessary so that leaders in both countries can counter hard-line opposition. The biggest payoffs right now would come from treaties to halve strategic nuclear arms and make substantial cuts in European-based conventional forces. Mr. Gorbachev has already agreed to vastly disproportionate reductions. There's new talk that Mr. Bush is contemplating even greater mutual conventional cuts; those would be all the more welcome.
What's necessary is to close out these talks quickly. Even with optimistic assumptions, it will take years to actually start receiving arms control dividends.
Understandings on Europe. Both sides are concerned about the transition occurring in the former satellite states, and about German reunification. Mr. Gorbachev has asked that the West not take advantage of the situation, and Mr. Bush has promised restraint. Yet Mr. Gorbachev continues to call for an even ''more rapid pace of change'' in Eastern Europe. And while the West can only applaud that, both sides know that more change will necessarily diminish Soviet influence. Western credits, goods and know-how will soon flood the area.
Practical Economic Assistance. It's a wonder that grim economic conditions in the Soviet Union are not worse. Soviet economists continue to stress the need for immersing an untrained people in a cold capitalist bath. They plead for membership in international trade and financial institutions.
These theoretical concerns have long-term validity but can do little now to fill shelves that are already empty and stomachs that may soon be so. Just as the West now agrees that Eastern Europe will need help, so it must be willing to respond to requests from Moscow to ease the pains of transition. That means being ready to make loan guarantees and lift trade and other restrictions, as apparently now planned by the White House. Without help in satisfying consumers, conditions could ripen for counterrevolution.
The Bush and Gorbachev Administrations have already been talking about arms control, Eastern Europe and economic relations. What has been lacking on the American side is concentration on the goal of helping Mr. Gorbachev to help the West, now. The Malta meeting is the place to start.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
When Farming Was the Soul Of Garden State

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
For more than 50 years, Lloyd Wescott ran a dairy farm in Hunterdon County about 30 miles west of here, on the Delaware River. Two years ago he sold it. At the age of 80, he was growing old for farming, and the dairy business simply was not making it.
He sold most of the farm - 250 acres - for $1.2 million. He could have received more, much more, selling to a developer. But he wanted the place to remain a farm. 
And it is, although the milk cows have been replaced by horses, and no ordinary horses at that. ''Dressage horse,'' said Mr. Wescott, the kind that compete at horse shows and the Olympics, ridden by the likes of Princess Anne. They are highly bred, highly trained and highly expensive.
''The big orchard right next to me, they now have Arabians,'' Mr. Wescott said. ''Fellow showed me one the other day and said, 'This horse, I paid $85,000 for.' ''
Mr. Wescott was on hand on Monday at the dedication of the New Jersey Museum of Agriculture on the campus of Cook College, the agricultural and environmental college at Rutgers University. Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who dedicated the intentionally barnlike $3 million complex that will be stuffed with 2,659 agricultural implements dating from the 18th century, said its intent was to ''keep the word 'garden' in 'the Garden State,' '' amid ''fear that the state will lose its link with its agricultural past.''
That does not seem to be an idle fear. Although farming is far from a museum piece, it is in sharp decline. Beyond Mr. Kean's observation that his own children did not know that Jethro Tull was the inventor of the horse-drawn seed drill and not just a rock band, agriculture here is undergoing an enormous squeeze and a transformation.
Mr. Wescott recalled that he sold his last farm horses for about $50. Of course, that was in the 30's, when he had his first dairy farm, 800 acres near Clinton. The area is now under water, a victim of progress, flooded by the Spruce Run Reservoir.
New Jersey is the most densely populated state, and with urban and suburban sprawl come land-use conflicts. Suburbanites tend to resent crop-dusters' buzzing over golf courses and skyrocketing land costs. The old ways just don't pay. Another visitor to the dedication ceremony was Edgar Van Zandt of Flemington, who donated a windmill erected by his father, a tractor dealer, in 1910. Mr. Van Zandt, 61, also sold tractors. But the tractor business in New Jersey and across the country has virtually collapsed. Since 1980, Mr. Van Zandt has been a consultant for the Farmers Home Administration. It is adapt, or die economically. Forty dairy farms went out of business last year, leaving 380, and many of those are in trouble. New Jersey now produces more horses - show horses, racing horses and even rodeo horses - than it does dairy cattle. The growing of meat and potatoes is quickly yielding to the cultivation of lawns and shrubs.
''New Jersey used to be a leading poultry producer,'' Mr. Wescott said. ''Now you can hardly find a hen.'' An assistant dean at Cook, Veronica M. Malone, said poultry and eggs were the state's biggest agricultural commodity in 1960, followed by dairy products and vegetables.
But the farmers appear to have beaten their plowshares into lawnmowers, to maim a metaphor. The biggest share of agricultural income these days, about $180 million at last count, in 1985, is growing. That comes from nurseries and greenhouses and sod, to green up the state's rolling tide of lawns, village greens and golf courses.
In 1961, the state had 18,000 horses and 128,000 milk cows. Today it has 60,000 horses and 31,000 milk cows.
Phillip Alampi, vice president of the agricultural museum and, for 26 years, until retiring in 1982, state Agriculture Secretary, recalled that in the early 80's, partly as a result of soaring taxes, the state lost six farms a day. Basing taxes on agricultural land values rather than development values helped the situation, Mr. Alampi said, adding, ''We slowed it to one farm every six days.''
In 1960, there were 15,800 farms on 1.5 million acres. Last year there were 7,400 farms on 830,000 acres, a decline of about half. The definition of a ''farm'' is a site that produces crops worth $1,000 or more a year.
Walt Ellis, in his 50's, is still an active farmer - ''a couple hundred acres of sweet corn'' - but said: ''The changes in agriculture are substantial. The plethora of regulation, overregulation of pesticides, land-use regulations is creating the specter that has the potential of taking away the value the farmer has worked for all his life.''

PUB-DATE: December 1, 1989

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 893 words

HEADLINE: Rohatyn Urges Dinkins to Hold Spending Line

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has warned that Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins should plan to hold spending in next year's New York City budget to the level of this year's revenues, in a drastic no-growth approach.
In an unusual letter Wednesday to the board members of his fiscal watchdog agency, Mr. Rohatyn also said the prospects for economic growth were so dim that Mr. Dinkins should consider deferring raises for city workers next year, or negotiating only modest increases below inflation and then reducing the work force through a hiring freeze and attrition.
As a member of Mr. Dinkins's council of economic advisers and transition team, Mr. Rohatyn, a general partner at the investment banking concern Lazard Freres & Company, has given him similar counsel in private. But his letter is effectively a public challenge to the Mayor-elect to heed that advice and to severely limit his options for new spending and programs when he takes office on Jan. 1. 
 
Persistent Shortfalls Cited
Mr. Rohatyn, who has long argued that the municipal work force and salaries grew too fast in the boom years of the 80's, said Mr. Dinkins must use extreme caution in planning the budget for the fiscal year that begins next July. He said he based his views on ''the consensus of economic forecasters'' and on persistent shortfalls in almost all city tax receipts.
Just yesterday, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin reported that city tax revenues grew 6.2 percent in the four months since July 1 compared with the same period last year, below the 8.3 percent expected in the city's latest financial plan, and well below the 9.8 percent predicted when the budget was adopted in June.
Mr. Rohatyn's letter said, ''The underlying economic and fiscal forecasts call for the new budget to be prepared at the same spending level as the current year, after a decade which has seen city spending double.''
He said the city must ''take steps to strategically allocate relatively scarce resources, within the $26.5 billon level of this year's budget for next year's spending.''
''In addition to establishing clear priorities for limited funding,'' he added, ''the city must begin immediately to establish and implement a program of large-scale management reforms, in which nothing is sacrosanct.''
 
'One Way of Looking at It'
A spokesman for Mr. Dinkins, David Fishlow, said the Mayor-elect had met with Mr. Rohatyn on Wednesday and had seen the letter. ''He has not yet adopted those recommendations as his policy, but will consider them along with other advice that he gets,'' Mr. Fishlow said.
The city's Budget Director, Paul Dickstein, said that he had not seen the report, but that holding next year's budget at this year's level would force a $1.7 billion reduction in services because of inflation and projected increases in workload, labor settlements and other mandated costs. ''And in my opinion that would be disastrous for the city,'' he said. ''You would be laying off thousands and thousands of people, no doubt in the Board of Education and, I expect, the Police Department.''
Mr. Dickstein also said he believed such a Draconian approach would end up generating a revenue surplus.
Mr. Rohatyn, asked in a telephone interview yesterday whether he thought his proposal had a realistic chance of being adopted, replied: ''Look, I don't know. But I also don't know what the situation is going to be at the end of April.''
 
Tradition of Forceful Advice
''It just seems to me that everything that I have seen keeps getting worse and worse,'' he said. ''Clearly, these are things that I have discussed with the Mayor-elect. But the fact that you give advice doesn't mean that that advice is necessarily followed, nor do I expect it to be, necessarily. He's going to have his own pressures and problems to deal with.''
Mr. Rohatyn's letter stands in the tradition of forceful advice that he established in the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, when the Municipal Assistance Corporation was created to help the nearly insolvent city raise money in the bond market.
Some officials in city government and civic group leaders saw Mr. Rohatyn's letter as an effort to remind Mr. Dinkins, lest there be any doubt, that he still considers himself a force to be reckoned with, and that Mr. Rohatyn was weighing in even more firmly on the side of fiscal conservatism as Mr. Dinkins struggles with the demands of his diverse constituencies, many of whom are seeking increased services.
''This is an effort to keep himself in the front of the agenda,'' Mr. Dickstein said. ''Everybody who comments on the city's budget agenda says the same thing about the problems out there. Felix says it more often and more publicly. But I would not infer from that that he has any indication that the Dinkins administration isn't prepared to do what it's going to have to do.''
An official of a civic group that studies municipal fiscal affairs, who spoke on condition of anonymity, called Mr. Rohatyn ''a sort of spear-carrier for a certain set of views.''
''And whether he picked it up as a result of conscious meetings with people in the business community or just has his usual good sense,'' the official said, ''the sum and substance of it is to create a mood that's going to cut down David's flexibility.''

HEADLINE: THE LAW;
For the Record

 BODY:

Texas Lawyer's Creed
Last month the Texas Supreme Court and the Court of Criminal Appeals adopted the ''Texas Lawyer's Creed - A Mandate for Professionalism,'' citing abusive tactics that ''ranged from lack of civility to outright hostility and obstructionism.'' The following excerpt is from the creed.
 
Our Legal System
I am passionately proud of my profession. Therefore, ''My word is my bond.'' 
I am responsible to assure that all persons have access to competent representation regardless of wealth or position in life.
I commit myself to an adequate and effective pro bono program. . . .
 
Lawyer to C<u1>l<u1>i<u1>e<u1n<u1>t
. . . I will endeavor to achieve my client's lawful objectives in legal transactions and in litigation as quickly and economically as possible. . . .
I will advise my client that civility and courtesy are expected and are not a sign of weakness. . . .
I will treat adverse parties and witnesses with fairness and due consideration. A client has no right to demand that I abuse anyone or indulge in any offensive conduct.
I will advise my client that we will not pursue conduct which is intended primarily to harass or drain the financial resources of the opposing party. . . .
I will advise my client regarding the availability of mediation, arbitration and other alternative methods of resolving and settling disputes.
 
Lawyer to Lawyer
I will be courteous, civil and prompt in oral and written communications.
I will not quarrel over matters of form or style, but I will concentrate on matters of substance. . . .
I can disagree without being disagreeable. I recognize that effective representation does not require antagonistic or obnoxious behavior. I will neither encourage nor knowingly permit my client or anyone under my control to do anything which would be unethical or improper if done by me. . . .
 
Lawyer and Judge
I will always recognize that the position of judge is the symbol of both the judicial system and administration of justice. I will refrain from conduct that degrades this symbol.
I will conduct myself in court in a professional manner and demonstrate my respect for the court and the law. . . .
I will be punctual.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Aid for East Bloc Expected To Be a Vital Summit Topic

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
Economic issues will be crucial in the talks between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev off Malta this weekend.
Both leaders have made clear their recognition that finding solutions to the economic problems racking the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe would be in their mutual interest -and could be critical to the world's future peace and prosperity.
The solutions are likely to require new forms of military, political and economic collaboration between the most powerful capitalist nation and the most powerful Communist nation. But both have been losing dominance within the blocs they lead, because of economic strains stemming in large part from their military rivalry. 
Oddly, after four decades of cold war, the issue of the day is how the United States can help the Soviet Union avoid an economic disaster -and what changes would be required on the Soviet side.
''The most important thing we can do,'' Prof. Abram Bergson of Harvard, a leading authority on the Soviet economy, said in an interview yesterday, ''is to move ahead on arms control that would result in cutting military expenditures.'' He considers the most serious economic problem the Soviet Union faces to be its enormous budget deficit, which is running this year at 90 billion rubles, or about 10 percent of its gross national product.
This huge deficit, roughly triple that of the United States relative to G.N.P., causes Soviet inflation; price controls repress that inflation but instead result in critical shortages of all kinds of consumer goods. ''Defense cuts are the most effective way Gorbachev has to restrict the deficit,'' Professor Bergson said, ''but he needs us to join in.'' Another way the United States can ease the economic problems of the Soviets is to open up the American market more widely to their exports, enabling them to earn the foreign exchange and pay for the imports they need. President Bush is prepared to lift trade restrictions if Moscow assures him that the Soviet Union will ease its curbs on emigration, Administration officials said yesterday. At present, the Jackson-Vanik amendment denies most-favored-nation status to the Soviet Union as a ''nonmarket economy'' that restricts emigration for political reasons.
Jackson-Vanik also denies American businesses seeking to export to the Soviet Union access to Export-Import bank loans and guarantees of credit. Further, even if Jackson-Vanik were waived by the Administration, the Stevenson amendment flatly limits the amount of credit that could be granted to exporters to a total of $300 million over four years.
The Soviet Union at present does not have a large volume of goods to export, but it regards Jackson-Vanik as of great symbolic importance in showing American discrimination against Soviet goods. Until now, American economists have criticized Mr. Bush for moving on the Jackson-Vanik issue ''with all deliberate slowness.''
Also in the trade area, the United States has been slow to reduce technical controls on American exports to the Soviet Union - more so than other countries. A report by the National Academy of Sciences concluded that the United States had been overly restrictive in limiting exports of advanced technology to the Soviet Union, unnecessarily hampering United States-Soviet trade.
A central issue is whether the United States should mobilize large sums of capital to lend to the Soviet Union to help it through its present troubles - and, indeed, whether the Soviet Union would be wise to become a huge borrower, like the developing countries or, for that matter, Poland, Czechoslovakia or Hungary.
George Soros, the president of the Quantum Fund, who has been closely involved in seeking to further economic reforms in Hungary, Poland and the Soviet Union, has proposed to have the United States quickly take the lead in establishing a international financial agency, separate from the International Monetary Fund or the World Bank, for the purpose of lending to the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries. The new institution would get only part of its capital from the United States, given its budget and balance-of-payment problems, but most from Japan, West Germany, and other industrial countries.
He would link this new institution to measures to make the Soviet ruble convertible, facilitating the Soviets' joining into the world economy and domestic economic progress. Mr. Soros calculates that since the current Soviet budget deficit plus the so-called monetary overhang amount to a total of about 350 billion to 400 billion rubles and since the black market rate of the ruble is now about 15 rubles to the dollar, it would require hard currency credits of only $25 billion to stabilize the ruble.
Felix G. Rohatyn, senior partner of Lazard Freres & Company and chairman of New York State's Municipal Assistance Corporation, urges emergency aid of food, fuel and clothing for the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and has taken an approach similar to Mr. Soros's, calling for a new institution, which he calls a Development Bank for Eastern Europe. He suggests that the bank can be started with the Western countries and Japan putting up just $5 billion and, like the World Bank, the new institution could borrow additional billions in the public markets.
But some skeptics - including bankers who have been involved in the problem of third world debt - put heavy stress on the importance of economic reforms by the Soviet Union or other Eastern European countries, if the foreign capital is not to be wasted or even to be counterproductive. William R. Rhodes, group executive of Citicorp, who has served as chairman of the Restructuring Committee for negotiating with the Latin American and other debtor countries, said in an interview, ''I think the key to American private-sector involvement in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe is the extent to which these countries are prepared and able to open up their economies and privatize.''
The financial markets will be looking at the Bush-Gorbachev meeting - and any surprises it produces - for signs of a whole new era in world trade and investment. Mr. Bush has warned against expecting surprises, but that has not dampened expectations of new opportunities blooming. He has plenty of options to discuss. As George Perry of the Brookings Institution put it, ''The important thing is that President Bush leave all possibilities open.'' Indeed, the President appears to be headed for the summit meeting in that spirit.

HEADLINE: Retailing Sluggish in November

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lackluster sales at several major department stores raised the specter of a disappointing holiday season, as the nation's big retailers reported yesterday on their November performance.
One favorable sign, however, was that selling momentum picked up late in the month, especially over the Thanksgiving weekend.
The nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Company, said sales fell 1.3 percent in the four weeks ended Nov. 25. Sales at Sears stores open at least a year, called same- or comparable-store sales, edged up just four-tenths of 1 percent. 
 
Gains for K Mart
The K Mart Corporation, the second-largest retailer, said sales rose 7.2 percent while its same-store sales grew 3.9 percent. K Mart's four-week sales period ended on Nov. 22, before the Thanksgiving weekend.
The Wal-Mart Corporation, the No. 3 retailer, reported a 27 percent increase in November sales. Its same-store sales rose 12 percent.
Same-store sales are regarded as a better reflection of a retailer's performance than results that include newly opened stores. New stores often benefit from retailing momentum because of their novelty.
A Commerce Department report released yesterday on personal income and spending confirmed consumer caution. The report said consumer spending fell two-tenths of 1 percent in October - the sharpest monthly decline in nearly three years - despite an increase in income of nine-tenths of 1 percent. [Page D5.] Analysts were divided as to what the figures indicated.
''I would say basically we're off to a good start,'' said Daniel Barry, an analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company.
 
'Touch and Go'
But Gary Saunders, an analyst for Josephthal & Company, said: ''I think it's touch and go. A lot of the discounters and big department stores have serious concerns for good reason. The likelihood is that it's going to be a very tough Christmas.''
Generally, sales of durable goods are expected to remain sluggish, and further promotional sales could eat into profits during the holiday retail season, which accounts for up to half of retailers' annual earnings.
Mass merchandisers - stores that carry a high proportion of durables like furniture, refrigerators and carpeting - could have the toughest time. Consumers, whose spending makes up about two-thirds of total economic activity, have been holding back on purchases of costly items.
Bernard F. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Montgomery Ward & Company, said consumer restraint was reflected in the company's November results.
''Holiday sales are off to a slow start due to continued economic pressures affecting big-ticket purchases and weather conditions that have negatively impacted apparel sales,'' he said.
Analysts blamed unusually mild weather in California for sluggish sales of warm clothing and other winter gear. But over all, apparel stores did better than general merchandise chains, continuing a pattern that has persisted all year.
Forecasters say the economy's weakness will make shoppers hold back a bit this year, and holiday sales are expected to rise only about 5.5 percent, compared with 1988's surprisingly strong 9 percent gain.
Many store owners are already resorting to discounts, and those that need cash to meet their parent companies' debt payments have been especially aggressive with markdowns.
Following is a list of domestic sales for November reported by a number of the nation's largest retailers:
 
Carter Hawley Hale Stores, up 4.7 percent, to $261.5 million, excluding sales from the Oakland, Calif., store.
Dayton Hudson Corp., up 8.4 percent over all, to $1.13 billion. Up 1.7 percent in same-store sales.
J. C. Penney Co., up 6.6 percent over all, to $1.48 billion. Up 6 percent in same-store sales.
K Mart Corp., up 7.2 percent over all, to $2.42 billion. Up 3.9 percent in same-store sales.
Limited Inc., up 14 percent over all, to $410 million. Up 9 percent in same-store sales.
May Department Stores Co., up 6.6 percent over all, to $867.7 million.
Melville Corp., up 10.6 percent over all, to $674.7 million.
Montgomery Ward & Co., down 2.1 percent over all, to $530.5 million.
Sears, Roebuck & Co., down 1.3 percent over all, to $2.96 billion. Up four-tenths of 1 percent in same-store sales.
TJX Cos. (formerly Zayre Corp.), up 10.2 percent over all, to $208.5 million.
Wal-Mart Corp., up 27 percent over all, to $2.64 billion. Up 12 percent in same-store sales.
F. W.Woolworth Co., up 12.8 percent over all, to $411 million.

HEADLINE: Technology Code Review Urged by U.S.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The United States and its allies should respond to the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe by relaxing controls on advanced technology to Communist countries, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said today.
''We and our Cocom partners will want to signal our clear willingness to respond constructively to the democratization under way in Eastern Europe,'' Mr. Eagleburger said at a conference at the State Department on government-business relations.
Cocom, the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, is a group of 17 Western nations formed more than 40 years ago to prevent high-technology goods from reaching the Eastern bloc. 
 
Willingness to Negotiate
Mr. Eagleburger stressed that he was not announcing a new policy but rather the willingess of the United States to negotiate changes in current rules.
''The best I can say without going too far, because it's going to take negotiations and time, is that I think you will find the United States and hopefully our allies prepared to recognize that we have to adjust Cocom and our whole concept of technology transfer to the East to the new realities,'' he said.
On Wednesday, a committee of business and labor advisers to the United States trade represenative, Carla A. Hills, called on the White House to give priority to streamlining export controls.
The group warned that if the United States did not move quickly, Europeans would buy fewer American high-technology goods and would cut United States companies out of cooperative research projects.
Mrs. Hills said the group's recommendations would receive ''careful attention.''
 
'Not an Obstacle'
Another United States official who insisted on anonymity said Mr. Eagleburger is trying to tell American companies that Cocom rules would not rob them of business opportunities as Poland, Hungary and other East Bloc nations overhaul their economies along market lines.
''For what the East Europeans need for their economic reforms, Cocom is not an obstacle,'' the official said.
Talk of easing Cocom rules will be politically sensitive on Capitol Hill.
Concern has expressed about the effect on national security of technology transfers to the Eastern bloc.
''It doesn't mean we won't turn down cases in the future, but there'll be a major effort to look at things constructively,'' the official said.
Despite perceptions that Cocom seriously hampers East-West trade, the official noted that the Boeing Company had received approval to sell its advanced 767 airliner to Poland and Airbus Industrie, a four-nation European consortium, was delivering equally sophisticated aircraft to East Germany.
 
West German Remarks
As Mr. Eagleburger spoke, the West German Minister of Posts and Telecommunications, Christian Schwarz-Schilling, said at a meeting in Washington that Cocom should review its restrictions.
Allowing the sales of restricted telecommunications equipment could help the economics and stability of the liberalizing Eastern European nations, he said.
''I think a reassessment of what can be exported to Eastern countries is overdue,'' Mr. Schwarz-Schilling said at a luncheon meeting given by the Konrad Adenauer Foundation, a West German research organization.
