HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Plans to Shut V-8 Engine Plant

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company told 900 employees at its Windsor, Ontario, engine plant that it will close the factory late next year. The plant was shuttered in 1981 during the auto industry's deep recession but reopened in 1983 when demand for the larger engines grew.
Company officials said the number of Ford cars and pickup trucks using the five-liter V-8 engine produced in Windsor has declined lately, while some five-liter engines have been replaced by a smaller V-6 engine produced at a neighboring plant in Windsor.

HEADLINE: Spending Drops Off; Income Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Consumer spending fell in October to its lowest level in nearly three years, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts said continued sluggishness in personal consumption is likely to be a ''major drag'' on the economy in the fourth quarter.
But personal income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, which analysts said indicated that consumers still had spending power but were waiting for bargains. 
''It's not going to be a great Christmas in terms of shopping,'' said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, a Washington consulting firm. ''People will just wait until things go on sale.''
 
A 'Weak Note'
The Commerce Department said that spending, reflecting plummeting automobile sales in October, dropped two-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.53 trillion, after edging up only three-tenths of 1 percent in September.
It was the first decline in personal spending since a one-tenth of 1 percent drop in September 1988 and the steepest since a 1.4 percent fall in January 1987.
Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, and the spending report provided fresh evidence that the economy is continuing to slow.
''Consumer spending is starting the fourth quarter on an extremely weak note,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. ''I think it will be a major drag on the economy in the fourth quarter.''
Income totaled $4.51 trillion, reflecting the largest advance since a 1 percent gain last March. It had risen three-tenths of 1 percent in September.
The earthquake in Northern California took $21 billion out of the income figure at an annual rate, but that was partly offset by other one-time ''special factors,'' including a $7.2 billion increase in farm subsidies and $6.8 billion in bonuses to auto industry employees.
''Excluding the impact of the special factors, personal income increased about $33 billion, or 0.7 percent,'' the Commerce Department said.
Mr. Jones and Mrs. Shaber, while expecting a weak fourth quarter, said the report by itself did not indicate an imminent recession.
In October, Americans' after-tax incomes rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, up from September's two-tenths of 1 percent gain, the department said.
The savings rate rose to 5.7 percent, the highest since a 5.8 percent rate last June, compared with September's 4.7 percent. The savings rate is a measure of savings as a percentage of disposable income.
 
Payroll Gains
Wages and salaries, the most significant component of personal income, rose $33 billion, compared with a $17 billion gain in September.
Payrolls at manufacturing companies rose by $6.8 billion, but would have been flat except for the $6.8 billion in auto bonuses.
On the spending side, the $6.1 billion decrease in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, compared with a $9.9 billion gain in September, when incentives drove up auto sales.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in moderately active trading yesterday. Market participants said they were particularly encouraged by a rise in initial unemployment claims for the week ended Nov. 18 and a drop in an index that serves as a proxy for manufacturing activity in the Chicago area, a monthly survey of purchasing managers.
The Chicago results were made available a day before a closely watched monthly survey covering the views of purchasing managers across the country is scheduled to be released.
''Chicago is a pretty diversified area, and nothing in the report is pointing us in a different direction away from the notion that the manufacturing sector is weakening,'' said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. 
 
No Fed Easing Expected
The data were weaker than anticipated, but Mr. Johnson and other analysts said that in light of recent events they were not of sufficient import to expect that the Fed will ease.
''After the embarrassing events of the past week, it will take something systemic, like a weak employment report, to persuade the Federal Reserve that it should ease policy,'' he said.
Mr. Johnson was referring to a series of steps taken by the Federal Reserve since Nov. 22 that market participants erroneously thought represented a move by the central bank toward an easier credit policy.
Traders sustained fairly substantial losses as a result of the error, and many are still licking their wounds.
But memories on Wall Street tend to be short, and some participants said that interest in longer-term securities, particularly from foreign accounts, was evident yesterday.
 
Greenspan Rumors Ignored
For the most part, traders of fixed-income securities tended to ignore rumors that the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, was about to resign. The rumors briefly roiled the foreign exchange markets and pushed the dollar lower in early trading. The rumors were met with a strong denial by a Fed spokesman later in the day.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 22/32, up 13/32, to yield 7.88 percent, down from 7.92 percent on Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, up 9/32, to yield 7.82 percent.
Meanwhile, the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.72 percent. And the new 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.71 percent. 3-Month Bill at 7.55% Short-term Treasury bill rates eased somewhat. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.55 percent, down 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 5 basis points, to yield 7.37 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to yield 7.18 percent. In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Nov. 20.
''There has been a modest pickup in money growth since midyear,'' said Wayne Smith, an economist at Ried Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn. ''But at this point, I wouldn't say there is anything to get concerned about. Based on our forecasts, M-2 and M-3 will start 1990 at slightly above the midpoints of their tentative target ranges.''
From the fourth quarter of 1989 to the fourth quarter of 1990, M-2, which includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts, nonbank traveler's checks and accounts like savings deposits and money market mutual funds, is scheduled to grow between 3 percent and 7 percent. M-3, which is M-2 plus less liquid accounts like certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000, is scheduled to grow between 3.5 percent and 7.5 percent.
The money supply report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
 
Maryland Bank Offering
In the corporate bond market, the Chevy Chase Savings Bank, a Maryland institution, offered $450 million of extendable credit card trust securities in two parts through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The securities are backed by credit card receivables and a letter of credit from Credit Suisse.
The first part of the offering, $300 million of 1989-B class securities, have a four-year average life. The 8 3/4 percent securities were priced at 99.578, to yield 8.936 percent, 1.15 percentage points over the prevailing yield on four-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $150 million of 1989-C class securities have a three-year average life. The 8.60 percent securities were priced at 99.531, to yield 8.808 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the tax-exempt bond market, New York's Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority offered slightly more than $224 million worth of serial and term revenue bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Serial bonds carry maturities from 1991 to 2005, with yields ranging from 5.90 percent on the securities maturing in 1991 to 7 percent on the issues that mature in 2005.
Included among the several term bonds offered was an issue that matures in 2009. That issue was priced to yield 6.90 percent. The Triborough bonds are rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by S.&P.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues rose by an eighth to a quarter of a point. Municipal bond dealers said prices in their market moved higher by three-eighths to half a point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Lower; Gold Prices Rise in the U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower in light trading yesterday amid uncertainty about the nation's economy.
Gold prices rose in United States trading after slipping overseas. In New York, gold rose $2.10 an ounce, to $411.60, on the Commodity Exchange.
The dollar fell in response to a Commerce Department report that personal income rose nine-tenths of a percent in October and to rumors that purchasing executives in Chicago believe the economy is weakening, said Marc Chandler, a currency market analyst with MMS International in Chicago.
These developments ''didn't contradict the idea that the U.S. economy continued to slow down,'' Mr. Chandler said.
When the economy slows, financial markets expect the Federal Reserve to nudge interest rates lower. Declining rates make the dollar less attractive, and the dollar tends to fall when yields decline.
The dollar also slipped as traders who had taken profits against the West German mark in recent days began to rebuild their positions, Mr. Chandler said. The dollar fell to 1.7815 marks in New York, from 1.7875 late Wednesday.
 
Today's New Data Awaited
Volume was light, as many traders awaited two economic reports to be released today: the Government's index of leading indicators and the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly assessment of the economy.
''Right now, dollar sentiment is so poor, we really need some strong fundamental data in order for it to rally,'' Mr. Chandler said.
Overseas dealers said the dollar fell sharply late in the day on rumors that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, was resigning because of his one-time consulting role with the troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.
A Fed spokesman, Joe Coyne, said the rumors were ''absolutely not true,'' and the denial helped steady the dollar somewhat.

HEADLINE: Why Yalta Isn't a Dirty Word

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel, author of ''Walter Lippann and the American Century,'' is professor of international relations at the University of Southern California.

DATELINE: Los Angeles

 BODY:
''Never another Yalta,'' says the common wisdom.
The common wisdom is wrong. Another Yalta is needed, but this time it should be made to work. As George Bush prepares to meet Mikhail Gorbachev, he should ponder what was right about Yalta, and what he can learn from it. 
Today, Yalta - site of the 1945 conference where Roosevelt, Stalin and Churchill tried to shape postwar Europe - is a dirty word. It connotes U.S. naivete, Soviet duplicity and great power deals at the expense of the weak.
Few know what happened, except that it was bad and left Eastern Europe under Communism. The truth is more complicated. Yalta failed because the great powers lost sight of their true interests and bartered away victory in squabbling over spoils.
The Big Three met as the Nazis were on the verge of defeat. The outlines of a new structure had to be worked out if Europe was not to fall into anarchy. The great powers realized they could protect their own interests only by cooperating: This is the situation at Malta today. Two items dominated the agenda: Germany's future and Eastern Europe's political complexion. Sound familiar?
The U.S. and Britain visualized a Continent open to Western influence, but Stalin's hand was strong. The Soviet Union had carried the brunt of the war, suffering terrible casualties and damage. It fought for three years before U.S. and British forces landed, had pushed the Wehrmacht into Germany and was in command of most of Eastern Europe.
Roosevelt's options were limited. He could not force the Red Army out of Eastern Europe, needed Soviet cooperation in the occupation of Germany and wanted the Russians to enter the war against Japan.
Ever the realist, he negotiated a remarkably good compromise. Stalin agreed to fight Japan, to accept the smallest and poorest part of Germany as the Soviet occupation zone and to a vaguely worded formula for free elections in Eastern Europe.
The treaty was applauded across the political spectrum. For John Foster Dulles, later Dwight D. Eisenhower's Secretary of State, it opened a ''new era'' in which the U.S. ''abandoned a form of aloofness that it had been practicing for many years and the Soviet Union permitted joint action on matters it had the power to settle for itself.''
The accords on Germany and Japan were honored. The one on Eastern Europe broke down as Stalin imposed Communist dictatorships on countries under Soviet control. The wartime victors, instead of cooperating, raced to enlist their old enemies in a new conflict: The cold war was on. This was what Roosevelt had tried to avoid by acknowledging Soviet concerns in return for cooperation in building an open Europe.
Today, the Soviets are dismantling their empire, shedding their ideology and eagerly seeking good relations with the West. The former satellites are experimenting with democracy. The Continent is knitting itself back together, and Germany, again Europe's economic powerhouse, is swiftly bridging its partition. Yet, the two great problems of 1945 remain unresolved: What to do about Germany and Eastern Europe? And how to protect the interests of the superpowers?
The creation of a single German state will change the European balance of power and sharply reduce the influence of the U.S. and Soviet Union. Eastern Europe will not necessarily become pacific and democratic. It has long been in a political deep freeze, cut off from modernization and democratization; old ethnic and tribal hatred, feuds over religion and frontiers, are erupting.
The end of the cold war does not mean the triumph of reason and brotherhood in Europe. Americans and Russians have earned a voice in the coming settlement.
For this reason, Malta should represent a return to Yalta - the Yalta where the great powers were driven to compromise and cooperation by a recognition of common interests. Yalta's purpose was to plan for the future. Because that plan failed does not make the need any less important this time around.

LENGTH: 1651 words

HEADLINE: Public Pension Funds Tempt States in Need

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The State Treasurer, Catherine Baker Knoll, sees Pennsylvania as a state with a fragile economy and a public pension fund that is bulging with $25 billion. To help the economy, she wants the fund's managers to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in local real estate, state highways and bridges and new businesses, especially those started by women and members of minorities.
Her proposals, now the subject of public hearings, are part of a rising national debate about the wisdom of investing public pension money to promote social goals.
At a time when most politicians are wary of raising taxes, the lure of the $700 billion stashed away in the pension funds for state and municipal employees and teachers is seductive indeed. And the amount of money, which stood at $210 billion in 1979, is growing rapidly. It parallels a surge in private pension funds that is a result of the bulge in the work force created by the baby boom generation. 
A Ford Foundation study made public last week provided the first comprehensive look at social investment programs by public pension funds. In studying 99 of the nation's largest pension funds with assets totaling $509 billion, it found that 41 had committed $7.2 billion to 78 social investment programs. The report did not spell out what investments had been made and what their rate of return was.
Most of the investments from public pension funds to advance social goals have been a result of political pressure. But now a growing number of officials are seeking laws that would mandate such investments.
At the heart of the debate about such laws is a basic question: Will beneficiaries of these funds be hurt if state and local governments require investments of their money to promote public policy goals?
One opponent of such investments, Richard C. Rowland, executive director of the Pennsylvania Association of School Retirees, said, ''I question the propriety of using the funds for those social purposes and question how it could be done without sacrificing benefits and jeopardizing earnings.''
But others say the investments need not be riskier than other strategies, which are usually to invest in bonds or stocks.
''As long as the investments are sound, you can do good things,'' said Karen Ferguson, an advocate for pensioners and executive director of the Pension Rights Center in Washington.
Supporters of social investments also argue that taxpayers ought to have some control over how public pension money is invested since public workers' retirement systems are supported by tax revenue.
Public pension funds provide retirement income for public workers -from teachers in local districts to bureaucrats in state capitals. They are governed by state laws generally modeled on the Federal law regulating private pension funds.
That law, the Employment Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, protects employee pension rights through standards for the conduct of plan trustees and asset managers who are required to invest pension funds prudently and ''solely in the interest'' of plan participants and beneficiaries.
 
Investing in Connecticut
A strong advocate of social investment of public pension money is Francisco L. Borges, Treasurer of Connecticut, a member of the advisory committee that helped devise the Ford Foundation's survey. As the state's sole trustee responsible for investing $8 billion in public pension money for state employees and teachers, he put $94 million into what he called a ''very sound'' downtown Hartford office project, Goodwin Square, that is scheduled for completion next month. The project is 60 percent leased and the projected rate of return is 12 percent, but could be twice that amount if the project does well.
Six months after taking office, in July 1987, he also committed $200 million to new companies, including a $20 million investment in new ones in Connecticut that compost autumn leaves and operate vans providing low-cost mammography examinations for women. Mr. Borges said it was impossible to speculate on what return would be provided by this investment of venture capital, intended to stimulate the growth of jobs.
''I am excited about the opportunity to invest in Connecticut,'' he said.
Others say that investing too heavily in a single state makes a pension fund vulnerable to a regional or local recession.
 
Alaska's Real Estate Collapse
Alaska provides a case in point.
To promote home ownership there, the state's two public pension funds invested $263.1 million, or 36 percent of their total assets of $718.6 million, in residential mortgages by 1980, said Milton B. Barker, who, as the state's Deputy Commissioner of Revenue, supervises the Alaska Public Employees' Retirement System and the Alaska Teachers' Retirement System. ''It was considered a prudent investment at the time,'' he said.
But when oil prices collapsed a few years ago, so did Alaska's real estate market. Mr. Barker said a third of Alaskan real estate loans are now delinquent and 14.6 percent have been foreclosed, a failure that cost the retirement systems millions of dollars.
Despite such cautionary tales, interest in the idea continues, particularly as lawmakers in 33 states debated and passed laws in recent years that prohibited using pension money in South Africa, said Carolyn Mathiasen, director of social issues at the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a nonprofit group that advises pension officials.
The idea of using private and public pension funds for social investments that pay competitive returns was popularized in a 1978 book, ''The North Will Rise Again'' by Randy Barber and Jeremy Rifkin. The book urges workers to demand a say in investment decisions; its title refers to the authors' thesis that union pension funds from Northern states have been invested in nonunion factories and service businesses elsewhere, particularly in the South.
 
Aid for New York City
One of the earliest social investments by public pension funds occurred in New York City during its fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's. Municipal and teacher pension funds invested hundreds of millions of dollars in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds and saved the city from bankruptcy, said Carol O'Cleireacain, chief economist of the city's largest union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
''It was a revolutionary investment and changed forever the way we looked at pension investing,'' she said. The bonds were high-risk investments, but had correspondingly high rates of return, she said.
Mr. Barber, director of the Center for Economic Organizing, which advises unions on financial matters, said, ''The basic idea is to take the capital that has been drawn from an area and reinvest it in that area to promote its future economic well-being.''
In 1988, the Rev. Jesse Jackson picked up the social investment idea in his Presidential campaign, with this added twist: a proposal that the Federal Government insure the safety of money invested by public pension funds in projects intended to benefit the public.
One of the most far-reaching proposals for social pension investments was made in New York in June. A task force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo recommended that the state's three public pension funds, which have more than $100 billion in assets, should invest more heavily in local projects, including new state roads and prisons.
 
Private Funds Do Better
While figures comparing the rates of return on investments in public and private funds are not available, pension specialists say that private funds have generally outperformed public funds. That is because private funds have tended to invest more heavily in stocks while public funds have favored bonds; over the long haul, stocks have provided much greater returns because greater risk is involved.
The author of the Ford Foundation study, James P. Love, a senior economist with Russel-Zisler, a research subsidiary of the Frank Russell Company, the nation's largest pension fund consultant, said in an interview that pension fund managers were ''frightened and troubled'' by political pressure to make unconventional investments.
 
In General, Satisfaction
''The moment you add a social objective, like creating jobs or encouraging home ownership, it becomes difficult for anyone to know how well the fund is doing,'' Mr. Love said. ''You can put a dollar value on social objectives, but it requires highly subjective judgments.''
The study found that pension managers were unable to measure the social benefits of their investments in terms like creating jobs or building housing and could not yet evaluate the financial performance of more than half of their social investments.
While fund managers are required by law to make periodic reports on their fund's performance, they often cannot give much indication of the performance of some long-term investments like new businesses; in these cases, the funds usually list the amount of their investment or its book value.
Pension officials said in the study that they were satisfied or very satisfied with most of their social investments; the questionnaire did not ask them to explain their reasons in cases in which they were dissatisfied. But Mr. Love noted that the managers also reported that they were planning to expand only seven of their current programs.
In most states, laws would have to be passed to require the managers of public pension money to consider social goals in making investment decisions.
In Pennsylvania, where such a law is being discussed, Mrs. Knoll, the State Treasurer, wants the three public pension funds to shift $400 million in overseas investment back to Pennsylvania and to a half-dozen other states, where state treasurers have agreed to urge their own pension officials to buy real estate in Pennsylvania on a reciprocal basis.

HEADLINE: AQUINO'S FORCES SEEM TO PREVAIL IN MANILA BATTLE

BYLINE: By SHEILA CORONEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Saturday, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Forces loyal to President Corazon C. Aquino appeared to be turning back an army rebellion today after seizing rebel-held military camps and television stations with the aid of American warplanes.
As Philippine Government warplanes attacked what appeared to be the last remnants of the rebellion near two military camps in Manila, President Aquino said today she would not negotiate with rebel forces.
''We leave them with two choices, to surrender or die,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement she read on television 36 hours after rebel troops began their attempt to overthrow the Government.
She vowed to bring to justice the officers and soldiers who took part in the coup attempt as well as civilians who supported it.
Calling them ''treacherous cowards,'' she named 16 officers, including a Navy commander and an air force general, who she said had participated in the mutiny. 
 
Turning Point
After earlier coup attempts, the Government had pardoned some rebel officers, but this time, Mrs. Aquino said, ''The Constitution shall not be perverted to shield those who wish to destroy it.''
The turning point in the rebellion apparently came late Friday when, in a show of force ordered by President Bush at the request of President Aquino, United States F-4 Phantom jets flew air cover, preventing rebel pilots from continuing attacks on Government installations and troops. Rebel troops then withdrew from the television stations they held and from Villamor Air Force Base.
But rebel soldiers marched with armored vehicles through the night toward Camp Aguinaldo, the armed forces headquarters about five miles away. Inexplicably, the rebels were not stopped by Government troops. Other rebels were reportedly holding out near Camp Bonifacio.
According to officials, the rebel forces numbered around 300 today; earlier estimates had placed their number at from 500 to several thousand. About 2,000 Government troops were massed against the rebels in the vicinity of Camp Aguinaldo.
By dawn today, fighting had resumed, with Government troops firing at rebel positions in the densely populated area of Camp Aguinaldo.
In one incident, Philippine warplanes hit pro-Government troops and civilians, killing at least 6 people and wounding 20, military officials said.
Defense Secretary Fidel V. Ramos described the incident as ''one of those things that happens in a situation like this.''
''We thought the planes were friendly, but they fired at us,'' said Brig. Gen. Thelmo Cunanan, commander of the Government force. He said the attack also destroyed nine jeeps and an ammunition truck.
 
Rebels March Toward Camp
The military also said today that it had arrested of one of the coup leaders, Lieut. Col. Tito Legazpi, as he was en route today to Bataan to recruit followers for further attacks against the Government.
The officer is a close associate of Gregorio B. Honasan, the cashiered officer who led the last major military coup attempt in the Philippines, in August 1987, and who the authorities believe is the principal leader of this one. The fugitive Colonel Legazpi had been sought for his role in the 1987 rebellion as well.
In almost two days of fighting, the casualty toll rose to at least 28 people killed and 87 wounded, mostly civilians. The toll was lower than that of the 1987 rebllion, in which 53 people died. But this coup attempt is viewed as the most serious against President Aquino because the scope of the two days of fighting, which included the bombing of the presidential palace and other Government installations, represented a marked heightening in the level of violence.
 
U.S. Provide Air Cover
Late Friday, the United States ordered two F-4 Phantom jets from Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila, to fly to the capital district to provide air cover for Government forces trying to dislodge rebel soldiers holding out at Villamor and at Sangley naval base in Cavite province, south of Manila. The American planes did not fire on the rebels.
The United States intervention apparently came as a shock to the rebels and caused significant disruption in their operations, according to sympathizers in Manila familiar with the rebel camp's operation.
Mrs. Aquino, in a statement from the presidential palace on Friday night, said she had requested the American support because loyal troops lacked the ability to contain the rebels. ''The enemy is routed,'' she said, ''but is not yet vanquished.''
Defense Secretary Ramos said American military support, requested by President Aquino at the behest of her military commanders, ''spelled the inevitable defeat of the rebels.''
Mr. Ramos described the American offer of help as a ''blank check.'' In addition to the F-4 Phantom jets, the United States flew in about 120 marines to strengthen security at the American Embassy compound overlooking Manila Bay. Although there were reports that the United States had offered to send in troops from its bases in Okinawa and Hawaii, it was not clear whether in fact Washington was prepared to commit ground forces to suppress the revolt.
A spokesman for the rebels said, however, that the decision by the United States to send in warplanes was an affront to Philippine sovereignty and that the rebels would hold the United States Ambassador, Nicholas Platt, personally responsible for the intervention.
The United States presence here is a contentious issue, with many Filipinos demanding the removal of American bases, so the American intervention appeared certain to cause further political problems for Mrs. Aquino.
 
Dissatisfaction Widespread
The attempted coup, which began late Thursday night, came at a time of public dissatisfaction over increasing economic hardships, a breakdown of public services and allegations of increasing corruption in the Government and among some of Mrs. Aquino's family and friends. Mrs. Aquino's popularity, which had shielded her from criticism, has slipped badly lately, and even some of her former supporters in the press and public service have turned against her.
''The rebels were taking advantage of legitimate grievances that people identified with,'' said Carolina Hernandez, a political scientist who has studied the Philippine military. ''But they misread the popular pulse. The dissatisfaction was not so much with democracy as it was the slow process of democratization.''
Military officers said Mr. Honasan, 42 years old, a charismatic former colonel who played a major role in the military-led uprising that installed Mrs. Aquino as President after the ouster of Ferdinand E. Marcos, is the leader of the coup attempt.
They said that Mr. Honasan, who was stripped of his rank and thrown out of the armed forces after the 1987 coup attempt, wanted to establish a junta but that the nature and composition of such a junta remained unclear.
Rebel sympathizers and associates said Mr. Honasan was one of the major figures in the revolt but not necessarily its leader. They also said a civilian-military junta figured in the rebel plans, with elections for president planned for a year after the junta's takeover.
Still, neither Mr. Honasan nor any other rebel figure came forward to issue a statement.
At the height of the revolt, the rebels seized two military camps, the Government broadcasting compound, the domestic airport and the Ninoy Aquino International Airport, which was closed to all flights. But by late Friday, with the introduction of American warplanes, the rebel troops abandoned the Government broadcasting station, the Villamor base and other strongholds.

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
The Soldiers in Europe's House

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE

 BODY:
By encouraging independence in Eastern Europe and withholding Soviet support for Tiananmen-style crackdowns, Mikhail Gorbachev gives preliminary shape to the political and economic arrangements he has in mind for a ''common European home.'' His ideas for the military arrangements -which he might discuss this weekend with President Bush - can only be guessed at, but there are some clear principles to keep in mind.
One is that the West German Army, if it should ever be combined with the East German Army, would add up to a number no one else will welcome. 
Another is that even after major reductions and withdrawal from Europe, Soviet forces would still threaten to overshadow other European armies. The Soviet Union, however friendly a neighbor, would thus be unlikely to be invited inside the European home.
A third principle is that some Soviet troops will probably have to stay in Germany, and be counterbalanced, in turn, by continuing American forces in Europe.
If Comecon, the Eastern bloc's economic group, seeks to join in the march toward European integration, NATO and the Warsaw Pact would also draw closer. Since each is the other's chief reason for existence, lessened tensions would lead to sharp mutual reductions. Bloc countries with large Soviet garrisons might well wish to be free of them; Hungarian delegates to the conventional forces talks at Vienna have already indicated as much.
But with Soviet garrisons withdrawn, East and West Germany together would possess the largest army in Europe. As the price for being allowed some form of political union, the two Germanys might be willing to accept some degree of continued occupation. A reduced Soviet garrison in East Germany would give the Soviet Union its guarantee against German revanchism. In symmetry, an American force would remain in West Germany giving other West Europeans their guarantee.
Such an equilibrium would provide the stability under which East and West could gradually disarm. Another military consideration will then loom large. For many years, the Soviet Union will need large forces to maintain order among its turbulent nationalities. Without restraint from Moscow, the band of southern republics from Georgia to Uzbekistan could dissolve into ethnic strife and chaos. However legitimate Moscow's need for a large army, European nations will not invite such a colossus into their common home.
So what does Mr. Gorbachev mean by the phrase? Some Soviet intellectuals interpret it literally, as the return to a single European civilization. ''The common European home means decomposition of the empire, in our own interest,'' says Andranik Migranyan, an analyst at a Moscow think tank.
There is no evidence that Mr. Gorbachev himself intends to go that far. But he is a radical reformist, even if not a revolutionary. It could be he foresees a day when the Soviet Union becomes a looser federation of republics, nationalist tensions are thereby relieved and far fewer troops are required to maintain order. Such a transformation would surely improve his chances of stepping from neighbor to resident of the European house.
To modernize his economy, Mr. Gorbachev needs credits and technology. His European home may still be just a castle in the air. But it is easy to share his general notion: The more walls he tears down within his domain, the more he can hope to share in the West's prosperity.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Port Authority Proposes $1 Increase in Tolls

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
The chief of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that he was recommending a $1 toll increase on all six of its bridges and tunnels and a 25-cent fare rise on PATH, the underground commuter rail system.
The surprise announcement by Stephen Berger, the Port Authority's executive director, came despite earlier assurances that the last toll and fare increase, in 1987, had been large enough to avoid any new ones until well into 1991.
The increases would go into effect on the crossings in April and on PATH in December 1990, Mr. Berger said. They would be used to close a Port Authority deficit that he said was likely to grow to $94 million, from the present $57 million, by the end of next year. 
The proposal came a day after the Taxi and Limousine Commission approved an 11.5 percent increase in yellow cab fares and as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority weighed its own planned fare-increase of at least 15 percent for buses, subways and commuter rail lines.
In July, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, an M.T.A. agency, imposed a 25 percent toll increase for its six major bridges and two tunnels.
Under Mr. Berger's proposal, roundtrip tolls would rise on April 1 to $4 a car from $3 on the George Washington, Bayonne and Goethals Bridges, the Outerbridge Crossing and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels.
The cost of a discounted package good for 20 roundtrip crossings would rise to $60 from $40.
Truck drivers, who now pay $3 an axle to use the crossings, would have to pay $4 an axle.
The new PATH fare, which would go into effect on Dec. 16, 1990, would rise to $1.25 from $1, while discounts would be offered for the elderly and those buying multitrip tickets. It would coincide with the installation of automated fare machines on the 80-year-old rail line.
Mr. Berger, calling his proposal ''a difficult decision,'' attributed much of the Port Authority's deficit to lower-than-expected revenues on the six crossings and PATH. He said the deficit was a direct consequence of the slowdown in the region's economy.
''In 1986,'' he told the Port Authority board in a letter dated Thursday, ''we projected total network revenues for 1989 at $503 million; today we expect this year's revenues to total $462 million.''
The economic downturn has been so far-reaching, he said, that it has even caused a $49 million drop in projected 1989 revenues at the World Trade Center and Kennedy International, La Guardia and Newark International Airports. Their income has been historically used to subsidize PATH and the bridge and tunnel crossings.
He also cited rising operating and maintenance expenses, especially on the heavily subsidized PATH system and the midtown Manhattan bus terminal, and a $1.3 billion capital spending program for 1990 that he said was vital to the agency's solvency.
Also, Mr. Berger said, over the last four years the Port Authority had absorbed ''over $100 million in additional expenses that we did not contemplate.''
 
No Government Subsidies
He said these included $15 million in programs to deal with the homeless; $50 million to remove cancer-causing asbestos from Port Authority properties, and substantial sums to pay for items like increased health costs, expenses associated with labor strikes and the replacement of defective rivets on bridges.
Mr. Berger noted that while PATH's 1989 operating deficit has already reached $106 million, it is ''virtually alone among urban rail transport systems in this country'' in not receiving Federal, state or local government subsidies.
''I think this will help cover us, but how long I cannot guarantee,'' Mr. Berger told a news conference at Port Authority headquarters at No. 1 World Trade Center in Manhattan.
The 12-member Port Authority board is to discuss and probably vote on the proposal Dec. 14. Public hearings would be scheduled later.
 
Governors Could Veto
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, each of whom have veto power in such matters, would have 10 business days after any board decision to respond. If the board does not render a decision until after Mr. Kean leaves office, the matter would fall to his successor, Governor-elect James J. Florio.
If approved, the toll increase would be only the Port Authority's fourth since 1927; the fare increase would be PATH's fourth since 1967.
The proposal was disclosed during Mr. Berger's presentation of the agency's 1990 budget, which calls for the spending of $2.9 billion. Of that, $1.3 billion would be for capital projects. Mr. Berger said the figure is the highest one-year total for capital spending in the Port Authority's 68-year history.
Among the more than 100 capital programs in the budget, Mr. Berger said, are major rehabilitation of bridges, tunnels and the PATH system; new construction at Kennedy International, La Guardia and Newark International Airports; work on a new Hoboken-to-Manhattan ferry; waterfront development in Hoboken, N.J., and in Hunters Point, Queens, and port improvements in Brooklyn, Staten Island and Port Newark/Elizabeth.

HEADLINE: The New Rush Hours: All Day Saturday

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARAMUS, N.J.

 BODY:
More and more, drivers encounter the worst traffic congestion not during commuters' rush hours but on Saturdays, the day for errands and shopping.
In New Jersey, where roads are among the most heavily traveled in the nation and malls and shopping strips abound, traffic congestion on Saturdays is expected to exceed that of the evening rush in the next few years.
''What we're going to begin seeing is Saturday shopping traffic equaling or surpassing rush-hour traffic,'' said New Jersey's assistant transportation commissioner, James Crawford. ''It is not a universal case now. It is something we do see in certain periods of the year in certain key places.'' 
Traffic officials and urban planners say Saturday congestion is worsening from increases in two-income families whose schedules leave little time but Saturday to shop and do errands; in shopping malls, with more being clustered together, and in the number of cars.
''This is not just a New Jersey or regional phenomenon,'' said James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University. ''It's a national phenomenon.''
In Texas and New York State, for example, some traffic experts have noted the trend, although others - in Connecticut and in counties with major shopping centers like Westchester and Nassau in New York, Fairfax in Virginia and Orange in California -say the evening rush hour continues to be the peak period. They say Saturday is the major shopping day.
Experts point out, however, that studies have tended to focus on the traditional weekday rush hour traffic, which usually peaks in the evening when commuters share roads with shoppers. Comparisons with Saturday traffic, which is usually heavy from late morning to early evening, have been rare, they said. As a result, said Thomas W. Casey, director of the division of transit planning and management for the Bergen County Department of Planning and Economic Development, the growth of Saturday congestion is something that has yet to be studied.
Paramus, with its five major shopping malls within a five-mile radius, ''is the classic one at Christmas time,'' he added.
On the Saturday after Thanksgiving, as shoppers searched 15 minutes or more for a parking place at the packed 1.6 million-square-foot Garden State Plaza here, one shopper, Fred Lorestani of Teaneck, said he was well acquainted with Saturday congestion.
 
Rise Across State
Some Saturdays, he said, it took him twice the time to travel a section of Route 4 on a shopping outing than it did in the morning going to work.
George Kuziw, manager of transportation data development for the New Jersey Department of Transportation, said comparative counts show that Saturday traffic in certain periods now exceeds weekday rush-hour traffic in some parts of the state and approaches it in others.
On Route 9 near Route 1 in the Woodbridge Center area, for example, there were 200 more cars in the northbound lanes during a peak hour on Saturday: 2,406 between 3 and 4 P.M., compared with 2,206 between a peak weekday hour of 3 to 4 P.M., Mr. Kuziw said.
Route 202/31 northbound, the main artery to a cluster of name-brand discount outlets in Flemington, had 251 more cars: 1,243 between 3 and 4 P.M. on a Saturday compared with 992 between 4 and 5 P.M. on a weekday.
 
Traffic in Houston
Route 3 east in Clifton, several miles from the discount outlets in Secaucus, had Saturday traffic almost equal to that of the evening rush hour, 4,377 between 5 and 6 P.M. on weekdays and 4,319 between 6 and 7 P.M. on Saturday.
Stephen Ha, a signal engineer for the Houston Department of Traffic and Transportation, said he believed Saturday congestion was almost equal to rush hour congestion near the Galleria, a 3.3-million-square-foot mall. The main road to the mall, Westheimer, carries up to 80,000 cars on peak weekday periods, he said, but Saturday traffic approaches that.
David Simchi-Levi, an assistant professor of industrial engineering at Columbia University, and his wife, Edith, a program analyst, and their two young daughters, drove from Manhattan on a recent Saturday to Garden State Plaza here.
The Simchi-Levis said they and their Manhattan friends regularly shop at the Plaza, which was built in 1957 as the first mall in the state, as well as at other Paramus malls. ''If the weather is nice, we go on a trip and then may go shopping,'' said Mrs. Simchi-Levi, ''but if it's not pleasant, we just go shopping.''
 
Women in Labor Force
Robert A. Weant, vice president of technical services at the Eno Foundation of Transportation Inc. in Westport, Conn., said the great infusion of women into the job market changed commuting and shopping patterns.
The foundation's 1987 report, ''Commuting in America,'' noted that since 1950, 30 million of 50 million entrants into the labor force have been women; in 1950, women accounted for 28 percent of the labor force, but they now exceed 44 percent.
Ira S. Lowry, a housing and development consultant from Pacific Palisades, Calif., wrote in a 1988 report to the Transportation Research Board that daily trips for family and personal errands and for social or recreational trips exceeded daily work trips.
The International Council of Shopping Centers said there are 32,563 shopping centers nationally, including 1,269 in New York, 736 in New Jersey and 566 in Connecticut.
 
Traffic Spreads Out
''You're now seeing malls across the street from malls,'' said Commissioner Crawford. ''Each of those has to draw a certain volume of traffic to be successful, and that traffic is all auto.''
But Lieut. Eric Kremer, head of the traffic unit of the Paramus police, said traffic congestion in the early 1970's was worse when there were fewer malls in town. With more malls here and in the area, traffic is more spread out.
The population of 30,000 in this 10.5-mile-square borough expands to 200,000 on weekdays and 300,000 on Saturdays. On Sundays, however, the Paramus malls are closed by municipal ordinance. Some store owners complain that the Sunday closing law aggravates the Saturday congestion.
Mr. Weant said congestion was also caused by an increase in cars and drivers: The number of drivers grew from 43 million in 1960 to 83 million in 1980; two-vehicle households grew by 172 percent, and three-vehicle households by almost 1,000 percent.
In New Jersey, car registrations increased 40 percent between 1980 and 1986, Commissioner Crawford said.
If Saturday congestion continues to get worse, as he predicts, ''It probably means we will begin seeing more pressures for either extended hours for shopping. Or we're going to see people putting up with levels of congestion on the weekend that they now put up with as they travel to their jobs.''

GRAPHIC: Traffic congestion on Saturdays sometimes exceeds that of evening rush hours in New Jersey where shopping areas abound. HEADLINE: A $1.15 Token Now Supported By Transit Staff

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
The staff of the New York City Transit Authority has revised a plan on subway and bus fares and is now proposing that the agency raise the price of a token to $1.15 from $1, but without offering discounts on bulk sales, a spokesman said last night.
The new plan, an alternative to the Transit Authority's original proposal of a $1.25 single fare - or 18 tokens for $20 - also calls for raising the fare for the elderly by a nickel, to 55 cents.
Before it is formally adopted, the new plan must be reviewed by the Transit Authority board on Thursday and the finance committee of the authority's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, on Dec. 11. It will then be forwarded to the full M.T.A. board, which has scheduled a vote on the fare question for Dec. 15. 
''But that is definitely the direction we are moving toward,'' said the M.T.A.'s chief spokesman, John Cunningham.
 
Original Plan Sharply Criticized
The spokesman said the new plan was worked out among M.T.A. and Transit Authority officials this week after politicians and the public had sharply criticized the original proposal.
The revised plan would also raise the price of one-way fares on express buses, currently $3.50, to $4.60, a 31.4 percent increase. The Transit Authority had originally proposed a 43 percent increase, to $5, which stirred outcries, especially from Staten Island riders.
Under the new plan, express bus riders could buy tickets in bulk for $3.75, by purchasing either a monthly pass for $150 or a two-week pass for $75.
The M.T.A. spokesman said the decision to eliminate discount subway and bus fares was the result of calculations by Transit Authority economists, who found that the agency would lose money if it offered discounts on tokens priced lower than $1.25.
 
Discounts Called Money Losers
Some advocates of lower fares had proposed a $1.15 fare and 9 tokens for $10. But the Transit Authority concluded it would lose $24 million in potential revenue.
Another suggestion - a $1.15 fare and 10 tokens for $11 - would cost the agency ''closer to $30 million to $50 million,'' Mr. Cunningham said.
While the Transit Authority acknowledged that a new fare of $1.15 had been agreed upon in 1987, after the Governor and the Legislature approved a five-year, $8.5 billion financing plan, they said a $1.25 plan was preferable because it involved only one additional coin. The two coins required in a $1.15 fare, authority officials insist, will create long lines at token booths and create more jammed fare boxes on buses.

HEADLINE: Anniversary Tribute to Neediest Cases Fund

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
In December 1939, Alfred I. Jaffe paid $2 for a license to marry Mimi Muschat. ''Several years ago, I decided to make my annual contribution a tribute to my wife on our anniversary,'' Mr. Jaffe, who now lives in Somers, N.Y., wrote to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I donated $2 for every year we were married, the $2 representing the original cost of our license.'' 
Today a marriage license in Philadelphia, where the Jaffes were married on Christmas Eve half a century ago, costs $13, and Mr. Jaffe's gift has kept pace with inflation.
''We've been fortunate in having good health for a couple of septuagenarians,'' Mr. Jaffe said, ''and we're thankful that millions of people in central Europe are beginning to breathe a bit of the air of freedom that we take for granted. Accordingly I'm happy to donate $500 this year in honor of Mimi Jaffe to help relieve poverty here at home.''
Family considerations were paramount to many who contributed to the 78th annual campaign during its first week. Three brothers, Roger Strong Jr. of Manhattan, Jeffrey Strong of Brooklyn and Thomas Strong of Columbia, S.C., sent $250. Roger Strong called it ''a significant gift to honor our grandmother's 85th birthday.''
''She has cared about us for a long, long time,'' Mr. Strong wrote. Their grandmother, whose birthday is Monday, is Marguerite G. Strong of Manhattan.
Reversing intergenerational honors, Martin and Mildred Weissburg of Southbury, Conn., who donated $50, wrote: ''This contribution is in honor of our granddaughter's 25th birthday! Pamela Altman born Dec. 17, 1964! Given with love.'' Few letters conveyed the spirit of the campaign quite as eloquently as the one from Eli Fogel of Long Island City, Queens, who wrote: ''I would like to commend The New York Times for giving me the opportunity to show my concern and care for people less fortunate than me. It makes one feel good to be able to share in helping people who are down and really need help from all of us.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1989

 BODY:

 
 
Markets
 Directors of the Securities Industry Association voted to drop the group's decade-long opposition to allowing banks to enter the securities business - a move that could lead to significant changes on Wall Street. The S.I.A. has spent millions of dollars to fight any attempt to weaken the Glass-Steagall Act, which was intended to keep commercial banks out of the securities business. [Page 33.] Stocks made their biggest gain in weeks, as institutions and foreigners bought heavily. The Dow Jones industrials soared 41.38 points, or 1.53 percent, to 2,747.65, the 10th-highest close ever. For the week, the average climbed 72.10 points, or 2.69 percent. [33.] Prices of Treasury securities rose only modestly in light trading. Dealers said that declines in the index of leading economic indicators and in the purchasing managers' monthly report had been expected and that the market was continuing to wait for further signals from the Fed on interest rates. [36.] The dollar made some gains against other currencies, as traders appeared to buy dollars as a hedge against any announcements from the Soviet-American summit meeting that could affect the market. Gold rose $2 an ounce on the Comex, to $413.60. [42.] Prices of energy futures rose sharply. Heating oil jumped more than 5 percent in the last three trading days of the week. [42.] 
 
 
 
The Economy
 The index of leading indicators fell 0.4 percent in October, in another sign that the economy is slackening. Although it was the fifth decline this year, many analysts say they see no end to a seven-year expansion. [33.] The economy continued to deteriorate in November for the seventh consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said. The purchasing managers said the index was affected by drops in production, new orders and employment. [34.] Construction spending rose a modest 1 percent in October, bolstered by the first gain in single-family home building in nine months. Analysts said the improvement suggested lower interest rates were helping to end a slump in construction. [34.] The assets of savings and loan institutions continued to shrink significantly in September in preparation for tough financial standards that take effect next week. Assets at the nation's 2,903 savings institutions fell by $15.2 billion, breaking the record set in August of $13.3 billion, the Office of Thrift Supervision said. [33.] Pennsylvania's State Treasurer wants to invest public pension money in state projects, amid a rising debate about the wisdom of investing pension funds to promote social goals. [1.]

The firm will also raise the minimum that current investors must maintain in these accounts to $1,000, from $500. [37.] A host of unexpected start-up problems have delayed the date by which Nucor is scheduled to reach capacity production at its advanced Indiana steel mill. [33.] Lear Jet is scouting for potential buyers again, since Chrysler decided not to acquire the manufacturer of business jets. Others said to be interested in Lear Jet are British Aerospace and Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. [35.] Pacificorp offered to buy all of Pinnacle West, which had rebuffed its offer to buy one utility. HEADLINE: Innovative Steel Mill Is Off to a Slow Start

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
These should have been heady days for F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman of the Nucor Corporation and a man celebrated for teaching Big Steel a thing or two about operating mills more efficiently.
Three months ago in Indiana, Nucor opened the first mill to apply the most significant technological development in the industry in 20 years - the low-cost production of very thin sheets of flat-rolled steel that can ultimately be used in the hotly competitive automobile and appliance industry. By now the plant, the latest of the mini-mills pioneered by Nucor, was to have been well on its way to threatening the nation's large steel producers.
Instead, Mr. Iverson is wrestling with a host of unexpected start-up problems that have pushed back for at least two quarters, until the end of next year, the date when the mill is scheduled to reach capacity production. Mechanical and technical difficulties have sent planners back to the drawing board more than once to revise the process. Meanwhile, losses at the plant have mounted, to about $1 million each week, and the figure of $30 million in projected start-up costs for the mill this year has already climbed to nearly $48 million. And the company's stock, which traded in the mid- to upper 60's in September, has retreated. The stock rose $1.25 yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, to $60.50. 
There are more than a few doubters. ''This thing has never been done,'' said the chairman of a major steel company who asked not to be named. ''It's not clear if the process will be able to produce the quality that customers will want or if it can operate with consistency.''
Many in the industry point to the plant's initial problems as evidence that the mill will not have much effect on the steel industry anytime soon. Moreover, bigger steel producers say that their costs have plunged over the last five years to a point at which they will remain competitive in quality and cost. ''At first it seemed like Nucor would have a real cost advantage over us,'' the steel company chairman said. ''But if that happens at all, it will still be some time from now.''
But most in the steel industry still expect the Nucor plant to succeed ultimately, although they say it will be several years before any products made in the Crawfordsville, Ind., mill will be competitive. ''To make their product fully competitive in the marketplace will surely take 5 to 10 years,'' said Roger P. Penny, senior vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel producer. ''There will be a longer learning curve than they expected.''
From the outset the new Nucor plant, built in a rural stretch about 35 miles northwest of Indianapolis, has been a bold gamble for a company noted for going against the grain of established operating practices of American steel companies. While the large steel mills were expanding in the 1970's, Mr. Iverson churned out strong profits through small mills that make steel from scrap metal, using nonunion employees who work under rules considered extremely flexible by American steel industry standards.
''Did things turn out to be more difficult than we expected?'' Mr. Iverson asked in a recent interview on the Indiana mill. ''Well, I think one's expectations of a situation are always higher than what occurs.''
 
Assault on Big Steel
 Nucor, based in Charlotte, N.C., is already the nation's largest mini-mill, a category that describes the second-tier steel companies known for making low-grade products for the construction industry. The plant in Indiana represents an assault on the mainstay of the big steel producers, the flat-rolled steel business, a $13 billion market that amounts to nearly two-thirds of Big Steel's revenues.
The thin-slab technology has been the talk of the industry ever since Nucor announced three years ago that it would be the first to produce steel under that method. It is still the only American company to use the method; other companies have waited to see how Nucor fares.
Developed by SMS Schlomann of West Germany, the process is designed to use less expensive scrap steel, as opposed to the ingots used by other steelmakers, to form molten steel into slabs much thinner than conventional casters produce. The slabs will be two inches thick, compared with the 10 inches from casters operated by large, integrated mills.
 
Much Thinner Slabs
 The slabs are flattened into steel sheets one-tenth of an inch thick. Because Nucor's slabs are so much thinner than other companies', the flattening of the sheets to their final thickness requires much less energy, manpower and wasted material. Nucor says five workers will be able to do what it takes more than 30 to do at most steel companies.
But skeptics question whether the final product from the Nucor process will be as durable as products from the existing process, and whether the process is reliable enough to avoid costly interruptions. Mr. Iverson expected to have answered the naysayers by now by having more of the thin-slab caster's products in the hands of steel customers. But the Crawfordsville plant produced just 6,000 tons of steel in September and October, about half of what Mr. Iverson expected. He hopes to produce 12,000 tons of sheet steel in December, still less than half the mill's break-even rate.
An important reason for the disappointing output is a number of mechanical and electrical problems at a plant that must operate with 96 percent reliability to be effective. An initial difficulty was controling the temperature of the molten steel, a problem that was ultimately solved by injecting argon through the heating ladle. There have also been problems with the nozzle that guides the molten steel into the mold having to be changed after every 250 tons of production, half the expected life span.
 
Devastating Problems
 Ordinarily, such problems would not be particularly devastating. But the Nucor caster operates as a single unit, unlike the series of stations in a typical large steel mill. As a result, the entire production line must shut down if any one function fails.
Nonetheless, Mr. Iverson remains confident that the difficulties are temporary and that the casting technology will be perfected by the end of next year. He said none of the mill's problems have ''indicated that the concept is at all unrealistic.''
''Actually, it hasn't been more difficult than what you'd expect with a new process of this type,'' Mr. Iverson said. ''Most of what we've gone through is nothing more than the normal array of start-up problems. But the difference is that our situation is exacerbated by the fact that this is a completely new process.''
 
In the Long Run
 Many in the industry agree. ''They are having a number of problems but it's going to work out in the long run,'' said John Jacobson, an economist with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia.
Since pulling the company from near bankruptcy 23 years ago, Mr. Iverson has carved a profitable niche in the steel market. Last year Nucor reported net income of $70.9 million on sales of $1.06 billion, although it reported a 19 percent decline in earnings for the first nine months of this year because of the new operations.
Mr. Iverson, who is now 63 years old, is passionate about keeping operating expenses low. He works out of a small office in a Charlotte shopping center, with fewer than 24 people on the corporate staff. He has relied heavily on automation and robotics while giving management and rank-and-file workers financial incentives tied to productivity.
Mr. Iverson said products from the Crawfordsville mill would initially go to lower-grade uses like decks, joists and siding for buildings. But he said there were also short-term automotive uses, like clamps that hold down starters and batteries.
Within a few years, he said, the mill should be making higher-quality sheets for automobile hoods and appliances. ''There is nothing we can see,'' he said, ''that won't allow us to provide a high-quality flat-rolled product that's as good as anything in the market today.''

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Down by 0.4% in October

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
In another sign of a slackening economy, the Government's main forecasting index fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the fifth decline so far this year.
But despite a host of recent lackluster-to-poor readings and the belief of some experts that a recession is imminent, many analysts said today that they still saw no end to the business expansion. The current recovery, the second longest on record, has just entered its eighth year, albeit amid indications that growth has slowed markedly.
''We're not part of this pack that says the economy is sagging into recession,'' said Stephen S. Roach, principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. He noted that the two biggest contributors to the latest decline in the index of leading indicators - a rise in initial claims for unemployment insurance and a decline in the length of the average workweek - were both adversely affected by special factors. 
Jobless claims spurted as a result of Hurricane Hugo, and the workweek was shortened by a strike, which has been since been settled, at the Boeing Company.
Meanwhile, the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private research group that is considered the unofficial arbiter of business cycles, has reported that its experimental recession index shows the chance of a recession within the next six months to be 9 percent. That is down from a 13 percent reading after the September indicators were announced. The Boston-based research organization holds ''a significantly more optimistic outlook'' for the economy now than it had in the summer and early autumn.
The Commerce Department's report today on the leading indicators, which was about as forecast, was not expected to have much effect on economic policy makers at the Federal Reserve. That is because most of the components had previously been reported and because the index has recently been criticized as unreliable and has been altered slightly as a result.
Nonetheless, the stock market got a lift from the news as investors appeared to believe that the central bank would soon decide to ease credit another notch to prevent the economic slowdown from turning into a contraction. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 41.38 points, to 2,747.65.
The bond market did not react in kind. Dealers said traders were continuing to wait for clear signals about the direction of interest rates. The price of the Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond rose yesterday as its yield fell to 7.87 percent, down from 7.88 percent on Thursday.
Additional evidence of a slowdown in the manufacturing sector emerged today when the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its main index of manufacturing activity fell a full point in October, to 46.6 percent, its seventh straight decline. The group says a reading below 50 is a sign of a shrinking economy.
Noting, however, that factories account for only 18 percent of American jobs - and that some areas of manufacturing continue to do well - Joan D. Schneider, an economist for the Continental Bank in Chicago, said she was not very worried. ''The economy doesn't have a lot of forward momentum,'' she asserted, while adding that it did not show signs of heading into a recession.
In all, six of the 11 components of the Commerce Department's index eased in October, but apart from jobless claims and the workweek all of the declines were small. These were in manufacturers' unfilled orders, consumer expectations, the slowness of supplier deliveries and manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and for materials.
Four components that rose, all by modest amounts, were building permits, the M-2 money supply, prices of sensitive materials, and contracts and orders for plants and equipment. Stock prices eked out a tiny advance - far less than one-hundredth of 1 percent - despite the plunge in the market on Oct. 13.
The Commerce Department also reported that it had revised slightly upward the gains in the leading index that it had previously reported for the two preceding months. The September increase is now three-tenths of 1 percent, instead of two-tenths, and the August increase is six-tenths, instead of five-tenths.
 
 Two Private Indexes
 But two predictive indexes compiled in the private sector were clearly negative. David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist at Jesup & Lamont, reported today that his macro-economic index, which signaled a recession in August by dropping below minus 50, skidded to a new low of minus 70 in October. The Safian Investment Research index, which has fallen every month this year except for August, fell again in October, but only slightly.
The Commerce Department's report also showed that the index of coincident indicators, which plots current economic conditions, was unchanged in October. The index of lagging indicators climbed by four-tenths of 1 percent.
This caused a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent in the coincident-lagging ratio, considered by economists to be an alternative predictor.
The various changes left the index of leading indicators at 144.6 percent of its 1982 base of 100. So far this year, the index has declined at a rate of four-tenths of 1 percent, in contrast to a 3.8 percent rate of advance for the comparable period of 1988.
Generally speaking, three straight months of a decline is deemed to signal a recession two or three quarters ahead. But, frequently, no such downturn has occurred - most recently in the final four months of 1987.

HEADLINE: A Soft Red Glow on Madison Ave.

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
In American marketing, the Russian bear has become a pussycat.
American popular culture has long followed the twists and turns of the nation's diplomatic relationship with the Soviet Union. The clearest example today is in advertising. When President Bush meets with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in Malta later today, he can look for support to the Pepsi-Cola Company, which recently released a commercial entitled ''Glasnost,'' a paean to the normal nature of Soviet family life, and to A.T.& T., which has been selling telephones with a television spot that depicts a Soviet-American friendship parade. 
The message in these and other new ads is simple: The Russians are just like us.
 
 Stolichnaya Sales Up
 It is a far cry from the winter of 1986, when a commercial for Miller Lite beer closed with Yakov Smirnoff, a Russian emigre comedian, saying: ''In America, you can always find a party. In Russia, party always find you.''
''It would not sell one can of beer today,'' Mr. Smirnoff said in an interview on Thursday.
The nation's new, benign attitude toward the Soviet Union is evident throughout the media and marketing industries. Home Box Office is broadcasting an original movie, entitled ''Red King, White Knight,'' about a former C.I.A. agent's effort to thwart the assassination of a Gorbachev-like Soviet leader. Domestic sales of Stolichnaya vodka, which declined in 1983 after the Soviets shot down a Korean Air Lines passenger jet, grew more than 50 percent between 1985 and 1988, as glasnost bloomed.
''There is a culture of cold war and a culture of detente,'' said Lary L. May, a University of Minnesota historian and the editor of ''Recasting America: Culture and Politics in the Age of Cold War,'' published by the University of Chicago Press last year. ''If the culture of detente wasn't there, you wouldn't have this quick switcharound we're seeing now.''
The transition has been dramatic in advertising, an area that many scholars believe both reflects and helps shape the larger culture. ''Advertising has played a significant role in establishing our frames of reference and perception,'' wrote Prof. Roland Marchand, a historian at the University of California at Davis.
 
Bottle Opener at the Ready
 Pepsi-Cola has released two television commercials that portray the Soviet Union favorably. The first, entitled ''Floats,'' first appeared 18 months ago, and depicts an American astronaut and a Russian astronaut in Earth orbit. A bottle of Pepsi floats into the hands of one. Serendipitously, the other produces a bottle opener.
Such imagery reflects the ad industry's acute sensitivity to anything that might help make a sale, including the slightest whiffs of social change.
''It's important for any product that wants to be in the contemporary mainstream to be not a step ahead, not a step behind, but a step with,'' said Philip B. Dusenberry, the chairman of BBDO, New York, the agency that creates Pepsi's advertising.
A television commercial currently on the air in Italy and created by the Young & Rubicam agency's Milan office shows a young couple cavorting in Red Square, playfully tossing snowballs and having their picture taken by a smiling Russian soldier. The product in question: Barilla, an Italian pasta.
 
Ale for a Hammer
 In the United States, other contemporary ads with an Eastern tilt include a new campaign for Lowenbrau light beer that mimics the imagery of the socialist realist art of the 1930's that exhorted workers to toil for the good of the state.
A subway poster for the new campaign shows a blond, cartoon worker boldly astride the world. Instead of a hammer, his upraised arms hold a bottle of golden ale.
This is not the first time that American popular culture has reflected shifting foreign policy objectives regarding the Soviet Union. From 1941 through 1944, Hollywood reveled in the World War II partnership between Washington and Moscow, Professor May said. Films like ''Mission to Moscow'' and ''Song of Russia'' extolled the courage of the Russian people and the beauty of their land.
But after the 1945 Yalta summit meeting that led to the division of Europe into Western and Communist blocs, Hollywood's ardor cooled considerably, impelled partly by the House Un-American Activities Committee's investigation of earlier films favorable to the Soviet Union. More than 40 movies with anti-Soviet themes, including ''I Was A Communist For the F.B.I.,'' were made between 1947 and 1952, Professor May said.
 
'Refreshing Changes'
 The latest shift in popular opinion has been accompanied by commercial messages from American companies like Pepsi and A.T.& T., several of which actually claim credit for themselves - and, by extension, for Western capitalism - for the changes taking place in the Soviet Union.
The Pepsi ad entitled ''Glasnost'' includes a young boy in a leather jacket listening to pounding rock music as his father complains - a familiar scene played in Russian with subtitles. Against it, an announcer says, ''Not very long ago, America introduced Pepsi to the Soviet Union. While it may be just a coincidence, a lot of refreshing changes have been taking place ever since.''
Four years ago, when negative Soviet imagery predominated, the advertisers overwhelmingly were small companies, like Royal Crown Cola, MCI Communications and Wendy's hamburgers, fighting for market share against large, entrenched competitors - like Pepsi-Cola, A.T.& T. and McDonald's - who were compared to the faceless Soviet bureaucracy that prevented people from choosing their own destiny.
Royal Crown humorously depicted downtrodden Russian peasants forced by commissars to choose between Pepsi and Coke. Behind closed doors, however, a group of dancing dissidents celebrated with R.C.
''The old ads deprecated the Soviets on one thing - the quality and level of consumption,'' said Robert Goldman, a sociologist at Lewis and Clark College in Portland, Ore. who studies advertising themes. ''My interpretation of the new ones is, the Russians are just like us - they want to consume.''
 
Changing an Act
 Americans who now empathize with, rather than ridicule, the economic plight of the Soviet Union have forced other, more subtle changes in popular culture. For example, Mr. Smirnoff, the Russian comedian, has changed the comedy act that propelled him to nightclub and television stardom.
''As my whole act was revolving around Soviet issues in a negative way, I had to change my whole image,'' he said. ''It has turned me from a Russian comedian into a comedian who used to be from Russia.''
While he is still in demand as a commercial spokesman, Mr. Smirnoff said agencies were changing the content of the ads they created for him. In a campaign planned for next year, he said, Best Western motels will use him to compare its effort to upgrade its lodgings to the Soviet Union's attempt at economic restructuring.
More significantly, American marketing's infatuation with all things Russian is being matched by glimmers of positive American sentiment in the advertising that has recently begun to appear on Soviet television.
Moscow residents have recently seen a commercial for Pilyot watches that includes shot after shot of victorious American athletes at the 1988 summer Olympic Games.

GRAPHIC: In a scene from the Pepsi commercial entitled ''Glasnost,'' young Soviet rock musicians pass a Pepsi kiosk as they drive to an engagement.
