HEADLINE: Assets Drop At Savings Institutions

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The assets of the nation's savings and loan institutions continued to shrink significantly in September in preparation for tough financial standards that take effect next week, the Government said today.
Assets at the nation's 2,903 savings institutions fell by $15.2 billion, breaking the record set in August of $13.3 billion, the Office of Thrift Supervision said.
In terms of deposits, a net amount of $8.9 billion was withdrawn from the institutions, which was up from $5.3 billion in withdrawals in August and the most since February. The February outflow of $9.2 billion had been the second-largest on record after January, which had an outflow of $10.8 billion. 
Early in the year depositors had fled savings and loan institutions -fearing a possible tax on their deposits as a way to finance an industry rescue - in favor of higher rates paid by money market funds.
September was the 16th month out of the last 17 to record an outflow. Deposits rose only in July, and then by just $51 million.
Economists attributed the continuing declines to the industry's efforts to meet new capital standards. The standards, which take effect on Thursday, require the savings and loan associations to back their lending and investments with more capital. The requirement is part of the Federal savings and loan rescue legislation enacted in August.
The rescue will provide $159 billion to close down almost 700 sick savings institutions over the next 10 years.
For years, the industry was permitted to operate at capital levels between 1 percent and 3 percent of assets, but those requirements will more than double under the rescue legislation. Some analysts predict the industry could be forced to raise more than $30 billion in new capital through stock offerings; cash infusions from mergers with outside investors, or by shrinking the overall size of the institution, while keeping the amount of capital constant.
The Office of Thrift Supervision has estimated that about 800 savings institutions will fall short of the new requirement.
Many savings institutions have had difficulty raising capital from private investors. As a result, they have been selling assets.
James Christian, an economist with the United States League of Savings Institutions, said the shrinkage will probably continue next year, but at a slower pace.
Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va., said much of the asset sales had been in mortgage-backed securities, which are among the most easily sold.
That could cause problems for the savings institutions. By July 1991, they will be required to hold 70 percent of their assets in housing, up from 60 percent.
But Mr. Ely said ''there is some sense - maybe it's more wish than hope - that Congress at some time is going to ease up on the standards'' for housing loans.
Mortgage originations of $15.4 billion in September were down $1.1 billion from a month earlier and were off 34 percent from the period a year earlier because of the softer real estate market in 1989, the Office of Thrift Supervision said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading; Gold Prices Also Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar posted some gains yesterday against other major currencies in relatively quiet foreign exchange trading.
Gold prices also increased. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose by $2 a troy ounce, to $413.60. 
Currency traders in Europe said the dollar was helped by profit taking in the West German mark, which has risen steadily against the dollar over the last month.
In the United States, analysts said many traders decided to buy dollars as a hedge against potentially market-moving announcements from the weekend American-Soviet meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
 
Weakening and Rebound
 ''The dollar traded with some strength today,'' said Craig Sloane, financial futures analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He added that the dollar received some early support from concerns about the attempted coup in the Philippines and each time the currency weakened, it managed to rebound.
Mr. Sloane said the Government's report that its index of leading economic indicators fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in October and the national purchasing managers' survey that indicated the economy continued to decline had little impact on the currency markets.
''There was nothing in those reports that wasn't anticipated by the market,'' he said. He described currency trading as light to moderate.
Against the West Germany currency, the dollar rose to 1.7865 marks, from 1.7815 late Thursday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing of 143.08 Japanese yen, from 142.90 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it slipped to 143.05 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 143.40 yen, from 142.80 yen late Thursday.
The dollar gained ground against the British pound. In London, the pound fell to $1.5665, from $1.5700 late Thursday. In New York, it fell to $1.5625, from $1.5700 Thursday.
 
Late New York Rates
 Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5995 Swiss francs, up from 1.5930; 6.1020 French francs, up from 6.0840; 1,316.50 Italian lire, up from 1,312.25, and 1.6505 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16405.
At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold was quoted late in the day at $413.50 a troy ounce, up $2.85 from Thursday's late bid.
In London, gold rose to a late bid of $414 a troy ounce, up from $410.60 late Thursday, while it climbed to $415 an ounce in Zurich, from $409.50 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose by $8.39, to $414.15 an ounce.
Silver for current delivery slipped 0.5 cent a troy ounce, to $5.663, on New York's Comex. Earlier, silver rose in London to a late bid of $5.70 a troy ounce, up from $5.64 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Angels and Langston Agree on $16 Million

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
In the ever-escalating world of baseball economics, Mark Langston is the latest highest-paid player in the game's history.
Langston, a free-agent left-handed pitcher, reached agreement yesterday with the California Angels on a five-year contract worth $16 million.
The Angels, with their owner, Gene Autry, leading the charge, won the expensive sweepstakes over the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers, who were willing to give Langston a five-year contract but, said one source familiar with the negotiations, not the no-trade provision the Angels agreed to.
The no-trade provision was one of the significant features of the contract because clubs have become reluctant to grant such clauses. Rickey Henderson received one when he agreed last Tuesday to remain with Oakland. 
 
First Five-Year Deal Since 1985
The length also is significant. It is the first five-year contract a player has received since Eddie Murray signed a five-year extension with Baltimore in July 1985.
''Length and the no-trade provision were determining factors,'' Arn Tellem, Langston's agent, said by telephone from his office in Los Angeles.
The value of the contract, of course, also is important because it continues the star-salary escalation that has whirled through baseball in the past two weeks.
On Nov. 17, Bret Saberhagen signed a three-year extension with Kansas City for $8.9 million. Five days later, Kirby Puckett of Minnesota became baseball's first $3 million-a-year player, signing with the Twins for $9 million over three years. Less than a week later, Henderson got $12 million over four years from the Athletics.
 
Most Money Ever Guaranteed
Langston could have been the first to average $3 million a year last summer if he had accepted Montreal's three-year, $9 million offer. But he rejected it, became a free agent and now has a contract that averages $3.2 million a year for two additional years.
Along with the average being the highest ever, the $16 million is the most money ever guaranteed a player. When Dave Winfield signed with the Yankees nine years ago, he was guaranteed $15 million for 10 years.
''It gives Mark peace of mind,'' Tellem said. ''He knows he's going to be there for five years with a team that is serious about winning. A player's control over his own destiny was a concern with me. The five years and the no-trade provision were important. Mark and I knew this would have an impact on other players. We wanted to send a message to other players that it could be done.''
The Angels, whose owner has tried desperately to reach the World Series, have been among the most aggressive pursuers of free agents. To land Langston, they gave him a $1.5 million signing bonus, to be paid next month, and salaries of $1.5 million next season and $3.25 million in each of the subsequent four seasons.
 
Yanks Strike Out
Perhaps the biggest losers were the Yankees, whose owner, George Steinbrenner, reverted to his strategy of courting free agents himself. Tellem declined to discuss details of his talks with Steinbrenner, but said they never really got into a specific amount of money.
Steinbrenner did not return a telephone call yesterday, but George Bradley, a club vice president, said money really was not an issue. ''Everybody who was in the Langston sweepstakes was going to be in the same area,'' he said from Tampa, Fla.
He denied that the no-trade provision had been a factor. ''We never got into that discussion at all,'' he said. ''We did everything we could, but we had no control over it. He wanted to go to the West Coast. We can't move New York between Los Angeles and San Diego.''
 
Yanks Need a Starting Pitcher
The failure to get Langston was a setback for the Yankees, who signed Pascual Perez but still need starting pitching.
''We started out to go hot and heavy for pitching,'' Bradley said. ''We got one, we didn't get this one. This isn't going to deter us. I think Langston was the impact player out there. We still want a starting pitcher.''
Langston, who earned $1.4 million this year pitching for Seattle and Montreal, had a combined 16-14 record. After joining the Expos in late May, he won 10 of his first 13 decisions, but he tailed off and finished with a 12-9 record. Langston, who led the American League in strikeouts three times with Seattle, had his biggest winning season in 1987, when he won 19 games.
 
 PHILLIES SIGN MARTiNEZ
 Carmelo Martinez, a San Diego outfielder last season, also signed as a free agent, agreeing with the Philadelphia Phillies on a two-year, $1.75 million contract.
Mark Davis remains one of the most desirable free agents still available, and the Padres have offered their star relief pitcher salary arbitration.

HEADLINE: Building Outlays Up In October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Bolstered by the first gain in single-family home building in nine months, construction spending climbed modestly in October, and analysts said the improvement suggested lower interest rates were helping end a construction slump.
The Commerce Department said today that spending rose 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $420.1 billion. The increase followed no change in September and a 1.5 percent gain in August. Construction spending fell in July and June. 
In October, residential construction, which accounts for nearly half of all building activity, rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent, to an annual rate of $193.6 billion, reversing a nine-tenths drop in September.
 
First Rise Since January
 Single-family construction rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent in October. It was the first increase since January and followed a 1 percent fall a month earlier. Multifamily building, plagued by high vacancy rates, rose by 1.8 percent after dropping 3 percent.
Analysts have been expecting the construction industry to begin rebounding in response to interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The Fed sought to dampen inflationary pressures by pushing rates up through the spring. By June, when signs of a slump emerged, the central bank starting nudging rates down, with the most recent cut coming early in November.
Fixed-rate mortgages, for instance, averaged 10.1 percent at the beginning of October and finished the month at 9.82 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. This week, they averaged 9.74 percent.
 
Nonresidential Increase
 Nonresidential construction advanced 1.2 percent during October, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $102.6 billion following a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent in September.
The gain was led by a 3.7 percent increase in shopping center and other commercial projects and supported by a 1.7 percent jump in factory construction. Hotel and motel building was flat, while office construction fell 1.1 percent.
Government construction spending rose 1.7 percent, to an annual rate of $88 billion, following a 2.7 percent increase in September. The biggest single government category, highway construction, fell 1.8 percent while construction of schools and sewers both increased.

HEADLINE: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report:
Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

BYLINE: By M. A. FARBER with DON TERRY

 BODY:
In midafternoon on Aug. 3, Randal Swanson, a 29-year-old baker from West Caldwell, N.J., steered his black Toyota along West 162d Street in Manhattan, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, looking to buy cocaine.
It took only seconds, he recalled last week.
''As soon as they saw my New Jersey plates, they ran over to the car,'' he said. ''I said what I wanted and I got it. I had $35 in my hand and we swapped. I barely stopped the car.'' 
But two or three blocks later, Mr. Swanson was stopped - snared in a Police Department Tactical Narcotics Team operation. At a red light, he was arrested by officers who, he said, threatened to ''blow my head off if I moved.'' His car was confiscated.
Throughout the year, thousands of people who live and work outside New York City - plumbers and doctors, homemakers and laboratory technicians, clerks and tile workers - pour into Washington Heights, Inwood and Harlem in Manhattan; the South Bronx; the Flatbush section of Brooklyn; the eastern end of the Rockaways in Queens, all in search of drugs.
They come from the middle-class or blue-collar reaches of northern New Jersey, from Nassau and Westchester and Rockland Counties, because the price or the quality of the drugs in New York City is often better than at home.
They come because the supply of cocaine or crack or heroin is temporarily short in White Plains or Jersey City or because, at odd hours of the night, when the need for a high may be pressing, dealers in the city are still awake and doing business.
They come because they do not want to be seen buying drugs in their own town.
And they come, frequently in pairs and carrying knives if not guns, despite the risks from those selling drugs -and from those trying to get drugs off the streets.
In some of the toughest neighborhoods in the city, the outsiders are valued customers, people who, for the most part, have enough cash and do not want to quibble or linger. It is easy, say both the police and the buyers, to get almost any drug in these quick, anonymous transactions.
It is not so easy, at times, to get home.
 
Three Who Died Violently
On Nov. 12, around 5:40 A.M., a 33-year-old woman from Weehawken, N.J., Janet Pierro, was shot to death while driving with her 4-year-old son near West 141st Street and Hamilton Place in Harlem. The police believe she was trying to buy heroin. The child was not injured.
Last December, a 24-year-old man from New Rochelle, N.Y., Willie Schaffer, was shot to death, and two friends were wounded, about 4 A.M. in the High Bridge section of the Bronx. The police said the three, as well as a companion who was beaten up, appeared to be seeking drugs.
In April 1988, a 32-year-old woman from Fairview, N.J., Lidia Ferraro, was shot to death by five police officers after a chase ended at 2 A.M. at Park Avenue and 124th Street in East Harlem. A toxicological examination showed cocaine and heroin in Mrs. Ferraro's body. A grand jury concluded that although the woman turned out to be unarmed, the officers were justified in using deadly force.
 
The Ports of Entry
 
Over the Bridge, Through the Tunnels
The police believe that upper Manhattan, particularly the Washington Heights section just east of the George Washington Bridge, is a prime locus for drug purchases by suburban residents and those from nearby cities.
In the year ended last August, the Port Authority police made 763 drug arrests at the George Washington Bridge, 694 at the Lincoln Tunnel and 146 at the Holland Tunnel. Most of the arrests occurred between 8 P.M. and 1 A.M., and most of the cars were returning to New Jersey.
Henry I. DeGeneste, Superintendent of the Port Authority police, said the people arrested ''run the whole socio-economic scale,'' with those at the lower end of the scale caught at the Holland Tunnel, those in the middle at the Lincoln Tunnel and people at the upper end of the scale at the George Washington Bridge, which is used by residents of some of New Jersey's wealthiest counties. Much of the Lincoln Tunnel traffic is bound for the Times Square area, the police say, and the Holland Tunnel is a frequent route to drug sellers on the Lower East Side and in Greenwich Village.
 
The Arrests
 
3,234 Cars Seized In Three Years
Superintendent DeGeneste said that while some drug buyers are caught at roadblocks set up to catch drunken drivers, most drug arrests by the Port Authority police begin with a car being stopped for speeding or making unsafe lane changes on the way back to New Jersey. On occasion, undercover officers who see a drug purchase in the city will radio ahead to the Port Authority or New Jersey police, giving them the buyer's license plate number.
''Basically that's how we come in contact with them,'' he said. ''They're in such a damn hurry to get back to their communities. It's amazing how often we find drugs just sitting on the seats. They don't think they're going to get stopped.''
Superintendent DeGeneste added that many of those arrested appear to be high and do not have the presence of mind to conceal the narcotics they are carrying. In addition to making arrests, the police and the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in mid-1986 began confiscating cars - usually from drug buyers rather than sellers -in which drugs were found.
From then until Oct. 31, 3,234 cars had been seized, almost half of them this year. More than 1,500 of the cars were registered to owners living in New York City, 877 in New York State but outside the city, 621 in New Jersey, 31 in Connecticut and 135 elsewhere. About a quarter of the owners have been able to reclaim their cars, most often in cases where the owner was not the one arrested. The city auctioned off 767 cars, raising $490,545.
While there is no complete profile of the owners of the confiscated cars, the police say the great majority are white, have no criminal records and range in age from late teens to early 40's. In the operation on Aug. 3, which has been repeated periodically, 102 people were arrested besides Mr. Swanson, and among the 82 cars seized 52 were from New Jersey.
Seventeen of those arrested on Aug. 3 were charged with felonies; the most severe sentence given so far was 90 days in jail. Of the 86 people charged with misdemeanors, the longest term was 23 days.
Capt. Robert J. Curley, commander of the Tactical Narcotics Team in upper Manhattan, said that while dealers in Washington Heights supplied wholesale quantities of drugs over several police precincts and beyond, most of the buyers from outside the city appeared to be interested in small quantities, up to a gram or two, for ''casual, personal use.'' Still, he said, ''these people help to drive the drug trade.''
 
A New Jersey Baker
 
At Home, the Price Is Twice as High
 Mr. Swanson, the New Jersey baker, described himself as just such an occasional user of drugs.
He said in an interview that he started coming into upper Manhattan to buy drugs about a year ago, with a friend who had been doing the same. The availability of drugs in the city was one factor, he said. But the main reason he came was to reduce his cost by eliminating a middleman.
''If I bought in New Jersey what I bought in New York,'' he said, ''the price would be twice as much. And the stuff wouldn't be as good. Getting it in New York seemed simple and easy.''
Mr. Swanson said that before his Aug. 3 arrest, he had been arrested once before in the city for having drugs. He said he was ''let go because it was a first offense,'' and afterward he refrained for months from coming into the city for drugs.
When he returned, he was surprised at being caught, considering, he said, that ''it's such a large market, so many people doing it.'' Mr. Swanson, who is married and has two children, agreed to plead guilty to a lesser charge, disorderly conduct. Now, he said, he plans to give up drugs.
''I was in the wrong, no doubt about it,'' he said. ''I was foolish. I learned my lesson.''
For others, especially those addicted to drugs, the lessons have come harder.
Three people from outside the city who have gone into treatment at Daytop Village recently described their experiences buying drugs in the city. Their stories illustrate the reasons for this variant on commuter traffic and the dangers in it.
 
A Former Student
 
'It's Amazing I Didn't Get Killed'
Eric Z., 24, a thin, blond former student at Rockland Community College, grew up in Rockland County. He started coming to the city to buy drugs while still in high school ''because it was fun,'' he said. He went at all hours to the streets around Yankee Stadium in the Bronx and to the side streets off Second Avenue in East Harlem. Eventually he bought heroin in Washington Heights, in abandoned buildings where ''pitchers'' would weigh out the heroin on scales and ''catchers'' would take his money.
''It's amazing I didn't get killed,'' he said. He was beaten up and robbed one night near Webster Avenue in the Bronx while his girlfriend sat a distance away in his 1979 Buick. He was stopped by the police on the Palisades Interstate Parkway, with syringes on the floor of his car, but managed to toss them out of sight. Another time, a friend swallowed a bag of heroin when a police car pulled alongside Eric's.
Occasionally Eric was sold tainted drugs. He lined up for drugs outside holes in the walls of buildings, speaking to other buyers only to ''find out what's good, where the best was that day.'' For protection he carried a knife. But once he was addicted to both heroin and cocaine, Eric said, he lost all fear of being in rough city neighborhoods and noticed that many of the other buyers, too, were ''more afraid of the cops than of the locals.'' At new spots, he often had to ''show my track marks to prove I wasn't a cop.''
Eric, who said he sometimes made two or three trips a day to the city for drugs, said he was able to support his $150-a-day habit by stealing jewelry at a store where he worked and by selling drugs, at a markup, to others in Rockland County.
 
A Jersey City Commuter
 
Drugs, Too, for Sale In Diamond District
Kim P., who is 29 and has lived all her life in Jersey City, bought cocaine on West 47th Street, in Manhattan's diamond district, when she worked in the area in 1988 as a dental assistant. ''It was over one of those watch places,'' she said, ''and they only took certain people.'' When she was ''really desperate,'' she recalled, she bought cocaine along West 42d Street, near the Port Authority Bus Terminal. ''But that was mostly junk,'' she said, ''a ripoff.''
As recently as July, Kim drove with male friends or acquaintances - never alone - over the George Washington Bridge to buy drugs near West 134th Street or in the Bronx. ''If you saw crowds at 3 A.M.,'' she said, ''you knew they were selling.''
In New York, Kim said, ''you could get drugs at any hour.'' In Jersey City, at night, the dealers might themselves be in New York. ''It all comes down to convenience and urgency,'' she said. ''The risk doesn't matter. You don't think about it.''
 
A New Jersey Carpenter
 
'You Do Anything To Get That Hit'
Dennis M., 30, a carpenter and former subway conductor in the city, grew up in Brooklyn and now lives in Sayreville, N.J. But on frequent visits back to Brooklyn, he said, he would smoke cocaine with friends. Often he took drugs home with him across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge or through the Holland Tunnel.
In recent months he began using crack and, finding none in the New Jersey bars where powdered cocaine was plentiful, bought crack in Flatbush. ''You do anything to get that hit,'' he said. He was soon stealing cars and was holed up in a crack house. He had, as he put it, ''hit rock bottom.''
Patricia B., 22, is a New York City resident. But she grew up in the leafy, suburban-flavored Riverdale section of the Bronx, a world away from the streets to which drugs took her. For six years she attended one of the city's most distinguished college preparatory schools, Horace Mann in Riverdale, and graduated from York Preparatory School in Manhattan, another private school. She started classes at Pace University. But, as she recalled, she might as well having been living ''on death row.''
 
'Just Wanted to Get High'
Patricia began using marijuana at 12, was sniffing cocaine by high school, and ''just wanted to get high and be left alone.'' By the time she was in college and working in a bagel store, she had her own apartment in Riverdale. A neighbor, Patricia said, ''turned me and my boyfriend on to crack.''
From then on, she said, her life was governed by the need for drugs. That meant constant forays - sometimes several times a night -into the drug markets of Inwood and Harlem and the South Bronx. When she lacked money, she said, she stole from her family, and she and her boyfriend worked out a way to rob gypsy cab drivers, some of whom chased them with bats. One night, ''after a few hits'' of drugs, she said, she was brutally attacked by a man to whom she was selling a chain.
Finally, when her weight had dropped to 88 pounds and, she said, ''I was ready to crack,'' a friend who had undergone treatment at Daytop Village persuaded her to go there. She is still in treatment, but has a job.
 
A Four-Minute Transaction
 
A Quick Conference At a Fruit Market
Despite the efforts of law-enforcement agencies, it still seems as easy to find an out-of-towner buying drugs in upper Manhattan as it is to find drugs themselves. And in all weather.
At 4:10 P.M. the other day, as the sky darkened and a biting wind swept the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and West 166th Street, and ''lookouts'' huddled in the doorway of the white stucco New Jerusalem Baptist Church, ready to shout ''bahando'' - ''coming down'' - if they spied the police, a blue Toyota Supra with New Jersey plates pulled up to the corner.
The driver stayed in the car, keeping the motor on. A gaunt woman emerged and hurried across Amsterdam Avenue to confer with a man in a baseball cap in front of Rosa's Fruit and Meat Market. The man left her for a minute, and the woman bounced up and down in the chill. The man returned. The woman dashed back to the Toyota. At 4:14 P.M., the car was gone.

HEADLINE: THE MALTA SUMMIT;
BUSH GIVES GORBACHEV ECONOMIC AND ARMS PROPOSALS

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 2

 BODY:
President Bush offered an array of more than a dozen economic and arms proposals to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today as they began their summit meeting, including an end to cold war trade restrictions.
Mr. Bush, meeting the Soviet leader on a gale-lashed day, proposed that immediate negotiations on a trade agreement, including giving normal tariff treatment to the Soviet Union, should begin once the Kremlin codifies new liberal emigration policy into law, according to White House officials.
The American officials did not say what proposals, if any, Mr. Gorbachev had offered, and no Soviet spokesman went into any detail on the first round of the scheduled two days of talks.
 
Storm Forces a Cancellation
The storm caused the two sides to cancel an afternoon session and an evening dinner because Mr. Bush could not travel from his base on an American warship to a Soviet ship 1,000 yards away. 
The White House officials, speaking anonymously, said that in five hours of shipboard meetings with the Soviet President, Mr. Bush had indicated that Washington would support granting the Soviets observer status at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Western-dominated international trade organization, once the current round of talks in Uruguay ends by the end of next year. Such status would amount to giving the Soviets an entry to the Western trading community. [A list of the President's proposals, page 29.] On arms control, Mr. Bush reportedly offered to drop his resistance to ending production of binary chemical weapons in return for Soviet acceptance of his arms proposals at the United Nations in September. He proposed that a Soviet-American agreement be signed by the end of next year limiting each side's chemical weapons stockpiles to 20 percent of the current American level.
 
June Summit Date Proposed
The President also proposed that the Foreign Ministers of the two nations meet in Moscow in June in an effort to conclude a treaty limiting strategic nuclear weapons in time for the 1990 summit meeting, which Mr. Bush proposed be held in the last two weeks of June in Washington.
Mr. Bush said that the two sides should conclude the East-West negotiations on conventional arms reductions in Europe so that a treaty can be signed in Vienna by the end of next year by all the parties.
''The President came here prepared to seize the moment in the U.S.-Soviet relationship, and he thinks he has done so,'' a senior Administration official said after the opening talks.
A senior White House official said Mr. Gorbachev was ''extremely positive'' in general. He added, however, that the Soviet leader had reacted negatively when Mr. Bush said Moscow's relationship with Cuba and Nicaragua was ''the single most disruptive element'' in American-Soviet relations.
The summit meeting opened against a backdrop of sweeping popular demands in Eastern Europe for democratization and an end to hard-line Communist rule. This was on the agenda, but only mentioned briefly in a summary of the morning session.
 
Seeking Public Relations Edge
As Administration officials circulated tonight offering details of what they termed the ''Bush initiatives,'' it became clear that the White House, far from taking this summit meeting as the informal get-together previously advertised, was working hard to regain some of the public-relations momentum from Mr. Gorbachev.
The Soviet leader responded to Mr. Bush's list of proposals by describing it as ''tangible evidence of the President's commitment to perestroika,'' according to an official present at the meetings.
Mr. Bush also invited the Soviets to join in proposing that the 2004 Olympic Games be held on both sides of the Berlin wall.
In his speech to the United Nations in September, Mr. Bush proposed that the United States and the Soviet Union begin to slash their chemical wepaons to a level of 20 percent of American stocks and that this be done before a worldwide ban is agreed to.
He said any worldwide treaty should call for eliminating 98 percent of American stocks over eight years. The United States would keep 2 percent until all nations able to make chemical weapons acceded to the treaty.
Despite the proposal, the Administration intended to keep open the option of producing advanced chemical wepaons, known as binary, once the treaty went into efffect. This would have meant amending the treaty under negotiation.
Allies of the United States objected, and today's proposal to Mr. Gorbachev seems to be a way of backing off from continued production of binary weapons. Binary weapons involve two separate chemicals that are otherwise harmless but that form a lethal poison when mixed together.
Mr. Bush proposed initiating these reductions next year even before a scheduled multinational convention on chemical weapons is concluded. A number of his summit offerings, as reported by Administration officials, seemed timed for the summit meeting next year in the United States.
 
Afternoon Session Canceled
The opening session of the shipboard discussions was described by the White House as ''very productive, informal and substantive.''
But the afternoon session and dinner had to be canceled as rough seas swept into the harbor here and pinned down Mr. Bush aboard the cruiser Belknap.
Sixty-mile-an-hour winds kept four-foot-high whitecaps between him and Mr. Gorbachev, who rested easier aboard the larger Soviet cruise liner, Maxim Gorky, placidly tied at dockside here, only 1,000 yards from the storm-battened Belknap.
By evening, the storm-isolated Mr. Bush provided a graphic display of nature's power to disrupt the best laid plans of superpowers. Even so, the ranking diplomats would not allow any dampening of their estimate of the day's import.
''A good beginning,'' Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d said. His Soviet counterpart, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, described the crimped summit as of ''fundamental significance for world politics.''
 
Meetings Aboard Gorky
Before the sea washed over the agenda, the two leaders managed five hours of morning and luncheon meetings aboard the Gorky, including ''one on one'' discussion of more than an hour in which they were free of ministers and attended only by note-takers and translators.
''The meetings were marked by a spirit of forward-looking cooperation during these increasingly changing times,'' the White House said in a printed statement. ''They recognized that economic and political challenges were ahead for Eastern Europe, and vowed to consider the opportunities presented with sensitivity and firm initiative.''
Mr. Bush was described by the White House as finding the opening session ''extremely productive.'' He talked for more than an hour at the first meeting, raising ''more than a dozen ideas for economic and political progress in U.S.-Soviet relations,'' according to the White House.
Mr. Gorbachev then spoke about his plans for renewing Soviet economic and political life. Whereupon Mr. Bush ''emphasized his support for the success of perestroika,'' or Soviet restructuring, the White House said.
 
Weather Remains Uncertain
Officials of the White House and Kremlin made plans to revise the second day of scheduled talks on Sunday. The weather remained an uncertain factor into the night, with 16-foot waves raging just beyond the summit scene in the Marsaxlokk harbor of Malta.
Navy officials insisted that the winds must subside considerably before Mr. Bush attempts any more harbor trips in the Belknap's 40-foot motor launch.
The two Presidents made light of the weather as they met and shook hands at 10:05 A.M. on the Maxim Gorky. The Gorky became a backup meeting scene when the rising morning seas already had a heavy roll under the Belknap and her Soviet counterpart, the Slava, the cruisers where the talks were originally planned to take place.
''Let's go to work,'' a beaming Mr. Bush said after a few minutes of small talk and photo posing.
''We will be discussing everything,'' Mr. Gorbachev said minutes later as they sat down with aides in the Gorky's card room, a spacious library-like room decorated in mauve tones.
 
Officials at the Table
The group at the table included Secretary Baker, Mr. Shevardnadze and other ranking advisers. Mr. Gorbachev was flanked by his Foreign Minister and Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, the Politburo member who is the Soviet leader's closest aide. Also there were Defense Minister Sergei F. Akhromeyev and Anatoly I. Dobrynin, the former Ambassador to the United States.
Mr. Bush's party included his chief of staff, John H. Sununu; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, Paul D. Wolfowitz, Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, and Robert Zoellick, counsellor to Mr. Baker.
The agenda, which had been planned as a fluid, informal way for the two leaders to become better acquainted, also included one of Mr. Bush's promised points of concern, his complaint that continuing Soviet military shipments to Cuba are finding their way into Nicaragua and El Salvador.
The Soviets issued no comparable details. Arkady Maslennikov, spokesman for the Supreme Soviet, summarized the initial session as ''not bad at all.''

Shevardnadze, left, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. (AP) (pg. 1); a Navy launch in heavy seas carrying President Bush back to the cruiser Belknap after his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev yesterday in Malta (Reuters); a Maltese man braving the weather to catch a glimpse of the Belknap, right, and the Soviet cruiser Slava, in Marsaxlokk Bay. (AP) (pg. 28)

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 29, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 903 words

HEADLINE: THE MALTA SUMMIT;
Is Summitry Outmoded?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 2

 BODY:
When President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union complete their summit conference on Sunday, they will head off to tell their friends how they have done.
 
Mr. Bush will fly to
Brussels to brief the Western allies at the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and Mr. Gorbachev will return to Moscow to confer with the other members of the Warsaw Pact. It is all standard operating procedure, the superpowers keeping the junior members of their alliances well informed of the latest policy developments.
But this time, things will be very different than in the past. 
Mr. Bush will be doing his briefing at the headquarters of a military alliance built to contain Soviet expansionism but now looking hard for a new role at a time when confrontation between East and West, across an iron curtain that is being disassembled, seems an increasingly remote prospect. And Mr. Gorbachev will be briefing a group of countries whose politics and leadership have been totally transformed by the dizzying events of 1989. A Cold-War Anachronism? To many Europeans, the whole notion of summit conferences between the Soviet Union and the United States, which have been so familiar a part of the cold war, seems as outmoded as the cold war itself. At a time when nuclear deterrence, for the first time in four decades, seems a less pressing question than the future shape of Europe, the critics say, it is the nations of Europe and not the United States and the Soviet Union that must make the really big decisions.
It is true that Mr. Gorbachev played a major role in the changes that have transformed Eastern Europe, first by instituting perestroika in his own country, then by accepting rapid political and economic evolution in Poland and Hungary, and finally by encouraging reform in East Germany, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. But he has less power now in the region than he did before.
''Think about it,'' said a leader of the Civic Forum opposition in Prague. ''The Soviets say that we have to keep the Warsaw Pact intact, because it will help to maintain stability in Europe, and the West agrees. But that's just a convenient fiction. Nobody in this part of Europe believes that Gorbachev could get the armies of Hungary and Poland and Czechoslovakia to take joint action anymore.''
 
'Let Them Have Their Meeting'
In the West, the decision of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to present, almost on the eve of the summit conference, a plan for the eventual amalgamation of the two Germanys demonstrated that NATO, while probably far more united than the Warsaw Pact at the moment, is not likely to be able to maintain the status quo for long either, however comfortable that might be.
The United States, furthermore, is not likely to be able to dominate the Western alliance in the way it once could.
At a conference in London not long ago, a French banker commented indignantly that he thought Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush should have changed their plans and invited all the major European nations to meet with them in Malta, ''to reflect what's really going on in the world these days.''
In reply, a Danish businessman advised him not to worry too much ''about two former superpowers, neither of them European, having their little meeting to talk about questions that Europeans are going to settle.''
 
Retooling the Old Alliances
Such comments are commonplace in Europe these days, but there are also many Europeans who welcome the idea of the United States and the Soviet Union maintaining an interest in their continent. Indeed, many would like to see NATO and the Warsaw Pact transformed into political organizations that would tie Moscow and Washington into the new political structures that emerge here.
Peter Jenkins, the political columnist of the Independent in London, is one commentator who believes that Mr. Gorbachev's acceptance of change in his sphere of influence is matched by a real commitment on the part of the Bush Administration to the idea that European integration is a good thing, not a threat to the United States. He thinks that this gives Europe a chance, which seemed improbable a few years ago, to shape its own future.
''Real Europeans should be drinking a toast to George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev,'' said Mr. Jenkins, ''and not grousing about their absence from the conference table in Malta.''
Nonetheless, nearly all Europeans accept the proposition that whatever the result of Mr. Bush's talks with Mr. Gorbachev here, the American military presence in Europe is likely to decline in the years to come. The support of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney for cuts in United States troop levels has had a major impact because of his reputation as a hawk.
 
European Community to the Fore
What this will mean, of course, is more responsibility for Europe and especially for the European Community. The Soviet Union and the United States will retain their nuclear arsenals for the foreseeable future, and in that sense they will remain superpowers.
But as President Bush implicitly acknowledged earlier this year in agreeing in Paris to work through the Community in aiding Poland and Hungary, the simple days when Moscow and Washington made most of the big decisions regarding Europe are coming to an end. And in that regard, at least, summit conferences like the one here this weekend may well be obsolescent.

TYPE: ANALYSIS

LENGTH: 475 words

HEADLINE: THE MALTA SUMMIT;
Proposals Made by Bush At Meeting With Gorbachev

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Following, as outlined by American officials, are the proposals made by President Bush today in his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union:
Strategic Nuclear Weapons: The next summit meeting should be in the last two weeks of June 1990, in the United States.
The foreign ministers of the two countries should meet before then in the Soviet Union to discuss progress toward the summit.
The two foreign ministers should deal with three specific issues in limiting strategic nuclear arms: air-launched cruise missiles, non-deployed missiles and encoding of missile-launch data. The purpose would be to work toward signing a treaty on such weapons at the June summit meeting. 
Conventional Forces: Both sides should support the convening of a European summit meeting in Vienna in 1990 to sign a multinational treaty on reducing conventional armed forces in Europe.
Nuclear Testing: The two sides should complete work on a threshold test ban treaty and a treaty on peaceful nuclear explosions to be signed at the 1990 summit meeting.
Chemical Weapons: Mr. Bush would drop resistance to a ban on production of binary chemical weapons if Mr. Gorbachev agreed to support his arms control proposal made at the United Nations.
The two nations should negotiate and sign an agreement in 1990 to reduce American and Soviet chemical warfare weapons to 20 percent of current American stockpiles.
Military Disclosure: The Soviet Union should publish details of its military programs, such as the status of its armed forces, budget and weapons production.
Trade: The two countries should immediately begin negotiations on a trade agreement that would grant the Soviet Union most-favored-nation status.
The United States will support giving the Soviet Union observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade starting in 1991.
The two sides should pursue expanded technical and economic cooperation in finance, agriculture, small business development, budget making, tax policy and stock exchanges.
Mr. Bush would explore with Congress the possibility of lifting restrictions on export-import credits in conjunction with most-favored-nation status.
The two sides should begin immediate negotiations on a bilateral investment treaty.
The Soviet Union should move toward market pricing on wholesale goods.
Human Rights: Mr. Gorbachev should resolve outstanding human rights cases. Mr. Bush presented a list of fewer than 100 cases, including those of divided families that Mr. Bush would like to see resolved by next summer.
Other Issues: The United States should sponsor a conference next fall on a global environmental treaty.
The two nations should exchange 1,000 college students beginning in the 1991 academic year.
Both countries should call for holding the Olympic Games in both parts of Berlin in 2004.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN EUROPE;
A Czech Tries to Start His Own Bandwagon

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The man who heads the Institute for Forecasting at the Academy of Sciences, a research bureau devoted to discerning Czechoslovakia's economic and social future, has decided to take a hand in shaping it, stopping just short of publicly declaring that he wants to be Prime Minister.
The not so bashful political newcomer, Walter Kamarek, has been seen on state television eight times in a week, and a senior television official said he continues to ask for more time.
Handwritten posters calling for him to be named Prime Minister have sprung up all over Prague. His outspoken criticism of the old regime and hopeful forecasts in public meetings have given him a sudden, large following. 
At the beginning of the week, Mr. Kamarek, an economist who was unknown to the general public before the sudden blossoming of freedom began last month, privately informed the leaders of Civic Forum, the opposition conglomerate, that he stood ready to stand as the group's candidate for Prime Minister, Forum leaders reported.
The proposal embarrassed the brain trust of the Forum that had formed around Vaclav Havel, the playwright and dissident who leads the opposition by spontaneous consent. He had a long private conversation with the would-be candidate.
 
Support for the Premier
On the one hand, Forum leaders consider the economist, who has gained mass appeal virtually overnight by his powerfully expressed criticism of the country's eclipsed rulers, as a possible future leader. But in its first meeting with Prime Minister Ladislav Adamec last Monday, the Forum accepted Mr. Adamec as head of government on condition he present a multi-party Cabinet acceptable to the opposition by this weekend.
A Forum strategist said that having given Mr. Adamec a chance, the opposition could not at the same time rally to another candidate, particularly since the Forum does not want to become a political party. ''Kamarek should wait until Adamec has tried and failed and then have his chance,'' a Forum leader commented.
Mr. Kamarek does not seem to be in a waiting mood. On Thursday he called a news conference, largely for the many foreign correspondents here, distributed what in the United States would be called a campaign biography and sharply accused the Forum of being idealistic but politically inexperienced and ready to compromise with the ruling Communist Party. He said this would be ''a compromise between a democratic future and the forces of darkness.''
He did not elaborate on what he thought the Forum was compromising, but opposition leaders believe he alluded to the opposition group's present acceptance of Mr. Adamec.
 
Party Structure 'Remains Intact'
In his news conference, the 59-year-old economist, who wears his hair like Albert Einstein and keeps his beard trimmed to a point like Leon Trotsky, warned that although the power of the Communist Party had ''collapsed,'' there was ''real danger of its renewal.''
Mr. Kamarek has been a member of the party since 1946, but that has not stopped him from harshly attacking those at the heart of the party, likening them to a band of gangsters who will not readily relinquish control over their now diminished but still dangerous patronage networks.
Mr. Kamarek contends that behind Mr. Adamec and what he termed the collapsing ''facade'' of the party, ''the structure of power remains intact.'' In one of the phrases that helped to account for Mr. Kamarek's popularity, the economist described as ''a dreadful Mafia'' the hidden structure of power that he said the Soviet and Czechoslovak security services built up after the Soviet-led invasion of 1968.
Mr. Kamarek said 200,000 to 400,000 people distributed through the party and government machineries and involved in state security and military commands formed a structure that since 1968 had exercised ''ruthless economic and political repression.'' In all, the Czechoslovak party has 1.5 million members.
''It is a curious historical situation pitting 200,000 to 400,000 people against the 15 million Czechoslovaks,'' Mr. Kamarek said. He said ''the constant theat of Soviet tanks'' maintained this lopsided balance until ''the heroic stand of Mikhail S. Gorbachev'' upset it, causing the leadership to react first with harsher repression, like ''a fascist dictatorship,'' and then to collapse.
 
Reformers 'Excommunicated'
Mr. Kamarek said that despite economic stagnation, he based his optimism for a brighter future on new people, not party ''reformers.'' Acting like ''social fascists,'' the party ''excommunicated'' its reformers, he said. ''But we have something different -we have a reformist nation of educated people with historic links to European thinking, culture and traditions.''
Skeptics among the Forum leadership criticized Mr. Kamarek for the contrast between the strong phrases like ''Communism is nonsense,'' which he dropped on Thursday, and his 43-year, continuing membership in the party. They believe that he is positioning himself to be invited by the Communists or the opposition to head a government.
The biography distributed at his news conference stresses the many difficulties that he experienced in his career for assuming strongly individual positions. However, critics note that when after the 1968 invasion most independent-minded professionals were purged from their professions and expelled from the party, Mr. Kamarek weathered the storm.
Still, it is widely agreed that Mr. Kamarek's institute provided employment to many independent-minded social scientists and produced critical reports in the years when criticism was not in fashion. He also impressed visiting foreign journalists with frank observations when conformity was the keynote in all official interviews.

GRAPHIC: Walter Kamarek, an economist in Prague, who has stopped just short of publicly declaring that he wants to be Prime Minister. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Scrambling to Be Counted in Census

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
For five years, an improbable collection of bureaucrats, business executives, health care professionals, members of ethnic groups and transportation planners have been trying to stake a claim to 3.5 square feet of valuable political real estate: the 1990 census questionnaire.
Their weapons are reports and statistical abstracts, memos, letters, and copies of laws, regulations and court decisions - the stuff that filing cabinets are made of. Their aim is, simply, to be counted.
At stake is access to, management of and often a share in hundreds of billions of dollars in Federal spending or tax breaks for groups of people the census tries to count, like the poor, the sick, the old, the young, homeowners and the homeless, veterans and the unemployed. 
The aim of the groups is largely to get questions on the long census form, which is sent to 17.6 million households and takes about 43 minutes to complete. There is also a short form, including questions asked of all 245 million Americans. It takes an average of 14 minutes.
 
Attitudes and Values
''If you win and you get on the form, you are then an identifiable social group - a race, or a single-family-house owner, or a television owner,'' said Margo Anderson, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin and the author of ''The American Census: A Social History'' (Yale University Press). ''The categories become the language we use to talk about ourselves.''
This decade's biggest winners were the advocates for the disabled, who sought a comprehensive count of all who have difficulty taking care of themselves or getting where they need to go.
The 1980 census form asked two questions, about a person's ability to work and his or her access to transportation. The 1990 form eliminates the 1980 question on transportation and tries with a single, two-part question to measure the disabled, a group that annually receives $70 billion to $75 billion through more than 50 Federal programs.
As a result, ''our needs will be much, much better understood,'' said Frank Bowe, a professor of education at Hofstra University and a former executive director of the American Coalition of Citizens with Disabilities.
''For example,'' Dr. Bowe went on, ''we now have before the Congress the Americans With Disabilities Act,'' a sweeping piece of legislation extending civil rights protections. ''Once the numbers are published, it becomes much more evident why that act is very much needed.''
 
Pressure Is From Bureaucrats
The pressure that is brought to bear on the Census Bureau is less from politicians than from Federal bureaucrats who administer the programs that depend on census figures.
To cope with the pressure, the bureau has a system of Federal interagency councils, each screening questions in a given subject area like housing or population. That is one of the ways the bureau insulates itself against overt political lobbying.
These groups sift the proposals that have arisen in 65 public meetings, dozens of private meetings and correspondence from advocates like Dr. Bowe. They conduct several dry runs on small groups, locally and nationally. The content of the questionnaire is decided about a year before April 1. Then the bureau takes the heat.
Almost without fail, Census Bureau staff members say, the greatest controversy is generated by questions on race.
That category, once labeled ''color,'' has expanded dramatically since 1870, when Chinese-Americans were included, through 1980, when Vietnamese, Guamanians and Samoans were added.
In 1970, a separate question about ''Spanish'' origin was introduced, and has been refined over the last 20 years in an effort to capture accurately the characteristics of America's fastest-growing minority.
 
Asian-Americans in Focus
But it was Asian-Americans, another diverse and growing group, who were at the center of controversy in the development of the 1990 form.
Last year, in an effort to streamline the race question and make room for other inquiries on a form that, as a matter of policy, is not allowed to grow from one decade to the next, the Census Bureau tested a questionnaire that eliminated the individual categories under the heading ''Asian and Pacific Islander.'' It asked members of these groups to write in their ethnic group. There were heated reactions. Although Patricia A. Berman, the bureau's Assistant Division Chief for Content and Data Products, maintains that the groups on the 1980 questionnaire and small groups like Cambodians would have been tabulated separately, several Asian organizations generated significant Congressional heat over elimination of their categories. The streamlined approach was abandoned.
Ms. Berman said, speaking of a place on the form where race is marked: ''People were were saying, 'We're culturally and ethnically different. You've always had my circle on the questionnaire - now you're taking it away!' ''
 
Trouble Seen on Disability
It is Ms. Berman's job to turn the decisions of the various screening groups into the two forms. While gaining a place on the form is a sign of recognition and often a sign that Federal aid is in store, some people are not enthusiastic about their distinction. Dr. Bowe, for instance, says he expects a mixed reaction to the new question on disability.
''Some people will say, 'Yeah, great, someone finally recognizes folks like me are important and finally they are asking,' '' he said. ''Other people will say, 'Oh, God, I don't want anyone to know what is the matter with me.' There will be a large number who will deny disability - who will be embarrassed by it.''
For the first time, there will be questions about stepchildren. A related question has been refined to reflect more accurately the relationships between unmarried partnerships and other nontraditional household arrangements.
All proposed questions were screened by the Federal interagency councils over the past few years on criteria from usefulness to taste. Questions on controversial issues like AIDS and abortion are barred for fear of provoking anger and noncompliance.
Other questions are deemed irrelevant to the main purposes. Some proposals that did not make it to this year's form involved ownership of personal computers, VCR's and cable television subscriptions.
A question on the number of household pets generated a write-in campaign from veterinarians and pet food manufacturers.
They are expected to try again in 10 years.
''Inevitably, more people want to get into the census than want to get out,'' said Dr. Anderson.

HEADLINE: ALASKA FEARS LOSS IN PIPELINE INCOME

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Dec. 2

 BODY:
After battling the Exxon Corporation over the huge oil spill near Valdez last March, the State of Alaska is again fighting the petroleum industry, this time over repairs to a pipeline that transports a quarter of the crude oil produced in the United States.
The $8 billion Trans-Alaska Pipeline is only 12 years old, but already one section has corroded so badly that $200 million in repairs are needed, the pipeline operator said Friday.
To meet this and other repair costs, the operator wants to raise charges for carrying crude along the pipe, which in turn will reduce state royalties paid by the oil industry. 
The Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, the seven-member oil consortium that runs the 800-mile line from the Arctic Ocean to the port of Valdez, says rust-proofing tape has failed to protect the steel pipe that each day carries 80 million gallons of oil.
 
Miles May Be Replaced
''It appears that the coat process was not adequately quality-controlled,'' said an Alyeska spokesman, George Jurkowich. He said almost nine miles would have to be replaced.
Alaska's Attorney General, Doug Baily, said he had started an investigation to determine if poor maintenance was partly to blame for the damage, both internal and external, and the subsequent reduction in state oil royalties.
Mr. Jurkowich denied that mismanagement was to blame. He said the oil companies have made regular reports on rust over the years to the state and Federal authorities. ''It is normal that pipes buried in the permafrost, in water and earth, are subject to some form of corrosion,'' he said.
About 85 percent of the Alaskan government's revenue flows from royalties and taxes paid by the oil industry. The industry pays as a royalty the value of one-eighth of the 1.9 million barrels of oil that flow through the line daily. The value is based on the ''wellhead'' price, the sale price to refineries minus the cost of transporting it from the fields.
Mr. Baily has appointed lawyers, economists and accountants to review industry claims that repair costs are pushing up the price they are charged to transport their oil.
 
High Tariffs Requested
Oil companies, including British Petroleum and Exxon, which are the pipeline's main owners, are seeking Federal regulatory approval to raise tariffs in 1990 by an average of 86 cents, to $3.89 a barrel, for transporting oil through the line.
The state estimates that each dollar-a-barrel increase in the tariff costs the government $150 million a year, so the increases proposed by the pipeline operators would cost the state $130 million in lost annual revenue.
Mr. Baily, questioning the extent of the rust, said the state also needs to do its own damage assessment. ''I've always had an unwillingness to accept information from Alyeska at face value,'' he said.
In March, the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound, spilling near 11 million gallons of oil and polluting more than 1,000 miles of shoreline.
The state battled all summer with Exxon over its cleanup operation and the environmental effect of the spill on the wilderness state.

HEADLINE: A Teahouse Links Japan And Virginia

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWPORT NEWS, Va.

 BODY:
A Japanese teahouse sits in a glade of pine and beech trees in this Navy town in southeastern Virginia, a few thousand miles from its native region of Kyoto.
Even though hardly anyone uses it for drinking tea, Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia has praised its value as a tool for international trade. Art professors and students admire its architectural simplicity. Local businessmen call it a kind of love letter to Japan from Virginia. 
''It says to the people from the Pacific Rim and to Japan in particular that Virginia is a good place to do business and, if you're going to establish an operation stateside, Virginia is the place to come,'' said Lloyd Noland, a retired businessman who had an electrical supply company here.
Along with Canon Virginia Inc. and Toshiba America Inc., Mr. Noland's company contributed a large part of the $400,000 that brought the teahouse to Newport News from the National Gallery of Art in Washington, where it was part of an exhibition of Japanese art and culture.
 
Not as Fragile as It Looks
The teahouse, 19 feet long by 13 feet wide by 17 feet high, is a replica of a 16th century building. It is an Ennan teahouse, so named because its wing-like roof is said to resemble the Ennan swallow. Its walls are made of cedar, its roof of dry vine and its windows of paper.
It looks fragile enough to be toppled in a slight wind, but the Japanese carpenters who assembled it in the summer on the campus of Christopher Newport College said that not even a hurricane could blow it down. When the edge of a hurricane reached here in September, it did no damage.
Inside one of its two main rooms, a modern tap provides water for the tea, but that is the single deviation from authentic decor. Utensils for the tea-serving ceremony are in an open cupboard.
In another room, bamboo mats cover the floor, and a paper lantern hangs from the ceiling. Otherwise, the structure has no ornament except a few sacred, but nondescript, stones near the entrance. Beginning in January, the college will sponsor six tea ceremonies and a local woman has asked to be married in it. But this year, tea has been served only once, when the teahouse opened.
 
Harmony Counteracting Turmoil
David Alexick, a professor of art at the college, says the teahouse seems incongruous, settled as it is among the thoroughly modern brick and concrete buildings. But its presence serves a worthy and necessary cause, he says: the promotion of things Japanese.
On a cool fall afternoon as pine needles wafted down, his class received a brief explanation of what the cedar walls, paper windows and bamboo signify to the Japanese.
The teahouse's harmonious lines reflect an affinity with nature. For centuries the Japanese have regarded those lines as a force to counteract turmoil. Warriors would remove their swords and helmets upon entering, sit down and drink tea together.
Newport News has the heaviest concentration of Japanese companies in Virginia, and their influx in the last four years made the customs, language and business of that country a top priority.
Last January, while touring an exhibition on feudal Japanese culture at the National Gallery of Art, Governor Balilies saw the teahouse and he spoke to the owners of the teahouse immediately about moving it to the Newport News area, a spokeswoman, Meredith Strohm, said.
Asahi Shimbun, a major Japanese newspaper, Nomura Securities Company and All Nippon Airways paid for putting up the building at the museum but had no plans for it after the show.
''It occurred to me that the Ennan teahouse should find a home in a part of America where history is remembered, where traditions are respected and where new knowledge is constantly sought,'' Mr. Balilies said at a luncheon in June.
 
A Two-Way Link to Japan
More than 100 people and companies quickly raised the money to take the teahouse apart, ship it to Christopher Newport College and have carpenters come from Japan to reassemble it in the glade. In 1987, the college had received $300,000 in state money to being an international education program, which includes a Japanese studies program.
Shin-ichiro Nagashima, the president of Canon Virginia, said the teahouse put a special seal on an already warm relationship between the people of the Tidewater region and the Japanese.
''There is a greater awareness in this community of understanding different cultures,'' Mr. Nagashima said. ''The teahouse symbolizes their interest in Japan.''
It also serves as a link between Japanese executives here and their homeland. Ichiro Hasegawa, an executive at Toshiba America, hesitantly admitted after a recent tour that even in Japan he had never ventured into a teahouse.
''Frankly, I found myself having a lack of knowledge about Japanese culture,'' Mr. Hasegawa said. ''This was my first time to visit any teahouse ever. The building was very curious to me.''
But the scenery around the teahouses lent it a familiar quality, he said.
''That area is very close to what we have in Japan, lots of pine trees and beeches,'' Mr. Hasegawa said. ''It doesn't look like America.''
It also has a practical value, in that Japanese investors who encounter a significant piece of their heritage are more attracted to the area, said Julius Denton, president of the Virginia Peninsula Economic Development Council. Business deals could even be initiated within its walls.
''You need everything you can get, because everyone else is doing the same thing,'' Mr. Denton said. ''The teahouse tells these people that once they break the ground, we don't forget them.''

HEADLINE: Linda Bell Weds R. L. Blackburn

 BODY:
Linda Brantley Bell and Ronald Louis Blackburn were married yesterday by the Rev. George H. White at the Central Brick Presbyterian Church in East Orange, N.J. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. John Jordan and Edward Brantley Salaam, both of Roselle, N.J. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lemuel H. Blackburn of Ewing Township, N.J.
Mrs. Blackburn, a magna cum laude graduate of Princeton University, is a candidate for a doctorate in sociology at Rutgers University and a manager of information services in Piscataway, N.J., for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Her husband, a graduate of Rider College with an M.B.A. degree from Fairleigh Dickinson University, is a regional sales manager for A.T.&T. in Liberty Corner, N.J. They are both visiting lecturers in the National Urban League's Black Executive Exchange Program. 
The bride's mother, Helen Jordan, retired as the credit union manager in Port Newark, N.J., for the Sea-Land shipping concern. The bride's father, also retired, was a metallurgist at the U.S. Metals Refinery Company in Carteret, N.J. Mr. Blackburn's mother, Louise Blackburn, retired as a claims adjuster for the State Unemployment Insurance Fund in Trenton. His father retired as a mail carrier in Princeton Junction, N.J.
The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did her husband's.

HEADLINE: 3 Organizations That Help Relieve New Yorkers in Pain, Visible or Invisible;
Assisting Henry I. In His Search for a Job

BYLINE: By DONNA A. SANTARSIERO; Executive Director, Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service

 BODY:
It was a year ago that the story of Henry I., a 27-year-old deaf man who is learning-disabled and successfully employed, was told. Until he began work at the H. B. Company in the East New York section of Brooklyn, he had never held a job very long.
Henry completed the job training program for disabled men and women at the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service. His success at the company was three years in the making, the result of training, counseling and job placement efforts by the Brooklyn Bureau. He started at the company in February 1987 on a two-week trial. 
I visited the company this past October to see Henry and the 13 other disabled men whom the Brooklyn Bureau trained for employment. We found them their jobs as well.
Henry uses American Sign Language. He showed me his work proudly, matching inventory members on boxes with the numbers on requisition forms. He stacks products on shelves for storage and loads some for delivery. With an expressive smile, he conveyed to me his happiness and satisfaction with his job and his newly found independence.
When Henry first came to the Brookyn Bureau, he didn't believe that he could ever work. He didn't believe anyone would ever hire him.
 
Destructive Conditions of Life
But how could Henry have known of the many people who believe that human beings whatever their circumstances can have a better life and believe that sharing to help those in need improves the way we all live. It is people who contribute generously to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who helped make Henry's new life possible.
To carry out the work of the Brooklyn Bureau, our social workers travel the streets of Brooklyn and see conditions of life that are destroying neighborhoods and families. But they also see the resilience and strength of the human spirit. We serve men and women who struggle to raise their families while living in poverty, families whose apartments are orderly in the midst of decay, crack houses and the skeletons of burned-out buildings, and mothers and fathers weary with fatigue after working all day who patiently help their children with homework.
We at the Brooklyn Bureau respond to their courage. Our mission is to work on many fronts to enable poor men, women and children to become economically and socially independent. This year we will help over 11,000 persons.
We serve thousands of children and their parents in our programs to prevent foster-care placement. Our social workers counsel men and women in the skills of parenthood, accompany them to government agencies and hospitals to solve immediate problems such as housing, government allowances or lack of medical care, and provide guidance in reaching vocational goals.
 
Training and Day Care
Our social workers are stationed in schools training teachers every day to recognize the indicators of abuse and showing them how to report cases that require child-protective investigations or removal of children from the home. And they visit families at home to strengthen the families' ability to handle the stresses of living in some of New York's most troubled communities. They help parents establish warm and nurturing relationship with their children.
Every day we provide job training and job placement services to 225 retarded and emotionally and physically disabled men and women, many of whom have never worked. And this year we will serve 1,400 children in day-care programs. Our purpose is to provide these very young children with positive experiences that will enable them to succeed when they enter school in the near future, while also enabling their parents to continue in gainful employment.
In response to the crisis of homelessness, we started this year two new programs. In the coming year, our staff will help over 1,000 homeless adults and children to move from the shelter system and stabilize themselves in permanent housing. We will be available to them 24 hours a day.
These are some people you have supported with your contribution to the New York Times Neediest Fund:
Many Helping Hands A young woman told our social worker that she was unable to control her anger and feared harming her two children. She was without money to buy food. We gave her food and money to pay for utilities. We worked with her to create a budget. We helped her find a decent apartment that she could afford and found a day-care program for her children. She is now in a job-training program. Our social worker has helped her relieve the stress she felt that resulted in anger toward her children.
We responded to a teacher feeling hopeless about how to teach a neglected, malnourished child. Our social worker visits his parents weekly and helps them to understand the importance of seeing that the child is well fed and clothed. We purchased winter clothes for the child. He is now much more alert and ready to learn.
For three weeks our job placement specialist accompanied a mentally retarded man, training him to travel between his home and the job she had found for him. And she shopped with him and bought the first work clothes he had ever owned.
A mother was hospitalized. Her sister could be with the children only at night. Our homemaker went to the home daily to feed and comfort the children, clean the home and help the children with their school work. When the mother returned from the hospital, the homemaker remained until the mother had the strength to manage the home.
For almost six months our homemaker bathed, dressed and fed a child with AIDS. Because the child's clothes were too big, she altered them to fit. Every day she gave him the affection he longed for. Our social worker has helped the homemaker as well as the family deal with the tragedy and grief of the child's illness.
Contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases campaign not only make a difference in the lives of many poor people but also make a difference in the lives of all of us.
A contribution will be used only for direct service and financial assistance to the poor people we serve. Last year we distributed over $240,000 of New York Times Neediest Cases funds in direct emergency financial assistance to poor people we helped in all our programs.
I want you to know how grateful we are for your support and to wish you a very happy holiday season and a happy and healthy New Year.

HEADLINE: 3 Organizations That Help Relieve New Yorkers in Pain, Visible or Invisible;
Best Minds Must Unite To Help a City in Need

BYLINE: By THOMAS A. DeSTEFANO; Executive Director, Catholic Charities,Brooklyn/Queens Diocese<

 BODY:
The men, women and children we serve are representative of a city in need. They have problems that challenge us beyond a one-time fix. They are a mosaic of human dignity. 
As the problems of human needs increase, we must be open to new and more effective approaches to their solution. This will require that the city's major institutions come together in an integrated approach to problem-solving. We must bring our best minds, our leaders, our decision makers from all institutions to plan together and solve together.
Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, talks about the city's institutions and their ''encrusted shell.'' In a recent study and survey of the changing patterns of contemporary family life, Catholic Charities of Brooklyn/Queens concluded, ''The challenge to our nation is toward the development of social policy and action in human service that will create caring communities, protect children, educate, serve and preserve family life at the neighborhood level.'' But for us to meet this challenge, all of us, individuals and institutions, must break out of our ''encrusted shells.''
Recently, we at Catholic Charities have taken steps to do that with a reorganization of our management and service-delivery structure. All systems are now better integrated so that we can provide the multiplicity of services required by most individuals and families who come to us for help. Medical or drug problems may be just one facet of a family's difficulties; they may be on the edge of eviction, facing homelessness due to unemployment and other economic problems.
Using a more integrated structure to deal with the overall problem, our caseworker can facilitate appropriate medical care, economic assistance, guidance and shelter until the family is back on its feet again and human dignity is restored.
In its conclusion, the Mayor's Commission for the 21st Century makes the following statement:
''In general the Commission emphasizes reorganization and reform, rather than additional resources. Poverty must be faced as the city's most serious pressing problem. To address poverty and dependency, education must have the highest priority; but human services must be reorganized.''
We see the need for this kind of reorganization and reform more vividly, perhaps, because we are committed to human services. All of our institutions must reflect these more structural and integrated steps to a ''New York Ascending,'' which is the title of the report on the year 2000. It is not the exclusive responsibility of our new Mayor, or the new Schools Chancellor or community boards; it is a responsibility all of us must share: government, schools, churches and the family.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund exemplifies all that is good, caring and decent about a great city in distress. Funds from the appeal help us, and other agencies, bring new hope to the neediest among us.
