HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Conran's Without Price Tags? Hardly

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Does a city really need a museum with a permanent collection featuring 15 typewriters, 13 calculators, dozens of cameras, and glass showcases filled with telephones, dishes, glassware and stereo equipment? No, it doesn't, and visitors are to be excused if they think they have mistakenly stepped into the electronics and housewares departments of Harrods. But if the Design Museum, which opened last summer on the south bank of the Thames, has a bit too much of the air of a retail establishment, this hardly matters. For this museum, temple to consumer objects though it is, has turned out to be one of the more exhilarating small cultural facilities in London.
The museum was created by the Conran Foundation, a charitable organization founded in 1981 by Sir Terence Conran, the architect who became rich selling well-designed household objects on a mass scale. It replaces the Boilerhouse, a Conran-sponsored design gallery that existed for four years within the Victoria and Albert Museum. The new Design Museum, like the Boilerhouse, presents temporary exhibitions, but the main event now is the permanent collection, a set of 20th-century objects to rival the holdings of the Museum of Modern Art in New York. 
In fact, while the collection of this new institution is not as deep as that of the Modern, the design of its galleries, by the British firm of Stanton & Williams, makes visiting it much more pleasurable. The permanent collection is displayed on the top floor of the three-story museum, in a sprawling room with huge windows overlooking the Thames. This gallery, like the building itself, is a classic modern space: simple white walls, light-colored wooden floor, glass showcases, plenty of natural light. It is big, clean and crisp, and unlike most modern designs these days, wonderfully un-self-conscious. The harshness and anger that emanate from so much modern design in Britain are nowhere present here; this building is more American, more like Richard Meier, a vision of modernism as sensual and benign. It makes you believe, if only for one fleeting moment, that modernism really is the only way.
It is not that the building, designed by the architect Stuart Moscrop of Terence Conran's firm of Conran Roche, is so remarkable. It is not. But Britain has precious few modern buildings that have any degree of amiability at all. Most modern buildings in this country look as if they were designed mainly to inspire people to join Prince Charles's crusade against modern architecture. This one, though, stands as a refreshing antidote to the ever more insistent debate surrounding the Prince's views: its modesty of scale, its mix of sharpness and gentleness, come into the heated battle over traditional versus modern architecture in Britain like a breath of cool air.
The building is part of a larger development project on the south bank called Butler's Wharf, slightly east of Tower Bridge and the Tower of London. Butler's Wharf is itself part of Docklands, the vast region of warehouses and industrial buildings that have lain fallow since London's shipping industry faded away; many of the brick warehouses are now being converted into apartments and offices, and there are the faint beginnings of a real neighborhood here. (At the moment the area around the museum is so filled with construction that the building is nearly impossible to reach by car, and visitors are better off traveling by subway to Tower Bridge and walking along the splendid riverfront esplanade that is one of the best aspects of this portion of the Docklands redevelopment.) Back to the museum. It would be unfair to describe the permanent collection as merely a set of consumer objects; there are also the requisite Breuer and Rietveld and Aalto chairs, and several automobiles, including a Citroen 2CV, the magnificent, simple, inexpensive car that was produced in France for what seemed like generations.
The Citroen 2CV stands as a kind of symbol of the museum's priorities: while the founding director, Stephen Bayley, and Mr. Conran did not exclude high art, they were clearly most interested in acquiring and celebrating those objects that have brought high design quality to the mass market. (By contrast, the car that stands as a symbolic presence in the Museum of Modern Art's design galleries is a Cistalia, a rare and expensive European sports car.) The curatorial bias here does parallel the stance of Mr. Conran's stores, which emphasize quality design in the broad marketplace, and the philosophical similarity between the stores and the museum may be too close for some visitors.
But the Design Museum is hardly a Conran's shop without price tags. Not only is there the rich array of older handsome and well-chosen objects, there are also numerous rare and special things here. Among the best: a full-size wooden model of a car designed by Le Corbusier and a full-scale model of a 1922 design by Werner Graeff for a De Stijl motorbike that is an utterly stunning folly. It is a welcome reminder that the museum's concern is not solely in the realm of the design of consumer products for the mass market.
The main gallery also contains an altogether splendid participatory computer game by which visitors can attempt to play industrial designer. An elaborate computer program allows six visitors at a time to use the computer to design a toothbrush, which is then evaluated for its practicality and economic viability in the marketplace. The game is marvelous fun, and a superb introduction both to the profession of industrial design and to the role of the computer as a design tool.
One floor below the permanent collection gallery is a room called the Review, where objects new to the marketplace or prototypes that have impressed the museum's curators are shown. Not long ago the Review room contained, among other objects, a Toshiba laptop computer, a Porsche washing machine, Philippe Starck's chairs for the Royalton Hotel in New York, and a truly marvelous art object, the Vodol Chair, a deviously witty ''deconstruction'' of Le Corbusier's classic Gran Confort chair.
There is also a large gallery for changing, thematic exhibitions, called the Boilerhouse in honor of its predecessor at the Victoria and Albert. Through Jan. 31 the Boilerhouse will house ''French Design 1960-1990,'' a show mounted originally at the Centre Pompidou in Paris. Designed by Philippe Starck and Philippe Delis, the exhibition is hopelessly cute, and renders trivial even the best objects it contains. Mr. Starck and Mr. Delis mounted each of the 150 objects in the show on an identical pedestal of unfinished wood, under a clear plastic cover. Everything in this exhibition, from an airplane to a chair, is therefore rendered at exactly the same size, a gimmick the organizers believed would give every object ''equal physical and historical significance,'' according to the wall text. It does indeed make all the objects the same - the problem is that all these models come off as playthings rather than real objects, and the only strong impression the exhibition leaves is of Mr. Starck and Mr. Delis's rigid Cartesian grid of wooden pedestals, marching relentlessly across the gallery. These trendy vitrines are the real consumerist offense here; they look like displays designed to promote French design in an airport concourse, and beside them the Design Museum's permanent collection feels like the National Gallery.

GRAPHIC: Part of the study collection on the top floor of the Design Museum, overlooking the Thames (Jonathan Player)

HEADLINE: TV'S BLACK WORLD;
Reality for Some

 BODY:
To the Editor:
According to Henry Louis Gates Jr., black television characters who are competent professionals, loving parents and hard-working college students are acting ''just like white people.'' If I didn't know Mr. Gates is black, I would have guessed him to be an unrepentant bigot who had never met a black person in his life.
No situation comedy can accurately depict every American's vision of reality in a half hour of television programming. What NBC's ''Cosby Show'' and ''A Different World'' do accomplish is a stylish and humorous presentation of slices of the contemporary black American experience with a message for Americans of all ages (and white South Africans, if necessary). 
Like the producer-director of ''A Different World,'' Debbie Allen, my roommate and I are products of Washington's Howard University. There we met black students of various colors, classes and capabilities from across the nation and around the globe. For us and the increasing number of young blacks choosing to attend historically black colleges and universities, no other television show comes close to depicting our reality. The show has tackled such important themes as date rape, alcoholism, poverty and single parenthood, always within the context of the unique nuances and values of black American culture.
If television shows depicting ambitious and successful blacks prompt some to blame members of the so-called underclass for their woes, it is not the fault of the creative forces behind them. Instead, we should cast a more critical eye toward political leaders and policy makers who promote stereotypes and bigotry and whose economic strategies deprive millions of the opportunity to improve their lives.
Against the odds, millions of blacks, my parents among them, have succeeded in reaping some of the benefits of economic success in this racist country. Don't they deserve to have a television show that reflects their life style and experience?
 
SABIYHA GRAHAM
Bronx, N. Y.
 
 Henry Louis Gates Jr. replies:
A joke told in Moscow during the recent food shortages: Is it true you can now order a steak over the telephone? Certainly . . . and it will arrive over the television. Reflecting on the hopes (and fears) that blacks have pinned to their televised images, I had a similar point to make about the kind of sustenance this medium can be expected to provide.
As Dr. Poussaint noted, my article focused on a contemporary phenomenon - the proliferation of highly successful black sitcoms on prime time, represented by ''The Cosby Show,'' its spin-offs and competitors. I suggested (and several correspondents evidently agree) that the sitcom is a particularly unlikely genre to look to for social realism. Are the white characters any less stereotyped than the black ones? Of course not. Historically, though, minorities have had a highly anxious relation to their public images. Imagine a white audience fretting about whether Pee-Wee Herman was embarrassing the race.
The basic point is that ''Amos 'n' Andy'' didn't enslave us; and ''Cosby'' will not free us. Which is hardly Cosby's fault. It is no reproach, then, to observe that America's favorite black family, the Huxtables, are in most respects ''just like white people.'' It's simply a fact about the precedence of class over ethnic identification - and thus about the cultural distances American viewers are asked to traverse. (That much we can say, I think, without recourse to the specious euphemism of ''universality,'' a property that now appears to be indexed to the Nielsen ratings.) In short, Mr. Cosby and Mr. Poussaint have nothing to apologize for.
Inevitably, though, some will persist in finding ironic the discrepancy between these images of affluence and the bleak statistical realities. Black America, your long-awaited dream of equality and prosperity has now arrived . . . over the television.

LENGTH: 3234 words

HEADLINE: Notes From a Prompter's Box On Making Opera Sing

BYLINE: By WILL CRUTCHFIELD; Will Crutchfield, a former music critic for The Times, teaches singing in Manhattan.

 BODY:
What if opera in New York so blossomed in the 1990's that only a curmudgeon would dream of griping about the Met; that the highlights of each season would truly be the talk of the town; that opera lovers would congratulate themselves on the good luck of being around for a golden age?
This is not utterly implausible, drastically as it may contrast with the tone of most operatic discussion today. There have been times when New York's operaphiles and opera houses lived in close harmony, and when the status of local operatic achievement was a matter of unquestioned civic pride. The parallel decade in the last century comes quickly to mind, but the period 1955 to 1965 wasn't half bad either, when you think about it. And there are good things going on in the world of opera today, buffeted as it may be in some respects. Why aren't more of them happening in New York, and how might they? That is a question worth asking in the last month of the 1980's, at a time of transition in the leadership of both our main companies. Hugh Southern is in his first season as general manager of the Met, and Christopher Keene has just inaugurated his administration of the City Opera with a series of promising proposals. 
One has to begin with a look at the current situation - not the standard list of problems (singer shortage, jet circuit and so on) but the intangibles that define a night's experience in the theater. To put it as simply as possible: Beyond Lincoln Center, I have seen more than a few performances that exceeded the sum of their parts and that gave genuine satisfaction even when faults could easily be identified. In adventurous St. Louis and conservative Washington, in the lively European shows imported at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (the next one due, in March, ''La Finta Giardiniera'' from Brussels), and elsewhere, some kind of esprit de corps has at least occasionally made performances mean more than they usually do at home. At the Met and the City Opera, most performances have added up to less than the sum of their parts. Verve, concentration, coherence, intelligence of approach and the excitement of joint effort in a great purpose have proved harder to find than sopranos and tenors.
Operatic New York has been through a crisis of managerial will and taste. Since 1972 the Met has had a series of general managers (Schuyler Chapin, Anthony Bliss and Bruce Crawford) who seem to have lacked passionate convictions about repertory, production style, musical quality, identity of the house in artistic terms. Some of them had views on those things, but that is not quite the same. And while James Levine has built the world's finest opera orchestra, he has not established a process that produces performances consistent with the level of his own gifts.
At the City Opera, Beverly Sills, general director from 1979 to 1989, was an effective fund-raiser and spokesman, but she did not recapture the company's flagging flair in presentation of the unusual, and her taste cannot entirely be exculpated from responsibility for the company's tendency to drift toward comfortable mediocrity in almost every aspect of programming and performance.
Of course there have been successes. I consider the Met's ''Ring'' cycle to be one, although that is not a widely shared opinion. Carlos Kleiber's too-brief visits (most recently for ''La Traviata'') have shown that Mr. Levine is not the only conductor who can make special music with the orchestra. ''Cendrillon'' and (with the right cast) ''The Mikado'' have been delightful at the City Opera. This list could be extended, but not very far. Barring individual triumphs from opera's aging and shrinking group of great singers, the best generally has been just respectable routine, and the worst has been the kind of performance that sends one home feeling that opera is dead even if you can find the sopranos and tenors.
Something very different is needed from management.- fewer and better-rehearsed operas, important repertory, a schedule of commissions - are, in my view, right on the mark. The test for him and for Mr. Southern will be whether they have a strong individual sense of what is really good work, and a willingness to intervene in its behalf. An enlightened manager is personally capable of recognizing mediocrity, poor taste and slovenliness and considers them insufferable; can engage in purposeful artistic discussion with leading artists, even (or especially) at moments of high tension in the rehearsal process; accommodates institutional pressures and makeshift solutions as a passionately contested last resort, not a comfortable calling.
Is this utopian? Only if one requires that the manager be infallible in all these things. My hope is for fallible leaders who have the wherewithal to aspire to that kind of role; the aspiration would make a world of difference. Here, in broad terms (ignoring some trees in an effort to see the forest), are some of the things such management would need to care about in a new way. The list reflects end-of-century conditions: not necessarily what made opera work in times past, but what seems to make it work best today.
 
The Question Of Preparation
 How an opera is put together musically is almost as important as who is cast in it. How long the participants live with one another in the company of the work, what kind of guidance is exercised and by whom - these are crucial factors; they cannot guarantee cohesiveness, but if the potential is there, they can foster it. Riccardo Muti had it right when he said ''the performance is created in the piano rehearsals.'' In our repertory houses the preparation is often in the hands of a coach or team of coaches, with the conductor joining the proceedings at a late point (as little as 10 days before the opening in some cases), and casts changing during a run.
It doesn't work. The coaches cannot substitute for the conductor in forming a musical partnership with the singers, in working out problems as they arise, in inspiring the ensemble and arriving at a living concept of the piece. When the maestro eventually appears, the opera is essentially shaped; if something major needs changing, from his point of view or the cast's, the choice is between tackling it too late and forcing it, or letting it ride. A few individual sessions at the beginning of rehearsals are not enough (and often even these are lacking); the team must be a team from the start.
This almost never happens at the Met. Mr. Levine spreads himself too thin, often with four of his operas being rehearsed or performed at a time (not to mention his ambitious outside projects), and visiting conductors facing a long run of widely spaced performances are rarely willing to give the Met an extensive rehearsal period beforehand. Small wonder so many performances are musically neutral. The City Opera has been similarly troubled and has had a still weaker roster of conductors - but Mr. Keene's announcement of closely spaced runs could presage a dramatic improvement.
 
The Importance Of Good Direction
The second great need is for responsibility in stage direction. Staging has been largely deplorable in both houses through the 80's, from the gaudy Franco Zeffirelli overproductions that affront good taste at the Met to the relentless middlebrow tackiness of comic opera across the plaza. It is hardly a question of traditional versus radical stagings; the great missing element at both houses is Personenregie. This is the German term for direction of actors and characters (as opposed to formulation of broad scenic and dramaturgical concepts). The productions that are failing in New York -and most are, artistically if not at the box office - are failing not because they are traditional but because they are poorly directed.
The main things opera needs from a director are care for the emotional truth of each moment; the discernment to arrive at a persuasive vision of that truth and the taste not to cheapen it for superficial responses; the imagination, patience and resourcefulness to work on each moment until it is right. And some understanding of music and singing. One director who fills this description and has worked in a ''traditional'' way (keeping the period and plot and other elements intact) is Giorgio Strehler, whose Scala productions of Mozart and Verdi are celebrated. Another who fills it and does antitraditional reworkings is the much-discussed Peter Sellars. Neither has ever directed an opera in New York City; this is typical.
There are few enough directors of real ability who see this kind of nuts and bolts work as their calling; no field is fuller of charlatans, pretentious amateurs, hacks (competent or otherwise) and self-aggrandizing showmen. Management should know the difference.
 
Ways to Obtain Better Singing
 The complaint one hears most often is about the poor level of singing, but some better singers could be engaged - and just as importantly, better work could be got out of the singers already engaged - by a company that articulated to itself a higher standard of respect for singing through its musical preparation and performance style.
What if, for instance, there were general agreement not to engage any singer with an ugly voice or a wobbling one, no matter how powerful? What if any inconveniences created by this policy had to be resolved by adjusting other elements?
This would cut in different directions at the two houses. The Met would have to face up to the fact that its magnificent orchestra is often simply too loud. Although the Met's music director is, at his best, an opera conductor with only one or two peers and no betters today, a comparison of his broadcasts with those of earlier decades speaks irrefutably: not about the balance per se, but about the level of sheer strain on stage. The effect on performance is profound.
The City Opera's problem is harder to address because the acoustics of the State Theater are such that only an exceptionally large and well-produced voice can seem powerful there, and such voices quickly become too expensive. To make matters worse, it is difficult to hear the orchestra from the stage when it plays softly (monitors are employed to pipe sound from the pit to the singers). This is a serious situation: The kind of company Mr. Keene seems to want and the theater in which it plays may be in irresolvable contradiction.
 
Should Revivals Take a Back Seat?
 New York's opera season, like most throughout the world today, is oriented around new productions, when new operas are introduced, or - far more often - when new scenery, costumes and blocking plans are bestowed on already familiar operas. The latter was of little moment until recent decades (Covent Garden's first ''Boheme'' sets were used from the 1890's to the 1960's; the Met's lasted almost as long; today, a 30-year-old production is ancient, and few make it that far).
The problem is that everything that is not a new production becomes a second-class citizen. The working assumption is that once the production is ''set'' in its opening run, reviving it is more or less a logistical task. Singers are permitted to arrive later; cast changes run rampant; conductors (often of little stature) are given less rehearsal time; an assistant director with a prompt-book and close to zero moral authority arranges stage traffic.
This is disastrous, and the limp, sterile results are on regular display. Except physically (the sets and, to an extent, blocking), a production has no continuing existence. Real action - character action - exists only to the extent that it is real and right in the moment it is happening. And this is what makes or breaks an opera dramatically. A revival needs the same caliber of creative energy, and the same kind of team effort, as any opera at any time. It gets nowhere near that here; even the best productions (for instance John Dexter's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites'') sag.
Can this be remedied within the repertory system that requires the curtain to go up seven times a week, with four or five operas juggled at once?
In the stagione system of planning, each opera can be taken up separately, with the full spirit of the house behind it, and given a run of closely spaced performances. There was a time when repertory and stagione were viable alternatives, but that was when opera houses had stable rosters that worked together over a whole season and when shared assumptions on both sides of the footlights made detailed stage rehearsal needless. Today, everyone realizes that something like stagione planning is necessary; the repertory houses simply cram it into the schedule as best they can. At the Met this takes the tone of formidable, faceless corporate efficiency in operatic mass production; at the City Opera there has been something of that element, but also something of the hectic improvised bargaining of a bazaar.
So why not abandon the repertory system? Because the companies have painted themselves into an economic corner: To go to the two to four performances a week that are usual in Chicago, Milan and London, our houses would either have to maintain salaries despite huge loss of revenue, or face bloody confrontations with their unions. Real leadership for management and labor both will mean laying the groundwork for evolutionary change: toward fewer performances in the quickest and most equitable way possible. Present schedules are simply unsustainable if artistic quality is in question.
Such an effort would have to be gradual, but even as it began, the ideal kept in distant view could fuel improvements in the present.Mr. Keene's plan - six performances a week but only two operas - is a great step forward. The Met still juggles four or five, but that is fewer than it used to do. Further reduction (especially in midseason) and closer spacing of the performances of a given opera would help make the total run manageable for visitors; never mind if this requires shaking up the broadcast schedule and subscription schemes.
 
How to Encourage New Productions
 The repertory system also discourages the production of new operas or of difficult and unfamiliar old ones. With the Met's untenable position that only an average capacity over 90 percent will do, and with the perceived necessity of ameliorating the cost of a new production over revivals, a new piece would have to be a masterwork to avoid being a failure. And since token novelties rub shoulders only with masterworks, not with a decent allotment of other new operas, any failures will be glaring.
But here, too, attitude is the most important thing. There are opera houses that give premieres happily (Houston and Santa Fe, for two - and Chicago has announced a bold program leading into the 21st century). They assume that their public is intelligent enough to understand that masterpieces cannot be guaranteed in advance; the public, or a decent part of it, returns the compliment by paying good money for a chance to watch an experiment. When a company puts on a modern work while holding its nose, clearly communicating that duty, not passion, is being pursued, that work is at death's door. When the house is really behind a piece - when management knows the opera and follows rehearsals eagerly, when the composer and performers can feel in the air and hear in the corridors how seriously their efforts are taken - then possibilities blossom. By no means do the progressive houses succeed with each new work, or even a majority: but they have a fighting chance, and are that much healthier because the fight is being fought.
This, of course, requires a manager who likes the idea of flying around watching new operas, who looks not for what he thinks he can get his audience to tolerate, but what he thinks he can sell with missionary fervor. This has been a traditional City Opera role that has faltered in the 80's; ostensibly innovative repertory was duly introduced, but with spotty and half-hearted results. Mr. Keene will have to do better.
There is another major question: Should New York in the 90's and beyond entrust opera solely to the Lincoln Center companies?
The alternatives have historically been of two kinds. Well-meaning shoestring operations do a service for amateur performers, aspiring youngsters and buffs curious to hear a little-known work even in sketchy form. And brief tour appearances by important European companies (the Finnish National, English National, Bolshoi, Paris and Scala operas, in the last quarter century), make important moments in New York operatic life. Neither of these, of course, can sustain the season in a great city with a large opera public.
There remains an unfilled need for high-level, philanthropically funded opera in a house of 1,200 seats or less. In the meantime, the Brooklyn Academy's Opera Project (directed by Matthew Epstein under BAM's president, Harvey Lichtenstein) is begining to provide a much-needed stimulus.
''Falstaff,'' a Welsh National Opera production directed by Peter Stein, was a good example of a highly focused ''traditional'' performance that transcended its components. None of the voices was of Met caliber (and yes, this matters); still, something happened. And then there was Lully's ''Atys,'' a production musically innovative and stunning, theatrically vivid without being either ''period'' or ''avant-garde.'' It was the result of one man's (William Christie's) personal conviction about the work and his ability to form an ensemble apt to it: the power of creative leadership and intensive musical preparation. A manager of vision is drawn to such a project like a magnet.) Here is an optimist's view of New York opera in the 90's. The Met, fired by a new sense of mission, makes dramatic improvements in its conducting and directing rosters; redefines rehearsal periods; works its way down to five performances a week by 1997; turns its back firmly on mindless gigantism but exploits its scenic resources imaginatively; combines canny fiscal micromanagement with seigneurial disdain for conventional wisdom about what will sell; represents conservative opera in its best sense, honoring precious traditions through loving, thoughtful renewal. The City Opera leaves Lincoln Center and becomes home base for America's best innovative designers, directors and composers; every new production is a hot ticket. Singers in both houses make more music and less noise. It becomes un-chic to grasp at trendy talk-show stardom. BAM keeps us all on our toes with the most interesting European work. A new company (or a mini-Met) creates a fresh New York tradition of intimate opera, led by a music director interested in the advances of early-instrument playing and fresh historical approaches to performance.
Here is a worst case: Met management decides that Disneyland is a perfectly good artistic exemplar; philistinism reigns and full houses are cited as proof that taste is bunk. City Opera, devastated by dwindling support and a protracted strike in 1995, closes its doors. Financing problems curtail the BAM initiative, and opera recedes ever more decisively from the leading cultural role it once played.
The reality will lie somewhere in between. But just think how much brisker and fresher the air will feel if everyone pulls together to get close to the first alternative.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: TOUGH TALK FROM TOKYO;
What to Do When Japan Says 'No'

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE SUMMER; Lawrence Summer is Nathaniel Ropes professor of political economy at Harvard University.

 BODY:
Dear Mr. Morita and Mr. Ishihara:
Most American economists, myself included, reflexively oppose any sort of policy proposal that interferes with free domestic and international markets. Your new book, ''The Japan That Can Say 'No','' shakes my faith, and will, I am convinced, shake the faith of many others as soon as they get hold of their bootlegged copy.
As with pornography, your unwillingness to permit your book to be marketed in the United States has only served to increase the demand for it. It will become more and more influential with the passage of time, for it performs an important educational function by demonstrating that if war is too important to leave to generals, international trade and economic policies are too important to leave to the lawyers and economists.
You both make it clear that Japan's strategy has not been one of maximizing the consumer's gains from trade. Policy makers in Japan do not regard keeping the prices of imports low to consumers as an important priority. Instead, economically, financially and technologically, Japan has tried - and succeeded in - converting the Japanese-American relationship from one of Japanese dependence to one of mutual dependence. You make it all too clear that the risk, from an American viewpoint, is that before too long, the United States will depend heavily on Japan, but it will not be mutual. 
Given your respective roles as a major Japanese industrialist and a prominent politician - perhaps the Lee Iacocca and Richard Gephardt of Japan - you must expect that your words will be taken as a serious reflection of Japanese attitudes.
Mr. Morita's analysis of American problems points in the right direction and is not as overblown as we would like to think. His asserts that ''We are focusing on business 10 years in advance, while you [the United States] seem to be concerned with profits 10 minutes from now. At that rate, you may never be able to compete with us.'' And he is supported by the record. Last year, Japan, with half our population, invested more heavily in plant and equipment than did the United States.
 
Pearl Harbor
 Mr. Ishihara's message is much less familiar and more disturbing. When prominent Japanese politicians seem to be spoiling for a fight with the United States, one can hardly expect that they will not get one. Professing to truly respect Minoru Genda, the planner of the Pearl Harbor attack, and quoting approvingly his view - ''Japan will be all right. It is able to defend itself. Japan's technology can be the basis for Japan's defense'' - is not the way to reassure Americans about Japan's intentions.
Nor is your own geopolitical assessment about the United States very reassuring. You write: ''No matter how much they continue military expansion, if Japan stopped selling them chips, there would be nothing more they could do.'' And you observe: ''If, for example, Japan sold chips to the Soviet Union and stopped selling them to the United States, this would upset the entire military balance.'' This means that Japan has leverage. You continue: ''Japan's technology has advanced so much, that Americans get hysterical - an indication of the tremendous value of that card, perhaps our ace. My frustration stems from the fact that Japan has not utilized that card in the arena of international relations.''
This is not to say that you are factually wrong. The Pentagon's Defense Science Board in 1987 concluded that ''U.S. military forces depend heavily on technological superiority to win. Electronics is the technology that can be leveraged most highly. Semiconductors are the key to leadership in electronics. U.S. defense will soon depend on foreign sources for state-of-the-art technology in semiconductors. This is an unacceptable situation.''
Besides the technological leverage you stress, there is also the question of financial power. So far the Japanese have used their financial power to stabilize the United States and world economies. At the insistence of the Japanese Ministry of Finance, Japanese insurance companies and other financial institutions lost tens of billions of dollars trying to stabilize the dollar's decline in 1986 and 1987. These losses represent a larger outlay than all of America's postwar assistance to Japan, even after allowing for price inflation.
 
A Dollar Free Fall
 But they may not always be so generous, particularly if confronted by American policies they do not like. If Japanese investors were to stop rolling over their investments in Treasury bills and certificates of deposit, the dollar would go into free fall, and America's financial institutions would be seriously threatened. Japanese deposits in many major American banks now exceed the value of those banks' capital. In such a situation, the Federal Reserve would have its hands tied. Providing liquidity would send the dollar through the floor, but protecting the dollar by raising interest rates would risk massive bank failures.
As you are at pains to point out, while American dependence on Japan may be increasing, Japanese dependence on the United States is declining. As the Soviet Union crumbles, and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cozies up, the American security umbrella means less and less to Japan.
Japan may have needed the American market in the past, but the booming economies of Asia will provide an important outlet for Japanese capital in coming years. Already, Japanese Government research centers have formulated plans for an ''Asian Brain'' operating out of Tokyo that would control the disposition of investment throughout Japan, and in the industrializing countries of Asia.
You also raise the ominous possibility of major Japanese involvement in the Soviet Union or China. Japanese businessmen are said to have been the first out of China after last spring's uprising and to have been the first back in. Mr. Gorbachev desperately needs hard currency to make his reforms work. What better way to get it than by giving a few islands back to Japan and inviting them to develop Siberia's vast resource pools? An economic alliance with the Soviet Union would also reduce Japan's dependence on Western raw materials.
Your book makes it very clear that when it comes to Japan, the United States now faces the dilemma of using or losing its economic leverage. There are omnious signs already. When American officials have sought to impose sanctions on Japan in recent years, as in the aftermath of Toshiba's illegal sales to the Russians, they had to face opposition from hundreds of American companies that protested that a cutoff of Japanese components would put them out of business. I hope as awareness of your book spreads, the United States will take the steps necessary to counter the threats you issue.
First, we must start investing in America. You are right to insist that America's competitive problems are of its own - not Japanese - making. As long as the United States consumes, publicly and privately, more than 97 cents out of every dollar it earns, Americans will not be able to make the physical investments necessary to make American producers competitive again. But the physical capital gap is less important than the human capital gap. Because of their longer school day and school year, the average Japanese 18-year-old has spent more time studying than the average American M.B.A.
Second, the United States needs to think seriously about the strategic implications of the composition of American production. No major corporation buys key components by searching for the lowest price at each moment without regard to issues of the security and continuity of supply. No major economy should either. When American purchasers of high-technology items shift to foreign sources, they impose a cost on the rest of the economy by increasing our vulnerability. There is little to be said for a laissez-faire attitude toward industries upon which our future security depends. Americans should be debating not whether, but how to restore their preeminence in the ''ace card'' semiconductor industry.
We economists have a congenital weak spot here. Just before the OPEC cartel became effective in the late 1960's and early 1970's, economists were urging that oil import quotas be abolished to help consumers, because dependence on foreign oil could not pose a serious threat to American security, since a cartel could never form. Those who resist efforts to maintain a viable semiconductor industry should remember that sorry episode. No one knows whether Sematech will work out. There certainly is a risk that the Government will have wasted its money. But this risk is small compared with the risk posed by America's dependence on a supplier of vital military parts whose leaders openly threaten a cutoff.
Third, the United States needs to carefully consider its approach to the newly industrialized economies of Asia. They are natural allies for the United States. They do not welcome suggestions like Mr. Ishihara's observation that ''those Asian nations where the economy has been a success story, such as Korea, Taiwan, and Singapore, were all, at one time or another, under Japanese administration. We are aware that some negative things happened under the Japanese administration, but it cannot be denied that many positive changes were left behind.''
 
Bargain for Results
 But our current Grenada-style trade policy of lashing out at small Asian nations for the sins of Japan is well calculated to drive them into the arms of the Japanese. Rather than condemning these countries' trade surpluses, the United States should applaud the successful development strategies that have made them possible and urge the developing nations of Latin America, Eastern Europe and Africa to follow their example. We should seek to draw these developing countries closer to us.
Fourth, Japanese mercantilism should be aggressively confronted. The Structural Impediments Initiative should be abandoned forthwith. We have far more urgent priorities than getting Japanese stores to open on Sundays or bringing shopping malls to Japan. And our negotiators must have better things to do with their time than listening to Japanese lectures about what is wrong with America's business culture.
The United States learned a lesson in dealing with civil rights. Only when policy shifted to a results-based standard, in which companies were presumed to have discriminated if they did not achieve certain hiring goals, did it start to have real effects. The same logic suggests that we should lead a worldwide effort to establish goals for Japanese imports of manufactured goods. If these goals are not met, we should find ways of retaliating that would harm Japanese commercial interests without hurting American consumers. For example, before imposing new restrictions on Japanese imports, we could convert existing restrictions from quotas to tariffs so that the Treasury captures the rents now enjoyed by American producers without producing shortages. Alternatively, we should insist on a renegotiation of current tax rules that give Japanese investors in the United States a free ride.
I do not know what motivated you to write ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' but I am glad you did. You have helped remind an excessively complacent economics profession that some things like national security are more important than good jobs at good wages. And I suspect your America bashing may have made a stronger case for a new American policy toward Japan than any American ever could.

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Shearson May Sell Stake to Outsiders

BYLINE: By WILLIAM S. NIEDERKORN

 BODY:
Raising capital was on the agenda last week at two top securities firms. An outside investor became a possibility at Shearson Lehman Hutton. Under the proposal, American Express, which owns 62 percent of Shearson, would sell some of its shares. Wall Street sources said seven potential bidders have expressed interest in buying a large percentage of Shearson's stock. ''We are deeply into developing a plan that we hope will answer the questions of the rating agencies,'' Peter A. Cohen, the Shearson chief executive, said. Also, Drexel Burnham Lambert will require its best-paid employees to take a portion of their year-end bonuses in Drexel stock rather than cash. The firm's commercial paper was downgraded by Standard & Poor's.
 
*
 The head of Deutsche Bank A.G. was killed Thursday when terrorists detonated a remote-control bomb, demolishing the automobile in which he was being driven to work. Alfred Herrhausen, 59 years old, died instantly and his driver was seriously wounded in the blast, which occurred in Bad Homburg, a fashionable suburb of Frankfurt. 
 
*
 The Soviet Union and the European Community agreed on a 10-year trade pact that would ease quotas for Soviet goods and increase technical cooperation. Separately, a Soviet enterprise that makes jet fighters has teamed up with Gulfstream to try to build a supersonic corporate jet.
 
*
 OPEC decided to revise its quota system to give Persian Gulf oil producers a firm grip on the group's prices and production in the next decade. It also agreed to raise its overall production ceiling.
 
*
 The index of leading indicators fell four-tenths of a percent in October after a rise of three-tenths of a percent in September. The drop was the biggest since May. The United States trade deficit deteriorated slightly, to $27.75 billion, in the third quarter. The nation's economy grew at a rate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said. It also reported that in October, construction spending rose 1 percent and consumer spending fell to its lowest level in nearly three years. Prices for raw farm products rose by 1.4 percent in November over October, the Agriculture Department said.
 
*
 Lackluster sales were reported for November by several leading department stores. The purchasing managers index declined in November by a percentage point, to 46.6 percent. A reading below 50 generally means the manufacturing economy is deteriorating. Orders for American machine tools dropped 32.3 percent in October over September, according to the Association for Manufacturing Technology.
 
*
 Japanese companies are in talks to acquire Perkin-Elmer's semiconductor equipment operation, one of the last American makers of devices used to etch circuits on chips. Senator J. James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, and Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of New Jersey, asked the Administration to bar a sale of the unit to Nikon. Nikon said it was not currently in talks to buy it.
 
*
 The Big Three auto makers suffered serious sales declines in mid-November, while Japanese auto makers posted sharp gains, as overall sales of domestically produced cars slumped 6.1 percent.
 
*
 The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 41.38 points on Friday, to 2,747.65, for a gain of 80.10 on the week. The yield on the Treasury's long bond was virtually unchanged, ending at 7.87 percent. The dollar rose on Friday but was down slightly for the week against all major currencies. Gold was down $5.30 an ounce on the Comex, at $413.60.
 
*
 Miscellanea. Northeast Utilities would acquire the Public Service Company of New Hampshire under a plan filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court, to which all major parties involved have agreed . . . The White House science adviser said the Bush Administration did not endorse a recommendation to provide Federal subsidies for the semiconductor and consumer electronics industries . . . Hungary's Minister of Trade predicted that trade with the U.S. would double by the early 1990's . . . Deutsche Bank agreed to buy Morgan Grenfell, one of Britain's biggest merchant banks, in a friendly deal that values Grenfell at $1.48 billion . . . General Mills and Nestle said they were creating a company to sell breakfast cereals in Europe . . . Campeau set a deadline of Dec. 8 for initial bids on its Bloomingdale's chain, executives said . . . The S.E.C. accused a typesetting supervisor of illegally trading on informationfrom advance copies of Business Week.

HEADLINE: FOR MIGRANT WORKERS, LEGALITY LOWERS WAGES

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP; Kathleen Sharp is a business writer based in Santa Barbara, Calif.

DATELINE: SANTA MARIA, Calif.

 BODY:
Thanks to the Federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, some 700,000 migrant workers in California's $16.6 billion agricultural industry have applied for legal residency in the United States. But the stamp of impending legitimacy has yielded a mixed harvest for workers.
Union organizers say the fields are flooded with legal workers, a condition that is driving down wages and encouraging abuse by employers. In Salinas, for example, at the northern tip of California's 600-mile-long Central Valley, wages have fallen from $7 an hour in 1984 to $5.50 an hour, said Peter Maturino, president of the Independent Union of Agricultural Workers. In winter, wages drop to $5 an hour, he said.
A 1988 survey by Congress' General Accounting Office reported that 40 percent of farm employers were expecting a labor shortage in 1989. Once workers attained the status of legal residents, the reasoning went, they would apply for better jobs. But it has not worked out that way. 
''Although farmers worry that an insufficient supply of seasonal workers will cause them to lose a crop,'' wrote Philip L. Martin, professor of agicultural economics at the University of California at Davis, ''there has generally been an oversupply of workers.''
A section of the act that allowed a worker to apply for amnesty if he could prove he had labored in the fields for 90 days in the 12 months ended May 1, 1986, attracted 1.3 million applications, by Friday's deadline, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Serivce. Of these, 55 percent, or 700,000 workers, were in California.
This, combined with the lack of afforable housing, has not made for an easy life for these workers. The cost of buying a small house in this area has jumped from $75,000 in 1984 to about $120,000 today. And the number of labor camps, which provided free, if only the most basic accommodations, has dropped from 240 in 1979 to 22. ''You get 19 people living in two-bedroom apartments,'' said Mr. Maturino. ''What are you going to do with them? Kick them out?''
One clear benefit of the new law, however, is that workers finally feel free to complain about longstanding problems. They are filing a large number of formal complaints and lawsuits against employers.
''Before the law, they didn't complain about working conditions because they were afraid of losing their jobs,'' said Javier C. Sanchez, of the California Agricultural Labor Relations Board. ''Now, they are speaking out about unfair practices and asking questions about unions.''
And, for the first time this decade, the growing workers' dissatisfaction is spurring an increase in union activity, say regulators. ''There have been more union elections this year than I've ever seen,'' said James H. Woltman, chief administrative law judge for the California Agricultural Labor Relations Board. The most accurate measure of union activity, say officials, is the number of requests filed by organizers seeking to enlist members in the fields. From January through the first week of October, there have been 158 such requests, compared with 56 for all of last year.
The 1989 figure includes the election involving the greatest number of voters recorded by the California Agricultural Labor Relations Board since its formation in 1975, said Lawrence Alderete, regional director with the board's Visalia district. It took place in May at Furakawa Farms, a strawberry producer here, about 160 miles northwest of Los Angeles, with the United Farm Workers winning the right to represent the farm's 500 workers.
Complaints of unfair labor practices have also risen this year, dramatically in some regions, according to Daniel M. Cornet, of the Department of Industrial Relations, division of Labor Standards Enforcement.
Unwittingly, California courts have helped fuel the increase in complaints. In a controversial ruling named for Richard Borello, a cucumber grower in Gilroy, the California Supreme Court held that sharecroppers were employees, not independent contractors, as growers had long contended. As a result, growers must now pay the minimum wage, workers' compensation and disability insurance, and comply with the same child labor laws and regulations that govern other employers.
Sharecropping has long been a tradition among growers of strawberries, snow peas, cucumbers, and garlic - an estimated $500 million sector of the state's market basket, according to the California Agricultural Statistics Service of the United States Department of Agriculture. The system employed about 20,000 farm workers, who would plant, weed, water and harvest a crop in return for a portion of sale proceeds.
Because of the Borello ruling, some payroll costs are slated to jump as much as 20 percent next year. ''That's quite a burden for farmers,'' said Richard S. Quandt, president of the Grower-Shipper Vegetable Association of Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo Counties.
On its face, the decision was a victory for workers. But it wreaked havoc in the fields. Some growers responded by canceling sharefarming contracts. Others bought out contracts, paying from $470 to $1,300 each, or the equivalent of 82 cents to $2.26 an hour. ''Different growers reacted differently,'' said Mr. Quandt. ''Some ignored the ruling.''
The inequities prompted workers to file unfair labor charges and wage claims against employers. In Santa Maria, for instance, workers joined a class-action suit filed by the California Rural Legal Association against Furakawa Farms. The suit seeks three years of back wages.
As employees rather than contractors, former sharefarmers now have the right to organize, said Michael Blank, a lawyer for the California Rural League Association. In addition to its victory at Furakawa Farms, the U.F.W. also won an election at Dan D. Packing, a cauliflower and broccoli operation here.
The U.F.W. has had company. This summer, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters won the right to represent workers at Bud Antle Inc., a large grower of lettuce and celery in Oxnard, 70 miles north of Los Angeles. In Castroville, 125 miles south of San Francisco, the Independent Union of Agricultural Workers claimed a victory at Inland Ranch, an artichoke grower.
Some farmers are trying to keep unions at bay by hiring labor management consultants. Vincent B. Zininovich, who operates a 1,000-worker table-grape vineyard in Delano, hired a consultant when two unions started organizing his workers.
The footwork apparently paid off. In the October election, workers voted overwhelmingly to keep both unions out of the fields.
Union leaders say more victories await, thanks to amnesty. Depite their gains, however, the unions may be in danger of undermining their own efforts through internal squabbling. Leaders of both the Independent Union of Agricultural Workers and the Anti-Racists Farm Workers criticize the United Farm Workers for not representing the field worker during the last decade.
The U.F.W.'s attorney, David Avizmendi, declined to respond to the criticism. But clearly the divisiveness is blunting organizing efforts.
In early October, 900 workers at Mr. Zininovich's vineyard turned out to vote in one of the largest union elections in California. Listed on the ballot were the Independent Union of Agricultural Workers, the Anti-Racists Farm Workers, or no union at all. Although the U.F.W. had organized at the farm, it wasn't able to register enough signatures to qualify for the ballot, said Mr. Alderete.
The day after the U.F.W. failed to qualify, Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., asked the state's agricultural board to defer the election so the labor federation could determine whether one union had interfered with another union's organizing efforts, in violation of bylaws.
The agricultural board allowed the ballot to stand, however, to the dismay of field organizers. Although union leaders admit that their fractured organizing efforts helped lose the election, they have not agreed to coordinate future efforts.
''We're helping the workers secure better conditions,'' said Mr. Maturino. ''At least, we're trying.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1040 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Realignments on the Home Front

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SOMETIMES losing an enemy can be more unsettling than losing a friend. The world order that since the end of World War II has shaped American politics, its view of the world and itself has suddenly come crashing down.
Through two generations, nearly every politician of national standing has been defined in large measure by where he stood on, and how he stood up to, the Red Menace. Just last year George Bush ran campaign commercials saying he could look Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the eye and not blink. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis allowed himself to be shown riding in a tank built to fight a land war in Europe. 
But the end of the cold war should bring the end of cold war politics. A central idea has been plucked from the heart of American political culture, and party leaders and academic experts are just beginning to grapple with the import of this.
''Every night for 40 years we walked into the bedroom, opened the closet and looked under the bed to see if we could find a Communist,'' said Representative Dante B. Fascell, the Florida Democrat. ''And one day we walked in, and he was in our bed, smiling. It's very confusing.''
Democrats calculate that they stand to gain as attention shifts away from fears of war to concern with the domestic issues that have been their bread and butter. For their part, Republicans concede they have lost an issue that helped them more than Democrats. But they hope benefits will flow to the party whose hard line, in their view, brought Communism to its knees.
Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic National Chairman, declared that the changes in Europe will ''help the Democratic Party immensely.''
The political dialogue will be thrown open to issues the Democrats feel stronger on, like education and the environment, said Mr. Brown, and ''it really does take a major arrow away from the Republicans.''
Perhaps, say Republican leaders. ''If our candidates are foolish enought to campaign as if the cold war were still on they'll get hurt,'' said Lee Atwater, the Republican National Chairman. But Mr. Atwater disputes suggestions that the Republicans will suffer at the polls now. President Reagan's hard line with the Soviet Government - indeed, with Marxist governments everywhere -helped produce the decline of Communism, he said, and George Bush will benefit by being at the creation of this new world.
Shortly before Mr. Bush left for his meeting in Malta with Mr. Gorbachev, some in Washington thought back to how Winston Churchill was ousted by the British voters almost immediately after the end of World War II. But Mr. Atwater sees no parallels. He said that while Americans are restless about the quality of life, they are not battered and hungry the way the British were. ''As long as the economy stays stable I am firmly convinced that the party in power benefits,'' Mr. Atwater said.
Some leaders in both parties concede they do not know what this will all mean. For one thing, the course of events in Europe is still far from clear. A retrenchment, either in Eastern Europe or in the Soviet Union itself, could revive cold war feelings here.
James McGregor Burns, the historian, suggests that the cold war cannot have a clearly defined ending. ''The cold war is not over because there will remain a huge reservoir of thinking from the cold war period still in the minds and attitudes of the American people,'' he said. ''That reservoir of feeling will be played on by politicians.''
Surveys support Mr. Burns. In a New York Times/CBS New Poll conducted last week, more than half of all adults who were questioned said they thought the cold war was not over yet. And the poll found general support for what Mr. Bush calls his ''prudent'' approach (and what Democrats call timid). A total of 67 percent of those interviewed either supported current levels of military spending or small reductions, such as Mr. Bush is currently considering. Just 21 percent said Pentagon spending should be subject to deeper cuts than have been proposed.
It may well be that the ultimate effect on American politics will not be to help one party over the other, but to fragment both. The stress on the Republicans is already clear. ''The collapse of Communism also means the collapse of a lot of the glue that has connected the various strands of the conservative movement,'' said William Bodie of the Smith Richardson Foundation, which supports many conservative groups.
Strains on both parties may result to the extent that economic concerns replace military and ideological ones. Fred Siegel, a historian at the Institute for Advanced Studies in Princeton, N.J., noted that the tariff battles of the 19th century tended to cause divisions within the parties as local economic interests overrode national ones. The same thing might happen again as each region weighs its place in the world market.
Anti-Communism has been central to the Republican Party, but it has also shaped politics among the Democrats. Not long ago, talk of the Jackson wing of the party referred not to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, but to Henry M. Jackson, the late Senator from Washington state whose support for military preparedness against the Soviets helped cement the bipartisan consensus of the cold war.
Some Democrats have tried to follow in Senator Jackson's footsteps in recent years, seeking to build reputations as strong supporters of the Pentagon. But already the scramble for new issues is under way. Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee, who sought the Democratic Presidential nomination last year as a hawk in a field of doves, has spent much of this year talking about environmental problems raised by the greenhouse effect.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York gave speeches last week on American competitiveness. Mr. Cuomo even used words reminiscent of the cold war talk of missile gaps. ''The Japanese and the Germans are moving ahead of us economically,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''It's a war for markets. It's a war for productivity and quality products. And you're losing now.''
Perhaps the American psyche has been so conditioned that it must regard the world in terms of wars and foes. Perhaps more likely, it will simply take some time to get used to the new world.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Turnstile Politics: Preparing for the $1.15 Token

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
LAST Monday, it seemed all but certain that New York City's $1 subway and bus fare would jump to $1.25 on New Year's Day.
But after a long hearing, the $1.25 fare - and a plan to sell 18 tokens for $20 - was fading fast. Transit Authority officials were talking instead about a $1.15 fare and no discount.
It sounded very much like the original blueprint that had been hammered out in Albany three years ago. 
What was behind the apparent retreat? Some suggested that the $1.25 idea had been a gimmick to allow politicians to rail against it - and look like heroes when they agreed on $1.15.
Transit officials insisted there was a more innocent explanation. ''My sense of what happened is simply that the public reaction killed the $1.25, $20-pack plan,'' said John Cunningham, chief spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency.
Judging by appearances, that could have been the case. On Monday, about 150 outraged citizens, joined by 17 elected officials, denounced the plan during an 11-hour public hearing in Manhattan. Many said that they simply could not afford it. ''$1.25 for What?'' was the title of a survey of subway services by the Straphangers Campaign, a rider-advocacy group, whose members argued that while improvements had taken place in subway service since the 1987 fare increase, the overall quality remained mixed - good on some lines and dreadful on others.
Others, like Beverly Dolinsky of the Transit Authority's citizens' advisory council, argued that there should be no fare increase without ''mitigating measures,'' such as multitrip discounts, and until the agency showed improvement in controlling fare evaders.
Some influential politicians, notably Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, let it be known that while they were prepared to accept a fare increase, they were unconvinced by the Transit Authority argument that a $1.25 fare would be logistically easier to handle than $1.15 because fewer coins would be involved. Moreover, Mr. Cuomo and others said the agency had no grounds to violate the 1987 agreement with its unions, the Governor and the Legislature, which provided for the $1.15 fare.
The agreement, which cleared the way for a five-year $8.5 billion capital investment - $6.6 billion of which was to go for subway and bus improvements - was based on an estimated M.T.A. budget deficit of $200 million in 1990, and on the conclusion that a 15 percent fare increase was the only way to close it.
Another assumption was that the 1990 fare increase would be followed by rises every other year that would roughly equal inflation, along with increases in tolls on bridges and tunnels controlled by the M.T.A. This, officials said, would have a long-term stabilizing effect on the fare.
''To climb out of a seemingly bottomless hole, everyone has to help by giving up something,'' Felix G. Rohatyn, a principal architect of the 1987 plan, wrote in a recent commentary. ''In return, the public at large gets something immeasurably larger than what has been sacrificed.''
But last week, not everyone was buying the idea that the projected deficit should come out of the riders' pockets - or that the deficit, at least a $200 million one, was unavoidable. The feeling deepened when the head of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced plans to raise tolls on those bridges and tunnels.
Some critics, like State Senator Franz S. Leichter of Manhattan, a longtime opponent of many M.T.A. policies, proposed that the Legislature close the deficit by taxing the rich, preferably through a surcharge on the capital gains tax on large industrial or commercial real-estate sales.
''The Transit Authority wastes prodigious sums,'' the senator said, asserting that the agency could save $40 million just by eliminating ''nonessential positions'' among what he described as its many highly paid executives.
Others also called for eliminating what the M.T.A.'s Inspector General and the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, have described as millions of dollars of wasteful practices.
Mr. Regan has also accused the Transit Authority of painting an overly rosy picture of its financial prospects over the next several years, suggesting that it has overestimated anticipated ridership and revenue from real-estate-related taxes and other sources.
The assumption behind the 1987 agreement was that if a huge sum of money was used to begin correcting long-term problems on the transit system, riders would begin to return.
To that end, the Transit Authority began buying and refurbishing subway cars and buses, eliminating graffiti, and repairing tracks and modernizing signal systems, while improving maintenance and on-time performance.
Unfortunately, the 1987 Wall Street crash, combined with social problems like homelessness and crack addiction, has thrown a monkey wrench into the agency's best-laid plans, and ridership has not gone up as much as officials would have liked.
On top of that, David L. Gunn, the Transit Authority's president, acknowledged, ''The public's perception of a lack of order on the system, resulting in part from numbers of homeless people, beggars and peddlers, has also deterred potential customers.''
As of last week, there was little to suggest that the city's long slog out of the ''seemingly bottomless hole'' was any closer to an end.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 25, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 887 words

HEADLINE: Is Eastern Europe Ready?

BYLINE: By Tad Szulc; Tad Szulc was The New York Times's bureau chief in Prague in 1968.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When Tadeusz Mazowiecki became Poland's first postwar non-Communist Prime Minister on Aug. 24, the euphoria at home and abroad was extraordinary. His ascent resulted from the overwhelming victory of the Solidarity-backed opposition over Communist candidates in the relatively free parliamentary elections in June -the first since 1946 - and it represented a turning point in Polish history.
Today, after Mr. Mazowiecki succeeded in the tough task of forming a coalition Government that has the primary job of averting economic collapse, he has been the target of such violent attacks from all sides - often from the new democratic press -that the survival of Poland's infant democracy may be in question.
This is the most alarming news to come out of Eastern Europe. My authority for alarm about Poland - and for concern that, if extreme care is not taken, similar situations may develop in other Eastern European nations - is primarily Jerzy Turowicz, Poland's most respected and courageous editor. 
His Roman Catholic-oriented weekly, Tygodnik Powszechny, defied Communist rule for 40 years despite merciless censorship. I was shocked to read in the Nov. 5 issue his front-page denunciation of the increasingly divided Solidarity and other democratic groups for joining the bankrupt Communist Party in undermining Mazowiecki programs through savage and irresponsible criticism.
He wrote: ''In the present and really exceptional situation, it is vital to have the absolute solidarity of the democratic forces with the Government of Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who was entrusted with the responsibility of squaring the circle . . . . Yes, let there be criticism of the Government, but only the kind that will help the Mazowiecki Government, not interfere or undermine [it]. Otherwise, the attempt to evolve from totalitarianism to democracy will not succeed.'' Poland's drama illustrates the horrifying problems facing Eastern Europe. Mr. Turowicz's warning should be taken with utmost seriousness. Because the Poles are the most advanced in the democratic direction and have had the most time to prepare for the transition, the Hungarians, East Germans, Czechoslovakians and Bulgarians must closely watch their experience.
The common demoninator in all of today's Eastern European crises is that the anti-Communist opposition -including the Poles, with nearly 10 years of Solidarity behind them -has not been remotely ready for the sudden unraveling of Communist rule: There are vacuums in political organization, leadership and programs.
Warsaw's problems are atrocious. Mr. Mazowiecki inherited a crippled economy, with inflation running at a monthly 100 percent rate (it is now 50 percent), a $40 billion external debt and a huge domestic deficit.
Perhaps his austerity program should have been better designed. Nonetheless, the tragedy is that it is being attacked not only by the Communists, who delight in seeing the democrats divided and paralyzed, but also by so-called liberal democrats, who are sniping for reasons of shameful political self-interest.
Hungary, where the Communist Party has formally abolished itself, is split over how to organize democracy. In last Sunday's referendum, the voters chose to delay indefinitely the presidential election out of fear that even a Communist reformer might win - but the margin of decision was surprisingly tiny.
Much ugliness, including new anti-Semitic tendencies, pervades Hungary's political climate. The economy is in bad shape despite vaunted reforms by party ''progressives,'' and heavy political infighting lies ahead. Meanwhile, no credible non-Communist leadership has emerged.
In East Germany, the Berlin wall is a memory, as is the Honecker regime, but the Communist Party remains in power, probably for a long time to come. The opposition born in the streets is not equipped to challenge it: The New Forum and the Citizens Democratic Movement are not political parties, there is no Lech Walesa and the anti-Communists are thus in no hurry to face the party in elections promised for 1990.
It is too soon to assess the Czechoslovak situation, but the Communists are still very much in control despite power-sharing commitments. The freshly organized Civic Forum does not regard itself as a political party. Months may elapse before traditional (or new) parties are organized. The new opposition lacks the leadership and programs of the liberal Communists when they launched the ''Prague Spring'' in 1968.
Internal democratic quarrels along with the democratic structural weaknesses suggest that Mr. Turowicz's gloomy prophesies for Poland may come true throughout the region.
If so, conditions may well be created for reactionary backlashes from the Communists, whose bureaucracies remain strong - and who run most of their countries' affairs because nobody is yet available to replace them - or from the right, which would impose neo-fascism complete with reborn anti-Semitism.
In the most pessimistic scenario, democratic failure in Eastern Europe could undermine Mikhail Gorbachev and perestroika. After all, it was Mr. Gorbachev who helped democracy flower among the former satellites, and, if disaster occurs, his domestic enemies will not let him forget. This should be a sobering thought in the midst of our euphoria over Eastern Europe.

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 25, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 784 words

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
New Summit Question

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta

 BODY:
There's a noticeable feeling of edginess as superpower leaders meet here to seek a grasp on a dizzily changing world.
The weather turned miserable shortly before Presidents George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev arrived, gale-force winds and driving rain making everybody wonder why on earth they're meeting on ships. A crack going around the meeting is that events in Europe were already running beyond their influence, but Malta proves they're impotent when it comes to controlling the climate.
Obviously this is a summit meeting that may mark a watershed. The Soviets hope so. They are looking for a declaration that can be presented as a ''common philosophy,'' a ''bottom-line concept'' of understanding on facing historical transition. 
Americans probably exaggerate when they say Moscow wants guarantees for what will happen in Europe. It's less in one way, more in another. The Soviets want to be sure things won't go too fast, especially in the Germanys. They would like changes to be predictable, which is asking too much, and they would like to feel that their security interests will be respected by all, though they are redefining them as their empire comes unstuck.
There is fear of domestic reaction and the doom of perestroika if disorder in East Germany should reach the point of attacks on Soviet troops. They are worried about extremists of all kinds, ''from the left or the right'' as one official put it. But even solid West Germany couldn't prevent the murder of the head of the Deutsche Bank.
Various Soviet officials discuss Germany's future and possible unity with different accents. Moscow's position isn't as solidly cemented as headlines make it seem. In their concern to slow the pace, the Soviets haven't appreciated the importance of pushing for early East German elections. There's no political organization with authority there now, no leaders who can speak for what people want.
Everybody knows what they don't want. But if they aren't offered concrete steps soon, a demand for quick reunification, which nobody else wants, could become inevitable. Calling for elections in late spring could launch an orderly political process, produce legitimate authorities who could deal with East and West in the rational way Moscow urgently seeks. Elections late in 1990 would coincide with West Germany's, an unsettling prospect.
The Soviets are pleased, after all, with the way relations have developed with the non-Communist Polish Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, after a moment of initial panic. They would be wise to urge East Germany to produce a representative government soon. That would make it easier for Washington, Bonn and others to show they take account of Soviet concerns.
The 35-nation Helsinki summit meeting Mr. Gorbachev proposed for late 1990 represents the evolution of his thinking, something more concrete than the ''common European house'' rhetoric, with the U.S. and Canada included, but not institution-building or alliance-threatening. The ideas are fuzzy because they haven't been worked out, but they no longer seem to be driven by propaganda. He does feel the need to show his people he is leading them into a safer world.
Arms control is necessarily a part of that, for political, psychological and economic reasons. It's not in the foreground of this meeting because current negotiations have already reached the point of largely technical issues. But if the Soviets can persuade Mr. Bush, there will be something said about going ''beyond Start,'' enhancing ''strategic stability,'' perhaps a major shift away from multiple-warhead missiles Mr. Gorbachev's push to include naval forces in conventional-arms cuts is rejected by the West at this stage. But it is something the Soviets will keep coming back to, probably arguing for removal of nuclear weapons from surface ships as a first step, an idea already launched by the former U.S. negotiator Paul Nitze. Now that Moscow has come up with ''minimal deterrence'' in Europe, instead of the utopian ban on all nuclear weapons, its argument is that the U.S. nuclear guarantee will be assured on land and needn't be reinforced on European seas.
On this point of short-range missiles, a surprise Soviet proposal is likely, whether in Malta or later. That is to cut tactical and shorter than the now-banned intermediate-range nuclear arms to 500 to 1,000 warheads. It would be a dramatic reduction for Moscow, much less for NATO.
But weaponry is less and less the issue as the sense of trying to make another kind of Europe grow. Not using them and getting rid of some is a great first step. Then what? It's a new question the summit meeting can't answer. But at least it's being asked.

HEADLINE: Letters

 BODY:

CAN A NOVELIST SAVE PERU? pretends to answer the question of whether Mario Vargas Llosa can ''save'' Peru (as if the days of one-man rescue missions still existed!). He focuses on the dilemma of a novelist-turned-politician who can no longer use his imagination, because ''in politics you have no use for the imagination'' (something I hope is vigorously contested). He offers an interesting psychological look at the novelist (for those interested), but he doesn't tell us what plans Vargos Llosa has to subdue the entrenched Maoist guerrilla movement, nor does he tell us what Vargas Llosa is offering, outside of free-market medicine for an economy gone awry, or what he will do to overcome the growing problem of narcotics trafficking.
The article quotes Vargas Llosa as saying, ''People have suffered so long, they are willing to suffer a little longer - if we can show them it is not for nothing.'' Easy for someone to say who has lived far away from Peru in the comfort of London for much of the past two decade; a trip to the southern highlands, where poverty and desperation gave birth to the guerrilla movement may teach Vargas Llosa that people can wait only so long.
 
JO-MARIE BURT
 New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: JUST ANOTHER NIGHT ON CRACK STREET

 BODY:
Philippe Bourgois provides a chilling account of East Harlem's drug culture (''Just Another Night on Crack Street,'' Nov. 12). The men and women he has lived with and observed appear to be ambitious and resourceful, albeit painfully misguided. They also appear to be firmly entrenched in their deviant life style. But what of the children growing up in this environment? Are they doomed to follow in the footsteps of Mr. Bourgois's subjects? If they have to choose between the underground and the service economy, we all will be losers.
 
JARED BERNSTEIN
 New York, N.Y.
