PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 28, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 3352 words

HEADLINE: BATTLE OF THE BEAUTY COUNTER

BYLINE: By Patricia O'Toole; Patricia O'Toole is a Connecticut-based business writer.

 BODY:
PATRICIA FRENCH, THE founder and president of Gazelle International, a black-cosmetics company, makes no secret of her ambitions. She says she spent most of a recent flight from Paris to New York engrossed in a biography of Helena Rubinstein. As for her publicist's claim that French will be ''the next Estee Lauder,'' the 33-year-old former model and makeup consultant smiles and says, ''We all have to have a goal and a dream.''
As the careers of Estee Lauder and Helena Rubinstein so amply illustrate, the titans of the beauty business have most often been women. Now another generation of entrepreneurs - including French; Naomi Sims, a 70's supermodel, and Juin Rachele Cooper, a former cosmetics executive - have staked their hopes on a new and fast-growing segment of the market: the stylish, affluent black woman.
The road has not been smooth. Department stores, the traditional marketplace for upscale cosmetics, have been in the throes of consolidation, creating an unreceptive climate for any new product lines. Moreover, the established leaders in ethnic cosmetics - Flori Roberts Inc. and Fashion Fair Cosmetics, owned by the Johnson Publishing Company - are aggressively pursuing the same segment. So are such mainstream cosmetics giants as Avon Products, Estee Lauder Inc. and the Revlon Group. 
Small wonder. The potential rewards are substantial. In the last decade, the number of black women in the work force has grown by 35 percent, and their median weekly earnings have risen by 70 percent. In addition, blacks typically spend more on personal-care products, from mouthwash to cosmetics, than whites. ''If you're black, you are trying your very best to make sure there is no reason you might be disregarded or thought less of,'' explains Kathryn D. Leary, president of Jamison & Leary, a black-owned advertising agency in New York. Industry analysts predict that the market for black cosmetics, now at about $450 million a year, could soar to $990 million by 1995.
IT WAS NOT UNTIL 1967 THAT A cosmetics line for black women found its way into the prestige department store market, and the products were the creation of a 38-year-old white publicist named Flori Roberts. Two years before, at a fashion show in New York, Roberts had heard several black models discussing the tribulations of using makeup meant for white complexions. She was surprised to discover that the models were putting together their own foundations, powders, eye shadows and blushes, mixing and matching various brands and colors until they hit on shades that worked.
Back home in New Jersey, Roberts discussed the subject with her husband, Craig, an ophthalmologist with a subspecialty in plastic surgery who had studied the chemistry of black skin. She also began buttonholing dermatologists and beauticians to learn all she could about the properties of black skin.
Roberts found that all skins are chemically identical, except for the size of the granules of melanin, or dark pigment. But the mere fact of color creates a welter of distinctions. The darkness makes oily areas gleam, while dry patches tend to have an ashy appearance. And blemishes can often leave permanent spots that are particularly difficult to cover. Then there is the matter of ''black'' itself: the term embraces more than 30 skin tones that include the undertones of red, yellow, blue and black. The Caucasian palette has fewer hues, and less variation on undertones of red, yellow and brown. Because of that difference in undertones, foundations and powders blended for white skin tend to look orange or gray on black skin.
Black women have traditionally used cosmetics intended for white complexions, creating their own versions at home or buying them at the neighborhood beauty salon. A number of small firms offered cosmetics actually designed for black women, but distribution of their products was limited to beauty salons, drugstores and other mass-market outlets. Since 1970, several companies that marketed black hair-care products have entered the field, including World of Curls in Compton, Calif., and Chicago-based Johnson Products (no relation to Johnson Publishing).
After Flori Roberts had spent a few months asking questions, she engaged a laboratory to translate her findings into samples of a cleanser, a moisturizer and a full line of makeup. Because of the crucial matter of undertones, the samples were produced in a wide range of colors; they were also made oil free, to avoid the shiny effect of oil on black skin.
In 1966, Roberts founded Flori Roberts Inc. in Lakewood, N.J. Throughout the year, she toted her wares to conventions and black-owned salons, with no success. Then, in 1967, she began making the rounds of department stores. ''Buyers would say, 'Our black customers use the cosmetics we already have,' or 'Blacks don't shop in department stores,' '' she recalls. Roberts was convinced that if black consumers were not coming in, it was because they felt unwelcome.
Her breakthrough came that summer, when she finally placed her line at Bamberger's (now Macy's) in Newark. Black women flocked to the Flori Roberts counter. ''They couldn't believe we had foundations and lipsticks and eyeshadows in colors that were right for them,'' says Marion Boswell, a black woman who became Roberts's first beauty advisor. Strong sales at Bamberger's helped Roberts get into Burdine's in Miami, Burdine's led to Foley's in Houston and Flori Roberts Inc. had found its venue.
For six years, Roberts had the department-store market all to herself. Enter John H. Johnson, publisher of the Chicago-based Johnson Publishing Co. In 1973 Johnson asked Kolmar Laboratories, a cosmetics manufacturer in Milwaukee, to produce samples of a black-cosmetics line to be called Fashion Fair Cosmetics, and advertised it in Ebony. Within six months, the magazine had filled 100,000 orders. On the strength of that response, says J. Lance Clarke, vice president and general manager of Fashion Fair, a subsidiary of Johnson Publishing, Marshall Field agreed to carry the line, but without promotion. By month's end, Fashion Fair was selling briskly.
Though it took the new black-cosmetics line only two years to open 500 doors (in retailing, a ''door'' refers to a location where a product is sold), acceptance was not automatic. ''Department stores wanted us and they didn't want us,'' Clarke says. Many of the establishments that took a chance on the line were persuaded as much by Fashion Fair's ties to Johnson Publishing as by the cosmetics themselves - ties that gave Fashion Fair access to pages of free advertising and editorial support in Ebony and Jet.
For a time after Fashion Fair's start-up, Ebony stopped accepting Flori Roberts's ads. Roberts stepped up her campaign on black-radio stations; she was already a frequent advertiser in Essence, the leading magazine for black women. Both Roberts and Fashion Fair also held fashion shows with black sororities and other women's organizations and used increasingly sophisticated direct-mail campaigns to push beauty clinics and other in-store sales promotions.
The strategies seem to have paid off. By the middle of this year, Fashion Fair claimed to have 2,000 doors in the United States and Canada, and Flori Roberts, 1,200 in the United States. Both lines are sold in Europe, Africa, the Caribbean and Latin America. Fashion Fair's line has grown from 100 to 300 products; Flori Roberts now makes 170 items, up from 35. Industry sources put 1988 revenues for Fashion Fair at $60 million, and those for Roberts at $25 million.
BY THE EARLY 1980'S, MAINSTREAM retailers and manufacturers had come to realize how lucrative the market for black cosmetics might be. But Revlon, after launching a black-cosmetics line called Polished Ambers in the 70's, dropped it in 1982. ''We see to it that our lines offer a very wide range of shades, from the darkest to the palest,'' says Revlon spokesman Daniel J. Moriarty.
For generations, the Avon Lady's door-to-door-sales calls gave blacks an alternative to shopping in department stores, which catered mainly - if not exclusively - to whites. But Avon Products offered few shades suitable for black complexions. In 1986 Avon revamped its line, broadening the color range. Since the introduction of Avon Color Products, there has been a double-digit increase in sales.
Estee Lauder has also added deeper shades: Color Brilliance, its new line, includes nearly 50 items for dark complexions. But the company does not advertise the fact, which irritates many blacks. ''It's a 'by-the-way' sale,'' says Mikki Garth-Taylor, beauty editor of Essence. ''They [black women] go to the counter to buy something else, like mascara, and the salesperson mentions the foundations.''
Lauder managers deny discriminatory intent. ''We feel this market should not be segmented,'' says Vivian Behrens, a vice president of marketing. ''Today's ethnic consumer wants to be approached not as part of an ethnic group but as an American.''
TWO YEARS AGO, NAOMI SIMS and Alex Erwiah, then her brother-in-law, launched Manhattan-based Naomi Sims Beauty Products Ltd. A Mississippi native, Sims, 40, was the first black model to make the cover of such national magazines as Ladies' Home Journal in the 1960's. She had also written beauty books and developed a line of wigs and a signature fragrance. Erwiah, a 40-year-old native of the Ivory Coast, has for 14 years owned a cosmetics import-export business in New York that represents American cosmetics companies in Africa.
To distinguish itself from Fashion Fair and Flori Roberts, Naomi Sims focused on skin treatment rather than makeup. The main pitch: stress, fast food, pollution and other banes of modern existence were leaving their mark on black complexions, but Naomi Sims could help. By using only three products - a cleansing milk, chamomile cream soap and primrose rinsing lotion - for just three minutes a day, Sims promised, black women could have skin as healthy as their mothers.
Advertising extensively in local black media during the summer of 1987, the company invited black wom- en to Abraham & Straus in Brooklyn, where Sims and several beauty advisors would show them how to care for their skin. Hundreds of customers stood in line for hours.
In 1988, says Erwiah - who is C.E.O. and sole owner - revenues hit $5 million. With 60 products in 125 doors, he anticipates sales of ''$5 million plus'' for 1989. Yet Erwiah calculates that it will be at least two years before Naomi Sims shows a profit. Promotion and penetration of new markets are costly, and the company has invested heavily in new products, adding color cosmetics to its original skin-treatment line.
Erwiah has another problem: for reasons that are not clear, Naomi Sims is no longer on the scene. Sims, whose title is chairman of the board, is unavailable for interviews and has no scheduled department store appearances. When asked to describe Sims's current role, Donna Italiano, the company's spokesman, will only say, ''I guess primarily the same as an Estee Lauder. Naomi has established the brand, and now she has taken pretty much of a back seat. Alex is the sole owner and Naomi Sims collects royalties.'' Italiano does confirm that Sims has been ill and was recently hospitalized in Manhattan.
While some observers question whether Naomi Sims Beauty Products can succeed, absent a compelling, credible figure with whom black women can identify, others declare that the day of beauty queens like Estee Lauder has passed. ''Today's cosmetics companies are selling image more than personality,'' says consultant Natalia Holynskyj of Kline & Co., a market research firm in Fairfield, N.J. ''Even Estee Lauder has changed. The company doesn't use the Lauder name with its Clinique and Prescriptives lines.''
THE IDEA OF CREATING COSMETICS for dark-skinned women came to Patricia French in the spring of 1981, while she was traveling in the Ivory Coast. A native of Warner Robins, Ga., French had moved from Detroit to Paris earlier that year and begun working as a freelance makeup artist. On one of her assignments, she flew to Africa to oversee the makeup for a group of models. ''I realized,'' French says, ''that African women had distinct beauty problems.''
While in Africa, French linked up with Amale Ayad, a chemist who had done research on skin-care treatments for black women. They began testing a range of moisturizers and lotions. In 1986, backed by $4 million raised mostly by French's husband, Lawrence Charfoos, an attorney, Gazelle International introduced its first 13 items.
In Paris, where the company is based, the line was launched at Galeries Lafayette, a department store, and heavily publicized in the black media. At the same time, the American debut took place at several Rich's department stores in Atlanta.
French says worldwide sales for 1989 will be $3.5 million, half of that from Gazelle's 34 doors in the United States. Abroad, Gazelle's 45 products can be found in 66 doors in France and in a number of former French colonies in Africa and the Caribbean. Like Naomi Sims Beauty Products, Gazelle has yet to break even. ''I've put in over $7 million so far,'' says French. ''I've been losing money since I started. I tell myself it's not a loss, it's an investment.'' She projects that it will take another $2.5 million infusion before Gazelle turns a profit.
FOR HOUSTON-BASED JUIN RACHELE Cosmetics, the price of doing business in department stores has proved too high. Juin Rachele Cooper, a former Max Factor executive, and her husband, Patrick D. Cooper - natives of Jamaica in their 40's - unveiled a line of 157 items at Saks Fifth Avenue and other stores in 1986. Sales topped $1 million in three months.
Patrick Cooper now thinks that Rachele could not have picked a worse moment to begin. ''We were getting started at a time when department stores were consolidating,'' he explains. ''They were trying to cut costs, and they asked us to pay expenses that we didn't think were fair.'' He was under the impression that retailers would pick up part of the tab for promotion. ''In the beginning they tell you they'll pay half, but with the exception of a West Coast store, we've never been able to get them to chip in,'' Cooper says. He claims his company felt the greatest pressure to increase sales at Bloomingdale's, where management went on a cost-cutting campaign in 1988, after Campeau Corporation's highly leveraged purchase of Bloomingdale's parent, Federated Stores.
At Saks, says Patrick Cooper, Rachele could not make ends meet. For 30 hours a week, Rachele posted a makeup artist at the counter; the rest of the time the line was to be sold by Saks employees. ''Most of them are white, and many are older,'' he says. ''The buyer worked hard to get us support, but it was difficult to get these saleswomen to recommend products they would not use themselves.'' Rachele also received complaints from black customers, who said they were not getting the help they needed. ''They felt the salespeople didn't want to touch them,'' Patrick Cooper says. Though he describes Saks managers as ''very concerned'' when he relayed the complaint, he claims, the situation did not improve.
A Saks spokesman, who declines to be identified, denies Patrick Cooper's assertions and insists that the store gave Rachele ''a tremendous amount of support'' in the form of publicity. Pointing out that Saks was ''the first to buy and the last to drop'' the Rachele line, she says it was ''a decent product, but there was no market expertise or follow-through. He [Cooper] had a makeup artist at the counter sometimes, but he didn't do it consistently.''
In August 1988, after piling up debts of $1.3 million and losing another $1.2 million, the Coopers filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition in Texas and started over. Their first decision was to pull out of department stores. Juin Rachele Cosmetics now consists of two boutiques in Houston shopping malls and a mail-order business based on customer lists compiled at Rachele's former department-store counters. Relieved of the expenses of doing business with major retailers, Patrick Cooper thinks Rachele can break even on much smaller sales.
SELLING COSMETICS IN DEPARTMENT stores has always been a costly affair. Traditionally, the manufacturer gives the retailer a 40 percent discount on its products; the company also pays for all or part of the advertising and promotion, and covers the commissions for sales staff, which range from 3 to 10 percent. Since manufacturing costs often come close to 25 percent for small entrepreneurs who don't enjoy the economies of scale of a Revlon or Estee Lauder, that leaves only 25 percent for everything else - staff, product development and, if all goes well, profit.
Still, none of the black-cosmetics makers has priced its products in the upper reaches of the prestige lines for white skin. For example, the least expensive of the ethnic products is one of Flori Roberts's liquid foundations, at $11 an ounce, while Naomi Sims makes a cream foundation that, at $20 an ounce, is the costliest. Yet all are well below the top-of-the-line liquid makeup from Estee Lauder, with its $30-an-ounce price tag.
Moreover, none of the fledgling cosmetics companies for the ethnic or the mainstream market - let alone the scores of fly-by-night shops characteristic of this business - has the deep pockets of the giant concerns, a distinct disadvantage in department stores. Says the cosmetics buyer for a leading specialty chain: ''With counter space getting more precious, I have to ask, 'Will this pay off or should I fund another product?' There is definitely a need for black cosmetics, but cosmetics can't be sold without expensive, consistent multimedia support. The big guys are in the magazines every day. You won't get market share unless people know about you.''
THAT ATTITUDE ANGERS SOME blacks. ''We can't be Estee Lauder overnight,'' snaps Michael Bellamy, vice president of sales at Naomi Sims. Unable to mount a media barrage, Naomi Sims runs ads in Essence and relies on local promotion. On a small scale at least, the strategy appears to be working. For its recent opening at the Toledo branch of Jacobson's, a Midwestern specialty chain, Naomi Sims put out the word to local black women's groups and persuaded Jacobson's managers to welcome them with a store tour and a credit card application. In the first week, sales hit $5,000.
Gazelle looks for retailers willing to invest time as well as money. ''It may take an hour to convince a black woman to buy one cream,'' says Patricia French. ''After using a lot of Caucasian products that haven't worked, she's afraid. But once you convince her, she's a loyal customer.''
Overall growth in cosmetics sales has slowed from about 10 percent annually a decade ago to 6 percent a year, and discounters are gradually winning customers away from upscale department stores, which have seen their market share drop to 15 percent from 18 percent three years ago. Yet, industry analysts predict that cosmetics sales to blacks will rise 10 to 13 percent annually for the next several years -twice the rate of the industry. ''At the moment, there are no mass-market ethnic lines out there to compete with the wide selection offered by department-store lines,'' says Sandra A. Wheeler of Ardnas & Associates Ltd., a Chicago marketing consultant.
In addition, claims Patricia French, the black woman wants to shop in department stores: ''She is moving in the opposite direction of the market. She bought mass cosmetics for years, and now that her income is growing, she is moving upscale. She will continue to come to the department stores because that's where she finds the products she likes.''
Nor does the mass market appeal to black-cosmetics entrepreneurs. ''The Lauders and Cliniques and Lancomes haven't gone mass; they've stayed with class,'' says Lance Clarke of Fashion Fair. ''We're in top stores, and we want to stay. I haven't enjoyed class for so long that I want to leave.''

GRAPHIC: Patricia French, head of Gazelle, and her makeup artist, Karen Leak, demonstrate their products to a customer at Strawbridge & Clothier in Philadelphia (pg. 28); Naomi Sims with Alex Erwiah, C.E.O. of the cosmetics company that bears her name (Jeff Scales)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 27, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 3505 words

HEADLINE: CAPTURING C.E.O.'s FOR POSTERITY

BYLINE: By Grace Gluek; Grace Glueck is art news editor of The Times.

 BODY:
''IT SEEMS TO BE A LAW OF NATURE,'' WROTE SIR MAX Beerbohm, the late English essayist and caricaturist, ''that no man is ever loath to sit for his portrait. A man may be old, he may be ugly, he may be burdened with grave responsibilities to the nation . . . but none of these considerations, nor all of them together, will deter him from sitting for his portrait.''
In the Manhattan studio of Everett Raymond Kinstler, a prolific painter of powerful men, Sir Max's ''law of nature'' is at work. ''A little straighter, John,'' says Kinstler. ''I don't want you to look as if you're slouching.'' John C. Angle, the retired chief executive officer of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, complies, a benevolent smile on his golf-tanned face, as Kinstler puts the finishing touches on the mellow likeness. Silver-haired and dignified, wearing gold-rimmed glasses and his C.E.O. uniform - dark suit, vest and rep tie - Angle looks every inch the model of a major corporate mover. 
He is participating in a retirement ritual almost as familiar in high echelons as the gold watch and the goodbye dinner - the board room portrait. The artist's version of the Angle visage, set against an architectural motif from Guardian's 78-year-old headquarters in Manhattan, will take its place in the company board room, along with portraits of earlier C.E.O.'s. ''I'm deeply conscious of the history of the Guardian,'' Angle says, ''and I'm happy to continue in the tradition of its portraits.'' Then, with a gracious nod to the artist, he adds, ''I'm sure this will be the outstanding one in the board room.''
Even in an era of corporate takeovers, as brisk rounds of musical chairs propel C.E.O.'s from one company to another, the portrait tradition endures. ''There may be more interest now than ever,'' says Marian MacKinney, director of Portraits Inc., a Manhattan gallery that matches artists with corporate clients. ''Fewer executives seem to think that having one's portrait done is a form of vanity, and they are finding the experience less intimidating.'' According to Ruth Sullivan, director of the portrait section of Grand Central Art Galleries, ''In the last five years our portrait business has increased by 300 percent.''
Kinstler, for example, whose long roster of subjects includes President Gerald R. Ford, John Wayne and Katharine Hepburn, has recently painted Alfred Brittain 3d of Bankers Trust New York, Robert Anderson of Rockwell International and Warren Anderson of Union Carbide.
The dean of the portrait profession, William Draper, whose commissioned subjects include the late Shah of Iran and President Richard M. Nixon, has recently painted both John R. Opel and Thomas J. Watson Jr. of I.B.M., and Edson W. Spencer of Honeywell. And Aaron Shikler, whose suave renderings appeal to sophisticated tastes - and who regularly shows work unrelated to his portraits in an uptown Manhattan gallery - counts among his subjects of distinction (besides John and Jacqueline Kennedy and Ronald and Nancy Reagan) William S. Paley of CBS and Time Inc.'s Andrew Heiskell, the retired chairman, and Hedley Donovan, the former editor in chief.
Although in recent years some corporations have elected to immortalize their chief executives in photographs, most still opt for paintings or sculptures. ''There's a sense of stability and permanence about an oil painting that you don't get from a photograph,'' says John Angle. Kinstler explains, more grandly, ''The camera records a moment, the painter makes a statement.''
One of Kinstler's recent ''statements'' is his portrait of William E. Simon, former Secretary of the Treasury, for Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., which built an economics research center with Simon's gift of $3 million in 1984. (Aside from board rooms, grateful institutions such as schools and hospitals provide popular settings for executive art.) In the three-quarter-length portrait of Simon, the smiling donor is seen in a striped shirt and rep tie, but with his suit coat hooked casually over one shoulder. ''He arrived in a dark suit,'' wrote Kinstler in the 1987 edition of his book, 'Painting Portraits,' ''and I suggested he pose in his shirt, since he tends to be informal. I asked him what he would normally do with his jacket, and he suggested this.''
But when Simon raised $15 million in 1986 - through his own and other donations - for what was to become the William E. Simon Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Rochester, the school and several of Simon's friends went for a full-length bronze. It was chosen, explained Dean Paul W. MacAvoy in Simon Business, the school's publication, ''to express the level of energy and initiative of our goals and our new patron.'' The six-foot-high sculpture by Wayne F. Williams depicts Simon in the same informal pose as Kinstler's portrait.
At the dedication, Simon said he hoped the bronze would become a reminder ''that the real treasure of the capitalist system lies here in our people's intelligence, faith, ideas and knowledge.'' In an interview recently, however, Simon took a more casual. ''I don't sit still long for things like that,'' he said. ''I don't think much of self-aggrandizement. Still, it's nice to be recognized in that fashion.''
NOT EVERY EXECUTIVE FEELS that he should loom large in the board room lineup. Take the case of the late Cleveland Dodge, at one time the chairman of the board of Teachers College at Columbia University and a director of Phelps Dodge, the giant copper company. He asked Raymond Kinstler to make another version of a portrait the artist had done for Teachers College, to be hung in the Phelps Dodge board room. ''He asked if I could make it smaller than the other board room portraits,'' says Kinstler. ''I asked why, and he said, 'Because I haven't done that much for the company.' ''
The process of choosing a portraitist can be casual or quite formal. After Kinstler had been selected by the Federal Government in 1974 to do the official portrait of Simon as Secretary of the Treasury, artist and subject became friends. So Kinstler was a natural choice to do Simon's portrait for Lafayette. Kinstler was chosen to paint Angle through a kind of old-girl network. Angle's wife, Catherine, had gone to Smith with Cora Lee Gibbs, whose late husband, Julian, had been president of Amherst College. Kinstler had painted Gibbs's portrait posthumously, and his wife mentioned it to the Angles.
''So then I called Ray,'' says Angle, ''and he came over with photographs of his work. I liked them. All that the company's human resources committee had said was that tradition should be carried out. If the portrait satisfied me, it was O.K. with them.'' But before Glaxo Holdings Inc., the American arm of the British pharmaceutical company, chose Zenos Frudakis to do a bas-relief and a bust of its retiring C.E.O., Joseph J. Ruvane, it hired an art consultant and set up a formal selection process.
''The portrait had been suggested by Dr. Ernest Mario, who replaced Mr. Ruvane as C.E.O.,'' says Jennifer McMillan, director of public affairs for Glaxo. ''He'd seen a relief of a president at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington and liked it, and we looked for an artist who could do a powerful statement.''
After scouting a number of art consultants, Glaxo settled on Art South, a company in Philadelphia, which showed them the work of several sculptors. ''We narrowed it down to two,'' says McMillan. She and Ruvane visited both artists, choosing Frudakis, whose studio is in Philadelphia.
It's not so easy to get a C.E.O. to sit still for very long, and portraitists sometimes depend entirely on photographs. But the top artists insist on sittings.
''I never use photographs,'' says William Draper, who takes no more than five days to do a portrait, and turns out some 15 to 20 a year, at prices ranging from $20,000 to $35,000, depending on the size. ''I paint very freely. They have to sit four hours a day, two in the morning and two in the afternoon. To get a portrait that pleases me and the sitter, we have to have a good time so he looks relaxed.'' To put his clients at ease, Draper will regale them with limericks and anecdotes; during breaks, he may play the baby grand piano in his studio to accompany his singing of slightly off-color ditties.
Aaron Shikler, too, tries to loosen up his clients during the four sittings he asks of them. ''Once they relax they get into poses,'' he says. ''The face in animation is usually the face that people know. The face in tight repose is not recognizable.''
Unlike Draper, Shikler - whose price range is from $75,000 to $125,000, depending on the complexity of the portrait - takes many photographs of his corporate sitters ''for detail work.''
In his studio recently, Kinstler, who spends an average of 80 hours on each portrait for a minimum of $15,000, was in the final stages of Angle's portrait, and occasionally stepped back to photograph his subject. ''I take photos frequently because after the pose is established different things begin to happen,'' he explained, ''and I want to have these for reference.''
The board room images that Kinstler and other artists paint are in most cases quite distinct from those they make to hang in less formal venues. ''If you do your own portraits of family and friends, you're free to paint within your esthetic ability,'' suggests Aaron Shikler. ''But when you paint a C.E.O., it's not just him but the corporation behind him.''
When he did the likenesses of Dr. Thomas F. Frist Sr. and Jack C. Massey, two founders of the Hospital Corporation of America in Nashville, Tenn., in the 70's, Shikler remembers, a third founder asked him to hold off on doing him. Dr. Thomas F. Frist Jr., who was younger than the other men by several decades, ''felt he didn't look old enough,'' says Shikler. ''At all times, C.E.O.'s have to be aware of stockholders.'' The younger Frist waited until he was 45, explaining, ''I thought I'd better get a few more wrinkles.''
One of the few female C.E.O.'s whose portrait adorns a company headquarters is Mary Kay Ash of Dallas, who in 1963, with her son, Richard R. Rogers, founded Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc., a multimillion-dollar corporation based on the direct sale of personal-care products.''Let's face it,'' says the 70-year-old chairman emeritus, ''there aren't that many women C.E.O.'s to begin with.''
She was painted twice with her son by the late Richard O. Skemp, as a gift from their employees on the occasion of the company's 20th anniversary in 1983. One portrait hangs in the lobby of the Dallas headquarters, the other in the executive offices on the eighth floor. She feels the portraits enhance the ''family'' atmosphere she has sought to create for the corporation.
THE TRADITION OF THE BOARD room portrait might be said to go back at least to the late 16th century, when institutions in the Netherlands commissioned group likenesses of their governors. In the 17th century, Dutch masters like Rembrandt and Hals were asked to paint officials of merchants' guilds; regents of almshouses and hospitals, and members of civic guards and militias. Rembrandt's ''The Night Watch,'' for example, is a group portrait of one of Amsterdam's civic guard companies.
In the 18th century, the artists Thomas Gainsborough and Thomas Lawrence did the leaders of the Equitable Life Assurance Society for its offices in London. They followed the conventions of Renaissance masters, who endowed merchant princes with the prestige earlier reserved for the nobility and the clergy. In 1782, for example, Gainsborough painted a full-length portrait of Sir Charles Gould, the fourth president of the company. The portrait still hangs in the Equitable board room.
Today's executive icon is also meant to be a piece of the company's history. Take, for example, a pair of portraits of Donald M. Kendall, former C.E.O. and now head of the executive committee of Pepsico Inc., and the late Herman W. Lay, who created the potato chip empire of Frito-Lay. In 1965, Lay merged his company with Pepsi-Cola, then headed by Kendall. The new company became Pepsico, with Kendall as chief executive officer and Lay as chairman. Their portraits now hang together in the lobby of Pepsico's headquarters in Purchase, N.Y. - both by John Howard Sanden.
''I had mine made to go with Herman's. We were extremely close,'' says Kendall. ''You have to look at it in a historical sense. We put the company together, and it's probably important to know how a company starts. When I leave, people who come afterwards will know.''
For Nynex, the international communications company spawned by the breakup of A. T. &T., Aaron Shikler did a full-length portrait of Delbert C. Staley, who recently retired as the company's first chairman. The portrait will hang at Nynex's corporate office in White Plains.''It's great that they wanted to recognize that I was the first Nynex chairman. Corporations do develop their own history, image and culture, and it's a nice way to start Nynex's.''
Most firms seeking portraitists for their C.E.O.'s tend to eschew venturesome artists for more staid practitioners with proven illustrational skills. That goes even for companies such as Pepsico and Nynex that collect art. Donald Kendall, who was instrumental in creating Pepsico's noted sculpture garden, which contains many outstanding modern works, and Delbert Staley, who has presided over the creation of Nynex's collections of contemporary art and 19th-century Hudson River paintings, both chose traditionalists to paint their portraits.
''Our clientele is not adventurous, generally,'' says Marian MacKinney of Portraits Inc. ''They don't want an artist who will give them too much of a painting.''
In England the same button-down attitude prevails. ''Most portraits,'' says Robin Gibson, curator of the 20th-century department at the National Portrait Gallery in London, ''have to fit in with the series of board room paintings that's already there.''
One sprightly exception is a portrait done in 1986 by the English artist Anthony Green for the Framlington Group in London, a middle-sized money-management firm. Ingeniously using skewed perspectives, Green depicted in life-size the three top Framlington executives at the time - Bill Stuttaford, Antony Milford and Tim Miller - in wilted workaday garb surrounded by the hardware and software of their trade. Behind them, the walls of the office bulge from the sheer dynamism of the enterprise.
The portrait, which caused a stir when it was shown in newspapers and at the Royal Academy in London, was commissioned by Tim Miller, then managing director of Framlington and a neighbor of the artist. ''Although it was only 15 years old, Framlington had become a very successful money-management firm,'' Miller recalls, ''and I thought it would be a good thing to have a picture, perhaps the beginning of a great collection.''
Green, a highly personal painter who says he takes on ''one portrait commission a year,'' was surprised by the assignment. ''But I set to work,'' he says. ''And I told them the painting could grow. If they added new men to the top management, I could paint them in; if the number was reduced, I could saw them off.''
Soon after the portrait was hung at Framlington, a hostile takeover bid succeeded. Tim Miller was out; his two teammates stayed on until this year. ''The portrait created a row because the people who were taking us over hated it,'' says Miller. ''One of the chief architects of the takeover looked at it with flashing eyes. 'That's the worst portrait ever painted,' he said. So when I left, I bought it, and now it hangs in my home.''
EVEN WHILE MANY CORPORATIONS remain conservative in their choice of an artist, there does seem to be a trend toward more informality of pose and dress. Raymond Kinstler notes: ''I'm a 20th-century painter, and in the last 8 or 10 years I've been able to persuade companies to go as they have with new architectural concepts - using backgrounds that reflect more color, open windows, people in more informal poses.''
Kinstler has painted Arthur Hauspurg of Con Edison, for example, in his shirt sleeves and a necktie, and Herbert V. Kohler Jr. of Kohler Inc., the plumbing-fixtures tycoon, in an open-collared sport shirt in an outdoor setting. ''Hauspurg came from Con Edison in a suit, and I took photos and sketched him,'' says Kinstler. ''Then I said, 'I'd like to see you in your office.' And there he was in his shirt sleeves. His secretary said, 'That's the way he is.' So that's the way it wound up.''
A refreshing change from the pin-stripe cliche is Daniel E. Greene's portrait of Robert Heffner III, a founder of G. H. K. Co., an Oklahoma City gas-exploration company. It depicts him in shirt sleeves, standing in a cluttered office surrounded - as in a Holbein portrait - by the attributes of his trade: maps and geological charts. ''His rugged looks suggested to me a character straight out of Ayn Rand's 'Atlas Shrugged,' '' says Greene.
Notable, too, for their informality are the portraits that Aaron Shikler has done of Time Inc. officials Andrew Heiskell and Hedley Donovan, both in their shirt sleeves. Although Delbert Staley insisted on wearing a jacket, Shikler managed to give him a casual air by portraying him with an overcoat draped over his arm - ''to avoid the Bachrach look,'' Shikler says.
As a matter of fact, Bachrach Photographers, image maker to American V.I.P.'s for 120 years, has itself gone into oil. Although its specialty is still magisterial color photographs, at prices ranging from $6,000 to more than $30,000, depending upon size, it also employs a staff artist, Arthur Pyykko, whose job it is to use Bachrach photographs to create oil paintings, should a client so desire.
The portrait in bronze, once a fixture in corporate headquarters, has seen something of a revival of late. Though bronze is more expensive than oil on canvas because of the high cost of casting, it is even more durable and dignifying. But the prices for bronzes run about the same as for oil portraits. The sculptor Zenos Frudakis, for example, charges between $10,000 and $30,000 for a bronze portrait.
In 1986 and '87, Allen H. Neuharth, former chairman and C.E.O. of the Gannett Company, was the subject of three bronze busts by Wendy Ross, a sculptor in Bethesda, Md. - though her only direct contact with him was a single dinner. From then on, she used videotapes and photographs supplied by Gannett. Two of the bronze busts rest at the home offices of two newspapers Neuharth founded, Florida Today, in Melbourne, Fla., and USA Today, in Arlington, Va. The third bust is part of a trio that includes Frank Gannett, the founder of the newspaper conglomerate, and Paul Miller, a former C.E.O. The works are displayed in the 31st floor rotunda of the company's headquarters in Arlington, Va.
Bronze is traditionally a stuffy medium. Not so the life-size statue of T. Boone Pickens, general partner of Mesa Limited Partnership of Dallas. Done by Leonard McMurry from action photographs in 1979, it portrays the flamboyant financier in shorts and a T-shirt, wielding a racquetball racquet. The bronze was given to Pickens, an avid player, by his employees, and now confronts them as they enter Mesa's fitness center in Amarillo, Tex.
Glaxo chose bronze to immortalize Joseph Ruvane because, according to McMillan, the public affairs director, his achievements called for ''more than a painting.''
''I sat for Zenos three times,'' Ruvane says, ''and during the process, he must have taken 500 photos. He worked on the bust and the bas-relief simultaneously, and we had great conversations.'' When the bas-relief was finished, Ruvane complained that his tie was crooked. ''But then,'' he recalls, ''we looked at the photos, and in every one, my tie was crooked. Zenos fixed it with a flick.''
HARD AS AN ARTIST MIGHT work to give a corporation what it wants, it's inevitable that some portraits have to be reworked or even redone. As Raymond Kinstler sees it, ''You usually have more problems with those who pass on the portrait than the subjects. I may negotiate, and make adjustments. Or I may say, 'I don't see it that way and I can't change it.' ''
Portraitists are often accused of flattering their subjects - or at least not probing beyond an acceptable likeness - and those who do board room portraits are by no means exempt from the charge. Most deny it, however. Kinstler, for example, says, ''I don't consider it my job to flatter people.'' On the other hand, he notes, ''Many of the men I've painted have served the company all their lives.''
Adds William Draper: ''I don't flatter people. I paint them the way they look at their best, the way they look to me. And usually they try to look nice.'' Asked if he makes them look younger, the 76-year-old artist said, ''A lot of that depends on how old you are when you paint. Everyone looks young to me, now.''

GRAPHIC: Zenos Frudakis sculpts a bas-relief of J. J. Ruvane, former C.E.O. of Glaxo; William E. Simon by Wayne F. Williams; Delbert Staley of Nynex by Aaron Shikler; Everett Raymond Kinstler puts finishing touches on a portait of John Angle, former C.E.O. of Guardian Life; (Jodi Bruen; others courtesy of the artists) (pg. 27); a portrait by Anthony Green of the top echelon of the Framlington Group, a British money-management company, in 1986: Bill Stuttaford, Antony Millard and Tim Miller (Mayor Rowan Gallery) (pg. 46); a 1782 portrait by Thomas Gainsborough of Sir Charles Gould, head of the Equitable Life Assurance Society in London (Derek Hudson/Sygma) (pg. 48)

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 20, Column 1; Business World Magazine

HEADLINE: THE LITTLE INDUSTRY THAT COULD

BYLINE: By Eden Ross Lipson; Eden Ross Lipson, an editor of The Times Book Review, is the author of ''The New York Times Parent's Guide to the Best Books for Children.''

 BODY:
AT THE WAREHOUSES OF HARPER & Row in Scranton, Pa., it was Christmas in September. The weather was hot and muggy, but crews were working like veritable elves, filling holiday orders from bookstores all over the country. No Grinch would steal Harper's Christmas this year. Five million books had left the warehouse in August; a similar number was rolling out in September.
When Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation bought the venerable publishing house two years ago, he primarily had his eye on the adult titles. He poured more than $2 million into modernizing Harper's warehouses. But lo and behold, as the 1989 Christmas rush proceeded, almost half of the books pouring out of the 300,000-square-foot facility were children's titles.
It is an industrywide phenomenon. Adult book sales have been flat for several years, while sales of hardcover children's books in the first seven months of 1989 were nearly 15 percent ahead of the 1988 pace. For paperbacks the seven-month increase was an astounding 51 percent. 
Elizabeth Gordon, a senior vice president at Harper & Row and the 46-year-old publisher of Harper Junior Books, had left her New York City office to visit the warehouses that September day to discuss shipping procedures for a new line of mass market children's books to be introduced next year. But she took time out to walk to the warehouse balcony and savor the scene below.
Dozens of cardboard packing boxes bearing the blue-and-white Harper logo were carried by a conveyor belt past shelves loaded with fast-selling books. Workers known as ''pickers'' rapidly pulled titles off the shelves, filling the moving boxes. In the warehouse were pallets with titles that sold so fast there was no reason to put them on shelves. With three exceptions - new books by the writer Erma Bombeck and the television comedian Roseanne Barr and a longtime Harper best seller titled ''The 8-Week Cholesterol Diet'' - all the books Gordon could see were Harper & Row children's classics: Maurice Sendak's ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' Shel Silverstein's ''The Giving Tree,'' Margaret Wise Brown's ''The Runaway Bunny,'' E. B. White's ''Charlotte's Web.''
In a prominent corner position was the pride of the warehouse, skid number J-40. There sat the boxed sets of ''Little House,'' nine paperback books by Laura Ingalls Wilder. The books, most of them published in the 30's and 40's, continue to sell at the rate of 80,000 a year at a price of $29.95.
For Liz Gordon, who had devoted herself to Harper's children's books for 16 years, it was a scene of personal triumph. But in retrospect it was a bittersweet moment. Just seven weeks later, Harper & Row issued a terse announcement that Gordon had decided to leave the company. She said later, ''You either accept another way of doing things, or you go. And my decision was to go.'' Industry speculation was that Murdoch, the new owner, was going to broaden the marketing of juvenile books and that Gordon's bailiwick would soon find itself with a new look. Murdoch has made sweeping changes in virtually all of the publishing properties he acquired. But after Gordon's resignation, George Craig, Murdoch's choice to head Harper & Row, insisted, ''We are in the business of maintaining the classy, high quality children's book publishing that is our inheritance and the company's heritage.''
Book publishing is a $13 billion-a-year business. In 1988, text books, professional and technical books accounted for $6 billion; book club sales, reference books and other specialized markets were worth another $3 billion. So-called trade books (hard cover and paperback books sold in book stores) and mass market paperbacks (less expensive editions that are issued in a standardized format and distributed through newsstands as well as bookstores) were responsible for $4 billion in sales. This year, sales of children's trade books alone are expected to exceed $1.5 billion.
THE REASONS ARE DEMOGRAPHIC. Four million children will be born this year, the same number as in 1953, at the beginning of the baby boom. Says J. Kendrick Noble, publishing analyst for Paine Webber, ''The boom will continue for at least 10 years because most children's books are sold to, or for the use of, 6 to 12 year olds.''
In children's books, the economic structure of the adult-book world is turned on its head. The typical adult book is marketed to have a shelf life of two months in hard cover, after which unsold copies are shipped back to the publisher for a full refund. Successful titles may continue in a paperback edition or possibly be sold to the movies. But, with the exception of blockbuster best sellers and classics that survive for generations in paperback, an adult book usually dies within two or three years.
Advances to authors of adult books can soar into the seven-figure range. Harper & Row, industry sources estimate, lost $300,000 on David Stockman's insider view of the Reagan White House, for which the company paid $2.4 million. ''Children's publishing,'' says Gordon, ''has been somewhat immune to the things that have hit adult publishing, because the amounts of the advances have been on a smaller scale.''
First printings are decidedly small (as little as 3,000 copies for a new author) and it can take almost two years to determine a book's success. Unlike the adult sphere, current best seller lists are almost irrelevant since children's books become established first in libraries and schools - roughly two-thirds of all juvenile books are bought by these institutions - and then begin to sell in bookstores.
''Librarians are held to be the experts in the field,'' says William C. Morris, Harper Junior Book's director of library promotion and advertising. These keepers of the junior literary flame make their selections based on recommendations in trade publications or follow the lead of the numerous children's book prizes.
Through this trickle-down system, a juvenile book may earn the writer considerable royalties. ''The books can be around for five, ten, twenty years,'' says Gordon. ''The authors have five, six or seven books that are making money.'' Contrary to adult publishing operations, these backlists generate a constant stream of earnings for children's book divisions.
In 1988, Harper issued a 25th anniversary edition of Sendak's ''Where the Wild Things Are''; it sold 100,000 copies in hard cover and 300,000 in paperback. Assuming Sendak received the standard royalty, he earned $274,200 on that edition in the last year. Harper & Row's annual operating profit on such a book, is estimated to be about $300,000.
ELIZABETH GORDON, A DOCTOR'S daughter from Lawrence, L. I., and a Cornell graduate, received her master's degree in English from New York University. In 1966, she attended the six-week-long publishing procedures course at Radcliffe College and then took a job at the small, prestigious house of Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
Gordon found herself in children's books, a quiet backwater of the book publishing industry. In the aftermath of Sputnik, the first satellite to orbit the globe, Washington made $100 million available to libraries for ''curriculum- oriented'' books. But for the most part children's divisions were considered a minor operation.
Editors of juvenile books, however, approached their jobs as a calling. Like the librarians, the editors saw themselves as guardians of the portals of children's literature. In 1973, Gordon moved to Harper & Row as an associate editor.
Harper Junior Books is neither the oldest nor the largest children's department; those honors belong respectively to Macmillan, which was established in 1919, and to Western, which produces the inexpensive Golden Books. But under Ursula Nordstrom, Harper & Row had nurtured many of the executives who define children's books today: Susan Hirschman of Greenwillow Books, Phyllis J. Fogelman of Dial Books for Young Readers and Charlotte Zolotow of Charlotte Zolotow books (a Harper & Row imprint). And, under Nordstrom, the company developed the backlist that supports the division to this day.
Ursula Nordstrom, who died last year, was not a college graduate, a teacher, a librarian or a mother; her qualification for heading ''Harper Books for Boys and Girls,'' she told a prominent librarian, was that she was ''a former child.'' She had already taken partial retirement when Gordon joined the department.
''She had an incredible instinct for what was a good children's book,'' Gordon says. ''And she could drive a hard bargain.''
By 1975, when Gordon became a full editor at Harper, the country was in recession; Federal funds had dried up and the entire book industry was stagnant. Several publishing houses either eliminated or pared down their children's departments. At the time, Gordon considered leaving Harper. ''In some sense I was bored,'' she says in her direct, unflinching way. ''If you were a woman, particularly a woman in the children's book department, nobody taught you about the business end of publishing.''
In 1977, Gordon enrolled at N.Y.U.'s night program for a master's degree in business administration, with a specialty in management and corporate development. ''I wouldn't put myself up there with the great children's book editors,'' she says with a grin. ''I have other talents: running things, putting together whole programs, managing people.'' The following year, she married Neil Lowenbraun, a manager at I.B.M. Their son, Matthew, is now nine years of age.
Meanwhile new opportunities were beckoning: the children's book business was being invigorated by a new wave of eager baby-boom parents. Stephen Roxburgh, the 39-year-old publisher of Farrar, Straus & Giroux's children's books, explains that ''My generation grew up just when the Government put a lot of money into public education. You didn't have books in the house, but you had access to books at the library. Today, my generation buys books and wants children to have books.''
Last year, 3.7 trade books were bought for every child in the United States, versus 2.1 trade books for every adult. Those figures do not include book clubs, which sell millions of books to children in school as well as to adults.
Just before Gordon finished her M.B.A., Norman Pomerance, group vice president in charge of Harper's general book program, offered her the post of publisher of Harper Junior Books and Trophy, then a small trade paperback line. One week later, Gordon assumed the title of publisher for T. Y. Crowell's and Lippincott's children's book departments as well.
''I initially thought of the M.B.A. as language study, that I would learn to speak to people in the treasurer's office,'' Gordon says. ''But it also gives you analytical skills and a means of looking at situations in terms of being financially responsible for a division.''
In 1982, when Gordon took over, net sales of children's books were $18 million; for 1989, they are projected at $50 million.
To snare prize authors, who make those kinds of sales possible, children's book publishers are just beginning to offer big advances. Last year Houghton Mifflin paid $801,000 at auction to win the right to publish a new children's book, ''Swan Lake,'' with text by Mark Helprin and illustrations by Chris Van Allsburg. Prices for previously published series of books, which can be issued in trade or mass paperback editions, are also rising steeply.
Book club, recording, film strip and toy licenses build reputations and establish awareness of authors and characters. Thus there is intense competition to reclaim paperback licenses for children's books that have been sold to other companies. This past spring the Dell Publishing Company bid more than $6 million to keep 17 books by Beverly Cleary in its Yearling line of trade books for elementary school readers. But Dell was outbid by Avon Books, which bought the titles for mass market paperbacks.
Classic titles - rediscovered by parents and passed on to their children - have become the equivalent of retail brand names. Mass market titles for younger children - the books by authors like Stan and Jan Berenstain or Richard Scarry - sell in the millions. ''Children's books were always the most profitable segment of the business,'' says Gordon. And now that segment is also the fastest growing. Among the foreign publishing giants who have acquired thriving children's book departments in the United States are Bertlesmann, which owns Bantam, Doubleday and Dell; the Pearson Group, which owns Viking Penguin, New American Library and the still-surviving Dutton children's book division, and Rupert Murdoch.
WHEN MURDOCH AND HIS LIEU tenants set about acquiring Harper & Row in 1987, they were aware of the company's backlist in children's books, which was 3,000 titles strong. But, says George Craig, the 49-year-old C.E.O. of Harper, ''We didn't fully understand the quality and depth of the Harper backlist, that we were getting a jewel.''
Almost immediately, Gordon recalls, ''A mandate came down to make the company profitable as quickly as possible.'' Approximately 70 people were laid off, all in the administrative and clerical divisions, none in editorial.
Craig was vice chairman of Collins, a British publishing house controlled by Murdoch, when the media baron asked him to sit in on the Harper negotiations. He was appointed to run the company in 1988.
''Liz Gordon and her team,'' says the Scottish-born Craig, rolling his r's, ''went out of their way to impress on us just how sacred some of their values were in Junior Books.''
According to Gordon, Craig was unfamiliar with the functioning of the children's book market in the United States, particularly the library market. ''Collins is much more of a mass market publisher,'' Gordon says. ''Mass market is marketing-driven. It is series dominated, where you are not selling a book, but a series with a marketing plan behind it. Trade publishing is more editorial-driven.''
Craig had assumed that Harper and Collins, which has its own children's department, would co-publish their books. But Gordon was of a different mind. ''American children want to read about what they know,'' she says. ''There are books that transcend national boundaries, such as 'The Secret Garden.' But the majority tend to be set in the child's very particular world.''
It became clear that Craig intended to integrate Harper & Row into Murdoch's media empire. In the spring, Gordon says, ''it may become Harper & Collins, and will include Angus & Robertson, the largest Australian publisher,'' another Murdoch property. ''I certainly think there is pressure to make it as global a publishing division as possible.''
GORDON WAS ONE OF the executives awarded a golden parachute when Murdoch bought Harper & Row. It entitled her to two times her yearly salary and bonus should she leave for ''good reason.'' Last year, Gordon negotiated an employment contract that would pay her considerably more if she left or was discharged.
From the perspective of Harper & Row's employees, the 1987 takeover was a financial boon. Employees received $65 a share for stock that had been credited to them, under the existing pension plan, at an assumed value of $8.75 five years before. ''So we are talking about a lot of money, for everyone in the company,'' says Gordon. ''Part of the stock option money financed my house in Scarsdale.''
Pre-Murdoch, Harper & Row lacked a mass paperback line. It meant, Gordon acknowledges, that ''there were books we went after, but didn't feel we could offer as much money as the books eventually went for.'' Presumably that will change with the addition of a new mass market line in January. The company has already announced a series of children's books that will be created especially for the division.
The books will be targeted for readers from the ages of 7 to 16; the series is being co-produced with Daniel Weiss Associates, a book packager whose previous books have included the wildly successful Sweet Valley High books and the Sleepover Friends series.
Gordon has nothing against ''light'' literature for children, she says. ''I've always been of the mind that adults don't have to go home and read 'War and Peace' at night. Neither should kids.'' On the other hand, she does not feel that ''popcorn,'' as she calls romances and mystery stories, should become a main part of a child's reading diet. ''Children will not become book readers if all they have are comic books . . . or a steady diet of formula fiction,'' Gordon wrote in a 1986 essay in Publishers Weekly. Formula fiction is just what Eddie Bell, the publisher of Harper Paperbacks and a senior vice president of the company, has ordered.
Last October Bell told Publishers Weekly that Harper will test the new titles using ''traditional focus groups and other methods as well -all the ways that any packaged goods organization goes about launching products.'' It was, he said, an attempt to make books competitive with ''other leisure items.''
While she was still publisher of Junior Books, Gordon, when pressed for a description of Bell's editorial style, said that he ''buys his ties at a different store.'' Her resignation behind her, she adds: ''You can't just take a literary novel into mass market, and it would have been foolish of Junior Books to think about publishing a Dan Weiss line without proper distribution. Even if we had editors who were champing at the bit to edit that sort of book . . . and we didn't.''
But when asked if the mass market issue had led to her departure, Gordon refuses comment. Craig will only say, ''It all happened pretty fast. I am very fond of her.''
Last month, Craig appointed Marilyn Kriney, the former editor in chief of Trophy, the juvenile trade paperback line, as publisher of the three children's book divisions. Kriney will report to Eddie Bell.
Says Kriney, ''Harper is, was and always will be a quality house. But we are going to broaden the base.'' Bell agrees: ''We have the most fantastic children's publishing house here - classy, high quality, commercial. But there are other opportunities.'' He plans 108 books for the mass market line next year, for both adult and children's markets.
Gordon's own plans are uncertain. ''All publishers secretly want to open their own country newspaper,'' she says, ''or start their own publishing company or open their own bookstore - where nothing will ever sully that very pure love of books. I want to look at every possibility. It could be children's television. It could be book clubs, the magazine business. I'm going to take a good look-and-see.''

HEADLINE: TO START WITH . . .;
VIVE LA DIFFERENCE

BYLINE: By PAM CYTRYNBAUM

 BODY:
WE ARE CHARGING what the market will bear. London is a more popular point,'' says a British Airways spokesman sounding not the least bit apologetic about the $3,606 one-way Concorde fare between New York and London. Air France charges $952 less, flying its Concordes on a route to Paris that is 186 miles longer. 
''In order to promote Paris as a gateway to Europe, we kept our fares down,'' says Jean-Claude Baumgarten, general manager of United States operations for the French airline. ''It was a competitive factor.''
Air France's 100-passenger planes - one a day each way - are on average 60-percent filled with World Bank officials, Middle Eastern diplomats and French and American fashion commuters. Among the regulars: trade publisher John Fairchild; Linda Dresner, the specialty shop doyenne of Park Avenue and Birmingham, Mich., and Alain Wertheimer, chairman of Chanel Inc.
Enough lawyers, investment bankers and the corporate raiders they serve - the likes of Henry Kravis, Sir James Goldsmith and Robert Maxwell - have given the British supersonic an average load factor of 70 to 85 percent.
Except for price, the differences between the British and French Concordes are subtle. The champagne, caviar and vintage French wines are practically identical (B. A. refers to its Bordeaux as claret) and the gifts of equal value: Cross pen sets and silver decanter labels aboard the British Concorde; Porthault boxer shorts for men on Air France.
Both airlines hope to keep their Concordes in service until the year 2005. French Concorde traveler Herve Aaron, president of the New York branch of Didier Aaron, the Paris antiques firm, is unconcerned that the next generation of faster-than-sound aircraft is only under study. ''I don't think my time is that valuable,'' he says.
A twice-a-year Concorde passenger to London, Richard L. Huber, executive vice president for capital markets and foreign exchange at Chase Manhattan Bank, is almost gleeful. ''I'll have a perfect excuse not to make certain tedious meetings,'' he says.

HEADLINE: IMAGE OF A CHAMPION

BYLINE: By Jay R. Tunney; Jay R. Tunney is president of Hobson's of Korea Ltd.

 BODY:
SIXTEEN MONTHS AGO, I BECAME the first American to open and run an ice cream parlor in Seoul. In some ways, it didn't make much sense. The South Korean Government was notorious for its unwillingness to open markets to foreigners. Moreover, Koreans traditionally have no taste for dairy products or sweet desserts. Yet somehow I think my father would have approved.
Gene Tunney was a businessman, an investor in numerous enterprises from coal production to banking. But he won his place in history because of his willingness to take on the toughest challenge he could find, in the person of Jack Dempsey, the heavyweight champion of the world. And because, as he showed in their rematch in 1927, he could get knocked around and still come out on top. In my own modest way, I like to think I'm living up to Pop's image. 
I was 50 years old when I received an invitation I couldn't resist, to start anew in a business about which I knew next to nothing. In 1986, Y. H. Kwong, a Hong Kong business friend, offered to sell me the Korean franchise for Hobson's Ice Cream, a superpremium product made in California. Kwong had himself acquired the master franchise for Southeast Asia after getting hooked on the product during a visit to a Hobson's store in Tokyo.
Except for one episode in 1970 when I helped run my brother John's successful campaign for the United States Senate in California, I had no experience in consumer marketing. Most of my career had been in commodities trading and in shipping in New York, San Francisco and Hong Kong. But when Kwong made his offer, the shipping business was suffering through one of its worst depressions and I had seen too many unhappy people. Ice cream has a way of making people smile, so I decided it was time for me to make the leap back to the consumer.
I knew the hurdles would be high, that the popularity of Hobson's and other American ice creams in Japan meant nothing. The Koreans are very different from the Japanese - economically and culturally - and light years behind them in taking to Western fast foods. One reason is their isolation from the industrialized Western world until just 35 years ago.
I was aware that Baskin-Robbins was already on the scene and that their joint venture with a Korean company was finding rough going. But I foresaw a huge consumer explosion like Japan's coming to Korea, now that the economy was waking up and the Government was beginning to loosen its protectionist bonds. Wendy's and Pizza Hut were doing a brisk business in Seoul. American fast foods were beginning to catch on. It would be like riding a surfboard, I thought: you want to get far enough out to catch the big wave.
So I passed the hat among friends, and with additional bank financing raised $400,000 to buy the franchise. As I was filing my application with the South Korean Ministry of Finance in September 1987, I knew that the elections in December might plunge the country into civil war. Believing that high risk spawns opportunity, I went ahead.
The permit came through in February 1988. I had persuaded the Ministry that I would be a symbol of entrepreneurship, competing for the consumer in the Koreans' own backyard, proving to the United States trade representatives that the Koreans could play fair after all.
But I had to yield on two non-tariff trade issues. The ministry directed me to share at least 25 percent of my enterprise with a Korean partner and to make my ice cream at a local Korean dairy rather than import it.
The big risk of political instability seemed to have evaporated by the time I opened my flagship store on July 29, 1988, in the gaudily commercial Itaewon district of central Seoul, just in time for the Olympics. The Koreans are wild about boxing, so I didn't think Pop would have minded my prominently displaying a huge picture of him in a 1920's fighter pose near the counter.
But over the next eight months, my path was to be studded with booby traps: bureaucratic red tape; visible and invisible import barriers; currency instability, and soaring inflation. Worst of all was the frosty Korean winter, which started in November and slashed the ice cream market by 60 percent. I was forced to install a small bakery as a line of defense against the eating habits of the Korean people, who are not accustomed to eating cold foods in frigid weather.
A turning point came last February when the food and beverage manager of the Seoul Hilton International Hotel came into the store and ''discovered'' our ice cream. Next thing I knew, he placed a big order for Hobson's to supply the hotel. We now supply several luxury hotels and private clubs in Seoul and Pusan. And I'm going ahead with plans to franchise stores and smaller retail outlets. As a one-man team on the spot rather than an emissary of a distant corporate organization, I have an advantage. I can be mobile and flexible, and know what the new Korean consumer is demanding from Monday to Sunday. Two months ago, a radical faction led some protests against Washington's continued trade pressure on Korea to open markets to American goods, but I remain optimistic. Anti-Americanism, I've discovered, does not get in the way of Koreans buying American consumer products.
With the goal of breaking into the black next year, I've been working 15 hours a day. That's nothing by Korean standards. This society has a mania for work, part of its Confucian heritage. Looking back over the last two years, I realize that I have relearned the work ethic. That's an edge we Americans no longer have. The United States is like a former champion who has lost his shape and form after attending too many banquets and receiving too many honors.
That's why I know Pop would have related to this venture. He was a self- made man, the son of a stevedore. It was his driving iron will, his determination to better himself, attended by the fear of humiliation should he fail, that made him succeed. That's what the Koreans are all about. They are unstoppable. Like my father. Like the United States, in the next round.
