The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 58, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 3189 words

HEADLINE: NEW RISK TAKERS IN THE REALTY GAME

BYLINE: By Richard D. Lyons; Richard D. Lyons is a reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
CHARLOTTE BALLARD HAD A PROBLEM. It was the summer of 1987, and the real estate developer had paid $475,000 for a dilapidated four-story apartment building on West 116th Street. If she could successfully renovate it, she felt, she stood a good chance of turning a profit on a dozen other run-down properties that she and her partners had bought in Harlem.
But before work could start, the drug addicts and squatters in the building had to be cleared out. She hired a neighborhood man to do the job, but several days later he was shot to death. It turned out that he had been a member of the New Vigilantes gang, and Ballard was told that he had been killed by rival drug dealers. ''I found myself in the middle of a turf war,'' the 56-year-old developer recalls. ''I was taken aback. Indeed, I was scared.''
She obtained a New York City Department of Health order calling for the building to be vacated on grounds that it was unsafe and unsanitary, and she asked the Police Department to enforce the order. A group of officers met her outside the building, but they refused to help. So Charlotte Ballard, all 5 feet, 5 inches and 112 pounds of her, marched into the building alone. 
''I realized that if I gave up now I would lose the building and maybe my others as well,'' she says, ''so I went in with only a flashlight - there was no electric power - and found a drugged-out guy on the second floor. I said, 'We've got to get the hell out of here. This is it, old boy.' '' She picked up his television set, and he followed her down the stairs and out the door, cursing and yelling. By the time she was through, Ballard says, the building was emptied of squatters and addicts, and the police prevented them from returning.
Charlotte Ballard is among the growing number of determined women trying to make their mark in the rough-and-tumble world of buying properties for renovation or new construction. In years past, women could hope only to sell individual properties on commission; the developers, virtually all of them men, took the big risks and made the big deals and the big money.
But the nature of the industry has changed, with the emphasis shifting from brawn to brains. ''Thirty years ago,'' says Charles S. Laven, director of the Real Estate Development Program at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation, ''development was a guy putting up a building. Today it is a very complex process involving government approvals, legal issues and financing as well as architecture and construction.'' A third of the students who graduated from the Columbia program last June were women, as are one third of the students at the Real Estate Institute at New York University.
Ambitious women are seizing the opportunity to enter the development arena - though generally on a scale far removed from the giant projects of a Donald Trump or a William Zeckendorf Jr. Some of the newcomers are former bank loan officers or insurance company executives. Says Norman Weinberg, director of N. Y. U.'s Real Estate Institute: ''The dinosaurs in real estate now realize that tough, smart ladies are analyzing their loan and mortgage proposals, so the old boys are only too willing to admit women into the development side of the fence. They feel that the women have earned their way in.''
For three women who have been developing properties in New York with varying degrees of success, real estate has lived up to its reputation as the most perilous of investment games. Despite the risks, Anne Dalton, a Peace Corps volunteer who became a developer of urban apartment buildings and suburban houses, still considers development ''an art form that allows you to express yourself.'' Charlotte Ballard, a native white South African who is learning it takes more than good intentions to turn a profit renovating Harlem buildings, continues to call her work ''a form of social commitment.'' And Meile Rockefeller, the great-great-granddaughter of John D. Rockefeller who has renovated residential and commercial buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn but has had trouble selling the properties, remains in development as a way to ''make it for myself in the world.''
CHARLOTTE BALLARD, WHO WAS BORN AND raised in Johannesburg, seems an improbable candidate for in the Harlem housing market. But she is feisty and outspoken. During a power breakfast of real estate luminaries in 1987, for example, she challenged assertions that it was impossible to make a profit from building affordable housing for the poor and middle class in New York City. When one developer suggested moving ''them'' to land outside the city, she shot back, ''You mean like Soweto?''
In 1956, recently divorced and the mother of an infant son, Ballard left her native land because, she says, ''South African girls are simply not prepared for careers, and I wanted a career.'' She headed to London to study economics and eventually joined an investment bank where she worked on real estate deals involving office blocks, housing developments and hotels in Europe, Africa and the Caribbean.
In 1964, Ballard arrived in the United States and married a San Francisco lawyer. The couple had three children, but Ballard was still determined to pursue a career. Over the next two decades, she held a variety of posts in investment banking and established a real estate investment firm. After her second marriage ended in divorce, she wed A. Verne Ballard, a businessman from San Diego. And in 1984 she began her real estate operations in New York. (The couple get together on weekends. ''I go there more than he comes here,'' she says, ''because he really doesn't like New York.'') In her first East Coast real estate venture, building town houses in Irvington, N. Y., Ballard says she and her investors doubled their money. Attracted by the opportunity to obtain renovation and development funds, in 1985 she began to buy Harlem properties, backed by West Coast banks, well-to-do friends and family money. In all, she says, Ballard Development Group Inc. has built or renovated about 270 housing units. She estimates she lost $250,000 on an apartment project on West 111th Street that she abandoned last year after the city withdrew its commitment to subsidize the renovation - and predicts she may soon lose another quarter of a million dollars on an unraveled plan to convert Harlem's Parkway Hospital into an intermediate-care facility for AIDS patients. But Ballard says her company has made about $4 million during the past four years. Some of the money, she adds, came from selling to other companies the Federal tax credits she received for renovating buildings in low-income neighborhoods.
When she sold the building on West 116th Street last July for $1.4 million, for example, the project also received $1.4 million in tax credits, which she has since sold. Ballard will not reveal how much she realized on the deal, but such credits typically sell for about 50 cents on the dollar.
It may be too soon to assess Ballard's impact. ''Charlotte Ballard came to West Harlem with the intention to do good, but without much guidance from local community groups,'' according to the leader of one nonprofit organization in Harlem, who says Ballard has sometimes misjudged the market.
In 1986, for example, The Community Preservation Corporation gave Ballard a $1.35 million construction loan to convert a building on 113th Street into low- and middle-income condominium units. But she was unable to find buyers for the apartments and subsequently sold the building to the state, which is using it as a mental-health facility.
Stanley Berman, an attorney whose firm has helped Ballard negotiate her way through the city and state bureaucracies on several of her projects, says the 113th Street units may have been priced too high. Renovating a building on a block with many other problems may not be enough to induce people to invest in a condominium, says Berman, ''no matter how beautiful it is.''
WHEN ANNE DALTON WAS A child, she used to look at maps and dream about leaving Woonsocket, R.I., for good. The old factory town, she says, ''depressed me even when I was 9 years old'' - and even though her father owned one of the factories.
She spent her college years close to home, majoring in music and education at Rhode Island College in Providence. But in 1966 Dalton joined the Peace Corps - ''out of a sense of adventure, not altruism,'' she says - and spent two years teaching elementary school in Liberia. Then she set out to explore Africa, South America and Europe on her own. Along the way, she sailed up the Amazon, played the piano in jazz bands in Paris, settled down for six months in the Canary Islands and for a year in Morocco, and crossed the Sahara. ''It was always, 'What do I do next?' '' she recalls.
Dalton's nomadic life style ended when she settled in New York in 1974, at the age of 31, and earned a master's degree in education from New York University. Within two years she had ventured into a popular downtown real estate game that was technically illegal but generally condoned by city officials. With money borrowed from friends, she would rent an industrial loft, make repairs, install a kitchen and bathroom, then sublet or reassign her lease to residential tenants and reap a ''fixture'' fee for the renovations.
''I did this about five times,'' Dalton says. ''The renovations generally cost about $15,000, and I charged the new renter from $30,000 to $50,000. It was a small opening in the world of New York real estate, and I walked through it.''
In 1985, she joined two partners - Michael LaBadie and Philip Mendlow - to form the L. M. Dalton Corporation, with Dalton as president. The company eventually bought three loft buildings in TriBeCa (an acronym for Triangle Below Canal Street), planning to renovate them into condominium units.
A few months later, Dalton was in a lawyer's office in Poughkeepsie when a broker told her that a parking lot next to the lofts was going to be sold that afternoon. ''Having the parking lot meant we could build a new building in addition to renovating the lofts,'' she explains. ''Because of the city's zoning regulations, there are very few opportunities to build new residential buildings in TriBeCa.''
Dalton and her partners snapped up the parking lot and made plans to build an 11-story luxury apartment house on the site. But first they had to raise the capital, and they had never put up an apartment building from scratch. (The loft buildings had cost L. M. Dalton $2.1 million, the parking lot $3.5 million. Building an 11-story building would take about $9 million.) ''We were turned down by dozens and dozens of banks, over and over again,'' Dalton says ruefully. ''We had to compile literally volumes of material in support of our loan applications. We began to feel like a publishing house.''
But Dalton is persistent. If everything else fails, she says, ''I've had temper tantrums, cried and yelled. And if I have to, I'll stand on my head to get something done.'' Finally, she received $18 million in construction loans from the Lincoln Savings Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. ''Lincoln Savings convinced Manny Hanny to go along with the financing,'' Dalton says.
The apartment building was to be erected on the parking lot, an irregularly shaped property roughly 80 by 100 feet. But Dalton discovered that a small strip in the middle of the site, measuring just 7 by 80 feet, remained zoned for manufacturing, even though the rest of this part of TriBeCa had been rezoned for residential use.
Changing the strip's zoning classification required the approval of Manhattan Community Board 1, the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate. The effort cost L. M. Dalton $400,000 for legal and consulting fees and the carrying costs on its loans as a result of the year-long delay. ''It was the city's oversight,'' Dalton says, ''but we had to suffer for it.''
The complex is called Dalton on Greenwich. The new apartment building contains 72 units, ranging from studios, which sell for as much as $280,000, to three-bedroom apartments, which go for up to $650,000. All but four of the apartments have been sold. The loft buildings have been converted into 12 condominium apartments. Eight have been purchased, the most expensive selling for $700,000.
Dalton turned next to the development of Washington Ridge Conservancy, a group of 22 single-family houses in New Milford, Conn. (She and her husband-partner Michael LaBadie, whom she married in 1987, and their two children spend weekends in their Bauhaus-style country house in that town.) The downturn in the Connecticut housing market, however, has forced Dalton to proceed cautiously with Washington Ridge. Her company has built and sold only two of the $700,000 houses. Another L. M. Dalton project, Dalton Farm, is planned as a development of 540 single-family houses and town houses in Beekman, N.Y., on a farm bought in 1985 from Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. Some 30 units have been presold, for between $140,000 and $250,000, Dalton says.
''It sometimes takes five, six, even seven years to get approval for such a large project from the State Department of Environmental Conservation,'' Dalton comments. ''There are zoning, sewage, drainage and utilities to consider. Some people who may not want the project take little pieces of the environmental impact statement you have to file and try to bring suit against the project, alleging some infraction of an almost endless set of rules.''
One environmental suit brought by a group of Beekman residents, Dalton says, cost the company $600,000 in legal fees. The hearings were heated - on one occasion there was a fistfight in the courtroom - but she prevailed.
Anne Dalton says she enjoys the real estate business because it involves ''getting my hands dirty and coming home with plaster dust in my hair.'' She insists she has not felt intimidated by the male domination of the business. She suspects that her height - she's 5 feet, 10 inches tall - may have helped. She says, ''I've never had trouble being taken seriously.''
I KNEW FROM VERY EARLY ON,'' says Meile Rockefeller, ''that I wanted to go into real estate.'' It could not have come as much of a surprise to her parents, Rodman C. Rockefeller and Barbara Ann Olsen Rockefeller. John D. Rockefeller Jr., Meile's great-grandfather, developed Rockefeller Center in the depths of the Depression, and her grandfather, Nelson, was responsible for leasing office space in the center.
During the summer before her freshman year at Williams College, Meile Rockefeller worked as an intern with New York's Battery Park City Authority. And she took a year off from college to serve another internship, this time with the planning commission for Manhattan's now moribund Westway highway project.
After her graduation in 1979, with a degree in political economics, Rockefeller worked briefly for a small development firm in Dallas. Then she set up her own development company, Anthemion Inc., and took a suite of offices in - where else? - Rockefeller Center. (She changed the company name to Rockefeller Properties in 1985.) Her first venture was the conversion of a brownstone rooming house in Brooklyn Heights into five cooperative apartments. The project, completed in 1983, gave her ''a lot of hands-on experience,'' she says - but very little profit.
She soon found that ''having the Rockefeller name can be a two-edged sword. It gives me accessibility. But some people might think it glamorous to have me in a deal. If I sense that, I won't get involved. I want to be known for what I do, not for what others have done.'' In 1985, Rockefeller purchased the century-old Mercantile Exchange building in TriBeCa for $4.1 million. The building, which had once housed the offices of dairy brokers, contained a 10,000-square-foot trading floor with a 30-foot-high ceiling. Rockefeller renovated the building into seven commercial condominiums while retaining much of its historic flavor. ''I was not about to tear down that lovely old building,'' the 33-year-old developer says.
At one point, Rockefeller says, she had a chance to sell the entire structure and realize a $2 million profit, but the deal was contingent upon the buyer taking possession before certain depreciation provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 took effect. She encountered one construction delay after another. The New York Telephone Company, for example, took months to bury a trunk line beneath the basement floor. ''I was ready to take an ax and chop the thing off myself,'' she says. ''Of course, it would have cut off telephone service to the whole block, but in retrospect I should have done it.'' The deadline passed, and the deal fell through.
The renovation of the exchange was completed in 1988 at a cost of about $3 million, but only four of the seven units have been sold. Still on the market is the former trading floor, now a two-story commercial condominium with a premium price tag of $250 per square foot. Rockefeller does not expect to make a profit on the project, given its high cost and the depressed state of the office-condominium market. But then, one advantage of being a Rockefeller, she allows, ''is not having to squeeze the last nickel out of a deal if I feel there might be other considerations, such as the preservation of a building that is architecturally significant.''
In 1985, the same year she purchased the Mercantile Exchange, Rockefeller also bought a 102-year-old TriBeCa building on Duane Street that had once been a cheese factory, planning to renovate the five-story structure for residential condominiums. She obtained a permit from the Department of Buildings to add extra rooms to the two penthouse apartments.
Then the official who had approved the permit was replaced, and Rockefeller was informed that she would have to eliminate the extra rooms because they violated the zoning laws. ''Finding out that a building permit is not a binding legal document cost me $150,000,'' she says. ''It cost $50,000 to put in the rooms, $50,000 to fight the denial of the original approval and $50,000 to redo the rooms to new specifications.''
The project, which was completed in 1987, contains six apartments, including two penthouses of about 3,500 square feet each, priced just under $1 million. Three of the apartments have been sold, as has one of two ground-floor commercial units. Rockefeller says she will not show a profit until the building's remaining units have been sold.
Last summer, Rockefeller decided to put her company ''temporarily on the shelf.'' She has become a consultant for a West German development company, which she declined to identify except to say it has ''very deep pockets.''
For the West German company, she is overseeing renovations and new construction in the New York area, and she hopes to ''learn how to manage successful partnership arrangements.'' Being a one-person show has its limits, she says: ''Almost nobody does a major development project completely on their own.''

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 60, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 2670 words

HEADLINE: CONJURING UP THE 1990's

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; As a State Department official in the 1970's, Jeffrey E. Garten could never have predicted that he would spend the 80's as an investment banker.

 BODY:
SOOTHSAYING HAS A long and checkered history, and the year-end predictions of economic soothsayers generally fare no better than the rest. How much more chancy is the task of the end-of-decade forecaster! Yet there is one clue to the proper approach, provided by the astounding record of the last 10 years: think boldly.
Transport yourself back to the waning days of 1979. Inflation was into double digits, unemployment a big worry. Banks fretted in the straitjackets that had been designed for them by Congress in the 1930's. Leveraged buyouts were rare; junk bonds slumbered in the backwaters of finance. The economies of Mexico, Brazil and Venezuela were growing apace, the United States was the world's largest creditor and Japan was running trade deficits.
Who could have foreseen with any confidence that, over the next decade, the economy would be transformed by massive waves of debt-fueled takeovers? Who could have predicted that a business boom could last seven years, barely missing a beat even when the world was jolted by the biggest stock market crash since 1929? How many seers knew that Japan would be running annual trade surpluses approaching $100 billion and that the United States would become the world's biggest debtor? Or that much of Latin America would be bankrupt? As for Mikhail Gorbachev embracing Adam Smith . . . 
Yet the seeds of those remarkable turnarounds were there in 1979 for anyone to see. And if the past is any guide, the coming decade could knock your socks off. Cautious soothsayers take heed. In that spirit, herewith a handful of scenarios, outrageous perhaps, but rooted in today's realities.
OVER THE LAST DECADE, pension funds have grown by some 500 percent. They now hold more than $2 trillion in assets, equivalent to 40 percent of the equity in all publicly traded companies, and that may rise to 66 percent by the end of the next decade. Meanwhile, our rate of private investment is at its lowest level in nearly half a century, and most of that is short term. By all accounts, the nation desperately needs a quantum increase in long-term investment in factories, research and education. In the 1990's, Washington may very well conclude that there is only one way to go: tap the pension funds.
Like nearly everyone else, managers of pension funds have a short-term horizon. They are under enormous pressure from their boards to match the performance of the stock market on a quarterly basis. They are also constrained by a web of Federal and state laws designed to safeguard workers' post-retirement income; these laws are typically interpreted to exclude long-term investments outside the securities and real estate markets. But a quarter-to-quarter investment strategy limited to the stock market does little to cure our national economic ills.
In the 1990's, we may find the Government pressing pension funds to drastically increase their long-term investments in the nation's productivity - putting their money to work modernizing existing industries and financing new business ventures. The funds might also be urged to invest in education through for-profit research organizations or in the rebuilding of the nation's infrastructure, with repayment by means of highway tolls and port fees. A glimmer of the future can already be seen in California, New York and Pennsylvania, where pension funds have been encouraged to invest in small and medium-sized companies that create new jobs in the states. In fact, some prominent lawmakers have recently talked about using the tax system to push the funds in a long-term direction.
In addition to its larger purpose, such pension fund investment could also benefit future retirees because the value of the securities held by the funds would almost certainly grow along with a more vigorous economy. The retirees might be protected in such a program by Government guarantees of some respectable long-term financial return.
PLAGUED BY DRUGS AND CRIME, drained by the needs of AIDS patients, the homeless, the tattered educational system, New York City seems well on the way to a replay of the financial crisis of the 1970's. This time around, however, there is considerably less fat to cut, taxes are already out of sight and the bankers are unlikely to come to New York City's rescue. Neither is the Federal Government, which is drowning in its own indebtedness. Before the 1990's are over, New York might have to follow a course pioneered by Argentina and Mexico: privatization.
The notion that New York might turn over a major chunk of its municipal services to be run by private business might strike many as a cure worse than the disease. But the benefits could be enormous. The city would be relieved of the cost of providing these services and, by adding the profit motive, might even find the work gets done more efficiently.
There are lots of straws in the wind. Around the country, cities are hiring corporations to take over management of their prisons, parks and municipal hospitals. New Yorkers who can afford it already are paying businesses to provide alternatives to much- strained municipal services, from privately operated emergency ambulances to platoons of security guards.
With his renovation of the city's Wollman skating rink, and his offer to repair the crumbling Williamsburg Bridge, Donald Trump provided the most trumpeted example of high-net-worth impatience with New York services. And short of supernatural intervention, the ever-tighter municipal budgets of the next decade are likely to leave the mass of voters open to any solution - even the prospect of having their schools run as businesses or their subways, buses and airports turned over to private investors.
Private contractors could cut the annual cost of repaving streets by $64 million, according to an analysis by E. S. Savas, chairman of the management department at Baruch College and a former assistant secretary at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. He also argues that privatizing garbage collection could save almost $200 million. Savas estimates that contracting out these and similar services could slash about 25 percent from the city's $26.6 billion annual budget.
 
MISSION IMPLAUSIBLE
The turmoil in the Soviet Union is ominous, and the economy seems on the verge of collapse. Chances are President Bush will end up organizing a multibillion-dollar international bailout. It could happen soon, and this could be the scenario:
As food shortages mount and perestroika is ripped apart by skyrocketing inflation and virulent corruption, a hard-line military clique tries to unseat the current Government. In the struggle for power, Mikhail Gorbachev calls on Washington, Bonn and Tokyo for loans, and for the bread, clothing and computers he desperately needs to show the Russian people that he really can raise their standard of living.
The Western nations, faced with the possibility of a new Stalinist regime and a return to the Cold War, would have little choice. Back in 1918, Allied forces landed in Siberia in a move against the Bolsheviks, who had just seized power. This time around, we would be sending money instead of troops, and that might prove to be more successful. If not, the Russian bailout of the 90's could make the Latin American debt fiasco of the 80's look like a petty-cash problem.
 
LITTLE BIG BOARD
By the year 2000, the stock market may be a shadow of its former self. The transformation is already well under way.
It all used to be so simple. The stock exchanges provided the most efficient means for a corporation to raise funds, selling its shares to individuals and institutions.
Now companies are taking a different tack. Instead of going public, many of them are obtaining capital by offering their stock directly to insurance companies, investment banks and leveraged buyout firms. Some are entering into joint ventures with larger organizations. Meanwhile, many public companies are buying back their own stock, and some are going private. Over the last five years, shares valued at more than $200 billion have been retired from the nation's exchanges.
Junk-bond buyouts have played a major role in the process, and their popularity seems to be fading. But the trend toward going, or staying, private is likely to continue. Private companies can achieve greater flexibility and efficiency, the argument goes, because they do not have to gear their strategies to short- term earnings or the possibility of a takeover. They also are spared the expense and red tape that public companies are obliged to endure because of Government reporting requirements, shareholder meetings and the like.
Of course, the stock market is not going to disappear. Companies in high-risk industries such as biotechnology will not be able to raise enough money from private sources; they will need to tap the public markets and their thousands of individual investors, each of whom is taking a relatively small gamble. But by the turn of the century, the Big Board may not be so big.
 
NATIONALIZING OIL
At the beginning of this decade, Ronald Reagan set out to dismantle the Department of Energy. Before George Bush leaves office, he may find himself giving the D.O.E. whatever power it needs to manage the de facto nationalization of the energy industry. The inspiration: oil shortages and price rises that would make the energy crunch of the 1970's seem mild by comparison.
The trends are ominous. Domestic drilling is way down, off-shore exploration is stalled because of environmental concerns, construction of nuclear power plants is at a standstill. During the first three quarters of this year, oil imports represented 46.5 percent of the nation's total consumption - 10 percent more than for the whole of 1973, the year of the OPEC embargo. If oil supplies from the Middle East are once again disrupted, if high energy prices threaten to put the economy in reverse gear, how will the President respond?
He might very well call upon the Secretary of Energy to take charge. Backed by new tax incentives and penalties, the D.O.E. could push the big oil companies into huge drilling programs and revised production strategies. Sites such as the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge could be opened up for oil exploration. High gasoline taxes would be just one possible means of curbing energy consumption; others would alter the hours we work or the location of new factories. With consumers pitted against producers, and one region of the country against the other, energy may once again become the nation's most divisive issue.
 
HAIL TO THE TSAR
For banks and securities firms alike, the risks of dealing in international markets require long arms and deep pockets. And these days ''global'' is beginning to sound a lot like ''gobble.'' The Hongkong and Shanghai Bank has acquired Marine Midland, Nippon Life Insurance Company has bought a big chunk of Shearson Lehman Hutton and Deutsche Bank is buying up banks and securities firms around Europe. As deregulation proceeds in the United States, Japan and Europe, the permutations and combinations will inevitably multiply.
By the end of the next decade, finance may be dominated by a dozen global behemoths with such names as Sumitomo Chemical, Prudential Paribas and Dresdner Smith Barney. They would represent the ultimate challenge for regulators. Just how could the government agencies of any one nation oversee the operations of multinational entities as they move their business from time zone to time zone and juggle their accounts in dollars, yen and marks? A new, Tokyo-based institution would be established, called something like The Supranational Agency for Regulation - TSAR for short.
In cooperation with national agencies, TSAR would seek to prevent money laundering, insider trading and currency manipulation. It would also set some minimal level of reserves to cushion the impact of losses, since the failure of one financial conglomerate could send the world economy into a tailspin.
 
AVE ATQUE, G.M.
The American automotive industry as we have known it could disappear before the next decade is over. There may still be companies called General Motors, Ford and Chrysler. They may still be selling cars called Chevrolet, Lincoln and Plymouth. But virtually all of the cars would be manufactured overseas - or in American-based factories owned by Japanese, Koreans and Europeans.
What about Detroit's much- touted revival over the last few years? It's been fun listening to Lee Iacocca's pep talks, but those rosy sales figures mask real, underlying problems. Sales have been pumped up by offering customers huge rebates, and with the help of Government limits on imported cars. Even the dramatic drop in the value of the dollar against the yen and the mark, giving American-made products a substantial price advantage, has failed to stem the move to foreign cars.
About 40 percent of the autos sold in the United States today are manufactured by foreign companies. We know what Honda and Toyota have done to the market for compact cars. And now the Japanese are assaulting the luxury-car market.
The Big Three have been closing automotive plants and scrambling to enter other businesses. General Motors bought Hughes Aircraft and Electronic Data Systems. Ford acquired a number of savings banks. Meanwhile, the Japanese, who had no auto-production facilities in the United States in 1980, have built eight state- of-the-art plants and some 150 factories to produce transmissions, engines and other components.
When the Japanese plants in the United States achieve full production in the middle of the next decade, the industry will have an excess capacity of some three million cars, assuming current levels of production by the Big Three. Something will have to give, and it's not apt to be the Japanese. Unless there are some remarkable changes in today's trends, only a miracle will allow Detroit to keep building cars in the United States. Add in a recession or a jump in energy prices that would send Americans scampering for more fuel-efficient cars, and even a miracle might not suffice.
 
JOKER IN THE DECK
These scenarios assume a continuation of what has been the most remarkable economic phenomenon of the 1980's - the Japanese juggernaut. There's just one problem: during the next decade, the juggernaut may run out of steam.
Japan's economic power is based upon a mountain of cash, which in turn is based upon a very high rate of savings on the part of Japanese citizens and a huge excess of exports over imports. After World War II, the Japanese saved because they had known poverty and despair, and because they didn't trust their Government to provide for their future. They spent next to nothing on consumer goods. Meanwhile, Government and industry were sinking every spare yen into making products for export.
The members of the new generation have known prosperity and, in their time, the nation has created a strong welfare system. The chances are good that the Japanese people are about to become big-time spenders. And the political leaders are already showing the way.
For all the complaints about protectionism, Japanese imports of food and manufactured goods are increasing dramatically. Foreign aid is soaring. The phenomenal growth in travel by the Japanese has produced a major outflow of funds, projected to exceed $20 billion next year.
Meanwhile, the people are clamoring for long-delayed improvements in housing, roads and sewer facilities. The cost of caring for the elderly - whose ranks are growing more rapidly than in any other industrial nation - is apt to double or triple.
Japan is not going to cease being one of the major industrial powers. But given the likelihood of a significant drop in savings, and a closer balance between imports and exports, Japan's global clout may soon peak.
That possibility may complicate the life of a soothsayer, but it should make a lot of Americans breathe easier.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 49, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 5924 words

HEADLINE: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR

 BODY:
This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1988. It suggests only high points in the main fields of reader interest, and it does not include the titles chosen by the editors of The Book Review as the Best Books of 1989. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review.
 
Autobiography and Biography
 THE AMBITION AND THE POWER. By John M. Barry. (Viking, $22.95.) This story of the rise and fall of Jim Wright, Speaker of the House, ''is an important accomplishment'' written by ''a fair and uncompromised observer.''
AMELIA EARHART: A Biography. By Doris L. Rich. (Smithsonian Institution, $19.95.) The author, a journalist and photographer, ''writes . . . parsimoniously and . . . colorfully'' about the life of the aviator who captured the country's imagination. 
AND THE WALLS CAME TUMBLING DOWN: An Autobiography. By Ralph David Abernathy. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) A colorful, controversial, earthy, often humorous account of the civil rights movement, written by a man who was at its center. ''His storytelling is gripping, even moving.''
THE ANDY WARHOL DIARIES. Edited by Pat Hackett. (Warner Books, $29.95.) A half-million words on nearly everything. ''Despite their virtuoso triviality, their naive snobbery and their incredible length, the diaries of Andy Warhol are not without a certain charm.''
BALM IN GILEAD: Journey of a Healer. By Sara Lawrence Lightfoot. (Merloyd Lawrence/Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) ''A daughter's loving biography of her mother,'' the pioneering child psychiatrist Dr. Margaret Morgan Lawrence, that records ''her long journey, as a gifted and accomplished black woman, across the rugged terrain of race and gender in America.''
BEHIND THE MOUNTAIN: Return to Tasmania. By Peter Conrad. (Poseidon, $18.95.) ''Sublime writing . . . memorable metaphors and . . . sere wit'' characterize this memoir of the author's childhood.
BERNARD SHAW. Volume Two: 1898-1918. The Pursuit of Power. By Michael Holroyd. (Random House, $24.95.) In this second volume of the playwright's biography, focusing on Shaw as a political fighter, he ''emerges as a man more baffled than triumphant in his quest.''
BITTER FAME: A Life of Sylvia Plath. By Anne Stevenson. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A biography of the poet, a suicide at age 30, that attempts to exonerate Plath's maligned family. ''In the work of sorting out these truths, half-truths and inventions, this new biography is a significant step.''
THE BROKEN CORD. By Michael Dorris. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) A painful personal chronicle of the writer's discovery that his adopted child is afflicted by fetal alcohol syndrome and a searing look at ''the condition that has blighted his son's life,'' written in ''clear and affecting'' prose.
THE BRONTES: Charlotte Bronte and Her Family. By Rebecca Fraser. (Crown, $25.) A look at the author of ''Jane Eyre'' ''as she appeared to her contemporaries. . . . A social historian's sense of place is everywhere present in this biography, and a novelist's imaginative feeling for detail.''
DAUGHTER OF DESTINY: An Autobiography. By Benazir Bhutto. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) A ''fascinating portrait'' of Pakistan's Prime Minister and her family.
FELIX FENEON: Aesthete & Anarchist in Fin-de-Siecle Paris. By Joan Ungersma Halperin. (Yale University, $35.) A ''detailed and fascinating biography of the contradictory and enigmatic'' critic of art and literature.
FIORELLA H. LA GUARDIA AND THE MAKING OF MODERN NEW YORK. By Thomas Kessner. (McGraw-Hill, $24.95.) ''This is a biography of a petty, petulant, often unpleasant little man who, with the passage of time, has come to be regarded as New York City's greatest mayor,'' written with ''sweep and lucidity.''
FORBIDDEN TERRITORY: The Memoirs of Juan Goytisolo, 1931-1956. Translated by Peter Bush. (North Point, $18.95.) The early life of one of Spain's leading novelists. ''It is against wanton destruction that Mr. Goytisolo writes. . . . Beneath his anger . . . there lies a belief in human survival.''
GEORGIA O'KEEFFE: A Life. By Roxana Robinson. (Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row, $25.) A portrait of the artist that is both ''levelheaded and protective''; it ''does much to give body to the O'Keeffe myth.''
GLENN GOULD: A Life and Variations. By Otto Friedrich. (Random House, $24.95.) A senior writer for Time writes a biography of the pianist that is ''touching, intriguing and ultimately tragic.''
GOLDWYN: A Biography. By A. Scott Berg. (Knopf, $24.95.) An ''absorbing biography, thick with amusing anecdote'' about the driven movie producer.
GINSBERG: A Biography. By Barry Miles. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A ''skillful,'' fact-filled life of the courageous, deliberately ridiculous poet - and hero of our time. ''Read it; you'll enjoy yourself.''
GOLDEN INCHES: The China Memoir of Grace Service. Edited by John S. Service. (University of California, $19.95.) A ''wonderful, sad, moving memoir by an indomitable American who went to China with her husband'' to further the work of the Y.M.C.A. in that country.
THE GOOD TIMES. By Russell Baker. (Morrow, $19.95.) The New York Times columnist recounts his life as a reporter. ''A superb autobiography, wonderfully told, often hilarious, always intelligent and unsparing.''
HARP. By John Gregory Dunne. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The autobiography of the Irish-American writer. ''He can wrench bleak emotions. . . . If you start the book you'll likely stay to the end, gripped by verbal resource or else by sheer morbidity.''
HATTIE: The Life of Hattie McDaniel. By Carlton Jackson. (Madison Books, $18.95.) A ''poignantly sympathetic biography'' of the actress, the first black artist to win an Academy Award. ''Mr. Jackson has succeeded enormously in writing a caring biography of a multitalented woman.''
HEMINGWAY IN LOVE AND WAR: The Lost Diary of Agnes von Kurowsky, Her Letters, and Correspondence of Ernest Hemingway. By Henry Serrano Villard and James Nagel. (Northeastern University, $21.95.) ''As well as serving as a corrective to literal readings of 'A Farewell to Arms,' the diary either directly or inferentially fills out the personality'' of Hemingway, a fantasist and self-mythologizer.
HIROHITO: Behind the Myth. By Edward Behr. (Villard, $22.50.) The biography of Japan's last Emperor is ''a thoughtful and appropriate challenge to the orthodoxy of the blameless Emperor that has prevailed in many English-speaking circles.''
HONORABLE JUSTICE: The Life of Oliver Wendell Holmes. By Sheldon M. Novick. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) ''The first full biography based on unrestricted access to the Holmes papers. . . . As chapter follows masterly chapter . . . hopes mature into admiration of author and awe of subject.''
THE IRON LADY: A Biography of Margaret Thatcher. By Hugo Young. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) ''With patience and comprehension,'' a veteran political journalist tells the story of Britain's Prime Minister in ''a model political biography.''
ISARA: A Voyage Around ''Essay.'' By Wole Soyinka. (Random House, $18.95.) The Nobel Prize-winning playwright and author of ''Ake'' continues his family story with a ''homage to his father'' and life in the Nigeria of 50 years ago; the book ''supplies the essential ingredient missing from history books - not only the Zeitgeist, but the heart that propels the spirit.''
LET THEM CALL ME REBEL: Saul Alinsky - His Life and Legacy. By Sanford D. Horwitt. (Knopf, $29.95.) ''A highly readable, exhaustively researched biography that is full of both playful anecdote and thoughtful political analysis'' about the legendary community organizer.
LEWIS MUMFORD: A Life. By Donald L. Miller. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $24.95.) The first full-length biography of the architect, urban activist and man of letters, written by a professor of history at Lafayette College. ''The value of this biography is its painstaking and competent assemblage of sources.''
THE LIFE AND DEATH OF ANDY WARHOL. By Victor Bockris. (Bantam, $21.95.) One of ''the best so far in an encroaching flood of Warholiana. . . . The one to read for knowledge of Warhol the man.''
THE LIFE OF GRAHAM GREENE. Volume One: 1904-1939. By Norman Sherry. (Viking, $29.95). The first installment of this thoughtful and ambitious biography of the writer ''provide[s] special satisfactions.''
LOST IN TRANSLATION: A Life in a New Language. By Eva Hoffman. (Dutton, $18.95.) An editor of The Book Review takes ''a sad, remorseful yet bright-eyed look backward'' to her childhood in Poland and her emigration to the United States. ''Thanks to its honesty, its bravery and its good humor, it is a book that repairs the very loss it laments.''
MARY SHELLEY: Romance and Reality. By Emily W. Sunstein. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) ''This [book] promises to be the definitive biography'' of the author of ''Frankenstein'' and wife of Percy Bysshe Shelley.
MILES: The Autobiography. By Miles Davis with Quincy Troupe. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) The ''profusely detailed, exceedingly candid and eminently readable'' story of the life and times of the musician whose ''siren call . . . abides as one of the most seductive in the music of this century.''
MOTHERWIT: An Alabama Midwife's Story. By Onnie Lee Logan as told to Katherine Clark. (Dutton, $16.95.) This oral biography ''reaffirm[s] the black woman's time-honored role in the ancient practice of midwifery. And the great American quilt of diversity gets another colorful square.''
NIXON: Volume Two. The Triumph of a Politician, 1962-1972. By Stephen E. Ambrose. An evenhanded, reliable examination of Mr. Nixon's second rise, from his defeat for Governor of California through two victories as President. ''What sets this book apart is Mr. Ambrose's commanding grasp of material.''
OUR KIND OF PEOPLE: The Story of an American Family. By Jonathan Yardley. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $21.95.) A family remembrance that ''reads like a first-rate novel,'' by a book critic for The Washington Post.
OURS: A Russian Family Album. By Sergei Dovlatov. Translated by Anne Frydman. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) ''Stalin dominates . . . this series of portraits'' of the author's family and homeland. ''The book is remarkable for its lack of acrimony, bitterness or even indignation.''
A PLACE FOR US. By Nicholas Gage. (Marc Jaffe/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) The author of ''Eleni'' picks up his own story of emigration to Worcester, Mass. ''A warm-hearted, likable contribution to its genre.''
PAUL ROBESON: A Biography. By Martin Bauml Duberman. (Knopf, $24.95.) ''The glorious and tragic life of Paul Robeson is a poignant, gripping story. . . . Mr. Duberman has written a superb biography of a great man.''
RICHARD MILHOUS NIXON: The Rise of an American Politician. By Roger Morris. (Holt, $29.95.) The initial work in a projected three-volume biography is filled with insightful and absorbing detail about the former President's early life. ''A massive, powerful biography.''
THE ROAD FROM COORAIN. By Jill Ker Conway. (Knopf, $18.95.) ''The historian and former president of Smith College, who grew up on a sheep station [in Australia], has written a remarkable memoir.''
SAYING GOODBYE: A Memoir for Two Fathers. By M. R. Montgomery. (Knopf, $18.95.) A writer for The Boston Globe tells the life stories of his father and father-in-law in a ''retrained but deeply moving book, a model of good prose.''
SELF-CONSCIOUSNESS: Memoirs. By John Updike. (Knopf, $18.95.) Parts of a life, as related by the novelist. ''His best writing . . . is the prose of rapture. . . . It is good to see a writer enjoying his talent and his luck.''
SKETCHES FROM A LIFE. By George F. Kennan. (Pantheon, $22.95.) ''Beautifully written diaries'' from a man considered ''the last of the architects of postwar American foreign policy.''
THE SOUND OF WINGS: The Life of Amelia Earhart. By Mary S. Lovell. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) The author of ''Straight On Till Morning: The Biography of Beryl Markham'' turns her attention to the first woman to cross the Atlantic by air, in a story that offers ''fascinating detail . . . on Earhart's relationship with her husband,'' George Palmer Putnam, the man who helped to make her famous.
STORMY APPLAUSE: Making Music in a Worker's State. By Rostislav Dubinsky. (Hill & Wang, $22.95.) A ''lively memoir'' written by the Soviet musician and first violinist of the Borodin Quartet, covering the period between 1945 and 1975.
THIS BOY'S LIFE: A Memoir. By Tobias Wolff. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) The author of ''The Barracks Thief'' tells his own story in a memoir that is ''literate and consistently entertaining - and richer, darker and funnier than anything else Tobias Wolff has written.''
WHEN HEAVEN AND EARTH CHANGED PLACES: A Vietnamese Woman's Journey From War to Peace. By Le Ly Hayslip with Jay Wurts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) ''A searing and human account of Vietnam's destruction and self-destruction. Lucidly, sometimes even lyrically, Ms. Hayslip paints an intensely intimate portrait.''
 
Children
 BILL PEET: An Autobiography. Written and illustrated by Bill Peet. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) A ''marvelous new species,'' this ''child's storybook'' that is also ''the memoir of an adult'' describes the life of the well-known children's book author who worked as an illustrator for Walt Disney from the making of ''Dumbo'' until ''Mary Poppins.'' (Ages 8 to 12) DOES GOD HAVE A BIG TOE? Stories About Stories in the Bible. By Marc Gellman. Illustrated by Oscar de Mejo. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) This joyful collection ''is in the tradition of the midrashim: stories, allegories, fables whose purpose is to interpret and illuminate the fixed narrative of the Scripture.'' They have ''the ring of folk-fables and the wit of a single, affectionate heart.'' (All Ages) LISA'S WAR. By Carol Matas. (Scribners, $12.95.) In her fine novel set in Copenhagen during the years of the Nazi occupation, the author is able to pose ''sophisticated concerns with an honorable simplicity.'' The central character, a young girl, joins the Resistance. (Ages 12 and up) NED AND THE JOYBALOO. By Hiawyn Oram. Illustrated by Satoshi Kitamura. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $11.95.) Ned finds a Joybaloo in the linen closet and, in a glorious fantasy, the little boy and his imagination soar. Dazzling illustrations capture the child and his playmate. (Ages 3 to 8) MAMMAL. By Steve Parker. (Knopf, $12.95.) The ''Eyewitness'' series of science books imported from England set a remarkable standard ''integrating text and illustration in a graphically exciting and intellectually enticing way.'' This stunning volume includes ''a remarkable photographic sequence'' showing a cat giving birth. (Ages 9 and up) THE OLD SYNAGOGUE. Written and illustrated by Richard Rosenblum. (Edward E. Elson/Jewish Publication Society, $12.95.) In this simple story book the author and illustrator conveys ''the complexities of both urban and religious life with great clarity and charm.'' (Ages 6 and up) SHABANU. Daughter of the Wind. By Suzanne Fisher Staples. (Knopf, $13.95.) The heroine of this novel set in the Cholistan Desert on the Indian-Pakistani border is 12. Her account of one year ''meticulously documents the rigors and tribulations of nomadic life, as well as the narrator's flowering from a child into a spirited young woman.'' (Ages 12 and up) SWAN LAKE. By Margot Fonteyn. Illustrated by Trina Schart Hyman. (Gulliver/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The plot of the popular ballet is retold in ''by far the most suggestive, complete and authoritative'' fashion in the slim, elegantly illustrated story book. (All Ages) THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS. By Jon Scieszka. Illustrated by Lane Smith. (Viking Kestrel, $13.95.) Are we to blame A. Wolf ''because, while on an errand to borrow sugar from his porcine neighbors, he happened to sneeze a few times''? The ''excited and funky'' illustrations match the hilarious revisionist text to a standard story. (Ages 3 to 8) THE TUB PEOPLE. By Pam Conrad. Illustrated by Richard Egielski. (Harper & Row, $12.95.) The seven painted wooden figures live ''in and about a bathtub and every day they frolic in the water and ride on a soap bar.'' In this small drama for preschoolers, ''the tension between the text and the pictures rivets'' young readers. (Ages 4 to 8)
 
Crime
 THE DEATH OF A JOYCE SCHOLAR. By Bartholomew Gill. (Morrow, $18.95.) The chief superintendent of Dublin's murder squad discovers his kinship with Leopold Bloom while hunting down the killer of a Joycean. ''An affectionate acquaintance with Joyce's Dubliners adds considerably to the pleasures of this profoundly clever literary mystery.''
THE FOURTH DURANGO. By Ross Thomas. (Mysterious Press, $18.95.) The tiny town of Durango, Calif., is the perfect hideout for a man with a price on his head - in this case, a judge who's been framed. ''We already know how witty Mr. Thomas can be about entrepreneurial greed and political chicanery,'' but his depiction of Durango ''is a revelation.''
JUICE. By Robert Campbell. (Poseidon, $18.95.) When nations owe other nations billions of dollars, what is there to say about a guy who's into a loan shark for $2,000, plus $200 a week in interest? ''Robert Campbell has a mouthful to say about a chump like that, and . . . he says it with grand panache, in the colorful patois of Hollywood 'gamooshes' and 'juicemen.' ''
THE KING OF THE NIGHTCAP. By William Murray. (Bantam, $16.95.) Shifty Lou Anderson is a dedicated horseplayer who plays detective to keep his favorite recreation clean and almost honest. ''The author's own obvious passion for the sport throws a sunny glow on the tracks where Shifty mingles companionably with jockeys and trainers.''
THE MARSHAL AND THE MADWOMAN. By Magdalen Nabb. (Scribners, $16.95.) Marshal Salvatore Guarnaccia investigates the apparent suicide of a crazed woman who lived in a poor section of Florence. ''The English author's new crime novel examines the human components of a murder case on a level of perception that surpasses mere mastery of form.''
MAY'S NEWFANGLED MIRTH. By Mary Jo Adamson. (Bantam, Paper, $3.50.) Mary Jo Adamson ''works the classical whodunit format with great ingenuity. She writes like a dream . . . threading into her tale of revenge and retribution ravishing descriptions'' of the Puerto Rican locale.
POODLE SPRINGS. By Raymond Chandler and Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $18.95.) The creator of the ''Spenser'' novels ''collaborates'' with the classic detective writer by completing Chandler's last book. ''At his very best, Mr. Parker sounds more like Chandler than Chandler himself - but with an edge the master had begun to lose in the waning days of his life.''
THE SIRENS SANG OF MURDER. By Sarah Caudwell. (Delacorte, $16.95.) Sarah Caudwell's trouble-prone young barristers return for ''another great lark'' in her latest novel. ''Although coincidence and happenstance loom large in the plot mechanics, the abundant wit and sheer insouciance of Ms. Caudwell's style make this no nevermind.''
THE STORY OF ANNIE D. By Susan Taylor Chehak. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) This is an ''absolutely stunning first novel'' about a small Nebraska farming town where the protagonist's best friend commits suicide and three young women are raped and murdered.
TALKING GOD. By Tony Hillerman. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) Lieut. Joe Leaphorn and Officer Jim Chee of the Navajo Tribal Police return in a ''brilliant'' and complex suspense story that is part of ''Mr. Hillerman's long-running show-and-tell course in Navajo language and culture.''
TICKET TO RIDE. By Dennis Potter. (Vintage, Paper, $6.95.) The author of ''The Singing Detective'' probes the shattered mind of a murderer ''with tremendous technical assurance'' and an ''expertly tight weave of . . . many rich symbolic and thematic strands.''
 
Current Affairs and Social Commentary
 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN. By Tracy Kidder. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) The author of ''The Soul of a New Machine'' examines ''a year in the life of a fifth-grade class in Holyoke, an industrial city in southwestern Massachusetts''; the book ''is full of the author's genuine love, delight and celebration of the human condition. He has never used his talent so well.''
BARBARIAN SENTIMENTS: How the American Century Ends. By William Pfaff. (Hill & Wang, $19.95.) ''A truly original critic of American diplomacy'' analyzes ''America's historic failure . . . to factor the power and persistence of nationalism around the world into its foreign policy.''
BIG SUGAR: Seasons in the Cane Fields of Florida. By Alec Wilkinson. (Knopf, $18.95.) A writer for The New Yorker manages ''to penetrate the mystery and the misery'' of the West Indian workers who cut America's sugar cane crop. ''Mr. Wilkinson has assembled a vivid collage of the cutter's world.''
CITY: Rediscovering the Center. By William H. Whyte. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The author of ''The Organization Man'' turns his attention to public spaces and urban life. ''His commentary . . . offer[s] a fresh, often controversial perspective. . . . There is genuine brilliance here, born of years of observation.'' THE COCAINE KIDS: The Inside Story of a Teenage Drug Ring. By Terry Williams. (Addison-Wesley, $16.95.) A New York sociologist's report on the five years he spent with a group of teen-age drug dealers. ''What makes [this book] particularly valuable is that Mr. Williams combines his talents as a keen observer with thoughtful, sophisticated analysis.''
THE COMMON INTEREST: How Our Social-Welfare Policies Don't Work, and What We Can Do About Them. By Leslie W. Dunbar. (Pantheon, $22.95.) A longtime liberal social activist challenges current views of poverty with case studies of poor people. ''In this moving book, Mr. Dunbar lets the poor speak for themselves.''
THE ENIGMA OF JAPANESE POWER: People and Politics in a Stateless Nation. By Karel van Wolferen. (Knopf, $24.95.) A Dutch journalist ''has written a distinguished and disturbing book about how the world's new economic superpower is run.''
EUROPEANS. By Jane Kramer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) ''If this truly pleasurable collection of her New Yorker essays is called 'Europeans' - not 'The Europeans' - it is because Ms. Kramer's methodology is to start at the grass roots and work upward. . . . The best reporting works the way she does it.''
FARM: A Year in the Life of an American Farmer. By Richard Rhodes. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The author of ''The Making of the Atomic Bomb'' turns his attention to a Missouri farm family and their cyclical struggles. ''Mr. Rhodes brings empathy and intelligence to his subject. . . . His chronicle is unvarnished, his vision acute.''
FORGIVEN: The Rise and Fall of Jim Bakker and the PTL Ministry. By Charles E. Shepard. (Atlantic Monthly, $22.95.) ''A fascinating behind-the-scenes look at the greed, deceit and manipulation that littered the path to [Jim] Bakker's downfall'' written by the Charlotte Observer reporter who won a Pulitzer Prize for his series of articles on the evangelist.
GENE DREAMS: Wall Street, Academia, and the Rise of Biotechnology. By Robert Teitelman. (Basic Books, $19.95.) ''With lucid grace and an insider's grasp'' the author explains how investors bought the latest scientific ''revolution'' long before profitable products existed. IF WOMEN COUNTED: A New Feminist Economics. By Marilyn Waring. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) ''The major contribution of this angry yet humorous, well-written and accessible book is to demonstrate that . . . the current system of national income accounts is not sufficiently accurate to serve as the basis for public policy decisions.'' INNUMERACY: Mathematical Illiteracy and Its Consequences. By John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) An ''entertaining book'' that attempts to ''inspire a mathematical way of looking at the world that does not depend on much actual mathematics.''
IN THE SHADOW OF THE SACRED GROVE. By Carol Spindel. (Vintage, Paper, $8.95.) A young American artist spends a year living and creating in a West African village. ''Her temperament shines through in her writing - clear, bright, full of splashes of color, skillfully composed . . . a remarkable work.''
JERUSALEM: City of Mirrors. By Amos Elon. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) This book ''is a word portrait like none of those that have come before of the fabled city. It is from the loving but unsparing pen of Israel's most elegant iconoclast.''
LEBANON: Death of a Nation. By Sandra Mackey. (Congdon & Weed, $22.95.) A freelance journalist's ''gloomy'' assessment of the country's disintegration ''consists in making the story of Lebanon's morass readable for the uninitiated.''
LIPSTICK TRACES: A Secret History of the Twentieth Century. By Greil Marcus. (Harvard University, $29.95.) ''A coruscatingly original piece of work'' about the ''carnivalesque subculture'' of the left in this century; ''an absorbing new study.''
LORDS OF POVERTY: The Power, Prestige, and Corruption of the International Aid Business. By Graham Hancock. (Atlantic Monthly, $17.95.) This blistering attack on foreign aid and the bureaucracies that administer it is ''a deadly serious book . . . [that] succeeds in standing the myth of foreign aid on its head, and demands a serious reply from the development industry.''
MAASAI DAYS. By Cheryl Bentsen. (Summit, $19.95.) A young American woman examines the lives of the Masai people of East Africa over a six-year period. The author ''deals with a very serious issue: how a people confronts massive social and economic change.'' MAD DREAMS, SAVING GRACES. Poland: A Nation in Conspiracy. By Michael T. Kaufman. (Random House, $19.95.) An ''indispensable'' account of the struggles between the Polish Government and the Solidarity movement, leavened with the story of the author's own family past.
MATERNAL THINKING: Toward a Politics of Peace. By Sara Ruddick. (Beacon, $24.95.) A philosopher posits a way of thinking based on the practical work involved in mothering children; a ''provocative argument.''
MORE LIKE US: Making America Great Again. By James Fallows. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) A ''balanced and judicious'' comparison of Japanese and American societies leads the author to conclude that the United States' great hope lies ''in its best and most characteristic virtues: its democratic manners . . . and readiness to offer everyone a second chance.''
MOSCOW SPRING. By William Taubman and Jane Taubman. (Summit, $18.95.) A couple who teach at Amherst College recount ''the heady atmosphere of Moscow . . . in early 1988, with all its contradictory nuances and uncertainties.''
THE NEW MONEY MASTERS: Winning Investment Strategies of Soros, Lynch, Steinhardt, Rogers, Neff, Wanger, Michaelis, Carret. By John Train. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) Written in ''a clean, easy style,'' the author has assembled eight profiles of investment geniuses who ''filter everyday experience differently.'' PRIVATE ACTS, SOCIAL CONSEQUENCES: AIDS and the Politics of Public Health. By Ronald Bayer. (Free Press, $22.95.) An associate professor at Columbia University ''has done . . . a welcome service'' in probing ''the manner in which officials have weighed the perceived dangers of AIDS against the individual's constitutional rights.''
SECOND CHANCES: Men, Women, and Children a Decade After Divorce. By Judith S. Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) A psychologist summarizes her 10-year study of the children of divorce with the help of a science writer who contributes to The New York Times. ''As a work of clinical observation, the book is a beautiful piece of writing, full of insights.''
THE SECOND SHIFT: Working Parents and the Revolution at Home. By Arlie Hochschild with Anne Machung. (Viking, $18.95.) This ''insightful report on two-career family life'' is the best discussion of ''what must be the quintessential domestic bind of our time.''
SOMOZA FALLING. By Anthony Lake. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) A ''worthwhile study'' by a former Foreign Service officer about the ouster of the Nicaraguan dictator and the resulting effect on American foreign policy.
THE SUN ALSO SETS: The Limits to Japan's Economic Power. By Bill Emmott. (Times Books, $19.95.) With ''unemotional, finely reasoned arguments,'' the author contends ''that Japan's huge financial surpluses could shrink as rapidly as they appeared and that its power and wealth could prove as ephemeral as that of OPEC.''
THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA: The Political Seduction of the Law. By Robert H. Bork. (Free Press, $22.50.) ''A learned and powerfully argued neoconservative book'' written by the Supreme Court nominee rejected by the Senate in 1987. The book ''is a lucid, elegant, provocative work of legal scholarship.''
TEN MEN DEAD: The Story of the 1981 Irish Hunger Strike. By David Beresford. Introduction by Peter Maas. (Morgan Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) An ''excellent'' history of the 1981 hunger strike in Ireland that details the ''broad cast of characters with insight and care.''
TERRITORY OF LIES. The Exclusive Story of Jonathan Jay Pollard: The American Who Spied on His Country for Israel and How He Was Betrayed. By Wolf Blitzer. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) The Washington bureau chief for The Jerusalem Post ''has written . . . a lucid, highly readable account of one spy case that shook the foundations of the relationship between the United States and Israel.''
WAR AND PEACE IN CENTRAL AMERICA. By Frank McNeil. (Scribners, $19.95.) A 30-year veteran of the Foreign Service writes ''an acerbic chronicle'' of United States policy in Central America since the late 1970's. ''Mr. McNeil deserves admiration for serving his readers as candidly as he served his Government.''
WASTED: The Preppie Murder. By Linda Wolfe. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) This story of the murder of Jennifer Levin, a young New York woman, is ''an excellent, valuable book.''
WOMEN OF DEH KOH: Lives in an Iranian Village. By Erika Friedl. (Smithsonian, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $10.95.) An anthropologist's ''enthralling'' view of an Iranian community of women, drawn from 20 years of fieldwork.
 
Essays, Criticism and Letters
 AGAINST JOIE DE VIVRE: Personal Essays. By Phillip Lopate. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A new collection of essays, ''prickly and combative . . . shrewd and uttered with a supple street-poet elegance.''
AN APPETITE FOR POETRY. By Frank Kermode. (Harvard University, $22.50.) This collection of 10 essays by a literary critic ''is a fervent reminder of the glory of literature in a greedy decade whose academic critics are rewarded for abandoning their calling.''
THE CALL OF STORIES: Teaching and the Moral Imagination. By Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) The eminent psychiatrist talks about why and how literature can make a difference, beginning with his own life; a ''persuasive book.''
THE COMPANY WE KEEP: An Ethics of Fiction. By Wayne C. Booth. (University of California, $29.95.) ''In this almost indecently satisfying book'' a professor of English ''examines the strategies of writers and the counterstrategies of readers, and speculates on all the possibilities of relation between these two.'' GREAT PLAINS. By Ian Frazier. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) The essayist takes readers on an expansive tour of the Great Plains. ''This is a terrific book. . . . Mr. Frazier is a skilled writer, and he succeeds in interesting us in what interests him.''
THE IMAGE OF THE BLACK IN WESTERN ART, Volume Four: From the American Revolution to World War I. Part One: Slaves and Liberators. Part Two: Black Models and White Myths. By Hugh Honour. (Menil Foundation/Harvard University, $50 each.) A British art historian's ''magisterial'' look at black people in white culture. ''It is a rare occasion in the history of art when we are able to glimpse so vividly how image-making serves as an instrument of oppression.''
ITALIAN DAYS. By Barbara Grizzuti Harrison. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $22.95.) A ''lush, compendious memoir of several months of travel in Italy . . . adds a new dimension'' to travel literature - ''a sense of personal direction.''
LETTERS FROM A WAR ZONE: Writings 1976-1989. By Andrea Dworkin. (Dutton, $18.95.) Essays, speeches and occasional pieces from the radical feminist writer and novelist. ''Andrea Dworkin is still out there fighting, and hers is a very specific battle: against the way American culture treats women.''
THE LETTERS OF JACK LONDON. Volume One: 1896-1905. Volume Two: 1906-1912. Volume Three: 1913-1916. Edited by Earle Labor, Robert C. Leitz 3d and I. Milo Shepard. (Stanford University, $139.50.) A collection of more than 1,500 letters by ''the most widely read American writer in the world.''
THE LETTERS OF JOHN CHEEVER. Edited by Benjamin Cheever. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Selected correspondence of the prizewinning fiction writer, ''colorful and witty . . . crude and routine.''
METAPHOR & MEMORY: Essays. By Cynthia Ozick. (Knopf, $19.95.) A collection of reviews and commentaries on writing and writers: ''When insight, feeling and the writer's art come together . . . the distinction between essay and story seems unimportant.''
THE MOST BEAUTIFUL HOUSE IN THE WORLD. By Witold Rybczynski. (Viking, $18.95.) A professor of architecture relates the experience of building his own home. ''A gem of a book . . . with a wealth of meaning.''
NO MAN'S LAND: The Place of the Woman Writer in the Twentieth Century. Volume Two: Sexchanges. By Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. (Yale University, $29.95.) In this second volume of a projected three-volume work, ''Ms. Gilbert and Ms. Gubar write with facility'' about American and British literary modernism and the sexual anxieties it expresses.
NOW, WHERE WERE WE? By Roy Blount Jr. (Villard, $17.95.) A ''deft new collection of essays'' from the humorist is ''brilliantly loopy, reassuringly subversive.''
READING RUSSELL: Essays 1941-1988. On Ideas, Literature, Art, Theater, Music, Places, and Persons. By John Russell. (Abrams, $29.95.) Depth, experience, seriousness and gentility are joined in this ''handsome'' book of pieces by the chief art critic of The New York Times.
TRAVELS WITH ALICE. By Calvin Trillin. (Ticknor & Fields, $18.95.) ''One of the classiest and funniest essay writers to appear regularly between hard covers'' continues his culinary adventures around the globe.
VLADIMIR NABOKOV: Selected Letters, 1940-1977. Edited by Dmitri Nabokov and Matthew J. Bruccoli. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $29.95.) A ''solid volume of selected correspondence . . . scrupulously prepared'' by the author's son and a professor of English at the University of South Carolina.
WHAT AM I DOING HERE. By Bruce Chatwin. (Viking, $19.95.) This last work by the author, who died in 1989, is a mixed bag of travel writing, fiction and reminiscences; ''what comes through in his last book is a life miscellaneous and on the move, traveled on foot, but never pedestrian.''
THE WRITING LIFE. By Annie Dillard. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) The author of ''Pilgrim at Tinker's Creek'' turns her attention to the work of being a writer. ''Annie Dillard is a wonderful writer and 'The Writing Life' is full of joys.''
WRITING A WOMAN'S LIFE. By Carolyn G. Heilbrun. (Norton, $14.95.) An ''astute and provocative book . . . of wise and witty essays'' about ''the lives of independent and ambitious women.''
