Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2045 words

HEADLINE: ART

BYLINE: By JOHN RUSSELL; John Russell is the chief art critic of The New York Times.

 BODY:
The price of books on art has been rising steadily, though by no means as fast as the price of some kinds of art at auction. What $20 would have bought not so long ago may cost close to $100 today. Sometimes it's worth it (always provided that we have the money). Year after year, the catalogues of major exhibitions are the definitive studies of the works in question. Current examples are ''Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism'' by William Rubin (Museum of Modern Art/Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown, $70), the Metropolitan Museum's ''Canaletto'' by Katharine Baetjer and J. G. Links (Abrams, $60) and the National Gallery's ''Frans Hals,'' edited by Seymour Slive (Prestel Art Books/Te Neues Publishing, 15 East 76th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; $60). 
 
*
 THE ART OF FLORENCE. By Glenn Andres, John M. Hunisak and A. Richard Turner. Principal photography by Takashi Okamura. 1,312 pp. in two boxed volumes. (Abbeville, $385.) Meanwhile, however, a barrier of some kind has been broken by the Abbeville Press in New York, which has produced a two-volume, 1,312-page book that retails at $385. The set is known to be both the brainchild and the favorite son of Robert Abrams, Abbeville's president. It was originally nurtured by H. W. Janson before his death in 1982. His one-volume history of art has long been standard reading for the student of the subject. Its general tone could, in fact, be called Jansonian - steady going, well paced, avuncular.
Architecture is given equal time with painting and sculpture. The city of Florence is treated as a composite work of art whose development is detailed from one generation to the next. Banking, trade, real estate, politics, religion and relations with other cities play their part. Anyone who works through the book, line by line, will know a great deal about Florence in its every aspect.
One reason for the layman to splurge on the book is that it is wonderful to look at. Takashi Okamura is in his way a great photographer. Thanks to him, the owner of this book will see more, and see better, than he will ever see in Florence. Standing shoulder to shoulder in the crowd, searching for the coin that will turn on the low-wattage lighting for two minutes, chasing down the sacristan who may or may not have the key, thwarted by strikes and inconvenient opening hours, we rarely see either the city or its works of art as Mr. Okamura presents them. In his streets, the human presence is nowhere to be seen. (Still less, the Florentine traffic.) In his churches, optimum conditions prevail. He has the best camera. The lighting is perfect. He sees the art at the right angle and from the right distance. Everything is done for him, and he delivers.
At the same time, it could be said that his arresting images are almost too luxurious, too satiny, too apparently pristine. Old master painting is rarely pristine and very often it is not easy. It has weathered the ages, but the ages are likely to have left their mark. And that mark may be vital to our understanding. Without it, something fundamental may be lost. The old masters did not have Japanese good taste and might not have wanted it.
And we have to ask who needs this book, and whether it is worth $385. Florentine art from 1299 to roughly 1575 has been covered in book form at every level from the tourist primer to the learned archival study that comes panniered with footnotes. Necessarily, the book covers ground that has been trodden many times before. It should also be said that it is as heavy as a chained Bible. To pick it up without wincing, you need to have won the Olympic shot put - not too long ago.
Even so, as a book to look at, this one is very seductive. If you want to give someone a bang-up, no-holds-barred, once-for-all-time present, this may be just the right thing.
 
*
 CHAGALL: The Russian Years 1907-1922. By Aleksandr Kamensky. Translated by Catherine Phillips. 376 pp. (Rizzoli, $100.) Until very recently the early years of Marc Chagall in his native Russia were not easy to decipher. Doors were closed. So were archives. In particular, what exactly had become of his big murals of 1920-22 for the Jewish Theater in Moscow was an impenetrable secret. All this was owed to many factors - not least, to the fact that Chagall was Jewish. (In his native Vitebsk, he is to this day virtually a taboo figure.) Yet Chagall had played an important role in Soviet artistic life after the Russian Revolution. Moreover, some of his best early work was believed to be still in private hands.
For all those reasons, Aleksandr Kamensky's book about his Russian years is indispensable. Though many of its illustrations are drawn from the West - above all, from the collections, lately much enriched, of the Musee National d'Art Moderne in Paris - it also digs deep into collections both public and private in the Soviet Union.
Vintage photographs of Chagall and his colleagues in the Jewish Theater give a vivid impression of those heady days, and the book also reprints some important articles and interviews that appeared in the Russian press from 1914. Mr. Kamensky's levelheaded text also contains much valuable material.
 
*
 UNIVERSAL LIMITED ART EDITIONS. A History and Catalogue: The First Twenty-Five Years. By Esther Sparks. 552 pp. (Art Institute of Chicago/Abrams, $95.) More than anyone else, Tatyana Grosman and her Universal Limited Art Editions transformed the potential of the print in the United States. A native of Siberia who immigrated here in 1943, she began U.L.A.E. with nothing at all in a tiny house in West Islip, L.I., in 1955. Her first press cost her $15, secondhand. She knew nothing about prints and nothing about business. Her capital was her feeling for art, her lifelong knowledge of artists and a granitic refusal to take either ''no'' or ''perhaps'' for an answer. If artists didn't want to work with her, she kept after them until finally they sank into the rented limousine that was to take them to West Islip. Once there, they loved it. How would they not, when each in turn had the exclusive attention of the entire workshop for as long as was needed, together with the inventive hospitality of its founder?
Neither time nor money nor trouble had any meaning. Schedules could stay open for years. Weeks of work could be ditched with never a cross word spoken. Food, drink, music (live or recorded) - all were custom built. Larry Rivers said: ''When she began to play Russian gypsy music for me while I worked, I'm afraid I was hers forever.''
She won over even those who thought, with Robert Rauschenberg, that the second half of the 20th century was ''no time to start drawing on rocks.'' And if museum people didn't want to see the finished product, she went on foot to call on them, carrying the prints in a portfolio bigger than herself.
From small beginnings (prices from $60 to $200) she went on to rack up in all 129 prints by Jasper Johns, 113 by Robert Rauschenberg and 21 by Barnett Newman, together with major undertakings by Helen Frankenthaler, Robert Motherwell, Larry Rivers, James Rosenquist, Jim Dine and others. The very word ''print'' had a new meaning by the time she was through, and so did the word ''quality.''
The present book derives from the purchase by the Art Institute of Chicago of Grosman's complete personal archive of the production of U.L.A.E. (to which she added as a gift, before she died in 1982, 4,200 drawings, proofs and other memorabilia). Written and compiled by Esther Sparks of the Art Institute, and with a memoir of Grosman by Amei Wallach, it has the right plain majesty.
 
*
 HEROIC DEEDS AND MYSTIC FIGURES: A New Reading of Rubens' Life of Maria de' Medici. By Ronald Forsyth Millen and Robert Erich Wolf. 321 pp. (Princeton University, $60.) RUBENS: The Artist as Collector. By Jeffrey M. Muller. 314 pp. (Princeton University, $55.) Next to his hometown of Antwerp, Princeton is now the second home of Peter Paul Rubens, one of the greatest painters who ever lived. These two new books detail, respectively, the precise history - social, political, allegorical - of one of his most glorious (and also most devious) commissions. Marie de' Medici as she appears today in a 24-part serial painting on the walls of the Louvre was a very different person from Marie de' Medici as she was in life. To the adjustments and transformations in question, Ronald Forsyth Millen and Robert Erich Wolf in ''Heroic Deeds and Mystic Figures'' are our surest guides. They are learned, lucid, concise and witty. There are even moments at which the Duc de Saint-Simon himself would not have been a sharper observer. What better recommendation?
That Rubens collected has always been known. But how much? And to what end? These have hitherto been the concern of specialists. It is Jeffrey M. Muller's contention in ''Rubens: The Artist as Collector'' that Rubens did not collect works of art simply for his private enjoyment, or to refill his professional gas tank (not that he ever ran on empty). On the contrary, almost his every purchase contributed in one way or another to the social, economic and political game plan that he pursued throughout his life with an incomparable dexterity. (Private affection entered into it, also. Any exchange of portraits played an important part in Rubens's emotional life.) It is the why, as much as the what, of the collections that is important to Mr. Muller, and he makes it important to us, too. Both these books will delight the Rubens enthusiast.
 
*
 EGON SCHIELE: Sketchbooks. By Christian M. Nebehay. Translated by Renee Nebehay-King. 374 pp. (Rizzoli, $65.) To some, the Austrian painter Egon Schiele (1890-1918) set a new standard of free and forthright expression in erotic matters and should be held in honor for that reason. To others, he is a gamy, one-note visual novelettist who is a master at grabbing our attention but does not sustain it for long.
Irrespective of where we stand on that matter, ''Egon Schiele: Sketchbooks'' is indispensable to any student of Schiele. This is the real thing, the firsthand thing, the thing done for the sake of it (and the sake of Schiele's sanity, too, sometimes). It can be welcomed unreservedly.
Hudson Hills Press has now brought out a second edition of Erwin Mitsch's ''Art of Egon Schiele'' ($50). It is a sturdy, hard-wearing survey by a Viennese scholar who organized a major Schiele show as long ago as 1968, and it touches all the bases.
 
*
 ART OF OUR CENTURY: The Chronicle of Western Art, 1900 to the Present. Edited by Jean-Louis Ferrier, with Yann le Pichon. Translation supervised by Walter D. Glanze. 896 pp. (Prentice Hall, $60; after Dec. 31, $70.) Something of a novelty in English, this book traverses our century from a strictly Parisian point of view. By no means the traditional wordy run-through, it comes in the form of a chronology combined with the techniques of the television news-bite. We get the facts, the dates and brief contemporary commentaries on the salient events of each year. We are not asked to agree with either emphasis or opinion, but we are shown the way the art world looked from the city that for more than half a century was its unquestioned capital. The pace is brisk, the spokesmen well chosen, the layout often arresting. We can all learn something from this book.
 
*
 BIEDERMEIER: 1815-1835. Architecture, Painting, Sculpture, Decorative Arts and Fashion. By Georg Himmelheber. Translated by John William Gabriel. 272 pp. (Prestel Art Books/Te Neues Publishing, 15 East 76th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; $65.) Long dismissed as timid, bourgeois and lacking in energy and panache, the Biedermeier style is back in fashion almost to the point of parody. This book (an abridged version of the catalogue of a great exhibition held in Munich last winter) is our best introduction to Biedermeier in architecture, painting, sculpture and the decorative arts. (Music gets a look in, too). As a corrective to certain supposedly bothersome aspects of our own day, and as a portrait of an age in which all went well (on the surface) and the arts were well made, well bred and essentially consoling, it could not be bettered. A prettier book will not soon come our way.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1350 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL

BYLINE: By ANATOLE BROYARD; Anatole Broyard, a former editor of The Book Review, teaches creative writing in Cambridge, Mass.

 BODY:
Like experimental novels in which the technique or approach take the place of plot or character, there are now travel books in which the vehicle is the thing and the place or people are secondary. Like modern paintings, these books suggest that we've already seen the world, and now it's best looked at from a kayak, a rubber raft or balloon, in what Willem de Kooning called ''slipping glimpses.'' Perhaps the quintessentially modern travel book would be that of the big-game hunter, who sees the sights only through his sights, who goes to a place to shoot and kill whatever ''wildlife'' it offers.
At the other extreme is a book like Tim Robinson's STONES OF ARAN: Pilgrimage (298 pp., Viking, $18.95), which is not so much an experience of a place as a kind of obsessive examination of it, as if the writer had lost something there - in the sand, the stones or high grass - and was trying to find it. This is a kind of travel writing The New Yorker sometimes sponsors: a virtuosity of gratuitous fact-gathering, a penitential recording of minutiae, a recitation of information as if it were prayer. Mr. Robinson seems bemused by matter itself. He travels not so much in a place as in ontology. 
An island off the west coast of Ireland, Aran was made famous by Robert Flaherty's film ''Man of Aran'' in 1934. But while Aran is certainly photogenic, especially in black and white, it's hard to see why Mr. Robinson, who is a map maker and conservationist, should be so fascinated by its kelp burning, its kiln firing and its legends. Most legends are about as interesting as somebody else's dreams. Reading Mr. Robinson, one longs for some human beings, some impious trespassers, to interfere with this solemn landscape. From time to time, the author's personality peeps out of his prose, as if he had taken his lunch out of his pocket, but after a few nibbles it's gone.
Eric Lawlor, the author of IN BOLIVIA (226 pp., Vintage, Paper, $8.95), is a British journalist who lives in the United States; he tells us that he went to Bolivia because it was the first word he ever spoke. At the age of 3, he ''was being fed an egg one morning when I swept my plate to the floor and bellowed 'Bolivia'!'' This is promising, and so is the fact that Bolivia was an ''obsession'' with his father. To travel through one's father's obsessions might give travel writing a new dimension - but Mr. Lawlor doesn't pursue this filial or Oedipal theme.
Even so, he is a bit too ready to see himself as picturesque, poised against incongruity. To travel in cleverness is just another kind of kayak. Some of his observations are amusing, like people running down the steep inclines of La Paz because, once started, they can't stop. But once again Mr. Lawlor misses a chance to do a metaphorical riff here.
There are too many Bolivians in this book who sound as if they've been lying in wait for Mr. Lawlor, editing their deadpan conversations. Just as Bruce Chatwin always managed to find someone, even in the Australian outback, to talk to about Wittgenstein, Mr. Lawlor can always come up with a Bolivian hawking small ironies in the street.
Jeremy Bernstein writes in two voices in his most recent book, IN THE HIMALAYAS: Journeys Through Nepal, Tibet and Bhutan (illustrated, 336 pp., Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $10.95). One voice sounds like a report from someone sent by a multinational corporation or some obscure arm of the State Department to assess the political and economic potential of Nepal, Tibet and Bhutan. Air service, malaria control, agricultural efficiency - there's not much here for the reader of average sensibility, though parts of this book did appear in The New Yorker.
But when Mr. Bernstein goes trekking in the mountains, the book ascends with him. It comes almost as a surprise to find him having fun. Like Tim Robinson, Mr. Bernstein seems at first to feel guilty about merely responding to, just enjoying, another culture.
Edited and translated by R. David Arkush, a professor of history, and Leo O. Lee, a professor of Chinese literature, LAND WITHOUT GHOSTS: Chinese Impressions of America From the Mid-Nineteenth Century to the Present (illustrated, 309 pp., University of California, $25) is a curious affair. At first all is surprise, as the earlier Chinese visitors flinch from the ''savage roar'' of American speech and wonder at the awful daring of the sexes who sit ''with their shoes touching.'' A later writer is bemused by the American inattention to the ''esthetics'' of ''human character.'' And then, as the Chinese begin to reflect the influence of their various cultural revolutions, we read of ''Spanish dancing'' to jazz in sadly inauthentic Chinese restaurants.
Zhang Jie, a popular Chinese novelist who visited New York in 1982 and became a friend of Annie Dillard, looks around her hotel room near Lincoln Center and asks rhetorically ''had anyone ever been killed in this room?'' In Times Square, she finds the decadence she came to see, remarking that ''there was absolutely no feeling of innocence, purity, beauty, goodness, or anything of that sort to speak of.''
First available here as ''The Sudden View'' in 1953, A VISIT TO DON OTAVIO: A Mexican Journey (319 pp., Eland/Hippocrene Books, Paper, $10.95) has been sporadically in and out of print and very hard to find. We should be grateful to Eland Books for bringing it out again. Mrs. Bedford is a well-known British novelist who also published a two-volume biography of Aldous Huxley, and ''Don Otavio'' is regarded by aficionados as a classic of British travel writing.
She went to Mexico with an unidentified American woman just as literary, conventionally snobbish and idiosyncratic as herself. ''Don Otavio'' is exactly what a travel book should be: an unpacking of all one's moral, intellectual and esthetic luggage in a foreign place. Mrs. Bedford has an opinion - one worth having - about everything. Naturally, she has many prejudices, for prejudice is the vehicle of the British literary traveler, and long may it wave.
She is generally either provoked, bored or amused, and these moods are like three wines served with each meal. She is provoked when ''Something Else'' creeps in: some unclassifiable quirk that is not consistent with her conception of the country. She is bored when her trip bogs down in the mechanics of travel, when ''the proposed enchantment is seen as our planned and burdened crawl about the earth,'' or because a place is ''forlorn to make one cry.'' She is amused when Mexico produces a grand eccentric with the face of one of ''Goya's minor courtiers'' and a beautiful house on a lake, where he presses Mrs. Bedford and her friend to stay forever.
She is dissatisfied with D. H. Lawrence's Mexican novel, ''The Plumed Serpent.'' ''Something,'' she says, ''was being constantly expostulated and one never knew quite what.'' Her own expostulations are never ineffable. She observes, for example, of Mexican folk music that ''it strives to be at once virile and melancholy, and succeeds in sounding military and yearning.'' At a museum, she and her companion are shown ''the embalming syringe'' used on the corpse of the Emperor Maximilian. Like the poet Elizabeth Bishop, who said of Brazil that there were ''too many waterfalls here,'' Mrs. Bedford's companion finds a volcano de trop.
About the attitudes of the Conquistadors and their descendants toward Mexico, Mrs. Bedford observes that ''the distinction between the spirit of adventure and the spirit of inquiry had not yet been drawn.'' And when a man on a bus offers them tortillas he has been carrying inside his shirt, she reflects that ''hygieneJU has cut off man from man more than any class distinctions.'' About two-thirds of the way through her trip, she says, ''I was in that as it were tertiary state of fatigue where the nerves and senses lie bared to direct contact with the world and there is no longer distance or matter between the vision and the absorption, where the mind races, recording, lucid but empty, and beauty can become ours through osmosis.'' That's traveling.

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 78, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 3185 words

HEADLINE: Notable Paperbacks

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
This list of paperbacks is a selection from the New & Noteworthy column since the December 1988 Christmas issue. It includes novels, poetry, stories, biography, memoirs, letters, history, essays and science.
 
ADAM, EVE, AND THE SERPENT, by Elaine Pagels. (Vintage, $8.95.) The author of ''The Gnostic Gospels'' shows how politics might have helped transform the cryptic Garden of Eden myth from a celebration of freedom to a condemnation of original sin.
 
AMERICA INVULNERABLE: The Quest for Absolute Security From 1812 to Star Wars, by James Chace and Caleb Carr. (Summit, $12.95.) The Strategic Defense Initiative, the authors argue, is the outgrowth of an obsessive belief in unilateral defense that is rooted in the War of 1812, when the British burned the White House. 
 
AN ARTIST OF THE FLOATING WORLD, by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Vintage, $8.95.) A novel about a Japanese artist who used his talents to glorify the imperialist movement.
 
ANTHILLS OF THE SAVANNAH, by Chinua Achebe. (Anchor/Doubleday, $7.95.) A Nigerian novelist's tale of three friends who try to run a country.
 
THE ARK SAKURA, by Kobo Abe. Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. (Vintage International, $8.95.) Inside a hollowed-out mountain, a Japanese beggar assembles a group of outcasts intent on surviving nuclear war.
 
BAD BEHAVIOR, by Mary Gaitskill. (Vintage, $7.95.) For the unhappy characters who populate these matter-of-fact stories, there is nothing very remarkable about sadomasochism.
 
BEING WITH CHILDREN, by Phillip Lopate. (Poseidon, $9.95.) A novelist and essayist tells about his experiences trying to teach writing to children on New York's Upper West Side.
 
BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Signet/New American Library, $5.95.) The true story of Rob Marshall, a wealthy New Jersey suburbanite, who arranges to have his wife shot to death during a faked robbery. Also available from Signet is a new edition of FATAL VISION ($5.95), Mr. McGinniss's account of the murder by Jeffrey McDonald of his pregnant wife and two children in 1970. In a new epilogue the author rebuts a New Yorker article that accused him of tricking Mr. McDonald into confiding in him.
 
THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD, by Iris Murdoch. (Penguin, $8.95.) A novel about lapsed revolutionaries from Oxford who decide to bankroll a friend who is writing a utopian tract.
 
BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $5.50.) In another novel about eccentrics in Baltimore, Maggie Moran, a cheerful, meddling woman, marries off her son to a 17-year-old she shanghais from an abortion clinic.
 
A BRIGHT SHINING LIE: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam, by Neil Sheehan. (Vintage, $12.95.) This story of an officer whose deceptions came to typify the war in Vietnam won a National Book Award and a Pulitzer Prize.
 
BY SILENCE BETRAYED: Sexual Abuse of Children in America, by John Crewdson. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A journalist shows that when it comes to sexual abuse children have more to fear from their families and friends than from violent interlopers.
 
CAPOTE: A Biography, by Gerald Clarke. (Ballantine, $12.95.) A mesmerizing account of Truman Capote's lifelong masquerade ball.
 
THE CAPTAIN AND THE ENEMY, by Graham Greene. (Penguin, $7.95.) A novel whose narrator, deep in the Central American jungles, seeks the true identity of a mysterious stranger who once spirited him away from a boarding school, claiming to have won him in a backgammon game.
 
CLOAK & GOWN: Scholars in the Secret War, 1939-1961, by Robin W. Winks. (Quill/Morrow, $14.95.) How Yale University has provided the Government with very well educated spies.
 
COMING OF AGE IN THE MILKY WAY, by Timothy Ferris. (Anchor/Doubleday, $10.95.) A chronicle of how the human spirit outgrew the earth and set its sights to the sky.
 
DANGEROUS DOSSIERS: Exposing the Secret War Against America's Greatest Authors, by Herbert Mitgang. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The Federal Bureau of Investigation's secret files on Sinclair Lewis, William Faulkner and other literary suspects.
 
THE CONTROL REVOLUTION: Technological and Economic Origins of the Information Society, by James R. Beniger. (Harvard University, $12.95.) How the Industrial Revolution begat the Information Revolution, by producing a society so complex that it requires computers to keep it from inevitably slipping toward entropy.
 
A DEADLY SILENCE. The Ordeal of Cheryl Pierson: A Case of Incest and Murder, by Dena Kleiman. (Signet/ New American Library, $4.95.) A New York Times reporter tells about the sexually abused Long Island teen-ager who paid a classmate $400 to kill her father.
 
DICTIONARY OF THE KHAZARS: A Lexicon Novel in 100,000 Words, by Milorad Pavic. Translated by Christina Pribicevic-Zoric. (Vintage, $9.95.) A novel, in the form of a do-it-yourself narrative, about a fictional tribe called the Khazars, who lived in a land where the seasons were marked by calendars that flowed in both directions and it was possible to read colors as though they were words.
 
DISCOS AND DEMOCRACY: China in the Throes of Reform, by Orville Schell. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) In a book published a year before China's latest cataclysm, a Western journalist wonders whether the ancient society can withstand the pressures of modernization.
 
THE DREAMS OF REASON: The Computer and the Rise of the Sciences of Complexity, by Heinz R. Pagels. (Bantam, $9.95.) A physicist tells how the computer, like the telescope and the microscope, will change the way we understand the world.
 
DUSK: And Other Stories, by James Salter. (North Point, $7.95.) Laconic stories about exiles and drifters.
 
EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) In one of these short stories, a high school astronomy teacher's campaign to save an old elm tree threatens to erupt into a neighborhood war.
 
AN EMPIRE OF THEIR OWN: How the Jews Invented Hollywood, by Neal Gabler. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) Spurned by East Coast high society, entrepreneurs like Adolph Zukor, L. B. Mayer, the Warner brothers and Harry Cohn established their own fantasy land in Southern California.
 
THE FACTS: A Novelist's Autobiography, by Philip Roth. (Penguin, $7.95.) Philip Roth comes clean with the true story of his heavily fictionalized life, including, for good measure, commentary by his character Nathan Zuckerman.
 
FAMILY MEMORIES: An Autobiographical Journey, by Rebecca West. Edited by Faith Evans. (Penguin, $7.95.) Surprisingly absorbing recollections about the writer's relatives.
 
FLANAGAN'S VERSION: A Spectator's Guide to Science on the Eve of the 21st Century, by Dennis Flanagan. (Vintage, $8.95.) After spending 35 years as editor of Scientific American, Dennis Flanagan learned that science is the greatest spectator sport of all.
 
HER OWN TERMS, by Judith Grossman. (Ivy, $3.95.) A refugee from dreary south London finds that the Oxford literary world can be just as oppressive to women.
 
HEROES OF THEIR OWN LIVES. The Politics and History of Family Violence: Boston 1880-1960, by Linda Gordon. (Penguin, $8.95.) A history of a society's attitudes toward child abuse, incest and wife beating.
 
THE HIGH ROAD, by Edna O'Brien. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) A novel about an Irish expatriate who shatters the languid calm of a Spanish island when she has an affair with a local peasant girl.
 
IN SEARCH OF J. D. SALINGER, by Ian Hamilton. (Vintage, $8.95.) A very unauthorized biography of the writer who chose to slip through a tear in the Veil of Maya and disappear into the silence of New Hampshire.
 
IN THE AGE OF THE SMART MACHINE: The Future of Work and Power, by Shoshana Zuboff. (Basic Books, $11.95.) Thanks to the computer, work is becoming less a matter of manipulating things than manipulating symbols.
 
JULIA PARADISE, by Rod Jones. (Penguin, $6.95.) The tale of a Shanghai psychoanalyst who cures a missionary's wife of tormenting fantasies by making love to her.
 
THE KING OF THE FIELDS, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) A fairy tale of sex and violence about a tribe of cave-dwelling hunters and gatherers who fight the farmers, set in prehistoric Poland. Translated by the author from the Yiddish.
 
LIBRA, by Don DeLillo. (Penguin, $4.95.) A novel about a C.I.A. conspiracy to kill President John F. Kennedy and blame Fidel Castro by fingering a Communist dupe named Lee Harvey Oswald.
 
LAST DAYS OF THE SICILIANS: The FBI's War Against the Mafia, by Ralph Blumenthal. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) After Carmine Galante was murdered in a Brooklyn restaurant in 1979, Federal investigators learned of a Mafia within the Mafia, which used a network of pizzerias to launder drug money.
 
THE LETTERS OF JOHN CHEEVER, edited by Benjamin Cheever. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) A hefty selection of letters, accompanied by editorial commentary, that presents a loving but far from idealized portrait.
 
LIFE, A USER'S MANUAL, by Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. (Godine, $14.95.) Complex word games and characters that include a millionaire who makes jigsaw puzzles that he himself must solve.
 
LIVES OF THE TWINS, by Rosamond Smith. (Avon, $3.95.) Joyce Carol Oates's pseudonymous novel about a woman who has a secret affair with her therapist's estranged identical twin.
 
LONGING FOR THE HARMONIES: Themes and Variations From Modern Physics, by Frank Wilczek and Betsy Devine. (Norton, $9.95.) How physicists find order beneath the cacophony of subatomic particles, quasars, pulsars and black holes.
 
MASCARA, by Ariel Dorfman. (Penguin, $7.95.) An ominous novel about a man without a face who steals the visages of others.
 
THE MATHEMATICAL TOURIST: Snapshots of Modern Mathematics, by Ivars Peterson. (Freeman, $10.95.) Mathematicians seek truth and beauty with fractals, prime numbers, strange attractors, cellular automata and other abstractions.
 
THE MIDDLEMAN AND OTHER STORIES, by Bharati Mukherjee. (Fawcett, $3.95.) From Vietnam, the Caribbean, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka to Queens, Ann Arbor and Cedar Falls, the modern immigrants in these short stories create a multiplicity of new worlds.
 
MISSING BEAUTY, by Teresa Carpenter. (Zebra, $4.95.) In a true story of obsession and murder, a middle-aged medical school professor resorts to homicide to kick an expensive habit: Robin Benedict, a prostitute from Boston's Combat Zone.
 
NATURAL OBSESSIONS: Striving to Unlock the Deepest Secrets of the Cancer Cell, by Natalie Angier. (Warner, $14.95.) A journalist becomes resident anthropologist in a molecular biology lab, chronicling the search for genes that cause cells to become malignant.
 
NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS, by Richard Wilbur. Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) This collection of poems by the man named the United States' poet laureate in 1987 won a Pulitzer Prize.
 
NORA: A Biography of Nora Joyce, by Brenda Maddox. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) A young Irish chambermaid named Nora Barnacle eloped with an aspiring writer named James Joyce for a mismatch made in heaven.
 
NOTHING BUT THE BEST: The Struggle for Perfection at the Juilliard School, by Judith Kogan. (Limelight Editions, $10.95.) A lawyer and harpist who graduated from Juilliard tells of cutthroat competition at her alma mater.
 
NOWHERE TO GO: The Tragic Odyssey of the Homeless Mentally Ill, by E. Fuller Torrey. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $8.95.) A psychiatrist blames his colleagues for treating the ''worried well,'' who can afford to pay their bills, at the expense of the homeless.
 
PACO'S STORY, by Larry Heinemann. (Penguin, $7.95.) A novel about a Vietnam veteran whose nightmares follow him back to Texas and a job in a greasy spoon. The novel won a National Book Award.
 
THE PAPER: The Life and Death of The New York Herald Tribune, by Richard Kluger with the assistance of Phyllis Kluger. (Vintage, $16.95.) The history of the newspaper that gave Tom Wolfe his start.
 
PARIS TROUT, by Pete Dexter. (Penguin, $7.95.) After a Georgia shopkeeper named Paris Trout kills a 14-year-old black girl, the people in the town of Cotton Point try to convince themselves that they are somehow different from their racist, paranoid neighbor. The novel won a National Book Award.
 
PARTING THE WATERS: America in the King Years 1954-63, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) A Pulitzer Prize-winning history of the Civil Rights movement.
 
THE PIGEON, by Patrick Suskind. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $5.95.) The well-ordered life of a Parisian bank guard is transformed completely when a pigeon shows up at his door.
 
THE POET AT THE PIANO: Portraits of Writers, Filmmakers, Playwrights, and Other Artists at Work, by Michiko Kakutani. (Peter Bedrick, $8.95.) A collection of profiles, including such subjects as Saul Bellow, Ingmar Bergman, Sam Shepard and Laurence Olivier, by a New York Times book critic.
 
THE POWER GAME: How Washington Works, by Hedrick Smith. (Ballantine, $5.95.) In recent times, Washington has become fractured into hundreds of power centers, each fighting to garner enough influence to get things done.
 
THE PREDATORS' BALL: The Inside Story of Drexel Burnham and the Rise of the Junk Bond Raiders, by Connie Bruck. (Penguin, $8.95.) The rise and fall of Drexel Burnham Lambert and its West Coast Wunderkind, Michael Milken.
 
THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED: Book Three of the Vampire Chronicles, by Anne Rice. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The mother vampire of them all awakens from a 6,000-year-old sleep with a plan to bring peace on earth by killing most of the men.
 
THE QUESTION OF HU, by Jonathan D. Spence. (Vintage, $8.95.) A history of a curious Chinese tourist who was thrown into a French insane asylum in the early 18th century.

THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS: Economic Change and Military Conflict From 1500 to 2000, by Paul Kennedy. (Vintage, $12.95.) When mighty empires hasten their own demise by spending too much money on the military.

THE THIRD GENERATION, By Chester Himes. (Thunder's Mouth, $11.95.) A searing novel, published in 1954, about a black professor whose wife tries to pass for white.
 
THREE SCIENTISTS AND THEIR GODS: Looking for Meaning in an Age of Information, by Robert Wright. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Masterly portraits of three eccentric thinkers in search of the secrets of life.
 
TRACKS, by Louise Erdrich. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The Chippewa ancestors of the characters in ''Love Medicine'' and ''The Beet Queen'' fight winter, smallpox and a conquering alien culture.

UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK: The Life Story of Christopher Nolan, by Christopher Nolan. (Delta, $7.95.) A paralyzed poet tells how he learned to flex the muscles of his mind.

WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The television journalist recalls how World War II transformed a sleepy city with Southern efficiency and Northern charm into a boom-town bureaucracy.
 
WHATEVER HAPPENED TO GLOOMY GUS OF THE CHICAGO BEARS? by Robert Coover. (Collier/ Macmillan, $7.95.) A novel about an ambitious young Quaker named Richard Nixon who becomes a football star.

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1610 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Rent Regulation;
Extending the Right to a Renewal Lease

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
WHAT is a ''nontraditional'' family? Should people who consider themselves members of such families have a right to succeed to a rent-stabilized apartment when the tenant named on the lease dies or moves out?
The New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal thinks so. As the administrator of the rent-stabilization code, the agency last month promulgated a new emergency rule granting lease renewal rights to those who are using an apartment as their primary residence and who can show an ''emotional and financial commitment and interdependence'' with the tenant named on the lease.
A temporary restraining order obtained by the Rent Stabilization Association, a major organization of rental owners, has prevented the order from going into effect. But the legal, practical and human questions it raises are unlikely to evaporate as long as there is the concern that elderly people or AIDS victims may be evicted and left homeless when their living partners, who are named on the lease, die or move out. 
As in the case of the five-year moratorium on alterations or demolitions of single-room-occupancy buildings by New York City, the state's order represents an effort to protect the occupancy rights of a socially fragile population on the basis of a housing emergency. In July the New York State Court of Appeals overturned the city's S.R.O. law, and last week the United States Supreme Court declined to hear the city's appeal.
Under the emergency stabilization order, owners would effectively lose the ability to select a successor tenant in an undeterminable number of apartments. They would lose the right to a vacancy rent increase in those apartments, and also the opportunity to sell them to an outside buyer, after the departure of the tenant named on the lease, if the building was undergoing a conversion into a cooperative.
The state's action offers another opportunity to consider the potential benefits and problems involved in seeking to achieve a humane policy goal through restrictions on the rights of owners of rental property. Case by case, courts will have to judge whether the claim to succession rights as a member of a ''nontraditional family'' is valid.
Since there is a shortage of apartments and, usually, a gap between actual rents and potential vacancy rents, the rule creates an inducement for tenants to form family-like relationships, or the appearance of them, to support a claim for succession rights.
In producing the regulation, the state has relied on Appellate Division decisions giving it broad authority to issue regulations on succession rights without legislative approval. Then, last July, the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, affirmed the right of a longterm unmarried partner of a deceased tenant to inherit continued occupancy rights in a rent-controlled apartment.
Four years ago, in the case of Brevard v. Sullivan, the Court of Appeals found that in rent-stabilized apartments, succession rights are limited to the tenant named on the lease.
Subsequently, the Legislature widened succession rights in stabilized apartments to include occupants who had lived in the apartment since the beginning of the lease or the beginning of the relationship. But ''relationship'' has always meant family members, construed broadly but specifically - spouses and children, step-parents and stepchildren, nephews, nieces, aunts and uncles, grandparents and grandchildren and in-laws.
WHAT opened the door to the broader interpretation of ''family'' was the Court of Appeals decision in the case of Braschi v. Stahl Associates. Writing for the majority in the 4-to-2 decision, Associate Justice Vito J. Titone said that Miguel Braschi could inherit full tenancy rights from his deceased longterm companion, Leslie Blanchard, in a rent-controlled apartment at 405 East 54th Street.
Protection against sudden eviction, Justice Titone said, ''should not rest on fictitious legal distinctions or genetic history, but instead should find its foundation in the reality of family life.'' A more realistic view of a family, he said, includes ''two adult lifetime partners whose relationship is longterm and characterized by an emotional and financial commitment and interdependence.''
Justice Titone distinguished the Braschi holding from the Brevard case, saying that rent stabilization is a less onerous burden on the property owner than rent control.
But Richard L. Higgins, the state's Housing Commissioner, said he could see no reason to make the distinction. ''If anything,'' he said, ''protections are more essential in stabilized housing because its less restrictive provisions make it easier to evict an apartment occupant.''
The state housing agency therefore proposes by regulation to extend these rights to occupants of stabilized apartments. The right would apply not only when the named tenant dies, but also when the tenant voluntarily vacates.
The emergency order is full of examples, drawn from language in court cases, of factors that give evidence of emotional and financial commitment and interdependence. One is the longevity of the relationship. No specific length of time is suggested, but under a different section of the stabilization law, family members claiming a renewal lease have to be able to show that they have lived in the apartment and used it as their primary residence for at least two years.
Another evidence is the ''sharing of or relying upon each other for payment of household or family expenses.'' A third is the intermingling of finances and a fourth is ''engaging in family-type activities'' such as holidays and celebrations.
It may also help to arrive before a sympathetic magistrate. It is difficult to imagine the tests being applied evenhandedly.
Evidence of emotional commitment that is specifically excluded from consideration is a sexual relationship. But gay-rights advocates considered the Braschi decision a major victory, and hope to build on it to extend rights for homosexuals beyond housing. The AIDS crisis has made their plea more urgent.
''IF a partner dies of AIDS, it's common for landlords to deny the survivor a lease in order to get a higher rent,'' said Thomas B. Stoddard, executive director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Eduction Fund, the national legal organization that works in behalf of homosexuals and AIDS victims. The AIDS situation led New York City to file an amicus brief on behalf of Braschi.
The state housing agency has a broader beneficiary population in mind - one that includes the elderly and disabled who have longterm companions who are not family members in the traditional sense.
How many households would be affected by the regulation? The Office of Rent Administration of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal notes that in the 1987 New York City housing survey, 49,400 rent-stabilized apartments were found to be occupied by two or more people who were unrelated by marriage or blood. That is about one in every 19 of the city's 935,000 stabilized apartments. There are 160,000 rent-controlled households.
These households consist of roommates, doubled-up families, elderly people living together, male homosexual and lesbian groupings, and nongay people who live together. The latter category is ''heterosexual and close to roommates, but different,'' said a Rent Stabilization Association official, Jack Freund.
The number of apartments actually affected each year depends on the turnover rate. Commissioner Higgins estimated that there were probably 2,000 to 4,000 turnovers a year in the affected apartments.
In practice, the burden would be placed on owners who want to gain possession of an apartment to demonstrate that an individual claiming succession does not indeed qualify under the regulation. That might well take expensive and intrusive investigation, with uncertain results.
TO owners, the standard of ''financial and emotional interdependence'' is vague, subjective and certain to lead to abuses. An unrelated individual might move in with a tenant, establish a joint bank account with an unspecified amount of funds, be seen at gatherings with the tenant and then inherit the apartment when the tenant moves away. But the owner would have to undertake a long and difficult procedure to prove that these were indeed the facts.
Considered as a family member, the individual would in some ways find it easier to take over an apartment than he would to sublet an apartment from a prime tenant. A prime tenant typically provides the owner with considerable information about a sublessee for an occupancy that can last only two years.
''On a sublet I can ask for financial back-up,'' said Andrew Hoffman, general manager of London Terrace Gardens at 415-455 West 23d Street and 420-460 West 24th Street. ''Here there would be no chance.'' He also predicted that in co-op conversions the regulation would establish a new market for the sale of insider rights - the right to purchase an apartment at prices available only to tenants.
Sherwin Belkin, lawyer for the Rent Stabilization Association, said the state was giving a ''blueprint'' for how people can acquire tenancy rights, in effect reviving the right to assign leases, which the Legislature eliminated in 1983. He also predicted that a black market would arise, with tenants, for a fee, collaborating with potential successor tenants to establish conditions that suffice to meet the standards of ''emotional and financial commitments.''
But Commissioner Higgins said the owners' fears were exaggerated. A hearing on the code amendment is scheduled for Jan. 22 at Police Plaza in Manhattan at 1 P.M.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

M.C.I. Rent Increases
Question: I am confused as to whether tenants in buildings where there have been rent increases for M.C.I. (major capital improvements) have to keep paying the higher rents once the repairs or new features have been paid for. A neighbor said the law has changed but our landlord says he does not have to reduce the rent and the M.C.I. change is permanent. Who is right? . . . B. W., Manhattan
Answer: Your landlord. The rent increases landlords get to cover the cost of building improvements are permanent. What your neighbors might be confused about is that there was a court challenge to this aspect of the rent-stabilization law. The suit was brought by tenants at the Ansonia apartment building in Manhattan challenging the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal's interpretation of the statute that makes the rent increases permanent. 
Last month, the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, reaffirmed the division's rule making M.C.I. increases permanent.
 
Right to Inherit a House
Question: I live, rent-free, in a two-family house owned by my father. I am my father's only child. He continues to tell me that in the event of his death ''eveything will be taken care of.'' He has indicated that the house will be mine but has not shown me the deed. I don't know if my name is on it. Another concern of mine is that my father and I have different surnames and his name is not on my birth certificate. Will I have a right to this property if he dies and my name is not on the deed? . . . Y. A., Brooklyn.
Answer: That would depend on certain other factors. According to Michael R. Winston, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters, for you to have an automatic right to inherit the property, your name would have to be on the deed or in a will in which your father leaves the property to you.
Mr. Winston said that if you believe your father genuinely wants you to inherit the house, you must let him know that you need more than an oral acknowledgement. While the terms of a will are private and not open to you, you would not need your father's permission to see the deed. Property ownership is a matter of public record. You can look up the deed in the Brooklyn office of the City Register at 210 Joralemon Street.
 
The Illegal Use of a Floor
Question: I was told that when the building where I rent was built the number of floors exceeded the legal limit set by the zoning code. I also understand that because of this error the city limited the landlord's use of the top floor, preventing tenancy.
Recently the owner/manager of the building moved his office into this unoccupied floor, as did a few other commercial businesses. We are trying to determine if this is a violation of some law or of the agreement between the city and the owner. Is there a city office where we can find out if the landlord can do this? . . . R. R., Manhattan
Answer: Yes. Your source would be the city's Department of Buildings. According to Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman for the agency, the building's certificate of occupancy would indicate all legal uses for various areas in the building. The C. of O. is on record in the Buildings Department's borough office. Mr. Tiryakian suggested that you start your search in the Index Section. All you would need is the address for your building. If, after checking, you find that the use of this space for offices appears to be a violation of the C. of O., you can file a complaint with the Department of Buildings.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Garment District;
Dressing Up Those Dowager Buildings

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
IN Manhattan's garment district at midday, pedestrians still jockey for sidewalk space with pushers of wheeled clothing racks, and huge delivery trucks still own the curbs on the side streets. But in the last few years the area has shed its drab industrial look for a more polished appearance.
The transformation, prompted by rising property values as well as broad changes in the garment industry itself, can be seen in newly marbled lobbies, high-speed elevators, central air-conditioning, carpeted corridors, and uniformed doormen in many buildings.
So far the metamorphosis has been most apparent on Seventh Avenue, the district's main corridor, where many of the industry's top designers have showrooms.
But now, two of the largest buildings on Broadway - long considered a less prestigious address than Seventh Avenue - are undergoing dramatic makeovers. 
The owners of 1412 Broadway, the 400,000-square-foot structure at 39th Street, and 1370, the 250,000-square-foot building at 37th Street, are redoing the lobbies and office floors as well as the mechanical systems.
Work is also under way on a 27,000-square-foot showroom building at 552 Seventh Avenue near 40th Street, which was damaged by a fire two years ago.
With the multimillion dollar modernization programs, the owners hope to keep valued tenants, attract new ones and raise rents. ''Owners are under pressure to upgrade now,'' said Laurence I. Landis, director of leasing for at 1412 Broadway, the 25-story building now known as the Fashion Gallery. ''One of the reasons is that tenants expect it now.''
Mr. Landis, who has been managing and leasing properties in the neighborhood for nearly 15 years, said that the distinctions people in the garment industries used to make among various buildings are dissolving.
''It used to be that if you were a name designer you had to be in a certain building on Seventh Avenue,'' he said. ''And if you manufactured junior sportswear or misses dresses you wanted to be in a certain building on Broadway. Tenants were very reluctant to make changes even for better spaces because they thought leaving certain buildings might mean a loss of business. The industry is changing on several different levels and tenants are more flexible today.''
Over the last decade the workforce in the garment district, the area from 42d to 34th Streets and from Avenue of the Americas to Eighth Avenue, has changed from mostly sewers and pressers to more white-collar employees of designers and manufacturing companies. The remaining hands-on garment jobs are mostly in sample-making.
A shift of production to overseas plants by American clothing producers and the consolidation of manufacturing companies were the main catalysts of the changes.
The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reports during the first quarter of this year the city had 100,910 workers in the apparel industry. That figure compares to 123,555 workers in 1984 and 150,549 in 1979. Included in the count were all types of workers from designers and their marketing people to production and other blue-collar workers.
Even those apparel industry production jobs still in the city tend to be in factories in Chinatown or the outer boroughs.
Eli Elias, the president of the Federation of Apparel Manufacturers, said that another force behind the changes has been an overall decline in the number of garment manufacturing companies.
''We used to have in the neighborhood hundreds of small companies producing one or two lines,'' he said. ''Now you have huge companies like Liz Claiborne with 15 or 20 different design and manufacturing divisions.''
THE result has been fewer companies, but those that remain are taking larger spaces, not for manufacturing but for functions as diverse as design and pattern-making, marketing and accounting. Design companies and large manufacturers are the kinds of tenants that owners like the Catalano Kornblum Development Corporation, which is nearing completion of its renovation of 1412 Broadway, hope to attract. The company's principals, Michael Kornblum and Peter Catalano, are like other new property owners in the garment district who have taken over buildings with renovation plans in mind.
''From our point of view,'' Mr. Catalano said, ''the buildings on Broadway were not meeting their potential. Most of them had not been improved in decades. The garment district has some of the most important designers in the world. But you could not tell that by looking at the buildings here.''
Mr. Catalano and Mr. Kornblum, who upgraded several buildings on Park Avenue South, another commercial district that has undergone a dramatic transformation, bought the building, constructed in the 1920's, about a year ago. Until then most tenants were textile companies, other manufacturers and shipping concerns.
Among the new showroom tenants are Escada, the German-based clothing design company, which has taken 35,000 square feet on two floors, and Cerruti 1881, a sportwear company that has taken 3,000.
Mr. Landis said that the asking price for renovated space is $35 a square foot, or 30 to 40 percent more than what tenants are currently paying for unrenovated space.
Dan Associates, the real estate investment company that owns 1370, has just started its makeover of the building which used to be known as the Fischel Loft Building. The work will include upgrading the mechanical systems and renovating the upper floors.
Marty Meyer, a senior managing director with Williams Real Estate, the company directing the building's leasing program, said the asking price for renovated space is $26.50 a foot. He added that rents in the area have not increased much in the past year or so.
''Tenants are a little more cautious than they were this time last year,'' he said. ''The economy in general has made manufacturers nervous and the major retailers are having their own problems.''
Moreover, the nature of the apparel manufacturing is such that the space needs of tenants are less predictable than for other industries. ''Companies expand and shrink from season to season as lines are started or discontinued,'' Mr. Meyer said. ''If retailing improves quickly we could have a sudden demand for space next year.''
But despite those physical changes, it is not likely that the garment district will soon be a neat-looking office center indistinguishable from others in Manhattan. The area remains a major distribution center for the apparel industry. Clothing may be made in Taiwan or Hong Kong, but much of it still passes through Manhattan on its way to retailers across the country.
''Even though fewer and fewer manufacturers have their production operations here,'' said Cory Greenspan, executive director of the Federation of Apparel Manufacturers, ''they still need to control distribution and quality from here. Unless a manufacturer delivers exactly what is ordered, he jeopardizes payment for the entire order.''
Another constraint on a complete transformation of the neighborhood was a zoning rule, put into effect by the city two years ago, that was intended to preserve the area's shrinking manufacturing spaces. The rule required that half the space in manufacturing buildings in midblocks from 35th to 40th Streets between Broadway and Ninth Avenue be maintained for garment-related uses.
But the Real Estate Board of New York and property owners in the area challenged the zoning measure, and last year Justice Carmen Ciparick of State Supreme Court overturned it, saying that city planners did not thoroughly assess its environmental impact. Last month the city filed an appeal of Justice Ciparick's ruling.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Providence;
Condo-Rental For Downtown

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST

 BODY:
FINISHING touches are being put on the conversion of the 104-year-old Conrad building into this city's first downtown residential development - a 24-unit project that will be half rental, half condominium.
Erected in 1885 in what was the city's theater district by a businessman, J. B. Barnaby, as a present for his daughter, the five-story building more recently housed music studios and one of the city's best known bars, Lupo's Heartbreak Hotel, which closed in 1988.
Its architecture - an eclectic mix of Moorish, Gothic and Renaissance styles, with floor-to-ceiling windows in all rooms - attracted Edmund Restivo Jr., an accountant turned developer. 
With $3.4 million in low-interest financing obtained through the nonprofit Providence Company, a group of businesses and banks with a $20 million revolving loan fund for downtown residential projects, Restivo Construction began the $4.5 million project in January 1988. The city, which has long been trying to attract residential development downtown, granted a $500,000 low-interest loan for the project. In addition to Mr. Restivo, his brother Thomas and his father, Edmund Sr., the partners are Vark Markarian, Anthony Silvestri and Michael Solomon.
The architect, David Presbrey of Providence, designed six basic styles of apartments. Five condominium units are under contract, said Edmund Restivo Jr., noting that prices for the units range from $99,500 to $242,500. Monthly maintenance fees are $200 and $350, depending on the square footage, which ranges from 800 to 1,400 square feet. Because the Conrad is a restored historic building, the developer got a $500,000 Federal tax credit. This saving, Mr. Restivo said, has allowed him to offer rentals at $750 to $1,250 a month. For $1,000, a renter can take an option, good for three years, to purchase at the original asking price. Seven units have been leased.
Despite the 19th-century exterior, complete with cast-iron detail, the interior is contemporary. The spacious feel in rooms with high ceilings and eight-foot windows is accentuated with white walls, counters, kitchen cabinets and tile floors. Buyers may choose the carpeting color. All units use an open-space concept, with no walls separating the kitchen from the living room and dining area.
Three units have two-bedrooms and the rest have one. Each comes with an intercom system, microwave oven and parking space in a nearby lot.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Civics Lesson;
Times Sq. Documentary

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Public school students in New York City will have an opportunity to view ways to change Times Square for the better through a 30-minute film that examines the history of the neighborhood and proposals for its redevelopment. Starting next month and continuing through the school term, the documentary ''Changing Times in Times Square'' is to be presented at 296 high schools and junior high schools in all boroughs. Later in the year it is due to be shown by local and cable television outlets.
The film was written and produced by Paul Budline, a professional documentary maker based in Manhattan, and narrated by Michael Presser, a producer of educational programs in the arts. Included are interviews with proponents and opponents of various redevelopment proposals. The intent, according to Mr. Presser, is to present both sides so that the film ''serves as a civics lesson aimed at showing the operation and complexity of our local government.'' The film cost $30,000 to make and was underwritten by funds donated to Mr. Presser's Midtown Management Group. The group's projects are supported by such donors as the Shubert Organization, Chase Manhattan Bank, Citibank, the American Federation of Teachers and city agencies.

HEADLINE: Retirees Are In Demand in Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
WHEN Emil Davidson retired 20 years ago, after selling the multimillion dollar plastics-molding company he founded in Elmsford, N.Y., he found the quiet life in his Scarsdale neighborhood frustrating. ''Here I knew all this stuff,'' he said, ''but nobody asked me any questions.''
Today, the former chemist and inventor, who holds 20 patents, has an international audience eager to hear his answers. The peripatetic executive, now 81 years old, has volunteered his management expertise for 12 projects in eight countries from Kenya to China, showing his African client how to make a better bottle cap and helping a Chinese factory computerize its operations.
Now he is waiting for a new assignment, in Eastern Europe. 
 
10,000 Volunteer Executives
Mr. Davidson is one of 10,000 volunteer executives with the International Executive Service Corps, a nonprofit organization based in Stamford that sends retired American business executives to developing countries to upgrade management skills and improve basic business technologies.
Although the corps was formed to encourage private enterprise in non-Marxist countries, its role has expanded to other countries including China. And recent developments in Eastern Europe have given the 25-year-old organization a new focus. It is finding an enthusiastic audience in Communist bloc countries where the population is engaged in pioneering efforts to transfer production from state to private hands.
 
Delegation to Poland
Last week, the president of the organization, Thomas S. Carroll of New Canaan, joined a delegation of United States Government officials, business, academic and labor leaders on a Presidential mission to Poland. The group will advise President Bush about the most efficient use of United States aid to that country and to assist the Poles in refining their own economic restructuring.
The five-day mission was led by Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter, Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher Sr. and Secretary of Labor Elizabeth H. Dole. It also advised Polish officials about how to sell state-owned operations to private enterprise and how to encourage individual initiative.
The trip was Mr. Carroll's second visit to the newly market-oriented country in the last month. It came after an agreement between Poland and the United States under which volunteer executives from the corps will be made available to provide management expertise to Polish industries.
''We are all participants in an event equal in importance to the industrial revolution,'' said Mr. Carroll, a former president and chief executive officer of Lever Brothers. ''As kids in this country, we all had lemonade stands or delivered newspapers, but anyone in Poland younger than 60 has never seen private enterprise before. You can hear the pages of history turning.''
The delegation will begin talks intended to lead to a capital-formation program for Poland, Mr. Carroll said, including the establishment of pension programs and the creation of a framework for a Polish stock exchange.
Additional volunteers from the corps, led by Robert Bishop, a former vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, will visit Poland and Hungary in January at the request of those Governments, to begin setting up stock exchanges and promoting their use as a vehicle for private investment.
''There is an estimated $3 billion in mattresses in Poland,'' Mr. Carroll said. ''The Poles don't want to put their money in banks or in any other institution. We are going over there to help structure this monumental cultural and economic change.''
The executive corps, founded in 1964 by David Rockefeller, is financed by grants from the United States Agency for International Development and by voluntary contributions from corporations and foundations.
The organization's $34 million budget last year helped send 710 volunteers to projects in 48 countries for two- to three-month stays. There they provided management and technological advice to help businesses in such projects as creating fish farms, exporting higher-quality furniture or building better steel mills. Each advisory mission cost an average $23,000.
 
Volunteers Are Being Recruited
Because there are no Agency for International Development missions in Communist countries in Eastern Europe, and because the fledgling private industries being developed there cannot make significant contributions, the executive corps first 10 projects in Poland are being financed by a $75,000 grant from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, which coordinates some philanthropic activities of the family.
Executive corps volunteers are being recruited for several projects there, said Charles V. Neiswender, vice president for planning for the corps. Among the projects are management assistance for a color picture tube company and a steelworks plant in Warsaw, a copper company in Lubin and a crude-oil processing plant in Gdansk.
''Poland won't modernize overnight,'' Mr. Neiswender said, ''and we're not so naive as to think they will. We are the beginning of a process, and we recognize that sending a volunteer for three months will not solve all their problems.''
In February, Mr. Neiswender will leave for the Soviet Union for meetings with a Soviet adviser, Alexander Biryukov, a close associate of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two men will discuss a series of five assignments for the executive corps volunteers in private-sector enterprises in the Soviet Union, a project that will also test the effectiveness of such assistance.
 
Executive Returns From Budapest
With the help of a $200,000 grant from the Soros Foundation - Hungary - which provides grants and scholorships to Hungarian citizens and institutions to promote the opening of that society - the executive corps has already completed l7 projects in Hungary, sending advisers to improve management techniques in meat-processing plants, rubber companies and fertilizer factories.
Peter W. Moyer, a 61-year-old retired financial executive with the Exxon Corporation, recently returned to his New Canaan home from a mission to Hungary to help the state-owned rubber company in Budapest learn cash forecasting.
''Their budget was running amok,'' Mr. Moyer said, adding that there were few if any management controls on borrowing for a company that he called the Goodyear Company of Hungary.
Among other measures, Mr. Moyer urged company officials to reduce inventory and to buy fewer raw materials. He said he was not certain that his advice was taken but he was heartened that two days before he left he was asked to deliver a two-hour presentation on his recommendations to the entire management staff.
The executive corps' current budget will provide enough money to send volunteers on 710 missions this year, a figure that would easily double if more funds were available, spokesmen for the organization said.
 
'Old Is an Interpretation'
Recruiting additional volunteer executives is relatively easy, said Casper J. Fishback, a 79-year-old volunteer executive recruiter from Rye, N.Y. ''Each of us have friends who want something to do,'' he said. ''Old is an interpretation and a personal thing. We have a number of 85-year-olds who want to know, when is the next project?''
Mr. Davidson said that when he walked into the executive corps offices for his interview at the age of 66, he thought to himself: ''This can't be for me. There are a lot of old people around here.''
Fifteen years later, Mr. Davidson spends three days a week at executive corps headquarters, between his own trips to help recruit additional volunteers and evaluate requests for help from participating countries.''
''There's a great demand for hands-on entrepreneurs around the world,'' he said. ''The concept of profitability is something many companies in these countries don't know anything about.''
