HEADLINE: Effects of Final I-287 Link Are Debated

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
FROM Montville to Mahwah, the final 19-mile link of Interstate 287 is slowly taking shape amid the crumbling rock and pristine riverbanks of some of New Jersey's most desirable real estate.
When construction on the project began more than 30 years ago, the federally financed highway was envisioned by officials as a crucial link for New Jersey, New York and southern New England. It would efficiently route interstate traffic around densely populated northeastern New Jersey and provide a quick and easy bypass to points north and south of the New York metropolitan area.
But after decades of controversy, the 19-mile swath of superhighway, which will slice through Morris, Bergen and Passaic Counties and which state and Federal officials believe will solve the area's transportation woes, is now perceived by residents, environmentalists and local officials as the harbinger of serious traffic and environmental problems as it leaves a wake of commercial, industrial and residential development in its path.
''It will cause a traffic nightmare,'' said Joseph Smith, chairman of the Fair Lawn Planning Board. ''I think that the benefits of the road locally are really nonexistent.'' 
The borough of Fair Lawn, a residential community at the intersection of Routes 4, 17 and 208, is nearly eight miles east of Interstate 287. But the fact that officials there are concerned with the highway's potential impact underscores the notion that the rambling interstate will have a widespread effect on traffic and congestion throughout the entire region.
This apparent paradox, the possibility that a high-speed, six-lane superhighway could make existing traffic problems worse rather than relieve them, has prompted the Bergen County Department of Planning and Economic Development to commission a study to assess the effect that completion of the highway will have on the surrounding area.
''We simply don't know the impact it will have,'' said Chester Mattson, director of the county agency. ''The reason is because patterns of development and patterns for the delivery of goods have undoubtedly changed since the roadway was designed.''
An interstate highway system, he said, is designed with regional traffic patterns in mind. ''You look at alternative routes, alternative pathways for the road, you go to public hearings, people complain, you come up with a final alignment, and then you build,'' he said. Often, he said, such planning ultimately overlooks local concerns.
The study, Mr. Mattson said, will use computer models of traffic flow, employment projections and population growth for 15 communities in northwest Bergen County - the area most likely to be affected by completion of Interstate 287 - to develop strategies to deal with anticipated traffic problems.
''We'll ask the computer to act like a commuter,'' he said. ''We'll just keep loading in new houses and new offices and ask the imaginary people who come out of them to get on the roadway system and go from here to there and back again.
''We hope it will tell us where traffic is going to be the heaviest, and we need to know that before the highway opens.''
Officials say the final section of roadway, which will link the rest of Interstate 287 with Interstate 87 in New York State, is scheduled to open in the spring of 1994, more than 35 years after construction began.
In 1956, President Dwight D. Eisenhower approved a 41,000-mile nationwide network of superhighways that was initially intended to ease movement of military troops and supplies and expedite evacuation of population centers in the event of a disaster.
Over the years, as the interstate system developed, New Jersey constructed more than 400 miles of highway with the assistance of large infusions of Federal funds - originally 90 percent of the total cost of each project.
Included in the system were Interstate 80, the east-west corridor that connects New York and Pennsylvania through northern New Jersey; the New Jersey Turnpike, which runs longitudinally from one end of the state to the other, and Interstate 287, which was to start at Perth Amboy and end at Mahwah and form the New Jersey segment of a ''beltway'' encircling the entire New York metropolitan area.
Construction of Interstate 287 started in 1958 in Somerset County and proceeded east toward Staten Island and north toward its New Jersey terminus just south of Suffern, N.Y.
In 1965, the first stirrings of public opposition to the roadway were heard when residents of Wayne, Franklin Lakes and Mahwah urged the State Department of Transportation to move the northern end of the highway more to the west.
The state demurred and retained the original routing, and since that time the fate of that last 19-mile stretch of road has been obscured by years of litigation, public protest, political infighting and even Congressional intervention. In 1973, a measure sponsored by Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of Pompton Lakes, required additional public hearings on the highway's routing.
Like a river seeking the path of least resistance, the last link in the 64-mile-long highway has since fought its way through mountains and valleys of natural obstacles and man-made political obstructions. Only in 1988 did the Army Corps of Engineers issue final permits allowing completion of the last link of the interstate.
 
'Fighting This for 20 Years'
''I've been fighting this thing for 20 years,'' Mayor William Vichiconti of Franklin Lakes said. ''I don't know how much more I can do, although I have seen them stop with bridges in the air before.''
Mr. Vichiconti acknowledges, however, that the likelihood of blocking the completion of the highway is remote. ''Now I'm just trying to make sure,'' he said, that the Department of Transportation ''does the right thing.''
His primary concerns, he said, are increased traffic and pollution of both air and water in the township. ''We've got 20, 30 lakes here of varying sizes - one major one is right off the highway - and I'm afraid we'll get pollution from gas and oil and salt that will drain off the highway and into the lakes,'' he said.
Mr. Vichiconti is not alone in his concern that completion of the highway may harm the environment.
''This highway destroys a considerable amount of wetlands,'' said Dr. Ella Fillipone, director of the Passaic River Coalition, an environmental group in Basking Ridge. The permit issued by the Corps of Engineers, she said, requires the Department of Transportation to create new wetlands to replace those lost as a result of the highway.
''The state must assure survival of the new wetlands for a five-year period,'' Dr. Fillipone said. ''But at the end of five years, who is going to maintain them?'' If the system is not manipulated to provide the area with a constant water supply, she said, the man-made wetlands will quickly revert to their natural state.
 
Better Air Quality Expected
''There's no question,'' said Robert A. Innocenzi, Acting Commissioner of the State Department of Transportation, ''that there are some environmental impacts when you build a highway. But once you get past construction, and complete the wetlands mitigation, I think the environmental impact is positive because you're moving traffic on the freeway, which will improve the air quality.''
In regard to maintenance of the new wetlands created, he said: ''Yes, they still have to be looked after, and we will look to the State Department of Environmental Protection to assist us in that regard.''
Residents in the area, however, also express concerns about the environmental and esthetic effects of the highway's completion.
''They're destroying the mountain,'' said Joe Iuelja, a resident of Oakland. ''When you look at the scenery now, all you see is rock. It's a shame. It used to be all woods.'' Experts, however, say that development necessitates certain trade-offs.
''You don't make an omelet without cracking a few eggs,'' said Dr. George Sternlieb, professor of urban studies at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. ''You have to balance the interest of a couple of hundred campers and hikers versus thousands of new housing units and jobs.
''In my eyes, I think that this is as painless a place as any to put a highway.'' He added that he did not think that the location chosen for the highway would have any severe consequences.
Highways, Dr. Sternlieb said, determine where people live and work. ''We're seeing that population and jobs follow the highway the way they used to follow the railroads,'' he said. Highways, he said, create development. And if there is one thing everyone agrees upon, it is that construction of the final link of Interstate 287 has created unprecedented demand for development in the area.
''I certainly think it's going to be an economic boon for the municipalities through which it passes,'' said State Senator Leanna Brown, Republican of Chatham.
 
Seeking to Be Included
Indeed, at the same time that Montville, Mahwah and Wayne were fighting to keep the highway out of their borders, Bloomingdale, Riverdale and Wanaque were fighting to get it in.
''We're all for it,'' Mayor Angelo Cutillo of Wanaque said. ''It's horrendous to get from anywhere in town to any major road.'' A proposed Interstate 287 interchange to be situated in the town, he said, ''will definitely alleviate our traffic problems.''
But the interchange, he said, will also solve another problem that Wanaque currently faces: ''We are in dire need of ratables,'' Mr. Cutillo said.
A proposal by the Hahn Company of San Diego and Cali Associates, a Cranford developer, would convert 600 acres of vacant Wanaque land into a shopping center complex with a hotel, movie theaters, restaurants and office buildings. The project, Mr. Cutillo said, would cost about $200 million. The entire 1989 municipal budget for Wanaque, he said, is $5.4 million.
''We're just waiting for the state to tell us where they're going to put the interchange,'' Mr. Cutillo said.
Over the last 20 years, largely as a result of the planned completion of Interstate 287, hundreds of millions of dollars have poured into the area as developers and investors buy up every piece of vacant land that becomes available.
In Mahwah, for example, from 1975 to 1989, 2,700 building permits were approved for individual dwellings, while 1,400 more are currently pending approval. More than two million square feet of office space has already been approved, while an additional 360,000 square feet is awaiting approval. Population in the town, which was 14,738 in 1987, is estimated at 24,750 by the year 2010.
''At this point,'' said Mayor William Raquet of Mahwah, ''we're not looking for any more ratables. We'd rather sort of see things settle down so that we can retain the open areas that are left.''
Since Mahwah was almost certainly going to be near an Interstate 287 interchange because of its location just south of Suffern, development in the town was virtually guaranteed.
 
Hotel and Office Complex Built
In 1984, for example, the J. D. Construction Corporation, a Mahwah developer, purchased the vacant Ford assembly plant at the proposed intersection of Route 17 and Interstate 287 in Mahwah and promptly tore it down. In its place, J. D. Construction built the $300 million International Crossroads, a 22-story hotel and office complex.
''When 287 is complete, it's going to take all the truck traffic off of Route 17,'' said James D'Agostino, chairman of J. D. Construction. ''It will be a great relief. The road network will be so good in this area that now we want to put up a shopping center in addition to the office building.''
McBride Enterprises, a Franklin Lakes development concern, has been accumulating and developing property from Mahwah to Montville for the last 20 years. Included in the McBride purchases are the Oakland Industrial Park, the Ramapo Ridge-McBride Office Park in Mahwah and Urban Farms in Franklin Lakes, one of the most expensive residential developments in the state.
There are those, however, who feel that development that encourages suburban sprawl is counterproductive and serves only to eventually increase traffic and congestion, aggravate negative environmental factors and foster abandonment of cities and urban centers of production.
For them, the completion of Interstate 287 accomplishes all those things and more.
''This is a project that never should have begun,'' said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood. ''For those who believe that there is economic development through further decentralization of our economic centers, then this is the answer.''
The funds used to complete the road, he said, would have been better spent to improve existing interstate highways that are desperately in need of repair.
According to Federal Highway Administration estimates, the cost of completing the final 19-mile link from Montville to Mahwah will be about $450 million. The original estimate for the entire 64-mile New Jersey portion of the highway was $156 million.

HEADLINE: Secaucus Journal;
From Farms to Shoppers' Mecca

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: SECAUCUS

 BODY:
YEARS ago, the town of Secaucus enjoyed two unusual claims to fame: the failed 1956 Presidential bid of Henry Krajewski, a local tavern owner, and the dubious distinction of being prime real estate for pig farmers. Indeed, Mr. Krajewski, who ran as an independent, adopted as his campaign slogan ''No Piggy Deals in Washington.'' Times have changed. Mr. Krajewski died in 1966, his Presidential aspirations unfulfilled. The pig farms have given way to warehouse outlet stores, corporate headquarters and elegant shopping malls. And a drive down Secaucus Road is now likely to lead to a stationary sea of cars filled with New York shoppers, all breathing the sweet smell of Secaucus's success.
In the last 25 years, this modestly sized slice of former wetlands on the fringe of Hudson County has become a major player in the shopping-mall wars of New Jersey. And while shoppers from as far away as Virginia search the outlet centers and mini-malls for bargains, officials and longtime residents seem to furrow their brows, scratch their heads and wonder how it all happened so fast.
''We just grew, and grew, and grew,'' said Mayor Paul Amico, who was recently elected to his 14th term. ''And I think that the benefits far outweigh the disadvantages.'' 
The benefits, he said, are primarily fiscal: new construction means more taxable property, which means more tax dollars for the town treasury. As a result, he said, Secaucus enjoys the lowest tax rate in Hudson County. In addition, Mr. Amico said, the increasing population base, now at about 16,000, is stimulating business in the ''mom and pop'' stores that have served Secaucus since the early days.
''Development has been good for the economy,'' he said. ''The stores in the center of town are busier, the banks are busier and we have very little unemployment.''
But development has its drawbacks, residents say. Increased traffic and congestion reign major among them.
''It's horrible,'' said Caesar Candeloro, 69 years old, who lives on Centre Avenue, a road used as a shortcut by shoppers and commuters going to outlets and offices in the west end of town. ''Between 8 and 9 in the morning, I can't even get out of my driveway.''
The scene is repeated at noon, said Mary Sciacchetano, 74, Mr. Candeloro's fiancee, when employees make their way back to the center of town for lunch and shopping.
''Twelve o'clock comes, bingo,'' she said. ''There they are again, bumper to bumper, blowing their horns. I wish they'd bring their lunch to the office.''
Secaucus's renaissance dates to 1968, when Hartz Mountain Industries, a New Jersey-based pet-food manufacturer, started buying property and constructing warehouse buildings in the meadowlands on the outskirts of town. The area had previously been considered undevelopable because of its topography. But rising real-estate values, proximity to the New Jersey Turnpike and other major highways and limited industrially zoned acreage close to New York City made even the soggy, cattail-covered marshlands increasingly valuable.
''It became worth the cost of developing it,'' said Mort Goldfein, senior vice president of Hartz Mountain. As a result, he said, the company has over the years purchased and developed almost 2,000 acres of meadowlands property.
The first residential project in the area was known as Harmon Cove, a town house development on the Hackensack River complete with street names like Sandpiper Key, Sunset Key and Egret Lane. Then the Hilton Hotels Corporation constructed a 300-room hotel in what was then considered the middle of nowhere, while just next door and to the north, Dr. Paul Cavalli, an obstetrician from nearby Union City, was planning to build a state-of-the-art 200-bed medical center.
Later, Hartz Mountain started work on Harmon Meadow, a multi-use complex on the north side of Route 3 that included restaurants, movie theaters, a shopping mall and office buildings, including Hartz's own corporate headquarters.
Secaucus was booming, but with almost all the new construction taking place on vacant land to the north and south, the town center remained virtually unchanged. (With the significant exception, however, of an elaborate multimillion-dollar Municipal Government Center, built in 1979 with the help of a $2.5 million Federal grant.) So Secaucus residents, who for years had been socially adrift from their Hudson County counterparts and subtly snubbed by their Bergen County neighbors, finally seemed to be finding their place in the sun. And then, the shoppers came. ''It's incredible,'' said Frank Yeo, 34, who has lived in town for the last eight years. ''They bring them in here by the busload.''
Secaucus, it seems, is once again flirting with fame - this time as the outlet capital of the New York metropolitan area.
''We have more than 100 factory outlets here,'' said Louis F. deRosa, public-relations representative for the Secaucus Outlet Center. ''And the business is definitely there; these stores are making money.''
The outlet center's success, he said, is based upon three factors: ''Name brands, good buys, no taxes.''
Indeed, with designer houses like Calvin Klein, Liz Claiborne and Harve Benard selling overstocked and out-of-season merchandise for far less than it could be purchased in department stores, the area became a mecca for fashionable, though bargain-minded, shoppers. Add to that the prospect of free parking, Sunday shopping and tax-free clothing, Mr. deRosa said, and it is a combination guaranteed to lure even the most dedicated New York shopper to the Garden State.
''About three hours,'' said Anthony Greco, 70, when asked how long it had taken him to drive to Secaucus from his home in Amsterdam, N.Y. 160 miles away. He estimates that the trip alone, which he and his wife, Lillian, make several times a year, costs about $50, ''including gas, tolls and a quick dinner.''
''Is it worth it? Personally, I don't think so,'' he said, while sitting in his car waiting for his wife to finish shopping. ''I'm not a bargain hunter,'' he said. ''When I want something, I just go and buy it.''
But his wife, he said, ''looks at every price, then she looks at every size, and then, maybe, she buys something.''
Although many Secaucus residents shop in the area and enjoy the tax benefits of the center's success, at least one official feels that some of the stores may be taking advantage of the town's accommodating attitude.
The stores were ''originally supposed to be distribution centers for excess merchandise,'' said Assemblyman Anthony Impreveduto, who is also a Secaucus Councilman. ''Now, they're turning into retail stores, and that is something that area is not zoned for.''
The stores cause traffic problems, he said, because while the new roads in the warehouse district may be adequate, the access roads that lead there were never designed to support the current volume. ''It's not like it was when this town was 8,000 people and pig farms,'' Mr. Impreveduto said. And while only the true old-timers remember those days, even some of the more recently arrived residents yearn for the return of an earlier Secaucus.
''It was so quiet and peaceful when I moved here,'' said Lillian Stahl, 56, who moved to Secaucus from Union City in the early 1970's. ''It was like real country then. But it's not the same as it used to be. Now it's just all congested and confused.''

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY FOLLOW-UP

 BODY:

 
Alice Paul House
FOR the suffragist Alice Paul, the struggle to obtain equal rights for women was a prolonged process, an effort beset with many temporary obstacles and one that could succeed only with a commitment from a wide-ranging number of individuals and institutions.
So too has been the attempt to preserve Miss Paul's birthplace in Mount Laurel.
A group of volunteers organized as the Alice Paul Centennial Foundation recently obtained a loan to help purchase Paulsdale, the three-story, 150-year-old Greek Revival farmhouse on Hooton Road.
The $365,000 loan, from a consortium of seven New Jersey banks, gives the nonprofit organization three years to continue its fund-raising efforts to purchase the home and its six and a half acres of land for $465,000. 
The foundation had a Nov. 15 deadline to exercise an option on the property. The deadline had twice been extended from its original Sept. 8 date by the home's current owners, Marvin and Miriam Feyerherm.
Real-estate appraisers had told the foundation that if the property were purchased by a developer, the house, which sits in the center of the lot, would most likely be destroyed to make room for 15 houses along a cul-de-sac. The parcel is near the intersection of Interstate 295 and Route 38, within a mile of three new housing developments. One of these is two-tenths of a mile down the road.
''We are very pleased that we have achieved this goal,'' said the foundation president, Barbara Irvine. ''But this is just the first hurdle. We must continue, and even intensify, our fund-raising efforts to raise the $100,000 we need to go to settlement on Feb. 1.''
Ms. Irvine said the money was needed to cover the settlement costs and the first year's interest on the loan, estimated to be $38,000 to $40,000. A previous fund-raising effort by the foundation raised $58,000 for the down payment and related costs from 650 donors through a direct-mail campaign. Additional fund-raising events are planned for 1990.
The group hopes within two years to turn the home into a conference center where leadership training programs for young women will be held.
''There is no other historical site in the state associated with a significant American woman that is used as this site is going to be used,'' Ms. Irvine said. She said that well-known national sites associated with women - like the homes of Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton - were used mainly as museums.
Miss Paul, who founded the National Women's Party in 1916, played vital roles in obtaining suffrage for women in 1920 and in trying to pass an equal rights amendment that she wrote in 1923. She died in 1977 at the age of 92.
Miss Paul lived in the house, built in 1849, for more than 20 years. It is her last remaining private residence and is listed on both the New Jersey and National Registers of Historic Places. Planned renovation, which is expected to cost $500,000, includes partial restoration of a broad wrap-around porch now missing from two sides of the house.
The New Jersey Economic Development Authority is guaranteeing the loan. The banks in the consortium are the Burlington County Bank, the Chemical Bank of New Jersey, the Continental Bank of New Jersey, the First People's Bank of New Jersey, the Jefferson Bank of New Jersey, the Mount Holly State Bank and the United Jersey Bank South.
Bills seeking $250,000 in state funds for the purchase and renovation were introduced last session, without result, in the Senate and the Assembly and probably will be reintroduced in the next session, Ms. Irvine said.
 
Fish Census
The continuing census of fish populations off the New Jersey coast shows that the greatest populations of many species are found close to the beach, in depths of 30 feet or less, thus making the state's inshore waters a collective refuge in need of protection, said Donald Byrne, a fisheries biologist with the State Department of Environmental Protection.
Discussing the first unpublished findings of the census, which started in the summer of 1988, Mr. Byrne said recently that the census voyages, made about every other month, had so far revealed ''a trend of most fish concentrating right off the beach in zero to 30 feet.''
Mr. Byrne said that catches of butterfish, squid, spiny dogfish and other species were ''10 times greater'' in the shallow waters than in the other census gradients of 30 to 60 feet and 60 to 90 feet, up to 12 miles out.
The findings, he said, could serve as an argument against establishing an inshore commercial fishery for butterfish, which has been informally proposed in recent years by commercial fishermen.
As Mr. Byrne pointed out, commercial trawling within two miles of shore has been prohibited by a state law since the 1950's. Among other things, the law sought to protect sport fishermen and party boats from the trawlers, which can scoop up tons of fish at a time.
''The inshore waters act as a refuge, and trawlers could put an even bigger dent in the populations of recreational species than they are now,'' Mr. Byrne said. ''A trawler net is so unselective that, in addition to getting butterfish and squid, it could be catching things like small fluke, which we would not want.''
The census has only begun gathering base-line data on the populations, Mr. Byrne said, and will become more valuable as time goes on for things like predicting the probable success of a fishing season, based on numbers of fingerlings and juvenile fish that show up in the nets two or three years before the season arrives.

HEADLINE: ART;
Photos and Soviet Posters

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
THE opening up of the Soviet Union and other Communist countries is an epic worthy of a less sleazy age. As it is, the show now in the library on Fairleigh Dickinson's Florham-Madison campus does more to convey the feeling of political meltdown than most of the reports by the press.
This is a group of about 60 posters done by Soviet contemporaries. About half are prints in editions large and small; the rest are originals that have yet to be reproduced. Titled ''Perestroika/Glasnost, Official and Unofficial, 1985-1989,'' this modest installation is concentrated around the library's turnstiles. 
It is one thing to hear of Soviet economic problems from Western observers, but quite another to see them satirized by an artist still living in the country. Tatyana Nemkova does just this with her silk screen of a plate flanked by a hammer and sickle instead of a knife and fork. Working with Georgi Kamenskikh, Ms. Nemkova comments on the slogan about apartments for all by the year 2000 in a painting of a crate furnished with curtains and a potted plant.
The Stalinist past is the prime target - see the photo blending the features of Stalin and Lavrenti Beria, by Konstantin Ivanov. But Mikhail S. Gorbachev does not escape: Yuri Bokser gives him the old-style dictator treatment with a portrait, minus birthmark, plus rouge and holding bunches of kittens and flowers.
As a rule, the heavier the irony, the less likely the image will have been published. Nevertheless, there are plenty of prints taking issue with evils like environmental pollution, and Aleksei Gornov's poster for AIDS is the largest edition in the show.
A 1940's poster of a young soldier surrounded by improving literature represents the ''wholesome'' Socialist Realism that swept the world in the 1930's. But of the severity that briefly dominated Russian art after the Revolution there is no sign. Artists look to the West - for Surrealism and for the concept of the poster as art first and communication second. Sometimes, it is the Surrealism of old Time magazine covers, the style favored by so many of our own illustrators, but a comparable show of their work would be slicker in execution.
A spectacle masterminded by the library's director, James Fraser, it comes with essays by Dr. Fraser and Anna Suvorova, a member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, and it is on view through Jan. 10. The library, which is closer to the university's Madison Avenue side, is open from 8:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. Monday through Thursday, 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Friday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and 2 to 10 P.M. Sunday.
At the Rothman Gallery on the other side of the campus is ''Photo Perception,'' a group of portraits by 30 photographers that was organized by Tim Volk. The earliest is Jacob Riis's 1895 portrait of a man who is as grubby as his setting, a coal cellar, but who nonetheless prepares for the Sabbath eve with a glistening hallah.
Mr. Volk's choices seem to fall into two categories. One is the portrait that implies symbiosis between photographer and subject, an excellent example being Paul Strand's ''Marsden Hartley, Maine'' (1927), where the painter's creased visage with eyes like transparent marbles looms gray against a white sky. The other category might be called ''opinion,'' typified by Nikki Berg's old woman holding a baby, both of them naked - a statement about the superiority of new over used flesh.
Variations within the classifications are largely technical. Photographing faces in fours, Mark Berghash mocks social distinctions by cropping the results so that the drifter can't be told from the solid citizen.
For ''Jessie at Five,'' Sally Mann lined up three little girls but focuses on the nymphet at the center, who sports lipstick, jewelry and an air of spine-chilling seductiveness. In sharp contrast, Robert Mapplethorpe presents his model, Lara Harris, as a glacier, despite her physical perfection and bared breast.
Once an artist in chiaroscuro, Timothy Greenfield-Sanders has now turned to giant color Polaroids. But he is still a Sargent-esque portraitist, as sensitive to elegance as to the character it enhances (or conceals). This is especially true in his Julian Schnabel, who sits stubbly of chin but swathed in a black and red opera cloak.
The gallery is open Monday through Friday from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. The show closes Dec. 15. A note on New Jersey's premier photographer, George Tice, and Art by Design, the new gallery in Rocky Hill that is showing 25 of his matchless black-and-white prints, many of them classics. Viewers can begin by, as it were, gassing up at the deserted Mobil station, which illuminates the darkness at Cherry Hill, proceed to the telephone booth doing the same for the night in Rahway and then repair to the White Castle, also in Rahway. One of the loveliest pictures, however, is of the Belmont Hotel, standing gray against the marginally lighter sky over Asbury Park.
That was the 1970's. In the 1980's, Mr. Tice may have traveled farther, notably for ''Hometowns,'' his book about Presidential birthplaces. But he is still the hyper-orderly romantic, seeming to arrange his rural and urban landscapes before photographing them. The show closes Dec. 9.
The gallery, directed by Alicia Nieves, is at 131 Washington Street (Route 518) in Rocky Hill, and its professional atmosphere, not to mention its pristine decor, augurs well. The hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday through Saturday.

HEADLINE: Retirees Are In Demand in Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
WHEN Emil Davidson retired 20 years ago, after selling the multimillion dollar plastics-molding company he founded in Elmsford, he found the quiet life in his Scarsdale neighborhood frustrating. ''Here I knew all this stuff,'' he said, ''but nobody asked me any questions.''
Today, the former chemist and inventor, who holds 20 patents, has an international audience eager to hear his answers. The peripatetic executive, who is 81 years old, has volunteered his management expertise for 12 projects in eight countries from Kenya to China, showing his African client how to make a better bottle cap and helping a Chinese factory computerize its operations.
Now he is waiting for a new assignment, in Eastern Europe. 
 
10,000 Volunteer Executives
Mr. Davidson is one of 10,000 volunteer executives with the International Executive Service Corps, a nonprofit organization based in Stamford that sends retired American businesspeople to developing countries to upgrade management skills and improve basic business technologies.
Although the corps was formed to encourage private enterprise in non-Marxist countries, its role has expanded to other countries, including China. And recent developments in Eastern Europe have given the 25-year-old organization a new focus. It is finding an enthusiastic audience in Communist bloc countries where the population is engaged in pioneering efforts to transfer production from state to private hands.
 
Delegation to Poland
Last week, the president of the organization, Thomas S. Carroll of New Canaan, joined a delegation of United States Government officials, business, academic and labor leaders on a Presidential mission to Poland. The group will advise President Bush about the most efficient use of United States aid to that country and to assist the Poles in refining their own economic restructuring.
The five-day mission was led by Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter, Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher Sr. and Secretary of Labor Elizabeth H. Dole. It also advised Polish officials about how to sell state-owned operations to private enterprise and how to encourage individual initiative.
The trip was Mr. Carroll's second visit to the newly market-oriented country in the last month. It came after an agreement between Poland and the United States under which volunteer executives from the corps will be made available to provide management expertise to Polish industries.
''We are all participants in an event equal in importance to the industrial revolution,'' Mr. Carroll, the former president and chief executive officer of Lever Brothers, said. ''As kids in this country, we all had lemonade stands or delivered newspapers, but anyone in Poland younger than 60 has never seen private enterprise before. You can hear the pages of history turning.''
The delegation will begin talks intended to lead to a capital-formation program for Poland, Mr. Carroll said, including the establishment of pension programs and the creation of a framework for a Polish stock exchange.
Additional volunteers from the corps, led by Robert Bishop, a former vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, will visit Poland and Hungary in January at the request of those Governments, to begin setting up stock exchanges and promoting their use as a vehicle for private investment.
''There is an estimated $3 billion in mattresses in Poland,'' Mr. Carroll said. ''The Poles don't want to put their money in banks or in any other institution. We are going over there to help structure this monumental cultural and economic change.''
The executive corps, founded in 1964 by David Rockefeller, is financed by grants from the United States Agency for International Development and by voluntary contributions from corporations and foundations.
The organization's $34 million budget last year helped send 710 volunteers to projects in 48 countries for two- to three-month stays. There they provided management and technological advice to help businesses in such projects as creating fish farms, exporting higher-quality furniture or building better steel mills. Each advisory mission cost an average $23,000.
 
Volunteers Are Being Recruited
Because there are no Agency for International Development missions in Communist countries in Eastern Europe, and because the fledgling private industries being developed there cannot make significant contributions, the executive corps first 10 projects in Poland are being financed by a $75,000 grant from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, which coordinates some philanthropic activities of the family.
Executive corps volunteers are being recruited for several projects there, said Charles V. Neiswender, vice president for planning for the corps. Among the projects aremanagement assistance for a color picture tube company and a steelworks plant in Warsaw, a copper company in Lubin and a crude-oil processing plant in Gdansk.
''Poland won't modernize overnight,'' Mr. Neiswender said, ''and we're not so naive as to think they will. We are the beginning of a process, and we recognize that sending a volunteer for three months will not solve all their problems.''
In February, Mr. Neiswender will leave for the Soviet Union for meetings with a Soviet adviser, Alexander Biryukov, a close associate of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two men will discuss a series of five assignments for the executive corps volunteers in private-sector enterprises in the Soviet Union, a project that will also test the effectiveness of such assistance.
 
Executive Returns From Budapest
With the help of a $200,000 grant from the Soros Foundation - Hungary - which provides grants and scholorships to Hungarian citizens and institutions to promote the opening of that society - the executive corps has already completed l7 projects in Hungary, sending advisers to improve management techniques in meat-processing plants, rubber companies and fertilizer factories.
Peter W. Moyer, a 61-year-old retired financial executive with the Exxon Corporation, recently returned to his New Canaan, Conn., home from a mission to Hungary to help the state-owned rubber company in Budapest learn cash forecasting.
''Their budget was running amok,'' Mr. Moyer said, adding that there were few if any management controls on borrowing for a company that he called the Goodyear Company of Hungary.
Among other measures, Mr. Moyer urged company officials to reduce inventory and to buy fewer raw materials. He said he was not certain that his advice was taken but he was heartened that two days before he left he was asked to deliver a two-hour presentation on his recommendations to the entire management staff.
The executive corps' current budget will provide enough money to send volunteers on 710 missions this year, a figure that would easily double if more funds were available, spokesmen for the organization said.
 
'Old Is an Interpretation'
Recruiting additional volunteer executives is relatively easy, said Casper J. Fishback, a 79-year-old volunteer executive recruiter from Rye. ''Each of us have friends who want something to do,'' he said. ''Old is an interpretation and a personal thing. We have a number of 85-year-olds who want to know, when is the next project?''
Mr. Davidson said that when he walked into the executive corps offices for his interview at the age of 66, he thought to himself: ''This can't be for me. There are a lot of old people around here.''
Fifteen years later, Mr. Davidson spends three days a week at executive corps headquarters, between his own trips to help recruit additional volunteers and evaluate requests for help from participating countries.''
''There's a great demand for hands-on entrepreneurs around the world,'' he said. ''The concept of profitability is something many companies in these countries don't know anything about.''
 
Must Offer Two to Three Months
Participation in executive corps projects is open to men and women of all ages, retired or not, who have management skills or an understanding of basic business technologies and who can donate two to three months of their time.
Although two-thirds of all client requests for volunteer executives can be met through the organization's computer bank, additional volunteer applicants are welcome to apply. Those with skills in agriculture, warehousing, trucking, tourism, banking, hospital administration and apparel manufacturing are especially welcome.
Applicants should contact the International Executive Service Corps by calling (203) 967-6000.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Peter W. Moyer, Casper J. Fishback, Emil Davidson and John Jinishian at the headquarters of the International Executive Service Corp. (NYT/Judith Pszenica)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: SIC3089 PLASTICS PRODUCTS, NEC (91%); 

COUNTRY: POLAND (95%); EUROPE (94%); UNITED STATES (94%); CHINA (92%); EASTERN EUROPE (90%); KENYA (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (56%); 

STATE: CONNECTICUT, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: MOLDING CO (91%); INTERNATIONAL EXECUTIVE SERVICE CORPS (56%);

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1581 words

HEADLINE: Signs of Resistance At Budget Hearings

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
SIGNS of taxpayer resistance to Westchester's proposed $1 billion 1990 budget, with record increases of 18 percent to 52 percent in county property taxes, surfaced last week at two public hearings of the County Board of Legislators and in individual expressions of anger.
The hearings, one in Mount Vernon and the other in Ossining, attracted the usual lineup of representatives from agencies and organizations that depend on public financing for survival. They asked not for more money, but for approval of the proposed allocations.
There were new faces in the crowd, however - homeowners, commuters, local officials and others condemning the proposed budget and pleading with the county legislators, members of the Committee on Budget and Appropriations, to reduce it sharply before approving a final version in late December.
 
Hardship for Many Is Seen
The change in profile of the legislative hearings, packed usually by speakers with specific interests, is characterized this year by residents who have no idea where the cuts should be made, but who see financial hardship for many in the county unless the spending plan is reduced. 
In Ossining, Brian Fitzpatrick, a local resident, said at a hearing that ''15 to 20 years ago, New York State had more jobs and people than any other state, but then taxes grew faster than income'' and businesses began to look elsewhere. He said the same was happening in Westchester.
''Taxes have gone up 75 percent here in five years, but income has gone up only 30 to 35 percent,'' he said. ''If jobs leave, we'll find population going, too. We don't want to acquire the same tax reputation as the state.''
 
Determining Local Impact
A Bedford resident, Oscar S. Pollock, said he had spent some time with the County Tax Commissioner and with the Tax Department in Bedford ''to determine the local impact.'' He spelled it out as several dozen men and women listened intently.
''Last year's budget, advertised by Mr. O'Rourke as a 'no-tax-increase budget,' '' Mr. Pollock said, ''resulted in an increase of 11.9 percent in county taxes - to $16.50 per $1,000 of assessed valuation - for Bedford homeowners. The proposed budget will mean an increase in our county tax of 36 percent, to $22 per $1,000.
''What does that do to our total tax per assessed valuation? It brings it to $85 per $1,000. The average home in Bedford has an assessed value of $100,000. That means this coming year the homeowner will be paying $8,500 in total property taxes.
''We have wealthy people in Bedford, but our community is not just composed of wealthy people. Any community is sunk if it crushes the middle class. A very modest house of $50,000 will pay $4,500 in property taxes. I hope that our Board will consider how middle-income people will be able to pay these increases. We are talking about big bucks.''
He turned to Sandra R. Galef of Ossining, the Democratic minority leader and a member of the Budget Committee, to ask if any ''economic analysis'' had been done ''on the position of middle-income groups in our community, on the elderly, on retired people.''
Mrs. Galef said that no such study had been conducted but that she favored cutting the budget. In fact, Mrs. Galef has said she hopes to cut the increase to 10 percent, which would mean removing $40 million from the budget, an almost impossible task, some of her colleagues have said.
 
Defense of Budgets Invited
County legislators have just begun the process that could lead to cuts and few have focused on areas to be trimmed. The Budget Committee began last week to invite commissioners in to defend their departments' budgets, and that process will last for at least two weeks.
Some Democrats are looking this year, as they do every year, at the ''phantom army'' of hundreds of financed but unfilled jobs. County officials have defended the practice of accumulating millions of budgeted dollars as a necessary source of funds for unexpected expenses, such as paying for what has been a rapidly growing homeless population. (That population now appears to be leveling off.) County budget officials say the 1990 budget has only half of the amount the county is likely to need for the salary increases expected in negotiations under way with representatives of the 9,000-employee county work force. They are looking to the unfilled jobs to pay for the other half.
The budget hearings were lightly attended this year, with few county residents prepared, apparently, to ask for more money for their organizations in the face of the proposed record budget increase. Nevertheless, the hearings drew concentrations of supporters from day-care centers, from the the Hudson River Museum and from libraries.
Robert Trudell of the Greenburgh Public Library sought support for a ''one-time increase'' in financing of $175,000 for the County Library System, whose professional staff and computerized techniques enable local libraries to share in a database of more than four million books.
 
A Threatening Shadow
A cloud in the form of a question by Edward J. Brady, the chairman of the Board of Legislators and a member of the Budget Committee, crossed Mr. Trudell's testimony, casting a threatening shadow as the budget-cutting process begins.
Mr. Brady asked, ''What does the future look like if you get this $175,000,'' and then he answered his own question. ''I can tell you, sir, you'd be the first one I ever met who got $175,00 from the county and didn't come back looking for the same amount the second year and more the third year.''
Mr. Trudell explained that the supplementary funds were needed to fill a gap created in Albany, where legislators failed to increase financing for a system they helped organize in 22 library systems statewide. The ''one time'' request, said Joan Silverstein, president of the Westchester Library System, represented thousands of dollars in savings for local libraries.
''We have pleaded and begged the state,'' Ms. Silverstein said, ''and I don't know if we will get more funding.'' She said staff cutbacks were likely in any case, but they could be handled in a more ''orderly fashion'' with the extra allocation.
 
Not 'Book Depositories'
She said libraries were no longer thought of as ''book depositories,'' but served also as job-information and counseling centers, locations for seminars for teen-agers and community groups and for cultural, informational and educational work. The centralized services saved local libraries thousands of dollars, she said.
Mr. Brady said, ''The fact is, a lot of people in the county have this problem because the state keeps mandating while it keeps cutting the funding.'' He said he saw little hope of any change in Albany, ''so we understand that if we fund $175,000, next year it will be $175,000 plus an amount for inflation, and so on.''
Sally Zeigler of the Child-Care Council was one of many who spoke for day-care financing as an investment that enables parents to earn a living - in some cases avoiding welfare - and contribute to the county's growth. ''We figure conservatively that the county gets back $4 or $5 for every dollar spent, just in the taxes paid by working parents,'' Ms. Zeigler said.
 
Day-Care Allocation Rises
Testimony for the value of day care, with some single fathers joining in support of the system for the first time, follows Mr. O'Rourke's proposal of a $1.2 million increase in the basic allocation as well as the first $500,000 of a two-year $1 million challenge grant, with the county matching costs of new or expanded day-care centers.
Supporters of the Hudson River Museum also came out in large numbers to outline the countywide aspect of its operation, serving schoolchildren in every community and offering ''outreach'' programs for minorities, the disabled and other groups, and for the professional level of its exhibitions, some of which have achieved national recognition.
Mr. O'Rourke set $600,000 aside for the museum, increasing this year's allocation by $100,000 to make up for most of the $120,000 it lost from Yonkers because of the city's budget problems. Speakers also testified at the hearings in favor of the Council for the Arts, which is getting an additional $155,000, with $50,000 of it earmarked for ''partnership grants'' to provide programs in participating communities.
 
Golf Course Proposal
Speakers praised and criticized a proposal to build a new county golf course to absorb increased interest in the sport and to enable refurbishing of existing courses. And they criticized a proposal by Mr. O'Rourke to raise the sales tax by one-half of 1 percent, although Leonard N. Spano, chairman of the Budget Committee, explained carefully that any such increase could not become effective before the 1991 budget and, in any case, there was virtually no support for it among legislators.
But the biggest change was the random, unorganized appearance of homeowners seeking what one man in Ossining called ''a kinder, gentler budget.'' Mr. Pollock, the Bedford homeowner who works as a stockbroker in Manhattan, said he had outlined his protest, with figures to back it up, in a letter he was circulating ''to get the ball rolling.''
''Many are unaware of this incredible increase,'' he said, ''so we're going to disseminate the information through friends and organizations - there are 3,000 people in Heritage Hills in Somers alone - in an attempt to alert homeowners to what they face.''

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
TAX STRATEGY IN A TURBULENT YEAR

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD; Carole Gould writes about personal finance from New York.

 BODY:
THE turbulence this year in the stock and bond markets has made year-end tax decisions more important than usual. There is, of course, the usual guessing game about where capital-gains tax rates are headed. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is up nearly 30 percent this year, leaving some investors wondering when to cash in their gains. Others, less lucky, bet on the troubled ''junk bond'' market and are contemplating losses. Here are some traditional year-end tax tools for investors, and a few new twists.
Strategies may depend on what an investor thinks will happen to the capital-gains rate. This year's top tax rate for capital gains and ordinary income is 28 percent, although some with high incomes may pay as much as 33 percent on a portion of their earnings. President Bush lobbied unsuccessfully to reduce the capital-gains rate this year. Most experts expect the President to have greater success next year. ''There is a lot of momentum, and it seems likely that the capital-gains rate will drop next year,'' said Vern E. Martens, vice president with the Merrill Lynch tax advisory group. 
Proposals have ranged from a flat 15 percent tax on capital gains to exempting a portion of gains from taxes. Also under consideration is some type of indexing, to eliminate the tax on the portion of the gain attributable to inflation.
Weighing the prospects for a rate cut, some investors might want to consider delaying their gains. One way to lock in profits but defer the tax is to ''sell short against the box'' - selling borrowed stock equal to the number of shares that you own. For tax purposes the gain is not recognized until the investor sells his original shares to close out the short position.
An alternative is to buy put options that expire in 1990. The option buyer has the right, but not the obligation, to sell a specified number of shares of the underlying common stock at a set price for a certain time. Thus an investor can lock in a minimum price for the shares during the option's duration and, unlike the short-selling method, reap additional profits if the stock rises.
The price for keeping that profit potential is the cost of the option, which may be several dollars per share. To justify the expense, the investor should expect the stock price to rise at least $10 or $15 a share, Mr. Martens advises.
The strategy is different for investors who also hold securities that have declined in value. For them, it makes sense to take as much of their capital losses as possible in 1989. Their losses can offset their gains, making the transactions tax-free, according to Tom P. Ochsenschlager, a partner with the accounting firm of Grant Thornton in Washington.
Losses can be realized using security swaps, a technique that lets investors take advantage of their losses without changing the character of their portfolios. In a bond swap, for instance, bonds whose prices have dropped are sold, creating a tax loss that can offset other income, and then the proceeds are used to purchase similar bonds.
There is one caveat. Under the ''wash sales'' rule, a person who sells securities at a loss and then buys back identical securities within 30 days cannot claim the loss. In the case of bonds, the rule of thumb is that investors should buy new bonds that differ from the old ones by at least 20 percent in terms of when they mature or by at least 30 percent on their interest rate, Mr. Martens said.
Investors with losses from this year's volatile junk-bond market have another option provided by the Pilgrim High Yield Trust. Until the end of the year, this mutual fund will allow holders of individual bonds to exchange their issues for shares of the trust, dollar-for-dollar, based on the bonds' current market value. For tax purposes the exchange is the same as selling the bonds at a loss, and the transaction does not violate the wash sales rule. Besides getting the tax loss, investors may be able to get slightly more for their bonds in the exchange than on the open market, says Palomba Weingarten, chairwoman of the Pilgrim Group Inc. in Los Angeles. For information, call 800 334-3444.
After using these techniques to offset any capital gains, an investor who still has net losses can use them to offset as much as $3,000 of dividends, interest or any other ordinary income. While a reduction in the capital-gains rate seems likely, what will happen to ordinary income rates is less clear. One change might be to end the anomaly that leaves some of the highest-income households paying a marginal rate of 28 percent, while households of lower income pay 33 percent.
Still, for most taxpayers, the rates will probably remain the same for at least another year. Thus the traditional approach to reducing tax bills - defer income and accelerate deductions - is still sound. There are several ways to defer investment income, one of them being as simple as buying certificates of deposit or Treasury securities that mature in the next year.
AS for deductions, it makes sense to consolidate investment and other miscellaneous expenses in one taxable year, since they are deducted only to the extent that they exceed 2 percent of adjusted gross income. Of particular interest to investors are expenses like set-up charges and annual custodial fees for Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans, if those costs are paid separately from contributions; safe-deposit box fees if the box holds investment documents; costs of investment books and periodicals; investment counseling fees; tax planning and preparation fees, and postage and telephone costs related to investing.
This year, investors can deduct investment interest to the extent of investment income plus $2,000 (dropping to $1,000 in 1990 and none thereafter). Investors with excess interest payments may want to consider selling profitable investments to secure a gain to be offset with the deduction.
One final note: Investors manipulating their year-end profits should beware of immediately reinvesting the cash in mutual funds. By law, funds must distribute to their shareholders virtually all of their income and capital gains each year, typically in late December. Since income is taxed in the year the distribution is declared, an investor who buys late in the year runs the risk of acquiring an unexpected last-minute tax liability.
For equity funds, much of the distribution comes from capital gains. One way to lessen the tax is to invest in an index fund, a mutual fund with a portfolio that approximates an equity index like the Standard & Poor's 500, advises Arnold Kaufman, editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook, an investment newsletter. Unlike an equity fund, only a small portion of an index fund's payout is capital gains.

LENGTH: 1773 words

HEADLINE: Biotechnology Poised for Breakthroughs

BYLINE: By CAROL STRICKLAND

 BODY:
''THIS lab is bugged,'' reads the hand-lettered sign on the door of Eugene Premuzic's laboratory at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton. The bugs in question are not transmitters for clandestine eavesdropping, but micro-organisms for cleaning up toxic geothermal energy byproducts.
Dr. Premuzic, a chemist, hopes to see a pilot plant in California by 1995 using his patented process of microbial detoxification. His laboratory, with 100-liter vats of dark geothermal sludge ready to be converted by bacilli to fine, clean sand, is in an old Camp Upton army barracks. ''My lab was the morgue,'' said Dr. Premuzic. ''I hope that's not a reflection on my work.''
In contrast to the obituaries for heavy manufacturing on Long Island, biotechnology is an area where birth announcements are warranted. 
Led by biomedical suppliers and instrumentation companies like Pall Biomedical Products, Brinkman Instruments and Olympus Corporation, the biotechnology industry on Long Island last year employed 7,000 people, according to Alex Selenow, director of management consulting services at the Long Island branch of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting concern. ''We're just seeing the genesis of this industry,'' Mr. Selenow said. ''It's growing very rapidly.'' Biotechnology will probably not, however, mean more blue-collar manufacturing jobs.
''Long Island will turn into a university park, with the corporate headquarters and brain trust here,'' Mr. Selenow predicted. ''The trend will be to move manufacturing facilities off-Island, while the intellectual component - research and development, engineering and design - remains.''
''Biotechnology signals a difference in industry,'' said Dr. Thomas J. Degnan, director of research at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell University Medical College in Manhasset.
''Industry used to be big chimneys, big steel mills and coal mines. Now we have the tools of molecular biology, which are more applicable to Long Island.''
Four research centers, Brookhaven National Laboratory, North Shore Hospital, the State University as Stony Brook, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory in Laurel Hollow, and 80 commercial firms comprise what many hope will be this next generation of industry for the Island.
Biotechnology, in which living organisms, usually bacteria, are modified genetically to perform special tasks, involves research and development leading to prevention, therapy and diagnosis of disease, as well as improving plant species through genetic engineering and biological solutions for environmental problems.
The industry also includes companies that supply equipment, reagents and diagnostic and analytic services to researchers and health care specialists.
Nationwide, according to an Ernst & Young survey, 1,100 biotechnology companies employed 60,000 people and accounted for $2 billion in annual revenues last year. Only a quarter of the companies, founded from the late 70's through the 80's, currently report profits.
The Industrial Biotechnology Association forecasts, however, exponential growth in products, personnel and facilities, with $20 billion to $40 billion in sales in the United States of genetically engineered drugs, such as interferon and human growth hormone, by the year 2000.
''There's no end to what biotechnology can do,'' said Dr. Terje Skotheim, a physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory and part-time entrepreneur who has started a company, Moltech Corporation, to develop biosensors for in-vivo measurement of enzyme activity.
 
Centers Are Elsewhere
The present geographic centers of the biotechnology industry are the San Francisco Bay area, Route 128 in Massachusetts and San Diego. Long Island is one of several challengers - the Baltimore-Washington metropolitan area and North Carolina's Research Triangle are others - making a strong bid for a piece of the action.
The Center for Advanced Technology at SUNY-Stony Brook recently sponsored the first conference designed as a showcase for potentially commercial discoveries from the Island's four major research institutions. Representatives from companies like Chicago's Abbott Laboratories, San Diego's Hybritech and Japan's Toyobo Company attended the three days of sessions entitled ''Progress '89: Biotechnology on Long Island.''
''The principal motivation for initiating the conference was the conviction that Long Island is a tremendous place for biotechnology because of its superb scientific community,'' said Richard K. Koehn, director of the Center for Biotechnology.
To encourage embryonic companies, the center pays for research with commercial potential, awards seed grants to new biotechnology companies and provides incubator space in the Life Sciences Building at Stony Brook.
Curatech, which now operates 13 wound-healing centers around the country, moved to Long Island from Minnesota two years ago because of the incubator facilities available.
''The ability to move into existing lab space and be up and running immediately was valuable,'' said Russell Whitman, Curatech president. ''It saved us probably a year.'' Curatech, which markets a platelet-derived growth factor, procuren, to treat wounds, soon outgrew its interim quarters. ''On Jan. 1, 1987, I was the only employee in New York State,'' Mr. Whitman said. ''We now have 50.''
The company's quarters have similarly expanded, from 1,200 square feet in the incubator to 13,000 in the Stony Brook Technology Center, with an additional 4,000 to come.
Oncogene Science, organized in 1983 and now at North Shore Hospital, is another fledgling biotechnology concern attracted by the area's scientific resources, namely Cold Spring Harbor researchers like Dr. James D. Watson, director of the laboratory and of the National Center for Human Genome Research, who served as the nucleus of its scientific advisory board.
''The intellectual infrastructure already here was the deciding factor in our move,'' said Dr. John Stephenson, president of Oncogene Science. ''For us it's a perfect location, with access to the right people and a good job market for recruiting.''
Oncogene Science, which has just begun to market TransProbe-1, the first oncogene-based diagnostic test, has also increased its staff from one to 75 employees, one-third of whom are Ph.D.'s, and its space from 5,000 to 43,000 square feet.
Figures are not available for current revenues and positions generated by biotechnology on Long Island, but the field holds promise for future payoffs.
''Initially, we're talking in terms of thousands of jobs before 1995,'' said Lee E. Koppelman, director of the Center for Regional Policy Studies at SUNY-Stony Brook. ''Each one is an embryo for the real explosion, which takes three to five years.''
''The biotech area is spawning its own infrastructure now,'' said Fenimore Fisher, chairman of the Long Island Forum for Technology. ''It will support larger and larger elements of our population.'' ''I suspect,'' said George C. Soos, president of the forum, that in the next 10 years ''we'll be looking at 50,000 jobs in biotechnology in this region.''
 
'A Clean Industry'
With general agreement that diversification is a remedy for the Island's economic slowdown, biotechnology business is worth wooing. ''It's the kind of industry that Long Island needs,'' said Ginny E. Llobel, assistant director of the Center for Biotechnology.
''It's basically a clean industry. It's got minimal transportation requirements. It's a low energy-consuming industry, but needs a strong base of knowledge and skilled workers, which Long Island has.''
The industry may be ideal for the Island, but is the Island ideal for the industry? ''On the downside, it's expensive to live and work here,'' said John Maroney, assistant administrative director of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. ''Power, space for buildings, the buildings themselves are expensive. Long Island is an ecologically sensitive area and disposing of sewage and chemical and medical waste is expensive.''
''We've had some difficulty attracting employees to Long Island from low cost-of-living areas,'' said Mr. Whitman of Curatech. ''We had to offer special housing allowances to induce people. But getting people from Boston and the West Coast was no problem at all.''
Citing the Suffolk County Legislature's zeal in environmental protection and video display terminal legislation, Dr. Koppelman perceived another chilling effect on business. ''The legislators were so eager to be first on the block and get headlines taking on issues that should be handled at the state and Federal level,'' he said, ''that there's no question people in the business and financial community lost confidence.''
Biotechnology faces obstacles more formidable than the Suffolk Legislature. Companies must spend massively on research and development before wending the maze of approvals from the Food and Drug Administration.
Seed capital is harder to raise since the 1987 stock market crash, with investors now leery of financing risky start-up ventures with no hope of quick compensation.
Patent litigation, product liability fears and inevitable delays and disappointments in bringing a product to market have also deflated once high-flying biotechnology stocks. ''It's difficult to predict when companies will turn from red to black ink and how fast that will happen on the Island,'' said Stony Brook's Dr. Koehn.
Another potentially dampening effect on the entire biotechnology industry looms with proposed National Institutes of Health guidelines regarding conflict of interest. The policy would prevent federally funded biomedical researchers from holding stock in companies affected by their research.
Although the guidelines are intended to prevent researchers from falsifying results in order to drive up the price of a stock, the plan might have the effect of impeding transfer of technology to the marketplace, since start-up companies often offer equity holdings to researchers. Richard D. Godown, president of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, calls the proposed guidelines ''anathema, an ill-conceived overreaction and a classic example of using a sledgehammer to kill a gnat.''
Of the need for conflict-of-interest guidelines, a senior staff investigator at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Andrew Rice, whose discovery of how the AIDS virus is activated has been licensed by a French drug company, said: ''There's a lot of room for corruption.'' .
''A scientist in the know could make a lot of money almost as an insider trader, knowing basic research that's going to influence the worth of a company,'' Dr. Rice said.

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 3, 1989

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 29, Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: At Lab Centers, The Future Is Now

BYLINE: By CAROL STRICKLAND

 BODY:
WHATEVER the eventual changes in the relationship between basic research and commercial efforts, the four Long Island biotechnology centers have many promising products in the pipeline of clinical trials and patent filings.
Much research at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory with potential medical applications stems from Dr. Michael Wigler's work on oncogenes, or cancer-causing genes. Although the laboratory receives less than $1 million annually in royalties, licensing fees and research support from the private sector, prospects for multimillion-dollar earnings are on the horizon.
If the Burroughs Wellcome Company wins its patent dispute with Genentech to sell its version of tissue plasminogen activator, a clot-dissolving drug, in the United States, the laboratory could receive $1.5 million a year in royalties. In addition, during the next 10 years, the patent for standardized bacteria used in recombinant DNA research should bring in $2 million to $3 million, according to Mr. Maroney. 
''The big one hasn't come yet,'' he said, ''though the prospects are real.'' The laboratory has already spawned a biotechnology company, Protein Databases Inc. of Huntington Station, which uses techniques and software developed at the laboratory to analyze proteins.
 
Laboratory Holds Patents
Brookhaven National Laboratory, which has 75 employees engaged in biotech-related research, has won 11 patents in the area of biotechnology since 1985. Dr. Paul Falkowski received patents for his research on increasing the yield of beta carotene (which has anti-cancer properties) and omega-3 fatty acids (a heart disease inhibitor) in microalgae.
Soon on the market will be a diagnostic kit for labeling red blood cells in cardiovascular examinations, a product of the research of Suresh C. Srivastava, head of the radionuclide and radiopharmaceutical research division.
Dr. Srivastava directs a team investigating the use of radio-labeled monoclonal antibodies as specific carriers of diagnostic and therapeutic radionuclides to tumors in vivo. ''In the next five to 10 years, we should have some very important materials to treat all kinds of diseases in patients using antibodies,'' Dr. Srivastava said.
Dr. Barry S. Coller, head of hematology at the University Hospital at Stony Brook, is also at the forefront of the hot field of monoclonal antibody research. Centocor Inc. of Malvern, Pa., is conducting clinical trials using a potent anti-platelet agent, a monoclonal antibody developed by Dr. Coller, in cases of acute heart attack and stroke.
The antibody, which has no toxic or hemorrhagic side effects and is more effective than aspirin in preventing reocclusion of arteries, may ultimately have a large role to play in heart disease prevention and therapy.
At Stony Brook's School of Dental Medicine, several patents have been issued based on the discovery of Dr. Lorne Golub and Dr. Thomas McNamara. A promising new drug they created, chemically modified tetracycline, may prove both the long-sought silver bullet in disease treatment as well as a gold mine in royalties.
Working in collaboration with physicians elsewhere, Drs. Golub and McNamara have found that tetracycline, stripped of its antibiotic properties, is a powerful inhibitor of tissue breakdown. By blocking production of excessive collagenase, CMT is effective against periodontal gum disease, corneal ulcers, diabetes-induced kidney disease, rheumatoid arthritis and the breakdown of bone in osteoporosis.
The latest use for this seeming-miracle drug, without toxic side-effects, reported in last April's The Lancet, a British medical journal, is its impressive suppression of blistering in dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, a life-threatening hereditary skin disease for which there is no known treatment.
''We may be lucking out on this,'' said Dr. Golub of the potential wide applications for CMT, a drug that seems safe even with prolonged use.
At North Shore University Hospital, ''Our research is directed toward rapid application rather than basic science,'' said Andrew Szilagyi, research administrator at North Shore.
''We're bridging the laboratory bench and bedside,'' said a hospital spokesman, Daniel Rosett, citing the example of a pioneering skin patch that zaps medication across the skin barrier with electric current. Already used for beta blockers, motion sickness drugs and nitroglycerin, the skin patch offers promise in delivering a controlled dosage of drugs like insulin to replace daily injections.
The major biotech thrust at North Shore centers on a procedure called positron emission tomography (PET), one of the few such facilities in the country. In simple terms, PET, according to Dr. Donald Margouleff, chief of nuclear medicine, ''is a way of sticking a patient in a big aperture and making nondestructive in-vivo measurements of metabolic and physiologic processes. Right now there's no other way to do this.''
PET uses radioactive tracers that localize in the patient's organs to yield images indicating the functioning as well as structure of the organs.
In a pilot study, physicians use PET to predict the success of coronary bypass operations. Currently, 20 percent of such procedures, at a cost of $2.5 billion annually, have no beneficial effect on patients. But with PET screening to reveal blood distribution and areas of active metabolism in the heart muscle, surgeons can rescue still living though nonfunctioning heart muscles.
Like many researchers in biotechnology, Dr. Margouleff seemed astounded at the brave new world created by tools of modern science.
''When I was in medical school,'' he said, ''I never thought we'd be able to see the functioning of organs like the heart or lungs separate from the body. We were limited to what we could figure out by thumping on the patient's body or listening with a stethoscope.''
 
Advances Anticipated
Even more astounding medical advances are anticipated as a result of the Human Genome Initiative, which will have equally far-reaching effects on the biotechnology industry. The Federal Government will spend $3 billion over the next 15 years to map the sequence of human genes, locating those associated with hereditary diseases.
''The knowledge it will catalogue is so vast as to be almost infinite,'' Dr. Rice said. ''The techniques that will be developed will be analogous to the space race and all the spinoffs that came from that.''
Biotech boosters hope Long Island workers will play as integral a role in the gene revolution as they did in the aerospace industry, with a comparable boon to the economy. ''We have a lot of start-up biotech companies gearing up,'' said Ms. Llobel.
''Eighty percent of industrial growth on Long Island has not been from outside firms coming in but these incubator firms that started with five or 10 employees,'' Dr. Koppelman said. ''I look to see growth from the inside, which then becomes a magnet for outside firms as in Silicon Valley.''
