HEADLINE: An Irish Baker's Path to Mount Vernon

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
WHEN John Tarrant turned 14 years old, in County Cork, Ireland, he was apprenticed to a baker. ''Did I want to be a baker? I wasn't asked and I never questioned it,'' Mr. Tarrant said the other day. ''That's how it was.'' The baker was his uncle. ''My father was a blacksmith and all his brothers were in different trades,'' Mr. Tarrant said. ''In our family of six boys and three girls, the boys were apprenticed early. My first responsibility was attending to the peat furnace when I arrived at work at 3 o'clock in the morning.''
That was 34 years ago. Now Mr. Tarrant, the president of the Traditional Irish Bakery, headquartered in Mount Vernon, no longer stokes peat furnaces in his gleaming, large new bakery in Mount Vernon. Nor does he have to go to work at 3 o'clock in the morning. He arrives on the job at 4:30 A.M.
Like previous generations of Irish entrepreneurs, Mr. Tarrant left Ireland in search of opportunity. 
 
Took a Degree in Baking
''When I was 20,'' he said, ''I wanted more education. So I left Ireland for the first time, for England, where I knew there was a good bakery school in London. I wanted to learn the technical and business side of the bakery business. I worked as a baker to support myself and went to school at night for four years until I earned a National Diploma in Baking.''
Mr. Tarrant then returned to Ireland and opened his first bakery, called the Pastry Shop, in Cork.
''The shop did very well but eventually I sold it and bought my uncle's business in Killarney,'' he said. ''American tourists would come in the store from time to time and they particularly liked our brown bread and soda bread. They said there was nothing like it in the States and they wished there were.''
Several years later, in the early part of this decade when the Irish economy stalled and business leveled off, Mr. Tarrant and his wife, Bernadette, made the difficult decision to leave Ireland.
 
Saw a Future in America
''I was 44 years old, we had three children. To be honest, we didn't feel - no matter how hard we worked - that we had a future in Ireland,'' Mr. Tarrant said. ''One of my brothers, who is a priest, was already in the United States. I had visited him and I found a lot of Irish in New York but I had never located a real Irish bakery. I always remembered that. So when my wife and I decided to take a big chance and sell our shop in Ireland, we decided to use the proceeds to start an Irish bakery in New York.''
Mr. Tarrant recalled that he walked and walked around Manhattan, looking for the proper site, until he spoke to a few people and they all advised him to go to the Woodlawn section of the Bronx, an area where Irish-Americans make up 90 percent of the community.
The Tarrants opened the Traditional Irish Bakery in a small store at 4268 Katonah Avenue in Woodlawn, on July 22, 1986.
''It took all our savings, $20,000, plus another $20,000 we borrowed from the Bank of Ireland in New York,'' Mr. Tarrant recalled. ''And at that we only had one oven and one mixer.
''I remember how nervous we were on opening day. In anticipation, we had made the same amount of baked goods we made every day in Killarney; about three dozen raisin scones, three dozen whole-wheat scones and the same amount of soda bread and whole-wheat loaves. We didn't advertise, but customers came by word of mouth and in less than two hours after we opened, we sold out. That little store did more volume in one day than we did in a six-day week in Killarney.''
 
A Role in the Community
The bakery also quickly became a community center, a place where many young Irish immigrants who had entered the country in recent years met over coffee and scones and got advice from the Rev. Michael Harrison, who is associated with St. Barnabas Roman Catholic Church in the neighborhood.
''It is hard for them,'' Mr. Tarrant said. ''Father Harrison helps them with their problems. He comes here on a regular basis several times a week.''
The store also stocks traditional Irish products such as Irish oatmeal and small gift items. But the authentic round Irish soda bread and the whole-wheat bread, at $2.30 a loaf, and the plump raisin-filled scones and whole-wheat scones at 60 cents each, have found such favor with neighborhood customers and food writers that Mr. Tarrant was encouraged to open three additional shops in succession in predominantly Irish neighborhoods in the Bronx.
''This year has been a big year for us,'' Mr. Tarrant said. ''I couldn't even imagine such rapid expansion without what I call a stroke of very good fortune.''
Good fortune started, he said, when his quest for more space for production took him to Mount Vernon.
''A local realtor, Joseph Torresi, showed me a building that was a former garage on Third Avenue,'' he said. ''It was nice and big but too expensive for me. Then a fantastic thing happened. Joe Torresi introduced me to Salvatore Quaranta and Mr. Quaranta suggested I apply for a New York State Job Development loan.
 
'I Was Scared'
''I was scared. He was talking about a $1 million project, converting the garage into a bakery. But Mr. Quaranta and Morton Marks helped me with the loan application and miraculously it was approved. Then I went back to the Bank of Ireland and they agreed to make me an additional loan of $456,000. I thought, this can only happen in America.''
Mr. Quaranta is president of the Industrial Development Corporation, a division of the Mount Vernon Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Marks is chairman of the chamber's local development corporation. The Industrial Development Corporation serves as the local development corporation in the acceptance, review and submission of loan applications to the Job Development Authority. In return for the financing assistance it receives, the Traditional Irish Bakery is providing jobs for Mount Vernon-area residents.
''The new bakery and store had its official opening on this Nov. 14,'' Mr. Tarrant said, ''Our new production facilities encompass 10,000 feet of space, which has allowed us to double and triple production. From a staff of four, which includes myself, my wife who does the books, and Douglas Smith, who has been our production manager since we started, we now have 27 people who work several shifts.''
 
He Uses Washington Wheat
Mr. Tarrant buys his wheat from Washington State because, he said, the climatic conditions there are almost identical to those in Ireland.
''We still bake the same way, using only the choicest ingredients,'' he said. ''The big sellers are still brown bread, soda bread and scones, but now that we've got the space we're expanding our line. We introduced rhubarb pies and we're selling a lot of them already. And I've learned how to make bagels, pumpkin pies and sweet potato pies, which are also selling nicely.''
The bakery has also introduced a line of Irish dessert treats, like steamed plum puddings and Irish porter cake for holiday delivery nationwide.
''We've got a lot of customers who aren't Irish now,'' Mr. Tarrant said. ''For example, two weeks ago here in Mount Vernon we sold almost two dozen loaves of soda bread for a wedding luncheon where the food was Italian. The bride's mother originally bought two loaves for the groom's family, who were Irish. But the bread was so popular with all the guests, they sent out in a hurry for 21 more loaves.''
Traditional Irish bakery products are also sold to restaurants and specialty food shops throughout the New York City area.
''We're looking forward to more growth,'' Mr. Tarrant said, ''I certainly don't think it would have been possible without the support and encouragement of the Mount Vernon Chamber of Commerce.''

HEADLINE: Third World Debt Never Shrinks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Just returned from a conference on debt and development in the Caribbean Basin, I find your editorial ''Costa Rica Breaks the Mold'' (Nov. 2). Debt reduction, your theme, is a most desirable goal. The financial obligations of Costa Rica and other third world debtor countries to foreign institutions, both private and public, have indeed been a major constraint on development in the 1980's.
What you fail to mention, however, is that the economic policies and measures promoted by the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, the United States and other donor countries as conditions attached to new lending and now to debt reduction have themselves presented serious obstacles to short-term and long-term economic recovery. Structural adjustment programs have had a devastating impact on women, children, the poor and other vulnerable groups (as well as on the natural environment), as resources have been increasingly diverted from their needs and their productive efforts and directed to export production -Northern trade protectionism notwithstanding.
After nearly a decade of adjustment, third world economies are more indebted than ever. And the situation will grow worse with the unification of the European market in 1992 unless fundamental changes are made.
These are realities you should be communicating. You should also make clear that it is the United States taxpayer who will be providing, under the plan of Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas Brady, guarantees for loans made by private banks, setting the stage for a likely bailout of those banks in the future. A serious public debate on World Bank and International Monetary Fund lending and on practical policy options is badly needed.
 
STEPHEN HELLINGER
Co-director, Development Group
for Alternative Policies Inc.
 Washington, Nov. 9, 1989

HEADLINE: The Budget Fix Needs Fixing

 BODY:
The 1985 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law was supposed to eliminate Federal deficits by next October. It won't. Worse, the law distorts budget decisions, encourages deceit and risks turning recession into disaster.
Even so, Gramm-Rudman is better than nothing, and it can be fixed to make it a little better still. 
Mammoth Federal deficits can hurt the economy by diverting savings from capital formation. Over time, that eviscerates productive capacity. Congress recognized the harm but was unable to discipline itself. By borrowing to increase agriculture subsidies or to lower taxes, legislators create visible winners and grateful voters. The cost is borne, invisibly, by future generations. No wonder the deficit spiraled out of control.
Gramm-Rudman was the remedy. It requires Congress to legislate reductions or else across-the-board spending cuts are made automatically. The law has done some good. Deficits have been restrained. But they remain far above targets because Congress has invented ways to evade the law. Budget discipline has become budget deceit. Gramm-Rudman also warps budget deliberations. It provides an all-purpose excuse for holding back on critically important initiatives like early childhood education; Eastern Europe should be getting billions. In reality, Congress could pay for these programs with tax hikes, but that option has been politically foreclosed. Despite its flaws, Gramm-Rudman remains a useful brake on Congressional irresponsibility. And it would be even more useful if some specific mechanisms were adjusted. Revise the Target. By targeting the actual deficit, Gramm-Rudman could worsen the next recession. Tax revenues fall as the economy slows, widening the deficit. Despite some protective language, the law could still trigger punishing spending cuts. Congress can remedy this by redefining its targets in terms of a hypothetical deficit: the deficit that spending and tax programs would cause if the economy were operating at full employment. Written in this way, the Gramm-Rudman law would impose no new spending cuts on a sluggish economy.
Revise the Accounting Period. Congress can now evade annual deficit targets by shifting expenses and revenues to other fiscal years. The solution is to make Congress take account of budgetary impacts before and after the current fiscal year.
Leave Social Security in the Budget. Congress ought not remove the growing Social Security surplus from the deficit calculation. To do that would unjustifiably exempt Social Security benefits from future budget pressures and make the Gramm-Rudman goal of a zero deficit excessively punitive.
If Congress achieves a zero deficit under the current rules, programs other than Social Security will be in deficit by about $100 billion in 1993. That's good enough, given the arbitrary way that the Federal deficit is now defined. Besides, a $100 billion deficit is small in relation to the size of the economy.
Gramm-Rudman is a poor substitute for a Congress willing to judge public needs, programs and taxes on their merits. But lacking this wise deliberation, Gramm-Rudman is a lamentable necessity -if these flaws are fixed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Subway Begging: Legal for Charity But Not for Poor

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
rrJoseph (Papa Joe) Walley, a 50-year-old former warehouse worker and recreation director, has been unemployed for the five years or so since he injured his knee. About the same time, his landlord abandoned the West Harlem building in which Mr. Walley was living.
Mr. Walley, a divorced father of three, slept in city parks and shelters until he found refuge at night in an Upper East Side synagogue. He collects about $42 a week in welfare and food stamps. When he sleeps in a city shelter, all he receives is $10.75 a week. He supplements that by begging on the subway, sometimes for the fare to get to hospitals where he undergoes therapy. On good days he collects as much as $25 in five or six hours. 
William P. Young Jr., a 40-year-old former truck driver, said he was dropped from welfare in September for missing an appointment, but still receives about $18 a week in food stamps, which he augments by unloading trucks. He, too, panhandles on the subway, where he often sleeps. He said he spends the proceeds on food, clothing, medicine for bleeding ulcers and high blood pressure and, if enough is left, a cheap room for the night.
The two men are bound together by mendicancy and as plaintiffs. They are named as representatives of other subway beggars in a Federal class-action lawsuit filed on their behalf by the Legal Action Center for the Homeless. The suit seeks to overturn the anomaly that allows groups like the Legal Action Center to solicit contributions in the New York City subway system to help people like Mr. Walley and Mr. Young, but bars individuals from panhandling to help themselves.
Their lawyers argue that Transit Authority regulations violate two Constitutional amendments: the 14th, by distinguishing, if ambiguously, between individuals who solicit alms and those who solicit for charitable causes; and also the First, by enforcing rules that could render beggars, particularly homeless beggars, silent if not invisible.
''To the extent that homelessness in New York is recognized as serious, it's largely as a result of their visibility and being heard,'' said Douglas H. Lasdon, the Legal Action Center's executive director. Their very visibility and volubility, though, is also what prompted the Transit Authority's response.
Ordinarily, thousands of summonses are issued annually for illegal panhandling in the subways. But the suit was inspired by a much-publicized enforcement campaign. It began this fall in response to complaints from riders offended by some of the thousands of people who called the subway system home and intimidated by aggressive beggars.
That solicitation for religious, political and charitable causes was still allowed - though not on subway trains or buses or within 25 feet of token booths - seemed inconsistent. It implied that the Transit Authority was aware of the potential First Amendment ramifications of its original rule. Also, it implied that the rule was directed at full-time mendicants rather than at more socially acceptable volunteers who, in helping poor people in general, are also presumed to be publicizing and promoting the destitute's interests. Lawyers for the homeless say a beggar's extended hand sends a message, too.
The apparent inconsistency also troubled Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan, who heard the case on Friday. He cited ''the anomaly that two mendicants can be in the subway, each soliciting for the other.''
Acknowledging that the rules do not distinguish between the homeless and others, George Sommers, a lawyer for the Legal Action Center, said: ''Maybe a rich person theoretically could go down and solicit alms, but, as the famous saying goes, the rich could sleep under the bridges of Paris, but they don't.''
Specifically, the rule bars solitication of alms without authorization, but Susan E. Weiner, deputy general counsel of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, conceded that no standards for granting authorization exist.
Judge Sand hailed as ''a helpful response'' an agreement by the Legal Action Center's lawyers that professional beggars be bound by the same restrictions imposed on fund-raisers for charitable causes - that is, no soliciting on subway cars or near token booths. The judge gently nudged the Transit Authority to agree, too, so its rules would ''be easier to enforce without requiring each transit officer to be an expert on the First Amendment.''
The Authority agreed only to stop distributing additional leaflets to the public proclaiming its enforcement campaign. It will presumably continue issuing summonses pending the outcome of the case. Its lawyers insisted that if the plaintiffs needed to panhandle they could do so outside the transit system.
With the onset of winter, Mr. Walley and Mr. Young beg to differ.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Exports Rise for 3 Nations

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The world's three largest trading nations all showed a big increase in the value of their exports in the first half of the year, compared with the first six months of 1988, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
Exports from West Germany increased 6.3 percent, to $169.1 billion, from $159.1 billion. The United States had a rise of 15.9 percent, to $182.7 billion, from $157.6 billion. Exports from Japan were up 7.7 percent, to $135 billion, from $125.3 billion, the I.M.F. said.
At the same time, West German imports rose 6.9 percent to $132.7 billion, from $124.1 billion. American imports increased 7.5 percent to $241.5 billion, from $224.6 billion, but Japan's imports dropped slightly, to $91.1 billion, from $91.5 billion.
The American trade deficit improved in the first six months to $58.8 billion, down from $67.1 billion in the period a year earlier.
Japan's surplus of exports over imports increased by nearly a third, to $43.9 billion from $33.7 billion. West Germany's surplus increased to $37.2 billion from $34.9 billion.
Increased deficits were reported for Britain, at $23.3 billion, compared with $21.1 billion; Italy, $10.3 billion, up from $6.8 billion, and France, $8.4 billion, up from $5.8 billion.
The fund reported a drop in inflation among industrial countries in the quarter that ended in September. Prices paid by their consumers rose at an annual rate of 4.5 percent, compared with a 4.8 percent rate in the spring quarter.

HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

INTERNATIONAL
 
Japanese officials have assured G.E. and Pratt & Whitney of a big role in a Government-financed project to design an extremely fast commercial aircraft. The Ministry of Trade and Industry hopes to spend $200 million in the next few years designing an engine for the ''hypersonic'' aircraft, which would travel at five times the speed of sound. The companies have indicated that they would need U.S. approval before signing any contracts. [Page D1.] 
 
Government and professional groups in Britain are pressing ahead with reforms that for the first time in decades could allow accounting firms there to incorporate for the purpose of raising outside equity capital. Outside capital has become more alluring since the profession's moves into nontraditional services. [D1.]
 
Dollars are costing far more on Czechoslovakia's black market. The word on the street - or at least in taxicabs where the drivers run a thriving money-changing business - is that many Czechs rushed to buy hard currency as soon as the Government said it would open the Czechoslovak-Austrian border. [D6.]
 
Beijing's political crackdown has stalled progress on an ambitious project to copy the success of Hong Kong on southern China's Hainan Island, where a chunk of land was to be leased to a foreign company for transformation into a duty-free port and a modern city of several hundred thousand people. [D6.]
 
Congress and the business community are likely to endorse President Bush's proposals at the Malta summit encouraging the Soviet Union's integration into the global economy. The President has offered to cut punitively high tariffs on Soviet exports and to support observer status for Moscow in GATT. [A11.]
 
The Republic of Malta is promoting itself as a new international financial center, to fill the role left by Beirut. [D6.]
 
The three largest trading nations all showed a big increase in the value of their exports during the first half of the year. [D6.]

Federal regulators rejected warnings in 1986 about the Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., former Government officials who were involved in the decision said. They said Federal action at the time might have prevented some of the more than $500 million in losses reported by the institution. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Gold Seen as Barrier to Fall in Interest Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A sharp rise in gold prices, often viewed as a harbinger of a rising inflation rate, may inhibit further declines in long-term interest rates for the balance of the year, some analysts contend.
Over the course of the fall season, gold prices have risen by about $60 an ounce, to a close on Friday of $413.60 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The run-up has become a concern to a number of credit market participants because other factors, most notably further softness in the economy, suggest that interest rates should fall further.
Equally disturbing is the lack of a clear-cut reason for gold's increase. Among the possible explanations being discussed are the upheaval in Eastern Europe; big purchases in Asia, where demand for gold is usually quite strong, and the recent dip in the dollar's value. 
''Until we figure out why gold has been going up, or it starts to come back down again, I don't think the bond market will improve that much,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities.
By the end of last week, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price to yield 7.87 percent, virtually unchanged from the level on Nov. 24.
To many analysts, the conventional explanation for gold's rise -real or imagined inflationary pressures - does not seem to fit this time.
''The gold price rise is a concern and the markets may be aware of it, but the inflation picture is ambiguous,'' said Gary Schlossberg, vice president and chief economist at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco.
Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company, said: ''The momentum on inflation is headed lower. I don't think the rise in gold prices is a statement that inflation in this country is going to get worse.''
Nevertheless, there are those who argue that gold's importance has not dimmed in the credit markets.
''The message gold has been sending is that of a growing fear the Federal Reserve will ease monetary policy too aggressively and risk reinflating the economy next year,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. ''In the final analysis, the gold market is always an inflation indicator. And right now inflation jitters are running through it.''
 
Effect on Fed Seen
In Mr. Kudlow's view, the rise in gold prices was enough to persuade the Fed to pull back from a move to lower interest rates just before Thanksgiving.
Market participants interpreted a move by the Fed to add reserves to the banking system on Nov. 22 as a clear signal that it had eased monetary policy. To the chagrin of many market participants, however, the Fed made it clear last week that its move had been misinterpreted.
''The Fed is trying to sell the story that they never eased in the first place, but I don't buy it,'' Mr. Kudlow said. ''Bureaucrats, just like the rest of us, are entitled to change their minds. And I think in large part they changed their mind because the easing move prompted a vicious reaction from gold.''
 
Surge of $8.10 on Nov. 22
Gold prices surged by as much as $8.10 an ounce on Nov. 22, to $411.60.
Because of the rise in gold prices, Mr. Kudlow contended, further easing moves by the Fed are ''unlikely'' for the balance of the year.
That opinion stands in contrast to the prevailing view among money-market economists, who continue to say the Fed remains responsive to developments in the real economy, and will ease policy when and if it sees further signs of weakness. An easing move could come soon, if prevailing forecasts about economic data to be released this week are borne out.
Most analysts expect that the November employment report, due out on Friday, will help to nudge the Fed toward approving a decline in the overnight Federal funds rate, currently trading at about 8.50 percent.
Along with a number of other forecasters, Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank, is projecting that non-farm payroll employment rose by 150,000 jobs last month, down from the rise of 230,000 initially reported for October. Moreover, Mr. Fine said the unemployment rate, a figure the Fed monitors exceptionally closely, could rise by as much as two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent.
''If my numbers are right, the Fed could ease,'' he said. ''But I would argue that bond yields won't go anywhere until we see signs of a recession or a lowering in inflationary expectations. Right now definitive signs of a recession are not there.''
 
Influenced by Malta Talks
Aside from the economic data, conditions in the credit markets could well be influenced by developments at the Malta summit talks.
Optimism about the talks was cited as at least a partial reason for last Friday's big rise in stock prices. In the past, participants in the fixed-income markets have exhibited an affinity to react to bold statements by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
In response to the positive tone that emerged from the summit meeting in Washington nearly a year ago, on Dec. 7, 1988, the bond market rallied by nearly two full points.

HEADLINE: The Malta Summit;
BUSH AND GORBACHEV PROCLAIM A NEW ERA FOR U.S.-SOVIET TIES; AGREE ON ARMS AND TRADE AIMS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 3

 BODY:
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended their first summit meeting today with an extraordinary public affirmation of the new relationship between their countries.
Mr. Gorbachev said he and Mr. Bush agreed that ''the characteristics of the cold war should be abandoned.''
''The arms race, mistrust, psychological and ideological struggle, all those should be things of the past,'' he said.
Mr. Bush said: ''With reform under way in the Soviet Union, we stand at the threshold of a brand-new era of U.S.-Soviet relations. It is within our grasp to contribute each in our own way to overcoming the division of Europe and ending the military confrontation there.'' 
 
Another Meeting Is Set
In the most substantial agreements reached at the meeting, the two leaders said they would strive to conclude treaties on long-range nuclear weapons and conventional arms in 1990. They also agreed to hold another summit meeting in June in the United States.
But the significance of the first summit meeting between the leaders seemed to lie more in the tone than the substance.
They ended their rain-soaked two-day meeting with the first joint news conference by Soviet and American leaders. [Transcripts of the joint news conference and of a separate news session held by Mr. Bush, pages A12 and A13.] The Tension Evaporates There had been some annoyance aboard Mr. Gorbachev's ship, the Maxim Gorky, on Saturday night when Mr. Bush canceled an afternoon session and a dinner because of a gale. [Page A11.] The tension lingered in the background today but it melted under the television lights in a 65-minute display of cordiality that ended with Mr. Bush reaching over to grasp Mr. Gorbachev's right forearm. The news conference was remarkable for its lack of conflict over issues that have long divided East and West, including arms control, the Middle East and economic relations.
For all the cordiality, the meeting did not produce any new treaties or specific agreements, or even a joint statement.
After eight hours of intimate discussions, the two leaders were still far apart on the issue of sea-based nuclear cruise missiles, a major point of disagreement on a strategic arms treaty. They remained at odds on Central America and Administration officials said Mr. Gorbachev did not give a definitive answer to Mr. Bush's proposals on an agreement reducing chemical weapons.
 
A Sense of Optimism
But Mr. Gorbachev, clearly pleased that Mr. Bush had shown some initiative on economic issues, registered approval on most of the proposals offered by Mr. Bush on Saturday, and the two leaders expressed broad optimism about the course of their relations.
Although they said they did not reach any specific accord on how to deal with the unraveling political power structure in Eastern Europe, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev seemed optimistic even about that problem.
''We searched for the answer to the question of where do we stand now,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. ''We stated, both of us, that the world leaves one epoch of cold war and enters another epoch.''
The two leaders did not dwell on Eastern Europe at length in their news conference, and American officials said the subject did not take up as much of the summit talks as they had expected. In response to a question about the two Germanys, Mr. Bush adopted what had long been the Soviet position. He said the conference on European security that began in Helsinki ''spells out a concept of permanent borders.''
Mr. Gorbachev said ''any artificial acceleration'' of the unification process would make it more difficult to carry through the changes taking place in Eastern Europe.
At times, the cautious Mr. Bush seemed to make an effort to show that all was not settled between the two nations. Even then, the statements from both sides were far more mild than the political oratory that has characterized the Soviet-American relationship for much of the last four decades.
Mr. Bush said his conversation with Mr. Gorbachev stayed cordial even on human rights. ''I remember a time when I first met Mr. Gorbachev and we talked about human rights and he became visibly agitated with me for raising it,'' Mr. Bush said.
''And I think there's been a great evolution in his thinking on that question, and certainly on his relations with the United States, just as there had been an evolution on my thinking,'' Mr. Bush said, noting that he had once opposed holding the very type of meeting he had with Mr. Gorbachev here.
 
A Briefing for the Allies
Indeed, when it came to what American officials said was the most troublesome policy dispute between the two leaders during the shipboard meeting - American charges that Nicaragua is sending arms to the leftist rebels in El Salvador - Mr. Gorbachev said, ''We understand the concerns of the United States.''
Mr. Bush, for his part, said he was ''angry'' about the issue but was not accusing Mr. Gorbachev of anything. Noting that Nicaragua had assured the Soviet Union that the arms shipments had ended, Mr. Bush said, ''I do not believe the Sandinistas have told the truth to our Soviet friends.''
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev talked to reporters aboard the Maxim Gorky, a Soviet cruise liner, before Mr. Gorbachev returned to Moscow.
Later in the day President Bush flew to Brussels, where he is to meet with heads of state and government of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on Monday. At the airport this evening, he paid tribute to NATO's role in maintaining stability in Europe, noting that ''this alliance of free nations remains the bedrock of peaceful change in Europe.''
He also dined with the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who was chosen as the first Western European leader to be personally briefed on the outcome of the summit meeting.
After the dinner, a spokesman for Mr. Kohl said Mr. Bush had provided the West German leader with a full rundown on his talks with Mr. Gorbachev, ranging over such topics as arms control, European integration and developments in Eastern Europe.
The spokesman, Hans Klein, said Mr. Kohl had heard nothing tonight to suggest that either Mr. Bush or Mr. Gorbachev had expressed any opposition to his 10-point plan, announced in Bonn last week, for the eventual reunification of Germany in the long term.
 
Bad Weather 'Doesn't Matter'
The meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev was confined to the cruised liner after a screeching gale whipped the seas so high that it was impossible to meet as planned on the Soviet and American warships that heaved forlornly on the waves in Marsaxlokk Bay.
Mr. Bush, whose staff resolutely tried to put the best face on the ruins of their strategy for television coverage, said ''it doesn't matter'' that the two leaders never set foot together on an American ship. Asked if the weather had ruined his summit meeting, Mr. Bush snapped back, ''Hell no.''
On Saturday, Mr. Bush outlined 18 proposals to Mr. Gorbachev that ranged from nuclear arms contol to educational exchanges. A senior American official who sat in on the talks said Mr. Gorbachev responded positively to almost all of them.
The notable exceptions, he said, were Mr. Bush's proposal that the two nations negotiate and sign an agreement in 1990 limiting their chemical arsenals to 20 percent of the present American level and that they call jointly for the holding of the 2004 Olympic Games on both sides of Berlin.
The official said that Mr. Gorbachev did not give Mr. Bush a clear no on those points but rather did not register the approval that he offered on the other issues.
In the news conference, Mr. Gorbachev said he had agreed with a suggestion by Mr. Bush that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, meet in the Soviet Union in January to discuss arms control issues in preparation for a summit conference in the United States that the two leaders agreed to hold in the last two weeks of June.
He reaffirmed Mr. Bush's hope that the two leaders could sign a strategic arms control treaty, cutting long-range nuclear arsenals in half, at the next summit meeting. Barring that, he said, he hoped the two ministers would be able to resolve enough outstanding problems that at the next summit they could ''agree on the provisions of the treaty and later in the coming months it might be ready for signature.''
Mr. Gorbachev said he also hoped that a treaty limiting conventional weapons in Europe could be signed in 1990 in Vienna. Mr. Bush told reporters that he and Mr. Gorbachev had discussed in general what further cuts might be made in conventional arms, but did not talk about specific numbers.
On strategic arms, Mr. Gorbachev outlined some major obstacles to an accord. He said he was particularly concerned about remaining differences on air-launched cruise missiles and added that he had not dropped his insistence on opening negotiations on sea-based nuclear cruise missiles. Noting the progress that has been made in a number of other areas, Mr. Gorbachev said, ''The time has come when we should begin discussing naval forces.''
Mr. Gorbachev did not make it clear whether he was still setting forth a side agreement on naval weapons as a condition for concluding a strategic arms treaty. But Mr. Bush did suggest that he has not eased his opposition to negotiating about such weapons.
''The chairman knows that I could not come here to make deals in arms control,'' said Mr. Bush, who has repeatedly promised to consult his allies before making any major new treaty proposals or reaching any substantive agreements with Mr. Gorbachev on reducing nuclear or conventional arms.
 
Trade Proposals Appreciated
Mr. Gorbachev was especially appreciative in public - and in private too, American and Soviet officials said - about Mr. Bush's proposals on trade and economic relations, which included his expression of support for Soviet observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Mr. Bush also said he would begin immediate negotiations on lifting American barriers to trade with the Soviet Union and would recommend most-favored-nation status as soon as new Soviet emigration laws are enacted.
Mr. Gorbachev, who has long been seeking these moves and had viewed the lack of progress on economic issues as a major problem in the superpower relationship, said Mr. Bush's ideas and the discussion in Malta ''could be regarded as a political impetus which we were lacking for our economic cooperation to gain momentum.''
Mr. Bush called trade ''one of the most fruitful parts of our discussion'' and said he would ''like to have a climate in which American businessmen can help with what Chairman Gorbachev is trying to do in terms of reform and glasnost.''
 
Differences Narrowed, Bush Says
On Central America, Mr. Bush said there were still clear differences between himself and Mr. Gorbachev. But he said, ''I'd like to feel that if there are some differences between the two of us, then they have been narrowed.''
Turning to the Middle East, Mr. Bush moved away from the often-expressed American view that the Soviet Union is impeding the peace process or, at best, trying to gain influence in the region at American expense.
''The Soviet Union is playing a constructive role in Lebanon and there is common ground there,'' Mr. Bush said, noting that it had ''not always been the case in history'' for an American President to take such a position.

HEADLINE: Homeless Plan Called Meager For New York

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The portion of the Bush Administration's new housing proposals aimed at the homeless will do little if anything to ease conditions for New York City's swelling homeless population, say city and state officials and advocates for the homeless.
The officials, like their counterparts across the country, have praised Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp for turning the Federal spotlight on housing assistance and homelessness after nearly a decade of neglect in the Reagan Administration.
But they have made it clear that the financing proposed by President Bush, $728 million over three years, is woefully inadequate to help the homeless.
In New York City, where there is an accute shortage of low-cost housing and where the vacancy rate for rental units is far below the level needed to keep the market moving, the problem is more complicated than simply a lack of Federal money. 
 
Need for New Housing
City and state housing officials said that even if the Administration were willing to devote significantly more dollars to helping the homeless, few of the estimated 70,000 to 80,000 homeless people now on the city's streets or in its shelters would be able to take advantage of the aid under the program as it is currently proposed.
Richard L. Higgins, New York State's Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, said a quick look at the housing arithmetic in New York City demonstrates the magnitude of the problem and the need for the kind of new housing production precluded under the Administration's proposal.
State and city officials cited these statistics:
* 36,000 people a night stay in city shelters, and at least that many are on the streets.
* 100,000 occupants in the city's 185,000 public-housing units are ''doubled up'' -sharing space intended for one family.
* The average wait for public housing is 12 to 18 months for ''priority cases'' and 10 to 20 years for others.
* The vacancy rate for apartments with rent under $300 a month is 0.96 percent. The vacancy rate for apartments with rent from $300 to $400 a month is 2.15 percent, while the vacancy rate for apartments at all rent levels is 2.46 percent. The vacancy rate considered ''normal'' for rental markets to function efficiently is 5 percent.
More than half of the money the Bush Administration envisions for programs for the homeless, $450 million, would be allocated for housing vouchers that can be used to pay a portion of a tenant's rent.
But as Felice Michetti, first deputy commissioner of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said, giving housing vouchers to homeless people in New York is like giving out food stamps when all the shelves in the grocery store are empty.
The voucher system, which has been a part of Federal housing programs since 1983, is aimed at giving tenants the flexibility to find rental housing in the location and price range of their choice. The Government sets a ''fair market rent'' for units of various sizes and pays the difference between that rent and 30 percent of the tenant's income.
 
Scant Relation to Reality
While the fair-market rent levels are intended to account for variations among housing markets, they often bear little relation to reality in a city like New York, said Steven Banks, who coordinates the New York City Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project and regularly represents clients who have vouchers but cannot find places to live.
For example, the city housing department's latest rent values - including utility costs - are $415 a month for a studio, $504 a month for a one-bedroom apartment, $593 a month for a two-bedroom and $743 a month for a three-bedroom.
Although New Yorkers living in rent-controlled or rent-stablilized buildings might pay rents at such levels, vacant apartments in many parts of the city would cost a new tenant twice and perhaps three times that amount.
Under the voucher system, a tenant who chooses a two-bedroom apartment renting for $1,000 a month would receive a monthly Federal subsidy based on the difference between the $593-a-month rent and 30 percent of the tenant's income. The tenant would have to come up with the additional money to meet the actual rent.
 
Potential for New Units
''We always felt that the voucher system was a little bit of a hoax,'' said Harold Sole, director of leased housing for the New York City Housing Authority. ''There's not much use in subsidizing people if, after subsidizing them, they are paying 70 percent of their income in rent.''
There are two other portions of the Administration program intended for the homeless: $150 million over three years for single-room-occupancy buildings that house mentally ill or drug- and alcohol-addicted people and $108 million over three years for other rental projects for the mentally and physically disabled.
Those programs hold the potential for creating additional housing units. But zoning, rent control and other problems in New York could severely limit the city's ability to make use of that money.
Under those programs, housing vouchers would be tied to the specific project rather than allotted to individual tenants. As a result, nonprofit developers would be guaranteed a 10- or 15-year stream of income that could be used as collateral to obtain loans that might finance low-income housing construction or rehabilitation projects.
 
Bleak Arithmetic
City officials estimate that there are 52,000 housing units in 7,000 privately owned S.R.O. buildings in New York. But as a result of a recent United States Supreme Court decision, the moratorium that had restricted destruction or conversion of those buildings to higher-priced dwellings has been lifted.
Officials said it was impossible to estimate how many private owners would proceed with conversions or how much Federal money might be available to help the city purchase some of the buildings and maintain them for low-income residents.
But Mr. Higgins said, given the costs for acquiring and rehabilitating a unit of S.R.O. housing, $40,000 to $60,000, the arithmetic was once again bleak.
''To the extent the Federal Government provides us with more tools to keep and build S.R.O.'s, we welcome it,'' he said. ''But given the magnitude of what we are talking about here, this program is not going to make a dent.''
A city housing official, who asked not to be identified, put it more bluntly:
''Two-hundred thousand dollars may go a long way in Denver, but it goes nowhere in New York City. Many of the nonprofit developers here would not even bother applying for that kind of subsidy because even if they got it, it would not begin to close their funding gap.''
Brad C. Johnson, New York State's chief lobbyist in Washington, said city and state officials regard the overall housing proposal as merely the first step in a long bargaining process that will begin formally when the Administration submits legislation to Congress next month.
''What Jack Kemp has done is to announce the end of the Federal retreat on housing and to overcome the forces within the Administration that wanted to use the H.U.D. scandals as an excuse to close down H.U.D.,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''Those are not insignificant accomplishments. He's at the negotiating table, and if he's willing to negotiate in good faith, we can make some progress.''

HEADLINE: The Malta Summit;
Tariff Offer Gives Soviets a Foothold

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
In offering to cut punitively high tariffs on Soviet exports and support observer status for Moscow in the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, President Bush has moved dramatically to encourage the Soviet Union's integration into the global economy.
The President's proposals at Malta were likely to win the endorsement of members of Congress and the business community, many of whom see a broader trade relationship not only reducing political tension but improving American competitiveness in the long term.
''Clearly, it is time now to unleash trade as a force for a better relationship,'' said Dwayne O. Andreas, chief executive of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, a food exporting enterprise based in Decatur, Ill.
The willingness to see the Soviet Union in 42-year-old GATT, which is both a fair-trade charter and an organization that promotes the opening of global markets, represents a shift in American policy. 
 
Why Moscow Was Blackballed
Although Moscow has been seeking to join the Geneva-based trade organization since the mid-1980's, Washington put the request on hold. American policymakers were deeply skeptical that the Soviet Union, with its centrally planned economy, could meet fundamental obligations of the group.
Members, or contracting parties as they are known in GATT parlance, agree to cut tariffs and remove other barriers to encourage free competition.
But in a centrally planned economy, competition has a limited role. Trade is more likely to be determined by currency availability and political considerations. Now that Moscow has begun pursuing market-oriented economic changes, some of that skepticism has been overridden.
 
Fear of a Politicized GATT
Another reason for blackballing the Soviet Union was a fear that it would politicize the organization and disrupt three-year-old negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round, aimed at further liberalization of global trade.
Some of those fears remain. President Bush pointedly noted that talks on observer status, which would permit Moscow to watch proceedings and prepare its case for full-scale membership, would not begin until after the completion of the Uruguay Round, scheduled at the end of next year.
At the same time, the reasons for barriers in American-Soviet trade are fast disappearing. Because of cold war tensions, the Soviet Union has been denied normal tariff treatment in the United States, known as most-favored-nation status, since the 1950's. Soviet manufactured goods imported into the United States have therefore been taxed at much higher rates than similar goods produced in other countries.
During the period of so-called detente in the early 1970's, an effort was made to negotiate an agreement that would have given the Soviet Union most-favored-nation status. But in 1974 Congress passed the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which linked Moscow's tariff status to its restrictions on emigration.
 
Old Arguments Fade
With more than 50,000 Soviet Jews expected to leave this year, compared with 19,000 last year and fewer than 1,000 a year from 1984 to 1986, the justification for denying Moscow normal tariff treatment is weakening.
''It looks as though most Soviet Jews who want to leave the Soviet Union can,'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said recently.
A co-author of the Jackson-Vanik amendment, former Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, asked: ''Why should Soviet products continue to face high and discriminatory duties in the American market, while almost all other U.S. trading partners enjoy M.F.N.? I can think of no political or economic reason that remains persuasive.''
A trade accord that President Bush says he wants to conclude with Moscow after the Soviet Parliament liberalizes its emigration laws would enable him to ask Congress for a one-year waiver of the amendment's provisions.
Under the schedule set at the Malta meeting, the President would probably seek the waiver around June, the time of the next summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. That would likely mean that the initial tariff cuts on Soviet products would come later next year, provided that Congress, as expected, agrees. $15 Off a Case of Vodka As one illustration of what most-favored-nation status could mean, it would knock $15 off the retail price of a case of Soviet vodka.
Soviet officials, mindful of the model of Japan and other prosperous countries of the Pacific rim, see increased trade as critical to growth in the domestic economy. The Soviet Union's level of foreign trade currently is about the same as Spain's or Australia's.
The Soviet Union pays tariffs on its exports to the United States that are up to 10 times the amount levied on other countries. Although few of their manufactured goods are now competitive in the United States, Soviet exporters are likely to try to sell more products like vodka, furs, small tractors and cold- weather gear.
Annual trade between the two countries now amounts to less than $3.5 billion. Eventually, many business leaders believe, they could be doing tens of billions of dollars, creating sales and jobs in both countries.

HEADLINE: The Taxi Quest: Seeking Ways to Make It Easier

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FREITAG

 BODY:
On a cold afternoon last week, Perry Gershon stood on the Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, trying to hail a taxi. Several occupied taxis went by before an empty one finally stopped. But just as Mr. Gershon was reaching for the door, a man darted out from behind him and leaped in.
One of the truisms of life in New York City - Mr. Gershon said he has learned it the hard way - is that it is almost impossible to get a yellow cab during rush hour. That is particularly true, he said, in midtown Manhattan on a cold or rainy day, when demand is at its peak. 
''I often don't bother trying anymore,'' said Mr. Gershon, a 27-year-old restaurant owner who lives on the Upper East Side. ''I'll just drive to midtown and put my car into a garage to avoid the hassle of hailing a cab.''
The difficulty in finding cabs during rush hour has been vexing riders and city officials for decades, taxi industry officials say. Efforts to raise the number of medallion cabs from the limit of 11,787, which was set in 1937, have been opposed for financial and environmental reasons. And attempts to get riders to share cabs in midtown have generally been unsuccessful.
 
A 'Clear' Goal
But the city keeps trying. Last Thursday, the Taxi and Limousine Commission approved fare increases that it hopes will make it easier for the 500,000 people who use yellow cabs each day to find them during rush hour.
''One of the clear goals of the fare proposal was that drivers would be more willing to drive in the central business districts and to take shorter trips,'' said Jack S. Lusk, chairman of the commission.
The higher fare may also improve rush-hour availability by prompting more commuters to use buses and subways, even though mass-transit fares are expected to rise next year, Mr. Lusk said.
Under the new cab fare, which goes into effect on Jan. 7, the initial meter ''drop'' will rise 34 percent, to $1.50 from $1.15, while the cost of each additional mile will increase 4 percent, to $1.25 from $1.20. Waiting time, the time spent in a motionless cab, will go to $12 an hour from $9, or 20 cents a minute from 15 cents. The cost of the average ride - estimated by the commission to be 2.9 miles with 5 minutes of waiting time - will increase 11.5 percent, to $5.90 from $5.25.
 
An Unsuccessful Proposal
The commission also considered a proposal that would have replaced the 50-cent night surcharge, in effect since 1981, with a 50-cent surcharge during the morning and afternoon rush hours. The taxi industry opposed that plan, saying the chronic shortage of drivers would become even more severe without the night surcharge.
Although Mr. Lusk favored the rush-hour surcharge, he does not believe that it would have had a significant effect on the availablity of cabs. He added that he did not believe any economic incentive, including the fare increase just approved, would solve the problem as long as there was a limited number of medallion cabs in the city.
The need for more yellow cabs was shown in the last few years by the large rise in the number of unlicensed ''gypsy cabs,'' which cruise the city streets illegally in search of passengers, and licensed radio-car services, which are permitted to pick up passengers who call a central dispatcher, he said.
In September, Mr. Lusk voted for a proposal to issue 400 new taxi medallions. But the plan was defeated by the commission after opposition from the taxi industry, which argued that the new yellow cabs would increase pollution and traffic congestion.
 
Like Airlines on Holidays
Ronald Stoppelman, president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, a fleet owners group that represents about 1,700 cabs, said he did not consider increasing the number of medallions a realistic solution.
''Even if there were 25,000 cabs, you can never supply the demand during rush hour, just as you can't get an airline reservation for a holiday weekend,'' he said.
Rather than try to have more cabs, the city should concentrate on ways to attract more drivers to the industry, Mr. Stoppelman said. A shortage of drivers already idles an average of 1,200 cabs a day, he said.
Mr. Lusk said medallion owners could get more cabs on the road simply by lowering the rates they charge drivers to lease their cars. But the owners make more money by maintaining the current number of drivers at the prevailing lease rates, he said.
Another possible way to reduce the rush-hour shortage of cabs may be to alter the time when taxi fleets change shifts. At 4 P.M., as many as 4,000 cabs go out of service for 20 to 60 minutes to change drivers and get fuel. The timing allows drivers working the day and night shifts, each of which lasts 12 hours, to share in the potentially profitable rush hours.
Mr. Stoppelman said the fleets were ''strenuously studying'' a proposal to start the night shift at 3 P.M. He said such a plan would probably be opposed because few drivers would want to start the day shift at 3 A.M.
The fleets also support proposals that encourage group rides. Although group-ride programs at the airports seem to be working, other tests have not fared as well and the city does not seem willing to pay for the necessary dispatchers, Mr. Stoppelman said. A new group-ride project on the Upper East Side is to start in January, Mr. Lusk said. Perception or Reality? The city's Transportation Commissioner, Ross Sandler, said that while he supported efforts to improve the availability of cabs at rush hour, he believed that the problem may be more a matter of perception than reality.
''Whenever studies are done, they show that the wait for a taxi is quite short,'' said Mr. Sandler, who is also a member of the Taxi Commission. ''In fact, it takes longer to get a car out of a garage than it does to get a cab, even when the theater has just let out.''
The perception that taxis are hard to come by is fed by the uncertainty and competition involved in hailing a cab, Mr. Sandler said. ''The time spent waiting for a cab is probably more anxiety provoking than getting in a car or taking mass transit,'' he said.
The city should not even try to solve the taxi shortage, said Alan B. Decker, a spokesman for the Minifleet Association. Minifleets, which each own two or three cabs, control about 5,000 of the city's taxi medallions.
''Do we really want more cabs available at rush hour, when the existing number can't move because it's so congested?'' Mr. Decker asked. ''The only way to move people during rush hour is to improve the mass-transit system.''

HEADLINE: The Malta Summit;
ECONOMIC PLEDGES CHEER SOVIET AIDES

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Pleased Soviet officials said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had achieved his major goal at the summit meeting: a critically needed turn away from economic cold war by President Bush.
While much of the focus at the meeting remained on arms control and personal relations between the leaders, Mr. Gorbachev's most pressing need was to finally bring home some hope for long-suffering Soviet consumers.
Mr. Bush accommodated him with proposals to move toward ending 15-year-old trade restrictions and to help the Soviet Union join the world trade community. Even more helpful, in the Soviet view, Mr. Bush was more explicit in inviting ''a climate in which American businessmen can help in what Chairman Gorbachev is trying to do with reform.'' 
''George Bush has in essence declared that Washington has stopped economic warfare against the Soviet Union,'' said Georgi A. Arbatov, the director of Moscow's Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada.
 
Gorbachev Seems Relieved
It was with an air close to relief that Mr. Gorbachev underlined this change at their joint news conference, praising this summit meeting over previous ones for delivering a ''political impetus which was lacking for our economic cooperation to gain momentum.''
''These are of principal importance,'' the Soviet leader said. President Bush described the economic discussions as ''an extraordinarily big plus'' and ''one of the most fruitful parts of our discussions.''
Mr. Arbatov in particular hailed the American President's proposal to help the Soviet Union take a step toward joining the world economic market by assuming observer status at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 97-nation organization that sets world regulations on fair trade.
 
Joining the Major Clubs
''This will prove that the Soviet Union is becoming a full-fledged partner in world economic affairs,'' Mr. Arbatov declared. He said the Soviet Union hoped eventually to attain full membership in GATT, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Mr. Bush also touched on another Soviet goal, most-favored-nation status in trade relations with the United States.
He proposed immediate negotiations toward lifting the restriction imposed by the Jackson-Vanik trade amendment once the Soviet Union codifies into law its liberalized emigration policy. The amendment bars most-favored-nation status for Communist countries that severely restrict emigration.
 
Many Admirers but No Soap
Soviet officials concede that while Mr. Gorbachev has won enthusiastic praise worldwide for his tireless diplomatic initiatives, his celebrity has yet to translate into something tangible for his nation's poorly stocked retail stores.
Before the Malta meeting, American diplomats singled out this shortcoming. An official suggested that one way that Mr. Bush could certainly bolster relations was by raising such unsensational topics as the current United States ban on credit guarantees for American investors interested in the Soviet Union.
This Mr. Bush did, proposing that an end to the ban be studied. This suggestion and others may prove as valuable to Mr. Gorbachev in symbolism as in substance.
President Bush's proposals did not neglect the enormous economic problems that face the Soviet Union even it receives outside help. He urged Moscow to begin moving toward the traumatic step of creating a free market for wholesale goods.
Top Soviet economists have been wrestling with such problems, with little positive effect. Although Mr. Bush's proposal was of no concrete help, Soviet officials welcomed the simple fact that the meeting addressed their economic crisis at all.
''Finally the Americans have come here with something,'' Mr. Arbatov said.

LENGTH: 1421 words

HEADLINE: As Inner-City Areas Decay, Blacks Flee to Small Towns

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Life in the inner city has become so bleak that a growing number of poor blacks are fleeing to smaller cities, towns and suburbs in search of opportunity or, at least, safety.
Althea Harris, a young mother on welfare, left the South Side of Chicago for Kenosha, Wis., where she and her five children lived for months without furniture, even a bed. They slept on the floor wrapped in blankets.
Even at its worst, she said, life in Wisconsin has been better than in Chicago, where a man had offered one of her sons $5 to deliver ''a little package of something.'' The boy was five years old. 
The grandchildren of Delores Long cried in fear about the rats that had chewed all the way through the back of the couch in their ramshackle Chicago apartment. But they stayed until a gang of young toughs knocked Mrs. Long aside one day last winter and stole her Social Security money. Mrs. Long, her daughter and six grandchildren moved to Three Rivers, Mich., where her daughter was able to find a job for the first time.
As for Orbbia Williams, whose family lived in a housing project on the city's West Side, the continual gunfire and the fear that the shots might come closer one day persuaded him to move to suburban Schiller Park.
The exodus illustrates the further collapse of poor neighborhoods in cities like Chicago, Detroit and New York City. Professional and middle-class black people began leaving the neighborhoods some 20 years ago, and they have become virtual prisons of poverty, ruled by gangs and ridden with drugs. The poor people who are leaving see moving as more an escape than a migration.
''We came to Chicago because it was the place where things would be better,'' said Mrs. Long, who moved to the city from rural Louisiana 51 years ago. ''But it's a different place now.'' Experts on poverty concede that it is difficult to measure the size or permanence of the exodus. And they acknowledge that the number of poor people fleeing the inner city remains very small compared to those who choose to stay or cannot leave. But they say anecdotal evidence clearly suggests that migration is accelerating.
 
A Sharp Increase in Migration
''I think we would find that there has been a sharp increase in out-migration of poor people from inner-city neighborhoods,'' said William Julius Wilson, a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago. ''People are leaving because there are no opportunities left there. And they're leaving because it's not safe.''
James P. Shenton, a professor of history at Columbia University, said: ''As conditions in the inner city worsen, the very people who could make a difference are leaving. They are abandoning any notion that they can make a difference. It reinforces the process of disintegration of those neighborhoods.''
The blacks living in the inner city are different from their counterparts in earlier years and from poor whites, Dr. Wilson says, because the poor blacks are increasingly concentrated in urban enclaves with acute social and economic problems.
As the Chicago metropolitan area's economy changed from manufacturing, it moved away from areas where blacks lived, widening the gap between blacks and other metropolitan residents, he said. By 1980, the median family income in two black areas of Chicago had dropped to one-third the city's average from two-thirds 30 years before in one section and to one-half the average from nearly being equal 30 years earlier in the other.
The new migrants usually leave the depressed inner city areas for a smaller city or town with an established black community, often taking shelter, at least initially, with friends or relatives there. While one of the first stops for the newcomers is often the local welfare office, many find greater opportunities for employment in their new hometowns.
Mrs. Long's daughter, Anita, a 23-year-old mother of two who had never held a full-time job, now works the second shift as an aide at a nursing home in Three Rivers. Mr. Williams has found enough odd jobs at carpentry to pay the bills. And Ms. Harris, a high school dropout who had lived on welfare for years, proudly tells of her recent job promotion at a clothing store, saying, ''I'm now the second assistant manager.''
The influx of poor people into these communities is often greeted with a measure of apprehension. Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, concerned that his state is becoming ''a welfare magnet,'' has urged the Legislature to consider reducing benefits for newcomers.
The Wisconsin Policy Institute, a conservative research organization, has estimated that the migration of poor people from Chicago is costing Wisconsin about $129 million a year in benefits and services, but liberal critics say that estimate is too high. In the last three years, more than 21,000 families who came from other states were added to the Wisconsin welfare rolls, nearly 30 percent of all new welfare cases in the state, according to a study by the institute. And the migration is growing each year, the institute says.
 
Small Towns Can Work Better
But Paul Voss, a demographer at the University of Wisconsin at Madison who has studied the influx of poor Chicagoans, said welfare ranks low among the reasons that motivate poor people to move.
''Over and over again, we heard from these people about the desire to get away from the harsh environment of the inner city,'' Dr. Voss said. ''They wanted to find a better school, a setting where there were fewer drugs and fewer chances to get entangled with the gangs.''
In some ways, smaller communities are better equipped to deal with the poor, since the ratio of impoverished people to the more affluent is so much smaller. In Kenosha, about 35 miles south of Milwaukee, many poor families are adopted and given presents at Christmas by a prosperous family.
''When the scale is small, people feel like they can have a direct impact,'' said Rick Rhey, who runs a community center for the poor in Kenosha. ''In big cities, people might not do as much for them because it's just a drop in the bucket.''
For the newcomers, who often arrive with little education, skill or money, the move requires no little courage. They must adapt to drastic changes, including those in the pace of life and the style of clothes. The children usually enter schools to find they lag far behind. And after living in all-black neighborhoods, the newcomers suddenly become a distinct minority.
''It was so hard,'' said Ms. Harris, her eyes filling with tears. ''There were times I thought about killing myself.''
There is, for example, the occasional racial taunt. Mrs. Long said a racial slur was directed at her by an elderly white man in the nursing home where she works. And Ms. Harris said one customer in her store refused to believe she was the manager, asking, ''Since when did they start making you people managers?''
Even so, the families say they found more acceptance than they expected. And they say that over all life has brightened considerably, especially their hopes for their children.
Mrs. Long's grandchildren now get tutorial help after school through a program called ''We Care.'' And Ms. Harris's children have joined the 4-H club in Kenosha and have taken such an interest in reading that the mother sees lawyers and doctors in the family's future.
Mrs. Long's grandchildren no longer have to worry about rats. Their modest frame house in Three Rivers, which is in the western part of the state about 20 miles south of Kalamazoo, rents for about $300 a month. That is no more than they were paying for their apartment in Chicago. And while 14-year-old Rita, like small-town teen-agers across America, complains that life is awfully boring, she takes her grandmother's word that she is better off.
Demographers say it is unclear if the migration of blacks from major cities will continue to grow. Much of it depends on the success of those who are making the move.
''As long as word gets back to a neighborhood that there's a place out there that offers a better opportunity,'' Dr. Wilson said, ''the poor will be willing to give it a try.''
After two years in Wisconsin, Ms. Harris said her children do not like returning to visit their old neighborhood in Chicago, where the sight of gangs and the sound of sirens frighten them.
''Our relatives in Chicago tease my kids because they say they talk like white people,'' Ms. Harris said. ''But you know what? They see how we're doing. And now they're thinking about moving up here.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 4, 1989

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 5; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 904 words

HEADLINE: Edberg Captures The Masters

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
After a bridesmaid's season in which he had twice been the runner-up in Grand Slam tournaments, a beaming Stefan Edberg was only too thrilled to get a grip on the flower-filled Tiffany trophy that pronounced him the champion of the 1989 Masters, the last event of tennis's year and the last run of the tournament at Madison Square Garden.
It was, for Edberg, a whirlwind of a weekend, during which he knocked down the top two players in the world: Ivan Lendl, a five-time Masters champion, and Boris Becker, the defending Masters champion.
Those victories were the only tonic he could imagine that would restore a self-image that had suffered this year as he gained a reputation for making progress to tournament finals only to crumble. Until he defeated Becker in four sets yesterday, Edberg's record in 1989 finals was a discouraging 1-6, and he had failed in five consecutive finals. 
More than any other player here, Edberg seemed sincere when he conceded, before the Masters began and after the tournament was over, that he had not only wanted to win the tournament; he needed to.
''I've been waiting for this one,'' said Edberg. ''It's something I really needed. I'm going to start believing in myself, and that's something I needed to do, because I know I've got the game and the talent to challenge for the No. 1 spot.''
Edberg, an even-tempered Swede who has been No. 3 in the world since last spring, followed his defeat of Lendl in two close sets in the semifinals Saturday with a 4-6, 7-6, 6-3, 6-1 dethroning of Becker, in a 3-hour-2-minute match yesterday afternoon.
''It's not the easiest thing in the world to beat Lendl or Becker on two consecutive days,'' said Edberg, who prefers an understated approach in his analysis of matches but could not help being bowled over by his achievement here. ''I played the best tennis of my life in those two days.''
 
Fadeout After First Set
Becker, whose banner year included two Grand Slam titles - Wimbledon and the United States Open -attributed his deflation as the match wore on yesterday to a simple case of burnout. After he had won the first set easily and come within a point of claiming the second-set tie breaker, Becker's resolve, usually omnipresent, vanished.
''I was getting tired physically and mentally,'' he said. ''Not many people understand how close a match can be. One set, and if I make that shot in the tie breaker, it's an easy three-set win for me. But sometimes I'm just empty. I'm exhausted, and that's the bottom line.''
Becker had needed to resort to acrobatics to force the second set to the tie breaker in the first place, saving himself from Edberg's well-aimed backhand pass at a break and a set point with a somersaulting backhand volley at the net.
 
Fateful Forehand Pass
He pumped his fist after two strong serves put him up, 6 points to 5, in the tie breaker, but lost his edge when Edberg, who had double-faulted twice at the start of the tie breaker, presented him with a service winner, then an ace, to take a 7-6 advantage.
Edberg won the tie breaker, 8-6, by returning Becker's second serve with a swift and unretrievable forehand pass.
''After I took the second set, I could see his serve breaking down,'' said Edberg, whose play, with the exception of a single game in the third set, only grew steadier. Consistency, from the back court and at the net and eventually on his serve, again paid off for Edberg.
Becker briefly made as if to run away with the third set, where he broke an angry Edberg to take a 2-0 lead. But after changing from a worn-out racquet to a fresher one, he was broken by Edberg. That left him fuming for the rest of the match, in which he won only 2 of the last 13 games.
 
Beginning of the End
The new racquet did not survive for long: Becker stalked away and smashed it after the third game of that set.
''I picked out a bad one,'' he said, ''and the racquet is now gone.''
In the final set, Becker progressively unraveled, raising his eyebrows at his own mistakes and raising them in grudging surprise as Edberg calmly splattered his passing shots off the side lines and laced his netside volleys with a geometry the West German could not solve.
Becker double-faulted three times in the course of losing his serve in the fourth game. When Edberg smashed an overhead to the court's hinterlands to go up by 4-1, he clenched his fist in an uncharacteristic display of bravado.
With careful, classic ground strokes, Edberg broke Becker to take a 5-1 lead. Then, serving for the match, he did not allow Becker a single point, ending the contest with a sharp backhand volley into a court his opponent did not bother to guard.
 
Big Plans for '90
Edberg was so excited about celebrating with his longtime coach, Tony Pickard, that he nearly forgot to shake hands with Becker.
Becker, acknowledged by all of his peers, but not by the computer, as 1989's finest player, said later that he expected either Edberg or himself to take the No. 1 spot away from Lendl in 1990.
''If we stay healthy and play long enough, I think it's definitely the case one of us will be the next No. 1,'' said Becker, who has a rematch with Edberg in two weeks when the two compete in the Davis Cup final in Stuttgart, West Germany.
''Now I'm kind of the unofficial No. 1,'' Becker said. ''To have it written down on paper that I'm No. 1 and Lendl No. 2: that I would like to see.''
