HEADLINE: The Malta Summit;
Transcript of the Bush-Gorbachev News Conference in Malta

DATELINE: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference today, the opening minute of which was not recorded. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, also responded to questions during the session. The transcript was provided to The New York Times by the Federal News Service.
 
A Better Understanding
A. . . . All the problems that have existed over the years between Western Europe and the rest of the NATO allies and Eastern Europe. But I understand better where he's coming from, and that, I think, is very important. And he understands our priorities. He understands the concerns, for example, that I feel about Central America, because we really had a good, frank discussion.
 
NATO and the Cold War
Q. But if I can follow up on this goal, as I say, you set for yourself, at least toward movings towards an end to the cold war. He said an epic has ended. How do you feel about that? 
A. I think this is a major step towards understanding and towards any - in trying to tear down any remaining barriers that shot up because of the cold war. There's no question that the conditions today are far different than at the depths of the cold war. No question about it. I haven't even heard anybody argue to the contrary.
Q. Mr. President, what do you think of NATO and Warsaw Pact evolving to political organizations and really moving out of a military mode?
A. Well, if we make the progress that I hope we'll make on various arms-control items and if tensions continue to go down, as they have, inside the Soviet Union and in terms of relations with the United States and Eastern Europe, who knows where the change will take us. But obviously, I have a certain responsibility for keeping NATO strong, and nothing here has altered that desire. But as you see the historical changes taking place, I think it's fine to envision a group of countries that spend a lot more time worrying about the economic side and less on the defense side. We are not there yet. We are not there.
Q. What are you going to tell --
Q. Mr. President --
Q. The NATO -- what are you going to tell the NATO leaders?
A. This is a follow up.
Q. What will you tell the NATO leaders?
A. Well, I'll wait until I get there to decide that. I'll give them a pretty good report on what went on in considerable detail - not all necessarily, because some relates to the U.S.-Soviet equation. But we'll have a good, frank discussion, and I think they will be pleased at what the results of the meeting are.
 
Tenor of the Talks
Q. Mr. President, other than the weather, were there any disappointments? You seem to still be at odds, very much so, on Central America. And was there anything Mr. Gorbachev told you that especially surprised or pleased you?
A. No, no surprises. And, I - but as I say, Michael, we cannot in, you know, 10 hours of discussion or whatever it is, solve all the problems that exist between the United States and the Soviet Union, and the way we look at different areas. But, it's - it would be euphorically optimistic to think that a meeting like this would solve all those problems. But it's better, we understand more. I've got some areas where I can now go back to him, various areas. But there were no surprises. It was a wide discussion - I'm not sure we left out any subjects in a geopolitical sense, but we covered a lot of them.
Q. How long --
Q. Disappointments - no specific disappointments? Something you wish he was more forthcoming on?
A. No particular disappointments, no.
Q. Mr. President --
A. Because I think the - I think the goal now is to go forward, as we have wanted to anyway, and demonstrate everybody's commitment to C.F.E. talks, everybody's commitment to chemical-weapons reductions, eventual elimination, and of course, the Start agenda.
 
Gauging Gorbachev
Q. Do you think that the --
Q. Mr. President, you talked about --
A. I'll be over, Terry.
Q. . . . now having a better understanding of Mr. Gorbachev after this meeting. Could you tell us what you know about him today, or understand about him today --
A. Well, I know that he's perfectly willing to have very frank discussions, even if I'm on the opposite side of a question from him. There was no anger, there was no vitriol. It was a very constructive set of meetings in that regard.
And so, I saw a man who is confident. I saw a man who was calm in our - in his presentations, and responded as factually as he could in some of the questions I raised. And so, I am convinced that the concept of getting together for a no-agenda meeting was very, very sound.
 
U.S.-Soviet Relations
Q. Do you think that the United States and the Soviet Union now are dealing with each other more as allies than adversaries?
A. I wouldn't say allies, but with far less misunderstanding, and with far more common goals.
Q. What do you think of the adversarial relationship, of the nature of the relationship now?
A. Well, I say - as I say I think it's vastly improved, tensions reduced - not eliminated but reduced. We still have different ways of looking at certain questions, and - but I think the answer is improved. Terry?
 
Flight 103 and Terrorism
Q. Mr. President, relatives of Pan Am 103 bombing were going to have a ceremony in the harbor today, drop flowers into the harbor as part of their attempt to have both you and Mr. Gorbachev work together in fighting international terrorism. Did this come up -
A. Yes.
Q. Specifically this weekend? Did you talk a little bit about it?
A. Not 103 per se, but you're talking about anti-international terror. Yes, it did, and also in the anti-narcotics efforts. So there's more we can do. We didn't discuss it specifically, but I'm thinking about certain kinds of intelligence interchange that can prove to be beneficial.
Q. What was the conversation he was referring to on Governors Island in the car?
Q. In the car.
A. No, no. The car was in Washington. You remember when we rode from the embassy over to -- (inaudible)
. . . perestroika failed, and that it wasn't going to fail, and it is irreversible. And I told him back then that I didn't think there were any serious elements in the United States that wanted to see perestroika fail. So that's probably what he was alluding to. I missed that part of it.
 
Soviet Role in Cuba
Q. Secretary Baker, before he came out here a couple weeks ago, said that the Soviet role in Cuba and Central America was the primary obstacle to a more beneficial full-scale relationship between the two countries. You agree - now you disagreed here, but did you advance the issue at all? Can you say -
A. I don't know we advanced it, but I was very, very clear in telling him how strongly I feel about that, and it did build on what Jim Baker had talked to Shevardnadze about out in Wyoming. So there is no doubt in their minds that their assistance to Cuba and their lip service for the Sandinistas give us a considerable amount of difference with them. I mean, so it's very clear - well, until we see a free Cuba, self-determination and the people deciding what they want, Cuba will stick out until that date, as a tiny country, but swimming against Mr. Gorbachev's own tide. And I made that point to him, and --
Q. How did he respond to that?
A. Well, I'll let you ask him first chance you get.
 
Arms Control
Q. Can I ask you a question on arms control? Did I understand President Gorbachev to say that you hope to have a framework agreement in late June, but not an actual Start Treaty?
A. I think we should shoot for a Start Treaty. I'm advised by some of the pros that that's complicated. But look, I think we ought to go forward and try to get a Start agreement. And I think there - I think most everybody would like to see that happen. I don't see any resistance to it, but we've got some technical problems involved, that - let the experts discuss, not me.
So I don't - if he said that there wouldn't be - I mean, if the implication that you got was there won't be a Start Treaty in the summer of '90, I didn't get that feeling from him. Now --
Q. So that you still think it's entirely possible or --
A. I think it's possible, but we have to drive the system.
Q. Is it likely?
A. I - it's hard to, hard to quantify my feeling on that one. But I don't - I really don't see a reason why it can't happen.
 
'Star Wars'
Q. What about S.D.I. in that context? Did you talk about S.D.I.?
A. Just a wide array, you can just be sure that defensive was talked about as well as offensive, as rockets as well as people. It was a wide, wide array of discussion on that general - yeah.
 
Troop Reductions
Q. Was the procedure for troop cuts beyond C.F.E.-1 discussed?.
A. Yes, he is very much interested in seeing troop cuts beyond C.F.E. He knows I'm part of an alliance and not going to go off on some unilateral tack on that. But I think in fairness to the man, he did - he did raise that. But I think we both agree that the immediate goal is to push the system on both sides so we can get a C.F.E. agreement. And back to Terry's question, I think that's entirely possible. It should be, and we're going to - I'm going to be driving our bureaucracy and discussing it at NATO, because I think it's a very important step.
 
Military Budget Cuts
Q. Well, in that respect are you going to cut the defense budget?
A. Not in that respect.
Q. Well --
A. We've already cut the defense budget.
Q. (inaudible) . . . Cheney certainly has been talking a lot about --
A. Listen, he's doing exactly what I want him to do - go back and question and see how things can be restructured. And if there is a way to prudently save money and not weaken the common defense of NATO or not weaken the defense - the ability of the United States to protect our friends around the world, fine. That would be acceptable to me. But we're simply not going to go out there and make draconian cuts in defense so I can solve this Gramm-Rudman problem.
 
The Kremlin and War
Q. Well do you believe him when he says he won't start a hot war?
A. I - I think he has no intention of starting a hot war. You mean - where he said - attacking the United States' interests?
Q. Well --
A. What - how did he phrase it? It was something like that.
Q. A hot war against the United States.
A. Yeah, - I have no - I have no evidence that there is anything other than the truth in that statement.
Q. May I ask --
FITZWATER: We're going to have to go. We'll give Frank a final one here --
Q. Just some person thoughts, coming here after all the preparation and some criticism of being --
BUSH: Yeah --
Q. (inaudible) . . . too timid or --
A. Wasn't that interesting - let me interrupt once to editorialize - wasn't it interesting the way he used the word caution, and I didn't put him up to it either. But go ahead.
FITZWATER: He said prudent at one time, too.
BUSH: Go ahead.
 
Meeting's Personal Side
Q. What was it - what was it like for you, what did it feel like sitting across from this man and in many ways discussing the shape of a world that cannot -- (inaudible)
A. Well inasmuch as I'd met him before and had a couple of private conversations with him before, it was probably less formidable than if I'd never, never met him. And given the changes that he's advocating in terms of, you know, self-determination and an Eastern Europe changing without any threat of force from them, the climate was easier because of those things.
But there still was, you know, a recognition on my part, one, that this was serious business, and two, that we have got to find ways to work for peace constructively. And sitting across the table from me was a person that can have as much to say about that as any other individual in the world, given the superpower defense status of both countries.
So there was a feeling of - there was a recognition that this was important, and yet the climate in the meeting - the climate in the meetings was without rancor and without hostility. I remember a time when I first met Mr. Gorbachev and we talked about human rights and he became visibly agitated with me for raising it.
And I think there's been a great evolution in his thinking on that question, and certainly in his relations with the United States, just as there has been an evolution on my thinking. You may remember I was the one who was against the very kind of meeting that I decided was necessary, because I think as these changes take place, this kind of meeting can be helpful.
So it was - the emotional part of it, Frank, is hard to describe for me because I'm not the most articulate emotionalist. But I just can't have asked for a better ambiance, a better feel from the meetings, even though the differences are acute in some areas.
 
The Emotional Side
But you get the feeling he really wants to work with us, and he knows that I'm cautious, and you heard him talk and use the word prudent. I'm sure that was deliberate on his part. I do think this, that six months ago, there was probably a misunderstanding on his part about the intentions of this new President.
And I think one of the good things is, I don't think he has any feeling that I'm going to be unforthcoming in situations where I should be. I don't think he has me down as a total negativist at all. And I certainly don't have him down and as I see the reception he gets in Italy, I can talk to him about why that emotional response, his identity with change.
So, back to the personal side, the events helped. His own personality helped. I'd like to think he thought I knew what I was talking about. And so we have a good exchange without having to go to the experts or go to the notebooks and it worked. And now we've got to move - now we've got to move forward and I think we can in a lot of ways. I think we can on the economic front. I'm convinced we can and must on the arms-control front.
 
Bush's Report to the U.S.
Q. You go before NATO tomorrow. How are you going to report to the American people --
A. I don't know whether we're having a -we may well have a press conference when we get back.
FITZWATER: At an unspecified time.
BUSH: That's the best way to do it.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Chrysler Loses Industry Rhythm

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
''THERE are rhythms in the auto industry, and Chrysler is out of sync with them today,'' says Raymond Vernon, a Harvard Business School professor. The current rhythm rewards the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company because they have big operations in Europe, where profits are easier to come by than in the United States. The Chrysler Corporation's European sales are minuscule, and that shortcoming endangers the company.
Chrysler executives are turning somersaults trying to correct the situation. Their strategy is to export mini-vans and jeeps, Chrysler's most popular vehicles, and supplement exports with limited manufacturing abroad soon. ''We consider it absolutely critical to be established in Europe in a meaningful way,'' said Michael N. Hammes, vice president for international operations. 
Chrysler once had European factories but sold them in the late 1970's, concentrating sales ever since in the United States and Canada. Now Chrysler has become a grand test of whether an American car maker can prosper without a large European-based operation.
G.M. and Ford each sell more than 1.2 million vehicles in the European Community, all manufactured there, and representing 24 percent of total European sales. Chrysler, by contrast will export 50,000 units to Europe this year, up from zero in 1987. And even under the best of conditions, sales in Europe will probably not exceed 200,000 jeeps, mini-vans and cars during the next three years, Mr. Hammes said.
Such limited sales handicap Chrysler, the reason being Professor Vernon's rhythms. New auto plants, mostly Japanese-financed, are proliferating in the United States just as the economy and auto sales are weakening. The upshot is too much supply, and in the competition for domestic sales, prices are being driven down, along with profits. Most of Europe, on the other hand, is thriving, and Europeans are buying almost as many vehicles as Americans. What's more, demand is outrunning supply, bolstering prices. That's partly because protectionist rules limit Japan's access to Europe.
The European advantage showed up in G.M.'s and Ford's third-quarter earnings. Both companies lost money on their North American operations, but handsome European profits more than offset the losses. Chrysler also lost money in North America, and only a one-time windfall kept the company in the black: the sale of half its stake in the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation for $309 million.
Ask auto industry experts - and Chrysler executives - what the company must do to survive through the 1990's, and they cite two requirements, both involving Europe indirectly.
One is to develop models that will be popular in the 1990's, a costly process. ''We need enough revenue from Europe so that we don't have to cut back on product development,'' W. Van Bussman, a Chrysler economist, said. ''It's an insurance policy.''
The other requirement is to sell enough American-made cars, here and in Europe, so that Chrysler can increase production at its North American factories, now operating below capacity. The more the plants produce, the lower the cost of each vehicle. A few years ago, Chrysler had brought unit costs down very low, and was often able to underprice G.M. and Ford and still make a profit. But Chrysler lost the advantage after purchasing American Motors, with its less efficient factories.
Chrysler should be able to squeeze 300,000 more vehicles a year from its American and Canadian plants, said John Hammond of J. D. Power & Associates, a consulting firm. But to sell that many more cars, exports to Europe will have to be stepped up, he added.
Mr. Hammes of Chrysler agrees. He says the full-capacity goal can be achieved if 75,000 cars and trucks can be exported annually to Europe, along with American-made axles and engines. These will go into a small new jeep to be made at a factory in Spain or Portugal. Chrysler and Renault will own the operation jointly, turning out nearly 100,000 of the jeeps by the mid-1990's.
But a strategy that relies so heavily on exports carries with it a guaranteed ceiling on European sales, Mr. Hammes said. ''To have most of our costs in dollars and then to sell in European currencies is too great a risk,'' he said. If the dollar were to rise sharply in value, Chrysler might have to raise prices abroad, losing sales. A safe export limit is fewer than 100,000 vehicles, he said.
The ideal alternative would be for Chrysler to have factories in Europe, mimicking G.M. and Ford. In Chrysler's case, that is not possible; the company simply lacks the capital to acquire them.
Instead, Chrysler is limited, well into the 1990's, to exports and joint ventures, first with Renault and soon with another European partner, to make perhaps 50,000 mini-vans, Mr. Hammes said.
The policy adds up to small potatoes in European sales. Alone among the Big Three, Chrysler is forced to stake its survival on the American market, a policy that bets heavily on Professor Vernon's auto industry rhythms. From Chrysler's viewpoint, the next rhythm must make American sales more profitable than those in Europe.

HEADLINE: New Medicare Proposal Targets Elderly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The E.T. Answer to Doctor Bills'' (editorial, Oct. 27) fails to identify the real risk associated with expenditure targets, or E.T.'s, an attempt by Congress to ration national health care benefits under Medicare. Since most Medicare beneficiaries are the elderly, expenditure targets are a program to limit health care for the elderly and deserves to be opposed.
There is little doubt that we have a problem with growing health care costs and escalating cumulative Medicare payments to doctors. To focus attempts at correction, it is important to understand the causes:
* Population growth: As the population grows, doctors are called upon to take care of greater numbers of patients. More doctors provide more units of service, thereby generating a larger total bill. 
* An aging population: Medical successes have extended life expectancy. We have more older people in the population. Older people get sick more often and require more medical care. Doctors are called on more often and provide more units of serv-ice for patients of an advanced age.
* Advancing technology: With each year, new treatments are based on improved and more expensive technology, which requires more highly trained personnel to operate. Improved technical training translates into higher personnel payments. Technically skilled physicians command higher fees.
* Inflation: Inflation is an inexorable fact of life and contributes significantly to Medicare expenditure escalation. In most cases, increases in the personal income of physicians have merely reflected changes in the purchasing power of the dollar. Medicare payments to doctors do not translate directly into physician income. The costs of practice, especially the costs of malpractice insurance, have escalated. Also, an indeterminate proportion of the cost of medical care reflects defensive medicine, in which a doctor performs procedures, not because he thinks the patient needs them, but to protect himself in case of lawsuit.
The escalating costs of medical care reflect the successes of modern American medicine. A proper approach to limiting the costs of medical care should focus on the causes. Reduction of the costs of malpractice insurance and reduction of the costs of defensive medicine would provide savings without limiting services for those who need them. It is estimated that in these two areas as much as 15 percent of total physician payments might be saved.
Society has hard decisions to make. Do we ration health care to the elderly? Do we limit use of modern technology? Do we bite the bullet on inflation, at the cost of economic growth? Decisions must be evenhanded so that we don't discriminate against any segment of the population. The aged have made their contribution to our society and now deserve our support.
 
EDWARD A. BRUNNER, M.D.
James E. Eckenhoff Professor
Northwestern U. Medical School
 Chicago, Nov. 3, 1989

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Kemp Homeless Plan Offers Too Little

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Mr. Kemp Faces Up to the Homeless'' (editorial, Nov. 15) could not be further from the mark. Yes, Jack Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and the Bush Administration have proposed a package for single room occupancy that might provide funds for a small fraction of the homeless mentally ill. But $243 million a year spread over the country is a drop in the bucket. 
All the homeless are not mentally ill. Hundreds of thousands in the country are without a decent place to live. Many are part of the structurally unemployed, who have been out of work so long that they are no longer counted. Others have been forced out of rent-controlled, S.R.O. or stabilized apartments in buildings torn down to make way for more luxury housing. Still others are alcoholics or drug addicts who live on the fringe of society. Has Mr. Kemp looked at New York's streets, parks and public transportation system?
The Federal Government must get back into the housing business. Mr. Kemp talks about ''incentivizing'' the private sector to build housing. How much more homelessness will we have to endure before we see that the private sector is not interested in building low- and moderate-income housing - unless developers can realize profits as usual? How many more housing scandals will shock us before we realize that the private sector wants to build more profitable housing for the well-heeled, especially when it is subsidized?
A national program spending $243 million a year for three years will do little to solve the dismal problem of the homeless mentally ill, and almost nothing about the overwhelming homeless problem in our cities. This is not ''a welcome sign of Washington's willingness to help American cities.'' We must see Washington roll up its collective sleeves and start to build housing.
 
RICHARD C. SACHS
New York, Nov. 15, 1989

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Mexican Papers Want To Keep Tie With State

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Something odd has happened to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's effort to reduce the Government's financial influence over Mexico's newspapers.
The newspaper publishers are resisting it.
Indeed, many publishers see the measure as a threat to longstanding business and political arrangements with the state.
Mr. Salinas, in an address to the Inter-American Press Association in October, offered to relinquish the Mexican Government's monopoly on newsprint to remove ''any obstacle to the full exercise of freedom of expression'' here. But the publishers' association responded by unanimously requesting that the company ''remain a public-sector enterprise.'' 
 
Control of the Press
Founded in 1935, the state monopoly, Productora y Importadora de Papel S.A., was originally set up to alleviate publishers' concerns about the scarcity and high price of newsprint. But Pipsa, as the monopoly is known, has frequently been used by the Government to insure its control of the press.
The reluctance of publishers to endorse the end of the long-unprofitable state monopoly is a vivid indication of the trouble that most newspapers and magazines are having in adjusting to changes in Mexico.
Last year's hotly contested presidential election and the emergence of a more competitive political system have led to a growing public dissatisfaction with a press that is widely viewed as corrupt and submissive to the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which has been in power since 1929.
Meanwhile, Mr. Salinas, who took office on Dec. 1, 1988, has carried out an economic program that includes withdrawing subsidies and selling inefficient state-run enterprises.
 
Good and Bad Relations
The newsprint question is important both for economic and political reasons, given that the Mexican Government has been known to limit supplies to publications that offend the state. In 1974, for example, the independent daily El Norte of Monterrey found its newsprint supply cut by 83 percent when Mexico's President, Luis Echeverria, was angered by the paper's news coverage and editorials.
''We have had fairly good relations with this administration and fairly bad relations with some previous administrations,'' said Ramon Alberto Garza, the editorial director of El Norte, which has long pressed for an end to the newsprint monopoly. ''But in a democratic regime, you can't depend on the good will of the President and the head of Pipsa.''
For many newspaper owners, though, the state monopoly offers financial advantages. As the editor of one leading daily acknowledged recently, Pipsa is ''a source of unlimited credit,'' which allows unprofitable newspapers to run up huge bills that are either not collected or heavily discounted.
Critics of the press argue that in return most major daily newspapers refrain from publishing articles that might offend the Ministry of the Interior, which runs Pipsa, or the PRI. In their statement calling for Pipsa to remain in state hands, the publishers denied those accusations.
 
Embarrassing Incident
One week before Mr. Salinas spoke, however, the Mexican press was publicly embarrassed when Manuel Becerra Acosta, the editor of the left-center Mexico City daily Unomasuno until early this year, told a Mexican news magazine that he had agreed to sell his shares in the newspaper and go into exile in Spain in return for a $1 million payment from the Interior Ministry. His troubles began, he said, when the Government demanded that he pay a $2 million debt to Pipsa. He also asserted that the Government now controlled his shares through a prominent business executive with close ties to the PRI.
The Interior Ministry has neither confirmed nor denied Mr. Becerra's account, and the new management of Unomasuno has denied the charges. But the incident further damaged the press's image and also cast doubt on the sincerity of Mr. Salinas's declarations that he wants to promote a strong and independent press.
In practice, the famous dictum about the Mexican press by the former President, Jose Lopez Portillo - ''I don't pay them so that they can beat up on me'' - still seems to be in force. Reporters at several leading newspapers, who asked not to be identified, say that Government ministries, the PRI, labor unions and others continue to pay monthly stipends to deflect unfavorable coverage, and that most reporters accept these bribes, which often total several hundred dollars.
 
Low Salaries for Reporters
What is seen by many here as institutionalized bribery has not been discouraged by many publishers, since it allows them to pay reporters' salaries as little as $150 a month. In addition, many reporters are expected to seek advertising from the state agencies, private companies or political organizations they cover.
The Government is the leading advertiser in newspapers and magazines, supplying some 60 to 80 percent of the revenues of most publications, editors and publishers say. Previous administrations have threatened to withhold advertising to punish publications that step out of line, which has led to editorial timidity.
''Newspaper profitability does not lie in the number of copies sold,'' said Miguel Angel Granados Chapa, an editor at La Jornada, a left-wing daily often critical of the Government. ''On the contrary, it lies in printing the least number of copies, since the main source of income is advertisements, especially Government advertisements, which do not bear any relation to the prestige and/or influence of a given newspaper.''

PUB-DATE: December 5, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1536 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SUMMIT;
BUSH SAYS SOVIETS MERIT WEST'S HELP TO FOSTER REFORM

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 4

 BODY:
President Bush said today that the West should help out President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to show support for the changes taking place in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
At a news conference after meeting the other leaders of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Mr. Bush provided new insights into why he offered economic concessions to the Soviet leader during their two-day weekend meeting in Malta.
Asked why he was now more supportive of Mr. Gorbachev than he had been earlier in the year, Mr. Bush said his ''new thinking'' was based on admiration for the ''the way in which Mr. Gorbachev has handled the changes in Eastern Europe,'' and for his willingness to go along with arms control reductions in which Soviet forces are cut deeper than Western forces. 
 
'Respect for What He's Doing'
''When I hear him talk about peaceful change and the right of countries to choose - countries in the Warsaw Pact to choose - that deserves new thinking,'' Mr. Bush said of the Soviet leader. ''And so I approach this, and I think, in step with our allies, with a certain respect for what he's doing, and thus we want to try to meet him on some of the areas where he needs help. I'm thinking of a few suggestions I had in the economic area.'' [Excerpts, page A16.] But Mr. Bush refused to endorse Mr. Gorbachev's comment on Sunday that the cold war epoch was over.
''Things have moved dramatically'' since the days when the two sides often confronted each other, Mr. Bush said. ''But if I signal to you there's no cold war, then you'll say, 'Well, what are you doing with troops in Europe?' ''
The first commentaries in the Soviet press today on the Malta talks praised the leaders for lowering tensions, advancing the cause of arms control, and endorsing Mr. Gorbachev's course of political change. Yuri Kornilov, political analyst for the news agency Tass, proclaimed the summit meeting ''the most important and most memorable political event of 1989.''
 
Caution on Western Aid
Soviet analysts barely mentioned Mr. Bush's offer of economic cooperation, in part because Moscow is wary of seeming to grovel for Western aid, and in part because it does not want to encourage the popular feeling there that the West can bail out the floundering Soviet economy.
At the news conference, Mr. Bush said he had also assured NATO allies about the continued American determination to keep ''significant'' military forces in Europe, despite any accords that might be reached on cutting conventional forces on the Continent.
He said he and Mr. Gorbachev had not reached any understanding on deeper cuts in each alliance's forces beyond those being discussed at the negotiations taking place in Vienna, which Mr. Bush wants concluded by the end of next year.
''The United States will remain a European power,'' he said. ''And that means that the United States will stay engaged in the future of Europe and in our common defense.''
Asked about the issue of German reunification, the President read a four-point statement that summed up the American position:
''Self-determination must be pursued without prejudice to its outcome, and we should not at this time endorse any particular vision. Secondly, unification should occur in the context of Germany's continued commitment to NATO, an increasingly integrated European Community, and with due regard for the legal role and responsibilities of the Allied powers. Third, in the interest of general European stability, moves toward unification must be peaceful, gradual, and part of a step-by-step basis. And these were - and lastly, on the question of borders, we should reiterate our support for the principles of the Helsinki Final Act.''
The Final Act, a document on European security and human rights, was ratified by 35 nations in 1975, Mr. Bush also said his specific proposal to grant certain economic concessions to the Soviet Union was meant to give Mr. Gorbachev an incentive to maintain the path of liberalization and change in Soviet society.
''There's a tremendous potential for a Soviet Union that is in accord with us on these democratic values,'' he said. ''It's a tremendous market, for example, but it needs the economic reform. So what we've got to do is be sure that we conduct ourselves in such a way that the changes, the political reforms, can keep going forward there in Eastern Europe, that they can - that the Soviet Union can do what Mr. Gorbachev is trying to do internally.''
Mr. Bush also went out of his way to emphasize that no decisions affecting the future of Europe were made during his talks with Mr. Gorbachev. He added that ''our trans-Atlantic partnership'' should play the central role in shaping a new Europe.
The President decided to stop over in Brussels on his way home to Washington after some West European governments expressed fears that the United States and the Soviet Union were seeking to reassert their traditional dominance over Europe at a time of dramatic and unpredictable change in Eastern Europe.
But the initial response of some key Western European leaders to Mr. Bush's report today suggested that he had succeeded in reinforcing a common NATO front on the two key areas of encouraging political change in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and of maintaining a strong alliance.
''Whatever the political nature of the speeches,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said after today's meetings, ''time after time, the need to keep NATO strong and secure came through.''
Describing her response to events in Eastern Europe as optimistic rather than euphoric, she praised Mr. Bush for being ''rightly cautious.''
 
NATO Supports Perestroika
The Secretary General of NATO, Manfred Worner, told reporters that the participating presidents and prime ministers gave ''unanimous support'' to the Soviet Union's program of liberalization, known as perestroika, and stressed the need for ''a common Western approach'' to developments in the Communist bloc.
''It is clear that we will respect - we will continue to respect - Soviet security interests just as we expect them to respect our security interests,'' Mr. Worner said.
Western officials said NATO's European members were also satisfied that while Mr. Bush promised the United States would work toward rapid conclusion of new agreements covering strategic, conventional and chemical weapons, he did not commit the alliance to further disarmament moves.
''I think the best thing to do is to take advantage of the moment and move forward in those three areas,'' Mr. Bush told reporters before returning to Washington tonight. ''We ought to manage that before we start the architecture of something else.''
But while much of Mr. Bush's presentation today was focused on fast-changing East-West relations, the meeting also took place amid growing nervousness in the alliance over how the delicate question of German reunification should be handled.
In Malta, both Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev placed the elimination of the division of Germany in the context of the broader elimination of the division of Europe, in both cases pointedly avoiding any reference to a time period in which this could take place.
Today Mr. Bush returned to the same theme, reiterating NATO's traditional support for the reunification of Germany, but stressing that it should occur ''in the context of Germany's continued commitment to NATO and an increasingly integrated European Community.'' He added that moves toward reunification should be ''peaceful, gradual and part of a step-by-step process.''
 
Kohl Thanks Bush for Support
The West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, told reporters that some adverse reactions to his 10-point reunification plan announced last week had come from people who had not read it. ''The timetable that people talk about has been set by others,'' he said. ''Our timing is embedded in the timing of Europe as a whole.''
After restating his ideas at the NATO meeting, though, the Chancellor acknowledged that ''there are some chiefs of government who harbor some reservation, although I have no intention of giving report card marks.''
Mr. Kohl, who was given a personal briefing by Mr. Bush on the Malta talks over dinner here Sunday, also thanked the President for providing his Government with political support during the current period of change in Europe.
Asked whether he consulted Mr. Bush before announcing his plan for German reunification, Mr. Kohl said: ''Concretely speaking, no. But it was not necessary because it was a reformulation of German positions.''
Significantly, despite recent speculation about possible American troop withdrawals from Western Europe as a result of developments in Eastern Europe, the subject of the allied military presence in West Germany was apparently not debated today.
Rather, Mr. Bush's message was that ''NATO's traditional security mission'' should be maintained since ''the potential for strife is inherent in any period of fundamental political transition.'' He added, ''I pledge today that the United States will maintain significant military forces in Europe as long as our allies desire our presence as part of a common security effort.''

HEADLINE: Manila Embassy Warns Americans

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The United States Embassy today urged Americans living in the Makati area, the financial center of Manila, to leave their homes for safer areas as heavy fighting resumed between Government and rebel forces.
Within hours of the evacuation order, employees of several embassies and their families, along with foreign and Filipino residents of the Makati area, streamed across the city toward Manila Bay.
Families that had not been able to leave their houses for days went to hotels in search of rooms, showers and food.
Rebel soldiers had trapped 2,000 foreigners, including more than 200 Americans, in hotels in Makati. In addition, thousands of residents were trapped in Makati's condominiums, apartments and office buildings. 
Efforts to evacuate the foreigners from the rebel-controlled area appeared to have stalled early today, though both the rebel camp and the Government had issued statements saying that the foreigners would be taken out of the area.
 
U.S. Plea Appears Unheeded
The American evacuation notice, repeated on television throughout the morning, came despite repeated statements by the Philippine Government that it had crushed the coup attempt against the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino. Troops loyal to Mrs. Aquino have surrounded the financial district and the American warning said that ''there is a possibility of increased hostility'' throughout the area.
A Western diplomat said the United States Ambassador, Nicholas Platt, had tried to persuade Mrs. Aquino to hold off on any assault in the Makati area but that she had refused, saying that her mind was made up. Government buses were reported on the way to Makati to evacuate tourists and, at one point, according to residents, rebels in control of apartment buildings urged occupants to move to basements for safety.
More than 2,000 Americans live in the area directly under fire and in the luxurious walled residential neighborhoods that surround it.
Because the rebel force of about 350soldiers is spread among 20 buildings in Makati, Philippine Government forces had held off from any direct attack because of the fear of extensive civilian casualties. But early today there were widespread reports that the Government forces would attempt to route the rebels from the Inter-Continental Hotel, where many Americans and other foreigners have locked themselves in their rooms. ''It's a very dangerous situation,'' one American official said.
 
Gunfire in the Streets
Automatic gunfire echoed through Makati's streets and three to five people were reported killed and more than a dozen wounded. In one instance, rebel soldiers reportedly opened fire on Red Cross workers seeking to get the injured out of the area. One American man was reported injured by flying glass; another was reported wounded by a stray bullet.
Two bombs exploded in the capital late Monday, but it was not known if they were linked to the coup attempt, which began on Friday and has so far killed 100 people and wounded more than 500.
One bomb exploded in the compound of the Central Bank, the equivalent to the Federal Reserve. There were no injuries. A second bomb went off in the tourist belt district of Ermita, damaging a vehicle and shattering windows.
The continued violence came amid heightened criticism here of Mrs. Aquino for drawing American forces into the effort to quell the rebellion. Commentators and newspaper editorials on Monday declared that her reliance on American help proved that Mrs. Aquino is a ''U.S. puppet'' and said that while the brief intervention of United States forces may have saved her presidency it undermined her credibility.
 
Some Normalcy in the City
Some measures of normalcy did return to the city on Monday, however. The main airport in Manila reopened for the first time since the coup attempt, though many flights into the country were canceled by airlines fearful of violence. Domestic flights were indefinitely postponed and schools were closed. But Government employees were told to return to work except in the Makati area.
The main streets were quieter than usual, but a local McDonald's restaurant was filled at dinnertime on Monday and even the shooting in Makati attracted crowds, some of whom numbered among the wounded.
In the last four days, most of the casualties have occurred in Makati and at Camp Aguinaldo, the army's headquarters.
Among those trapped in the office buildings and hotels of Makati were about 200 Americans, 300 Japanese, 70 Germans, and 50 to 100 Canadians, both tourists and business executives. Some were injured in the shootings, mostly by flying glass. ''We're like sitting ducks here,'' said Noemi Balpazar, a Canadian citizen. ''Why doesn't the Government care about us?''
 
Pleading With Rebels
In fact, late Monday the Department of Tourism pleaded with the rebels not to further harm the Philippine economy by continuing the standoff. ''Let us not create further tension among our foreign guests who are not involved in this struggle,'' said Rafael Alunan, who heads the Tourism Department.
The chaos and gunfire has sent Manila's diplomatic community scurrying, but Government officials said they could do little to either free those caught in the crossfire or end the fighting. An Australian man was reported severely wounded and a Taiwanese woman was killed. ''It is not a hostage situation,'' said Jerry Huchel, the spokesman for the United States Embassy. ''They just can't leave.''
In an interview broadcast here on Monday, Capt. Alfred Yen, a leader of the rebel troops, said that foreigners might be allowed to go today. But the fighting, he said, would go on. ''We will hold the line to the last drop of our blood,'' he said.
 
Feeding Criticism of Aquino
Although the rebellion seems likely to fail, the rebels appeared determined to further undercut Mrs. Aquino's authority, feeding criticism that she is weak and indecisive.
Foreign diplomats now say that she had no choice but to turn to the United States for help, and most agree that President Bush's willingness to use American Air Force fighters to quell the rebellion probably saved her Government.
But for Mrs. Aquino the price was high. Even some of her supporters have assailed the involvement of foreign forces in Philippines domestic affairs. Some believe that it will now be harder for her to negotiate a new agreement for American use of bases here without appearing to be repaying Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Embraces Trappings of New Wealth

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Along with the disabled who beg for change in the business district, young American street musicians can be spotted these days performing for the spare change of Chinese executives walking from their gleaming office buildings to their Mercedes-Benzes.
The image of Americans with their hands out, a stark turnabout from the envy that many Chinese here used to feel for American military officers or business executives, is a sign of the explosion of wealth in Taiwan in the last few years. Although Taiwan's economic development progressed steadily over the decades, it has recently became much more obvious. The stock market began an extraordinary boom four years ago that has boosted the value of trading volume to levels exceeding that of the London Stock Exchange. Property prices also have soared, with a plush apartment in Taipei now worth $1 million or more. 
Internationally, Taiwan is wielding more muscle. Its official foreign exchange reserves total $73 billion, a level exceeded only by Japan. Taiwan also has become one of the biggest foreign investors in Asia, and that role is expected to expand.
Because the boom has brought a growing willingness to spend money instead of save, the streets of Taipei are clogged with Mercedes-Benzes and Volvos and Jaguars in addition to the usual motorcycles. Some tycoons have gone in for conspicuous consumption, like $3,000 meals of bear paw.
''We're starting to see the trappings of a consumer society,'' said Peter Kurz, managing director of Baring Securities Ltd. in Taipei.
The rise of the Taiwanese consumer, represented by the luxurious new Sogo Department Store in the city center, is a sharp break with the tradition here and in other Chinese societies of favoring saving over spending. In Taiwan, the savings rate has averaged a stunning 30 percent in recent decades and is one of the reasons for the country's extraordinary economic growth.
The newfound wealth seems to have bred some dissatisfaction, however.
''Per capita incomes have gone up drastically, but the real quality of living did not,'' said Jaw Shaukang, a legislator in the ruling Nationalist Party. ''In fact, in some areas, the quality of life decreased.'' He pointed to traffic congestion, crime, pollution and the rising cost of housing.
The malaise is compounded by a growing disparity in income. After land redistribution in the 1950's, Taiwan had become one of the world's most egalitarian societies. While income is still more evenly distributed than in most countries, the gap has widened over the last five years as a new wealthy class emerged.
''Our per capita income is $7,500 a year; yours is $17,000,'' Fredrick F. Chien, chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development, told an American the other day. ''Ours is less than half the size of yours. But looking at the way people spend money, it seems they are enjoying a higher standard of living even than our American friends.''
The boom in consumption results primarily from the rise in paper assets. Stock prices have risen 10-fold in the last four years, and property prices by nearly the same amount. People with an extra bit of land or with an account at a stock brokerage saw their net worth soar, and salaries skyrocketed in the real estate and investment sectors. A stockbroker may now earn $20,000 a month or more in commissions.
''It's not a sudden wealth,'' said Paul S. P. Hsu, a prominent Taipei lawyer. ''It's an accumulated wealth.'' An average middle-class family gets only half its income from salaries, he said, with the rest coming from bonuses, stock market gains and other investment earnings. With its accumulated savings, Taiwan has a much higher level of assets per capita than a typical economy with the same level of income.
Estimates of Taiwan's income vary. The official per capita estimate was $7,500 this year and is projected at $20,000 by the year 2000. But experts say that real per capita income may already exceed $10,000 because of the tremendous amount of business that for tax reasons is never reported.

HEADLINE: Zaire's Trade With Pretoria Isn't Slowing

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Dec. 4

 BODY:
As the Zairian diplomat poured sparkling wine for a visitor, he made no effort to hide the label, which proclaimed, ''Product of South Africa.''
Dressed in a silk ascot and an elegant abacost, the lapelless suit designed as a Zairian answer to European business dress - its name is a contraction of ''a bas le costume,'' French for ''down with the suit'' - the diplomat said the wine was ''a lot cheaper than imported French champagne, and it's almost as good.''
In much of black-ruled Africa, Pretoria remains a pariah, at least publicly. But in Zaire, trade with South Africa is not only tolerated, but increasingly seems to be officially encouraged. Zairian stores these days are awash with South African goods, from frozen chicken livers to refrigerators, toys and small appliances. Three airlines -TAP, the Portuguese carrier; Sabena, the Belgian line, and U.T.A., a French-owned company, fly frequently between Kinshasa and Johannesburg. 
 
Afrikaans-Subtitled Movies
South African Airways now schedules direct flights to Lubumbashi, the capital of Zaire's mineral-rich southern region. At least two South African trade missions have visited Zaire in recent months, and several South African businessmen are now permanently based here. The Inter-Continental, Kinshasa's premier hotel, shows movies with subtitles in Afrikaans.
Since early November, under the terms of a new agreement, South Africans and Zairians no longer need visas to vist each other's countries for two weeks or less.
''There is a certain tolerance'' for doing business with Pretoria, said Nkema Liloo, a senior adviser to President Mobutu Sese Seko. ''Private businessmen are very aggressive here, and the Government can't stop it.''
Mr. Nkema and other Zairian officials say they have no way of knowing the extent of Zairian business dealings with South Africa, but Western economists here say it has increased markedly in recent years.
According to one estimate, South Africa, which two years ago was not even among Zaire's top 10 trading partners, has risen to No. 4, behind Belgium, the United States and West Germany.
 
Trade and Investment Sought
President Mobutu can use new sources of trade and investment right now. Although his Government is usually described as pro-Western, private investors, particularly from the United States, have long been reluctant to invest in an economy plagued by mismanagement and corruption.
Per capita income in Zaire, which is widely believed to be one of the five poorest countries in the world, is about $150 a year.
Zaire is not South Africa's only trading partner on the continent. African diplomats say that Nigeria, Kenya and Ghana are believed to be the only black-ruled countries that really have virtually no trade or diplomatic contact with Pretoria.
South African officials say openly that economic expansion into the rest of the continent is an integral part of their efforts to gain political acceptability. Nearly one-third of all South African exports of manufactured goods are now flowing north to black-ruled countries in an attempt to forge new ''economic bridgeheads,'' said Kent Durr, South Africa's Minister of Trade, Industry and Tourism, according to an article published earlier this month in South Africa.
''We must look at our neighbors with new eyes.'' Mr. Durr told a business conference.
 
Tie Worries Some Zairians
The relationship worries some Zairians, although there is virtually no public discussion of the issue in a country where news organizations are tightly controlled by the Government.
''It's definitely hypocritical'' to continue trading with South Africa while publicly opposing apartheid, said Bongoma Koni Botoke, a prominent Zairian journalist.
''Sanctions were imposed to get South Africa to change its policies, but that hasn't happened, so we should continue sanctions,'' Mr. Bongoma said.
Zairian officials argue that the trade between the two countries is not propping up apartheid. ''It is not the African countries that are making South Africa richer,'' said Mr. Nkema, the presidental adviser, ''it is the United States and Japan.'' Trade between South Africa and its black-ruled neighbors is a ''drop of water in the ocean,'' he said.
With Woes Behind, Mahorn Focuses on Image Former Piston Aims to Leave an Indelible Impression on the 76ers, His New Team JMP. HED MAHORN 76ers' Mahorn Puts Woes Behind By CLIFTON BROWN PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 - All things considered, Rick Mahorn is glad to be in Philadelphia.
Mahorn spent the off season watching his basketball career turn into a soap opera. And there were many moments when he wondered not only where he would play this season, but even if he wanted to play anymore.
But as Mahorn wheeled his black sports car through the City of Brotherly Love recently, the music on his compact disk player was blaring and Mahorn was smiling.
His troubles were behind him. His thoughts were focused on basketball again, and his most immediate goal was to leave an indelible impression on his newest team: the Philadelphia 76ers.
 
Survival of the Fittest
''Only the strong survive,'' said Mahorn, a 6-foot-10-inch, 252-pound power forward who is nothing if not strong. ''That's the attitude I have, and that's the attitude I'm bringing to Philadelphia.
''I went through a lot this summer, but now that I'm with Philadelphia, the Sixers are my friends and everyone else is the enemy. I'm just glad things worked out the way they did.''
Ironically, Mahorn's off-season problems began immediately after one of the happiest periods of his life. Mahorn helped the Detroit Pistons win their first National Basketball Association championship in June, and his play as the starting power forward was an integral part of their success.
The 31-year-old Mahorn fully expected to finish his career in Detroit. But just two days after the championship game, the Pistons left Mahorn off their list of protected players and he was selected by the Minnesota Timberwolves in the expansion draft.
Mahorn was shocked and hurt. And the timing was brutal, because Mahorn was told he was no longer a member of the Pistons immediately after the championship parade.
 
Never Saw It Coming
''I didn't have a clue they would let me go,'' Mahorn said. ''I had just finished enjoying the celebration, then smack, I was gone.''
Because of Mahorn's history of back problems, the Pistons felt he was more expendable than either James Edwards or Vinnie Johnson. Detroit tried to work out a deal with the Timberwolves to keep them from taking Mahorn, but was unsuccessful. So Mahorn was let go.
From there, things got worse. Mahorn visited Minneapolis, met with the team's management, and said he was genuinely impressed with the new franchise. But before he would play in Minnesota, Mahorn asked to renegotiate his contract. He was in the final year of a contract which paid him $675,000 a season. Mahorn asked for a new three-year deal worth at least $1.5 million a year.
''Minnesota was over $3 million under the salary cap, so why not give some of that money to their marquee player, the starting power forward on a championship team?'' said Alton Walton, Mahorn's agent. ''But Minnesota didn't see it that way. The negotiations got nasty.''
When the Timberwolves refused to renegotiate Mahorn's contract, Mahorn refused to report to training camp. Then he considered retiring. Then Mahorn was offered a contract by the Verona team in the Italian National League.
 
Some Summer Vacation
Mahorn spent a week in Italy, liked what he saw, and was offered a seven-year contract worth a reported $6.5 million. Minnesota threatened to sue Mahorn for breech of contract if he signed with the Italian team.
This was not the kind of summer vacation Mahorn had had in mind.
''It just kept getting worse, Minnesota threatening me, us threatening them,'' Mahorn said. ''Honestly, I would have played in Minnesota for a lot less than I was asking. I had even told my daughter, Moyah, that Minnesota was going to be a nice place for her to grow up. But I couldn't see playing there for far less than what I was worth.''
The stonewalling finally ended Oct. 27, when the Timberwolves traded Mahorn to Philadelphia for a first-round draft choice in 1990 and second-round picks in 1991 and 1992. The 76ers rewrote Mahorn's contract and gave him a new three-year deal worth $3.8 million.
Mahorn is happier and richer, but it hasn't taken the edge off the way he plays basketball. After a month with the 76ers, Mahorn is playing the same hard-nosed basketball that has become his trademark. Among opposing fans and players, Mahorn is one of the league's least-liked players. He couldn't care less.
 
Equipped With a Shoulder Chip
''I go through a personality change when I hit the court,'' Mahorn said. ''I come to games with a chip on my shoulder. If somebody's not wearing the same color jersey I'm wearing, then basically, they're not a friend of mine.''
Over the last three seasons, Mahorn has been involved in as many altercations as any player in the league. He has been fined numerous times, ejected from games and served a one-game suspension two years ago for a flagrant foul against Michael Jordan.
Yet Mahorn's value to a team is unquestioned. He is an excellent defensive player, a capable scorer and his physical, no-nonsense style has been known to intimidate some players.
Since Mahorn joined the starting lineup on Nov. 22, the 76ers are 4-2. Jimmy Lynam, the 76ers' coach, said that is no coincidence.
''Ricky is very, very bright,'' Lynam said. ''He may be the most intelligent defensive player I've been around since I've been in the league. He's a winner and as an opponent, you don't appreciate how good he is.
''I've always liked him, although he wasn't so sure of that when he first came here. He takes a perverse delight in annoying the opposition, and he figured I was mad at him about some things he did against the Sixers in the past. But I wasn't.''
 
Laughing at an Image
Not everyone agrees. When he played with the Washington Bullets, Mahorn and Jeff Ruland were nicknamed McFilthy and McNasty for their tactics. In Detroit, Mahorn was part of The Bad Boys, the moniker given to the Pistons who were unquestionably the league's most physical team.
Mahorn has learned to laugh at his reputation, even if everyone else does not laugh with him.
''What's to be intimidated about with me?'' Mahorn said. ''I put my clothes on the same way everybody else does. Maybe the media hype of Rick Mahorn, the big bad guy, makes people feel that way. I can walk through the streets of a bad neighborhood and people say, 'What's up Rick, how you doing?' I might be scared to death, but they don't know it.
''I get booed everywhere, but those people don't pay my check. I got booed when I went back to Minnesota. I even got booed in Hartford, my hometown. You know it's bad when they boo you in your hometown. But as long as my daughter and my family weren't booing, I didn't care. It used to bother me, because I know I'm not the person they think I am. Now it doesn't. I used to got booed in Philadelphia, too, but now I get cheered.''
 
Philadelphia Pranksters
In Philadelphia, Mahorn is teamed with Charles Barkley, giving Philadelphia the league's strongest pair of starting forwards. Barkley loves having Mahorn for a teammate, not only because of his talent, but because of his sense of humor. Barkley and Mahorn are two of the league's biggest pranksters, and anyone entering the 76ers' locker room does so at their own risk.
''Rick can't fight a lick,'' said Barkley, after grabbing Mahorn in a post-practice bear hug. ''He's living on reputation.
''He's a better player than people think, and he's going to make us better.''
Mahorn already has March 2 circled on his calendar, the night the 76ers will play Detroit at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich., for the first time since Mahorn left.
''It'll feel good to be back, and they're going to have a ceremony to present me with my championship ring,'' Mahorn said. ''The main thing I want to do is to show management they shouldn't have let me go. But no matter what happens, I know I've survived. That's the key. Now I can go back to having some fun again.''
