The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 5, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 3609 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SUMMIT;
Excerpts From Bush's News Conference After NATO Meeting

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Bush's news conference today after his meeting here with leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
This year, the people of the East made fundamental choices about their destiny, and governments there began to honor the citizens' right to choose. What these changes amount to is nothing less than a peaceful revolution. And the task before us, therefore, is to consolidate the fruits of this peaceful revolution and provide the architecture for continued peaceful change, to end the division of Europe and of Germany, to make Europe whole and free.
Great choices are being made, greater opportunities beckon. The political strategy for NATO that we agreed upon last May makes the promotion of greater freedom in the East a basic element of alliance policy. Accordingly, NATO should promote human rights, democracy and reform within Eastern countries as the best means of encouraging reconciliation among the countries of Eastern and Western Europe. 
Although this is a time of great hope - and it is - we must not blur the distinction between promising expectations and present realities. We must remain constant with NATO's traditional security mission. I pledged today that the United States will maintain significant military forces in Europe as long as our allies desire our presence as part of a common defense effort. The U.S. will remain a European power, and that means that the United States will stay engaged in the future of Europe and in our common defense.
Many of the values that should guide Europe's future are described in the Final Act of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. These values encompass the freedom of people to choose their destiny under a rule of law with rulers who are democratically accountable.
I think we can look to the C.S.C.E. to play a greater role in the future of Europe. The 35 nations of the C.S.C.E. bridge both the division of Europe and the Atlantic Ocean. It is a structure that should be able to contribute much to the future architecture of Europe.
I also appreciate the vital role that the E.C. must play in the new Europe. And it is my belief that the events of our times call both for a continued, perhaps even intensified, effort of the 12 to integrate and a role for the E.C. as a magnet that draws the forces of reform toward Eastern Europe. . . .
We stand on the threshold of a new era, and we know that we are contributing to a process of history, driven by the peoples determined to be free. The people of Europe, especially the brave citizens of the East, are illuminating the future, and yet the outcome is not predestined. It depends on our continued strength and our solidarity as an alliance.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
The 'Peace Dividend'
 
Q. Mr. President, I have a two-part question. You have made it clear that you are going stay in Europe. But in view of the dramatic reduction in tensions and the obvious weakening of the Warsaw Pact, what will be the real American role? And two, will there now be more money for the poor and the homeless, public housing? The nation is really badly in need of repair of infrastructure.
 
A. We have a lot of demands at home, and there's no question about that. But I think it is premature to speak, as some are at home, about a ''peace dividend'' - take a lot of money out of defense and put it into other worthy causes. . . . We are under a tremendous burden to get our total spending down in order to meet the Gramm-Rudman and the Gramm-Rudman targets. . . .
 
German Reunification
 
Q. Mr. President, Vernon Walters, your trusted adviser and the Ambassador to Bonn, said that he envisions a - said that Germany, East and West, will be reunited within five years. Do you think that's possible? And what would be the implications for NATO and the Warsaw Pact?
 
A. I am not into the predicting of time on the question of Germany. . . . I think it's better to let things move on their own and without the United States certainly setting some kind of deadline.
 
What Bush Learned
 
Q. Mr. President, you said, in announcing your meeting with Chairman Gorbachev, that one of the main reasons was that you wanted to make sure that, in this time of change, you didn't miss anything. In your two days of meetings, did you learn anything that you fear, or feel, that you might have missed had you not had this?
 
A. Yes. What I would have missed is I wouldn't see quite as clearly his priorities. I see them more clearly because he and I sat down and talked. . . . And I feel I can sense much more clearly the things he feels more strongly about.
And we had a good chance to point out to him some of the difficulties with our relationship. It wasn't all sweetness and light. I had a very - very good opportunity to tell him how we view the - our problems in our own hemisphere: the sending of arms in there to help the F.M.L.N., and the role that - unhelpful role - that Cuba is playing. I recited in detail the Oscar Arias phone call to me: ''Please raise with Mr. Gorbachev the unhelpful role, the destructive role of Cuba.'' . . .
And I think he was pleased, because I think from his standpoint - and this is important from mine - he now sees that we want to have a cooperative, forward-leaning relationship with the Soviet Union.
 
'Decoupling' the NATO Link
 
Q. . . . After World War II, the Europeans needed our money for the Marshall Plan. Then they needed our military backing because of the Soviet threat. But now . . . what are they going to need from us? What role do we really have to play here? We don't live on this continent.
 
A. You mean - would - why will there always have to be a U.S. presence?
 
Q. Why will there always have to be a NATO?
 
A. Well, I'm not sure - I'm - if you want to project out 100 years or--
 
Q. Well, no.
 
A. --take some - take some years off of that, you can look to a utopian day when there might not be. But as I pointed out to them, that day hasn't arrived, and they agree with me. And so the United States must stay involved. What we don't want to do is send the signal of decoupling, the decoupling of the United States and Canada from NATO, particularly at this highly sensitive time, and Mr. Gorbachev understood that.
 
Impressions of Gorbachev
 
Q. Mr. President, you had mentioned that you got some insight into President Gorbachev at this summit. I wonder if the insight included any sense of his internal position. Did he behave as if a man operating from a strong position, a man who seems to be in jeopardy, or how do you feel about that?
 
A. I thought he seemed very much in control. You can tell the way that he interacted with his own top people there. And he felt very confident in discussing . . . a wide array of subjects with me. . . . He seemed - ''subdued'' is the wrong word, but I would say determined and unemotional about it. The most emotion we saw was at that press conference yesterday, but it was a wonderful presentation. And the climate for - leave out the weather - the climate for the discussions was really good. . . .
 
Gorbachev's Views on Germany
 
Q. Mr. President, again as part of the insight you gained, what is your understanding about Secretary General Gorbachev's view of the unification of Germany? Do you think he's as opposed as he's said in public, or do you think that he accepts the fact that--
 
A. I think his view was one of . . . caution, and I really believe that. I think he recognizes the rapidity of change. He has very constructively talked about ''peaceful change,'' and I don't - I think his hope is that people don't try to set up some artificial calendar by which - date by which that reunification should happen. And I think he feels that, if there were outside forces setting dates on something like that, that would complicate the way in which he is managing the change and helping manage the change in the Pact. . . .
 
Troop Reductions
 
Q. Mr. President, there was a lot of speculation going in that you and Mr. Gorbachev might get involved in talking about deeper cuts, particularly in European forces. Did you, in fact, do that? And is there skepticism within this organization here about moving too rapidly beyond what has now been dubbed C.F.E. 1?
 
A. No, we didn't get into that. We talked very broadly about our aspirations for further arms control, but there was no emphasis on that. And I - there may be some strains in one country or another viewing the rapidity of change differently than we do. But what I suggested to our NATO allies is let's go forward with the agreements we've got out there. The C.F.E., let's get it done.
I, the President of the United States, will kick our bureaucracy and push it as fast as I possibly we can. . . . I'm convinced that we -I must do more to keep it on schedule. And I've encouraged the other allies to do the same. I don't think there was any resistance to that. Similarly, Start and chemical weapons.
So before we go into a wide array of other questions, I think the best thing to do is take advantage of the moment and move forward in those three areas. And I - we went - I went over that in little talks with individuals from NATO, as well as in the meeting itself. . . .
 
Q. But do you accept the principle of a C.F.E. 2?
 
A. Well, I'd like to get a C.F.E. 1 in the bank first, get it locked up, get those troops out, move down to equal levels - U.S. and Soviet forces. And so we ought to - we ought to manage that before we start the architecure of something else. I want to see that done on time. . . .
 
East German Instability
 
Q. Mr. President, on East Germany, as you know, the party structure, the Communist Party structure has collapsed there. It's unclear who's running the Government. I wonder if you talked about that, if you personally think that it's a dangerous situation, if that moves unification up in the timetable at all? And secondly, what Gorbachev said to you when you said to him, unification of Germany would have to be in the NATO context?
 
A. No, I don't think it's a dangerous situation. I don't think anybody here in this room, including myself, has been able to predict the rapidity of the change, the totality of the change. But I don't see it as dangerous, as long as the Soviet leader and the Germans and the West conduct themselves the way I've been - been urging.
What was the second part?
 
Q. Well, what Mr. Gorabachev said to you when you said unification, but only in the NATO context? I mean, he keeps saying it has to be in the Warsaw Pact context.
 
A. No, we - we - we were - I don't think we went into that in real depth, Lesley.
 
Q. Well, what do you think he thinks about it? I mean, obviously--
 
A. Well, that's too hypothetical. I got trouble figuring it out on our side with all our experts, rather than knowing what I think he might think about something he hasn't thought about maybe. . . .
 
Bush's New View of Gorbachev
 
Q. Mr. President - Mr. President, you seem to have traveled some distance between what you were saying about Mr. Gorbachev a year or so ago and some of the things you said yesterday. Could you please talk in a little bit more detail about the evolution in your thinking that you mentioned yesterday, how that happened and what persuaded you along the way?
 
A. As I watched the way in which Mr. Gorbachev has handled the changes in Eastern Europe, it deserves new thinking. It absolutely mandates new thinking. And when I see his willingness to give support to a C.F.E. agreement that calls for him to disproportionately reduce his forces, and that is there on the table, I think that mandates new thinking. When I hear him talk about peaceful change and the right of countries to choose -countries in the Warsaw Pact to choose -that deserves new thinking.
And so I approach this, and I think, in step with our allies, with a certain respect for what he's doing, and thus we want to try to meet him on some of the areas where he needs help. I'm thinking of a few suggestions I had in the economic area. But I also believe that the West must remain strong and together and try to be helpful where we can in a united way, but not be imprudent. . . .
 
The Moments of Tension
 
Q. Mr. President, you mentioned earlier that there was some tension during the meetings and earlier, to reporters you had said that there was no personal rancor. Could you outline the moments of tension or tell us a little bit about the moments when you felt there was tension between you and the Soviet leader?
 
A. . . . We have a big difference on how we look at Central America. And I would like to see him use his influence with Mr. Castro, and if he's got any left, with Mr. Ortega, to facilitate democratic change in the Western Hemisphere. . . . So when you get into a subject like that, where he may have a different formula, it's a little more concentrated than when you're clicking off agreements in some areas.
 
Gorbachev and the GATT
 
Q. Mr. President, in the last two weeks of June, Mr. Gorbachev will be in the U.S.A. for the summit. The very beginning of July the G-7 will be meeting in Houston. Now you said in Malta that you wanted to help steward or to help steer the Soviet Union into the global economy. Is there a prospect that Mr. Gorbachev might stay on for the G-7 summit? . . .
 
A. The answer is, I don't think so. Put it this way, two chances: slim and none for that - for that particular meeting. Nor did he request to be included in that particular meeting. But we're in times of rapid change and we'll see how things move forward in terms of having a common subject to discuss.
You see, we've got to - got to understand his dilemma. They have not had a market economy, they have not had the privatization that is - that joins the G-7 together. It's different. And so what I have proposed . . . is that we work with them in observer status in the GATT eventually, as soon as the Uruguay Round is over. Do more for him to do more with O.E.C.D. It is important that not just the Soviet Union but other countries in Eastern Europe understand the market economies, understand the dynamism of the economic systems that join those seven countries. So I don't think it's likely that, you know, that he would hang around Houston waiting for the next meeting. . . .
 
More Swords and Plowshares
 
Q. Mr. President, you stepped aside on a question about the ''peace dividend'' and said that you've got a terrible Gramm-Rudman problem next year. As you look at the changes in Europe and the possibilities of further defense cuts, do you expect any time in your first term to have a dividend, a ''peace dividend'' to apply to some of the economic and social problems at home? And when would you expect that?
 
A. That's an awful tough question to answer about any time. I would think it would be extraordinarily difficult because of the -of the - not only the enormity of the Gramm-Rudman - the difficulty of reaching the Gramm-Rudman target this year, but what follows on. . . . There just isn't a lot of quote excess money unquote floating around there.
 
Q. Not for the foreseeable future, not for the rest of your first term?
 
A. Well, look at the Gramm-Rudman targets that face us. I don't want to hold out to those that want to rush out and spend a lot more money the hope that that is going to happen. We've got some tremendous economic problems that have to be solved. Because the best answer to helping people . . . is to have a job. And the best way to have the climate for a job is to have a sound economy. And to our foreign friends here, I'd say one of the things that would be the best guarantee of that would be to get our Federal deficits down. It would also help us with investment. . . . I had a letter from a distinguished senator before I left, because he had read about possible defense cuts, a reduction in the defense budget, saying take that money and spend it for a cause that he felt was very worthy. And I had to write him back and say, ''Look, that isn't the way it's going to work.'' That isn't the way it's going to work.
 
Q. Chairman Gorbachev said yesterday that you and he agreed in your talks that the world - that the Malta meeting marked the end of the epoch of the Cold War and entering a new period. Do you agree with him that the Cold War is over?
 
A. Carl, let me tell you something. We're fooling with semantics here. I don't want to give you a headline. I've told you the areas where I think we have progress. Why do we resort to these code words that send different signals to different people? I'm not going to answer. I can--
 
Q. (Inaudible)
 
A. Well, good. He can speak for himself very - in a very eloquent way. But in terms of if you want me to define it - is the Cold War the same - I mean, is it raging like it was before in the times of the Berlin Blockade? Absolutely not. Things have moved dramatically. But if I signal to you there's no Cold War, then you'll say, ''Well, what are you doing with troops in Europe?'' I mean, come on! . . .
 
Q. Mr. President, what is your reaction to Chairman Gorbachev's proposal that NATO and the Warsaw Pact should not remain yet military alliances, but rather become military-political alliances, and later on just political alliances? Can you envisage in the future any form of cooperation between the two alliances?
 
A. Well, I can see an economic interaction. And I hope that NATO will, along with the E.C. and along with O.E.C.D. and these other areas, will take more of an active East-West role in the economy, in helping each other in terms of systems. But he did not press that point with me at all. I think he envisions an active U.S. presence in Europe, in one way or another. . . .
 
High-Seas Machismo
 
Q. Mr. President, after five hours of talks on Saturday, despite extremely treacherous seas, and you even had trouble getting to the talks, you got back in your launch and went back to your ship. Mr. President, why did you do that? And--
 
A. Because I wanted to go back in time to receive him for dinner.
 
Q. Didn't you understand you were risking the summit, number one? And number two, what do you think Gorbachev thinks of your judgment?
 
A. Maureen, you've been to Maine. Don't tell me that that little chop was - was risking anything. Frankly, I haven't had that much fun in a long time . . . But we didn't miss a beat. In fact, we had a very relaxed evening out there, and then showed up and we got eight hours of talks in. . . . I didn't feel there was any risk in getting into a little safe launch like that and going back out to the ship. It was sheer pleasure, really.
 
Q. And it was hot-dogging?
 
A. Hot-dogging? No. Well, you know, these charismatic, macho, visionary guys - they'll do anything. . . .
 
Nicaragua
 
Q. Mr. President, a few moments ago, you questioned whether Gorbachev had any influence at all over Daniel Ortega. Yet in his news conference yesterday, Chairman Gorbachev indicated that there may be an opportunity now for peace in the region. Did he indicate to you in any way whether, one, he had any control over Ortega, or, two, whether there was something in the works that may lead to some kind of peaceful political--
 
A. No, he didn't, but I think - he didn't indicate whether he had any control over him. What he did indicate was that there were going to be free elections. And I told him, that's fine to have those free elections, but they've got to be fair. You have to have access from - for the minorities to - minority parties and the opposition party, the UNO, to get in there and participate, a full access. And so we had a little discussion of that. But that was about it.
 
Q. To follow up, if he indicated there would be free elections, that in turn would indicate that he does in fact maintain some sort of influence on Ortega. And then wouldn't you hold him further responsible to stop that flow of arms in El Salvador?
 
A. Well, I'm not sure that - I don't see quite the logic, that if he says there's going to be a free election that means he controls them. I'm unclear on your--
 
Q. How could he - how could he assure you that there would be free elections?
 
A. I don't - oh, excuse me - I don't think he assured me there was. He just says free elections are scheduled. And I told him how important we felt it was that they go forward.
I am told that our Congressional delegation, made up of some who've been rather generous in their comments about what the Sandinistas were about, or at least were less than supportive historically for the contras, were on this delegation, and that the delegation was denied the right to come in and take a look. And I told him this is counterproductive. This doesn't help. And so - but I don't want to imply from that, that he can - he can just snap his fingers and have Mr. Ortega - I think he was - do what he said.
I think he was impressed - I may be wrong, but I - I think he was impressed by the message from Oscar Arias. And I asked Arias if it was O.K. to tell him of the call, and he said, ''Yes, I hope you will.'' So when I said this man, this Nobel Prize winner - prize winner down there - who - with whom we've had some differences, though normally we're in pretty good sync - appeals to you, ''Use your influence to, you know, stop the export of revolution,'' it may have made an impact.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 5, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 804 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SUMMIT;
Soviet Sway in Cuba and Nicaragua Called Slight

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Experts on Central America said today that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, would have difficulty stopping the flow of arms through Cuba and Nicaragua to Salvadoran guerrillas even if he made assiduous efforts, as President Bush has demanded.
But they said Mr. Gorbachev could do much more than he has done to persuade Havana and Managua to stop the flow of weapons. American officials said Moscow should have substantial influence over what Cuba does because it provides Havana with aid and subsidies worth $4 billion to $6 billion a year.
President Fidel Castro of Cuba has been asserting his independence of Moscow, and there are tensions between him and Mr. Gorbachev over many issues, including the merits of perestroika, Mr. Gorbachev's program of economic and political restructuring. 
''Theoretically the Soviets could cut off'' the flow of arms from Cuba into Central America, but ''practically they can't,'' said Viron P. Vaky, a former Ambassador to Costa Rica, Colombia and Venezuela. He drew an analogy to the United States' relationship with Israel, noting that Washington could not govern Israeli behavior even though it provides $3 billion a year in aid to Israel.
 
'Lean Even Harder'
Central America was the major irritant between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev when they met in Malta over the weekend. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said, ''The Soviet Union has told us that they are leaning on Nicaragua and Cuba not to send weapons'' to the Salvadoran guerrillas. ''But that has not worked,'' he said. ''So we are encouraging them to lean even harder.''
The Bush Administration contends that Moscow has more influence with Havana and Managua than it acknowledges. ''It's not acceptable to us for the Soviets to make a routine or perfunctory inquiry,'' a State Department official said today. ''The Soviet Union may have to raise its voice to get a positive result.''
But Senator Christopher J. Dodd, chairman of the Foreign Relations subcommittee on Latin America, said, ''I am not sure Mr. Gorbachev is any great hero in Havana or Managua'' or in the mountain camps of the Salvadoran guerrillas.
''The old hard-line confrontational rigid ideologues don't take any great comfort in a man who sits back and encourages the recent events in Poland, Hungary and East Germany,'' said Mr. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat. ''He may be seen as something of a traitor to the hard-liners.''
 
'Looking the Other Way'
Cuba has huge stocks of weapons, built up in part for its large ''people's militia,'' now supplemented with arms brought home by Cuban troops returning from Angola, American officials said. So it would appear that Mr. Castro could continue arming the Sandinistas and the Salvadoran rebels whatever Mr. Gorbachev might advise.
Otto J. Reich, who served as Ambassador to Venezuela from June 1986 to July of this year, said: ''Castro is trying to ruin the superpower relationship emerging from the last two summit meetings. He's a convinced ideologue, and the demise of Marxist-Leninist ideology is not in his interest. He is doing what he can, from his small island in the Caribbean, to stop the rapprochement between the superpowers.''
American officials said the Soviets had probably talked to Cuba about its support for the Salvadoran guerrillas, but the United States doubts the Soviets have exerted much influence on Cuba to curtail arms shipments. ''The Soviets are looking the other way,'' said Mr. Reich. Administration officials expressed similar views.
Wayne S. Smith, who served as head of the United States Interests Section in Havana from 1979 to 1982, said that if Moscow urged Cuba to stop arms shipments to Central America, ''the Cubans might or might not take that advice.'' Likewise, he said, there is no guarantee that Nicaragua would follow such advice.
 
'No Reason Not to Talk'
''The Cubans have recently sent a message to the United States saying they would be willing to sit down and discuss the arms supply question,'' Mr. Smith said. ''I see no reason not to talk to the Cubans. We won't solve all this by talking just to the Soviets.''
A light plane carrying two-dozen antiaircraft missiles crashed in southeastern El Salvador on Nov. 25. American officials say that evidence recovered at the scene indicates that the flight originated in Nicaragua and was carrying arms destined for the Salvadoran guerrillas.
The United States has been unwilling to say where the missiles were manufactured. Initially, Salvadoran officials said they were Soviet-made. But last week a State Department spokesman said they ''were not Soviet-made.''
''Based on our analysis of the evidence,'' he said, ''we believe they were supplied by a regime with close military logistical connections with the Soviet Union.'' He did not specify the country.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SUMMIT;
President Thinks He Struck The Right Balance at Malta

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 4

 BODY:
President Bush ended the Malta summit talks confident that he had shown global leadership while not angering a Western alliance resistant to American dominance in world affairs, Administration officials said today.
In the Administration's view, a senior official said, Mr. Bush could claim credit for opening the way to improvements in economic relations and arms control with the Soviets, even though those changes were seen as largely inevitable and likely to provide more benefit than cost to the United States.
In his two days of talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, officials said, Mr. Bush was able to offer Mr. Gorbachev trade concessions and assurances of technical support without committing American money to an uncertain economic future in the Soviet Union.
On the arms control front, they said Mr. Bush's proposals answered complaints that the United States was slipping from the leadership of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But at the same time they said the President was careful not to try to carve out a new European map or undertake the kind of unilateral, impromptu arms control negotiations that so alarmed Western Europe when President Reagan met with Mr. Gorbachev in Reykjavik, Iceland, in 1986. 
 
'To Demonstrate Leadership'
''We're standing here at the seat of NATO, and it's clear they perceive that the President of the United States has done what they fundamentally want the President of the United States to do: to demonstrate leadership in an international environment,'' a senior official said after Mr. Bush briefed his allies on the Malta meetings.
''They like the President to demonstrate a sense of direction,'' the official said. ''But they definitely don't like the President jumping out too far too fast.''
Mr. Bush repeatedly said before going to Malta that he was determined not to become engaged in detailed arms control negotiations. But part of the credit for avoiding a repetition of the Reykjavik situation must go to Mr. Gorbachev, who seemed equally aware of the new pressures on the superpowers from their own alliances and did not set any tripwires for the American President.
Mr. Bush was able to point to Mr. Gorbachev's agreement to speed the negotiations on a treaty to reduce strategic arms and on conventional weapons in Europe. But they were both able to say to their allies that they had not tried to go too far beyond those frameworks. The delicacy of this issue seemed apparent in the relative lack of emphasis that Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev have given to Eastern Europe in their public statements.
 
In Defense of NATO
Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev were careful to stress that they were not calling for the eventual dissolution of the NATO and Warsaw Pact alliances. Administration officials said before the Malta talks that they were keenly aware that NATO provides the United States with a foothold in a Western Europe that is becoming increasingly integrated economically.
''The United States must stay involved,'' Mr. Bush said at a news conference here. ''What we don't want to do is send the signal of decoupling, the decoupling of the United States and Canada from NATO at this critical time.'' Mr. Gorbachev, he said, ''understood that.''
During the summit meeting, Mr. Bush seemed to take a considerably milder tone toward Soviet behavior in regional conflicts than was struck by Mr. Reagan and even by some Administration officials before they went to Malta.
A senior official said today that the United States remains deeply concerned about Soviet support for Nicaragua and about arms shipments to the leftist rebels in El Salvador, which Washington says are being provided by the Sandinista Government in Managua. But he said American officials believe that they have much to gain from trying to work with the Soviet Union on Middle Eastern, African, Asian and even Central American issues.
This explains Mr. Bush's purpose in trying to separate American attitudes toward the Sandinistas from the Soviet-American relationship by saying the Nicaraguans had lied to Moscow about arms shipments to El Salvador.
 
'Work in Common Cause'
''If you can diminish tensions, there are a lot of issues in which the United States and Soviet Union can work in common cause and draw benefit,'' an American official said. ''Soviet behavior has already led to results in some places that are very much in the interest of diminshing conflict.''
On economic issues, Administration officials said Mr. Bush had given Mr. Gorbachev two important offers that he had long sought: American support for Soviet observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and a promise to consider lifting American trade restrictions.
Neither one will cost the United States money, Administration officials said. At the same time, they argued, the White House stands to gain from the proposals.
Mr. Bush's suggestion satisfies complaints from the Soviet Union, Western Europe and even back home that he has not done enough to capitalize on the economic evolution in Europe. In addition, an American official said, the United States believes it is encouraging the Soviets ''to make adjustments that we have been seeking for a long time.''
Soviet-American economic cooperation will allow the United States to remain more closely engaged with the Soviets, the Americans argued.
''If through your economic proposals and the institutionalization of a human rights agenda, you can build a more pluralistic Soviet Union, that helps make the changes in the Soviet Union less easy to reverse,'' an official said. ''It also makes for a more transparent Soviet Union, so you have a beter sense of whether there are really changes.''
 
Personal Stake for Bush
There was an intensely personal stake for Mr. Bush in the Malta summit. He demonstrated that he was able to deal with Mr. Gorbachev smoothly and effectively and tried to dispel the notion that he was missing opportunities.
''He took my measure, and I took his, and we both feel more comfortable about our common objectives,'' Mr. Bush said.
The President retained some of his characteristic reserve today, declining to answer a question about whether, like Mr. Gorbachev, he now considers the cold war to be over. ''I don't want to give you a headline,'' he said.
But he seemed clearly sensitive to the criticism that he has been too timid and lacking in a world vision. Asked why he had insisted on staying aboard his warship, the cruiser Belknap, during the summit despite a powerful gale, Mr. Bush replied: ''Well, you know these charismatic, macho, visionary guys. They'll do anything.''

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SUMMIT;
Soviets Say Gorbachev Gave Bush a Spy Map of U.S. Navy

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The chief Soviet spokesman said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was so emphatic in raising the issue of naval disarmament at the Malta summit talks that he handed President Bush a classified map of K.G.B. intelligence on American fleet movements and installations of particular concern.
Invoking the memory of President Bush stranded aboard a naval cruiser ''impotent against the rough seas,'' the spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, emphasized at a briefing that Mr. Gorbachev would continue to press the naval issue, which President Bush firmly rebuffed at the weekend meeting.
''The American President was stuck on his ship, which only proves our point that you don't really need all these navies,'' Mr. Gerasimov declared in the briefing, conducted on the flight home from Malta.
Responding to reporters' questions, the Soviet spokesman said President Bush had raised the issue of the Soviet Union re-establishing diplomatic relations with Israel. ''We have nothing against it,'' Mr. Gerasimov said, ''providing we have progress in a settlement there.'' 
 
Says Baltics Didn't Come Up
In raising issues and offering a score of proposals, President Bush did not mention the Soviet Baltic republics, Mr. Gerasimov said. The United States still does not recognize the republics' incorporation into the Soviet Union as legal, and some specialists anticipated that Mr. Bush might press the issue at the summit talks. ''Of course not,'' Mr. Gerasimov said, when asked whether the topic was mentioned.
The spokesman said that the Soviet Government was already pursuing one of the issues raised by Mr. Bush, the need for disclosure of military budget and weapons production figures. ''The Soviet Union is preparing to publish this kind of information,'' he said.
While hailing the summit meeting as a constructive and friendly ''threshhold'' to a new era in Soviet-American relations, Mr. Gerasimov could not resist sarcasm at times.
Sitting in the front cabin of the returning press plane and wearing a ''Malta to Yalta'' T-shirt, Mr. Gerasimov repeatedly invoked the image of an American president tossed by the seas, and of the summit haven provided by Soviet officials aboard their luxury liner, the Maxim Gorky.
 
A Victory in Imagery
He made it clear that Soviet officials were savoring something of an imagery victory, and he was similarly sarcastic in asserting that the issue of Soviet human rights, until lately a cause of worldwide criticism, had become ''a two-way street.''
In comparison with Mr. Bush''s presentation of an ''extremely short list'' of complaints about Soviet citizens separated unwillingly from loved ones abroad, Mr. Gerasimov said, the Moscow Government had ''a very long list of Soviet citizens who cannot go to the United States and cannot get a visa.''
He sardonically suggested that perhaps the Soviet Parliament should adopt an ''Ivanov-Petrov amendment,'' similar to the Jackson-Vanik amendment approved by the Congress, and thus help ''all those Soviets who want to go the United States.'' The Jackson-Vanik amendment mandates trade restrictions on the Soviet Union because of human rights abuses.
Mr. Gerasimov did not mention that while the United States is processing record numbers of Soviet visa and emigration applicants, it has had to set firm limits as larger numbers of Soviet citizens sought to leave. A more liberal climate under Mr. Gorbachev has emboldened many to come forward as the Soviet economy fails to improve.
 
'Not a Single Quarrel'
Mr. Gerasimov hailed the tone of the eight hours of summit talks as ''something of a continuation of an interrupted conversation'' between serious leaders, with ''not a single quarrel.''
''There was a lot of progress and concrete things were discussed,'' he said. ''I think the Malta meeting will give impetus to the negotiations in Vienna,'' he added, referring to the talks on reductions in conventional forces.
He said that Mr. Gorbachev had the naval intelligence map ready to hand to the President Bush ''to prove we feel a little insecure being surrounded by all these ships and military bases.'' He said that Mr. Bush promised to look it over with his own experts.
On the resumption of diplomatic ties with Israel, Mr. Gerasimov emphasized the need for a Middle East settlement involving several nations. The Americans are ''destined to fail,'' he said, if ''they go it alone'' without a joint approach involving the Soviet Union.
''If Mr. Shamir is not warming, then we are not warming,'' he said, referring to the Israeli Prime Minister.

HEADLINE: Criminal Inquiry Is Opened Into Ex-H.U.D. Chief's Acts

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Justice Department announced today that it had opened a formal criminal inquiry to determine whether a special prosecutor should investigate allegations of perjury and conspiracy against former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. The announcement came as New York State prosecutors released documents showing that a longtime friend of Mr. Pierce, Samuel P. Singletary, was under indictment on larceny charges when his consulting firm received a $350,000 development grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development in 1985.
Only weeks after the H.U.D. grant was formally approved, records show, Mr. Singletary pleaded guilty to stealing New York State funds from a job-training program he had once run in Westchester County. Prosecutors said the theft totaled $17,000. 
A former H.U.D. offical said today that the department was aware of the charges against Mr. Singletary when the grant was awarded. One of Mr. Pierce's lawyers said today that his client had no recollection of the grant to Mr. Singletary.
 
Three Months to Decide
The decision by the Justice Department to open what is known as a preliminary investigation was announced by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. Under Federal ethics laws, Mr. Thornburgh now has three months to determine whether there is sufficient evidence of criminal wrongdoing to warrant appointment of a special prosecutor, formally known as an independent counsel.
Mr. Thornburgh's announcement came in response to a Nov. 2 request from 19 members of the House Judiciary Committee, who said in a letter that evidence gathered by Congressional investigators showed that Mr. Pierce ''may be implicated in a conspiracy to defraud the United States.''
Mr. Pierce is at the center of allegations that, in his eight years as President Ronald Reagan's Housing Secretary, H.U.D. awarded billions of dollars in housing grants to prominent Republicans and close friends, regardless of merit.
Democrats responded favorably to Mr. Thornburgh's announcement. ''I'm pleased that the Attorney General has announced that he's taking the next step towards appointment of an independent counsel,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat. ''This investigation is the fairest and most thorough way to get answers to questions that are not going away.''
 
'Look at This More Closely'
In his announcement today, Mr. Thornburgh did not explain his reasons for opening the investigation of Mr. Pierce. But a senior Justice Department official, who spoke on condition that he not be named, said Mr. Thornburgh had rejected a recommendation from prosecutors in the department that the investigation of Mr. Pierce be shut down for lack of evidence.
''The Attorney General concluded that it was simply imprudent to close the matter at this time,'' the official said. ''People are uncovering things on an almost daily basis, and the Attorney General feels it prudent to take more time and to look at this more closely.''
One of Mr. Pierce's lawyers, Paul L. Perito, said in an interview that ''given the very low threshold of the statute, it is not surprising that the Department of Justice's careful lawyers would want to take the entire 90 days to investigate.'' He added, ''We're very secure that at the conclusion of that period, a decision will be made not to apply to the court for the appointment of an independent counsel.''
 
Singletary Indictment
The Democratic lawmakers have also questioned whether Mr. Pierce committed perjury when he testified before a House panel last May and indicated that he had not ordered H.U.D. aides to award housing grants for political reasons. ''I did not have hands on,'' Mr. Pierce said of his management of the department.
In the case of Mr. Singletary, prosecutors in Westchester County disclosed today that he was indicted there in July 1985 on charges of grand larceny and falsifying business records.
He was accused of stealing about $17,000 by submitting vouchers to the New York State Labor Department claiming reimbursement for false expeditures in providing job training for unemployed youths, Frank Castaldi, the chief of the frauds bureau in the Westchester County District Attorney's office.
 
Discretionary Funds
At the time of the indictment, H.U.D. was weighing whether to provide the $350,000 grant to Mr. Singletary's consulting concern, the Center for Resource Development, for projects designed to lure private development to two New Jersey cities.
A former senior H.U.D. official who asked not to be named said that at least some Federal housing officials in Washington were aware of the criminal charges at the time, but that the grant had been approved anyway.
A former aide to Mr. Pierce, DuBois L. Gilliam, has said in interviews that he was ordered by Mr. Pierce to assist Mr. Singletary with the $350,000 grant, and that it was provided under one of two large discretionary funds under Mr. Pierce's control.
Mr. Singletary, a Republican, helped direct Mr. Pierce's unsuccessful campaigns in 1959 and 1960 for election as a Manhattan judge.
 
Restitution of $17,000
According to H.U.D. officials, the grant to the Center for Resource Development was approved by Mr. Gilliam in August 1985. Two months later, on Oct. 22, Mr. Singletary pleaded guilty to one count of grant larceny in a plea agreement and was sentenced to five years' probation and restitution of about $17,000.
Mr. Perito, Mr. Pierce's lawyer, said today that his client had ''no specific recollection'' of the grant to Mr. Singletary.
Asked if Mr. Pierce would have awarded the grant despite the Westchester County indictment, Mr. Perito indicated that the criminal charges might not have provided enough reason to deny the grant. ''Even if Mr. Pierce was aware of the charges when he met with Mr. Singletary, fairness and presumption of innocence would have been applicable,'' the lawyer said.
Mr. Singletary has denied using improper influence with Mr. Pierce to obtain the grant.

HEADLINE: To Shattered City and Its Merchants, Earthquake Proves an Opportunity

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Dec. 1

 BODY:
It has been a surprisingly cheerful month for the merchants of Santa Cruz. Selling from big tents because the Oct. 17 earthquake leveled their downtown shopping mall, many say that the day after Thanksgiving this year was their best ever and that sales have remained strong since.
Now the business owners hope they can harness the good feelings that have flowed from the cooperative effort to rebound from the quake. In a city where developers and politicians have been at odds for years, the business interests hope to rebuild the mall in record time. 
For the moment, merchants and landowners are apprehensive as they look forward to filling the rubble-strewn lots that now dominate downtown and to rebuilding the Pacific Garden Mall. A tree-lined street of turn-of-the-century buildings, the mall has spurred the economic regeneration of downtown Santa Cruz since its completion 20 years ago.
Some fear that the redevelopment of the mall will become mired in an endless planning process, a victim of a virtual no-growth policy that has resulted from the difficulty of getting building permits.
Louis E. Rittenhouse, president of the Downtown Association, a group of merchants and landowners, said he realized the night after the quake that ''the disaster was minor compared to the chaos that was possible once this became a redevelopment site.'' His family, which arrived in Santa Cruz a century ago, owned five buildings on the mall; four of them fell in the quake.
 
Without Development, 'No Future'
To overcome the legacy of hostility to development in this coastal city 90 miles south of San Francisco, Mr. Rittenhouse and others are putting together a public and private redevelopment foundation that will include elected officials, merchants, landowners and neighborhood groups. Modeling its efforts on redevelopment projects in Baltimore, in Columbus, Ohio, and in Portland, Ore., this group believes that it can accelerate the planning process by reaching a consensus on the mall's future.
''The earthquake opened up the power structure,'' said William Rubel, chairman of the Downtown Commission, a group that advises the City Council. ''The disaster made people work together, and now we intend to keep working together.''
Mr. Rubel, whose commission helped bring the tents to the fallen mall, said he hoped the earthquake had permanently changed local politics. ''Now, development is on the agenda,'' he said. ''There really is no future for anyone without development.''
Mr. Rubel said the foundation would take its strength from a diverse board of 30 to 40 citizens who would look for consensus among the city's antagonistic camps.
Mayor Mardi Wormhoudt agreed. While the foundation's role will be advisory, she said, ''if it does its job well, the recommendations it comes up with will be compelling and will be hard for anyone in the city to resist.''
To many merchants and landowners, the recovery from the quake is an opportunity to address longstanding problems. A chronic parking shortage had prompted many large businesses, including every downtown bank, to leave the area. And while the mall was full, it was still underused because the second and third floors of the old buildings had fallen into disrepair. Merchants say they and their shoppers had daily confrontations with increasingly aggressive panhandlers who loitered at the mall.
 
A Place to Live, Too
Now they say a redeveloped mall can address these issues. ''For me, it's an exciting possibility, an opportunity to solve a whole lot of problems,'' said Ron Lau, who owned the brick building occupied by Bookshop Santa Cruz. He and others hope to put residential apartments on the upper floors of their new buildings, which they say will provide additional income and make the mall a livelier and safer place at night.
Mr. Lau, who had earthquake insurance and whose tenant, the bookstore, is anxious to move back in, hopes to have a new building finished within 18 months. But for other owners and tenants of the 25 buildings that were destroyed, the future is less certain.
Rents were low on the mall, partly because many of the buildings had little or no debt. New construction loans will drive rents higher, and some people worry that the small local businesses the old mall accommodated will be priced out of the new one.
But town leaders also say the tents, which at first seemed only an expedient solution to a pressing need, may have inspired a vision of the future for these local entrepreneurs in downtown Santa Cruz.
 
'Phoenix Pavilions'
Open and airy, made of cloth and aluminum, the tents have a festive character. Dubbed ''Phoenix Pavilions'' by the Downtown Association, they were rapidly raised by volunteer union labor. Many of them now house several businesses, and because they have no interior walls, shoppers can look into one store while standing in another. Several merchants say the increased exposure has lifted sales far above pre-earthquake levels.
''What do you do about the 800-square-foot small shop?'' said Matthew Thompson, a partner in Thacher and Thompson, a leading architectural firm here. ''I think the Phoenix Pavilions are going to teach us.''
In the meantime, Mr. Rubel of the Downtown Commission is working with local artists to use the empty spaces until construction begins. He plans sculpture gardens, a stage, sound and light shows and painted cloth images of buildings to fill in the gaps. He is also working with the curator of the city museum to place kiosks at each space showing the different buildings that have occupied it over time.
''We are not just coping with a bad situation, but rising above it to do something very attractive,'' Mr. Rubel said. ''This will be the best time for pressing high-quality development, for finding out what is really possible.''

GRAPHIC: photo of merchants operating out of tents on Cedar St. (NYT/Terrence McCarthy)

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Agree To Hear Case On Water Use

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve an intensifying conflict between the Federal Government and the states over regulating the environmental impact of hydroelectric power plants.
The question is whether the Federal Government or the state is entitled to the final word on how much water can be diverted from a free-flowing river to serve the needs of a hydroelectric plant.
The rate at which the plant's operators are required to keep the water flowing is an important element in the consideration of the balance between the environmental impact and the economic benefit of such a plant.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which licenses hydroelectric plants under the Federal Power Act, takes the view that it has the authority to establish the water-flow rate. Under that view, states may not impose requirements on a hydroelectric plant that are stricter than those the Federal agency has chosen to attach to the license. 
 
California Appeals Decision
That position was upheld in a decision earlier this year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco. California appealed to the Supreme Court, arguing that states must be free to make ''important policy judgments concerning allocation of water among competing public and private needs.''
The Federal Government opposed California's appeal, which was supported by a brief signed by 43 other states. In addition, a group of national environmental organizations filed a brief on California's behalf. The American Public Power Association and the Edison Electric Institute, representing the utility industry, filed a brief urging the Court not to hear the appeal.
The case, California v. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, No. 89-333, involves a 3,000-kilowatt hydroelectric power plant on a tributory of the America River, near Placerville, Calif. In 1983 a development partnership received a Federal license to withdraw water to run power turbines and to return the water to the river about a mile downstream.
The Federal license set a minimum flow rate of 11 to 15 cubic feet per second. But California officials concluded that this would not leave enough water to protect the river's fish. The state set a considerably higher minimum of 30 to 60 cubic feet per second. The partnership, which said the plant could not generate enough power at that level to be economically feasible, then sought and received from the Federal agency a declaration that the state had no authority to set the water rate.
The case requires the Court to interpret Section 27 of the Federal Power Act, which gives the states the right to regulate the use of water for irrigation and for ''municipal or other uses.'' The legal question is whether that ambiguous language also applies to the type of environmental regulation at issue here.
Because Congress has recently established financial incentives for hydroelectric plants, interest in building them has grown rapidly. There are now about 2,000 in operation.
Other action at the Court today included the following: Solicitor General's Advice The Justices usually pay close attention to the advice they get from the Solicitor General's office, which represents the Federal Government in the Supreme Court.
But today was a notably unsuccessful one for that office. Not only did the Court accept two appeals over the Government's opposition, including the California water case, but it also turned down one of the Government's own appeals.
The other case the Court accepted was also an environmental case, concerning enforcement of the Clean Air Act. When a state submits a revised plan to comply with the act's requirements, the Environmental Protection Agency has four months to review the plan and decide whether it is acceptable. But the agency often misses the four-month deadline, and lower courts have disagreed over whether the E.P.A. can then continue enforcing the old state plan before it has acted on the revisions.
The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, ruled in favor of the agency, refusing to block it from enforcing emission limits in Massachusetts after it missed the deadline for approving a revised state clean air plan. The case was brought by General Motors, which operates an assembly line in Framingham, Mass., and which challenged the Federal agency's effort to force it to comply with the old plan.
General Motors appealed to the Supreme Court (G.M. v. U.S., No. 89-369), arguing that the four-month deadline was absolute and that the penalty for the agency's failure to meet it should be loss of its enforcement authority.
 
Military Liability
The Court refused to hear a Government appeal from a ruling that the Government could be sued for accidental injuries to a civilian on a military base that were caused by the actions of off-duty service members.
Two Navy men were trying to repair a car at the Point Mugu Naval Base in California when flaming gasoline shot out and injured a child. The child's family sued under the Federal Tort Claims Act, which provides damages for injuries caused by Government employees acting ''within the scope'' of their employment.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that the Government was liable because the sailors had a continuing duty to adhere to the base's fire regulations even when they were off duty. In its appeal, U.S. v. Washington, No. 89-482, the Government argued that the decision went beyond the law, turning the Untied States ''into a virtual insurer of the conduct of members of the service on military bases.''

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush, Talking Like a Leader

 BODY:
Firmly and unambiguously, President Bush said on leaving the Malta summit talks what his Administration has needed to say with one voice: ''We stand at the threshold of a brand-new era of U.S.-Soviet relations.'' And finally, he demonstrated that he understands the new era's opportunities by sending three strong messages on the Soviet economy, arms control and regional conflicts.
On Sunday in Malta Mr. Bush sent the most important possible message to the Soviet people: The U.S. stands ready to help make Mikhail Gorbachev's economic reforms work, and won't simply sit on the sidelines to gloat or cheer. 
This message tells a people who sorely need encouragement that the West will help them with trade and credits through the next trying years. That, in turn, strengthens Mr. Gorbachev's hand against growing unhappiness with his reforms.
Then yesterday in Brussels, Mr. Bush conveyed the right message to his own somewhat divided Administration: ''I, the President of the United States, will kick our bureaucracy and push it as fast as I possibly can'' on arms control. That means he wants no more foot-dragging on reaching mutual compromises, particularly in slashing strategic nuclear arms. Both the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. need cuts in nuclear and conventional forces to release resources and repair economies burdened by the years of cold war.
In recent hours Mr. Bush has also conveyed appropriate warnings about warfare in Central America. Soviet arms, with or without Moscow's knowledge, continue to make their way into rebel hands in El Salvador, and Mr. Bush rightly raised the issue at Malta with Mr. Gorbachev. They should also be talking about their other proxy wars, in Afghanistan, Cambodia and elsewhere. Regional flareups could still singe the new cooperative efforts in Europe.
Mr. Bush's first two messages don't sit well with American conservatives who can't seem to get their bearings without Godless commies to kick around. They're already charging that the President is giving away the store. They complain, for instance, that he will weaken the U.S. nuclear deterrent before bringing about equality in European conventional forces.
But if Moscow can be persuaded to cut its strategic forces in half for much lesser American cuts, that makes eminent sense even without agreement on Europe. And in any event, Mr. Bush is simply directing that both treaties be finished in time for the next summit meeting in June. Some conservatives also criticize him for offering economic help without getting pledges from Moscow on military restraint. What better demonstration of restraint could there be than yesterday's Warsaw Pact statement condemning the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968?
Mr. Bush need not fear these gripes and moans. In the last few days, he's finally brought his leadership into focus. ''What we've got to do is be sure,'' he said yesterday, ''that we conduct ourselves in such a way that the changes, the political reforms, can keep going forward'' in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Finally, that's a leader talking.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Plenty Of Credit

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
No doubt many Americans do not yet believe ''the cold war is over,'' just because Presidents Bush and Gorbachev say it is. But even skeptics must concede that both sides have come a long way from the depths of dangerous hostility reached in the 50's, at the time of the Cuban missile crisis or in the early years of the Reagan Administration.
In fact, some hard-line anti-Communists who used to scoff at the idea of a less-threatening Soviet Union now attribute the improved superpower relationship to Mr. Reagan's arms buildup and to their own support for it. This claim can't be entirely disputed; even the Strategic Defense Initiative, properly scorned by most American scientific and arms-control authorities, seemed to impress the Soviets as a chal-lenge that they might not be able to meet. 
But to see the immense changes now taking place as a mere backdown by Moscow against U.S. might ignores, for one thing, the internal economic, political and structural problems that had been rising within the Soviet Union as the Communist system failed. It ignores, too, the willingness of Mr. Gorbachev to face up to these problems and to try to deal with them.
The Reagan arms buildup no doubt speeded reform within the Soviet Union, but sooner or later internal Soviet problems would have forced some Soviet leader to adopt a similar policy. Once perestroika began in the U.S.S.R., change was inevitable in Eastern Europe, where the Communist satellites also were failing - although virtually no one foresaw how swiftly the regimes symbolized by the Berlin wall would come tumbling down.
Mr. Gorbachev did not just let the transformation happen. He could hardly have forced Eastern Europe to retain a system he was trying to reform within the Soviet Union; nor could he have maintained his credibility in the West by using tanks. But when on Aug. 22, in a telephone call to Warsaw, he specifically cleared the way for a Solidarity government in Poland, he sent a clear signal that reverberated throughout Eastern Europe; later, he told Czech Commu-nists to get in line with a reform movement he knew they could not stop.
Nor was Ronald Reagan's arms buildup - more costly than effective - his only contribution to recent remarkable events. Hard-liners do not like to remember that in his second term, Mr. Reagan embraced Mr. Gorbachev, entered into the I.N.F. treaty curbing medium-range missiles and linked arms with the Soviet leader in Red Square and at the Statue of Liberty. For his part, Mr. Gorbachev confessed that the Krasnoyarsk radar was a treaty violation, and apologized for the invasions of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and Afghanistan in 1979. So both leaders share credit for what, after Malta, can reasonably be called the end of the cold war.
To the extent U.S. politics and policy did precipitate this welcome development, hard-liners' attempts to take credit are more than a little exaggerated. Wasn't it they who insisted that Communist regimes could never change, that Mr. Gorbachev would not be permitted by his own party to effect reforms, that he might even be a trickster trying to lure the U.S. into letting down its guard?
Hard-liners insisted, too, that the United States should not help perestroika to succeed, that Mr. Gorbachev should be left to struggle alone, and was likely to fall anyway. Some insisted that the Soviets would never let go of their Eastern European shield, and that Mr. Gorbachev could not be trusted unless he proved himself by letting the Berlin wall come down.
Many hard-liners who supported the arms buildup opposed arms control measures, even the I.N.F. treaty, which actually took weapons out of arsenals on both sides. Hard-liners consistently resisted other efforts to improve relations with the Soviets, and not a few preached the nightmare doctrine of Armageddon - an ultimate military showdown between what they regarded as the forces of good and the forces of evil.
If the West, led by the United States, outlasted the Communist powers in the postwar years, its stance was largely devised by Harry Truman, George Marshall, Dean Acheson, Dwight Eisenhower and others pilloried at the time by hard-liners. Therefore, as the right wing at last faces political life without the Red issue, Americans need less to hear vainglorious boasts that the hard line brought the Soviets to their knees than to understand that for the promising new world we face, there's plenty of credit to go around.

HEADLINE: Bush Wasn't Tough Enough

BYLINE: By Kenneth L. Adelman; Kenneth L. Adelman was director of the Arms Control and Disaramament Agency from 1983 to 1987.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The ''no surprises'' summit meeting was surprising in its lack of ''new thinking'' about the new world unfolding. This summit smacked of summits of the 1970's, with arms control once again raising the highest expectations.
President Bush and his top advisers are now poised to lunge for the capillaries, as they promise gala summertime summit signings, staff-kicking and deadline-setting for three new major accords this year. Secretary of State James Baker heads off next month to Moscow, where he will dive into SS-18 throw weight and other arms control nitpicks. 
Rather than rework outdated past proposals, the Bush team should push two big-ticket items of grand historical sweep and significance.
The first is the complete removal of Soviet forces from Eastern Europe. This would end the cold war where it began. It need not be reciprocated by all our G.I.s leaving Europe. For sundry reasons, reunification among them, Mikhail Gorbachev may not want all U.S. troops to leave West German soil soon.
The second item to push for is an end to Leonid Brezhnev's legacy of bailouts of Cuba, Nicaragua, Vietnam and Afghanistan, which would save Mr. Gorbachev $10 billion yearly.
Why should Mr. Gorbachev spend gobs of scarce, hard currency to keep these mostly far away Marxist regimes in power when he smiles as Marxists fall next door? Does he really care more about Fidel Castro's fate than about Erich Honecker's?
Besides constituting a major diversion, the arms control hype will yield positive harm at worst and dubious benefit at best.
Take the treaty on strategic arms. Aside from horrendous verification woes (some seemingly insolvable), are persistent doubts about whether the agreement helps U.S. strategic stability.
Before joining the Bush Administration as national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft and the ambassador to the Vienna arms talks, R. James Woolsey, wrote that Start could push the U.S. into ''a new kind of triad: vulnerability, wishful thinking, and a hair trigger.'' Not reassuring words, but unfortunately still true.
Or take the conventional-arms accord. While beneficial to NATO when first proposed earlier this year, it has been overtaken by events. If concluded, this accord would legitimize the continued presence in East Europe of some 300,000 Soviet troops beyond the mid-1990's.
This is odd when the Hungarians and Czechs are calling for a complete Soviet troop withdrawal from their countries. Mr. Gorbachev reportedly speaks of removing all his forces in East Europe by the year 2000. So why are we still proposing an accord that legitimizes the Soviet military's presence there indefinitely.
Or take a worldwide ban on chemical weapons. This noble aim is simply unachievable, since verification is impossible.
Mine is not a broadside attack on either arms talks or formal arms accords. But rather than go for agreements without real arms control, without clearly helping security or saving money, we should seek real arms control without agreements.
We should adopt an approach of evolving, parallel policies with the Soviets. Reductions initiated by their side that are below our levels in key categories would be matched by us, and vice-versa. Each side thereby tailors its forces to make them affordable, survivable and sensible.
This is a dynamic approach, one that recognizes rapid changes in Eastern Europe and in economic conditions. The formal number-crunching approach must end in a static formula.
However, formal arms control could reduce one severe threat: the wildfire spread of ballistic missiles. Washington and Moscow could jointly open to all nations the intermediate range nuclear forces treaty's ban on ballistic missiles of a range between 300 to 3,400 miles. This verifiable accord could help prevent more than 15 countries from producing ballistic missiles within a decade.
History is already being kind and gentle to President Bush. It is handing him enormous opportunities to usher in a far safer future.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Life Support for Moscow

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Over the weekend the people of Czechoslovakia and East Germany made it vividly plain that their goal was to eliminate Communist Party rule over their nations - and that they would not rest until they reached it.
Those same days, a few hundred miles away off Malta, President Bush committed the political and economic power of the United States to trying to maintain the rule of the Communist Party in the Soviet Union.
That is the essential meaning and historic irony of Malta. The United States has decided to try to halt or at least delay the great international revolution against Communism in one country - the very country that was the birthplace of Communist tyranny and has suffered most from it for 70 years. 
Until Malta, there was a strong and growing possibility the monopoly of Communist Party power in the Soviet Union would end soon, a year or two, and Mr. Gorbachev would be forced to accept the sharing of political power essential to a free democracy.
If he continued to refuse, he would be swept away by public fury against the Communist Party - as have the Communist Party rulers of the Eastern European nations now surging to freedom.
As long as the Communist Party rules alone, commanding all the government and military power of the Soviet Union, it will try to control reforms to maintain its position. Only when that monopoly ceases can the world be sure that there will be no reversal and that days of police power will not return.
Malta did not end the possibility of the overthrow or surrender of the Soviet Communist Party. The whole system is so rotted with corruption by its very nature that it cannot indefinitely be saved. No, not even by the American investments Mr. Bush now proposes be guaranteed by the American taxpayer.
But some of the Soviet citizens who years ago forecast the Soviet political and economic collapse now believe sorrowfully that Malta can delay the end of Communist power in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Gorbachev got all the economic support he dreamt of. That will help him stick temporary patches on his sinking boat. More importantly he received the political and emotional commitment of the United States Administration against those Soviet liberals who fight for the end of party rule.
Washington's support is a powerful weapon for Mr. Gorbachev to bring home for use against those who once trusted America to remain the enemy of Communist Party domination.
Mr. Bush could have gone another way, and should have. He could have said the United States would negotiate for all arms control agreements that benefited both sides.
He could have limited his collection of economic benefits to just one - the suspension of the punitive measures that were enacted to force Moscow to allow its citizens to emigrate.
And, while acknowledging Mr. Gorbachev's role so far, Mr. Bush could have stated the simple truth that a revolution against Communist monopoly is still going on and nearing achievement. He could have said the United States had no right to intervene to stop it by economic and political support on the side of the endangered Soviet Communist apparatus.
Without taking any action against Mr. Gorbachev he would have put this country where it belongs - on the side of those in the Soviet Union who continue to struggle for real freedom against one-party rule. That might even have helped Mr. Gorbachev conclude there was no other alternative.
Why did President Bush decide to turn Malta into an instrument for the preservation of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union? Was it out of fear that oppression, even a form of Fascism, might follow Mr. Gorbachev? That is a possibility because for 70 years the Soviet system has permitted or encouraged such fertilizers and fruit of Fascism as anti-Semitism - and still does.
Clearly a democratic system is what the liberal and radical opponents of the Communist Party are fighting for. But the longer the Communist Party imposes its monopoly rule, the greater the danger of anger leading to another tyranny, not the less.
Most likely, Mr. Bush thought Americans wanted him to seize a role in shaping a new world and liked the idea himself. But that world is emerging only because of the collapse of Communist parties throughout the Soviet empire.
Surely Americans never realized the role Mr. Bush selected would be to provide life support for the Soviet Communist Party, keeping it breathing through more years of pain and suffering for the Soviet people.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
American Faces Eviction On Morris Street

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
Evaristi Corrales, who owned and ran a bakery in Havana, fled from Cuba in 1962, three years into the regime of Fidel Castro, partly out of fear, but mainly for economic reasons. The Marxist government seized the bakery. ''I could not work after Castro took it,'' Mr. Corrales said. ''He took everything.''
So Mr. Corrales, who is 63 years old, and his wife, Leonar, 60, came to the United States, settled in Yonkers, and he got a job as a toolmaker. Fifteen years ago the couple bought a house on Morris Street, at the corner of Riverdale, and 10 years ago they bought the bar behind them and turned it into a small grocery, the El Rancho, and have done fairly well ever since. 
But on Oct. 23, the City of Yonkers, under Federal court order to build new schools to remedy a pattern of discrimination in both housing and schooling, obtained a court order, through eminent domain, seizing the property of the Corraleses and five other homeowners on Morris Street.
The six homeowners had nothing to do with the suit itself. But their property is on the block where the city will build the new school to satisfy the Federal court order.
''What was it that Jimmy Carter said when he was President?,'' said J. Radley Herold, the city's Corporation Counsel, ''Life is not fair? I wish it were.''
''It's garbage,'' said Mr. Corrales. ''I never in my life took the welfare. I work, work, work. The taxes go up, up, and up, and now the City Hall, the Yonkers City Hall, plays with me. They play with me. They put out my tenants. They put me out. It's done. It's finished. I lose.'' The Corrales's house is big, a turn-of-the-century Victorian with 14 rooms, 5 on the top two floors, which they rented, and 4 on the bottom, which they occupied. The city assessed it, and the store, at $205,000, and that is what they will be paid, unless they sue for more.
The Coralleses say they have looked at comparable houses, but they cost considerably more, around $100,000 more. Demolition, said Mr. Herold, is scheduled to start ''very soon,'' but no firm date is set.
The Corrales's two tenants are gone, evicted by the condemnation order. One, a family of three from Ecuador, paid $550 a month, and now pays $850. The other, from Puerto Rico, simply moved away, Mr. Corrales said.
Next door on Morris Street, Oscar Flzo, 32, a carpenter who occupies a $400-a-month room in the home of Florrenda Nieves, also purchased through condemnation, for $167,000, said he had not found a new place to live.
Mr. Flzo said that he had been in this country for nine years and that he had become a citizen a year ago. He lived on Morris Street for four and a half years. And now?
''Either somebody has to move or there is demolition,'' he said. ''I don't know. I try around . . . .'' He shrugs.
Two houses down Morris Street is the home of Caroline Miranda, 82; her sister, Helen Gallagher, 80; her brother, Theodore Kurkeviez, 83, and Mrs. Gallagher's son, Robert Gallagher, 58, a partially disabled former Marine who works at the Post Office. Other than Mr. Gallagher's income, they live on Social Security.
The house is big, in good shape, they have separate bedrooms, and it has been in the family almost 50 years. ''We've been happy in it, we'd love to stay on,'' Mrs. Gallagher said.
But they have also been told to move. ''We're in the same boat as everybody else,'' said Mrs. Miranda, who, like her sister, is a widow. She thought a minute. ''They're killing us,'' she said. Appraisers decided the 12-room house was worth $160,000, and that is what they will be paid for it. The sisters have been looking, but it is hard.
''We've seen about 40 houses,'' Mrs. Gallagher said. ''It's hard to get a house under $249,000, at all.''
It seems anomalous, displacing the poor, the aged, the ill, immigrants, as a remedy for racial imbalance. Perhaps it is the price that must be paid for municipal intransigence in defiance of a determined Federal court.
But the residents of Morris Street say it all came suddenly, that although they have known for as much as a year that their street had been designated as the site of a court-ordered school, that it was only in the last month that it all crystallized for sure, and they were ordered to move. The actual eviction date, Dec. 1, has already passed, but the checks for the assessed payments have not been drawn and delivered, and no one has been evicted quite yet. They will be if necessary. Mr. Herold said everyone knew ''the day of judgment was coming and when it comes, you have got to be moved.''
