HEADLINE: Town Copes With Growth And Trouble It Can Bring

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOMERS, N.Y.

 BODY:
This northern Westchester town, its hills still flecked with silos and old stone walls, is starting to realize the price it has paid for financial security.
Now that the I.B.M. and Pepsi-Cola complexes are built, together representing more than 1.5 million square feet of office space, taxes are going down. But traffic now clogs country roads. Land erosion causes flooding when it rains. Sometimes at night, the corporate lighting creates an eerie orange haze, or ''sky glow.'' And during the day, the International Business Machines complex is visible for miles.
''When you come up Interstate 684, you don't feel like you're in the country anymore because you see these four monstrosities on top of the hill,'' said William C. Harding, the Town Supervisor of Somers, referring to the lofty pyramids that crown the I.B.M. complex, itself perched on a hill. ''That has a devastating psychological impact.'' Growth or Rural Character? The tensions in Somers have reverberated in recent years in many communities on the fringes of the New York metropolitan region. The heart of the issue is whether municipalities can achieve a balance between fostering economic growth and protecting their precious rural character. 
At the start of the decade, while its neighbors clung to the countryside by barring development drawn by the construction of I-684 in the late 1960's, Somers acted instead to capitalize on that development. And it went all out to attract Pepsi-Cola and I.B.M. by rezoning almost 1,000 acres from residential to commericial use.
But now Somers has turned itself around on development, and town officials, residents, builders and environmentalists attribute it to the impact of I.B.M., and to a lesser extent, Pepsi-Cola. In electing Mr. Harding as supervisor in 1987, the town replaced the three-term Republican incumbent, Wayne Van Tassell, who had invited the two companies to town, with someone who had no government experience but was strongly anti-development and pro-environment.
Mr. Harding, a Republican, was re-elected last month, and the town board, whose majority had supported measures for growth for as long as anyone in Somers can remember, is now unanimously in favor of ''slow growth'' and protecting the environment. Recently proposed environmental ordinances for the town would, if passed, be so tough on future builders that they have even been criticized by the Westchester County Planning Department as excessive.
But many in Somers, a town of 18,000, believe they have no choice. ''Somers burned its hand on the stove, and people asked whether we were really doing the right thing,'' said Mr. Harding, a 37-year-old biologist, who says his mission now is to stop developers from ''attempting to pave every square inch'' of the 33-square-mile town.
There is no question that residents are reaping the benefits of the town's expanded tax base, made larger because the self-contained office complexes do not drain police, fire or educational services. One indicator is that despite a school budget rise of 21 percent over the last two years, school taxes, which make up two-thirds of the total property tax bill, decreased by one-quarter of 1 percent in the same period.
This school year, 25 percent of the $19 million in school taxes was paid by the two companies. ''The fact that I.B.M. and Pepsi-Cola are totally on the tax rolls is an overall boon to the school district,'' said Joseph Sabatella, an assistant superintendent. ''We were able to put in new programs on all levels. Before you were seeing school tax increases of 7, 8, 9 percent a year.''
In addition, the town tax will not rise at all next year, compared to the 5 to 6 percent increases seen earlier in the 1980's, but Mr. Harding credits the cuts he has made in town spending more than the new corporate taxpayers. ''They are not the savior everyone said they would be,'' he said.
 
Frustrating Builders
Some large property owners and builders accuse Somers of being elitist and selfish in its new hard-line stance toward development. They argue that after taking its money and running, the town is now frustrating smaller builders who want to work there and young families who want to move there.
''Everyone who comes into Somers wants to be the last one here,'' said Robert L. Stuart, 37, who runs his family's 200-acre apple orchard and vegetable farm here. ''Most of them come up from the city, and they don't want to see it like White Plains or New Rochelle.''
Others praise I.B.M. and Pepsi-Cola for building on only a fraction of the nearly 1,000 acres in the two complexes. ''A quarter of a century from now, the town of Somers will still look semirural, and one of the reasons, shockingly, is I.B.M. and Pepsi-Cola because they have created so much green belt,'' said Jerry Billingsley, who owns a real-estate concern in Somers.
Many other residents, as well as town officials, have regrets, especially about I.B.M. But Pepsi-Cola has been a model member of the community, said Mr. Harding, with an intelligent, environmentally sensitive site plan and frequent contributions to the town, including a fireworks display last Fourth of July.
A nine-story building is used by 1,500 employees of the Pepsi-Cola Worldwide Beverage Corporation, a division of Pepsico. Employee traffic enters and exits directly onto I-684, avoiding tie-ups in town, and the pink-granite complex is inconspicuously built into a hillside.
 
Soil Erosion
But the 1.2 million-square-foot complex housing the 2,200 employees of I.B.M.'s manufacturing and development headquarters is, according to the Somers Planning Director, Edward Burroughs, a ''disaster,'' with problems of soil erosion, traffic and light pollution.
He added that mud and rain-borne oil from the 2,500 cars using the I.B.M. parking lot have cascaded into the Muscoot Reservoir, which feeds New York City's water supply. I.B.M. draws 750,000 gallons of water a day from the ground, but its parking lot is believed to prevent rain from recharging the ground water. Consequently, the levels of nearby wells have fallen.
''From a planning point of view it doesn't relate well to the land,'' Mr. Burroughs said. ''Having looked at several I.B.M. projects, I see their approach is to put them on top of a hill. It provides a nice view for them, but it sure doesn't blend well with the suburban topography.''
Mr. Burroughs said Pepsi-Cola's going before the town board in 1983 with a professional plan paved the way for I.B.M. the next year. ''After Pepsi, the assumption on the part of the town was that these corporations have a lot of money and know what they're doing, and I.B.M. coasted on that,'' he said.
In response to the town's criticisms, I.B.M. said it was unaware of any environmental trouble but vowed to look into the complaints. ''We have a corporate policy to protect the environment in communities where I.B.M. facilities are located, and if there is a problem and we determine that we are responsible, we will take the appropriate steps to correct it,'' said Jim Smith, an I.B.M. spokesman.
 
Not Paying Attention
The shift in the town's direction, from pro-development to pro-environment, came not during discussions about I.B.M. or Pepsi-Cola but right after, with a 1986 proposal for a giant shopping center. That same year saw the formation of the now-influential environmental organization, Save Our Somers.
''I wasn't paying attention, and I think probably a lot of people weren't paying attention when I.B.M. and Pepsi were before the board,'' said Nancy Mirman, chairwoman of Save Our Somers. ''But after the fact, people sat up and took notice. There was a feeling that there was too much development and that we were going to lose what many of us came here for.''
The organization gathered 2,500 signatures and helped defeat the shopping center plan. In 1987, it endorsed Mr. Harding for supervisor. ''It used to be that there was only one advocate for the environment on the board,'' Mrs. Mirman said. ''I remember his telling the others at a meeting that the town should protect the aquifers, and the other four members looked at him like he had four heads.''
 
A New Master Plan
Today's atmosphere has local builders seething. ''The proposed legislation is not designed to protect the environment,'' said Gus Boniello, a 33-year-old builder from neighboring Lewisboro. ''It is designed to completely devastate building in Somers.''
The proposed ordinances, which will now be reworked in light of the county's criticisms, seek to protect wetlands, ground water, meadows, scenic vistas, steep slopes and trees. The Town Planning Board is drafting a new master plan that is expected to zone up broad sections of the town by increasing the minimum size for building lots.
''The skids aren't greased like they were 10 years ago,'' Mr. Harding said. ''A guy comes in with 100 units, and I get him down to 70. Or I make the process so tough, some of them just blow away.''

HEADLINE: Santa Claus, North Pole, 33d Street

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
Each year about 18,000 letters addressed to Santa Claus arrive in Manhattan's General Post Office, and you can read them like a script for New York itself: tales of need and greed and shining expectation, of entitlement or estrangement, of a chance to get something for nothing, or even, at times, to gain nothing at all but the chance to give to someone else.
This year, Angela Tellez, 15 years old, wants sweaters (''size: medium in misses''). Isaias Noyola wants ''two Nintendo tapes like . . . Marble Madness. Please Please Please Please Please Please.'' And a correspondent who identified himself only as Fredrick seeks a box of diapers for his little sister: ''Luv's Deluxe, size medium for girls (pink).'' 
These and other dreams went on display yesterday in the lobby of the General Post Office at Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. Anyone can answer them, and many do. Shortly after noon, business executives, school groups, and other passersby began sifting through the piles, which will be available during business hours throughout December.
About 7,000 of them are answered each year, often anonymously, by strangers sending everything from toys to tombstones.
 
'See You Soon. Love Patty.'
''Dear Santa,'' began Patty Allen, 10. ''For Christmas could you buy me a dress and a pair of shoes...right now my mother doesn't work. Santa I want to thank you a wish you a Merry Christmas and Happy New Year. See you soon. Love Patty.''
Donna Figuera, the girl's mother, said her daughter, a fifth grader at P.S. 137 on the Lower East Side, wrote Santa for the first time last year and received Barbie dolls and clothes. Ms. Figuera said she is unable to give Christmas presents to Patty and her two sisters, Krystal Ortiz, 3, and Stephanie Ortiz, 5, because she is unemployed and gets only $231 a month in welfare.
In past years, it was only the grandchildren of Milagros Orta who wrote, but this season Mrs. Orta joined in. ''Dear Santa,'' she began. ''My name is Milagros. I'm 50 years old. I'm a sick lady with cancer. I'm always with pain in the body. I like a Quilt so I could be warm at night.''
Mrs. Orta said she moved to the United States from Puerto Rico when she was 13, and later spent 11 years working in a social service office, helping clients fill out benefit requests. Illness forced her to retire in 1979 - and seek benefits herself.
 
'It's Beautiful, You Know'
In her own situation she sees a reflection of New York's hardening from the beckoning city of the 1950's, in which she remembers reasonably priced food and shelter being widely available, to the harsh landscape of the late 1980's, in which her family must seek help from strangers.
In recent years, letters from her grandchildren have brought toys and clothes. ''There are people out there who care,'' she said. ''I couldn't be more grateful to them, deep in my heart. It's beautiful, you know. I cannot express it.''
This year her grandson, Willie Ortiz, who lives with her, said he wrote about 20 different letters.
But that's nothing compared with Olga Cespedes. At least 72 separate handwritten letters bore her Hayward, Calif., address. One of them explained that she and her mother came to the United States two years ago from Nicaragua, and that, of her mother's $550 monthly earnings, $300 goes to rent and $200 to food.
 
Bedroom Ensemble
Several letters carried her wish for a bedroom ensemble. ''Size full,'' specified one. 'Size queen,'' ordered another. ''Size twin'' read the third.
And why would the residents of Hayward be looking to Manhattan?
''In the past years, the program has gotten so much publicity - even Johnny Carson, who flashes the address - that we even get foreign letters,'' said Andy Sozzi, a postal employee who packed himself into a Santa outfit to kick off this year's program.
The correct address is Operation Santa Claus, Manhattan General Post Office, New York, N.Y., 10199-9641, but even letters that come through local post offices addressed North Pole, North Pole, have made their way into the piles.
 
'You Cut the Stone . . .'
This was the fourth year that Frank Stiefel took time out to sift through the boxes. His production company, Stiefel & Co., makes television commercials for clients like Chevrolet and Michelob, he said. Rather than send clients ''a bottle of Scotch or whatever dopey gift'' at Christmas time, the company chooses 30 to 40 letters and answers the requests in Santa's name. Then it forwards the letter to the clients, letting them know that the acts were undertaken in appreciation of their business relationship.
''Clients love it,'' he said, and so do the 17 members of his office, who shop for the gifts and wrap them.
''There was one a couple of years ago that was remarkable,'' he said. ''It came from a grandmother in California, and what she wanted was a headstone for her grandchild.'' Mr. Steifel said he called a tombstone maker and told him, ''If you cut the stone, we'll cut the check.''
Then, Mr. Steifel said, the tombstone maker ''went to visit the grandmother and found that the child had died six, seven years before, and they'd never been able to afford a stone.
''He called and said, 'You know what, don't cut the check. This is my gift.' ''
''I wished him a Merry Christmas,'' Mr. Stiefel said, ''And he thanked me - for giving him the chance to have a Merry Christmas.''

GRAPHIC: Stephanie Ortiz, 5 years old, who wrote to Santa with her sisters Patty Allen, 10, and Krystal Ortiz, 3. (NYT/Michelle V. Agins)

HEADLINE: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
Economists say the cost of illicit drugs to American society has risen substantially in the last few years, to far more than $60 billion annually. At the same time they are discovering vast new areas of additional economic impact that they are only now beginning to understand.
The new estimate for the annual total cost is based on the first major Federal study since 1984 of the adverse economic effects of drug addiction, and according to the researchers it represents an increase since 1985 of more than $10 billion, even after discounting for inflation. Increased medical costs for crack addicts and drug-addicted AIDS patients represent a significant portion of the rising expense.
''It's clear that for 1989, the cost of drugs on society is tremendous, far more than $60 billion,'' said Dorothy Rice, a former director of national health statistics at the Federal Department of Health and Human Services and a medical economist who was commissioned by the Government to conduct the study. Full details of the report will not be released until next month, but officials made known its major findings in recent interviews. 
The newly detected areas of economic impact - unexpectedly large cash surpluses that have appeared in some Federal Reserve Banks and artificially altered real estate values -are being explored on campuses and at Government agencies that are trying to set drug, health, economic and foreign policies and enforcing existing laws against money laundering. The medical bills for drug abusers and victims of drug-related crimes, along with the expenses incurred in expanding law enforcement systems, are other important factors adding to the increased costs.
Economists say the current estimates do in fact amount to a staggering price tag. Medical experts compare the drug cost to the enormous economic effects of the nation's battle against cancer, which the American Cancer Society estimates at about $70 billion annually.
 
Offset by Cigarette Taxes
A recent Rand Corporation study pointed out that the price paid by society for cigarette smoking is completely offset by Federal and state taxes on cigarette sales, but there are no similar revenues generated by illegal drugs.
The costs to some extent are offset at least in the short term by large amounts of cash accumulated by the illegal drug industry, which invests much of that money in legitimate enterprises. But no one knows how to assess that effect, and it is believed to be short-lived.
''The study means that narcotics is one of America's major industries, right up there with consumer electronics, automobiles and steelmaking,'' said Robert B. Reich, a political economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Goverment at Harvard University. ''Unlike our other major industries, however, the narcotics industry doesn't have a net effect of creating wealth. It makes us all substantially poorer. In fact, it is like a reverse industry, tearing things down rather than producing anything.''
Economists readily acknowledge that figures in economic research on drugs are always difficult to obtain. ''It's a very, very tough area to work in because of the assumptions that have to be made and the available data,'' said Al Harwood, an official at the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Rockville, Md., who has been overseeing the latest study.
But he said the recent analyses were more accurate because of advances in gathering basic data and computerizing statistics. More specific costs of drug-related treatment are now available, for example, as well as better information on worker absenteeism and drug-related budgets for local, state and Federal criminal enforcement programs.
 
The Cost for Addicted Infants
One cost growing at an alarming rate is treatment for infants addicted to drugs, said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, who notes that intensive-care costs alone last year reached $2.5 billion. He said Federal and local governments would soon be spending $15 billion annually to prepare addicted children to enter kindergarten and at least $6 billion more a year to get them through high school.
It is in the broader areas of international and local economies that experts are seeing effects they had not been fully aware of or studied before.
The sudden flow of large amounts of cash in and out of the banking centers of some urban areas is believed to be related to illegal drug profits that are ultimately draining money out of local economies, though where and how is not known.
According to a report by the Federal Reserve, for the first six months of 1989, the Miami Federal Reserve branch reported a cash surplus of $2.8 billion, Los Angeles $2.7 billion, Jacksonville $1.5 billion and San Antonio $1.2 billion. Houston, El Paso and New Orleans all experienced large increases of cash surpluses as well, from 219 percent to 56 percent. Surpluses in Miami and Los Angeles are growing by 10 percent annually.
The Federal Reserve says it believes that these surpluses are drug related, especially since the increases coincide with record-breaking drug seizures in these cities.
 
Hard Cash Disappears
A more direct effect is the disappearance of hard cash. Over all, the drug industry is contributing to the unaccounted loss of billions in currency from the economy. Experts estimate that perhaps $125 billion in American currency is ''missing.'' Much of it is said to be used in illegal drug and arms transactions, often winding up in foreign banks and markets. It forms the basis for an enormous tax-free underground economy.
According to a study by the Treasury Department, the preferred denominations for drug transactions are $10 and $20 bills. The study, which examined the possibility of withdrawing $100 notes from the economy, says law enforcement agencies around the nation say that $100 notes account for 25 to 30 percent of the currency seized in drug raids and arrests.
New patterns of flight capital, particularly from Peru, Colombia and Bolivia, are also being perceived by economists. Most of the cocaine smuggled into the United States and Europe is processed from coca plants grown in the Andes.
 
Drug Profits Invested
The Latin drug dealers have traditionally moved a substantial share of their profits out of their relatively poor and unstable countries, adding to economic and political difficulties there, and reinvested the money in apparently legitimate enterprises in North America and Europe. A major share now, however, is going to Hong Kong, where the money is said to be easier to conceal. Indeed, officials say, Hong Kong has become an international center for drug-money laundering.
Experts estimate that as much as $250 billion in assets owned by Latin Americans is invested abroad. A recent report by the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control concludes that most of the world's cocaine profits do not return to producer countries but are invested in tax havens, offshore bank accounts and real estate abroad.
In those instances where some money does remain in these drug producing nations, it is not used to help build a solid economy. ''Cocaine traffickers are not captains of industry like the Harrimans, Rockefellers and Carnegies of yore,'' said Rensselaer W. Lee 3d, a consultant who is teaching at George Washington University. The way the narcotics traders ''invest'' their money locally, he added, was in bribing law enforcement officials, operating assassination squads and buying arms.
 
A Lift for Peasants
Nevertheless, the report by the House Select Committee notes, the cocaine industry has ''revolutionized expectations and aspirations within Andean societies, for peasants especially.'' It added, ''Television sets, videocassette recorders, stereos and cars have become attainable.''
Thus the cocaine trade has spawned new constituencies that place new demands on Andean political systems. And, as Mr. Lee put it, entire regions of South America have come to depend economically on coca cultivation.
In Boliva alone, where the export of legal goods is about $800 million each year, illegal cocaine exports may exceed that amount. As a result, the drug industry has become an institutionalized source of many jobs. It is estimated that 1.5 million people are employed in Andian production of cocaine and as many as 50,000 work in marijuana production in Colombia alone.
 
'A Safety Valve'
So for the short term at least, the drug industry clearly has some value, both economically and as a temporary relief from political tensions. ''Cocaine has acted as a safety valve for the Andean countries where the economy fails to deliver,'' Mr. Lee said. ''This substitution is most advanced in Peru and Bolivia, which have performed poorly on nearly every economic front in this decade.''
The broad effect of drug-money laundering on local economies in the United States is being seen by bank regulators who have discovered unusually large numbers of cash sales of real estate, automobiles and boats evidently financed with drug money. In Dade County, Fla., economists have estimated that as much as 2 to 10 percent of the area's business boom has been driven by drug profits, often transacted in cash.
''Either there's a lot of tourists not using credit cards or there's lots of drug money,'' said Dexter Lehtinen, the United States Attorney in Miami. Mr. Lehtinen said that in Miami, some $220 million in cash has been spent on automobiles in the last three years, while Jacksonville and Tampa had about $24 million in cash sales of cars in the same period. And in parts of southern Florida as much as 20 percent of the transactions for real estate are in cash.
 
Inflated Prices Seen
Some local officials and prosecutors say that while these sales may prove lucrative to sellers, they have the effect of inflating the price of real estate and causing property taxes to increase as assessments go up. Of course, values of many inner-city properties are also seriously deflated because of the drug business.
Real estate transactions represent only a small piece of drug investments. As regulatory barriers that had limited international investments are being removed, and as stock and currency markets become global, narcotics profiteers are finding it easier to conceal their illegally earned wealth.
''The transferring of profits to avoid tax liability, and hedge and insurance trading are becoming commonplace,'' said R. Thomas Naylor, a professor at McGill University in Montreal who specializes in the underground economy. ''There has become a blurring of the line between the behavior of legal and illegal money.''

HEADLINE: U S West In Budapest Phone Deal

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
U S West Inc., one of the nation's seven regional Bell telephone companies, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Hungary to build a mobile cellular telephone system in Budapest.
The Hungarian cellular system will be the first such telephone network to be constructed in Eastern Europe. Because of the shortage of telephones in the nation, Hungarians are expected to use cellular telephones for basic home service, as well as mobile communications.
For Hungary and the other Eastern European countries, which have antiquated telephone systems, it will be faster and cheaper for the Government to deliver telephone service by cellular networks than it would be to rebuild the nation's entire telephone infrastructure. 
 
At First, Only Budapest
A cellular telephone network transmits calls on radio waves to small receiving antennas, called ''cell'' sites, that relay the calls to local phone systems. The system to be built in Hungary, which is viewed as an alternative until the country can develop its infrastructure, will transmit calls from cellular phone to cellular phone and through the existing land-based telephone network.
The system, which is scheduled to go into operation in the first quarter of 1991, will initially provide cellular communications to Budapest's 2.1 million residents. Eventually, the system will serve all of Hungary, which has 10.6 million citizens.
Hungary currently has 6.8 telephone lines for every 100 people, according to The World's Telephones, a statistical compilation produced by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. By comparison, the United States has 48.1 lines for every 100 people. Demand for telephone service in Hungary exceeds supply by 300,000 to 500,000 lines, industry analysts said.
U S West, based in Denver, said that under the agreement it would own and operate 49 percent of the cellular network and that Magyar Posta, the Hungarian postal, telegraph and telephone organization, would retain the rest.
Because the Hungarian cellular telephone system will rely on sophisticated computer software, U S West needs the approval of the 16-nation Coordinating Committee for Strategic Exports, or Cocom, to build the network. Cocom limits the transfer of technology from Western countries to the Eastern bloc.
 
'A Prime Place'
Dick Callahan, president of U S West Diversified Group, said he was certain the company would receive Cocom approval because the Bush Administration has said it was considering relaxing some Cocom restrictions on technology transfers for Eastern Europe and because the technology has been available for a number of years and does not have sensitive military applications. ''Our view is that of the Eastern European countries, Hungary is the most open to adapting to change and that makes it a prime place to do business,'' Mr. Callahan said.
Cellular telephones, said Diana Munger, manager of telecommuncations and East West affairs for the United States Council for International Business, ''are very tempting prospects for countries whose telecommunication infrastructure is undeveloped. She added: It's a cheap, rapid upgrade because there is no need to tear up the streets and install miles of cable.''
Joel Gross, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said: ''It's a good move because it gives U S West a foothold in Eastern Europe and shows other countries what they can do. I think they can leverage this into other opportunities. It's hard to impugn this move because we have no sense of the long-term economic or political risks.''
 
One-Time Connection Fee
Mr. Callahan of U S West said that the price of cellular service in Hungary would be considerably less than it is in the United States because the capital costs for property and equipment for the network are much less.
Hungarians would pay a one-time connection fee and be billed a monthly charge. As in the United States, the cost of using the new service will be more expensive in Hungary than the regular service.
U S West said that its cellular telephone and NewVector Group divisions will provide operational management for the project, including technical assistance, design and marketing. Magyar Posta will provide interconnection services, engineering and construction.
The first phase of the project that will bring cellular telephone service to Budapest will cost about $10 million, which U S West and Magyar Posta will split.
Analysts said they did not expect U S West to make a profit on the deal until the middle of the upcoming decade at the earliest, and added that there was a great deal of uncertainty, given the current political and economic turmoil, about how or whether hard currency would be forthcoming from Hungary. They also noted that while it was difficult to place a value on the cellular venture, a $5 million investment did not constitute a considerable risk for a $9 billion company.
 
A Personal Link
U S West said it had been negotiating with Hungary to build the cellular system since last summer and that initial talks were the result of the close ties that U S West's international group vice president, Andres Bande, whose grandparents are Hungarian, has with the Government.
A typical cellular system in a major city can accommodate several hundred thousand users because it divides the area into the small ''cell'' sites. Each cell has an antenna that covers an area no more than 50 miles across and can transmit and pick up thousands of calls simultaneously.
As a customer moves from one cell to another, the call is transferred from one cell antenna to another, without the customer realizing the signal has been shifted to keep it strong. The computer software that shifts the call from cell to cell is the part of the cellular system that is subject to Cocom approval.
The cells relay the radio waves to a centralized computer called a mobile telephone switching office that connects the calls with the local telephone network.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Steel Importers' Trade Plea

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Steel importers said yesterday that fair-trade laws were being abused to protect United States steel companies from foreign competition and urged an international trading body to examine the issue.
The importers directed criticism at anti-dumping laws, which are intended to prevent foreign companies from selling in the United States at unfairly low prices. 
Foreign producers can run afoul of anti-dumping laws through no fault of their own, simply because of a drop in the dollar's value, the American Institute for Imported Steel contended at a New York news conference.
A consultant for the trade group said in an interview that Commerce Department officials had admitted to him that they selectively prosecuted foreign companies under anti-dumping laws as a warning to others.
''They were actually proud of using the laws somewhat unevenly - just to keep the foreign producers on their toes,'' said Hans Mueller, an economics professor at Middle Tennessee State University.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chase Names Director Of Securities Activity

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Commercial banks are pushing hard to combine their recently gained powers to trade and sell corporate bonds with other financings like interest-rate swaps or interest-rate caps and floors.
As part of that effort, Walter J. Mullen 3d was named yesterday as managing director in charge of coordinating the swaps and securities activities at Chase Securities, an arm of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
In rate swaps, two borrowers agree to exchange interest-rate payments, believing that the type of payment they will be making, at either a fixed or floating rate, will fit better into their financial plans. As part of his new job, Mr. Mullen will also oversee the issuance of instruments that are often sold in conjunction with swaps, like commercial paper and short-term bank loan participations. 
Mr. Mullen, 40 years old, will be coming to Chase from the Security Pacific Corporation, where he specialized in showing companies how to use new financing products. He said he sees rate swaps and related businesses as an area ''where banks are on a level, or slightly superior, playing field to the securities firms.''
There is a tendency among securities firms, he said, to regard the swaps business as ''an ornament'' to their primary business of selling securities like stocks and bonds. The merging of Chase's established swaps and related businesses with the banking company's newer venture in the securities markets ''is clearly the avenue for the most growth and profit,'' Mr. Mullen said.
Rate swaps require a mastery of mathematics and the business sense to apply them to a company's particular need. They also require skills in persuading a corporate treasurer that they help protect against the risks of fluctuating interest rates. Since it was invented in 1980, the rate swap market has grown to $1 trillion outstanding.
Mr. Mullen, who is known as Jack, started his career at the Commercial Credit Corporation, where he was one of the first corporate financiers using swaps. He also held a position at the First National Bank of Chicago.
Mr. Mullen said his job at Chase would be to manage a staff of experts, ''to serve as a sounding board for their ideas, and to take the ideas that work and apply them through the group.''
Mr. Mullen, who lives in Scarsdale, N.Y., with his wife, Carol, and three children, is a fitness enthusiast. ''Physical fitness is a requirement for mental fitness,'' he said, adding that he plays basketball and golf.
Born in Columbia, S.C., Mr. Mullen received a bachelor's degree from the University of Maryland and an M.B.A. from Loyola University in Baltimore.

HEADLINE: Home Sales Down 0.5% In October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Government reported today. Analysts said that overall purchases were driven down by a 24.7 percent decline in the West because of the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake and the effects of the slowing economy.
But economists said the sales pace should improve somewhat in coming months as mortgage interest rates drop to the mid-9 percent range. No analyst predicted a surge in sales. 
''The report says that housing market activity has improved some from the sluggish pace of March and February, but that the market is by no means taking off,'' said Thomas Holloway, senior economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
 
Gains in Most Regions
The Commerce Department said new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 649,000 in October, after a revised 10.2 percent plunge in September. The Government originally reported that sales in September declined 14 percent.
Sales in the West fell 53,000 units on an annual basis, to 161,000 homes. But all other regions reported gains. David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, said that ''the earthquake appeared to keep people from buying new homes.''
Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said economic sluggishness also contributed to the lack of sales in the West. Part of the problem, he said, was slower military spending, which resulted in layoffs.
Home sales had fallen significantly earlier this year as the Federal Reserve Board pumped up interest rates to slow the economy and contain inflation. As inflationary pressures cooled, however, the Fed has permitted gradual decreases in rates.
The interest rate on fixed-rate mortgages fell to an average of 9.82 percent at the end of October, after rising into the double digits in September, according to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
The Commerce Department said the median price of a new home in October rose 5.3 percent, to $127,900. The median means half of the homes cost more and half less. The average price of a new home was unchanged at $151,900. The National Association of Realtors reported today that the median price of an existing single-family home was $92,100.
New-home sales in the Northeast rose 47.8 percent, but Mr. Berson of Fannie Mae said that reflected a low September sales count rather than growing market strength.
The South posted a 5.7 percent increase, while the Midwest recorded a 3.7 percent gain.
New-home sales for the first nine months of the year were down 4.4 percent from the corresponding period in 1988.

HEADLINE: Durables Lead Factory Orders Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
New orders for manufactured goods fell for the second consecutive month in October, the Government said today, in a new sign of slack economic growth.
Much of the manufacturing weakness was concentrated in the durable goods sector, where computer and auto equipment orders fell sharply. But healthy demand for nondurables, like food and chemicals, helped temper the October fall, leaving it down two-tenths of 1 percent, at $233.9 billion. 
The factory order figures buttressed other indicators showing a sluggish pace of growth in the manufacturing sector.
 
Fed Action Predicted
Economists said the Federal Reserve may soon have to relax credit to prevent the slowdown from worsening.
''The whole durable goods sector has clearly lost momentum, but in the soft goods area, like food and chemicals, there is still a good deal of strength,'' said Norman Robertson, an economist with the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
''Manufacturing output is going to remain rather flat into the first quarter of 1990,'' he added.
The decline in October orders came after a revised 1 percent drop in September, with both months heavily influenced by a swing in military orders. Excluding this category, orders rose three-tenths of 1 percent in October, after falling 2.2 percent in September.
The Government had originally reported that total factory orders in September had been unchanged.
Factory orders have been hurt by a decline in orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods, items like appliances, cars and industrial equipment that are expected to last more than three years. If the Fed eases credit, those orders, which are often financed by borrowing, could benefit.
The Commerce Department said orders for non-electrical machinery slumped 6.7 percent, with a decline in office and computing equipment accounting for 40 percent of the fall. The category also includes engines and turbines and construction and mining equipment.
Orders for automotive equipment declined 3.1 percent, after falling 13.7 percent in September.
''Much of the pervasive weakness in the durable goods sector is concentrated in the auto industry and its suppliers,'' Mr. Robertson said.
The auto downturn was offset by a 3.9 percent rise in aircraft orders, lifting the entire transportation sector 1.7 percent in October, after a 10.8 percent drop in September.
Excluding the transportation sector from both months, factory orders fell five-tenths of 1 percent, after a climb of eight-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Military orders for capital goods, which soared 33.7 percent in September, fell 12.1 percent in October. Nonmilitary capital goods orders, which are considered a broad indicator of business investment, fell 1.8 percent in October.
Unfilled orders by factories rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in October, but the Commerce Department said backlogs have been shrinking since February, excluding the transportation sector.
Shipments declined six-tenths of 1 percent, marking the seventh monthly decline this year.

HEADLINE: Stocks Extend Gain as Dow Advances 5.98

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Stock prices extended their gains yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 5.98 points, to 2,753.63.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 150.4 million, compared with 199.2 million on Friday, and 810 issues rose in price while 708 fell.
On Friday, the market surged to its 10th-highest close, and some traders hoped that as the economy eased and the summit meeting in Malta progressed, credit would be eased.
 
Waiting for a Signal
The traders said the market was awaiting a signal from the Federal Reserve on its credit policy, but few expected an easing until the Government employment figures for November are released on Friday. 
The Dow utility average climbed a slight 0.44 point yesterday, to 228.24, a historic high, making it the first of any widely watched market index to reach a high since the Oct. 13 decline of 190 points. The advance of the utilities reflects the widely held expectation among investors that interest rates are headed down. Historically, utilities offer attractive returns in such an investment climate.
Shares of Texas Utilities Company, a Dallas-based electric utility, advanced 5/8, to 35 5/8. With more than 4.6 million shares changing hands, the utility was the most heavily traded issue on the Big Board. A spokesman for the company said the heavy trading was dividend related.
Among the most active issues, USX advanced 3, to 37 3/4, on heavy trading after a report that the investor Carl C. Icahn was considering a $50-a-share offer for the giant energy and steel conglomerate. Mr. Icahn holds 13.6 percent of the company's shares.
Technology issues advanced broadly. International Business Machines moved up 2 1/8, to 99 1/4, after Data Switch introduced a component switch for I.B.M. computers.
Among other technology issues, Cray Research moved up 3 1/8, to 36 5/8, as favorable long-term prospects, which includes the outlook for a recently completed Cray computer, encouraged investors. Some analysts released higher earnings forecasts for the supercomputer maker.
Digital Equipment jumped 3, to 88; Honeywell gained 2 5/8 to end at 82 7/8; Microsoft moved up 1 1/4 points, to 86 1/4; Apple Computer advanced 1 1/4, to 45 1/4, and Intel Corporation rose 1/2, to 35 3/4.
Mattel Inc. rose 1 5/8, to 18 7/8, after the company announced that it expects a 25 percent rise in sales of its entire line of toys in the fourth quarter. Sales of the company's Barbie doll are expected to reach $600 million this year, far above the $100 million in sales last year.
Shares of First Interstate Bancorp rose 2 1/2, to 53 3/4, but spokesmen for the bank said the company knew of no reason for the run-up in its stock.
L. A. Gear gained 2 1/4 to end at 35 1/4 after the sneaker maker reported sharply higher sales and orders. Nike, another sports shoes maker, lost ground, falling 1, to 55 3/4.
The Dow transportation average moved up a sharp 15.29 points, largely on the gains made by UAL. Shares of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, rose 5 1/2, to 179 1/2, on news that Coniston Partners had raised its stake in the airline company and met with its management and unions to discuss a transaction designed to lift the stock price. Coniston, a New York-based investment firm, has said it plans to oust management and pursue an extraordinary transaction. Coniston raised its holding in the company to around 11.8 percent, from 9.7 percent.
Shares of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, rose 1 to close at 66 1/2.
 
Broader Indexes
Among broader market indexes, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was up a slight 0.78, to 351.41, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained only 0.41, to end at 194.07.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index lost a slight 0.92 to end at 374.66.
The Nasdaq composite index advanced 1.18 points, to 458.28. Among the most active over-the-counter issues, MCI Communications was down 1/8, to 44 3/4, on fairly heavy trading. The company announced that it was considering a common dividend.
Lin Broadcasting, which was up 1 1/2, to 121 5/8, announced after the close of the market that its board would recommend that shareholders accept a revised buyout offer from McCaw Cellular, which was up 3/4, to 39 1/4.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Mixed in Light Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very light trading yesterday, as market participants pointed to the release of November employment data on Friday.
''With the exception of a holiday period, this is the slowest trading day I have ever seen, and as far as I know this is not a holiday,'' one government bond trader said.
''A lot of it has to do with the fact that market participants are placing a lot of importance on the employment numbers at the end of the week, and have already established their positions in advance of that report.''
MMS International, an economic information service firm, said in its daily commentary that ''release of the Fed's tan book on Wednesday may be the only hope for volatility ahead of the employment data,'' referring to the Federal Reserve's economic survey of regional Federal Reserve banks. It added, ''We still expect Fed easing and higher Treasury prices before 1989 comes to a close, but for now patience will be the key.'' 
 
Major Commodity Prices
By focusing on the employment figures, traders yesteday tended to ignore a big drop in the major commodity prices that make up the Commodity Research Bureau's price index, as well as a $12.50-an-ounce decline in gold prices, to $401.10. Some credit market analysts have cited the recent run-up in gold prices as a major impediment to higher bond prices.
The fact that participants did not respond to what should have been positive developments disquieted some portfolio managers.
''The market has been getting an unending stream of good news, and yet it can't move ahead,'' said Roger A. Craig, manager of the fixed-income department at the Banc One Asset Management Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. ''I am beginning to think the market is way ahead of itself. If that is correct, at best prices are going to stay where they are and at worst they could sell off.''
Yesterday bond prices did marginally better than note issues in the secondary Treasury securities market.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 7/8, up 1/32, to yield 7.87 percent.
 
Ten-Year Note Offering
Meanwhile, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 14/32 in late trading, down 2/32, to yield 7.81 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, down 2/32, to yield 7.71 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction, interest rates eased slightly on the new three- and six-month securities.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.55 percent, down from an average rate of 7.63 percent a week ago.
Six-month bills were offered at an average rate of 7.30 percent, down from 7.45 percent at last week's auction.
New corporate issues priced yesterday included an offering of $250 million of three-month floating rate notes from the Chrysler Financial Corporation.
The notes, which have a final maturity date of Dec. 9, 1992, were priced at 5/16 of a percentage point over the prevailing yield on the three-month London interbank offered rate. The notes will reset and pay interest quarterly. The first rate will be set on Dec. 11.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues rose by 1/8 of a point to 1/4 of a point in sluggish trading.

HEADLINE: Justices to Decide if Citibank Must Pay on Foreign Deposit

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether American banks, which ordinarily are not liable for deposits made in their foreign branch offices, must use their worldwide assets to repay depositors when a foreign government closes a branch or otherwise makes a normal repayment impossible.
The case is an appeal by Citibank of a ruling last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, which held Citibank liable for repaying two $1 million certificates of deposit that its Manila branch had issued in 1983 to a Singapore subsidiary of the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco.
That ruling caused widespread concern among American banks with foreign branches and among Federal bank regulators. Nearly 900 foreign branches of 171 federally chartered banks hold some $240 billion in deposits, according to the Federal Reserve Board. 
 
Order by Philippines
The branch could not repay the six-month deposits because late in 1983 the Philippine Government issued an emergency economic order barring banks from sending dollars out of the country. The deposits were in Eurodollars, a term for dollars held by banks outside the United States and payable outside the United States.
The appeal, Citibank v. Wells Fargo Asia Ltd., No. 88-1260, raises two interrelated questions.
The first question concerns the characteristic of Eurodollar accounts in foreign branches. The appeals court acknowledged that under general banking law principles, a deposit at a domestic or foreign branch is the obligation of that branch alone. But the appeals court said it was creating an exception in this case based on its finding that the two banks, in agreeing that repayment would be made by wire transfer through corresponding banks in New York, had in effect agreed in advance that the general rule insulating branch deposits would not apply.
 
Operation of Market Cited
The Federal Government, urging the Supreme Court to hear the appeal and overturn that finding, said the appeals court's conclusion was ''contrary to the actual operation of the Eurodollar market.'' The Government said that while repayment on such accounts was often made by wire transfers through New York, these ''standard routing instructions'' should not be interpreted to change the nature of the deposits from foreign to domestic ones.
''The court of appeals has made a serious mistake with potentially far-reaching consequences,'' the Government's brief said.
The second issue in the case goes beyond Eurodollar deposits to the more general question of whether the home office may ever be required to make good on deposits in foreign branches. Many Federal bank regulations, such as reserve requirements, do not apply to foreign branches, and as a result, these branches are often able to offer higher interest rates. Foreign deposits are not protected by Federal deposit insurance.
 
Distinctions Ignored
Citibank, which is a subsidiary of Citicorp, is arguing that it has long been understood that foreign depositors bear risks to which domestic deposits are not subject. The appeals court ignored the distinctions that banking policy makes between domestic and foreign deposits, the bank told the Court.
The appeal was also supported by the New York Clearing House, an organization of 12 leading commercial banks. It said that the appeals court's decision ''provides a blueprint for the waging of economic warfare against the United States'' and would encourage foreign governments to confiscate the foreign assets of American banks.
The Court took no action today on a related appeal by Citibank. The bank was found liable last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, for repaying a $1,400 deposit a Vietnamese customer had made in the bank's Saigon branch in 1974. The branch was confiscated the next year by the victorious North Vietnamese. In the appeals court, Citibank argued unsuccessfully that it retained no obligation for the Vietnamese deposits once it lost the branch.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Closes Mixed As Traders Focus on Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against major foreign currencies yesterday as traders renewed their interest in the West German mark.
Marc Chandler of Money Market Services International in Chicago said currency dealers directed attention mainly to the mark and bought on speculation that West Germany will have to raise interest rates to stem a possible surge in economic growth.
The Swiss franc was weighed down by heavy selling related to Switzerland's lower interest rates compared with its European neighbors, particularly West Germany, Mr. Chandler said. 
Trading in dollars is expected to be light this week before Friday's report on domestic unemployment.
 
Little Effect in Factory Report
A Government report that United States factory orders fell two-tenths of 1 percent in October evoked little reaction among dollar traders although it reinforced the notion that economic growth is sluggish.
Currency dealers overseas, meanwhile, were said to be closing out positions before the end of the year. Market volume tends to decline toward the end of the year, when dealers are hesitant to risk profits or add to losses.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.48 Japanese yen, up from 143.08 on Friday. Later, in London, it rose to 143.57 yen and, in New York, to 143.65, from 143.40 late Friday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.5638, from $1.5665 late Friday. In New York, the pound fell to $1.56225, from $1.5625 late Friday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes included: 1.78425 West German marks, down from 1.7865; 1.6065 Swiss francs, up from 1.5995; 6.0915 French francs, down from 6.1020; 1,314.50 Italian lire, down from 1,316.50, and 1.16365 Canadian dollars, down from 1.6505.
Precious metals prices declined in what dealers described as a technically motivated correction to a recent powerful run-up.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $406.25 an ounce, from $414 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $408, from $415 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.79, to close at $409.31.
Silver for current delivery slid to $5.509 an ounce, from $5.663 Friday on New York's Comex. Silver fell in London to a late bid price of $5.60 an ounce, from $5.70 bid late Friday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metal Prices Fall After the Summit Meeting

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Precious metals prices tumbled yesterday, and dealers said the decline came in part because the weekend summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev raised promises of reduced global tensions.
The recent strength of the United States stock market added further pressure on gold prices, which carried over into the silver and platinum markets, the dealers said.
At the close on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot December gold delivery settled at $401.10 an ounce, down $12.50 on the day, while the more active February 1990 contract plunged $12.70, to $406.60. The spot December Comex silver delivery settled at $5.525 an ounce, down 15.4 cents, with the more active March contract off 15.8 cents, at $5.63. 
The spot January platinum delivery settled at $503.50 an ounce, down $17 at the New York Mercantile Exchange. The more distant precious metals deliveries are, the higher the price because futures contract prices are calculated to include such costs as storage, insurance and financing.
''Just as gold prices began to climb in Asia right after the Oct. 13 stock market break, it was selling from Asians that triggered today's big setback,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''The selling from the Far East was then followed by considerable unloading by the Swiss and other European interests. So when the Comex opened traders just followed suit. Then a number of technical factors took over.''
Ms. Raptopoulos noted that the weakness in precious metals actually began last week, when many traders started to convert some recent profits into cash or, in the case of institutional investors, began to move back into the equities market in anticipation of a year-end rally. Last week, the spot December Comex gold contract fell $5.70, for example.
Frederick R. Demler, metals economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said the biggest bearish technical factor in gold was the failure of the February contract to stay above $412. Some metals market analysts believe that $412 was the trigger for sell orders for gold because most of the trading above that price represented buying by smaller investors and other latecomers to the market. Why $412? Mr. Demler said the reasons that programmers of computer trading strategies choose particular levels for buying and selling varied.
In any event, Mr. Demler said silver and platinum markets simply followed the gold market, adding: ''The selling was most pronounced in silver after it failed to hold above $6. As for platinum, the thinnest of the precious metals markets, it, too, followed gold although both South Africa and the Soviet Union seem to have reduced their sales of late.''

HEADLINE: Careers;
Positive Outlook on Employment in 1990

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
CITING the results of Manpower Inc.'s latest quarterly employment survey, Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of the large international supplier of temporary help, spoke last week of a ''soft landing'' for the economy, not a recession, in 1990.
Manpower, based in Milwaukee, surveyed the managers of more than 14,000 large and small businesses; it found that 65 percent planned no changes in staff size in the first quarter, while 20 percent said they expected to increase their work forces and 12 percent planned cutbacks. The percentages are strikingly similar to those that Manpower found a year ago.
Mr. Fromstein's optimism comes at a time when many people in the New York City area are losing their jobs. Some 1,700 B. Altman & Company employees face unemployment when that retail chain ceases operations, and hundreds of workers on Wall Street are to be dismissed as Merrill Lynch & Company and other brokerage firms pare their operations. Many of the jobs cut in these corporate revampings are in middle management. 
Stressing geographic differences, Mr. Fromstein agreed that in the Northeast there would be an overall drop in hiring but that in some other regions staffing is expected to remain at or near the levels of 1989.
''I would say that anything that looks encouraging like this study would apply to all levels of employment,'' Mr. Fromstein said. ''I am cautiously optimistic. What we don't know is if this hiring strength is driven by economic or demographic conditions.''
A similar view was expressed by the human resources outlook panel of the Conference Board, a New York-based research group that is supported by many corporations. Audrey Freedman, management counselor of the Conference Board and author of many of its reports, summed up the main finding at a recent panel discussion: the economy will avoid a recession next year.
She also emphasized the panel's prediction that ''labor shortages will force companies to hire individuals they would not have employed previously.'' This group of potential workers includes women and recent immigrants.
One panelist, Irving Margol, who is executive vice president, management services group, of Security Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles, said the bank had been advertising for workers in foreign-language newspapers as well as on foreign-language radio and television stations.
''We are also recruiting at shopping malls, sporting events and putting up signs in buses,'' he said.
The obvious conclusion is that companies will be forced to spend more time and dollars not only on recruitment, but also on training newcomers. Training for specific jobs is already a growth industry.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Fromstein spoke about companies' growing demand for Manpower to train their employees. ''We have trained about 285,000 workers, including our own temporaries as well as permanent employees of many of our customers,'' he said.
Training takes on even more importance as corporate managers realize that the United States ''cannot remain competitive without raising productivity of its workers,'' said Mrs. Freedman of the Conference Board. Higher productivity requires lowering costs through more efficient production. ''Only better management of resources - human and capital - can improve it,'' she said.
In a Conference Board study issued a few weeks ago, Mrs. Freedman warned that the nation's living standards would decline in the next decade unless companies raise their productivity.
Manufacturing productivity will continue to rise, advancing about 3 percent in 1990, Mrs. Freedman predicted - a figure in line with annual increases during the 1980's. Agriculture, too, can be counted on to increase productivity in the 1990's in areas like grains, cotton, tobacco, vegetables and fruit, said Mrs. Freedman, who added that telecommunications would be the ''brightest spot'' with annual increases of about 4 percent.
But she estimated that productivity would grow by ''less than 2 percent a year'' in the 1990's in the service industries, like retailing, real estate and professional services.
Among the barriers to productivity gains, Mrs. Freedman said, are failure to communicate with workers, inefficient use of technology, bureaucratic stifling of creativity, and managements that seek to cement their control over a company rather than develop entrepreneurial strategies.Blue Arrowd(manpower)

SECTION: Section A; Page 35, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1077 words

HEADLINE: The Twilight of Superpower Summits

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is director of Soviet studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, said recently that Moscow ''feels immeasurably more comfortable in the international arena than ever before.'' After last weekend's meeting at Malta between George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev, Soviet leaders are entitled to relax still further: Soviet-American relations have never been so free of irritants.
Virtually nothing remains on the agenda of issues that divided Moscow and Washington during the past decade. Arms control negotiators, once obliged to protect each side's right to modernize its forces, have now been instructed to keep pace with the desire for deeper and deeper cuts. 
The issue of human rights has been similarly transformed. Once a clash of values, at Malta it was a mere review of technicalities. Now that Soviet officials have explained their legislative calendar for passing a new bill on free emigration, working groups will meet to lift the trade restrictions of the Jackson-Vanik Amendment. Secretary of State James Baker has even mused about the circumstances in which the U.S. might not object to the Soviet use of force in preserving domestic order.
As for arms shipments to Central America, which Mr. Baker identified beforehand as the most contentious item for discussion, the President seems to have concluded that Cuba and Nicaragua are keeping their Soviet patron in the dark. Once the beating heart of an evil empire, Moscow is now gently chided for being out of the loop.
The new ''I'm O.K., You're O.K.'' mood is an achievement for Mr. Gorbachev. With it, he has brought Bush Administration policy into line with the far more enthusiastic view of perestroika that has prevailed in Europe, both East and West.
Yet, there is an irony in the timing of this conversion. The Americans have joined the party at the very moment that Soviet relations with Europe may be taking a turn for the worse.
West Germany is the outstanding example. Mr. Gorbachev's trip to the Federal Republic in June, and his part in weakening the East German regime, have given him immense personal popularity. He has neverthless had to spend the past month growling at West German leaders.
German unity, Mr. Gorbachev insists, is not open to discussion; ''history will decide'' the fate of the German states. Ignoring such warnings, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has built a domestic consensus in favor of challenging the status quo.
Attacking this consensus head-on will take a toll on Soviet-West German amity. But there is hardly more promise for Moscow in the indirect route of trying to rally Bonn's allies against reunification. Mr. Gorbachev will discover when he meets President Francois Mitterrand of France tomorrow that West Germany is too important to its partners in the European Community for them to break ranks on this issue.
Soviet frustration in trying to influence the new Europe is not confined to the west. In Eastern Europe as well, Mr. Gorbachev is likely to encounter continuing difficulties. He faces the risk that reformist governments, to cement their legitimacy, will rethink their earlier vows of loyalty to the Warsaw Pact. Electoral pressures may lead even Communist leaders (like those in Hungary) to fan public demands for an early withdrawal of Soviet forces.
Some states will revive territorial claims against Moscow. Already, there are stirrings on this question in Poland, Rumania and even in Finland, all of whom lost territory to the Soviet Union in the past.
Oddly, new economic policies in Eastern Europe may also have damaging consequences for perestroika. These states export much more to the Soviet Union than all the nations of the industrial West put together. U.S. officials now hope for a Soviet economic turnaround but, to promote their own recovery, East Germany, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia want to reorient their trade. The result will be new disruptions for Soviet industry and new privation for Soviet consumers.
There is no mystery in the disparity between European and American approaches to the Soviet Union. For the U.S., discarding the ''enemy image'' of the other superpower means that every East-West dispute becomes susceptible to compromise. Lesser powers draw the opposite conclusion. Those that have for years been unable to raise the issues that concern them are encouraged by Soviet flexibility to push their own goals harder. They can be less fearful now of how Moscow will react.
This trend, which is fully consistent with (even inseparable from) support for perestroika, gives a nasty reply to one of the favorite ideas of Mr. Gorbachev's foreign policy advisers. They used to promise him that the world's medium powers were full of latent anti-American feeling that was ripe for Soviet exploitation. So far, such assertiveness has been directed at the Soviet Union instead. (The pattern holds outside Europe, too: Japan is less receptive to a compromise on the Northern Islands, India is more irritated by its unbalanced trade with Moscow, and so on.) Facing such problems, how will Mr. Gorbachev conduct himself at the 35-nation Conference on European Security that he and Mr. Bush have just agreed to convene in 1990? The Soviets may hope that this forum will endorse the demilitarization of the two alliances and the removal of all armies to home territories. Yet, such a symmetrical outcome looks harder and harder for Moscow to achieve. Soviet allies are undermining the Warsaw Pact from within, while U.S. allies have just reiterated their interest in a continuing American military presence in Europe.
For governments across Europe, the U.S. contributes to the emergence of a stable new order by keeping at least some troops in place over the long term; the Soviet Union, by withdrawing its forces. The new buzzword in negotiating European security will therefore be asymmetry. It is a measure of how much Mr. Gorbachev has redrawn the horizons of Soviet security policy that his officials do not dismiss such ideas out of hand.
Before Malta, a senior Bush Administration official reportedly said of the meeting ahead, ''It's one-on-one, and at stake is the world.'' In fact, Mr. Gorbachev's revolution ends the heroic age of superpower diplomacy. After Malta, mano a mano summitry looks more and more like an institution of the cold war, a relic of the time when the superpowers, and they alone, could resolve the big issues. When the new shape of the world is decided, it won't be one-on-one at all.

HEADLINE: Bush Aides Say Gorbachev Sees Economy as Key

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
In a discussion of Soviet domestic problems with President Bush in Malta, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called his campaign to end consumer shortages in the Soviet Union ''the ultimate test'' of his leadership, senior Administration officials said today. The Soviet leader reportedly left some American officials with the impression that he was at a loss over how to solve his economic problems.
In talks with Mr. Bush during lunch on Saturday aboard the Soviet cruise liner Maxim Gorky, Mr. Gorbachev also said he felt that his position was secure and not threatened by political opposition, the Administration officials said.
One official said Mr. Gorbachev's remarks seemed to make it clear that he was ''very much not in control of his destiny'' when it came to the economy. Still, the Soviet leader discussed Moscow's intractable economic problems with ''a sober sense of confidence'' that some improvement could eventually be achieved, another official said. 
 
Bush Meets With Cabinet
Mr. Bush said Mr. Gorbachev's remarks made a strong impression in terms of helping him understand the Soviet leader's thinking and approach to events. But they were not the inspiration for Mr. Bush's proposals on improving economic ties with the Soviet Union, which had been worked out in advance and presented before Mr. Gorbachev mentioned economic problems.
As new details emerged today about the two-day meeting in Malta, Mr. Bush, back in Washington, met with his Cabinet and the National Security Council to talk about the new timetable that he and Mr. Gorbachev set for reaching an agreement on reducing strategic nuclear weapons and conventional armed forces in Europe.
''He told his associates today that we're going to get the work done,'' a senior official said. ''The President is determined and he said it would be one thing if we cannot reach agreement because the Soviets are unreasonable, but what will not happen is that we cannot reach agreement within the U.S. Government.''
 
Pleased at Changes
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev instructed Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to meet in the Soviet Union in January to discuss three major obstacles to a strategic weapons treaty - sea-launched cruise missiles, encoding of missile-launching data and non-deployed missiles. They said they wanted those problems resolved by the summit meeting they arranged for June, during which they hope to finish work on a treaty that might be signed later in the year.
American officials said they were struck by how pleased Mr. Gorbachev seemed at the Malta meeting with the pace and nature of change in Eastern Europe, telling Mr. Bush repeatedly that he, Gorbachev, had worked to encourage the reforms.
He did not put any limits on what might happen in Eastern Europe, an official said, except when it came to East and West Germany. ''Up until that point, it was incredible to see the leaders of these two countries sitting at a table and saying they were both happy with the situation in Eastern Europe,'' the official said.
But then Mr. Gorbachev made it clear that he and Mr. Bush were far apart on the German issue and that he opposed a unification of the two Germanys. ''He didn't say forever,'' the official said. ''But he did say, 'History created this problem and history will have to solve it,' and he didn't say how long history will be.''
 
Heaping Bowls of Caviar
Mr. Gorbachev began his discussion on the Soviet political and economic situation at Saturday's lunch as liveried waiters passed around heaping bowls of caviar.
American officials said they were struck by the intensity with which Mr. Gorbachev talked.
''I don't believe he is worried about anything in the political sense,'' an official said today. ''But I do think he is very much not in control of his destiny on certain problems, especially the economy.''
Mr. Gorbachev mentioned consumer goods two or three times, officials said. ''The tremendous shortage of consumer goods was very much on Gorbachev's mind throughout the discussion of Soviet domestic issues,'' one official said. ''It may certainly be the defining problem for him.
''He said the solution to that problem represents the ultimate test in his own mind for whether or not he himself has succeeded as a leader.''
Consumer goods have long been in short supply in the Soviet Union, but since Mr. Gorbachev began making changes in the economy the problem has worsened. There have been shortages of sugar and soap in recent months.
 
'A Major Preoccupation'
Other officials said they did not have such a stark impression of Mr. Gorbachev's view of the economy.
''It's clear that this was a major preoccupation for Gorbachev,'' one said. ''He did not convey a sense of alarm or anxiety, but he said he knew what the problems were, that they were very serious problems and he was setting out to find the solutions.''
During the 90-minute lunch discussion on Saturday, the official said, Mr. Bush explained ''the virtues of the free-market system in a way that said: 'We don't want to force this on you. You have to make your own choices, but let me tell you why we think capitalism works.' ''
In their public statements, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev have given relatively little emphasis to their discussions of Eastern Europe, apparently concerned that they not appear to be dictating a future course to their own alliances and perhaps aware that they are not in a position to do so.
But Administration officials said they devoted a large part of their talks, both in the larger sessions and one on one, to Eastern Europe.
''I think Gorbachev succeeded in making it clear that, as a lot of people had begun to suspect, he is not just accepting what is happening but is truly encouraging the kinds of changes that are taking place,'' a senior official said.
''There was a constant repetition of support and encouragement,'' the official said, but he added that the discussions were general and ''on a high philosophical plane'' and did not involve specific proposals or blueprints.
 
'Most Disruptive Element'
In their discussions on Central America, an official said, Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that arms shipments to Nicaragua and the leftist rebels in El Salvador were ''the single most disruptive element of our relationship.'' But Mr. Bush took pains not to connect the regional conflicts to any particular area of Soviet-American relations. ''He never tied it to anything officially or made it a litmus test on anything,'' the official said.
Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, said the summit left him optimistic for progress in Afghanistan, but he and other Administration officials refused to go into detail.
Both Mr. Scowcroft and Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, dismissed suggestions today that Vice President Dan Quayle disagreed with Mr. Bush about Soviet foreign policy. The Washington Post quoted Mr. Quayle today as saying that despite the improvements in Soviet-American relations, the Soviet Union is still ''a totalitarian Government'' that wants to ''create instability'' in Central America.
''We're talking maybe about a slight difference in perspective,'' Mr. Scowcroft said. ''There's no difference in substance between the two.''
