HEADLINE: Dinkins Picks 4 Deputy Mayors, Led by a Former Sanitation Chief

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In his first broad move to put his stamp on City Hall, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins has chosen four deputy mayors, a corporation counsel and a press secretary to serve at the center of his administration, members of his transition team said yesterday.
Mr. Dinkins's aides said the appointments would not be announced until preliminary background checks were done, but officials said the appointees include Norman Steisel, a former City Sanitation Commissioner, as first deputy mayor, and Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, the city's Commissioner of Financial Services, as deputy mayor for economic development.
Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, and his acting chief of staff, Barbara J. Fife, will also be deputy mayors. Victor Kovner, a lawyer, will assume the job of corporation counsel, which Mr. Dinkins offered him before his election last month. Albert Scardino, a reporter who covers the news media for The New York Times, will be press secretary. 
Nathan Leventhal, the chairman of the transition committee, said Mr. Dinkins had ''invited and gotten acceptances'' from candidates to fill six posts, ''deputy mayors and others'' and that they would be named as soon as checks by the Department of Investigation are done, possibly by Friday. But he refused to discuss any names.
Word of the appointments seeped out yesterday as Mr. Dinkins faced mounting pressure to name at least some officials to his administration now and as he found news reports about him being dominated by renewed controversy and a Federal investigation into his transfer of stock to his son.
 
To Inspire Confidence
The appointments, naming a mix of longtime aides and experienced city officials, seemed intended both to inspire confidence in Mr. Dinkins's stewardship and to reassure the diverse ethnic and political constituencies that helped elect him.
Mr. Steisel, now a partner at the investment banking concern of Lazard Freres & Company, would not answer any questions yesterday about the possibility of his appointment.
Officials involved in the transition said there would be four deputy mayors, including a first deputy responsible for overall management of the city. That would add one deputy to the scheme currently used by Mayor Edward I. Koch, but does not come close to the seven he named at the beginning of his administration 12 years ago.
Mr. Dinkins has repeatedly said that finding a budget director is among his highest priorities. But one senior aide said yesterday that the budget chief would not be in this first group of appointees.
 
Broad Range of Groups
The Mayor-elect is understood to have decided on several of the appointments some time ago but wanted to wait to announce them together to demonstrate his efforts to reach a broad range of groups. For example, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who is Hispanic, was asked only last night to assume her post.
Mr. Lynch is black and a veteran of many liberal Democratic campaigns. He was chief of staff in the Manhattan borough president's office before he took a leave to run Mr. Dinkins's campaign and was replaced by Mrs. Fife. Both Mrs. Fife and Mr. Kovner are Jewish, and associated with liberal causes.
Mr. Steisel, a former deputy budget director and then Sanitation Commissioner in the Koch administration, was widely praised for overseeing the reduction of the number of workers on garbage trucks from three to two, which saved the city many millions of dollars.
 
Financial Advisers
As deputy mayor for economic development, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who was formerly a senior aide to Mr. Dinkins in the Manhattan Borough President's office, will round out Mr. Dinkins's group of financial advisers, which also includes such figures as Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation; David Rockefeller, the retired head of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express. She could not be reached for comment.
Mrs. Fife would not discuss any appointments and Mr. Lynch did not return repeated telephone calls seeking comment.
Mr. Scardino last night declined to answer questions about appointments.
 
Won Pulitzer Prize
Before joining The Times, Mr. Scardino was editor of The Georgia Gazette, a weekly newspaper in Savannah that won the Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing in 1984. As Mr. Dinkins's press secretary, he would replace the campaign press secretary, David Fishlow, a former aide to State Attorney General Robert Abrams, who often tangled with reporters during the campaign.
Mr. Kovner did confirm that he had agreed to serve as the city's chief lawyer.
Mr. Dinkins's search committees seeking candidates to head city agencies are to report to him by Monday with suggested names. The search committees are meeting throughout the week and into the weekend to interview candidates.

HEADLINE: Fast Food? It Just Isn't Fast Enough Anymore

BYLINE: By DENA KLEIMAN

 BODY:
Welcome to the Age of Zap.
With the ever-accelerating pace of life, the act of eating - once a leisurely undertaking synonymous with pleasure and social interaction -has been reduced to a necessary function not unlike shaving or refueling the car, in the view of food manufacturers, social scientists and others.
Not only is the relationship Americans have with food changing, but the preoccupation with speed is also now forcing fast-food companies and food manufacturers to offer consumers faster and faster options.
Indeed, many fast-food restaurants are scrambling for ways to shave seconds off service by eliminating seats to accommodate customers who no longer have time to sit, by installing computers to accommodate customers who no longer have time to speak, and by eliminating the wasteful ''think time'' that customers take at the counter. At the same time, food manufacturers are taking advantage of consumers' reluctance to wait by introducing fast-food look-alikes that can be prepared quickly in a microwave oven. 
Although data are sparse on exactly how much time Americans spend preparing their food and consuming it, food manufacturers, restaurateurs and others say fast food is no longer fast enough and that staples like the freshly prepared homemade sandwich or can of soup - once considered timesavers - are quickly becoming obsolete.
''People are standing in front of the toaster saying, 'Faster, faster,' '' said Joel Weiner, who was until recently a marketing executive at Kraft General Foods, which recently came up with Zap-a-Pack, a processed cheese spread that can be heated in only a minute by microwave to use as a dip or a sauce. ''It's gotten to the point where it is too burdensome to open a can of soup,'' Mr. Weiner said.
When Americans do find time to eat, they seem to expect less enjoyment from it and accept that as a trade-off, experts say.
''Hunger is a chore to be finished rather than an event to be savored and enjoyed,'' said Robert B. Cialdini, a social psychologist at Arizona State University and the author of ''Influence: The New Psychology of Modern Persuasion'' (Quill, 1985).
In a poll in September by the Gallup Organization, only about one in three adults said he or she typically dined at home with other people and engaged in conversation during meals without other distractions. A majority - 64 percent - watched television, read, worked or did something else while eating. Just over half of those interviewed in the poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, said that on a typical night they consumed a meal prepared from scratch. The others said they typically relied on frozen, packaged or takeout meals.
Less than half the 1,225 respondents, who were interviewed by telephone at their homes, said they enjoyed eating ''a great deal.'' ''We've moved beyond grazing and into gulping,'' said Al Rosenfeld, the publisher of Frozen Food Age, a trade publication based in New York.
Clearly, if any one invention is responsible for these changes, it is the microwave oven. Whereas 10 years ago, less than a quarter of American households owned microwave ovens, the food industry estimates that three-quarters do now, creating powerful new expectations by consumers for speed in food preparation and delivery.
And those new expectations have created new challenges for the fast-food industry, which until recently had little competition from the home kitchen.
''Fast food can no longer live up to its name,'' said Mona Doyle, the president of Consumer Network, a Philadelphia concern that does marketing consultation for the food industry. ''There are never any lines at home. With the microwave, you just reach into your freezer and pop it into the oven and zap! it's done.''
At the headquarters of the White Castle System in Columbus, Ohio, Christopher Thomas, the director of marketing, said: ''I don't even like to use the term fast food. What is fast to me may not be fast to you. When you think back to 30 years ago, 60 seconds was fast. Now it's not fast: it's quick.''
It isn't that Americans, who spent some $60 billion last year on fast food, have soured on it. It's just that after double-digit sales growth that lasted into the early 1980's, the pace has slowed and the market has become saturated, creating increased competition among chains.
Some chains, like Arby's, which is based in Atlanta, are experimenting with computerized screens that let customers make selections, to cut down on the 8 to 10 seconds of ''talk time'' they normally take. Wendy's, the hamburger chain based in Dublin, Ohio, recently had staff members take orders from customers standing in line, to reduce the estimated 30 to 40 seconds of ''think time'' at the counter. The G. S. Blodgett Corporation of Burlington, Vt., a leading manufacturer of pizza ovens, has a computerized pizza maker that cuts the preparation and cooking time for commercial pizza to three minutes and is now in use in California.
Because fewer and fewer people want to get into their cars to pick up dinner, Kentucky Fried Chicken is experimenting with home delivery. Pizza Hut is taking pizza to the consumer not only by home delivery but also with a kind of Fotomat-equivalent that lets them order and pick up a pizza in 30 seconds.
''We are looking at things down to the seconds,'' said Roger Rydell, a spokesman for Pizza Hut. He said the company had pizza ovens in student cafeterias, hospitals and malls, taking the product wherever the impetuous consumer might roam. The company has even considered establishing a nationwide toll-free number, so home-delivery customers won't have to consult the telephone directory.
To save time, McDonald's is now giving robots a try at cooking french fries. ''We are always looking at ways of shaving off 25 seconds here, 25 seconds there,'' said Terry Capatosto, the director of media relations for the company in Oak Brook, Ill.
At the same time, big food companies have zeroed in on the fact that people can now prepare fast-food meals at home in less time than it takes to get in a car and go buy them. This has led to one of the most dramatic changes in the food business: the ascent of the frozen sandwich.
Sales of frozen offerings like hamburgers, cheeseburgers and fish sandwiches - which can all be prepared in microwave ovens in 90 seconds to 4 minutes - have exploded from $49 million in 1984 to $153 million in 1988, said Alan Miller, a consultant to Arbitron/SAMI, a market-research concern in New York.
The Campbell Soup Company has introduced frozen soups and sandwiches, Hormel and White Castle are among the many companies offering frozen hamburgers in the supermarket case, and Kraft recently introduced Zapetites, an array of frozen miniature hot dogs and other snacks that can be prepared in a minute.
Food manufacturers are developing other products that set new speed records, like Betty Crocker's new Microrave cake, which takes only four minutes to make in a microwave oven and saves washing a pot.
Many food manufacturers concede that these remarkably fast products leave a lot to be desired when it comes to flavor.
''Clearly you don't get as much pleasure out of food that you microwave,'' said Richard Nelson, the director of market research services for Campbell Soup in Camden, N.J. ''But food today is more of a maintenance function than pleasureable experience. The word trade-off is a real clue that people are willing to accept something inferior as long as it is fast.''
Why Americans are so eager to eat quickly has as much to do with the stresses of two-career families, single parenthood and other aspects of modern life as with other factors, say food anthropologists, social psychologists and others.
''These days there are so many choices,'' said Mr. Cialdini of Arizona State University. ''There are so many options, so much information, so much stimulation that we must deal with each activity in a less fully considered way. It is a regrettable but necessary feature of modern life that we don't take time to smell the roses. We gulp down things that are worth savoring.''
Speed of food preparation and a reduced emphasis on the leisurely sharing of meals carries with it another attraction: the ability to accommodate individual tastes and needs. With frozen entrees that can be prepared in minutes, everyone in the family can have something different for dinner.
''Speed today means being an individual and ordering what you want,'' said George Armelagos, a food anthropologist at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
''Speed has truly liberated the woman,'' said Rita Denny, a senior vice president of Holen North American, a marketing research and management-consulting concern in New York. ''Mom no longer has to be head of house. Household members are more autonomous and providing for themselves.''
Eating fast is nothing new in the United States, said Harvey Levenstein, a social historian at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, and the author of a social history of American food titled ''Revolution at the Table: The Transformation of the American Diet'' (Oxford University Press, 1988).
''Americans are just getting back to their roots,'' Mr. Levenstein said. He explained that they had always bolted their food, until the late 19th century, when the family meal emerged as the central ritual for family life.
''Back in 1830 the idea was, ''Why not get it over with?' '' he said. ''You don't like the taste and you can get on with the things you enjoy more.''
Still, Mr. Nelson of Campbell Soup said he was concerned about what this all means for the future.
''What worries me are the children,'' said Mr. Nelson, who predicted that by 1992 automobiles would come equipped with microwave ovens. ''When you think about imprinting and how you can remember your first date, your first kiss, your first corsage, you have to think of what that first imprinting will be of cooking: which buttons to press on the microwave. I'm not sure where the stove and the oven will fit in.''
Or - it might be said - a decent, carefully savored meal.

HEADLINE: Cease-Fire in Manila Allows For Evacuation of Foreigners

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 6

 BODY:
As the military coup attempt against President Corazon C. Aquino continued for a sixth day, rebel troops in the city's business and financial district and the Philippine Government reached a cease-fire today long enough to begin evacuation of hundreds of foreigners trapped in their hotels by the fighting.
By this morning, roughly 500 people, including about 90 Americans, were reported to have been evacuated in Government buses. Several thousand people, including more than 200 Americans, had been trapped since the weekend, when the rebels moved into hotels and office buildings in the financial center, Makati.
But even with the evacuation under way and negotiations to end the standoff continuing, Manila remains a city divided - its business area and rich residential heart paralyzed by 400 rebel snipers and surrounded by loyalist armored vehicles, while the rest of the city goes about its business with surprisingly little sense of crisis. 
What began as an effort to topple the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino has turned into a standoff, with no sign of an early end. Makati seems firmly in the hands of a highly organized, disciplined force of rebels who are convinced that Mrs. Aquino is weakened every day that the stalemate endures.
But a few miles away, where joggers run on a path near the bay, it was hard to find much out of place.
Neither Mrs. Aquino nor the rebels have been able to tap into the ''people power'' that swept President Ferdinand E. Marcos out three years ago. Tired of an economy that will not run and turmoil that will not end, most people here seem sharply critical of both sides.
The negotiations have continued on two fronts, Philippine officials said. The cease-fire discussions apparently had the sole aim of extracting the foreigners trapped in four hotels occupied by the rebels.
Simultaneously, loyalist officers continued negotiations with their own estranged comrades, trying to find an alternative to feared building-by-building gun battles, something many fear could cost hundreds of lives.
The Philippine Red Cross said today that 74 people had been killed in the fighting so far, more than in the worst previous coup attempt against Mrs. Aquino's Government. The latest violence has also left more than 500 wounded.
On Tuesday, the Government troops seemed somewhat at a loss over what to do next. In a tour of the perimeter of the Makati area, Government forces could be seen massed around a large firehouse, positioning armored personnel carriers that bore yellow ribbons to make it clear that they were siding with Mrs. Aquino, who adopted yellow as the color of her campaign against Mr. Marcos three years ago.
 
Firing at Will
But when the troops moved into the center of the business district, a now-deserted area usually jammed with traffic, they fired indiscriminately, with no visible objective. This prompted return fire that was similarly random.
A senior Government adviser with access to the negotiations suggested today that the troops loyal to Mrs. Aquino had little stomach for a showdown with the rebels, who include some of the country's best units.
The adviser also said that ''the military is negotiating with its hands tied'' because it had no power to make the kind of political concessions that the rebels have demanded.
So far, the chief demand is Mrs. Aquino's resignation and new elections. That approach has also been pressed by the country's Vice President, Salvador Laurel, who said again today that he would resign if Mrs. Aquino would step down with him.
 
President Is Uncommunicative
The President has rejected the idea. In the last few days she has virtually disappeared from view, saying little in public about the military standoff.
The Government's troubles extend beyond Manila. In Cebu, 350 miles to the south, rebels still hold the airport and have reportedly wired commercial aircraft on the ground there with explosives, threatening to blow them up if attacked by Government forces.
So far, the Government has let several deadlines for the rebels' surrender pass without mounting any attacks.
For their part, the rebels have been trying to project an image of restraint. They have been polite to hotel guests, according to the few accounts that have emerged from the sealed-off buildings in Makati, and a leader of the group, Gregorio Honasan, issued a statement that seemed aimed at allaying fears in the United States that the coup leaders are anti-American.
 
Not Fighting U.S., Leader Says
''The United States of America is not our enemy,'' he said after the Bush Administration sent F-4 fighter planes over Manila to keep rebel aircraft out of the sky. ''To this great country and to our foreign friends and allies, we wish to assure them that our undertaking is purely internal to our country and is not intended to prejudice their legitimate rights or interests in the Philippines.''
Mr. Honasan, a former lieutenant colonel who led a 1987 coup attempt, then escaped from prison last year, asked all foreign governments ''not to allow themselves to be used in any manner to defend the criminal interests of a regime that has become the enemy of the Filipino people.''

LENGTH: 935 words

HEADLINE: Whatever the Outcome, Aquino Stands to Lose

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Dec. 5

 BODY:
President Corazon C. Aquino may yet find a neat way to finish off the most serious coup attempt of her four years in office, but her ability to deal with widespread complaints about her administration has been severely undermined.
More important, perhaps, is the damage done to the Philippines' fledgling sense of the rule of law, the nurturing of which is Mrs. Aquino's proudest achievement.
Though she and her Government seem to have survived, they are much weakened. The democratic institutions and constitutional processes she helped to re-establish in the ''people power'' uprising of 1986 have been brazenly challenged by a divided military she thought had reconciled itself to political control. 
The population that rallied to her yellow banner and confronted Ferdinand E. Marcos's tanks has held back this time in ambivalence or has regarded the sometimes brutal street warfare as a sort of spectacular entertainment.
 
A Blow to Nationalism
The nationalism inspired by the downfall of Mr. Marcos - a sense of independence and unity historically missing in this agglomeration of long-colonized peoples - has been deflated by the intervention of the United States and its jets in this affair, no matter how dire the circumstances or delicate the rules of engagement.
And most seriously for her own future, Mrs. Aquino's most substantial achievement - three years of modest but steady economic growth despite crippling debt - has been given a severe knocking.
The country's economic heart, the Makati district in Manila, is held hostage by rebel soldiers and surrounded by loyalist troops. Tourism, always high at Christmas, is bound to be affected by the coup attempt.
Investor confidence, crucial for the creation of new jobs for a rapidly growing population, will suffer sharply from this renewed sense of instability and chaos. A Philippines-based mutual fund, which Mrs. Aquino inaugurated with such pride on Wall Street just last month, has taken a beating.
 
'An Unmitigated Disaster'
When finance and commerce eventually resume in Makati, they are expected to suffer badly. Diplomats say the Manila composite index, which was at near-record highs, is likely to drop as much as 30 percent when trading resumes.
''This coup is an unmitigated disaster,'' said a Western diplomat here.
A senior Philippine intelligence official who has long struggled for constitutional rule said: ''I have a deep sense of tragedy. We've been here before. Why are we here again?'' Senator Rene V. Saguisag, an Aquino supporter, said, ''The setback is unquantifiable in terms of the rebuilding of our institutions and our economy.''
With the squandering of national resources, he said, ''it will now become much harder for the President or anyone else to deliver the basic services everyone wants, and the rebels who make it harder for us to do our job will now blame us for being unable to deliver.''
Even before the coup, said Teodoro Benigno, Mrs. Aquino's former spokesman, the Government was perceived by many Filipinos as indecisive, directionless and unable to control a corrupt bureaucracy. There have been accusations of corruption among her own family and colleagues.
 
Services Deteriorate
Basic services like transportation, electricity, telephones, water and garbage collection have been deteriorating, making daily life for many urban residents increasingly annoying, time-consuming, unpredictable and fetid. Government promises of improvement have not produced results; Mrs. Aquino's ratings in the opinion polls has been plunging. Only a month ago, in an interview, she spoke elegiacally of her presidency and said she had decided not to run again in 1992.
The exercise of democracy itself has been an uneven and sometimes trivial one, diplomats say.
The members of Congress elected after Mrs. Aquino's triumph are collectively regarded as petty, posturing and themselves corrupt. The democratic opposition to her Government, which includes her own Vice President, Salvador H. Laurel, and her former Defense Minister, Senator Juan Ponce Enrile, are widely thought to be cynical opportunists possibly involved in the latest coup attempt.
''In the Philippines we don't yet have the cultural and political bedrock belief in democracy of the West,'' Mr. Benigno said. He called Mrs. Aquino ''the light'' of the democratic revolution, but said it ''begins to sputter,'' and with it he the idea of democracy itself flickers.
 
Stature 'Badly Battered'
Senator Saguisag said that ''the principle of democracy itself has been saved,'' but that Mrs. Aquino herself must begin ''to lay down the law.'' ''One hopes for a higher sense of urgency,'' he said.
Mr. Benigno agreed and expressed worry that Mrs. Aquino might not survive the political and economic tests to come. With her popularity already declining, he said, her political stature ''has been badly battered by this last coup.''
With the economy already in difficulty, Mr. Benigno said he feared increased popular unrest as prices rise, electricity blackouts continue and the gap between rich and poor increases.
The possibility of another coup cannot be ruled out, he said. ''She realizes the shadow of the military is closing around her.''
If the edge of precipice unleashes her instinct for self-preservation, he said, she may yet respond as her supporters would wish - ''mounting the horse and being perceived to move strongly into the fray, even by declaring a state of emergency or martial law.''
But he said that if Mrs. Aquino ''stonewalls instead and reverts only to prayer, it may be the end of her.''

HEADLINE: DRUG WAR STALLED IN 2 KEY COUNTRIES

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
Though President Bush announced in September that he was sending several hundred million dollars to fight drugs in South America, no new funds have reached Peru and Bolivia, the world's two main growers of coca.
As appropriations move slowly through Congress and administrative procedures are completed, American officials here say it is unlikely that money to carry out the President's program will begin flowing before February. ''The new anti-drug strategy hasn't arrived here yet,'' a senior United States official said.
As a result, little is being done to stop the growth of the cocaine business in either country. Peasants are expanding coca fields, and shipments of semi-refined cocaine from Peru are picking up after a brief decline. Also, more of the final processing, usually done in Colombia, appears to be taking place in Peru, United States officials said. 
In Peru, where a guerrilla war is intensifying, the army is pursuing a strategy that is allowing coca growers and drug traffickers to prosper.
Shining Path, Peru's main guerrilla organization, has become deeply involved in the narcotics industry, serving as broker for coca growers, collecting taxes from cocaine traffickers and defending both from security forces.
The army field commander, Brig. Gen. Alberto Arciniega has been trying to root out the guerrillas but is steering clear of the growers and traffickers. Interfering with the growers, he says, would drive them into a closer alliance with the guerrillas. As for the traffickers, he says he does not have the strength to take on them and the guerrillas simultaneously.
 
A Cocaine Boom Town
United States officials say aircraft landing fees that the guerrillas have been collecting from traffickers, as well as payments from coca farmers, are being used to improve the cocaine boom town of Uchiza, where General Arciniega has his headquarters, and to buy food for the general's troops.
Announcing his new anti-drug program on Sept. 5, President Bush said he was allocating $261 million for Peru, Bolivia and Colombia, mostly for the military and the police.
Colombia received $65 million in emergency military and police assistance shortly after President Virgilio Barco declared all-out war on drug traffickers in August. But the Bush Administration has made no special funding requests for Peru and Bolivia.
The main coca-growing areas are crucial targets for reducing the flow of cocaine to the United States, American officials say. Yet one senior official here said, ''There are a good deal of misgivings among people in Washington, in both the executive branch and in Congress, as to whether you can effectively invest money in anti-drug programs in Peru.''
Neither Peru nor Bolivia, whose economies depend on income from the drug business, has done a great deal in the past to counter cocaine production, and both remain equivocal on how much effort they are willing to make. Both Governments say they want to reduce production and crude refining of coca, but both say the United States should place less emphasis on military and police action and more on economic programs aimed at getting farmers to voluntarily switch crops.
 
Opposition to Herbicides
Peru has halted the forced manual eradication of coca crops, and eradication efforts in Bolivia have slowed. American officials have been testing herbicides in Peru, but opposition to their use is running high. ''Who can guarantee that these chemicals will not ruin our fields forever?'' a senior Peruvian military officer asked.
Both Peru and Bolivia are grappling with severe economic problems. President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia declared a state of emergency last month and jailed hundreds of union leaders and teachers who he said threatened his Government's anti-inflation policies with their wage demands. In Peru, the gross national product fell by 20 percent last year, and inflation is running at an annual rate of 2,500 percent.
In the past, almost all of the anti-drug work in Colombia, Peru and Bolivia has been done by the police. The armed forces argue that their task is to guard against invasion and subversion, and some officers also worry that bribery by cocaine traffickers would corrupt their forces.
But the Bush Administration wants to get the armed forces involved and is offering them the major share of its money for the region. In Peru, for example, $39 million is to go to the armed forces, $26 million to the police.
The armed forces have started carrying out some anti-drug operations in Colombia, but most of the work there is still being done by the police.
Senior Peruvian military officers say they plan to use the new United States money to intensify their campaign against the guerrillas and to try to prevent the smuggling of chemicals needed in the refining of cocaine. United States officials say they accept the Peruvian argument that the guerrillas must be attacked first, opening areas in which the police will be able to move against drug traffickers.
But they are also trying to get the military to end their tolerance of the growers and traffickers and to cooperate with the police. ''It is enormously frustrating to all of us that things are going so slowly,'' an American official said. ''There is a sense of urgency in what we're trying to do. But that urgency and frustration are tempered by a desire to make real achievements and not just spend money.''

HEADLINE: Bush Proposing Talks in U.S. on Global Warming

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
In a policy shift, President Bush has proposed that the United States sponsor an international conference in Washington next fall to begin negotiating a treaty on global warming.
Until now, White House officials have resisted a specific commitment to begin such negotiations, choosing instead to play down the urgency of the global warming issue. In recent months, however, Mr. Bush has faced pressure from members of Congress, Administration officials and several European nations to take stronger action.
The President made the treaty proposal at the Malta summit conference with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The United States and the Soviet Union lead in emissions of carbon dixoide, which scientists say is accumulating in the atmosphere and contributing to global warming. 
 
A Hint of Greater Action
The Bush Administration has made no specific commitment to reduce such emissions. But in seeking an international conference, the United States is tacitly acknowledging that it will take further steps, environmentalists say.
As host of such a conference, the United States is likely to subject itself to heavy pressure to make specific commitments. Representatives of several environmentalist groups, which have criticized Mr. Bush for failing to deal with the global warming issue, said the President would not have made the offer unless he was prepared to move ahead more quickly.
Administration spokesmen today denied that the President had shifted his strategy, and suggested that the offer was part of a natural policy evolution. ''I don't think for a moment it represents a change of heart,'' said Dr. D. Allan Bromley, the President's science adviser. ''This really is part of a coherent program that we have been working on for a long time.''
''Whether it's evolution or revelation, I think the President is to be congratulated on taking this initiative,'' said Senator John Heinz, a Pennsylvania Republican who has criticized the President's policies on climate change.
 
Gore Is Wary
But Senator Albert Gore Jr., a Tennessee Democrat and another critic of Mr. Bush's climate-change policies, said, ''It remains to be seen whether this is a real change.'' Mr. Gore termed the proposal a ''begrudging acceptance of political reality.''
At the summit conference, Mr. Bush also offered to convene in Washington next spring an international meeting of scientific, environmental and economic officials to address climate change. The Soviet Union did not respond to Mr. Bush's proposal to host the treaty conference, a White House spokesman said today. The President's offer will be formally considered by the United Nations Environment Program, under whose auspices international talks on climate change are now taking place.
The United States and the Soviet Union, along with Japan, have been hesitant to discuss negotiating a treaty on global warming because of doubts about whether emissions of carbon dioxide and other so-called greenhouse gases are changing the climate. Stabilizing and reducing carbon dioxide emissions, produced by the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil, would have enormous social and economic costs.
The Administration has been divided about how quickly to move on global warming. John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Dr. Bromley have urged a deliberate pace until more data are available.
The United States has backed a United Nations-sponsored panel that is scheduled to report its findings next fall.
The report would be followed by an international conference aimed at obtaining a general consensus. Then, a second round of talks would produce specific national commitments on cuts in emissions.
Other Administration officials, like William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, have advocated more aggressive steps to show that the United States considers global warming a serious environmental threat.

HEADLINE: DEFICIT AND TAXES TRY LEGISLATORS

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Faced with voters who threaten them with political and even physical harm, Massachusetts legislators are trying again this week to figure out how to go about the distasteful business of raising taxes.
The stakes are particularly high for George Keverian, the House Speaker who lobbied hard for a $1.2 billion tax package that died on the floor of the House on Friday.
Mr. Keverian, a Democrat who is a candidate for state treasurer, has tried to fill a leadership vacuum left earlier this year when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis announced he would not seek re-election.
But in a state where the Republican presence is so small that the battles in the Democratic Party are what count, Mr, Keverian was unable to muster enough support to pass the tax package, even after pressuring his committee chairmen by suggesting that anyone not planning to support it should resign. One chairman did resign, another offered to do so, and six others shrugged and voted against the measure. 
All this only adds to the bleak economic picture in Massachusetts, where the deficit for this fiscal year is about $1.2 billion, the worst in state history. Mr. Dukakis has called for a tax increase before the end of the year to cover the deficit. Only the Massachusetts House can introduce tax legislation, so the action will have to start there.
 
Package Was Doomed, Some Say
The tax package that fell apart Friday would have raised the capital-gains tax retroactively to Jan. 1, pushing it to 7.5 percent from 5 percent. The package also called for a 2-cent increase in the sales tax, which is now at 5 cents on the dollar, and an increase by 10 cents a gallon by 1992 for the gasoline tax.
Privately and publicly, many legislators - all of whom are up for re-election next year - said they believed such increases were doomed from the start. Some wondered why the tax package was introduced before a $300 million spending-reduction bill was voted on in the Senate. Mr. Keverian said he wanted to go ahead and act on the tax package to save time.
''There's no argument now that $1.2 billion was just too large for anybody's personality,'' said Representative Robert A. Havern, a Democrat who is a member of the House Committee on Taxation.
The lack of support for the House package is considered a reflection of a bitter general attitude toward additional taxes.
 
'Wrong Thing to Do'
''I voted against it because I just think it's the wrong thing to do,'' said Representative Robert Cerasoli, who resigned his chairmanship of a House committee before he voted. ''There are many, many accounts in the budget that could be cut. Right now, all the little people are being hurt.''
''That is the public mood,'' said Representative Steven Pierce, the Republican minority leader. ''When there are hundreds and hundreds of bureaucrats paid very well and with impressive benefit packages, and the government talks about cutting services, that fuels public cynicism.''
That cynicism has produced an intense wave of vitriol toward public officials. Representative Patricia Fiero's receptionist took a call from a man who said he would used a chainsaw on the Democrat's house if she voted for the tax increase. ''One of my closest friends in the House is a single woman who is really afraid to go home at night,'' she said.
 
'They Call Up Very Rudely
Mr. Keverian, whose weight exceeds 300 pounds, said he gets 30 to 50 letters a day and has received as many as 1,000 phone calls, many of them hostile. ''Mainly they call up very rudely, talking about my weight,'' he said. ''They say things like: 'You big fat jerk. If you can't control your own weight, how can you control the budget?' Now I turn my tape recorder on only to get depressed.''
The capital-gains provision, which was considered the main measure of support for the package, was defeated by a vote of 94-64, and the rest was withdrawn. It is being revised in committee, but when a new version will be introduced is anybody's guess.
The latest round is already looking ugly. Mr. Keverian has indicated he would consider asking for broad cuts in state aid to local governments, a form of aid that pays for police officers and teachers, among other necessities. That met an immediate public outcry. ''The point is, if the mood is such that we cannot convince a majority of the House members that there should be a revenue program,'' Mr. Keverian said, ''then what, pray tell, do you do if you have a deficiency and you can't raise money? The options are to borrow, which you may not be able to do without a steady flow of revenue, or to cut.''
The total budget deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, is $1.25 billion, the largest in state history. Last July, Governor Dukakis outlined spending cuts that he said would solve the deficit, then estimated at just under $500 million. By October, the state was lacking another $500 million in revenues, a number that was quickly revised up to $750 million. A $600 million tax package proposed by the Governor in January was rejected by legislators without a vote.
Poor forecasting by state agencies has been blamed for the gap between expectations and reality. But most legislators now agree that figuring out who to blame is less urgent than figuring out what roles taxes will play in balancing the $13 billion budget, which is required by law.

HEADLINE: Vermont Court Blocks Homes in Deer Habitat

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 5

 BODY:
The Vermont Supreme Court has blocked the construction of a vacation-home development on the ground that it would deprive about 20 whitetail deer of a vital winter habitat.
The court, in a ruling announced Monday, upheld a decision by the State Environmental Board to deny an environmental permit for the 33-home development in the Stratton area. The permit is required to show that there is no threat to wildlife or the environment. 
The development, proposed by Southview Associates and John Lese of Rye, N.Y., would have been on 88 acres in a protected deer habitat. Six deer would have been directly affected, although the site supports about 20 whitetail deer over the winter.
The board denied the project in 1987, saying the habitat was the only such area within a 10.7-square-mile region that contained softcover critical to deer in the winter.
 
Decision Is Hailed
''It's certainly a wonderful decision,'' said Stephanie Kaplan, executive director of the Environmental Board. ''It strengthens the wildlife habitat in this state and the animals themselves.'' The case was considered so important by environmentalists that Attorney General Jeffrey Amestoy decided to argue it in person before the high court.
''Many developments do have an impact on wildlife habitats,'' Mr. Amestoy said. He added that the decision would affect development in Vermont and that it might have an impact on other pending cases, including a Killington Ski Area proposal to build a snow-making pond near a black bear habitat.
This was the first challenge to the process involving a wildlife habitat under the environmental law. But Southview challenged the board's decision, arguing that the development would not threaten the whitetail species, would not affect the scenic beauty of a natural area and would contribute more to the economy of the state than deer hunting.
Mr. Lese, the developer, said Monday that he could not comment on the ruling because he had not seen it.
During the Supreme Court arguments in October, Mr. Lese's lawyer, Raymond Perra, told the justices, ''This trial is about six deer.
''The deer herd is so large and healthy, it is not an endangered species,'' he said. ''Nor is this particular habitat necessary for the survival of the species.''
Vermont's deer herd is estimated to number about 90,000.
The court upheld the board's conclusion that ''the environmental and recreational loss to the public from the destruction and imperilment of the habitat is not outweighed by economic, social, cultural, recreational or other benefit to the public from the project.''
Nor did Southview employ ''all feasible and reasonable means of preventing or lessening the destruction and imperilment of the deer habitat,'' the board found.
Finally, the board could not exclude ''the possibility of less intensive development in other areas of the site.''
As a result of the development,'' the board wrote, ''it is likely that the deer will abandon the remaining cover altogether and those that remain will be less likely to survive due ot the high potential of stress created by wintertime noise and activity from people, vehicles, and pets,'' the board wrote.

HEADLINE: Communism, Exposed

 BODY:
Harmonious in mood. Conciliatory on arms. Cooperative on investment and trade. President Bush brimmed with good will toward Mikhail Gorbachev at their Malta summit talks - and small wonder. He knows what terrors may await the Soviet leader. All the astonishing changes that Mr. Gorbachev has already unleashed on the Communist world are mere economic prologue.
Mr. Gorbachev's plan to restructure the Soviet economy has touched only the surface of Soviet society. If perestroika is to succeed, it will have to be far more ambitious. The ultimate goal must be a system that relies on prices determined by a market, not on the commands of bureaucrats. 
Why does that goal embrace possible terrors? Because neither Mr. Gorbachev nor anyone else, anywhere, knows how to decentralize an economy strangled by an entrenched bureaucracy. There are no historical precedents - nor even theoretical models - to guide the transition.
What Mr. Gorbachev does know is that price decontrol threatens every Soviet citizen and his own political survival. It is not surprising that he is not yet ready to expose Communism to a market price system, and has put price reform on indefinite hold.
But in the meantime he wants to prepare his economy and population for more radical reform. He will need help, which is exactly what President Bush pledged at Malta. It's the right step, as an understanding of the Soviet economy makes clear.
The Soviet Union suffers from excessive central planning. Economic signals are so screwy that farmers feed bread to their animals because it is cheaper than unprocessed grain. Consumer items are either nonexistent or shoddy. The system stagnates. Some central planning can be preserved. But a lot has to go.
The core of perestroika is to decentralize decision making. Plant managers, not Moscow bureaucrats, would decide what and how to produce. But this would mean giving plant managers the right to decide who to hire and fire and what equipment and materials they need to buy. Wholesale trade among companies would replace assignments by central planners. But decentralized trade can work only if managers can respond to prices that reflect true economic value. That means prices must be stripped of unwarranted subsidies. The implication is that unproductive enterprises will perish. And if managers are to buy equipment and materials, they must be able to bid for bank loans by paying interest.
Finally, if businesses can hire and fire, workers will be threatened with unemployment. All of this would be new - and frightening. There is no guarantee that perestroika would survive the political storm.
The biggest economic obstacle to price reform is ''ruble overhang.'' Soviet citizens are hoarding billions of rubles because - at the low, controlled prices - goods move instantly and there is nothing left on store shelves to buy. If prices were decontrolled these shortages would disappear, but only because the excess rubles would ignite an inflation that would ruin the poor. While the overhang endures, widespread shortages cannot be ended. Soviet economists are flirting with several solutions, more ingenious than promising.
Mr. Gorbachev has begun to prepare the economy for price reform. Defense expenditures and investment have been cut back to make way for production of more consumer goods. Government deficits, currently three times larger than in the U.S., will be pared.
He needs more time, which is where Mr. Bush comes in. The United States can't solve Mr. Gorbachev's problems. But it can provide foreign investment and favorable trade relationships. And Washington can provide credit if the Soviets need to import desperately needed food and other consumer items.
That's exactly what Mr. Bush pledged last weekend. None of the specifics will have an immediate impact. But taken together they assure Mr. Gorbachev that America will help out in a crisis. The Soviet leader has provided no clear plan for the future, but he'll need help, and courage, to move his country's economy to the terrifying but necessary next level. If Mr. Bush emboldened him, he will have done all America can do.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Express-Bus Lines and Commuters Can't Afford a Higher Fare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Transit Authority has proposed an increase in the city's express bus fare from $3.50 to $4.60 - a whopping 31.4 percent increase (news story, Dec. 2)! Even a 50-cent increase would be a hardship for the more than 100,000 commuters who use our service daily from the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn to get to their jobs in Manhattan. Since private operators are contractually obligated to New York City to seek the same increases as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, we will be forced to raise our fares to the level of city-operated commuter express bus lines.
In transportation, the only purpose of a fare increase is to increase revenues. An increase in the express bus fare will have the converse effect: it will decrease revenues. The proof is in the last fare increase. In 1986, when the express bus fare was raised from $3 to $3.50, we lost 20 percent of our riders, and as a result generated less revenue with the higher fare than we did when the fare was at $3. We project another 20 percent falloff in ridership with just a 50-cent increase. Once ridership falloff reaches 12 percent, the so-called financial benefits of the higher fare are negated. 
The effects of even a 50-cent increase - let alone $1.10 - would be devastating. It would force commuters to pay an exorbitant fare, it would drive private operators out of business, and the city - which is already economically hard pressed - would be forced to pay millions of dollars in additional subsidies to those operators able to survive. Studies have also shown that those commuters who are driven from the system would opt for private car services, their own autos and illegal minivans to get to work, causing more traffic congestion and pollution in Manhattan.
Express bus commuters have already paid a disproportionate share of fare increases this decade. The last three increases in subway and local bus fares in 1981, 1984 and 1986 totaled 56 percent, while express bus fares for the same period jumped 103 percent. The cost of living during the same period rose only 25 percent. In addition, express bus commuters in the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn already pay as much as $40 more to commute to Manhattan than their Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk county and Connecticut neighbors who use Metro North and the Long Island Rail Road.
We do not need this fare increase, and our commuters should receive a waiver this time around. When was the last time a group of private express bus operators in this city opposed a fare increase of any amount?
 
EDWARD ARRIGONI
Vice President, Mass Transit
Operators of New York
Jamaica, Queens, Dec. 4, 1989

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Program Trading, Blame the Market;
The Governor's Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was dismayed by Senator Thomas F. Eagleton's resignation from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, but his Op-Ed article of Nov. 14 (''Chicago's Markets: Corrupt to the Core'') still came as a surprise. As a public governor of an exchange myself, I find the role a complicated one. My comments refer only to how I view our exchange, for generalizations cannot cover all exchanges. 
My obvious task is to defend the public interest, but beyond prevention of fraud and compliance with exchange and Commodity Futures Trading Commission regulations, there are many issues and responsibilities ranging from budgets to staffing and, of vital interest, maintenance of orderly markets and liquidity.
All boards must be wary of cliques and insiders. With floor brokers, commission houses and trading houses all represented on our board, it is difficult for any small group of insiders to dominate the exchange.
Disciplinary functions are the responsibility of the governors, all of whom receive summaries of violations and penalties. Any two governors can request a review for the next board meeting, and the board can recommend appointment of an appeal panel to review the lower committees' decisions. This is also the ultimate exchange appeal panel, and the practice has been that it is always headed by a public governor.
A defendant can next appeal to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission; virtually everyone who appears before our appeal panel does so, and I am pleased to say the C.F.T.C. has generally left our decisions and penalties intact.
Regarding the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, it no doubt lacks the clout of the Securities and Exchange Commission but it is also a much newer agency. Congressional reauthorization every three years is scarcely reassuring and that should be corrected forthwith. The exchanges do have considerable power with Congress, as Senator Eagleton says, and independence from that power is vital if the commission is to operate properly.
Self-regulation is not a myth when the exchanges police themselves well. At our exchange the audit trails are among the best, yet inevitably there are areas for improvement.
We are hopeful that hand-held recording devices, among other things, will narrow the areas of abuse. A vigilant compliance staff and responsible board of governors must have timely and accurate data on which to base their self-discipline. Other steps will follow. The exchanges are essential parts of the world economies. I believe that on our exchange and on others as well the customer can expect equitable treatment. But just as commission houses have an obligation to know their customers, so must the customer know his or her broker. There always will be unscrupulous operators in any business, and the commodity business is no exception.
Public governors have a difficult role. My associate public governor and I are up for re-election every year, and while we leave the room during the discussion and vote, I expect that the decision is not unanimous to re-elect.
That's fine; the positions we take are not always popular nor should they be. One of these days I won't be re-elected, but when that happens it will be for senility or a too-aggressive defense of principles - and that's fine too.
 
ERIC P. BIERRIE
New York, Nov. 20, 1989
 The writer is a member of the Commodity Exchange board of governors.

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Program Trading, Blame the Market;
Trouble With Futures

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Alan C. Greenberg's letter (Nov. 14) about index arbitrage and program trading recommends using ''circuit breakers'' and other devices to mitigate potential damage to financial markets from these activities. But he and other analysts, including the Brady Commission, don't get to the root of the problem, namely, trading in futures contracts per se.
Buyers and sellers of futures contracts, either in stock index futures or commodities or currencies, etc., agree to complete a transaction at some future date, usually 30 to 180 days from the date of trade execution. However, 99.9 percent of all futures contracts are liquidated, which means that 99.9 percent of all transactions entered into are never consummated during the life of the contract. The millions of futures contract trades executed each year representing trillions of dollars are in reality engagements for mutual speculation conducted in an environment of institutionalized chicanery which, except for the employment of several thousand floor brokers in Chicago and New York, serve no useful economic purpose. 
In addition, 80 to 90 percent of all speculators in futures contracts (mostly the little guy) traditionally lose money from these transactions. And the primary regulators of futures exchanges, namely the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the governing bodies of Chicago Board of Trade and other futures exchanges, are graduated floor brokers who unfortunately enjoy many of the same attributes of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board that has regulated savings and loan banks so irresponsibly over the last 10 years.
However, what's really troublesome is that on occasion, activities in futures-exchange pits take on a life of their own, oblivious to the real world. For example, in 1980 when the Hunt brothers cornered the gold and silver futures markets, the ''circuit breakers'' triggered by moves up to the limit in gold and silver prices did not halt the crescendo of gold prices to $870 per ounce and silver to $50 per ounce. During one period, gold and silver futures went up to the limit some 20 days in a row. The inflationary impact of this futures market activity was almost devastating: long-term interest rates exceeded 20 percent and the United States came close to becoming a banana republic with rampant inflation.
The obverse of the above - particularly a series of limit-down days in stock index futures - can create 1929-type disaster both for financial markets and the world's economy.
Why should we be subjected to a risk of this magnitude, however remote? Better that arbitrage and other program-trading schemes employing futures markets be eliminated from the panoply of financial markets. Congress and the Bush Administration should promptly initiate these re-forms since it is unreasonable to expect the Chicago Board of Trade and others voluntarily to give up untold profits each year for the good of mankind.
 
S. GEORGE GIANIS
New York, Nov. 27, 1989
 The writer heads an investment banking company.

HEADLINE: About New York;
A Tour Guide Who Sidesteps All the Schmaltz

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Marvin Gelfand grew up in a Brooklyn family faithful to a tradition prevalent when housing was far more abundant. They moved twice a year to take advantage of the month's free rent offered to new tenants.
This was an older, bolder New York - at least in memory, and what else is there? Mr. Gelfand, now 55 years old, remembers the sun glinting off hot asphalt, teeming peddlers' markets, ''the hugeness of the Irish cop.'' People didn't realize how lucky they were: ''The subways more or less worked, the libraries stayed open, the museums were free and the Dodgers were a going concern,'' he said. 
Nostalgia? Certainly, but not purposeless nostalgia. This is a story about how a young man fell in love with the world's greatest city, got lots of education, developed a point of view and ended up making a career out of leading people around town and telling them a thing or three. He became a tour guide.
Some quick detail: A scholarship to Cornell, then on to Columbia for a Ph.D. A professor at several colleges, then editing a book review. When the review moved out of New York in the early 1980's, he noticed the surging popularity of tours, long an institution in London and Paris. Well, why not? Mr. Gelfand led a ''Lovers and Losers'' tour for St. Valentine's Day trekkers. He was off and walking.
He loved it. Being a tour guide afforded him a captive audience, and the opportunity to flaunt a pugnacious, anti-authoritarian personality. ''I'm a street kid,'' he said. ''I see a lawyer in a pinstripe suit and I start throwing darts.''
He had joined a fraternity whose members range from college professors to former cab drivers.
Some specialize in buses, but purists prefer to let their feet do the walking. Most of the best work for several organizations - including the 92d Street Y, the Municipal Art Society and travel companies.
A colorful sampling of these self-described street warblers gathers monthly at an Upper West Side pub. The group includes a retired police captain who specializes in tours of Hell's Kitchen, a gourmand who noshes through the Lower East Side, people who can find ghosts in all five boroughs and a man who takes you to a SoHo shop where people spend $150 on polyester jackets. The net effect is a beery cacaphony of minute information, wild opinion and shameless self-promotion.
The other night, Mr. Gelfand encountered James S. Kaplan, a Wall Street lawyer (pinstripes, of course) who also leads excellent tours. The two enjoy a continuing duel. When Mr. Kaplan suggested that Tammany Hall wasn't all bad, Mr. Gelfand accused him of sanctioning corruption. And so on and on.
''You've got it all wrong, Jim!'' Mr. Gelfand shouted.
There are good days and bad days in the tour game. Mr. Gelfand was recently herding a Long Island synagogue group, about half of them children, through the Lower East Side. ''We don't want to see this through a haze of schmaltz,'' he began.
He told how these low-rise blocks were once a filthy slum and the world's largest Jewish city. Immigrants were crammed 14 to a room, sweatshops were rampant, anarchists railed. For the desperately poor, economics superseded morality, Mr. Gelfand said, launching a discussion of prostitution. So far so good.
Suddenly, the largest man shouted an arcane architectural question. Mr. Gelfand answered, then tried to return to his bawdy subject. The man bellowed another query. Soon, adults were lining up to say the leader was talking over children's heads.
''I told them I wasn't going to be all sweetness and light,'' Mr. Gelfand muttered. At the earliest opportunity, he left the group at a pickle store.
His crotchety soul needed solace. He grabbed a cab to Wall Street, where Mr. Kaplan was midway through a tour. Mr. Gelfand good-naturedly heckled his friend for lionizing J. P. Morgan and underemphasizing slavery's contribution to New York's economic growth. At the end, a happier man announced, ''I want to thank Jim for letting me mouth off.''
Season upon season, Mr. Gelfand leads people all over Gotham on what he calls his ''Walk of the Town.'' On the Upper West Side, he points out the house where he thinks Dreiser's Sister Carrie lived. In Harlem, he talks about the singer Billy Holliday and Benny Leonard, the boxer. George Washington is the hero of Mr. Gelfand's Bowery.
It isn't getting any easier. Mr. Gelfand -who has had seven eye operations and is now pretty much blind - must count steps to know precisely where he is. But he acknowledges just one problem.
''I can't see pretty girls the way I used to,'' the professional sightseer said.

HEADLINE: Koch Urges Tough Stance On the Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
In what amounted to a political valedictory, Mayor Edward I. Koch offered yesterday an ardent summation of his 12-year tenure, advised his successor to ''be not afraid'' and strongly criticized the Federal Government as being unfair to the city.
Speaking in an overflowing City Council chamber, Mr. Koch contended that, given a slowing economy, ''the city's best interests will require cutbacks in virtually every agency'' and that ''tax increases will be necessary to maintain vital services.''
He also said a proposal to raise the tax on gasoline, as part of a statewide program, and use the money the city gets to pay for repairs to city roads, bridges and highways and other structures should be considered.
At one point during his 50-minute speech, Mr. Koch looked at Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, the man who thwarted his bid for a fourth term and whom Mr. Koch quickly endorsed, and said that over the next few years ''it will be necessary to say no over and over again.'' Later, Mr. Koch offered ''a personal word to David, our new leader.'' 
 
Dinkins Hedges on Raising Taxes
''Have the best advice,'' he told him, but do not ''hesitate to rely on your own instincts.''
''Every mayor-elect has a certain anxiety, a certain fear about whether or not they're up to the job,'' he said. ''The people decided you were, and that's all that's requried.''
Asked afterward about the spending cuts that Mr. Koch spoke of, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I don't disagree with anything he said along those lines.'' But the Mayor-elect hedged on increasing taxes, saying he did not know yet whether there would be a need to raise them. ''Should it develop that there is a need, of course the City Council will have to address that,'' he added.
It was Mr. Koch's second State of the City Message in 1989. The first came in January of a year in which Mr. Koch would set out for a historic fourth term. At that time the Mayor, while not unmindful of the city's looming fiscal problems, announced several bold initiatives, including a plan to close the warehouse-like armories where thousands of homeless people are billeted.
Yesterday, his vision of the city was more sobering. He said that New York City was recording ''a barely perceptible level'' of economic growth and that the downturn in corporate profitability may be a harbinger of reduced employment that could in turn lead to lower personal income tax receipts, which if serious could ''put us in a full-blown recession.''
 
Strongest Language
The Mayor reserved his strongest language for the Federal Government, complaining that changes in policy were costing the city about $1.1 billion a year. ''Since 1981 we've had Presidents who said 'make my day' and 'read my lips.' We made President Reagan's day by keeping our eyes on his 'shining city on the hill.' But while our eyes were on the hill, his hands were in our pockets.''
''President Bush told us to read his lips,'' Mr. Koch said a little later. ''Well, I have read those lips. I can tell you that although the President's mouth says, 'No new taxes,' his lips say, 'Plenty of new taxes, all passed by state and local governments.' ''
Affirming a theme of his administration, Mr. Koch warned that the city's means were limited and that the government's ambitions to help the poor should be constrained by the need to maintain ''fiscal integrity.''
''Our desire to be generous is deep, as it should be, but our pockets are not,'' he said. ''New York City doesn't have the resources to become a social-welfare state on its own.''
He was not entirely gloomy about the future. ''Yes, the city faces serious problems,'' he said. ''But don't listen to pessimists crying doom and decay. Never mistake the end of a cycle for the end of the city.''
 
A String of Statistics
Much of Mr. Koch's message seemed recycled from campaign speeches in which he typically recited numerous statistics to demonstrate the gains made under his stewardship. Yesterday, he mentioned his $5.1 billion, 10-year housing plan, the more than 50 percent reduction in the number of homeless families in welfare hotels, programs to help treat people afflicted with AIDS, the more than 25,000 arrests made since the Police Department's Tactical Narcotics Teams began patrols last year and the more than doubling of the city's jail beds since 1983, among other achievements.
Speaking of violent crime, Mr. Koch said it was time for the State Legislature ''to give our courts a choice between capital punishment and life imprisonment without parole.''
And referring to possible conflicts between branches of the government under the revised City Charter, Mr. Koch urged cooperation. ''The city needs a mayor with the power to get things done,'' he said. ''There can only be one chief executive.''
Mr. Koch was given a 40-second ovation as he entered the Council chamber and was applauded about five times during his speech. He also solicited applause for several past and present members of his administration, whose contributions he praised.
The Mayor, who returned Sunday from a European vacation, has scheduled his traditional year-end interviews with the City Hall press corps for Dec. 26. But aides said there were no plans now for any major speeches before Mr. Koch leaves office Dec. 31.
 
Balancing the Budget
Since losing the Democratic primary to Mr. Dinkins in September, Mr. Koch has focused on the city's finances. After disappointing tax collections in the first three months of the fiscal year that began in July, he announced a program of spending cuts and other actions to balance this year's budget.
In contrast to the city's dimming fortunes, the Mayor has lined up a series of new jobs, some apparently lucrative. He will be a lawyer, university lecturer, radio commentator and newspaper columnist and is also mulling offers to make commercial endorsements.
Although he made headlines several weeks ago at a City Club meeting, when he sounded a 10-point warning on the city's future that seemed largely directed at programs and policies endorsed by Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Koch has been supportive of his successor. And he has refrained from commenting on reports that some of Mr. Dinkins's financial transactions were being investigated by a Federal prosecutor.
In his speech yesterday, Mr. Koch acknowledged that circumspection was not always his way. ''I always tried to speak out strongly on issues, issues of every kind,'' he said. ''In speaking out, it was not my intention to offend but rather to defend - to defend the people and the future of New York City. On occasion clearly I have failed in that objective. And for that failure I ask your forgiveness.''
''I know I did my job honestly,'' Mr. Koch said a few moments later. ''History will determine if I did it well.''

GRAPHIC: In his last State of the City Message, Mayor Edward I. Koch gave a summation of his 12 years in office, criticized the Federal Government as being unfair to the city and advised his successor, David N. Dinkins, far right, to ''be not afraid.'' (The New York Times/Keith Meyers)

HEADLINE: Greenwich's Private Deal for Public Problem

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 5

 BODY:
When the Greenwich Board of Education went shopping for a new superintendent this year, its members knew that it would be difficult to offer a package of pay and perquisites large enough to enable an out-of-town administrator to buy a home here. After all, the average price of a four-bedroom colonial on one and a half acres is $837,000.
So, the board members, like many struggling first-time home buyers in Fairfield County, devised a creative financing plan. A group of local investors will lend $200,000 to the new superintendent to help meet the down payment on a house in Greenwich. 
The plan is believed to be one of the largest housing subsidies ever developed by a suburban school system.
It is one of the rare instances in which a community enlists private aid to compensate a superintendent.
''It was necessary - I couldn't do it on my own,'' said John A. Whritner, who was named superintendent here last month and will start March 1. He currently holds the same post in Grosse Pointe, Mich., where housing costs are less than half of those in Greenwich.
''We're not talking a mansion,'' said William D. Davies Jr., a partner at Heidrick and Struggles Inc., an executive search firm in Greenwich that helped the town develop the plan. ''We're talking a sensible responsible home.''
Housing allowances and bridge loans are not uncommon in school districts in many parts of the country. For example, Westport, Conn., has provided its superintendent with an annual $12,000 allowance. Many districts provide free housing, as New York City will for its new Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, who will also receive a $10,000 annual expense account raised from private contributions.
Free housing can leave an official ''equity poor'' if real-estate prices rise rapidly, as they have in the Northeast and in California in the last decade.
Indeed, Mr. Whritner, 54 years old, has cited the free housing he received in Grosse Pointe during his five years there as one of the factors that left him unable to make a down payment on a Greenwich home. Free housing, sometimes of dubious condition, is perhaps most common in school districts in rural areas and in the Midwest.
''It is really a two-edged sword because you can lose capital appreciation,'' Mr. Davies said.
The arrangement between Greenwich and Mr. Whritner entails the investors, whose names the board has refused to release, lending him $200,000. In return, they will receive $200,000 equity in the house he purchases, plus a proportionate amount of the appreciation when the house is sold.
 
Salary of $105,600
Mr. Whritner, who worked as the superintendent in East Lyme, Conn., and as an administrator in White Plains before moving to Grosse Pointe, also will pay the investors 5 percent annual interest on the loan, but he will receive an $11,400-a-year stipend from the district to defray mortgage costs.
Additionally, he will receive a tax-deferred $15,000 annual annuity for retirement or, with board's approval, to buy some of the investor's equity in his home. His salary next year will be $105,600.
''There are a lot of communities where a $350,000 house is a very nice place to live, but its hard to find a home for that in Greenwich,'' said Donald S. Rotzien, chairman of the Greenwich Board of Education and a senior vice president at Union Trust Company. ''And we felt that it was important for the superintendent to live in and become part of the community.''
''It's a creative way to solve a problem and to attract the kind of person they want to attract,'' said Gary Marx, spokesman for the American Association of School Administrators in Arlington, Va. ''It's something we may be seeing more of in the future.''
School boards, perhaps more than other branches of local government, are feeling the pressure to increase compensation packages or improve housing accommodations because many superintendents are retiring, and competition is fierce among districts seeking the best of the next generation of administrators.
 
Honors for District
Many of the most highly regarded school systems are also in affluent suburban areas, where housing costs may be prohibitive. Greenwich's schools, for example, are widely regarded as among the best in the nation. The district has 6,400 pupils and a $50 million budget.
The district's library and media center has won many awards. Two Greenwich High School science teachers have won prestigious Presidential Awards. And the Federal Department of Education recently honored the high school as one of 276 of the nation's outstanding schools.
And in many small-to-medium-size communities a superintendent's post may be the only job for which a nationwide search is held, as local candidates are often hired for other high-ranking municipal positions. In the Northeast and California, such a search increases the likelihood that a superintendent will be moving from an area with lower housing costs.
''Superintendents are the equivalents of corporate leaders,'' said Ernest B. Fleishman, who left the Greenwich superintendent's position in June after 13 years and now works at Scholastic Inc., a Manhattan educational publishing concern. ''The public sector has to look at what it takes to attract people.''
Mr. Whritner's arrival comes as Greenwich schools are facing recent drops in Scholastic Aptitude Test scores, less-than-desired results in the Connecticut Mastery Test, deteriorating buildings and an increasing enrollment, particularly from minority-group members and non-English speaking students, who currently make up 14 percent of the district's student body.
 
Some Opposition to Plan
''The issues the new superintendent will be facing include a national desire to demand more of our students and that they achieve at higher levels,'' said the Acting Superintendent, Douglas W. Fainelli.
The plan to ease the new superintendent's housing costs, however, has not won unqualified endorsement in Greenwich, a staunchly conservative town of 60,000 residents 25 miles from Manhattan on the border of Westchester County. The local newspaper, Greenwich Time, has questioned whether the secrecy surrounding the identity of the donors could cloak conflicts of interest. And some local officials have questioned its economics.
''It will upset the pay scale for the town, everybody else will want the same thing,'' said E. Sidney Willis, the president of the Greenwich Chamber of Commerce. ''I realize that it's hard to get people here because of the housing but that's part of the game.''
It is difficult for many school officials to live in town. The headmaster of Greenwich High School, who earns $83,755, lives across Long Island Sound in Manhasset, L.I. An assistant superintendent, who earns $84,755, lives 25 miles - but about 40 minutes away -in Newtown. A starting teacher earns $26,919, and the average teacher salary is $43,000. About 35 percent of the district's 609 teachers and administrative employees live in town.
The problem has worsened in the past decade, as Greenwich has become a base for several Fortune 500 companies. In 1976, for example, the average cost of a Greenwich house was about $140,000, and the superintendent's annual salary was about one-third of that figure: $45,000.
''We would love to have all of our staff live in town,'' Mr. Rotzien said. ''But we know that's not possible.''

GRAPHIC: John A. Whritner, the newly appointed Superintendent of Schools in Greenwich, Conn., who will get help from the school system in buying his home.(The New York Times/Peter Yates)
