HEADLINE: 13 Join a Panel for Jersey City Schools

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The State Education Commissioner announced today the appointment of 13 Jersey City residents to a 15-member advisory Board of Education that will operate in the shadow of the state's all-powerful Superintendent in managing the public schools here.
Commissioner Saul Cooperman and Superintendent Elena J. Scambio stressed that the role of the board would be only advisory and expressed hope that it would function primarily as Dr. Scambio's link to taxpayers.
''With this board, we now have an important vehicle for community involvement and educational improvement,'' Dr. Cooperman said at a news conference. At the conference, Dr. Cooperman, Dr. Scambio and some board members offered views on how powerful and influential the board might be. 
Dr. Cooperman's aides chose 13 from among 150 residents who responded to an invitation to be members while the state reorganizes the 28,000-student district, which the state has condemned as educationally bankrupt. The members were selected in part to reflect the ethnic and racial composition of the city's population of 220,000. They include five blacks, four whites, three of Hispanic heritage and one Pakistani.
 
Makeup of the Board
Seven members have children in the system, and three are on the City-Wide Parents Council, the city's strongest pre-takeover parental voice in school operations. One is a homemaker, and two are clergy members. The others come from many professions. The members include an investment banker, a librarian, a nursing instructor, an auditor, a bookkeeper, a community-affairs coordinator in the New York schools and a director of minority affairs at St. Peter's College here.
Because Gov. Thomas H. Kean and top state officials have said they believe a long tradition of nepotism, cronyism, patronage and City Hall's politicizing of the schools is the root cause of its failure, the state screened out applicants with close associations to Mayor Gerald McCann and his precedessor, Anthony R. Cucci, officials said.
''We weeded out people we felt, based on past political associations, might have their role on the board compromised,'' said Walter McCarroll, an assistant commissioner who led the takeover campaign.
City Hall has the authority to appoint two members to complete the board. The members have not been chosen. Under a 1988 law that the Education Department invoked on Oct. 4 to seize the system and oust its nine-member board, Dr. Scambio has absolute authority for five years over curriculum, personnel, budgets, administration and maintenance. The law requires her to give the board monthly reports on her decisions. The board can review them and make recommendations.
Questions about the recommendations drew differing responses from Dr. Cooperman, Dr. Scambio and some members. Dr. Cooperman said he expected pragmatic and constructive advice, adding, ''They can say, 'I think that's a lousy idea.' ''
Dr. Scambio said she viewed the board members as conduits for information.
''I will set the agenda,'' she said. ''I'll rely on them to assist us in presenting our programs to parents and parts of the community. As I present proposals, I hope they would review them and give input drawn from the community.''
Some members offered different perceptions.
''It's a two-way street,'' said the Rev. Alexander M. Santora, parochial vicar at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church. ''I see it as a sounding board for the Superintendent.''
 
Delineating Some Problems
Father Santora and others said they had topics they wanted to see addressed. He said the system was not educating children who had severe economic disadvantages.
''I want to see what's going to happen to those who have fallen through the cracks,'' he said. ''How will we reach out to them, and what kind of programs will we offer them?''
The librarian, Joan Lovero, said years of inefficient administration had discouraged teachers and other employees.
''We should give them a new charge of energy,'' she said. ''There's a lot of creativity and talent among teachers that should be encouraged, reinvigorated and released.''
The other board members are Susan S. Hatzopoulos, the Rev. David E. Hoffman, Mohammad Imran, Jacqueline L. McReynolds, Raymond J. O'Brien, Hilda Perez-Santiago, Robert E. Perry, Ines Rodriguez, Kabili Tayari, Holly Ann Wojciechowski and Della Womack.

HEADLINE: Albany's Figures Show A $500 Million Shortfall

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Maintaining its drum roll of bad news, the Cuomo administration predicted today that tax revenues for the current fiscal year would be even worse than it had estimated just last month.
Figures provided by the State Department of Taxation and Finance indicate that the state's shortfall could grow to $500 million by the end of the fiscal year, almost $200 million more than the estimate in November, if business tax collections do not pick up markedly in the next few months.
After the November, estimate, the administration immediately called for a 2 percent across-the-board cut in spending by state agencies. 
Today, the State Budget Director, Dall W. Forsythe, said that the budget division had not been gloomy enough in its projections, particularly in the area of corporate tax revenues.
''What we've seen in November indicates that we will have to lower our business tax estimates,'' Mr. Forsythe said. ''Our preliminary results continue to be poor.''
 
Business Tax Collections Down
Mr. Forsythe insisted that he had not yet fully analyzed the data and did not know how much the state's budget problems had grown.
Because the budget gap has been disclosed so late in the fiscal year, this year's deficit will almost certainly be carried over into next year, adding to the state's problems in the spring. The Budget Director has already estimated that the state is facing a potential shortfall of $1 billion or more for the next fiscal year, but an analysis prepared for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's economic advisory committee indicates that the shortfall could swell to as much as $2 billion under some circumstances.
In the midyear report issued last month, the state budget division had already lowered its estimates of corporate tax revenues by $108 million, to $3.7 billion. But in its report, the division predicted that corporate tax revenues would rise significantly in the second half of the fiscal year.
''If I were doing the midyear report now the numbers would be lower,'' Mr. Forsythe said. The midyear report predicted total state tax revenues of $29.6 billion.
Corporate tax receipts throughout the Northeast have been steadily declining over the last few years, and economists are at a loss to explain why. Possible explanations include the stock market crash of two years ago, unanticipated effects of Federal tax code changes and an increase in deductible interest payments resulting from a rash of mergers and acquisitions.
In New York, corporate tax collections during the first part of the fiscal year have been running about 16 percent below last year's level.

HEADLINE: A.M.A. EXECUTIVE LEAVING AMID RIFT

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The American Medical Association's top executive, whose approval of two financial deals that lost money led to a dispute in the organization, has announced that he will retire when his current contract ends.
But he denies that it was the dispute that spurred his decision.
''I accept responsibility for the errors and the changes that are needed to prevent their recurrence,'' the 63-year-old official, Dr. James H. Sammons, said Sunday in remarks to the opening session of the group's midyear meeting. 
 
Plans Known Months Ago
Dr. Sammons, the group's executive vice president, and Dr. John J. Ring, its board chairman, said in speeches at the meeting that Dr. Sammons's plans to retire when his contract expires, in 1991, were known months ago.
The 425 members of the group's House of Delegates are meeting through Wednesday to set the group's policies on a number of health care issues, but the financial dispute has captured much of their attention. With nearly 300,000 members, the group is the nation's largest organization for doctors.
The dispute centers on two financial deals, the first involving Dr. Sammons's approval of a loan in 1985 to an A.M.A. executive to buy a condominium. The second involves Dr. Sammons's approval of a $353,000 reimbursement to a former A.M.A. executive for losses from a 1987 stock market investment. Dr. Sammons's approval of the two deals became known this fall.
On Saturday, the board issued a report that said Dr. Sammons acted within his authority in approving the two deals but ''failed to follow the usual fiscal policies and procedures.'' A spokesman for the group, Mark Stuart, said the board would not elaborate.
 
Default by Loan Recipient
The former executive involved in the stock-market loss has promised to repay the money he was given, with interest. The recipient of the condominium loan defaulted on it, costing the group $50,000 to foreclose.
Dr. Ring told the delegates that an investigation of the deals is continuing and a full report will be made to the House of Delegates. He said the board will take steps so that ''this will not happen again.''
The board also said it had accepted Dr. Sammons's plan to retire on March 31, 1991. Mr. Stuart said it was unclear why the board had included its statement about accepting the retirement plans in the report on the deals.
 
Hiring of Acccounting Firm Urged
Dr. Sammons, who is widely respected for rescuing the A.M.A. from financial difficulties after taking the job in 1974, plans to end his day-to-day management of the group at the end of next year.
The report by the board also proposed hiring an outside accounting firm, and it said the board would set tighter limits on the financial authority of the executive vice president, but did not elaborate.
At the meeting, the group's delegates are to consider taking these actions:
* Acknowledging the right of a patient to basic and essential health care.
* Establishing policies about instances of maternal-fetal conflict, including situations in which a pregnant woman refuses medical treatment that would benefit her fetus.
* Encouraging health insurance companies to reduce coverage costs for non-smokers.
* Urging that the blood-alcohol level at which a driver is considered to be legally drunk be lowered to 0.05 percent from 0.10 percent.
* Working toward doctors' listing tobacco on death certificates as a contributing factor.
The group's delegates are also to consider a resolution passed last month by the Washington State Medical Association urging that Dr. Sammons be placed on administrative leave until the investigation of the financial deals is completed.

HEADLINE: Education;
Governors and Experts Are Divided On Setting Nation's Education Goals

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
There may be only one thing that educators, business leaders, governors and President Bush agree on: America's schools are in trouble.
But as a committee of governors and White House staff members meets in Washington tomorrow to define the national educational goals they discussed with the President in the ''education summit'' meeting in September, experts are divided over what the real problems and solutions are. The committee also faces skepticism that the nation has the political will and financial commitment to make changes.
Disagreement abounds over the purely educational parts of the puzzle, to say nothing of battles over ideology and finance. For example, should the country emphasize raising test scores and imposing tougher graduation requirements, or changing schools' structure and teaching methods to reach poor and minority children who are not learning now? Are the national goals being considered by the committee the right ones, or should the nation be paying more attention to the connection between poverty and school failure, as some contend? In any case, how will proclaiming national goals insure that they are met?
 
No Place for the Unskilled
In some ways, the United States faces a new task: educating all students for an economy that no longer rewards unskilled labor. Many educators contend that the vision of a good public school system that transformed the lives of immigrant children is now largely a myth, and is no guide for solving current problems. Indeed, high school dropout rates in the decades before World War II were higher than they are now; the difference is that it mattered less.. 
Most educators were publicly ecstatic when Mr. Bush convened the education meeting in September. At the least, they hoped his ''bully pulpit'' approach would help rally public support in what they see as a national crisis.
The September meeting ended with a commitment to define broad educational goals by February and then devise a strategy to see that the states' performances improve accordingly. The meeting in Washington tomorrow marks the first step of that process, where the governors and White House representatives will hear proposals from education, labor and business leaders on what those goals should be.
But many people remain skeptical that far-reaching changes can take place without more money, which is nowhere in sight, and without the political courage to take on entrenched interests that range from teachers' and administrators' unions to textbook publishers, state legislators and religious groups.
 
Ignoring the Resources
''I'm not going to wait for national leadership,'' said Robert S. Peterkin, Milwaukee's superintendent of public schools. ''I don't have the time for it. It might be valuable to have a broad set of goals, but we still seem to be ignoring what the resources are.
''When the military is having problems, we allocate money,'' he continued. ''When the savings and loans industry is having problems, we allocate money. When education is having problems, we say we could possibly allocate a few dollars.''
Others say the governors and the President did not address the central issue: poverty.
''We can do a lot more with schools to be successful, but we can never get sufficiently successful when we have growing poverty in this country,'' said Harold Howe 2d, a senior lecturer on education at the Harvard Graduate School of Education and a former Commissioner of Education. ''But attacking poverty is very expensive, and means doing things politically that are either impossible or very difficult to bring off.''
 
The Great Unmentionable
Money was the great unmentionable at the September meeting. But attaining many of the goals the President and the governors discussed -including improving literacy, reducing dropout rates, finding more qualified teachers and increasing nutrition and education programs for preschool children - will cost money.
Nor has Mr. Bush's pledge to be the ''education President'' meant more money for education. The Education Department's budget for elementary and secondary education in the fiscal year 1990 increased by 5 percent from 1989, while that for the previous year increased by nearly 10 percent.
Some educators are also urging the President and the governors to bridge the gap between rich and poor school districts created by reliance on local financing of education.
Gov. Bill Clinton, an Arkansas Democrat who is co-chairman of the governors' task force on education, says he is confident that defining goals will coax and embarrass states and schools into meeting them. ''Once we decide where the country needs to be, we can get there,'' he said.
 
A Greater Federal Role
But the Governor added that making changes will require a greater Federal role, counter to a long tradition of state and local control over schools.
Many of America's most formidable economic rivals, like Japan, have a nationally controlled educational system that produces universal literacy. And the Japanese Government pays nearly half the cost of education; in the United States, the Federal Government pays about 6 percent of the total.
No one is suggesting that money alone will remake the schools. James D. Robinson, chairman of American Express Company who is one of many business executives worried that the nation's schools are turning out an unskilled work force that hurts American competitiveness, said many schools were mismanaging the money they receive.''What's needed is reform of the school system in terms of accountability and spending,'' he said.
Deciding what else to do depends on how the governors, business leaders and educators define the problem. Some emphasize declining standardized test scores, high school seniors' ignorance of historical facts and the poor showing of American schoolchildren against other countries' students in mathematics and science.
 
Tougher Standards Urged
These critics include Diane Ravitch, a professor at Columbia University's Teachers College who is co-author of ''A Nation at Risk,'' a 1983 report that helped start the current drive for reform, and E. D. Hirsch Jr., author of ''Cultural Literacy: What Every American Should Know.'' They call for tougher high school graduation and college entry requirements and a national curriculum detailing what children in each grade should learn.
Other educators, like Mr. Peterkin, maintain that imposing requirements will not be as effective as exploring new teaching methods that capture students' interest and motivate them to learn. The most serious problem in American education, they argue, is the failure of schools to educate children who are poor and members of minorities.
''Just raising standards itself will create larger numbers of youngsters at risk,'' said Lester W. Young Jr. New York States's assistant commissioner of education. He and many educators who work with minority children say they do not believe in lowering expectations for such children, but in finding ways to lift their confidence.
Mr. Robinson and other executives generally want more emphasis on basic skills, computer literacy and work habits. Many companies are adopting schools, sending their employees to talk to students and serve as mentors, advising school administrators on management and personnel strategies, or creating training centers of their own.
 
Poverty and Poor Schooling
The programs are just some of many changes since education thrust itself into the spotlight in the early 1980's. Average teacher salaries have risen 19 percent in inflation-adjusted terms, foundations have bankrolled dozens of innovative programs, and many states have imposed stricter curriculum requirements and substantially increased the amount of money they spend for education.
While most of the goals proposed at the education summit meeting have the support of different ideological camps, educators raised several areas they believe the governors and Mr. Bush ignored. Most prominent among them is the link between poverty and poor schooling. Schools are reeling under the burden of caring for students whose families have disintegrated under the pressure of poverty or drugs.
''Making schools work for poor people is a brand new task,'' said Colin Greer, author of ''Choosing Equality,'' which outlines ways schools can reach poor students.
Several educators offered a range of other possible goals, including reducing teen-age pregnancy and getting teen-age mothers to return to school so they can motivate their children to succeed. Other goals involve efforts to attract more qualified teachers who are members of minorities and improving teacher training.
 
A Commitment From Parents
Achieving any of these goals will require a commitment not only from the governors and the President, but also from parents - who, Professor Ravitch said, have not demonstrated that they care enough. The real test, said P. Michael Timpane, president of Teachers College at Columbia, is yet to come.
''Is this nation going to find a way to put education at the top of its priorities?'' he asked. ''Will the important politicians stay involved? Will they set up a process by which they commit themselves to do whatever's necessary, whether money or leadership, or will they try to make quick improvmeents and diverty their attention to someone else?
''If the answer is yes, the summit will have been a very important event,'' he said. ''If no, it will have been a public relations exercise.''

CORRECTION-DATE: December 7, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Education page yesterday about national educational goals misattributed the 1983 report ''A Nation at Risk.'' The report was written by the National Commission on Excellence in Education; Diane Ravitch, a professor at Columbia University's Teachers College, was not a co-author and has never been a member of the commission.

HEADLINE: FOOD NOTES

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Takeout From Arcadia Arcadia, the two-star restaurant on East 62d Street in Manhattan, has branched out into the retail food business in time for the holidays. About a month ago, Anne Rosenzweig, the chef and owner, opened Out of Arcadia, a pocket-size shop in the Citicorp Center, 151 East 53d Street; 212-308-1320. Food to go is available for a quick lunch or a more elaborate catering job.
The menu changes daily. For example, there may be eggplant and ratatouille pizza ($4 a slice), crab and lobster cakes to be eaten hot or cold ($4 each), superb cheese straws ($2 each), sticky buns ($3 each) and currant scones ($1.50 each). Sandwiches on excellent breads are $3 to $8. 
 
Dutch Treats
Peter G. Rose, a food historian who was born in the Netherlands and who is researching the influence of Dutch foods in the United States, has now made it possible to sample some historic Dutch treats. With John and Peter DeJong, the owners of the Village Bake Shop in Mount Kisco, N.Y., she has developed four cookies that are being sold in museum gift shops.
The delicious assortment includes speculaas, a traditional crisp spice cookie topped with almonds; albimaids, two oval sugar cookies that were named by a baker in Albany at the turn of the century; a sweet pretzel, actually delicate puff pastry in a pretzel shape, and a Half Moon shortbread cookie named for Henry Hudson's ship.
The cookies are $1.50 each and come with a paragraph of historic information. They are sold in the gift shops at the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street; Van Cortlandt Manor, 5 Riverside Avenue, Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and at Philipsburg Manor on Route 9 and at Sunnyside on Sunnyside Lane, both in Tarrytown, N.Y.
 
Two Recipe Contests
To promote good nutrition, Community School Board District 13 in Brooklyn is sponsoring a recipe contest for children and adults. Entries may be submitted by adults living in the school district and children attending one of the 23 elementary and junior high schools in the district. The district covers Fort Greene and Brooklyn Heights and parts of Park Slope and Bedford-Stuyvesant.
Recipes should be nutritious and economical, using ingredients that are readily available. Prizes include dinners at local restaurants, including Gage & Tollner, and gift certificates at local food stores. The recipes, accompanied by the entrant's name, address, age, and if appropriate, school, should be sent before Jan. 1 to Erica Zurer, Community School Board District 13, 355 Park Place, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11238. Information: 718-789-0239.
The stakes are higher in Kids in the Kitchen, a recipe contest sponsored by Shoprite Supermarkets and open to children age 6 to 13 in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Delaware. The grand prize in each of six categories will be a trip to Disney World.
Recipes must be postmarked by Jan. 15. Entry blanks can be obtained at Shoprite stores or by sending a stamped, self-addressed envelope to Kids in the Kitchen, Shoprite Supermarkets, P.O. Box 7812, Edison, N.J. 08818-7812.
 
Ban on Irradiated Foods
As of Nov. 21, the sale of irradiated foods was banned in New York State, with the exception of spices and foods served to hospital patients with immune-system deficiencies.
The Federal Food and Drug Administration approved the irradiation of fruits, vegetables, pork products, grains and spices in 1986 to destroy insects and bacteria and retard spoilage. The safety of the technique has been hotly debated, with some scientists contending that it destroys vitamins and may create carcinogens.
Under the New York law, irradiated foods already on the market do not have to be withdrawn. Kevin Burns, an assistant director of the nonprofit New York Public Research Group in Manhattan, said it is almost impossible to know exactly what those foods are, since irradiation labels are required only when the entire product has been treated. When one or more ingredients have been irradiated, labeling is not necessary.
Maine is the only other state to have banned irradiated food, but similar bans are being considered by New Jersey and Massachusetts.
The New York law expires after two years, which means that the issue will be reconsidered in 1991.
 
The Most Basic of the Fold Arts
IN conjunction with ''America Eats: Folk Art and Food,'' a show that opens tomorrow and continues through Feb. 4, the Museum of American Folk Art at Columbus Avenue and 66th Street has scheduled a series of four lectures. The first, on Shaker food, will be at 6 P.M. Tuesday. The other topics: food of woodland Indians, Dec. 19; Early American pastries, Jan. 9, and Pennsylvania German cooking, Jan. 16.
Each session costs $10 for museum members, $15 for nonmembers. For reservations, checks, payable to the museum, should be sent to the Museum of American Folk Art, Curator of Education, 61 West 62d Street, New York, N.Y. 10023. Information: 212-977-7170.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Bonnard's Graphics Illuminate His Entire Output

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
''Pierre Bonnard: The Graphic Art'' is a major contribution to the understanding of a French modernist revered for the lushness and luminosity of his color and light and for his discreet yet voluptuous vision. Bonnard (1867-1947) arouses such loyalty not only because of the poetry of his painting but also because of its integrity. There is a very strong sense of him as an artist beyond fashion whose men and women prefer introspection to confrontation and whose paintings are not in a hurry to tell anybody anything.
This exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is the first in 25 years to insist that all aspects of Bonnard's achievement be considered as a whole. It suggests why his paintings, which can seem so limpid, are so concentrated and substantial. By focusing on the graphic work with which Bonnard was seriously engaged only during one decade (the 1890's), the exhibition opens up everything he did. It is in the graphic work that Bonnard's ideas and influences may be most accessible. 
The roughly 125 works in the exhibition include some of Bonnard's best-known images. ''France-Champagne'' is the famous 1891 poster -with its young woman as effervescent as Champagne and the sickle-shaped letter ''C'' ready to cut the ribbon of her dress - that established Bonnard's reputation. Bonnard's poster for ''La Revue Blanche'' in 1894, with the shadowy elegance of its tall Parisienne, her body looming behind a masklike face that seems as discardable as paper, is a dazzling and disconcerting fin-de-siecle icon.
During this formative decade, Bonnard was anything but a marginal figure. His prints of the 1890's ''reflected activity at the absolute center of the Parisian avant-garde in a way his art would never do again,'' writes Colta Ives, the Met curator who organized the show, in the beautifully designed catalogue. Bonnard felt the excitement of Paris at a time of mounting energy, nationalism and self-consciousness, and he let this excitement carry his work.
There was almost no major artistic development to which he did not respond. The graphic work offers plenty of evidence of the styles and compositions of Japanese prints, of the themes and suggestiveness of Symbolism, of the flatness and nerviness of Post-Impressionism and finally of the free touch of Impressionism. Bonnard came to Impressionism after Post-Impressionism, after he had already defined his commitment to memory and imagination, which helps explain the blend of transparency and impenetrability in his painting.
He tried just about every artistic activity. Like other members of the influential group of painters known as the Nabis, he believed in what he later called ''popular production.'' He designed birth announcements, concert programs, magazine covers, theater posters and screens. In the two folding screens called ''Promenade,'' from 1894 and 1895 - reunited in this show for the first time in 40 years - he made Paris street life part Roman frieze, part Japanese print and part cabaret.
He drew illustrations for a music primer in the early 1890's. For Paul Verlaine's ''Parallelement,'' published in 1900, he made nudes, sleeping, locked together and haunting the page in ways that reflect the erotic reveries of the poems.
This celebrated livre de peinture suggests Bonnard's awareness of the emotional currents lying below the surface of the middle-class life that he both embraced and exposed. While discussing this work in her catalogue essay, the art historian Sasha Newman cites Bonnard's famous statement in 1891: ''I am of no school. I am looking only to do something personal.'' She interprets this remark to mean he was looking for a ''subject that would liberate the development of his inner core, his subconscious -what Bergson and Feneon called intuition.''
In short the show demonstrates conclusively that Bonnard should never be seen as an alternative to the avant-garde - as a bastion of artistic serenity in a century of provocation and change. His experience with the avant-garde remained part of him long after he left Paris and began moving about incessantly. He never repudiated his beginnings. Even when he lived somewhat reclusively in the south of France, he never stopped returning regularly to Paris to measure himself against what other painters were doing.
In the landscapes, interiors, nudes and self-portraits for which he is best known, Bonnard incorporated what he had learned as a young man. One of the reasons for the power of his paintings that seem to celebrate the almost clannish intimacy of middle-class life is that they are branded by the sensibility of an outsider. One reason his stillness and light are so persuasive is that they are so fiery and driven, and they invariably carry the memory - in the walls, curtains, leaves and bodies - of something fleeting, burning and unstable.
One of the great strengths of this exhibition is its insight into the way Bonnard worked and thought. Sometimes the insight is provided by juxtapositions - of prints and paintings, of early and later work, of studies and prints.
For example, ''The Square at Evening'' is among 12 lithographs from the 1899 series ''Some Aspects of Paris Life,'' published by the celebrated dealer Ambroise Vollard. It is crowded with well-dressed shadowy figures, including a woman who seems not only pressed against the picture plane but also in front of it. To the right is a woman crossing the street, head down, almost in a trance.
Alongside the lithograph is a study of her alone - just a few lines drawn with such economy that she is futuristic and almost formless - which clarifies her position as the hinge or wheel around which everything in the lithograph turns.
The lithograph and two of the studies for ''The Little Laundry Girl'' from 1895-96, suggest Bonnard's humor and bite and his ability to put his own stamp on popular motifs - in this case, a fashionable lady walking her dog. The laundry girl was a common sight. ''By midcentury,'' Ms. Ives writes, ''the laundry industry was employing over one-fifth of the population of Paris and its environs.''
In one study, the little girl in black who seems barely a child yet already an old woman, has a dog alongside her as she walks a cobblestone street. In another study, the dog is in front of her, by the curb, beside three faceless grown-ups on the sidewalk. In the lithograph, the street is empty except for the girl in sooty silhouette and the spotted, brown-and-white dog, now eyeing each other in recognition. The young girl, her hair slightly disheveled, is dragging a cart of clean white laundry that looks like a cradle, and the dog seems a few steps from jumping in.
This work is tender, acerbic and tremendously self-assured. It is worth remembering Bonnard's agility and curiosity the next time his paintings, in all their inflamed deliberation, are assembled. From this show it will be easier to locate the tightrope Bonnard walked between paradise envisioned and paradise lost.
''Pierre Bonnard: The Graphic Art'' remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Feb. 4. It was financed by the Real Estate Council of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the William Randolph Hearst Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts. The exhibition will travel to the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston (Feb. 25 to April 29 1990) and to the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston (May 25 to July 29).

GRAPHIC: ''La Revue Blanche,'' an 1894 poster that is in the exhibition ''Pierre Bonnard: The Graphic Art'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

HEADLINE: Art Prices Are Still Astonishing, But Fever Seems to Be Cooling

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Art is still commanding breathtaking sums in the auction houses. Pablo Picasso's ''Pierrette's Wedding'' was bought last week by a Japanese real-estate developer for $51.3 million, the second highest price ever paid for a painting. But indications are that the feverish buying of recent years is beginning to cool down and that buyers are becoming more selective.
This was in evidence at auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art held in New York, London and Paris last month. Buying was more selective, the prices paid for some major works were lower than the auction houses had expected, and more than a few paintings and sculptures were not sold.
Art dealers and representatives of the auction houses attribute the shift in climate to several factors, including a general economic slowdown, exaggerated estimates by the sellers and auction houses for some works and a shift away from Impressionist works, which have become too expensive for all but the wealthiest buyers - chiefly the Japanese. 
 
Some Disappointments
Unrealized expectations included a sale on Nov. 12 by Habsburg, Feldman in New York of 95 artworks in which only 36 were sold for $14.9 million in a sale that had been valued by the auction house at $32 million to $41 million. At another sale, held by Guy Loudmer in Paris at the Drouot, the 65 artworks that were sold brought $13 million; the 22 that did not were valued at $5 million. At Christie's in New York, in an auction of 97 artworks, 29 did not sell, including 7 from the Paul Mellon collection.
Many of the disappointments were in Impressionist and modern art. Sales showed a decisive turn toward early 20th-century modern artists as Cubist and abstract works increased substantially in value.
The New York art auctions began with spirited bidding on Nov. 7 at Christie's with a sale of 101 contemporary artworks. Most postwar styles were represented - Pop Art, Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism, Color Field art and others. Although the sale totaled $62.43 million - double the highest previous amount for such a sale at this house - and had 26 records for the works of artists, it was an auction without fireworks.
 
Getting More Selective
The high point of the night was the sale of Roy Lichtenstein's ''Torpedo . . . Los,'' a 1963 comic-strip image of war, for $5.5 million, an auction record for a work by the artist.
After that sale, Thomas Ammann, a Zurich art dealer, commented on the changed mood of the art market. ''The good pieces brought very strong prices,'' he said. ''But people are starting to be a little bit more selective. They are not just snapping up everything anymore.''
''Maybe the auction houses have been a little more aggressive than they needed to be and promised collectors too much,'' said Richard Gray, a Chicago dealer, after the Christie's auction on Nov. 14, at which half the Mellon collection did not sell and the other half brought less than expected. ''As prices continue to escalate, the buying pool tends to shrink a little.''
The most important Mellon work, Edouard Manet's ''Rue Mosnier, Paris, Decorated With Flags on June 30, 1878,'' was sold to the J. Paul Getty Museum of Malibu, Calif., for $26.4 million, a record for the artist and for any Impressionist work. But the price was below the ''more than $30 million'' Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in the United States, said it would bring when he announced its sale in September.
Nevertheless, in capturing the Manet, the Getty again demonstrated that it is alone among museums in being able to compete at the highest level. In May, the museum acquired Pontormo's ''Halberdier'' for $35.2 million.
 
Effect of the Japanese
Mr. Burge said: ''The Impressionist market is too expensive. I do not think it is helped by the fact that the Japanese, bidding against each other, pushed Impressionist prices so high.''
One Japanese buyer spent more than one-tenth of the total taken in by Christie's and Sotheby's in New York and London during these art sales in November. The buyer, Aska International, paid $115.8 million for paintings by Renoir, Monet, van Gogh and Gauguin at these two houses and spent $6.5 million at Habsburg, Feldman. Aska, which operates the Aoyama Gallery of Tokyo and became a major stockholder in Christie's in October, is owned by the Aichi Corporation, a Tokyo-based finance company headed by Yasumichi Morishita.
''There wasn't anything that ran away this time at the highest level,'' said David Nash, who heads fine art sales at Sotheby's in New York. ''The disappointments in the auctions this time have to do with expectations.''
''The last three years was up, up, up with no end in sight,'' Mr. Burge said. ''We can now more clearly chart expectations for sellers.''
In sharp contrast to the upbeat mood that prevailed at most of the sessions that took place in May and in November 1988 in New York, euphoria was absent from these art sales.
''I think the sales went fantastically well when you consider that we are in the middle of a downturn,'' Stephen Hahn, a Madison Avenue art dealer, said.
 
The Successes
Successes could be seen in the record prices for the works of scores of artists and for several categories of art sales. Sotheby's in New York took in $269.5 million - a record for any art sale - on Nov. 15, the night Walter Annenberg bought Picasso's ''Au Lapin Agile'' for $40.7 million.
In less than a month, 18 artworks were sold for more than $10 million each - 9 at Sotheby's in New York, 8 at Christie's in New York and London and 1 at the Drouot sale by Binoche & Godeau in Paris. Of these, 6 were sold for more than $20 million each - 3 at Sotheby's in New York, 2 at Christie's in New York and the 1 at the Drouot -more than double any past performance at these sales.
 
Buyers Spent $1 Billion
The market may have cooled somewhat, but it is far from frozen. Even though these were sales in which applause was rarely heard and van Gogh's ''Irises'' was not eclipsed as the world's most expensive painting at $53.9 million, buyers spent about $1 billion for artworks produced mostly over the last century - a figure well above the previous record of $700 million set in May, the last period of major art sales.
Works by Picasso continued to figure prominently in auctions this season. The November sales in New York, London and Paris offered seven Picasso paintings valued at more than $10 million each. Of these, six were sold for a total of $163.7 million. Only one, ''Death of a Harlequin'' from the Mellon collection at Christie's, which was expected to bring about $20 million, failed to sell, possibly because of its somber theme.
''There was no Japanese support for 'Death of a Harlequin,' '' Mr. Burge said. ''One potential buyer said he thought his young son would be frightened by the subject.''
Leo Castelli, the New York art dealer, emerged more thoughtful than elated from one Sotheby's sale at which Willem de Kooning's ''Interchange'' brought $20.7 million - the highest price paid at auction for the work of a living artist and for a contemporary artwork. The sale itself was a record for any auction of contemporary art - $98.3 million.
''What is really miraculous,'' Mr. Castelli said, ''is that the prices are holding up and that there is so much money around to buy so many expensive paintings.''

HEADLINE: U.S. and Canada in Accord On Speeding Up Tariff Cuts

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The United States and Canada, which last Jan. 1 put into effect a free-trade agreement aimed at wiping out practically all trade barriers between the two countries within a decade, have decided to speed up tariff cuts covering $6 billion in trade.
The decision affects chemicals, pharmaceuticals, printed circuit boards, scientific instruments, electric motors and other items, and could mean lower prices in both countries for those and related products. The new schedule was seen as a healthy sign for the overall agreement, which had a shaky start chiefly because of opposition in Canada.
''Entrepreneurs on both sides of the border like free trade so much they want more of it,'' said the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills. Since March, she has been working out the speed-up with her Canadian counterpart, Trade Minister John C. Crosbie. 
Despite the sluggishness this year in the Canadian and American economies, Mrs. Hills said in an interview today, trade between the two countries continues to expand ''and some of the credit has to be given to the free-trade agreement.'' She added, ''Entrepreneurs are striking at areas of opportunity.''
The acceleration, which eliminates tariffs that were not scheduled to come off under the original accord for five or, in some cases, 10 years, is a response to requests from American and Canadian industry, including many multinational companies seeking to trim costs on imported components.
Being eliminated, for example, are the 8 percent Canadian and 5.3 percent American duties on printed circuit boards, which will cut costs for a wide range of electronics products, including computers. The two countries already exchange more than $200 million worth of printed circuit boards.
Also coming off are Canada's 8 percent to 12 percent duty on electric motors and the American tariff of 3 percent to 5 percent. This could mean lower prices for products that use electric motors, like refrigerators. There is at least $50 million a year of two-way business in such motors, which is likely to expand.
Derek Burney, Canada's Ambassador to the United States, said in an interview today that tempers had cooled in Canada and the free-trade agreement was now seen ''more as an economic instrument and less in psychological terms.'' He said, ''The apocalyptic forecasts of the opponents have just not materialized.''
Much of the Canadian opposition was based on fears that American industry would overwhelm Canada, causing unemployment and a loss of national identity.
 
Easy Approval Seen
The acceleration would take effect April 1, and needs the approval of the Canadian Parliament and the United States Congress. Because the tariff cuts are only in cases where there has been no industry opposition, the agreement is expected to pass easily in both countries.
In the United States, the process includes a 60-day review by the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. Barring opposition, the necessary amendments to the United States tariff schedule would be made by Presidential proclamation.
In Canada, customs tariff amendments would be required after publication of a notice in the Canada Gazette. The Gazette is the equivalent of the Federal Register in the United States, where the new tariff cuts would also be published.
The acceleration process was started by the two Governments at the request of Canadian and American industries. A further speed-up is expected in 1991.
Under the free-trade deal, some tariffs were wiped out last Jan. 1, but the bulk would be eliminated in stages over five and, for the most sensitive products, 10 years.
The cuts affect more than 500 products, about 10 percent of the initial requests by the industries of both countries. The trade benefits are divided equally, with the package covering $3 billion of Canadian exports to the United States and approximately the same value of American exports to Canada. $200 Billion in Trade The original free-trade agreement took two years to negotiate and was ratified by Canada only after a general election victory last year by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a Conservative who supported the pact. It is, in effect, a framework for managing the world's largest and most complex two-way trade, approaching $200 billion of goods and services this year.
In addition to writing tariff-cutting schedules, the pact sets rules for trade in manufactured goods, agricultural products, energy and services; calls for investment liberalization, and sets up procedures for dispute settlement.
The two countries continue to have a number of arguments over trade issues, chiefly related to agricultural products. But as Mr. Burney commented, ''The agreement sets up the machinery to contain these disputes.''

HEADLINE: Stocks Take Taiwan on Giddy Ride

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
To investors in the Taiwan stock market, ''research'' often means talking to a fortune teller, and ''long-term investments'' tend to be measured in weeks instead of years. But what the Taiwan Stock Exchange lacks in pinstripes and gravity, it makes up for in size and performance.
The stock market on this island of 20 million people is the busiest in the world, based on the number of shares changing hands. More than 20 billion shares are traded on a typical day -about 20 times the average in Tokyo and more than 100 times the average in New York.
When measured by the total value of transactions, Taiwan consistently ranks third in the world, behind Tokyo and New York, although on a really good day the value of transactions here may exceed that of the New York Stock Exchange. 
''They're gambling their hearts away,'' Blair C. Pickerell, president of the Taiwan International Securities Corporation, said as he pointed to the hundreds of clients gazing intently at careering prices on electronic tickers above his company's trading floor.
To be sure, with its sharp daily swings, the Taiwan market often seems a gambler's playground. For example, the market plunged 5.7 percent on Nov. 28, leading to street protests in which investors demanded that the Government prop up the market. The authorities responded by announcing that a proposed stock-trading tax would be lower than planned, sending the index jumping 6.5 percent the next day.
Still, the Taiwan market has proved to be mainly a one-way bet in recent years. The market index first broke through the 1,000 barrier in 1986, and this year it jumped past the 10,000 level. It has since come down from that peak, and closed at 8,701.15 on Tuesday, up 35.3 points.
The rise of the Taiwan market reflects more than the speculative froth on a fast-growing East Asian economy. The growth of the market is due in part to the financial restructuring of Taiwan companies, as they mature beyond entrepreneurial family businesses and need equity capital to pay for further growth.
 
More Overseas Investment
Moreover, the financial wealth of Taiwan is likely to become more apparent to outsiders as it increases its investment abroad. In the first 10 months of this year, Taiwan's overseas investment increased by two and a half times, to $609 million. Though far smaller than that of Japan, the financial might of Taiwan owes much to its being a highly competitive manufacturer; its persistent trade surplus creates wealth at home and then is partly invested overseas.
Indeed, the stock market boom gives Taiwan's companies tremendous potential buying power: one financier recently noted casually to a foreign businessman that he could finance the purchase of Chase Manhattan Bank.
The biggest banks in Taiwan have market capitalizations greater than those of Chase Manhattan and Citicorp combined. This is mainly because Taipei's price-earnings ratios have soared to breathtaking levels; the stock of Hsin Chu Medium Business Bank, for instance, is trading at nearly 900 times earnings.
The average price-earnings ratio for the market is variously calculated as anywhere from 65 to 130, depending on whether the average is weighted by the market capitalization of the listed companies. In contrast, the average price-earnings multiple of stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 is now about 15.
 
Foreigners Are Barred
Foreigners are not allowed to purchase shares directly in Taiwan, but they can buy into four funds that represent packages of Taiwan equities. Two of the funds, the RoC Taiwan Fund and the Taiwan Fund, are listed on the New York Stock Exchange. The others can be purchased through specialized brokerages.
The Government has pledged that it will eventually open its markets to foreigners, but it has not given a timetable. Some foreign analysts are skeptical, suggesting that the stock market will be opened only after a crash, when investment is needed.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange is often described as a ''cowboy market,'' and playing it has become a national pastime. There are several million private investors, and they dominate the market. Institutions account for only about 20 percent of trading.
Investors trade very frequently, constantly ducking into and out of stocks. The equivalent of the total market value of the Chia Hsin Livestock Company, for example, turned over 2.5 times in October, meaning that the average share was retained less than two weeks. Although that was unusually high volume, the average turnover is also much higher here than in other markets.
 
Furtive Visits to Brokerages
Bank tellers and office clerks are often seen with earphones, listening to a radio station that broadcasts nothing but stock prices. They periodically assert an urgent need to visit the washroom, only to rush outside to the nearest brokerage. After making a trade, they return to work.
''Even a lot of blue-collar workers have decided to quit their jobs and spend the time playing the market,'' said J. C. Chu, vice president of the Taiwan exchange. ''The ministry of economic affairs has expressed concern about the impact if blue-collar employees decide to stop working.''
Cars are invariably double-parked outside brokerages; investors rush in to check prices and make trades. Brokerages are jammed with hundreds of people who play the market full time. A slight majority are housewives, but students, businessmen and taxi drivers also rub shoulders.
''The stock market has been growing very irrationally,'' said Fredrick F. Chien, chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development. ''It was growing by leaps and bounds, and it created a lot of fantasies.''
 
Important to Taiwan
But Mr. Chien and others stressed that the market is important to Taiwan's development. Chang Liang, president of the Shearson Lehman Hutton subsidiary in Taipei, suggests that the stock market is coming to play an important role in the country's industrial revamping, in which companies take on equity for debt to strengthen their balance sheets.
Outside mainland China, companies founded by Chinese entrepreneurs - particularly those in Taiwan - are often said to be spectacularly successful at the initial stage, when they are run as family enterprises. But as they grow and the founders hand them to their children, the companies have frequently encountered severe difficulties.
Mr. Chang suggested that the stock market was helping to overcome these problems, by rewarding firms that adopt international standards of accounting and management.
''The well-being of Taiwan's economy depends on this capital market,'' Mr. Chang said. Not everyone is so enthusiastic, particularly about the market as it now exists. Diane Ying, a prominent local magazine publisher, said that while Taiwan needed an efficient capital market, it must be supervised and regulated more closely.
''This is a gambling joint, and a rigged gambling joint,'' she complained.
Insider trading is technically against the law here, but almost everyone acknowledges that it is widespread and that a large share of trades are made on tips of one kind or another. ''Everybody's got a tip,'' Mr. Pickerell said. ''The only question is whether it's right.''
 
Margin Violations
A greater concern to some analysts are violations of restrictions on margin trading. No one knows how widespread the practice is, but some analysts say that up to 30 percent of investments are made with borrowed money. One scenario that creates nightmares is that the market would fall far enough to force these investors to sell their stakes and repay their loans. A few defaults could drive the market much lower and cause a serious crash, some say.
Almost no one rules out the possibility of a crash - indeed, there have been two plunges of about 40 percent in the last few years, and other smaller plunges - but local investors seem optimistic. They say that Taiwan is awash with money, and that there are few other places to invest if people pull out of stocks.
And, they note indulgently, some people grew nervous in 1986 when the index reached 1,000. They pulled out of the market and missed the subsequent tenfold leap of prices.

HEADLINE: Car Sales Off, With Big 3 Hurt the Most

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and trucks fell in late November and were down sharply at the Big Three. Japan's auto makers, however, continued to show relative strength.
Sales of vehicles produced at Japanese plants in the United States surged, while sales of imported models fell at a relatively modest rate.
Indeed, the Honda Motor Company's rising share of the American market, now 9.6 percent, moves it close to the Chrysler Corporation, whose share has slipped to 10.3 percent. 
Among European makes, sales of Porsche, Mercedes, BMW and Saab were off compared with November 1988. Audi, VW and Volvo were flat.
Over all, the sales reports heightened fears that an automotive recession is under way.
From Nov. 21 to Nov. 30, which included eight selling days, the General Motors Corporation said domestic car sales dropped 24 percent from the period a year ago. The Ford Motor Company posted an 8.7 percent drop in car sales, and Chrysler had a 15.7 percent decline.
For the month, G.M.'s car sales were down 22.6 percent, Ford's 15 percent and Chrysler's 17 percent.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate for car sales for November was six million, roughly the same rate as in October. Large cash rebates in August and September had attracted some car and truck customers to buy sooner, leading analysts to expect the October drop. The continued sales weakness in November led analysts to conclude that consumer demand remains soft.
 
Still at 'Dismal Level'
''We didn't get any improvement,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. ''The numbers are holding at the dismal level of October.''
The ripple effects of the automotive recession have been showing up in Big Three production plans. More cuts in factory schedules have been confirmed by G.M., Ford and Chrysler, which will mean more layoffs and plant shutdowns at least through March, industry analysts said.
G.M., for example, confirmed that it will reopen its midsize car plants in Fairfax, Kan., and Doraville, Ga., on Jan. 16 instead of Jan. 2, to reduce inventories of the Pontiac Grand Prix and Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme.
Late yesterday Ford announced that it was idling its Lorain, Ohio, van plant and the work force there of 2,900 for the week of Dec. 11.
 
Chrysler Write-Offs Confirmed
A Chrysler spokesman confirmed that it would declare write-offs against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the cost of closing its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit and to cover the cost of dismissing a number of white-collar workers.
Chrysler did not quantify the write-offs, but analysts estimated that they would total at least $300 million, assuring that the car maker will be unprofitable for the quarter.
Chrysler's stock fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $19, on the New York Stock Exchange. That was its lowest level of the year. In January, Chrysler was trading at $29.625.
Ford's stock slipped 37.5 cents, to $45.25, while G.M. rose 25 cents, to $44.625.
Domestic light-truck sales were stronger than car sales in late November, dropping only 3.8 percent from a year ago. Through aggressive rebates, Chrysler increased its sales of trucks, vans and Jeeps by 1.6 percent. For the month, light-truck sales were down 7 percent from a year ago, to 306,891.
 
Honda Tailgating Chrysler
For November, sales of domestically produced Hondas were about flat, at 33,771. Honda's share of the car market was 9.6 percent, compared with 8.1 percent a year ago. That brings Honda close to Chrysler's 10.3 percent share.
Sales of domestically produced Toyotas more than doubled, to 21,058, giving it an 8.5 percent share, up from 8 percent a year ago. Sales of Nissan cars made in the United States were up 31.3 percent, to 8,757, for a 5.9 percent market share, up from 5.1 percent.
Sales of domestically produced Mitsubishi cars reached 3,305 for the first year of production, and sales of Mazdas built in the United States were up 21.7 percent, at 3,116.
 
G.M. Share Slips Badly
The Japanese strength came at the expense of the Big Three. G.M., which had managed to halt the decade-long decline in its market share by aggressive use of rebates, slipped badly for the month, its share of the domestic car market dropping to slightly less than 32 percent, compared with 35.5 percent a year ago. G.M.'s share of the light-truck market also fell, to 35.8 percent, from 37.2 percent a year ago.
Even Ford's share, which had gained steadily in the 1980's, felt the surge of the Japanese transplants.
Ford's share of the car market dipped less than half a percentage point, to 20.2 percent, and the company's share of the light-truck market was 29.7 percent, compared with 30.4 percent a year ago.
Chrysler's share of the light-truck market was a bright spot, rising to about 21 percent for the month, from 19.4 percent a year ago. But Chrysler's car share dropped to 10.3 percent, from 11 percent last year.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
In Takeovers, Play's the Thing

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ARE hostile takeovers bad for children and other living things? Or are they simply nature's way of telling incompetent managers to step down?
One way to get a fix on this elusive issue is to plow through the manifestoes of assorted economists, financiers and Congressmen currying favor with their favorite campaign contributors. A less tiresome, altogether superior way is to spend an evening at ''Other People's Money,'' Jerry Sterner's melodrama with a comic edge now playing at the Minetta Lane Theater.
The scene is the ramshackle office of Andrew (Jorgy) Jorgenson, the 68-year-old chairman of New England Wire and Cable and the largest employer in an unnamed Rhode Island mill town. All is not well with the company: Stiff competition from hard-working, underpaid Koreans has made its core business unprofitable. 
But Jorgenson, a man of traditional values, is not about to abandon the enterprise he knows best or the hundreds of workers who depend upon it for a living. And thanks to William Coles, the chief operating officer brought in a decade earlier, there is no pressure for triage: Healthy earnings from plumbing supplies, adhesives and similarly unglamorous items that Coles has added to the product line have offset losses in the wire and cable business, allowing the company to remain debt-free -and out of the clutches of creditors.
Enter Lawrence Garfinkle, the obese, foul-mouthed New York takeover artist whose passions are (in no particular order) sex, money and goo from Dunkin' Donuts. ''Larry the Liquidator,'' as Garfinkle is known on the Street, is always on the lookout for companies worth more dead than alive. And with the help of Carmen, his trusty computer, Garfinkle has discovered New England Wire. By scrapping the wire and cable business and selling the other divisions for six times cash flow, he discovers, the stockholders could realize at least $25 a share. That is a lot less than the $60 they were once worth - but a lot more than the $10 at which the shares have been languishing. ''Restructuring,'' explains Garfinkle, ''means never having to say you're sorry.''
Jorgenson is slow to see the risk posed by Garfinkle, who has been quietly buying stock with money raised by Drexel. (''Give them 15 percent plus a fee,'' says Garfinkle, ''and they'll get you the bucks to buy a slag heap in Mound City, Mo.'') He is, however, finally persuaded by the more worldly Coles to hire Kate Sullivan, a hard-as-nails anti-takeover specialist from Morgan Stanley, who happens (natch) to be young, brilliant and beautiful.
Jorgenson is appalled by the sleazy defenses offered by Sullivan. He refuses to bribe Garfinkle to go away with greenmail. He will not hear of reincorporating in Delaware, where the laws are stacked in favor of entrenched management. (''Delaware? I've never even been to Delaware.'') He will not cooperate in the search for a friendly corporate partner, or ''white knight.'' And he rejects the idea of creating a ''poison pill,'' a bylaw automatically setting off the dilution of stockholders' equity the moment Garfinkle accumulates 30 percent of the stock.
To this point Jorgenson, with his concern for his workers and their community, has a monopoly on the high moral ground. ''We might not have flourished,'' he tells stockholders convened to decide the company's fate, ''but we survived.''
''This man,'' he adds, referring to Garfinkle, ''creates nothing . . . builds nothing. . . . In his wake lies nothing but a blizzard of paper to cover the pain. . . . God save us if you vote to take his few paltry dollars and run. God save us if . . . we become a nation that makes nothing but hamburgers, creates nothing but lawyers, and sells nothing but tax shelters.''
But playwright Sterner is not about to make it easy for his jury of theatergoers. ''For the last 10 years,'' Garfinkle tells the shareholders, ''this company has bled your money. Did the community care? . . . We're paying twice [in taxes] what we paid 10 years ago. . . . And our devoted employees, after taking no increases for three years, are still making twice what they made 10 years ago. And our stock is one-sixth what it was 10 years ago. . . . Who cares? I'll tell you: me. . . . ''I don't make anything? I'm making you money. . . . Take that money and invest it somewhere else. Maybe you'll get lucky, and it will be used productively. And if it is, you'll create more jobs and provide a service for the economy and - God forbid -even make a few bucks for yourself. Let the Government and the mayor and the unions worry about what you paid them to worry about. And if anyone asks, tell them you gave at the plant.''
Who wins the debate - and the company? Good playwrights do not telegraph endings, and neither should newspaper columnists. Suffice it to say that Garfinkle gets his just . . . well, desserts.

HEADLINE: Economic Worries Push Dow Down 11.95

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Stock prices were broadly lower yesterday amid continued uncertainty over the economic outlook. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.95 points, to 2,741.68.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 154.6 million shares, compared with 150.4 million on Monday. Declining issues outstripped advancing ones, 831 to 656. 
''The market has had a resistance level for the past three sessions between 2,750 and 2,760,'' said Kenneth Spence, the head of technical analysis for Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York. ''It's showing signs of being overbought.''
 
I.B.M. Seesaws
Early in the day, the Dow was up more than 18 points from Monday's close, bolstered by International Business Machines, which was up 2 5/8 after announcing an overhaul, including the reduction of more than 10,000 jobs through attrition.
But ardor for I.B.M. ebbed later in the day, and it ended up 3/8, at 99 5/8. The company, based in Armonk, N.Y., also plans to take a $2.3 billion pretax charge in the fourth quarter, a share repurchase program of up to $4 billion, in addition to the $1 billion buyback it announced in October.
Other technology issues were mixed. Xerox advanced 1 1/4, to 60; Cray Research jumped 1 1/2, to 38 1/8; Digital moved down 1/4, to 87 3/4, and Apple Computer fell 1/4, to 45.
Quaker Oats fell 3 3/4, to 58 3/4, after the company, based in Chicago, said it expected lower earnings for its second fiscal quarter ending on Dec. 31, analysts said.
 
USX Off on Icahn Talk
USX fell 7/8, to 36 7/8, as speculation continued that the investor Carl C. Icahn was preparing to make a $50-a-share bid for the Pittsburgh-based steel and energy company. Rumors circulated yesterday that Mr. Icahn was trying to line up a buyer for the company's Marathon Oil unit before making a bid.
Automobile stocks generally fell after the eight domestic manufacturers reported a decline in car and truck sales for November. Ford Motor dropped 3/8, to 45 1/4; Chrysler lost 5/8, to 19, while General Motors bounced back to close up 1/4, to 44 5/8.
Oil stocks also fared poorly, with Exxon losing 1/4, to 47 7/8; Phillips Petroleum falling 3/8, to 23 7/8; Texaco dropping 1, to 54 3/8, and Chevron losing 1/8, to 70 3/4.
Bank stocks also lost ground. First Interstate Bankcorp, the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, fell 1/2, to 53 1/4, on a volume of more than 2.8 million shares. Citicorp lost 1/2, to end at 29 5/8, while Chase Manhattan lost 7/8, to 36 1/2, and Wells Fargo was down 2 1/4, to 74.
L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said in a speech yesterday that he was troubled by bank lending for real estate deals and said that could hurt the Federal agency that insures the banks.
 
Deere Drops on Report
Deere slipped 2 3/4, to 56 7/8, after the company, based in Moline, Ill., said higher earnings for the fourth quarter were offset partly by rising expenses and start-up costs. The company's 22.2 percent drop was the largest on the Big Board. Caterpillar also fell, by 7/8, to end at 59 5/8.
Circle K dropped 1, to 3 1/2, after the company's creditor banks said they had agreed to extend a deadline for the convenience-store company, based in Phoenix, to reach a new short-term credit agreement.
The Germany Fund, which floated about $45 million worth of additional shares yesterday, closed down 3/4, to 12 3/4.
The Dow transportation average registered a slight gain, advancing 3.20 points, to 1,220.84, as UAL, the parent of United Airlines, continued to advance on speculation regarding Coniston Partners, an investment group. The group holds a large stake in the airline and has met with management and unions to discuss a possible buyout or similar transaction.
 
Utility Average Off
The Dow utility average, which reached a historic high on Monday, slipped to 228.06, down 0.18.
Among broader market indexes, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.83, to 349.58, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index lost 0.88 to end at 193.19. On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index gained a scant 0.22 point, to 374.88.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 0.27, to 458.55. Among the most active over-the-counter issues, MCI Communications lost 1/4, to 44 1/2. McCaw Cellular Communications, which is negotiating to acquire Lin Broadcasting, closed up 2, to 41 1/4. Lin closed up 1 3/8, to 123.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germany's Trade Potential Helps Mark to Dominate

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The mark continued to dominate foreign exchange trading yesterday, with traders focusing on West Germany's potential for trade with its eastern neighbors, dealers said.
The mark's value has already taken into account an expected increase in West German interest rates and a further decline in United States rates, dealers said.
The Swiss franc also advanced on expectations of a rise in Swiss bank discount rates from the present level of 6 percent to battle rising inflation in that country. 
''Whatever moves the dollar made today in effect were by default, because the cross rates dominated trading, especially the mark-Swiss franc rates,'' said Scott R. Greene, vice president at the New York office of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. ''Specifically, we saw heavy selling of marks against the Swiss franc.''
 
Rumors of Swiss Rate Rise
Despite rumors that the Swiss discount rate is about to be raised from its present level of 6 percent, which would push up all rates on Swiss franc-denominated investments, Mr. Greene continued, there are many who still believe the recent weakness of the Swiss franc provided a buying opportunity, just as others hold that the recent strength of the mark has been overdone.
In other cross-rate trading, both the mark and Swiss franc rose against the Japanese yen. Partly as a result, the dollar rose against the yen to 143.79, from 143.65 Monday, while it fell against the mark to 1.7772, from 1.78425. Against the French franc, the dollar fell to 6.0690, from 6.0915, and it took 1,309.50 Italian lire to buy a dollar, down from 1,314.50 Monday.
David S. Gilmore, a foreign exchange analyst at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, said: ''The currency market believes the Bank of Japan wants to see the yen below 140, largely because of trade considerations. At the same time, Japanese demand for Canadian dollars continues unabated. A major reason is that Canadian interest rates are more than competitive with our yields.''
For example, he said, the rate on 90-day Canadian Treasury bills is 4.4 percentage points higher than the United States Treasury bill rate. ''That may be a historically wide spread,'' he added.
The United States dollar fell to 1.1633 Canadian dollars, from 1.16365 Monday. The British pound rose to $1.57, from $1.56225, after being weak earlier in the day because Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher did not receive as much support in a Conservative Party vote as had been expected. ''But she got enough votes to make currency traders change their minds, and sterling erased the early losses,'' Mr. Gilmore said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Fall Sharply; Precious Metals in Rebound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The prices of copper futures fell sharply yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange as traders reacted to a downturn in demand for the metal.
In other markets, precious metal futures rebounded from Monday's selloff, grain and soybeans futures were higher, while livestock futures gained, hog futures closed mixed and energy futures climbed.
Copper settled 1.35 cents to 2.40 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in December at $1.0620 a pound. 
Copper prices plunged at the opening bell and continued under pressure throughout the day as traders failed to hold support levels.
Don Tierney, an analyst at Stanley Bell & Company in New York, said consumption of copper was declining because of the softening economic climate.
Precious metal futures rebounded on the Comex as traders operated on the belief that Monday's sharp decline was overdone, Mr. Tierney said.
Helping gold and silver prices was the weakening of the United States dollar against the Swiss franc and the West German mark.
Gold was $2 to $2.40 higher, with December at $403.50 a troy ounce. Silver was 2.4 cents to 3.5 cents higher, with December at $5.533 a troy ounce.
Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher in modest trading on the Chicago Board of Trade as the market recovered some losses sustained in the previous session.
 
Corn Leads Trend Upward
Corn futures led the trend upward in the aftermath of Monday's United States Department of Agriculture weekly export inspections report, which was higher than expected, said Dale Gustafson, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Chicago.
The inspections tally of 79 million bushels was well above trade estimates for 67 million to 73 million. The inspections are an indication of the amount of grain ready for export.
Nearby wheat prices were lower, but the new crop futures gained on reports that weather conditions in the winter wheat crop areas continue on the dry side.
Soybean futures trading continues sluggish, as a lack of export sales dampens the market.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
On 3d Ave., Location Isn't Enough

BYLINE: By Richard D. Lyons

 BODY:
THE old cliche that the essence of real estate is location is coming under increasing challenge in Manhattan's midtown leasing market.
Appearance has become the important new buzzword along Third Avenue, with location often cited by leasing specialists as the second major consideration by prospective tenants and mechanical systems as the third. And with appearance in mind, an increasing number of structures that went up in the real estate boom along Third Avenue in midtown in the 1950's and 1960's are being spruced up with new lobbies, facades, windows and other esthetic features.
The 30-year-old office building at 750 Third Avenue, at 46th Street, for example, is undergoing a $7 million face lift in which a 48-foot-high glass atrium decorated with cascading plants and supported by granite columns has been carved out of parts of the second, third and fourth floors. The project, which started 18 months ago, is under the direction of the Manhattan architectural firm of Haines, Lundberg & Waehler. 
In addition to new sidewalks and the planting of new honey maple trees in front of the 34-story building, due for next spring, the owners have installed new security monitors, modernized the air-conditioning system and elevators and caulked and scrubbed the exterior.
The building has 15 tenants occupying its 672,000 square feet of office space, with McCann-Erickson Worldwide, the advertising agency, as the main tenant.
The building is one of five midtown properties owned by the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, which with its companion organization, the College Retirement Equities Fund, has $3.7 billion of its $80 billion in assets invested in 281 separate properties around the country. The two groups have about a million members in the nation's educational institutions.
''The renovation of 750 Third Avenue reflects T.I.A.A.'s commitment to provide quality space to our office tenants,'' said Stan Sledz, senior vice president of the organization, which has its national headquarters in the neighboring building at 730 Third Avenue, one block south.
Yet some leasing experts say the big reason for such renovations is competition for tenants in a sour market, a situation compounded not only by a tender local economy but also by a slew of new midtown office buildings offering more amenities than many older structures.
Indeed, said one expert, Benjamin Fox, many buildings that went up in the East Side boom 30 years ago ''were paste-up jobs made from flimsy materials, and architecturally dreary as well.''
''At that time it was considered utilitarian architecture, which might have been all right then,'' Mr. Fox said, ''but today it is the sort of style that many corporate clients find not particularly pleasing esthetically, and thus unsuitable.'' Mr. Fox is executive vice president of New Spectrum Realty Services Inc., a leasing agency for midtown office space.
''Increasingly, tenants choose buildings for appearance because they want their clients thinking positively when they walk in - esthetics helps business - and only then do they consider location and the state of the mechanical systems such as the air-conditioning and the windows,'' he added.
His comments were echoed by Faith Consolo, senior vice president of Garrick Aug Associates, another East Side agency, who asserted pointedly: ''Let's face it: In order to stay competitive in a bad market the owners have to spruce up their properties. The owners of a lot of older buildings with leases running out are suddenly finding themselves competing with schmaltzy new buildings such as Trump Plaza so they have to call in the architects and renovate.''
One Manhattan architect who specializes in the renovation of commercial properties is Der Scutt, who said he has undertaken seven such projects in the last two years.
''Right now we are renovating the ugliest building in America, 575 Lexington Avenue,'' Mr. Scutt said, reprising remarks often made about the 36-story structure that went up in 1958 at the corner of 51st Street.
The building has been regarded by many as an East Side eyesore, mainly because the original gold-colored aluminum cladding unexpectedly weathered to a bilious shade of yellow that blotched in places. The owners, Koeppel & Koeppel, a New York real estate investment firm, are spending $18 million to dress the structure with a new bronze cladding, while upgrading the elevators and storefronts and rebuilding the lobby.
''We also found that many of the original windows leaked badly because their gaskets were loose, which made them energy-inefficient and let in street noise as well as rain,'' Mr. Scutt said. ''So they too are being replaced.''
He added, however, that some of his renovations had been for the purpose of restoring facades because current owners now realize that the original, esthetically pleasing appearance of their buildings, changed for the worse over the years, is becoming more attractive to potential tenants.
