HEADLINE: VISIONS OF EUROPE: THE VIEW FROM WASHINGTON - A SPECIAL REPORT:
UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Changes in East Call for a U.S. Balancing Act

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
A senior policy maker was explaining the other day that the Bush Administration had two sets of policies for Eastern Europe - one for that night's network news and one for the year 2010. But the real challenge for Washington, he said, will be developing approaches to Europe not for tonight and not for the next century, but for next year, 1992 and 1995.
''Our internal debates are either very technical or very cosmic,'' the policy maker said. ''Look, our long-term goal, the 'vision thing,' is obvious. It doesn't glitter. It doesn't blind you. It isn't a new Jerusalem. It is something very simple: all the countries in Eastern Europe should have democratic institutions and not go to war with each other. It isn't any more complicated than that.
''What is complicated,'' he said, ''is getting there. It is that middle distance - the policy for 1995 - that's the problem. It has to be something more than a Polish aid package and something less than the vision of a 'Europe whole and free.' '' 
 
New Thinking Is Needed
Ultimately, it will be policies for the middle distance that will determine how effectively the United States can help Europe make its transition from the barbed-wire-divided landscape of the recent past to a continent whole and free. In addressing the NATO allies in Brussels this week after his meeting in Malta with President Michail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, President Bush acknowledged this challenge.
''The U.S. will remain a European power, and that means that the United States will stay engaged in the future of Europe and in our common defense,'' Mr. Bush said. But he was quick to add that the task required a reversal of old approaches almost as great as that being tried in Moscow.
''As I watched the way in which Mr. Gorbachev has handled the changes in Eastern Europe, it deserves new thinking,'' the President said. ''It absolutely mandates new thinking.''
 
Time May Be Short
But if the United States is to be involved in drawing the Europe of the 1990's, as the President vowed, what are the immediate goals it is seeking there? With budgetary pressure mounting for a reduction in the number of American troops in Europe, what form will the United States presence take over the middle distance? At a time when American officials themselves admit they have little leverage to influence the pace and scope of change in Eastern Europe, how can the United States develop a blueprint for the future that will not be overwhelmed by events? Finally, is there a threat that the emerging unity of Eastern and Western Europe may lead to a growing disunity in the Western alliance?
The time available for answering these questions may be less than anyone imagines. Administration officials say that although President Bush and Mr. Gorbachev never really got around to exchanging detailed plans for a new Eastern Europe, what the Soviet leader did say left the Bush team feeling that he was not only pleased with the nature of change there, but intended to continue promoting it. In other words, events are likely to move faster before they move slower.
The fact that senior Administration decision makers have not yet produced clear-cut blueprints for the middle distance appears to be more a result of their being overwhelmed by events than a lack of imagination. It seems that too much is changing too fast in too many unexpected ways for the leadership to get too far beyond the day-to-day.
''I don't think people genuinely have recovered their breath from what has happened,'' said a top Administration policy maker. ''I have spent my entire grown-up life not knowing the difference between Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. They were like Central African lakes to me. There was never any reason to think about them. If you had told me two years ago that I would now be drawing careful political distinctions between Estonia and Lithuania, I would never have believed it.''
Nevertheless, interviews with a range of officials, scholars, policy analysts and historians made clear that there is no shortage of ideas on how the Administration should act toward Europe in the middle distance. The German Question A Dream, Reunion, And 2 Nightmares At the heart of all the ''new thinking'' about Europe in Washington lies the German question. How the United States relates to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Community will be shaped to a large extent by whether East and West Germany are reunited and if so, how.
The Bush Administration has made a strategic decision in recent months not to oppose German unification in principle provided it is done through free elections. But in his Brussels speech the President sketched out for the first time other conditions Washington would insist on.
''Unification should occur in the context of Germany's continued commitment to NATO, an increasingly integrated European Community, and with due regard to the legal role and responsibilities of the Allied powers,'' Mr. Bush said. ''In the interest of general European stability, moves toward unification must be peaceful, gradual and part of a step-by-step basis. And lastly, on the question of borders, we should reiterate our support for the Helsinki Final Act'' - which declared that Europe's postwar borders were inviolable.
But the question remains how the Administration should go about imposing these conditions.
 
U.S. Role 'Appropriate'
''We would be nuts to try to oppose German reunification - there is nothing to be gained by antagonizing Germany - but we would be equally nuts to keep our hands off and say that German reunification is only a question for the German people,'' said Burton Yale Pines, an expert on Europe at the Heritage Foundation, a Washington-based conservative research center.
''Because of the instabilities a united Germany has created in this past century, it is absolutely appropriate for Moscow and Washington to begin talking now, along with Britain and France, about how Germany should be reunified - what sorts of weapons it should be allowed to have, what limitations on its troops should be imposed and how it would relate to its neighbors.''
Administration officials say they are concentrating their energies now on insuring that there is a unified Western approach to the German question before they begin talking with the Soviets. Washington's nightmares here are two. The first is that East Germany will literally collapse tomorrow, fostering a popular momentum for unification and possibly prompting the Soviets, who have some 400,000 troops in East Germany, to intervene to halt the process.
The Administration's view is that keeping East Germany propped up so that it can make a gradual transition to unification is primarily the job of West Germany, the only country with the resources and contacts to make it happen.
Which leads to the Administration's second nightmare: As East and West Germany inexorably grow closer together, even if step by step, deeply rooted fears about a united Germany will set off an earthquake in the NATO alliance, with its epicenter in London, where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has opposed unification at this time.
 
Baker Plans European Trip
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will be going to Europe next week for meetings in Bonn and Brussels with the aim of obtaining a NATO consensus on Mr. Bush's approach. At the last minute he added London to his itinerary to try to ease Prime Minister Thatcher's anxieties.
In Bonn, Mr. Baker will try to continue the Administration's approach of hugging the West Germans to the Western camp. That means, an official said, letting Bonn know that Washington has ''total confidence'' in the prudent way West Germany has handled the situation up to now and wants to consult with Bonn at every step of the way. At the same time, the official said, Washington will need to reaffirm by words and with arms around the shoulder that it believes Bonn must continue consulting with the West and reiterating its unshakable ties to NATO and the European Community.
Such commitments are necessary both to reassure the rest of Western Europe and to send a signal Mr. Gorbachev. Administration officials left Malta with a sense that while the Soviets continue to oppose total German unification, they too may be starting to recognize that it may be inevitable and hence they may begin insisting that such a unified entity be ''neutral.''
 
The Longer-Term Question
In London and in Brussels, Mr. Baker will try to promote Mr. Bush's position that German unification in the context of continued membership in NATO and the European Community is nothing the allies need to fear.
''This is a policy that is going to require a lot of handholding,'' a State Department official said. ''Once we have a framework agreed on with the British, French and West Germans then we can start talking to the Soviets.''
The longer-term question, policy analysts say, is how can the United States insure that a unified Germany is firmly anchored in the Western alliance when the lessening of the Soviet threat will feed budgetary momentum in Congress to bring the bulk of the 317,000 American troops in Europe home?
The answer, said Stephen F. Szabo, a German expert at the National War College, is for the United States to take a much more active role in promoting European integration, not only the plans of the 12 members of the European Community to turn themselves into a single market by the end of 1992, but also their proposals for a European monetary union and for a defensive structure of their own to augment NATO. This would both dilute the power of a unified Germany and keep it enmeshed in the West.
''We are going to be playing a declining military role, so we better have something there in place when we leave that can both maintain an overall balance of power with the Soviets and at the same time be a firm anchor holding Germany to the West,'' Mr. Szabo said. ''This means trying to promote more European control of NATO.''
 
The Ultimate Guarantee
Even over the long term, Administration officials are convinced that Mr. Gorbachev does not want the United States out of Europe, but instead sees a continued American presence there as the ultimate guarantor that neither the German question nor intra-European antagonisms will get out of control. Administration officials say it is premature to even begin talking about a changed American relationship to NATO, let alone the United States leaving Europe.
''NATO provides the single greatest institutional tie the United States has to Western Europe, and no one wants to see that relationship attenuated,'' said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger. ''Over time I am sure we will have to adjust our relationship, but we are not there yet. I don't think anyone at this point can envisage how the relationship will change.'' The Aid Question New Democracies and New Challenges If there is any real threat from Eastern Europe to American interests in the middle term it is no longer the threat of a Warsaw Pact invasion but rather a Warsaw Pact economic collapse. When Administration officials talk about their ''worst case scenario'' for Eastern Europe, it always begins with economics, not politics.
''The worst case,'' a senior State Department official said, ''is that the Eastern Europeans get bogged down and can't make the structural changes in their economic and political systems and then you see pessimism and cynicism set in. That could get ugly.''
It is often forgotten that in the first few years of the cold war, American policies in Europe were not primarily military but economic. The Marshall Plan was intended primarily to strengthen European countries, which had been devastated by the war, so that they could resist decay, instability and Communist subversion. NATO and the policy of military containment came into their own only after the Korean War raised the specter of a Soviet-led strike across Central Europe.
''With the diminished threat from the East, American European policy no longer has to emphasize military containment,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on East-West relations at the Council on Foreign Relations. ''We are back to the situation of 1947 - helping fledgling democracies, devastated in this case by the calamity of 40 years of Communist rule, trying to get on their feet.''
 
Development Bank Suggested
For the short term, the Bush Administration, prodded by Congress, has come up with a package that provides $938 million in grants, investment funds, bank credits, scholarships, job-training schemes and environmental protection projects for Poland and Hungary. But this package will expire in three years, and does not even address changes in Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.
For the middle distance, Felix G. Rohatyn, a senior partner in the investment bank Lazard Freres & Company, has suggested that the United States should take the lead in creating a permanent Eastern European Development Bank.
''For the longer haul,'' Mr. Rohatyn said, ''it seems to me that some kind of multinational development institution should be created by the Europeans, Japanese and ourselves along the lines of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of the 1930's.''
The capital, Mr. Rohatyn said, should be held by Japan, the United States and the European Community.
''I would begin with $5 billion, which would allow them to borrow much more, and put the bank in Vienna,'' he said. ''Any country that has made the political reforms - that is free elections and recognition of the principle of private property - but not yet the economic ones could apply.''
Such a bank, he said, would act as a permanent provider of financing for infrastructure projects, like telecommunications and irrigation systems, and for developing free-market instruments and skills, like accounting systems, mortgage institutions, copyright laws, credit and banking systems.
 
The Money Question
To transform the economies of Eastern Europe in a stable manner from planned economies to more free-market systems ''is going to take a long time, so we need institutions that can work over the long haul,'' Mr. Rohatyn said.
And there is the rub, some American officials say.
''I represent a great power and we reach into our pockets and all we have is loose change,'' a State Department official said. ''I am not saying you should substitute check writing for policy making. But let's face it: student exchanges, leadership grants, banking credits, new consulates - these are the network of things that bring us influence on the ground. You have to put your money where your mouth is, and we're broke.''
Administration officials concede that they will have to influence economic development in Eastern Europe with a small purse, at best. Their policy for the middle distance is to make a virtue of necessity and share leadership on the aid front with both the European Community and the Group of 24 leading Western industrial nations.
''There is a lot we can do without money - providing technical assistance, or incentives for reform or intellectual capital,'' an Administration official said. ''We're going to have to do more of that. Look at all we offered Gorbachev in Malta. Did that cost us any money?''
 
Ready for Anything
Everything Is 'Back To Square One'
Out of all these loose threads today's decision makers will somehow have to weave a policy for the middle distance. Those who will have to carry it out greet the task with excitement and humility, dread and awe, said Raymond G.H. Seitz, the Assistant Secretary for European Affairs, whose father was a United States Army general in command of American forces in Munich when the Berlin wall went up in 1961.
''When I was 20, I came home from college for the summer to visit my family in Munich,'' he recalled. ''I remember very well the night when the red phone in the house rang and my father was told that the East Germans are putting up a wall in the middle of Berlin. Now his son is one of those dealing with the implications of that wall coming down.''
''I guess history comes in waves,'' he added, ''and this is one that is clearly cresting. It is not coups we are talking about. It is mass movements, people in the streets. What it has lacked up to now, thank goodness, is a feature that always gives history its real pungency, though. That is violence and barricades - 'Les Miserables.' So we may not get on-Broadway plays out of this moment, but we'll definitely get off-Broadway.''
When asked how he was instructing his staff to go about planning for the middle distance, Mr. Seitz mulled the question over for a moment before answering.
''Everything goes back to square one now,'' he said. ''No assumptions are valid, nothing is ruled out anymore. Of course that is exciting. Bureaucracies are meant to operate within a framework. In terms of European policy we have had that framework established for a very long time. There was NATO, the Warsaw Pact, the wall, the spending levels. They were all thought to be immutable.''
''The bureaucracy is not like academe, where you are trained to question assumptions,'' he continued. ''Around here you don't have time to question assumptions, and anyway you know that they are valid. Right? Now everything is back to square one. Nothing is immutable. It requires a total intellectual retooling.''

LENGTH: 1834 words

HEADLINE: Grim Outlook of Early 1980's Is Back for U.S. Auto Makers

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The prospects for the American automobile industry are more uncertain today than at any time since the early 1980's, when the Detroit producers ran to Washington to push for ''voluntary'' quotas on Japanese imports.
Sales are slumping, and the Big Three are being forced once again to weigh shutting plants, laying off workers and delaying investments.
As sales have weakened, the Chrysler Corporation has closed a plant in Wisconsin and announced another shutdown in Michigan. To raise cash for its auto business, Chrysler announced today that it was putting its military electronics and Gulfstream business jet subsidiaries up for sale. [Page D1.] The General Motors Corporation has ''indefinitely'' idled factories in Georgia, Massachusetts and Michigan. Even the Ford Motor Company, which has been the least affected so far, said on Tuesday that it would temporarily close an automotive van plant in Ohio. And analysts say more layoffs and plant closings are inevitable. 
 
Little Room to Maneuver
Today, the American producers have little room to maneuver, making the next few years a particularly stiff challenge. The domestic auto makers have done much to cut costs and improve quality in the seven years since the last big downturn. But the Japanese still hold a competitive advantage, and some analysts say Detroit used too little of its profits from the quota-protected years to develop new products. Now the Japanese, loaded with cash, are able to speed the pace of new-model introductions and increase the pressure on Detroit.
''It used to be that when a downturn came the Big Three could cut costs,'' said James Womack, research director of a Massachusetts Institute of Technology project investigating the future of the automobile. ''That isn't an option in 1990. The Japanese companies, on the other hand, have the resources to plow right through.''
 
Japan's U.S. 'Transplants'
And this time the Japanese have a powerful new weapon: their ''transplant'' car factories in America, efficient plants staffed mainly by younger, nonunion workers. These new plants can build a car for an estimated $500 to $800 less than most of the Big Three's factories.
The transplants, which are a byproduct of the trade restrictions Detroit had lobbied so hard to get, will be stepping up their output sharply in the next few years in an already overcrowded American car market. In large measure, the future of the domestic automobile industry will effectively be decided by the Japanese. The question is how aggressively the Japanese companies, as the most efficient producers, will push to lift their stake in the United States market, forcing further contraction for domestic companies.
''The big question is how the Japanese will respond,'' said Donald E. Petersen, chairman of Ford. The Japanese auto makers, he added, might moderate their assault on the American market for fear of provoking a political backlash, though he acknowledged that was ''very hard to predict.''
 
Detroit's Job Loss
The Big Three's share of the American market, which has dropped from 84 percent to 69 percent in the last decade, seems sure to erode further, analysts agree. Detroit's unionized work force, down from 1.6 million to 1 million in the last decade, will also be trimmed further, they say.
G.M., the industry giant, has watched its hold loosen considerably. Ford, No. 2, has recovered vigor and market share in recent years. But Chrysler, bailed out a decade ago by the Government, is the most vulnerable of the three. Analysts and Detroit executives now say Chrysler may be forced to seek a merger partner if the current slump is prolonged.
Moreover, unions seem in no mood for another round of cost-saving concessions. The United Automobile Workers cooperated with Detroit in the mid-1980's, accepting moderate wage settlements, more flexible work rules and job cuts to help make Detroit more competitive so the remaining union jobs would be more secure.
The companies, in turn, forged some innovative Japanese-style relationships with workers to try to raise quality and productivity. Yet the implicit pact with the unions was that another wave of austerity was not in the offing.
 
Resisting Plant Closings
Chrysler recently announced a plan to shut down its factory on Jefferson Avenue in Detroit, and the U.A.W. has said it plans to resist such closings, and might even strike in protest. The Detroit producers face negotiations on a three-year wage pact in 1990, and analysts agree that a strike could be devastating.
The previous automotive recession, from 1980 to 1982, came as Japan was stepping up imports and carving niches in the low-price end of the market. The American auto makers responded by playing a political card; they lobbied for Government protection and got it, a Washington-Tokyo pact that now limits Japanese imports to 2.3 million vehicles a year.
Yet the export-restraint pact, by forcing the Japanese to invest in America, assured that Detroit would confront a new form of foreign competition, within its borders. The nine Japanese transplant factories are scheduled to build roughly 3.5 million cars and trucks a year by the mid-1990's, up from 2.1 million now. About 15 million cars and trucks are sold each year in America.
 
Woven Into the U.S. Fabric
By investing in American factories, the Japanese have woven themselves into the fabric of the American industry - so much so that the Big Three are partners with the Japanese in four of the nine transplant operations.
Thus the Japanese have become important employers of American blue-collar workers while cultivating their own political constituency in Washington. With transplants now producing cars even more cheaply than in Japan, given the strong yen, the Japanese are poised to grab a much bigger chunk of the United States market. The Toyota Motor Corporation, the biggest Japanese car maker, recently announced that its goal is to increase American sales of cars and trucks to 1.5 million by the mid-1990's, up from about 950,000 now. And about half those vehicles will be assembled here.
Toyota has decided to expand its dealer network significantly, especially in areas of the Midwest where it has never sold before. The company could not expand before because it did not have enough vehicles.
 
Japanese Share Rising
So far this year, sales of Toyota, Honda, Nissan and Mazda vehicles have fallen much more slowly than those of the Big Three, which means they are gaining a bigger share of the American market. Hence, G.M., Ford and Chrysler are being forced to devise plans for surviving the coming hard times, possibly including mergers. Not far from anyone's mind are the dwindling fortunes of the American Motors Corporation, which merged with Chrysler in 1987 to stave off certain demise.
The Big Three, in trying to match the factory-floor performance of the Japanese, agreed in 1987 to various job-security provisions for hourly workers in return for greater flexibility on productivity and quality issues. Those provisions will be tested as falling sales and the need to cut costs aggravate the problem of overcapacity, which is particularly acute at G.M. The U.A.W. was not happy with G.M.'s recent decision to shut a Lakewood, Ga., plant and has hardened its stance on ''cooperative'' programs with management.
 
Tough Bargaining Ahead
Unless the climate between management and labor improves, bargaining for a new national contract next fall could be difficult.
A strike would be disastrous, experts agree. What has changed is that the Japanese transplants are willing and able to pick up the slack in the marketplace in any work stoppage. Thus, Big Three managements will have to consider carefully before risking a union confrontation.
The Big Three's strategy in staying abreast of the Japanese through the 1980's has been to build large numbers of vehicles and lure consumers to buy them with incentives like rebates and low-interest financing.
But rebates have cut heavily into profits, which are the fuel for product development. Big Three executives agree that they must eventually find a way to match Japanese quality, price and design if they hope to avoid further erosion of market share.
 
Coming Up Short on Quality
The Big Three's cars and trucks, while vastly improved since the early 1980's, continue to come up short in most evaluations. A recent survey of performance, quality, safety and resale value by Automotive Industries magazine rated the Acura Legend, made by the Honda Motor Company, as the industry benchmark. Frank A. Olson, chairman of the Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest rental car company, noted that his fleet's Japanese cars are still 15 to 20 percent better than American autos, in terms of defects and maintenance costs.
The cost of developing a new model, however, runs into billions of dollars and continues to climb. G.M., for example, badly needs to replace its outmoded Pontiac Firebird and Chevrolet Camaro models, based on the same body and chassis. The sporty cars appeal mainly to younger buyers, a category in which G.M. has lost a great deal of ground since the current car was introduced in 1982.
But G.M. planners have still not been able to propose a business plan that shows how they can make money with a new Firebird/Camaro. Without such a plan G.M. top management will not approve the tremendous capital outlays required for engineering, new tools and training.
The lag in Detroit's new-car development is evident at Ford as well. Ford won kudos with its Taurus and Sable in 1985, the same year a new Honda Accord appeared. This year, however, Honda introduced an all-new Accord, while big changes for Taurus are still years away.
 
'Financial Staying Power'
''Financial staying power is critical for keeping new-product plans alive during a downturn,'' Mr. Womack of M.I.T. said. ''If you try to save money by slowing your new products, it doesn't hurt you in the short term. But in the next go-round you'll lose more share by not having the products.''
The need for large capital outlays at a time of heightening competition puts a premium on the ability of the Big Three to share costs by forging effective joint ventures and partnerships with foreign auto makers, particularly from Japan.
All three companies are learning to do this. Ford has parlayed its 25 percent interest in the Mazda Motor Corporation into an arrangement to build cars jointly in Flat Rock, Mich., and to develop jointly the new Ford Escort, which will appear in the spring. G.M. has multiple arrangements with Toyota, Suzuki and Isuzu, but none have yet produced the ''home run'' vehicle the company so desperately needs. Chrysler has done well with its Diamond Star transplant in Bloomington, Ill., co-owned with its Japanese affiliate, the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation. Chrysler is also pinning big hopes on a sports car it is developing with Mitsubishi, called Stealth, due to appear in 1992.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Shaping a Risky New Strategy to Gain Leverage Against U.S.

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 6

 BODY:
A light plane that crashed while carrying sophisticated antiaircraft missiles from Nicaragua to Salvadoran rebels was part of a risky new Nicaraguan strategy to gain negotiating leverage against the United States, diplomats and Sandinista officials say.
Nicaraguan leaders have refused direct public comment about the plane, which was carrying 24 Sam-7 antiaircraft missiles and other weapons when it crashed in pre-dawn darkness in Eastern El Salvador on Nov. 25.
But diplomats and officials close to the Sandinista directorate say that the flight was approved as part of a calculated attempt to establish a tradeoff between Sandinista aid to the Salvadoran guerrillas and American aid to anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua.
 
At Bottom, the Contra Issue
American military aid to the contras was cut off by Congress in 1988. But the contra army continues to receive non-military assistance from the United States, and its presence remains a deep concern for Sandinista leaders, who see it as a military and political threat in national elections planned here in February 1990. 
Over the past year, Nicaragua has won two major regional agreements calling for the dismantling of contra bases in Honduras. The contra leaders, apparently with American support, have refused to give up their fight, and a regionally agreed deadline for the rebels' departure passed unheeded on Tuesday, further enraging Sandinista leaders.
Diplomats and Sandinista officials said the antiaircraft missiles were sent to deal a powerful but precise blow to the American-backed Salvadoran military, which has relied heavily upon air power to defend against a fierce guerrilla offensive that began on Nov. 11.
 
Trying to Set Off Alarms
The purpose of that blow, the officials say, was to set off alarm bells in Washington, placing America's extensive involvement in El Salvador at risk from weapons whose supply is controlled from Managua. Although the Salvadoran guerrillas receive arms and ammunition from many sources, they have never before received sophisticated antiaircraft missiles. And Nicaraguan officials say that Sandinista leaders have retained tight, high-level control of the new missile shipments, leaving open the possibility of trading a cutoff in future shipments for an American agreement to disband the contras.
American officials, for their part, have expressed deep public concern over the implications of the missile shipment, and have said that missiles apparently delivered by similar recent flights have now begun to appear in combat in El Salvador. But they have dismissed any suggestion the United States would make a deal to prevent new missile shipments, particularly at the expense of the contra army, which was justified in its early years precisely as a means of interdicting Nicaraguan aid to the Salvadoran guerrillas.
''The makings of a deal may be there,'' said one non-American diplomat here. ''But that doesn't mean it would be easy for anybody in Washington to accept.''
 
Long-Planned Strategy
The strategy for sending the missiles is believed to have been developed in late October as part of a broader set of military steps designed to increase pressure for the dismantling of the contra army. Sandinista officials say that the strategy included the government's dramatic decision on Nov. 1 to end a 19-month-old cease-fire with contra units inside Nicaragua. They said that the measures had been designed and personally overseen by major Sandinista leaders, including Humberto Ortega Saavedra, a leading architect of the Sandinista revolution who is the Defense Minister, and a brother of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra.
Last week, the Nicaraguan authorities presented a pilot from the national airline, Aeronica, at a news conference here after he was erroneously identified by Salvadoran officials as one of three crew members who died when the plane crashed. A fourth man aboard killed himself to avoid capture shortly after the crash.
But Government leaders pointedly refused to discuss the shipment itself, and the case of mistaken identity was quickly overshadowed by other evidence of Nicaraguan participation in the flight. The aircraft involved was identified by Nicaraguan ground personnel queried by reporters at Managua's Augusto Cesar Sandino Airport, and local residents confirmed that two light aircraft, protected by a cordon of army troops, took off in the early morning hours of Nov. 25 from the Nicaraguan airstrip shown on recovered documents as the departure point of the downed plane.
Both the lifting of the cease-fire and the missile shipment have brought sharp international condemnation of the Managua regime, including strong private criticism from the Soviet Union. Last week, diplomats say, the Soviet Ambassador to Nicaragua, Valeri Nikolaenko, met with President Ortega to deliver a stern rebuke for allowing the missile shipment to occur on the eve of last weekend's superpower summit meeting in Malta.
 
Sandinista Resolve Hardens
But diplomats say that the outcry appears only to harden Sandinista resolve. And they say that Nicaraguan leaders appear prepared to press their position with even riskier military undertakings, like the massing of troops to threaten invasion of contra base camps in Honduras near the Nicaraguan border.
The motivation for such measures, diplomats say, is the Sandinista Government's increasing concern that the presence of the contras could endanger their chances of winning the elections scheduled for February, or of asserting unchallenged control in the event of a Sandinista victory. Since August, the number of contras inside the country has roughly tripled, to more than 3,500, and armed rebel units have successfully mobilized anti-government voters - and intimidated government supporters - in many rural areas.
The measures taken by the Government have cast a pall over the elections, which the Sandinistas have carefully cultivated in the hope that the vote will certify their democratic credentials and win desperately needed economic and political support from abroad.
But officials close to the Sandinista Directorate assert that the substantial risks of the new strategy are outweighed by its benefits.
 
Yielding Propaganda Gains
At a minimum, they say, the ending of the cease-fire has permitted large contingents of Government troops to force the contras inside the country into hiding, and to establish a strong new Sandinista military presence throughout the countryside.
It may also yield propaganda gains: speaking to closed meetings of trusted Sandinista Party militants, Government leaders have asserted that the end of the cease-fire will help turn the campaign away from the country's failing economy and toward questions of nationalism, where the Government believes it is strongest.
More broadly, the diplomats and officials say, Sandinista leaders expect to convert the shipment of the anti-aircraft missiles into a strong new bargaining chip to persuade the Bush Administration to support the immediate disbanding of the contra base camps in Honduras.
Such a tradeoff between the Salvadoran conflict and the contra war had long been opposed by the Sandinistas, who feared that it would be used to obstruct progress on demobilizing the contras. The idea of such a linkage is now being raised directly by Sandinista officials. And the paired Nicaraguan and Salvadoran issues promise to be the central focus of discussion when the five Central American Presidents meet for a regional summit meeting in San Jose, Costa Rica, early next week.
''The two issues on the table are El Salvador and the contras,'' said one European diplomat. ''The question is how they will be connected, and by whom.''
 
Makings of a Deal
At the heart of a possible deal, diplomats and Government officials say, are important calculations about the evolution of American interests, which Sandinista strategists believe are now tied far less closely to the contra movement than to the progress of the war in El Salvador.
Nicaraguan leaders have long asserted that American officials have been waiting for an opportunity to revive the 10,000-man contra army. But Sandinista leaders considered it a watershed event when, after President Ortega ordered an end to the cease-fire, the Bush Administration made no move to request new military aid for the contras. Instead, regional diplomats say, the Administration worked behind the scenes in an attempt to limit damage to the electoral process here and to encourage Honduras to participate in negotiations aimed at re-establishing the truce.
''The United States wanted the cease-fire,'' said one Sandinista strategist. ''Daniel gave them the choice of war or elections, and faced with that choice, they took elections very clearly.''

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
English Spoken Here (by Would-Be Expatriates)

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 5

 BODY:
A class of 40 nervous students looked blankly at the teacher who had just asked a sample question on an English test, about the purchase of shoes from a catalogue. ''Class, what is a catalogue?'' the teacher asked.
Several students squirmed in their seats, for none of those in the cold, damp classroom had ever heard of buying from a catalogue. Shoes were bought in shops, not catalogues. They shrugged, and hoped that the issue would not come up in a test of English as a foreign language. 
They had signed up for this series of English classes to prepare for the test, which is required of foreign students by American universities. Many young intellectuals, thrown into a depression after the military suppression of the democracy movement in June, regard study abroad as the best escape hatch out of China.
The more the Chinese authorities attack the United States, the more many intellectuals perceive the political climate to be worsening, and the more fanatically they study English to try to get to the United States.
''We are all trying to get out,'' said a young Chinese man planning to study abroad. ''There is little hope for us here.''
 
Pointless to Remain, They Say
It is not so much that they are afraid of being arrested; rather, they say they believe there is no point in remaining, for they will be given no opportunity to use their talents in China.
Paradoxically, the biggest obstacle for many is not permission from the Chinese authorities, at least for the moment, but American immigration law. The United States Embassy here is reluctant to give visas to those who cannot show a good reason why they must return, such as a spouse who is remaining behind, and so a large number of single men and women who have been accepted at universities abroad find that they are denied visas.
''I don't think I'll be able to go abroad because it's nearly impossible to get a U.S. visa,'' said a young Chinese woman who was taking a class to prepare for the English test.
Because of their passion for getting away, many Chinese with only an inkling of English are brushing up on their Americanisms. In Shanghai, novice English-speakers boldly walk up to foreigners and offer to be their guides, just for the sake of speaking English to a foreigner.
 
Some Use Connections
Those hoping to take the English test are not just from the universities. Technicians, physicists, philosophers and computer programmers are among the thousands flocking to English classes and standing in line to register for the test, which is given four times a year.
The next test date is in January, and some people lined up for two days to insure a spot on the registration list at one of about a dozen locations in the city.
Yet the authorities have already started to make it difficult for Chinese people to prepare for and take the test. Late in October, the authorities closed down the English Corner, an officially designated area in Purple Bamboo Park in Beijing where people could go to practice English. About 100 Chinese gathered in the English Corner last Sunday in defiance of the Government ban.
It has also been hard for Chinese who work in units that are being scrutinized because of the pro-democracy demonstrations this spring. Most Chinese must obtain permission and a letter of introduction from their work unit to register for the test, and some Chinese without connections say they have been denied that permission.
''This Government controls nearly every aspect of our lives, down to the very food we eat,'' said a young woman who, like many Chinese, lives in a dormitory and eats at a cafeteria run by her work unit. She also planned to take the English test, but was denied permission.
 
Rumors of a Rules Change
One Chinese worker infuriated officials when they found out he had used a letter of introduction written months before for an earlier test date to register for the January test.
The rush to study English has been fanned by rumors that the Government will change the regulations for studying abroad sometime next year.
Among the fears is that the Government will not allow Chinese people over 35 years old to go abroad for study, although they may make an overseas trip as part of a business delegation or other work. Others fear that the Government will not let students who have just graduated from college go overseas to study until they have worked in China for four to seven years.
 
A Fear of Rejection
Some Chinese are confident they will obtain passports, a process that sometimes can take as long as six months, but are concerned they will be rejected by foreign embassies.
But a United States Embassy official said the visa approval rate for study, now about 50 percent or higher, has remained essentially the same as it was before June. Moreover, the official said there had not been a noticeable drop in the number of passports issued, although many of the people applying for visas now had applied before June for their passports.
But figures for visas issued from April to September at the United States Embassy suggest that fewer lecturers and researchers have applied to go to the United States since June. The largest drop in applications was in the category of business travel.
''This category had grown 20 to 30 percent a year,'' the official said. ''It's usually a barometer of the state of economic relations.''

LENGTH: 665 words

HEADLINE: AQUINO IS PRAISED FOR REVOLT MOVES

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The United States praised the Government of the Philippines today for arranging the release of American citizens trapped in hotels in Manila, and the Bush Administration said the Philippine President, Corazon C. Aquino, was acting within her authority when she declared a state of emergency.
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, pointedly refrained from criticizing Mrs. Aquino for invoking broad emergency powers to cope with the revolt by soldiers demanding her resignation.
''We're strongly and fully supporting the Aquino Government,'' Miss Tutwiler said. She reported that the state of emergency decree, including restrictions on the content of radio and television news broadcasts, had been declared under a provision of the Philippine Constitution explicitly authorizing such action. 
Miss Tutwiler expressed ''appreciation to the Government of the Philippines for the careful and effective manner in which it dealt with the situation in the Makati commercial district'' of Manila, arranging for the evacuation of Americans and others trapped in the standoff between rebels and Government forces there.
 
Private Investment and Aquino
''We commend the Aquino Government for organizing and carrying out this operation,'' Miss Tutwiler said. ''All Americans are safe. No injuries are reported. Some 280 Americans have been transported by bus from several hotels in the Makati area.''
With many American businesses concerned about the turmoil in the Philippines, Bush Administration officials said the revolt should not deter potential investors.
The United States Government has pledged $200 million and Japan has pledged $1 billion as part of a $3.5 billion economic-assistance package for the Philippines in the coming year.
Philippine and American officials said they feared that private investors would lose interest. But, they said, Government aid from the United States and other countries will probably not be affected as long as Mrs. Aquino stays in power.
 
Effort to Rule at Gunpoint
Elliot L. Richardson, the former Attorney General who was appointed by President Bush to coordinate American assistance to the Philippines, said today that there had undoubtedly been some ''damage to investor confidence'' because of the rebellion.
In an effort to reassure potential investors, Mr. Richardson, who returned Tuesday from Manila, said there was ''a realistic prospect of stability'' in the Philippines. The military uprising should not be a deterrent to investors, he said.
The uprising was the sixth since Mrs. Aquino took office in February 1986. L. John Swallow Jr., a spokesman for the United States-Philippine Business Committee, an arm of the United States Chamber of Commerce that promotes trade between the two countries, said: ''Investments have been growing in spite of the coup attempts. We don't see any correlation between the coup attempts and investment in the Philippines.''
Mr. Richardson said the rebels ''arrogantly assume that they can seize power through terrorism and rule the Philippines at gunpoint.'' But, he said, ''They cannot.''
 
U.S. Backs Emergency Decree
President Bush said he was ''very encouraged'' to learn that the Americans in Manila were safe. All Americans who wanted to leave the Makati district were able to do so, White House officials said.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, declined to comment on the state of emergency declared by Mrs. Aquino. ''We're looking into the details of it,'' he said. ''We don't have a reaction at this point. But we will take a look at it and see if we have any concerns.''
Miss Tutwiler said the state of emergency decree had been issued under a section of the Philippine Constitution that permits the Government temporarily to ''take over or direct the operation of any privately owned public utility or business.''
State Department officials said the United States had not had any contact with the rebels since the rebellion began on Friday.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
U.S. Offers Moscow a Few Ideas On How to Improve Its Economy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Soviet Union received some free economic advice from American officials during the Malta summit meeting on how Moscow could put a chicken in every pot - or least some soap in every washroom.
A senior Administration official said today that during last weekend's meetings Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d presented Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze with a paper detailing benefits to the Soviet economy of diverting to domestic programs $15.5 billion that Moscow is spending this year on foreign military and economic aid. The total is the estimated dollar value of the Soviet aid, much of which is military equipment. 
The paper, prepared by the State Department's Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs and translated into Russian, was intended to demonstrate the ''opportunity costs'' of Moscow's assistance to Cuba and other third world nations, the official said. Estimates From the C.I.A. The sum of $15.5 billion is the amount that the Central Intelligence Agency estimates is provided by Moscow in military and economic assistance to Afghanistan, Angola, Cambodia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Nicaragua and Vietnam.
Mr. Shevardnadze reportedly did not tell Mr. Baker what he thought of the paper, which presented rough calculations of how the diversion of Moscow's assistance could help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign to reform the Soviet economy and society.
According to the paper, the diversion of a even a small fraction of the funds could markedly improve the quality of life in the Soviet Union. Diverting $500 million could provide each Soviet citizen with 10 times as much soap a year as is now available, the paper says, alluding to the current shortage of soap in the Soviet Union.
The paper also outlines possible alternative uses of the Soviet aid.
In one projected case, it would enable almost two million Soviet families to double their annual consumption of goods and services, the paper states. There are about 72 million Soviet families, according to the 1989 Soviet census.
 
More Meat on the Table
Alternatively, the sum would be sufficient to increase per capita meat consumption by 31 pounds per year. The average Soviet citizen consumers about 145 pounds of meat each year, less than half of the amount consumed by the average American, according to American officials.
An expenditure of $15.5 billion could lead to more than a fivefold increase in investment in health facilities, such as hospitals, clinics and sanitariums. Such a sum could also be used to double state expenditures to meet immediate health care needs, boosting spending for medicine and doctor's salaries, for example.
Whether Moscow is open to the American suggestions of how it might apply its ''peace dividend'' remains to be seen. Soviet officials have, however, publicly stressed their interest in the ''economic conversion'' of some military assets, such as missile factories, for the production of goods for Soviet citizens.
There has been relatively little talk such ''economic conversion'' in the United States. And some specialists speculate that Moscow may be tempted to respond with its own paper, detailing, for example, how the cancellation of the B-2 Stealth bomber would free up funds for the homeless.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (91%); AFGHANISTAN (79%); 

CITY: MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (91%);

HEADLINE: Mrs. Aquino Fights the Odds

 BODY:
The fighting in the Philippines has produced only losers. Military rebels have failed to shoot their way into power. President Corazon Aquino has suffered serious damage. The biggest casualty of all could be the Philippines' chances of consolidating democratic institutions and joining the East Asian economic boom. 
Mrs. Aquino's best hope is to use her new emergency powers to revive the reform program she rode to office nearly four years ago.
Cory Aquino is only partly to blame for her predicament. Though she is no longer the heroine of 1986, polls taken just before the attempted coup showed her with nearly 60 percent popular support. In a normal democracy, that would not provide fertile ground for a political crisis.
But normal democracy is something the Philippines has never known. The Aquino period has brought undeniable political progress: a democratic Constitution, reasonably fair elections at all levels and a less intimidated judiciary.
At the same time, huge obstacles remain. The most immediately dangerous is an unbalanced relationship between civilian and military power. Mrs. Aquino won a popular mandate at the polls but wrested power from Ferdinand Marcos only with the help of military force.
The leaders of that rebellion, Fidel Ramos, Juan Ponce Enrile and Gregorio Honasan, still exercise extraordinary influence. General Ramos, now Defense Minister, has repeatedly rescued Mrs. Aquino from military enemies. But he has also helped push aside reformers within the Aquino coalition. Mr. Enrile quickly became an active opponent, Mr. Honasan a renegade. A continuing Communist-led guerrilla campaign has further eroded civil power, forcing Mrs. Aquino to cede scarce resources and a policy voice to military chiefs.
The Aquino Government is also handicapped by ties to the traditional elite in a country marked by extreme poverty. Mrs. Aquino, from one of the nation's richest landowning families, has yet to produce sweeping land reform. Some of her closest associates are corrupt. Vice President Salvador Laurel openly welcomes conspiracies.
Her problems don't stop there. She has no real political party; politicians who have run under her banner hold no commitment to reform. And now she is sure to draw strong nationalist criticism for asking the U.S. for military help.
All this helps explain civilian disillusionment and military unrest. Yet those who long for stronger, cleaner, more reform-minded rule ought to have no trouble choosing between Mrs. Aquino and her enemies. These enemies represent a return to all that held the Philippines back during the Marcos era. Mrs. Aquino could do better, and now needs to. But she remains her country's best bet.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 8, 1989, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Philippine military rebellion gave an incorrect date in some copies for Corazon C. Aquino's election as President. It was February 1986, not August 1986.

HEADLINE: Rockefeller Labs, Roosevelt Homes

 BODY:
Two development proposals deserve continuing strong support of the outgoing Koch administration and a welcome from the incoming Dinkins government. They are the $80 million expansion of Rockefeller University's laboratories and a scaled-down housing plan for Roosevelt Island. 
Rockefeller University brings together pioneers of biomedical research, offering support for their work and the chance to share ideas. In 1973, the State Legislature authorized construction over the F.D.R. Drive. Now the university, with help from the Howard Hughes Foundation, has the resources to proceed. Without student body or patients, the university attracts little traffic and few visitors. Expansion over the drive poses no threat to neighbors. This valuable institution merits the Board of Estimate's support.
Directly across the main East River channel, meanwhile, the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation plans to complete the residential community that has awakened that underused urban island. In the early 1970's the development corporation created Northtown, with 3,258 apartments. It now seeks bids for Southtown, with almost 2,000 apartments and community facilities and parks. That would create homes for 12,000.
Half the Southtown apartments are planned as low-rise luxury housing; their developer must, in the other half, provide greater subsidies to low- and moderate-income families than those the state and city governments have promised. The increase in population will help support community facilities and the aerial tramway to Manhattan.
This version of the plan eliminates once-contemplated office buildings and a hotel that no longer seem economical. Their absence increases open space dramatically. This is, in short, a sensible way to improve Roosevelt Island and provide New Yorkers with some additional housing they desperately need. It merits continued support.

HEADLINE: Fast 'Maglev' Trains vs. Short Air Trips

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Federal funding of research, and development of a 4,000-m.p.h. ''hypersonic plane'' may give the U.S. a lead in a spectacular form of transportation, as William Safire notes (column, Nov. 20), but in everyday problems of transportation, such as delays from overcrowded hub airports and highways, this project won't do any more than putting a man on the moon did.
It's time for Congress and the Administration to heed the challenge of Senator Moynihan (Scientific American ad, Op-Ed page Nov. 8) to support research and development on the magnetic levitation (''maglev'') technology, which can address those problems and more. Maglev routes can replace fuel-inefficient short-haul jet flights and free airspace for more long-distance flights. At the same time, if there is a rapid transit link between hub airport and downtown, intercity commuters can forsake their autos for safe 300-m.p.h. transportation. The combination of airline ''feeder'' traffic and intercity commuters will provide enough ridership for the system to be economical.
High-speed trains are a highly visible mode of transport. While Europe builds a network of 186-m.p.h. wheels-on-rails trains, the U.S. can vault into the lead by capitalizing on Japanese and West German maglev research, and recent breakthroughs in superconductivity. As an added benefit, aerospace manufacturers can gear up to develop and produce maglev vehicles, which are essentially aircraft without wings. A shrinking defense budget can be an opportunity, rather than a problem, for U.S. employers to fill a transportation need far more effectively than sprawling new airports and highway expansion ever can.
 
WILLIAM L. SCHLOSSER
 Indianapolis, Nov. 20, 1989

HEADLINE: Fernandez Appoints Another Deputy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Joseph A. Fernandez, who is to become New York City's schools chancellor on Jan. 2, yesterday named a woman with little academic training in education as his deputy chancellor for programs, signaling once more that his administration will be rather unconventional.
The appointee, Amina Abdur-Rahman, is vice president for education of the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit business organization. Ms. Rahman, 41 years old, worked for several years as a teacher in the New York City Urban League's street academies for high school dropouts, eventually directing the league's education programs, and went on to become educational adviser to Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins, now the Mayor-elect. But she never received a college degree, although she said she had completed her college course work.
''She's earned her degree in the field of battle,'' said James S. Vlasto, Mr. Fernandez's press secretary. 
 
Commitment to Reform
On Tuesday, Mr. Fernandez named Stanley S. Litow, a leading critic of the city's schools and a man who has never been a superintendent or principal, as the deputy chancellor and chief operating officer.
The appointments of Mr. Litow and Ms. Rahman suggest that Mr. Fernandez is less concerned with traditional credentials and licenses than with a proven commitment to reform.
That predilection may have other practical consequences as Mr. Fernandez evaluates how well the administrators in the central office and superintendents, principals and teachers are doing their jobs. Mr. Fernandez has already declared himself an opponent of the city's Board of Examiners, which tests and licenses teachers and administrators.
There was some confusion yesterday over the responsibilities that Ms. Rahman will have. Ms. Rahman said she would have authority over guidance and other support services and such programs as drug and AIDS education and would involve herself in ''some aspects of curriculum development.''
 
'Knows the Education Field'
But Mr. Vlasto said she would have ''no involvement in curriculum'' or in teaching processes. Responsibility for those areas, he suggested, might require state certificates that Ms. Rahman does not possess.
Ms. Rahman said she did not know her salary although deputy chancellors have been earning $109,725 a year.
Ronald K. Shelp, the president of the Partnership, which supports work to improve education, housing and economic development, said Ms. Rahman ''knows the education field immensely, from curriculum to management of schools.''
Ms. Rahman, who so far is the highest black appointee in the Fernandez admninistration, was raised in Harlem and attended the city's public schools and City College. In an interview, she said she interrupted her studies when she became a mother - her daughter, Sabra, is now 20 and a college student in Delaware - and gradually completed her course work in education and history at Long Island University.
 
Taught at Street Academy
She said she never filed papers requesting that a degree be sent her nor did she pay a necessary bill. ''At that point I was interested in completing my course work,'' she explained.
Ms. Rahman, who changed her name from Sherron Jackson, is divorced and lives in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.
In 1969 she joined the Urban League and taught at one of its 15 street academies, a storefront in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn that worked with fewer than 100 students and was sponsored by the Union Carbide Corporation. It taught basic skills in reading and writing to students who could thrive in the smaller setting of the academies. Many students took their high school equivalency tests and enrolled in colleges, Ms. Rahman said, and the concept was eventually copied in alternative high schools set up by the Board of Education.
Mr. Litow said a third deputy chancellor will be Harvey Robins, who is now the deputy chancellor for financial affairs.

HEADLINE: Bush's Next Budget Falls Within Deficit Limits Without a Tax Increase

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
To the surprise of budget experts outside the White House, the Bush Administration is proving able to prepare a budget for the next fiscal year that would meet the deficit requirements of the budget-balancing law without raising taxes or cutting fundamental domestic programs, authorities in and out of the Government say.
''A couple of months ago, people, myself included, thought it would be virtually impossible to get there without raising taxes,'' said Robert D. Reischauer, who as director of the Congressional Budget Office is Congress's chief economist. Now, Mr. Reischauer added, he is confident that the $64 billion deficit target set in the law can be reached. Other economists who follow the budget closely agreed. 
The President's budget, which will be sent to Congress on Jan. 22 and covers the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1, is expected to show small spending increases for selected education and environmental programs but no expensive initiatives.
But some of the White House proposals, including Medicare reductions and a lower capital gains tax, are likely to be vigorously opposed in Congress, and the lawmakers are expected to seek much more money than President Bush wants for child care programs.
Officials at the Office of Management and Budget, where the budget is being put together, will not discuss it. But budget officials in Congress and various departments and agencies as well as groups that lobby in particular areas know enough about the proposals that they can see what the framework of the new budget will look like.
 
Military Cuts Help
They say the relative ease with which the Administration has been able to find about $40 billion in measures to reduce the deficit results primarily from the Administration's new willingness to accept lower military spending, from tightened reins on Medicare spending and from the unusual way that the Government's transactions involving failed savings and loan institutions are accounted for.
The Administration is expected to calculate that if all tax laws and spending programs continued without change, the deficit in the next fiscal year would be $100 billion to $105 billion. To comply with the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law, the Administration must produce a budget that shows enough revenue increases or spending reductions to lower that figure to $64 billion.
 
A Savings? Well, Yes
The Administration, which once intended to increase the Pentagon budget in the 1991 fiscal year by about $15 billion, is now likely to recommend that military spending be little higher than the $291 billion being spent this year. In the odd way budgets are calculated, that would mean $5 billion to $10 billion in deficit reduction, since the amount would be that much less than the sum needed to keep pace with inflation, which is expected to be about 4 percent.
Similarly, spending for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, would have to grow to $130 billion next year from $114 billion to keep up with inflation. But budget documents show that the Administration plans to hold the line at $122 billion, a reduction of $8 billion. That would be accomplished by curtailing some programs and applying a payroll tax to all new state and local government workers.
The budget could show up to $10 billion more in deficit reduction depending on the timing of the sale of savings and loan associations. Under the system, the money to purchase failed savings institutions is raised outside the budget, but the income from the sales can be counted as revenue within the budget.
An additional $5 billion to $8 billion is expected to be saved by projecting the abolition of some small domestic programs and freezing the spending of others at this year's level, without adding enough to keep up with inflation. Congress is not likely to agree to many of these proposals. But that does not matter from the point of view of the budget drafters, who are intent on hitting the $64 billion target.
''They don't have to propose a budget that's going to pass,'' said Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse-U.S., the accounting firm.
 
Sources of New Revenue
The remaining money needed to reach the $64 billion deficit mark is expected to come from new revenue obtained by selling Government assets, by lowering the capital gains tax and by extending existing taxes, like the one on long-distance telephone calls, that are due to expire.
A reduction in the capital gains tax rate can be expected to create additional income in the first year because investors will sell more assets to take advantage of the lower rate. Many economists believe the lower rate would lose revenue in subsequent years.
The President is expected to propose as much as $200 million in new spending for operating and maintenance of national parks. More money may also be made available for air and water quality programs and for cleaning up waste sites.
The education budget is expected to include about $400 million for grants to reward successful schools and outstanding teachers, for magnet schools and for other measures that the President proposed this year but that were never acted on by Congress.
President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, has established a new technique this year that forces agencies to compete directly with one another for money.
Under this system, each department and agency will be allotted a specific amount of money. In addition, a limited pool of money will be set aside for spending increases across the Government.

HEADLINE: Bush Readies Big Cuts In '91 Pentagon Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to propose a Pentagon budget of $295 billion for the 1991 budget year, substanially less than the Defense Department had hoped to receive, an Administration official said tonight.
The Pentagon initially had planned to propose a budget of $311 billion for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Such a request would have provided for a small increase in military spending, after inflation is taken into account, but the smaller amount reportedly backed by the President would not be enough to keep up with inflation.
Those plans were upset in recent months because of growing pressure to cut the Federal budget and the decline in public support for military spending that followed political changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. 
Despite these developments, Pentagon officials had hoped that Mr. Bush would still approve a Pentagon spending request of about $300 billion. However, Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of the Management of the Budget, reportedly has sought to lower the request to roughly $290 billion. Mr. Darman has sought deeper cuts in the Pentagon budget to reduce the Federal deficit.
 
Compromise Is Approved
The figure picked by President Bush represents an apparent compromise between the recommendations of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Mr. Darman.
A senior Pentagon official said Mr. Bush's decision would probably force another round of retrenchments in Pentagon plans, as Defense Department officials struggle to fit their programs within the new spending requests.
The Pentagon budget request for the 1991 budget, which will be officially unveiled in late January, has been the focus of high-level White House meetings in recent days. Mr. Bush deferred a final decision on the level of military spending until after his Malta summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Mr. Bush met Tuesday with Mr. Cheney, Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Mr. Darman to discuss the Pentagon budget before making his final decision, officials said.
 
The Inflation Factor
Congress approved $295 billion in Pentagon spending authority for the 1990 budget year. But actual spending power will be reduced to about $291 billion because of the reductions under the Gramm-Rudman budget-deficit law, Congressional experts say.
A budget spending request of $295 billion would result in a decrease in Pentagon purchasing power of about 2 to 3 percent, once inflation is taken into account, one Congressional specialist said.
The Penatgon's spending request for the 1991 budget year is in terms of budget authority, or the amount of money that is made available to the Defense Department to spend. That money is expended as ''outlays'' over a period of years. The Federal budget deficit is determined in terms of such outlays.
The Pentagon spending request does not include Energy Department expeditures for making and testing nuclear weapons, which are likely to total several additional billions of dollars.
 
Cuts Already Planned
Mr. Bush's decision comes as the Defense Department has already begun to plan for spending cuts. Mr. Cheney recently directed the services to identify about $180 billion in potential spending cuts from the Pentagon's previous plans for increasing spending from 1992 to 1994.
The effect of such a cut - which reflects the Pentagon's ''worst case'' assumptions about the extent of reductions that might be needed - would be to reduce military spending for those years at an average annual rate of about 5 percent, after inflation.
The services have suggested cuts to carry out those reductions but no final budget decisions have been made.
Pentagon budget cuts have important diplomatic, as well as military implications. Pentagon officials have said that the cuts are being made at a time when there is not only welcome political reforms in Eastern Europe but also some worrisome instability.
Mr. Cheney urged Western European Defense Minsiters at a recent meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to shoulder their share of the military spending burden. Some West European defense ministers said the American decision to reduce its military budget was making it hard for them to win support for military spending.

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: John Casey, Pleased but Humble, Savors Late-Blooming Success

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
John Casey is pleased, of course, that his ''Spartina'' won this year's National Book Award for fiction, but there is little chance, he said, that the prize will ''go to my head.'' Why? Because two months ago his brother-in-law, Dr. Harold E. Varmus, shared the 1989 Nobel Prize in Medicine. Last spring, Mr. Casey's niece, Jessica Tuck (who plays Megan Gordon in ''One Life to Live'') appeared on the cover of TV Guide. And another brother-in-law, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, formerly the Minister of Mines and Energy in Peru, is about to publish another book on economics -a subject Mr. Casey failed at Harvard.
''Everybody in the family is very nice to me about my efforts,'' said Mr. Casey, who is leaving for Stockholm today with Dr. Varmus to attend the Nobel awards ceremony on Sunday.
Besides, Mr. Casey is hardly an overnight sensation. Now age 50, he has been writing for more than 20 years. During those lean years, he published another novel, ''An American Romance'' (1977), and a novella and three short stories under the title ''Testimony and Demeanor'' (1979). He has also completed the first draft of another novel and another collection of stories that will form a trilogy with ''Spartina.'' 
 
The Plot That Won the Prize
''Spartina,'' which the jury that awarded Mr. Casey the $10,000 prize described as a ''passionate portrait,'' focuses on the two worlds of an angry, brooding 40-year-old Rhode Island fisherman, Dick Pierce, who builds a 50-foot fishing boat named Spartina in his backyard and launches it just before a big hurricane hits. Although married and the father of two children, he begins an affair with a younger woman, Elsie Buttrick, a Fish and Wildlife officer and longtime neighbor.
The book received pre-publication praise from Ann Beattie, Paul Theroux and George Garrett. In The New York Times Book Review, the novelist Susan Kenney said ''Spartina'' was ''just possibly the best American novel about going fishing since 'The Old Man and the Sea,' maybe even 'Moby-Dick.' ''
Carol B. Janeway, Mr. Casey's editor at Alfred A. Knopf, said: ''What distinguishes John is an extraordinary respect for and complete control of individual words, so that every word in a sentence or paragraph carries its maximum resonance and weight. He has what I would call a 'Japanese style,' which is to say one in which everything extraneous or decorative is pared away to leave the beauty of maximum simplicity.''
John Dudley Casey divided his youth between Worcester, Mass., his birthplace, and Washington, where his father, Joseph Edward Casey, was a Democratic Congressman from 1934 until 1942, when he was defeated by Henry Cabot Lodge in a race for the Senate. Paving the Way for Kennedy? ''He was a Massachusetts Irish politician who adored F.D.R., when most Irish in Massachusetts were opposed to lend-lease and were not eager for Washington to take care of people - that was the job of Mayor Curley,'' said Mr. Casey the other day in a telephone interview from his office at the University of Virginia, in Charlottesville, where he is a professor of English literature. Referring to John F. Kennedy's subsequent victory over Mr. Lodge, Mr. Casey added, ''J.F.K. knocked Lodge off the next time around, and I like to think the old man softened him up.''
Mr. Casey wrote poetry in high school in Washington, but at Harvard he tried acting. ''In my sophomore year I was in four plays,'' he said, ''because I discovered I did not stutter on stage.''
In accepting the fiction award last week, Mr. Casey told the overflow audience in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre hotel that he started to write partly because he stutters. ''I had to think of lots of words to replace the ones I couldn't say,'' he said.
He might have been onstage more often had he not been expelled after failing economics and violating college regulations. ''It was the traditional sophomore year filled with craziness and despair,'' he said. After six months in the Army, he was re-admitted to Harvard on probation, where he majored in Russian history and literature. Barred by his probationary status from acting during his junior year, he wrote stories and began a novel.
 
The Career That Never Was
After college, Mr. Casey enrolled in Harvard Law School, bent on a career in diplomacy or public service. In his last year he took a workshop with Peter Taylor, the novelist and short-story writer, who encouraged him to become a writer. William Abrahams, a literary book editor, told Mr. Casey to discard the novel he was working on, but gave him $300 to encourage him to write another.
''The psychological thrill was huge, but I still hedged my bets by passing the D.C. bar in 1966,'' Mr. Casey said. For a time he practiced law with his father, but then accepted a one-year fellowship to the Iowa Writers Workshop. He liked it so much he stayed three years.
During that time Mr. Casey completed a novel, which he sent to Mr. Abrahams - who promptly rejected it. ''I was so dazed by his rejection letter,'' Mr. Casey recalled, ''that I never read the novel again.''
But he had a suitcase filled with stories, two of which he sold to The New Yorker, another to Sports Illustrated. Emboldened by the ease with which he sold them, he and his wife bought a four-acre island in Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island. There Mr. Casey fished, raised vegetables and published a few stories, as well as freelance articles about the outdoors.
 
Benefits of Saying It Straight
Those nonfiction pieces proved helpful to his fiction. ''Having described fishing or cross-country skiing with no emotional resonance,'' he said, ''when you use them in fiction the rough edges are off - you can use it as though the character had been doing it all his life.''
After Mr. Casey had been living on on the island about four years, Mr. Taylor, who was on the faculty at the University of Virginia, invited him to teach writing there. He planned to do it temporarily, but by then he had two daughters. ''I got hooked on having a salary and being around students,'' he said.
Because of the difficulty of teaching full time and writing, Mr. Casey said he takes off as much time as he can afford. He has received fellowships from the Guggenheim foundation and from the National Endowment for the Arts.
 
Public Success, Private Loss
In 1979, Knopf published Mr. Casey's story collection. But his publishing triumph was marred by a number of personal losses. Within a year, his godson and former student, Breece D'J Pancake, killed himself at age 26. Mr. Pancake was a talented writer and his posthumously published collection,''The Stories of Breece D'J Pancake,'' received excellent critical notices; Mr. Casey wrote the afterword. Mr. Casey's father died of cancer. And he and his wife divorced. (Mr. Casey has since remarried, to Rosamond Pinchot Pittman, an artist and calligrapher. They have one daughter and another child on the way.) His trilogy will have taken about a decade to finish. ''When people hear that, they often make the mistake of admiring the virtues of patience,'' Mr. Casey said. ''But when I started, I thought it was going to take only two years. It's like La Salle - he comes out from French Canada, finds the top of the Mississippi River and thinks it's going to take him a week to find the Pacific. So he keeps on going. I think of myself as La Salle.''
