HEADLINE: Graphs showing the sources that cover U.S. health care; what Medicare saved by shifting to employers the bulk of the cost of medical care for workers age 65 and over (source: Federal Health Care Financing Administration) (NYT);
Scramble on Health-Care Costs

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The Government and private industry are scrambling to make each other pay billions of dollars in medical bills for the elderly and the working poor.
The Government is intensifying efforts to force private health plans to pay bills for elderly workers covered by such plans. Until the early 1980's, the Federal Medicare program had the primary responsibility for the people it covers, those age 65 and older.
Also, both Medicare and the Medicaid plan for low-income people no longer fully cover medical costs incurred by patients under the two programs; thus, doctors and hospitals are raising rates for private payers.
 
Cutbacks by Employers
At the same time, some employers are cutting back health benefits for retirees and older workers eligible for Medicare, leaving the cost to the Government. And smaller employers are deciding not to offer health insurance, leaving their workers to fend for themselves. Uninsured people often end up owing money to tax-supported hospitals or are too sick to work and thus eligible for public aid programs. 
''The tension is growing,'' said Walter B. Maher, director of Federal health policy relations with the Chrysler Corporation. ''It is a symptom of the absence of any type of national health policy. We have all these thousands of bill payers trying to dodge a bullet, trying to shift costs and pay less.''
The efforts to shift the bill to other parties have spurred complaints and accusations, as well as a debate about what should be done. Proposed solutions include suggestions to increase competition in the health-care marketplace; mandates that would tax businesses that do not provide benefits, and a Government-controlled national health system like Canada's.
 
No Current Statistics
There are no current statistics to show how much of the nation's health-care costs have been shifted by the Government to private insurers. But most private experts believe that the Government has had most of its success in the last two years. The latest Government figures, which are for 1987, show that private insurers and patients themselves paid about 59 percent of the nation's health-care bill in that year, about the same as they had for the previous decade. Public programs, including Medicare and Medicaid, paid the remaining 41 percent.
The cost shifting by the Government takes a number of forms. Medicare officials say the Government saved $1.3 billion this year by shifting to private employers doctor and hospital bills for elderly workers and their spouses. This move was accomplished by requiring employer health plans to fulfill their benefit obligations before Medicare kicks in.
Moving to increase the savings, Congress voted Nov. 22 to authorize computerized checking of Internal Revenue and Social Security records to identify workers over 65 who are covered by employer health benefits. The new search is expected to shift $780 million to $900 million more in expenses to private payers, according to estimates by the Congressional Budget Office and the Administration. The nation's total health-care bill is expected to exceed $600 billion this year, up about 11 percent from 1988.
 
Hospital Strategies
On another front, ceilings on what Medicare and Medicaid will pay for a procedure have prompted hospitals and doctors to raise charges for patients covered by private insurance, says the American Hospital Association, which represents hospitals.
But not everyone agrees that hospitals are doing this. Guy King, chief actuary of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, said hospitals were generally absorbing such costs by reducing payroll expenses and limiting charity care.
Increasingly tight eligibility requirements for Medicaid have left more low-income people without coverage and unable to pay.
The American Hospital Association said unpaid hospital bills amounted to $8.3 billion last year. ''Business can find itself paying as much as a 20 percent surcharge to cover the needed cost shift,'' said Carol McCarthy, the hospital group's president.
 
Meeting Higher Costs
One-third of the increase in health insurance costs charged to employers this year resulted from cost-shifting, mainly from Government programs, said Dr. Dan Dragalin, vice president for medical services with the Prudential Life Insurance Company.
Many employers expect cost shifting to them to increase under newly approved changes in the way Medicare reimburses physicians. Congress has just approved a system that will pay more for doctors' consultations with Medicare patients and less for surgery and expensive technology. The employers worry that specialists like surgeons and radiologists will compensate for their loss of Medicare income by raising charges for private patients. ''Those costs will be shifted to the private sector, too,'' said Thomas R. Burke, a former Reagan Administration health policy official who is a principal with A. Foster Higgins & Company, a benefits consulting firm.
And on the state level, legislatures in several states are considering programs like those in Hawaii and Massachusetts, which require employers to provide health benefits for employees.
 
Subsidy Programs
Also, Medicaid programs for low-income patients have begun to adopt policies that experts say transfer some costs to other payers. At least a dozen states are experimenting with subsidy programs that encourage small employers and low-income employees to pay at least part of the cost of private health insurance.
The programs are supposed to save money for the state in the long run. If the employees or their families become ill, the state-subsidized insurance would help them to get care without exhausting their savings and becoming nonpaying patients in tax-supported hospitals or giving up their jobs in order to become eligible for Medicaid.
In a similar experiment, Michigan recently started paying insurance premiums to maintain the private health coverage of Detroit-area AIDS patients, who were running out of money and would have become eligible for the state's Medicaid program. Michigan hopes the program will allow a net saving of $4 million a year in potential Medicaid expenditures by 1991.
 
State Programs
State Representative David C. Hollister, Democrat of Lansing, who sponsored the Michigan law, said that similar legislation was under consideration in Wisconsin and Colorado and that 21 other states had inquired about the program.
John Luehrs, director of health programs with the National Governors Association, noted that most states spend 15 percent of general revenues on Medicaid, up from 8 percent five years ago.
For their part, employers have been working to hold down expenditures by deflecting costs. A few large companies, including Ralston Purina, Boise Cascade and the Whitman Corporation, have eliminated company-paid health benefits for future retirees, replacing them with employee stock and savings programs. As a result, when these people reach age 65, they will be more likely to rely on Government programs to pay their medical bills - Medicare and, in cases when they have drained their savings, Medicaid.
 
Plight of Small Employers
Many small employers have dropped or cut back their coverage in recent years as insurers raised their rates or rejected applicants they thought had a high risk of becoming ill.
Because many large employers and insurers are leaning on hospitals to provide discounts for their groups, businesses that are too small to negotiate such favored treatment have been hit with increases of 30 percent or more in their health insurance premiums.
At least 15 million working people, many employed by small businesses, have no medical insurance. The Government has picked up the health-care costs of some by expanding Medicaid to cover more low-income mothers and their children.
''As the insurance industry has gotten more competitive, insurers have been less willing to take anybody who is going to be unprofitable,'' said Dr. Karen Davis, a health policy economist at the Johns Hopkins University School of Public Health. ''I am worried about who falls through the cracks between public and private programs.''
 
Blaming Each Other
Such concerns have given rise to accusations and counteraccusations about which side is not living up to its responsibilities.
''It's interesting that those who profess to provide insurance are avoiding it,'' said Bob Hungate, who watches health policy in Washington for the Hewlett-Packard Company. Medicaid and some insurers are avoiding risks by shifting costs to other payers, he continued, adding, ''We don't think it's going to work in the long run for us to pay four times as much as Medicaid and for small employers to pay probably 50 percent more than we do.''
For their part, insurers say the Government programs are ducking responsibilities that they used to bear. ''A whole new theory of public finance has grown out of fiscal limitations in the public budget,'' said Carl Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurers' trade group.
 
Uncovered Epidemic
He said AIDS was the first epidemic in which primary care was not provided by the states. ''Even in the 1950's, municipalities were opening publicly owned or sponsored hospitals for tuberculosis,'' Mr. Schramm said.
The more than 30 million Americans without health insurance represent a similar evasion of responsibility, he said. ''Congress is inclined to lay blame on the private sector and attempt to shift costs into the private sector,'' he said. ''But the large number of people without insurance represent a broken promise on the part of the Government. In the late 1970's, Medicaid was available to 76 percent of the people whose incomes were under the Federal poverty level, but now only 38 percent of those under the poverty level are eligible.''
Dr. Davis at Johns Hopkins said both the Government and private insurers should be required to pull their weight.
''We're going to have to do patchwork for some time,'' she said. ''The Federal Government should take the lead, but it is not realistic to abolish private coverage and rely exclusively on universal public coverage. For a long time, we will have some people covered by public programs and some by private insurance.''
John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Workers Employees International Union, added, ''The major forces in business, government and unions and consumers are all coming to the point where they agree that health care is a national problem that has to be addressed - not just cost containment but access to care and the quality of care.''

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Calls Economy Stable to Growing Modestly

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Economic activity in most sections of the country is ''stable to modestly expanding,'' with even generally becalmed manufacturing displaying ''pockets of strength,'' a survey by the Federal Reserve Board of its 12 district banks stated today.
The accounts, collected and summarized by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, appeared slightly more optimistic than some analysts had expected, in light of numerous recent reports on the economic weakness that included automobiles, housing, personal spending, durable-goods orders and unemployment claims.
That led some analysts to suggest that the Fed would not hasten to take another step to cut short-term interest rates in the hope of heading off a possible recession. The survey published today was in anticipation of the next meeting, on Dec. 18-19, of the Fed's Open Market Committee, the central bank's main policy-setting body. 
Last month, the summary of the Fed survey, contained in its so-called beige book, described economic growth as ''slow to moderate'' in most districts.
In another development, the National Association of Business Economists published the somewhat startling results of its latest group forecast, in which 62 percent of its members said the next recession is at least three years off.
At a luncheon meeting with reporters, a senior Fed official gave no indication that he had any serious concern about the economy's performance. ''We expect domestic consumption to be solid enough to sustain things,'' this official said. He added, ''I still would characterize what we've been seeing as fitting within the 'soft landing' scenario'' in which inflation is subdued by an economy that slows down but does not lurch into recession.
The official insisted that he not be named or further identified. It was not clear whether his views represented those of the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan.
The survey of business economists was described as ''a sea change forecast'' by James F. Smith, a professor at the University of North Carolina and the group's current president. He noted that in September a scant majority of the respondents expected the current expansion to last through 1991.
 
Reasons for Shift
Asked what accounted for the shift, Professor Smith cited a relaxation in Federal Reserve monetary policy, some modest progress in reducing the budget deficit, the political disintegration of Eastern Europe, some signs of rebound in housing and a growing belief that Detroit will soon respond to slumping car sales with large sales incentives rather than production cuts.
Half the 38 percent minority that does expect a recession before 1993 believes, however, that the economy's vulnerability is greatest in the current quarter and the first quarter of 1990. The group's 100-member panel - 59 of whom responded by the mid-November deadline - also predicted that gross national product would rise 1.8 percent next year, down from the 2.9 percent gain now expected for 1989.
While the beige book suggests otherwise, one well-known private analyst, Allen Sinai, said today that the economy had fallen into a mild recession, dragged down by a slowing in the manufacturing sector.
At a meeting with clients in New York, Mr. Sinai, who serves as president and chief economist of the Boston Company Economic Advisers Inc., said growth will contract at a 1.1 percent rate in the current quarter, and will decline a bit further during the first half of 1990 before recovering. For 1990, Mr. Sinai said, overall economic growth would rise by a paltry seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Richmond Slowdown
The Fed's beige book survey, based on information obtained before Nov. 28., found most districts conforming with the central bank's ''stable to modestly expanding'' description. The two exceptions were Richmond and St. Louis. In Richmond, business conditions moved lower from an already ''sluggish'' pace earlier in the fall. In St. Louis, transportation equipment accounted for most of its slowdown in manufacturing and construction was reported as weak.
Conditions in the San Francisco district, on the other hand, were called ''generally healthy'' except for Arizona, and the Chicago district reported that while manufacturing was softening, this was predominantly related to motor vehicles.
''Markets for many types of industrial machinery and equipment have continued to expand,'' the district reported. ''In some cases, sales have been stronger than expected.''
Over all, the New York Fed concluded, retail sales have been ''mixed'' with nondurables doing markedly better than big-ticket items and contruction ''strong or improving in the West and Midwest but somewhat sluggish in most other areas.''
The report's brief summary passage on inflation declared: ''Those districts that reported on price developments generally noted flat to modestly increased input prices, with several mentioning the continuing escalation of medical insurance costs.''

HEADLINE: Shell Plans Deep Drilling Off Texas

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Shell Oil Company said today that it would develop a promising oil and gas field at a record depth of 2,860 feet in the Gulf of Mexico, more than 250 miles southeast of Houston. It estimated the cost at $1.1 billion.
The project, called Auger field, exceeds the world record set last month for deepwater production by more than 1,000 feet. It will also be more than 100 miles beyond currently active deepwater platforms off the Texas and Louisiana coasts. 
The Shell project is likely to bolster the oil industry's case that it has the technology to recover large quantities of oil and natural gas from the nation's coastal waters, where drilling is banned, industry analysts said.
It should also produce sharply higher estimates of recoverable energy reserves in deepwater areas because the United States Geological Survey, the Federal agency that compiles estimates of American energy reserves, has limited its analysis to shallower production areas.
''The wonderful benefit of this is that if Shell can make it work, we will gain new information on these deepwater areas,'' said Philip K. Verleger Jr., a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. ''Our estimates right now are very weak.''
Shell, the domestic subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of the Netherlands, estimated that it would produce about 220 million barrels of oil and natural gas from the Auger field over several years. Tom Marsh, the drilling editor of Offshore Data Services, a research company based in Houston, estimated that production might continue from the Auger platform for 15 years. $4 Billion in Revenues At current oil prices of about $19 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude, Shell would recover more than $4 billion in revenues from the project.
Jack Little, the executive vice president for exploration and production at Shell, said much of the money would go to operating the platform, taxes and Federal royalty payments, but ''obviously, we expect to make an appropriate return on our investment.''
Last month, Conoco Inc. set a deepwater production record when it began operating a platform at 1,760 feet about 170 miles southwest of New Orleans in the Green Canyon. The Conoco project, begun in 1987, cost more than $400 million.
The technology that Shell will use to assemble the platform is similar to the concept begun by Conoco in the North Sea and applied in the Gulf of Mexico. Instead of resting on a fixed platform extending to the sea floor, the platform floats on four large cylindrical tanks connected to the sea floor by a dozen steel tendons, or tension legs.
 
Two Wells at 7,000 Feet
Mr. Little said the technology would enable the Houston-based Shell to produce oil in 4,000 feet of water, but many of the analysts believe the potential is greater. Shell apparently does, too. It has drilled two exploratory wells at more than 7,000 feet.
The Auger platform can accommodate 32 producing wells and will process the fuels before they are transported through pipelines to onshore refineries.
Shell paid $11 million for the lease rights to the area, and it holds a third of the leased acreage in the Gulf of Mexico at water depths of more than 1,500 feet. Shell also owns offshore leases off the California coast and in two areas near Alaska.
The Auger platform is expected to begin operating in 1993, producing oil at a peak rate of 40,000 barrels a day in 1995 and 150 million cubic feet of gas daily in 2001.

PUB-DATE: December 7, 1989

SECTION: Section D; Page 4, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 455 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Control Data Names New Chief Executive

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation made it official yesterday, naming Lawrence Perlman chief executive to succeed Robert M. Price. Mr. Price will remain as chairman.
The succession had been expected for some time, and analysts and major investors in the company were behind Mr. Perlman, who has been credited with helping to turn the company around. Suspense built, however, as a succession committee of the board reviewed candidates from outside the company. 
Control Data, based in Minneapolis, began to post losses in the mid-1980's. It reported an operating profit in the third quarter but cautioned that it still faced major challenges. ''We must contend with the major transition the mainframe market is undergoing and the subsequent impact of that transition on growth opportunities,'' Mr. Price said in a shareholder letter.
Mr. Price, 59 years old, was named to lead the company in 1986 as the handpicked successor to the company's founder, William C. Norris. Last December, he relinquished the president's title to Mr. Perlman and in September he asked the board to choose a successor to him as chief executive.
Mr. Price, who joined Control Data as a mathematician in 1961, took over leadership at a difficult time. His role was fighting a rear-guard action, selling some of the company's big units and making other restructuring decisions, and he was often upstaged by Mr. Perlman's success at operations.
Mr. Perlman, 51, is known as a high-energy leader who transformed Control Data's disk drive operation from an ailing unit into a profitable one. He has been working to buck up employee morale.
In a September talk to managers, he said bluntly that Control Data was not working. ''The missing ingredient is a passion for winning,'' he said, adding: ''It all comes down to winning. I love to win. I hate to lose.''
Yesterday, in a telephone interview, he listed three characteristics of the company he visualizes. ''I'd like it to be a highly profitable company characterized by excellence in mangement,'' he said. ''I'd like it to be a source of high-quality products and services, and I want it to be an employee-oriented company.''
When all this will happen is uncertain. ''There's no finish line,'' Mr. Perlman said. ''It's a journey and we've started on many aspects of it already. Our most visible task is to improve profitability,'' and he expects that to happen next year, he said.
Mr. Perlman, a Harvard-trained lawyer, joined the company as general counsel in 1980 and was named to head its Commercial Credit Company unit, later spun off. He will assume his new job as president and chief executive Jan. 1, while Mr. Price, as chairman, will focus on industry issues, government policy and the like.
